article name: Ted Cruz Values a Lot of the Things We Value; To Mr. Cruz I say: Aim your fury at Hillary and Bernie.
article text: Regarding Bret Stephens's "What Ted Cruz Values " (Global View, Jan. 26): I am a very conservative voter, and I will vote for the eventual GOP presidential nominee, whomever it is. I am tired of the GOP voters who stay at home on Election Day because the nominee isn't conservative enough, or took money from this person or that super PAC, or changed his or her position on some issue. Not showing up on Election Day because the nominee doesn't fulfill your profile of an ideal candidate is a losing strategy (see Mitt Romney and John McCain). The object of the entire GOP tent should be to win the presidency, giving one at least four years to convince the president and Congress to work on laws favorable to your stand on particular issues.If folks like Mr. Cruz continue to divide the GOP and polarize groups of supporters, they will never convince enough independent-minded voters that the GOP presidential nominee is capable of leading this country out of the mess that President Obama and the progressive left have made for the last seven years.To Mr. Cruz I say: Aim your fury at Hillary and Bernie, play to win the election with the "most conservative candidate who can win" (as William F. Buckley said), and then try to make policy changes using the system and our American political process.Mark PetrusHomewood, Ill.I share some of Mr. Stephens's pessimism but given the real state of the union, Ted Cruz represents a real change of direction. Whatever he does can't be worse than the path we are on now. To be successful, he must appeal to less sophisticated and demanding Americans than Mr. Stephens.Among the current candidates one doesn't find the ideal package, so one must decide what one most wants and choose from an imperfect group. Playing Diogenes is a cop-out.John PeggSpokane, Wash.I am a Ted Cruz supporter. I agree that he used one wrong word--he should have called Donald Trump a "New York liberal," rather than referring to "New York values." If he had gotten that word right, he would have been accurate. Mr. Trump is at best a Nelson Rockefeller Republican.Donald W. LargeGreen Valley, Ariz.Any solid conservative knows Mr. Cruz, in his dismissal of "New York values," was referring to those in New York City who chased away Wal-Mart and its hundreds of jobs, and those in Albany who outlawed fracking and its numerous economic benefits. I, and millions like me, support Sen. Cruz and embrace his values and traditional conservatism.Patrick J. CallahanSouthampton, Pa.

article name: Obama's Democratic Divide; How the President created Bernie's best political issue.
article text: Hillary Clinton is campaigning as a better heir than Bernie Sanders to sustain President Obama's legacy, but if she wants to know why she's having such a hard time closing the deal, she might want to blame . . . President Obama.That's one of the intriguing messages from the entrance polls of Democratic Iowa caucus voters. The pollsters asked caucus-goers to choose one of four issues that mattered most to them in voting for a candidate. Mrs. Clinton easily won on health care, terrorism, and even the economy and jobs (51% to 42%).But Mr. Sanders won big on the fourth issue: income inequality, which 27% of voters said was most important. The Vermont socialist won 61% of those voters while Mrs. Clinton settled for 34%. This no doubt reflects that Bernie has made inequality a major theme in his campaign, but then again socialists have been railing about the gap between rich and poor for decades.The question is why this issue is resonating so much with Democrats this year, and we think Mr. Obama gets the credit in two ways. The President himself has made income inequality an abiding concern across his time in office, and his followers have come to believe him. "I believe this is the defining challenge of our time," Mr. Obama said on Dec. 4, 2013.Mr. Obama's other contribution is that his economic policies have, if anything, widened the income gap. Middle-class income gains have been meager thanks to the historically slow economic expansion, while Americans who own stocks or other assets have seen their wealth and incomes increase thanks to Federal Reserve policies targeting asset prices.When a President calls an issue "defining" and then makes the problem worse, it's no surprise that some other politician will take up the cudgel. Mr. Sanders's political obsession is Mr. Obama's creation.

article name: Hillary Clinton Beats Bernie Sanders by Slim Margin in Iowa; Both candidates begin weeklong sprint in New Hampshire after 'historically close' race
article text: Jennifer Levitz contributed to this article.NASHUA, N.H.--Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton was declared the winner of the Iowa caucuses Tuesday, barely surviving a surprisingly stiff challenge from Sen. Bernie Sanders, as the two candidates arrived in New Hampshire to begin a weeklong dash to the nation's first primary.The Iowa Democratic Party declared the caucuses "historically close." Final results put Mrs. Clinton's delegate count at 49.9%, to Mr. Sanders's 49.6%. Mrs. Clinton's victory means she will collect 23 of Iowa's delegates and Mr. Sanders will get 21. It takes 2,382 to win the Democratic nomination for president.The race was called for Mrs. Clinton by the Iowa Democratic Party and, by early afternoon, the Associated Press.The close margin didn't stop Mrs. Clinton from declaring an outright victory. "I am so thrilled that I'm coming to New Hampshire after winning Iowa," she told the crowd at a get-out-the-vote event in Nashua, N.H. "I've won and lost there--it's a lot better to win."Mr. Sanders, though, said Tuesday afternoon he wasn't ready to concede the close Iowa race to his rival."We want to look at some of the numbers," he told reporters after his first post-Iowa rally in the college town of Keene, N.H., a short drive from his home state of Vermont.Mr. Sanders portrayed his performance in Iowa--after surging from little name recognition and low polling--as one for the political record books."We made history," he said. "We fought Clinton to a virtual tie."A third candidate, former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, finished far behind the two leaders and dropped out Monday night.The results came after a campaign in which Mrs. Clinton argued that she is the one who can advance the Democratic agenda, and with a sophisticated ground operation that her campaign began building on the day she announced her candidacy in April.Both Democratic contenders were digging in for what promises to be a protracted campaign, and far from the coronation many expected when Mrs. Clinton launched her candidacy in April.Election 2016* Clinton Briefly Savors Victory, Gets Back to Work* Cruz Defeats Trump in Iowa GOP Caucus* Cruz, Rubio Shift the GOP Conversation* Capital Journal: Front-Runners Give Ground as Rivals Make Mark* Cruz Sticks With Religion, Reagan in New Hampshire* New Hampshire Primary Is an Unpredictable One* Clinton, Sanders Turn to South Carolina's Black VotersAddressing her supporters in Des Moines on Monday night, Mrs. Clinton signaled a long battle ahead between her brand of pragmatism and his call for a political revolution."It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for." She added that she was "breathing a big sigh of relief."Mr. Sanders, a Vermont independent who attracted large and passionate crowds with his clarion call for a political revolution and an unabashedly liberal agenda, claimed a measure of victory of his own."I think the people of Iowa have sent a very profound message," Mr. Sanders told cheering supporters. "It's just too late for establishment politics and establishment economics." His cheering supporters replied, "Feel the Bern!"The outcome offered a measure of vindication for Mrs. Clinton, whose third-place finish in Iowa eight years ago made clear that her once-inevitable campaign faced a serious threat from another challenger, then-Sen. Barack Obama.Still, Mr. Sanders's success exposes real vulnerabilities with her candidacy.Both candidates flew overnight to New Hampshire to begin a weeklong sprint to the Granite State primary, where Mr. Sanders is 18 points ahead of Mrs. Clinton, according to a Real Clear Politics average of polls. With strong fundraising, Mr. Sanders is positioned to press forward for the foreseeable future, though the Clinton campaign sees advantages in the states that come later in the month.The Iowa results were delivered from precincts across 99 counties after a 10-month campaign that showered attention on this rural Midwestern state, which has long taken pride in its role as the first stop on the road to the presidential nomination.Over dozens of trips to Iowa high schools and diners, in small discussions and big rallies, the two candidates engaged in a vigorous and sometimes sharp debate as Mrs. Clinton positioned herself as a pragmatic, can-do fighter, while Mr. Sanders appealed to the party's most deeply held ideals.She battled reports that classified material was sent via her private email system. He battled suggestions that he couldn't win a general election, and that he has no real plan to implement his agenda.On Monday, some Clinton supporters said they were drawn to Mr. Sanders but, in the end, concluded his call for a political revolution would be easier said than done--a point Mrs. Clinton voiced repeatedly."I think he's wonderful man, but I don't think what he says is realistic," said Michelle Wilson, a corporate compliance administrator from West Des Moines. She served as a precinct captain for Mr. Obama in 2008; on Monday, she came to caucus for Mrs. Clinton.But in Clive, west of Des Moines, Carol Ferrell, 59, decided at the last minute to support Mr. Sanders. "As much as I admire Hillary Clinton, she's got a lot of baggage," she said.The candidates offer Democrats with two very different visions for governing.In speeches that remained almost identical across months of campaigning, Mr. Sanders promised to break up large banks, said Wall Street is built on fraud and unapologetically vowed to impose higher taxes to provide universal health care , free tuition at public colleges and more generous Social Security benefits. At a rally on Saturday, as Mr. Sanders ticked off society's problems, the crowd spontaneously began chanting, "Enough is enough!"Mrs. Clinton, for her part, highlighted her perseverance and qualifications for the presidency, including four years as secretary of state, along with what she describes as a pragmatic, effective approach to governing. She also portrayed herself as the most electable candidate whose nomination is necessary to block Republican ideas.Her policy platform includes a new program for debt-free tuition and an increase in solar panels, as well as changes in health care and Social Security that are more modest than her rival's.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Clinton, Sanders Locked in Tight Race for Delegates; Clinton campaign says it's well positioned; Sanders vows to press on
article text: Battling for the Democratic presidential nomination, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders were locked in a tight race for Iowa's delegates and the momentum that comes with a win in the nation's first contest.Mrs. Clinton maintained a narrow lead through much of the night, but with 93% of precincts reporting, her advantage was just 49.8% of the delegates versus 49.6% for Mr. Sanders, according to tabulations from the Iowa Democratic Party.Election 2016* Voters' Desire for Change Hints at Lingering Unease* Iowans Entertain Radical Messages Amid Seeming Prosperity* Why Democratic Lawmakers Hope Cruz or Trump Win GOP Race*Interview With Jane Sanders: Bernie's Words Are Backed by 'Real Plans'"It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for," Mrs. Clinton told supporters in Des Moines late Monday night, ahead of the announcement of final results. She didn't declare victory but thanked the people of Iowa and said she was "breathing a big sigh of relief."Credit: By Laura Meckler, Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Martin O'Malley to Drop Out of Democratic Presidential Race; Campaign overshadowed by Clinton, Sanders
article text: DES MOINES, IOWA--The first casualty of Iowa's caucuses is former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, who announced Monday night that he was dropping out of the Democratic presidential race after a disappointing showing .Mr. O'Malley told supporters at a Des Moines bar that he was suspending a campaign that never gained traction against rivals Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. He did not endorse either of the two.With about 90% of the Iowa caucus results reported, Mr. O'Malley stood at less than 1%.Flashing smiles, Mr. O'Malley said: "When I got into this, eight months ago, I had no doubt that it would be a tough fight. And it has been a tough fight."Election 2016* Iowa Caucuses: Live Coverage* Voters Seek Change at Iowa Caucuses* Photos: Iowa Caucuses Kick Off U.S. Presidential Election* How the Iowa Caucuses WorkMr. Sanders, in a speech late Monday might, thanked Mr. O'Malley. "He should know that he contributed a whole lot to the dialogue," the Vermont senator said.Mr. O'Malley had sought to position himself as a liberal alternative to Mr. Sanders--a seasoned executive who had the skills to put his ideals into practice. At age 53, he also cast himself as part of a younger generation who was not part of Washington's political culture. The arguments fell flat, though, and he never came within striking distance of Mr. Sanders or Mrs. Clinton. In national polls he never cracked an average of 5%, according to Real Clear Politics.After Mr. O'Malley dropped out, his campaign manager, David Hamrick, sent out an email saying, "Entering the race as an unknown, he always faced long odds--especially against a candidate as universally known as Secretary Clinton."Mr. O'Malley jumped in the race in May and struggled to gain name recognition or raise the money needed to be competitive. At some of his events in Iowa, people who came to see him had no idea where he was from or what offices he had held. He collected about $5 million in campaign contributions, according to the Center for Responsive Politics. By contrast, Mr. Sanders raised $20 million in the month of January alone.When it came to policy, Mr. O'Malley had little to offer that distinguished him from his rivals. All have said they favor gun control, aggressive steps to combat global climate change and an immigration overhaul that provides undocumented immigrants a path to citizenship.Mr. O'Malley put great stock in the Democratic debates. A fluid speaker with good looks, he hoped to turn in strong debate performances that would cause Clinton and Sanders backers to give him a fresh look. But the schedule approved by Democratic National Committee chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz did him no favors. The party set a total of only six debates and threatened to punish candidates who took part in debates that it had not sanctioned. Mr. O'Malley accused the party leadership of favoring Mrs. Clinton.In a speech at a Democratic National Committee gathering in Minneapolis in August, he took aim at the party's decision to hold only six debates, saying, "Whose decree is this actually? Where did it come from? To what end and what purpose? What national or party interest does this decree serve?"(Under pressure from Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton, the party now seems likely to accept more debates .)Yet when the debates began last October, Mr. O'Malley found himself a bit player on stage. He could not match Mrs. Clinton's command of policy detail or Mr. Sanders's populist fervor.Before the caucuses, O'Malley aides signaled that the Iowa results would determine whether he would plow forward. When Iowans gathered for the caucuses Monday night, they showed little appetite for his candidacy.At a West Des Moines church, nearly 300 people crammed into a room that was set up to hold about half as many caucusgoers. Only five supported Mr. O'Malley; three were undecided. As the numbers were read aloud, an O'Malley supporter yelled out, "We beat undecided!"Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Natalie Andrews at Natalie.Andrews@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Natalie Andrews

article name: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Take Off Gloves Going Into Iowa Vote; Latest polls show two Democratic candidates locked in tight race
article text: DES MOINES, Iowa--Iowa voters were set to decide Monday between upstart liberal Bernie Sanders and Democratic establishment-favorite Hillary Clinton in the state's caucuses, kicking off the presidential primary season with what was expected to be a nail-biter of a race.Mr. Sanders has drawn large, energetic crowds for his brand of "democratic socialism," which includes proposals to create a government-run, single-payer health-care system , increase taxes on the rich, break up big banks and make public colleges tuition free. He is hoping the enthusiastic turnouts at his rallies translate into big turnouts at the caucuses, and that he can leverage a win here to victories in the contests that follow, and ultimately the nomination.Mrs. Clinton, for her part, has highlighted her perseverance and qualifications for the presidency, including four years as secretary of state, along with what she describes as achievable but important policy objectives. She has also pitched herself as the logical successor to President Barack Obama and the most electable Democrat in November's general election, while highlighting the potential for voters to make history in electing the first female president.Polls show Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders are locked in a tight race. A Des Moines Register/Bloomberg Politics Iowa Poll released Saturday showed Mrs. Clinton edging ahead of the Vermont senator, 45% to 42%. A third contender, former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, has 3% support in the poll."It's a tie ballgame, that's where we are," Mr. Sanders said Monday . "We will win tonight if the turnout is high. We will struggle tonight if the turnout is low. That's a fact."Mr. Sanders, closing out his campaign in Iowa, took a strategic gamble in hopes of notching a victory: He went negative. His campaign ran a new TV spot that implies Mrs. Clinton is in the pocket of Wall Street, a criticism he has made of her repeatedly. And after refusing to talk about the Democratic front-runner's use of a private email server as secretary of state , Mr. Sanders on Sunday called her email practices a "very serious issue" that could render her unelectable.Similarly, a Clinton campaign that had once ignored the 74-year-old democratic socialist is now casting him as a pie-in-the-sky dreamer whose ideas are utterly impractical."I don't want to over-promise and under-deliver. I'd rather under-promise and over-deliver," she said at an Iowa rally. She added: "I know what it's going to take."Mrs. Clinton is also looking to put the ghosts of 2008 behind her, when she placed third and then-Sen. Obama won--and went on to win the Democratic nomination. This time around, Mrs. Clinton has seen Mr. Sanders cut into her once-yawning lead, and he currently runs ahead of her in New Hampshire, the next contest after Iowa.Mrs. Clinton has campaigned with her husband, former President Bill Clinton, and daughter, Chelsea Clinton, during the final days leading up to the Iowa caucuses, collectively offering a nostalgia-tinged closing argument for Mrs. Clinton.Election 2016* Iowans Entertain Radical Messages Amid Seeming Prosperity* Trump, Cruz Lead Pack Going Into Unpredictable Iowa Caucus* Why Democratic Lawmakers Hope Cruz or Trump Win GOP Race* Jeb Bush to Iowa: Pick Me, Not 'a Big Blowhard'Mr. Sanders is making the case that Mrs. Clinton is beholden to Wall Street. Speaking to reporters at a Bloomberg Politics breakfast last week, he mentioned that she had just attended a fundraising event at a Philadelphia investment firm.The combative posture poses risks for Mr. Sanders--something his team acknowledges. He has pledged to usher in a more uplifting style of politics. He has said he would inspire voters and thus expand turnout on Election Day much as Mr. Obama did eight years earlier.Recognizing the potential damage to the Sanders brand, his aides say there are lines he won't cross: He won't air the classic political attack ad complete with ominous music and unflattering pictures of Mrs. Clinton."He's not going to go there; it's not in the cards," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders campaign strategist.So, instead, some of Mr. Sanders's ads left it to voters to connect the dots. The latest spot features Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and its role in the 2008 financial collapse. No pictures of Mrs. Clinton's face appear in the ad; her name is never mentioned. Yet she is the star.Mrs. Clinton and her husband have a long history of dealings with Goldman. Together, they have collected nearly $3 million in speaking fees from the company since 2005.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Sanders's New Weapon: Going Negative Against Clinton; Vermont senator, seeking Iowa victory over Hillary Clinton, runs a negative ad and knocks her email practices
article text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa.--Sen. Bernie Sanders, closing out his campaign in Iowa, took a strategic gamble in hopes of notching a victory over Hillary Clinton in the state's Democratic caucuses Monday night: He went negative.The Sanders campaign ran a new TV spot that implies Mrs. Clinton is in the pocket of Wall Street. And after refusing to talk about the Democratic front-runner's use of a private email server as secretary of state, Mr. Sanders on Sunday called her email practices a "very serious issue" that could render her unelectable.Similarly, a Clinton campaign that had once ignored the 74-year-old democratic socialist is now casting him as a pie-in-the-sky dreamer whose ideas are utterly impractical."I don't want to over-promise and under-deliver. I'd rather under-promise and over-deliver," she said at a rally here. She added: "I know what it's going to take."This wasn't the way many thought the Democratic primary would conclude before the balloting began.When he jumped in the race in May, Mr. Sanders looked to many Democratic officials like a candidate who wanted a forum to talk about income inequality in America and who didn't really believe he could win. But the Vermont senator's success at raising money and attracting young voters has upended the race. The Sanders campaign announced Sunday it had raised $20 million in January alone.On the eve of the caucuses, Iowa was up for grabs. Given the stakes, both the Clinton and Sanders campaigns are offering some sharp assessments of the opposition.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 news.* GOP Vote in Iowa Hinges on Newcomer Turnout* Gowdy Stumps for Rubio, but Voters Want to Talk About Benghazi* Democratic Party Sets Stage for Thursday N.H. Debate*Before Caucuses, Clinton Mixes Practical With Aspirational* In Iowa, Trump Campaign Makes Final FlourishAssessing the new tone, Matthew Dowd, a former strategist to President George W. Bush, said: "It's been ratcheted up. Hillary understands that if she wins Iowa, she basically begins to end the race. Bernie realizes that the whole premise of his race is contingent on winning Iowa, and he's trying to do whatever he possibly can at this point to get over the hump."Spotlighting a vulnerability, Mr. Sanders is making the case that Mrs. Clinton is beholden to Wall Street. Speaking to reporters at a Bloomberg Politics breakfast last week, he mentioned that Mrs. Clinton had just attended a fundraising event at a Philadelphia investment firm."That's how she has raised money throughout her political career," he said. "Millions of dollars from Wall Street and from other very powerful special interests."The combative posture poses risks for Mr. Sanders--something his team acknowledges. He has pledged to usher in a more uplifting style of politics. He has said he would inspire voters and thus expand turnout on Election Day much as Barack Obama did eight years earlier.Recognizing the potential damage to the Sanders brand, his aides say there are lines he won't cross: He won't air the classic political attack ad complete with ominous music and unflattering pictures of Mrs. Clinton."He's not going to go there; it's not in the cards," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders campaign strategist.So, instead, some of Mr. Sanders's ads leave it to voters to connect the dots. The latest spot features Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and its role in the 2008 financial collapse. No pictures of Mrs. Clinton's face appear in the ad; her name is never mentioned. Yet she is the star.Mrs. Clinton and her husband have a long history of dealings with Goldman. Together, they have collected nearly $3 million in speaking fees from the company since 2005.In the spot, a narrator says "millions in campaign contributions and speaking fees" enabled Wall Street firms to engage in reckless practices.In an interview with NBC News over the weekend, Mrs. Clinton said her opponent's method is to discredit her through "insinuation and implication.""That's disappointing," she added, "because he's always prided himself on being a candidate, a politician--he's been in politics a really long time--not to go negative."As the campaign unfolds Mr. Sanders has flashed increasing irritation at some of the criticism lodged by Team Clinton. Clinton allies have said that Mr. Sanders's socialist views would be exploited by Republicans in a general election.On Sunday, Mr. Sanders tried to turn the tables. Asked by ABC News if he would get "slapped" with the socialist label should he win the party's nomination, he pointed to recent disclosures that top secret information passed through Mrs. Clinton's private email server.Having memorably told Mrs. Clinton in a debate in October that Americans were "sick and tired of hearing about your damn emails," he said Sunday: "Look at the front pages in terms of what Secretary Clinton is getting slapped with."Mrs. Clinton dismissed the latest controversy over her email as an "interagency dispute" that pales next to the larger issues on voters' minds.For all the sparring, both campaigns are also taking pains to put out a positive message. But their core arguments are very different.Mrs. Clinton says that her strength is persevering in the face of setbacks. A biographical video that plays for crowds ahead of her appearances ends with Mrs. Clinton saying, "I don't quit"--a theme of her campaign since it launched last April. She says she has the experience and stamina to both accomplish her goals and beat the Republican nominee this fall.Mr. Sanders is laying out a broader vision of a country that seeks to overturn a political system that favors the richest Americans. He is calling for a bottom-up "revolution" that will compel Washington officials to act in the interests of a struggling middle class.A huge rally he held Saturday in the college town of Iowa City captured the campaign's mood. As he finished his remarks, the rock band Vampire Weekend took the stage and invoked an optimistic spirit of America at its best. The band played Woody Guthrie's "This Land is Your Land," and were joined by Mr. Sanders and his wife, Jane, who, together with the crowd sang along: "From the redwood forests to the Gulf Stream waters, this land was made for you and me."Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary and Bernie Recall LBJ More Than JFK; JFK is remembered primarily for his tragic death, not for his too-brief push for lower-tax, pro-growth, supply-side economic policies.
article text: Regarding Edward P. Lazear's "If Only Hillary and Bernie Would Recall JFK " (op-ed, Jan. 29): While it is true that individual Americans migrate among all five annual income quintiles, all boats don't move up and down by the same amount in a rising tide.Regarding Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, the questions for America include whether they want to limit boating or add a ton of freight to some people's boats, and not allow other vessels to sail during any tide. President John F. Kennedy understood incentives. He understood, 20-plus years before the Laffer curve, that if you want more of something, tax it less. Americans may not be able to handle a president with policies that mandate some boats get torpedoed, while others are allowed to sail on subsidized biofuel.Michael J. Perullo, CPAAtlantaMr. Lazear claims President Kennedy believed "a rising tide lifts all boats." However, that was only until JFK read "The Other America," Michael Harrington's 1962 exposé of the millions of Americans left behind as the country prospered in the post-World War II boom. Afterward, Kennedy immediately directed his Council of Economic Advisers to look into the issue of poverty in America. Chairman Walter Heller and the council concluded that, in fact, a rising tide doesn't lift all boats.Records show that poverty was one of the last things JFK focused on before his assassination, and that he wanted to make it central to his 1964 legislative agenda. Lyndon Johnson took up this charge and launched the War on Poverty, designed to be a hand up--not a handout--and lift people out of poverty.Class warfare isn't the answer, but it's about time to realize that it takes a lot more than tax cuts and other incentives for the so-called "job creators" to lift today's 50 million Americans out of poverty and revitalize the country's struggling middle class. Now, if only Hillary and Bernie would recall LBJ.Tyler RossChicagoIt is a testament to Democratic and media image-making that JFK is remembered primarily for his "Camelot" White House and his tragic death, not for his too-brief push for lower-tax, pro-growth, supply-side economic policies. The one stain on JFK's thousand days in the White House was his support of a disastrous attempt to overturn Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba. That failure allowed the Castro brothers to show what happens to an economy that is built on class warfare rather than growth. Many leftist American admirers of Castro are flocking to Cuba before capitalists start renovating the dilapidated buildings in Havana and destroy its 1950s ambience. Cuba's economy needs to cross the bridge to the 1960s before making any leap into the 21st century.Why can't we learn that class war is economic hell for all classes?William HoganSavannah, Ga.President Kennedy also said, "Ask not what your country can do for you--ask what you can do for your country."The Democratic Party message of 2008, ever more strident now, is: "The government will see that your needs are met. Someone else will pay for this, and you need not be personally responsible." How far today's Democrats have moved from the uplifting words of JFK, and how unfortunate for our country's future.Beverly Holland ReichelSanta Monica, Calif.

article name: Democrats Battle Over Vision for Party; Hillary Clinton's narrow win over Bernie Sanders in Iowa magnifies debate over whether party should emphasize idealism or pragmatism
article text: Jennifer Levitz contributed to this article.Hillary Clinton's razor-thin win over Sen. Bernie Sanders in Iowa is magnifying a battle among Democrats over whether they should emphasize idealism or pragmatism.As the Democratic presidential race moved on to New Hampshire on Tuesday, both candidates signaled that they would press their cases in the ideological clash over the direction of the party.In Keene, N.H., on Tuesday, Mr. Sanders was asked whether Mrs. Clinton is a progressive. "Some days," he replied. "Except when she announces she's a moderate. Then she's not a progressive."For her part, Mrs. Clinton frequently describes herself as a "progressive who gets things done."On issue after issue, Mr. Sanders sees a more robust role for government than Mrs. Clinton does, and he calls for significant new taxes and programs to address what he considers unmet needs. Enacting his agenda, he says, will require a "political revolution'' in which Americans demand change so loudly that Congress cannot ignore them.In Mrs. Clinton's view, a more targeted and in some cases more modest approach can best solve problems. Better to find consensus on something achievable than to wage an extended battle that will only lead to gridlock."It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for," Mrs. Clinton said Monday night in Des Moines, after the slimmest of victories in the Iowa caucuses, the opening contest in the presidential nominating season.The debate is important for Democrats' identity and for setting the party's course on policy, as well as for its political implications.Many Democrats fear Mr. Sanders is too liberal to win a general election, and some are concerned that Mrs. Clinton will be pressured to take left-leaning positions that could hurt her, if she wins the nomination.Others say there is strong support for liberal policy and that these positions would help either candidate in the fall.Final results from Iowa on Tuesday showed the former secretary of state winning 49.9% to Mr. Sanders's 49.6%, or four more state delegates out of more than 1,400 at stake. The race now moves to New Hampshire, which holds its primary this coming Tuesday.Before then, Democrats will have two opportunities to assess their choices--on Wednesday evening at a CNN forum, and on Thursday in what will be the candidates' first one-on-one debate. Late Monday, a third candidate, former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, dropped out.When Mrs. Clinton's husband was running for president in 1992, the centrist wing of the Democratic Party was ascendant, with Democrats seeking to shed their image as tax-and-spend liberals and address middle-class concerns. As president, Bill Clinton declared that the "era of big government" was over. He signed a welfare overhaul, negotiated a balanced budget and focused on reducing crime, among other things.Since the 1990s, the party has moved to the left on a swath of issues as voter anger over the financial crisis and slow recovery has swelled.Nothing demonstrates the shift more clearly than the rise of Mr. Sanders, a political independent from Vermont who identifies himself as a democratic socialist. Some Democrats worry that the term "socialist" would scare off independent voters in a general election. But for many primary voters, it represents a commitment to fight for their causes."We love Bernie Sanders," said Amy Noon, 28 years old, a massage therapist in Iowa City, Iowa. "He stands for everything we wish the country was and is not. [Mrs. Clinton] stands for everything the country already is."In Iowa, the party's "very liberal'' and "moderate'' wings were equal in size at the Democratic caucuses but had different memberships, surveys taken Monday at caucus sites showed.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* New Risks for Trump After Iowa Loss* Rubio Campaign Sees Opening After Iowa* Cruz Win Chips Away at Ethanol's Clout* Obama, Ryan See Potential for a Tax-Policy Compromise* Sanders's Tax Increases Fall Short of Paying for Health Plan, Analysis FindsCaucusgoers who called themselves "very liberal'' tended to be younger, and more of them had at least a four-year college degree. Their top issue was income inequality.By contrast, more than half of the self-described moderates were age 60 or older, and 60% of them didn't have a college degree. The economy and jobs were their top issues.The two groups also had different views of the direction the nation should take once President Barack Obama leaves office, with "very liberal'' caucusgoers saying they wanted the next president to pursue more-liberal policies, and moderates saying they wanted to "generally continue'' Mr. Obama's course.As her party has changed, Mrs. Clinton has shifted to the left on some issues. In 2008, for instance, she opposed new Social Security taxes on the wealthy; now, she supports them. Her anti-Wall Street rhetoric has risen, too, and she now talks about jailing executives who break the law.Her backers tend to minimize the differences with Mr. Sanders, saying that many of Mrs. Clinton's plans--such as her $350 billion, 10-year college plan--are bold. But Mr. Sanders and his aides see differences in stark terms."This is a fight for the soul of the Democratic Party," Sanders strategist Tad Devine said Tuesday.One clear divide is tactical. Mrs. Clinton regularly warns that trying to enact a single-payer health-care plan, as Mr. Sanders favors, would lead to gridlock and endanger progress made under Mr. Obama's Affordable Care Act. Better to act incrementally to deal with lingering issues, such as high out-of-pocket costs, she has said.Mr. Sanders has said nothing in his agenda will come about without a revolution, but he is vague about how the revolution will come to pass.The two candidates' perspectives differ in two fundamental ways: on their view of the economy, and on their view of how much government is needed to address society's problems.On the role of government, Mr. Sanders wants to expand the suite of benefits offered to all Americans, while Mrs. Clinton favors more targeted ideas. For example, Mr. Sanders would increase Social Security benefits across the board, while Mrs. Clinton wants an increase targeted to the poorest senior citizens. Mr. Sanders would give all Americans government-run health insurance, while Mrs. Clinton wants to patch holes in the Obama health law.Mr. Sanders also wants to make tuition free at public colleges. Mrs. Clinton has a plan that would allow students to attend college without taking on debt, but it wouldn't be free.Many also see a difference in how the candidates see the economy. Mr. Sanders describes the economy as unfairly rigged to favor the rich, while Mrs. Clinton offers a more textured explanation for economic pressures, including the impact of technological change."Sanders says that the rules are unfair because specific individuals have crafted those rules to their advantage," said William Galston, a Brookings Institution scholar who was an adviser in the Bill Clinton White House and now writes an opinion column for The Wall Street Journal. "The center left is more inclined to give at least equal weight to long-term processes like globalization and technological change in explaining what's going on in the economy."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary Clinton Beats Bernie Sanders by Slim Margin in Iowa; Both candidates begin weeklong sprint in New Hampshire after 'historically close' race
article text: NASHUA, N.H.--Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton was declared the winner of the Iowa caucuses Tuesday, barely surviving a surprisingly stiff challenge from Sen. Bernie Sanders, as the two candidates arrived in New Hampshire to begin a weeklong dash to the nation's first primary.The Iowa Democratic Party declared the caucuses "historically close." Final results put Mrs. Clinton's delegate count at 49.9%, to Mr. Sanders's 49.6%. Mrs. Clinton's victory means she will collect 23 of Iowa's delegates and Mr. Sanders will get 21. It takes 2,382 to win the Democratic nomination for president.The race was called for Mrs. Clinton by the Iowa Democratic Party and, by early afternoon, the Associated Press.The close margin didn't stop Mrs. Clinton from declaring an outright victory. "I am so thrilled that I'm coming to New Hampshire after winning Iowa," she told the crowd at a get-out-the-vote event in Nashua, N.H. "I've won and lost there--it's a lot better to win."A third candidate, former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley , finished far behind the two leaders and dropped out Monday night.The results came after a campaign in which Mrs. Clinton argued that she is the one who can advance the Democratic agenda, and with a sophisticated ground operation that her campaign began building on the day she announced her candidacy in April.Both Democratic contenders were digging in for what promises to be a protracted campaign, and far from the coronation many expected when Mrs. Clinton launched her candidacy in April.Election 2016* Clinton Briefly Savors Victory, Gets Back to Work* Cruz Defeats Trump in Iowa GOP Caucus* Cruz, Rubio Shift the GOP Conversation* Capital Journal: Front-Runners Give Ground as Rivals Make Mark* Cruz Sticks With Religion, Reagan in New Hampshire* New Hampshire Primary Is an Unpredictable One* Clinton, Sanders Turn to South Carolina's Black VotersAddressing her supporters in Des Moines on Monday night, Mrs. Clinton signaled a long battle ahead between her brand of pragmatism and his call for a political revolution."It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for." She added that she was "breathing a big sigh of relief."Mr. Sanders, a Vermont independent who attracted large and passionate crowds with his clarion call for a political revolution and an unabashedly liberal agenda, claimed a measure of victory of his own."I think the people of Iowa have sent a very profound message," Mr. Sanders told cheering supporters. "It's just too late for establishment politics and establishment economics." His cheering supporters replied, "Feel the Bern!"The outcome offered a measure of vindication for Mrs. Clinton, whose third-place finish in Iowa eight years ago made clear that her once-inevitable campaign faced a serious threat from another challenger, then-Sen. Barack Obama.Still, Mr. Sanders's success exposes real vulnerabilities with her candidacy.Both candidates flew overnight to New Hampshire to begin a weeklong sprint to the Granite State primary, where Mr. Sanders is 18 points ahead of Mrs. Clinton, according to a Real Clear Politics average of polls. With strong fundraising, Mr. Sanders is positioned to press forward for the foreseeable future, though the Clinton campaign sees advantages in the states that come later in the month.The Iowa results were delivered from precincts across 99 counties after a 10-month campaign that showered attention on this rural Midwestern state, which has long taken pride in its role as the first stop on the road to the presidential nomination.Over dozens of trips to Iowa high schools and diners, in small discussions and big rallies, the two candidates engaged in a vigorous and sometimes sharp debate as Mrs. Clinton positioned herself as a pragmatic, can-do fighter, while Mr. Sanders appealed to the party's most deeply held ideals.She battled reports that classified material was sent via her private email system. He battled suggestions that he couldn't win a general election, and that he has no real plan to implement his agenda.On Monday, some Clinton supporters said they were drawn to Mr. Sanders but, in the end, concluded his call for a political revolution would be easier said than done--a point Mrs. Clinton voiced repeatedly."I think he's wonderful man, but I don't think what he says is realistic," said Michelle Wilson, a corporate compliance administrator from West Des Moines. She served as a precinct captain for Mr. Obama in 2008; on Monday, she came to caucus for Mrs. Clinton.But in Clive, west of Des Moines, Carol Ferrell, 59, decided at the last minute to support Mr. Sanders. "As much as I admire Hillary Clinton, she's got a lot of baggage," she said.The candidates offer Democrats with two very different visions for governing.In speeches that remained almost identical across months of campaigning, Mr. Sanders promised to break up large banks, said Wall Street is built on fraud and unapologetically vowed to impose higher taxes to provide universal health care , free tuition at public colleges and more generous Social Security benefits. At a rally on Saturday, as Mr. Sanders ticked off society's problems, the crowd spontaneously began chanting, "Enough is enough!"Mrs. Clinton, for her part, highlighted her perseverance and qualifications for the presidency, including four years as secretary of state, along with what she describes as a pragmatic, effective approach to governing. She also portrayed herself as the most electable candidate whose nomination is necessary to block Republican ideas.Her policy platform includes a new program for debt-free tuition and an increase in solar panels, as well as changes in health care and Social Security that are more modest than her rival's.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Dig In for Long Battle Beyond Iowa Caucus; Party's tabulations put Clinton's delegate count at 49.8%, Mr. Sanders's at 49.6%
article text: Natalie Andrews contributed to this article.DES MOINES, Iowa--Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton barely survived a surprisingly stiff challenge from Sen. Bernie Sanders in the Iowa caucuses, as the two candidates arrived in New Hampshire Tuesday morning to begin a weeklong dash to the nation's first primary.The Iowa Democratic Party declared the caucuses "historically close." With all precincts reporting, the party's tabulations put Mrs. Clinton's delegate count at 49.8%, to Mr. Sanders's 49.6%."The results tonight are the closest in Iowa Democratic caucus history," said Andy McGuire, chairman of the Iowa Democratic Party.Mrs. Clinton declared victory early Tuesday morning after a campaign in which she argued that she is the one who can advance the Democratic agenda, and with a sophisticated ground operation that her campaign began building on the day she announced her candidacy in April. Sen. Sanders, a Vermont independent who attracted large and passionate crowds with his clarion call for a political revolution and an unabashedly liberal agenda, hadn't yet conceded Iowa early Tuesday.After that razor-thin outcome in their first matchup, both candidates came to New Hampshire claiming a jolt of momentum as they prepared to hit the trail. Sanders campaign officials said they had successfully fought to a draw with a formidable opponent.Meantime, Brian Fallon, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton, said that "we believe strongly that we won tonight." Speaking to reporters after midnight as the Clinton press plane prepared to depart Iowa for New Hampshire, he added: "Sen. Sanders has been saying for several weeks that if this caucus was a high turnout affair that he would win. He was wrong."Both candidates were digging in for what promises to be a protracted campaign, and far from the coronation many expected when Mrs. Clinton launched her candidacy in April.Addressing her supporters in Des Moines, Mrs. Clinton signaled a long battle ahead between her brand of pragmatism and his call for a political revolution."It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for." She added that she was "breathing a big sigh of relief."Mr. Sanders, addressing his own supporters, claimed a measure of victory of his own."I think the people of Iowa have sent a very profound message," Mr. Sanders told cheering supporters. "It's just too late for establishment politics and establishment economics." His cheering supporters replied, "Feel the Bern!"The outcome offered a measure of vindication for Mrs. Clinton, whose third-place finish in Iowa eight years ago made clear that her once-inevitable campaign faced a serious threat from another challenger, then-Sen. Barack Obama.Still, Mr. Sanders's success exposes real vulnerabilities with her candidacy.Both candidates flew overnight to New Hampshire to begin a week-long sprint to the Granite State primary, where Mr. Sanders is 18 points ahead of Mrs. Clinton, according to a Real Clear Politics average of polls. With strong fundraising, Mr. Sanders is positioned to press forward for the foreseeable future, though the Clinton campaign sees advantages in the states that come later in the month.A third candidate, former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, finished far behind the two leaders and dropped out Monday night.The Iowa results were delivered from precincts across 99 counties after a 10-month campaign that showered attention on this rural Midwestern state, which has long taken pride in its role as the first stop on the road to the presidential nomination.In a sweltering school lunchroom in Windsor Heights, a suburb of Des Moines, Clinton backers wooed their neighbors with offers of bottled water. A few miles away, in Clive, Sanders supporters ran out of seats so stood against the wall, beneath Sanders signs reading, "A Future to Believe In."Over dozens of trips to Iowa high schools and diners, in small discussions and big rallies, the two leading candidates engaged in a vigorous and sometimes sharp debate as Mrs. Clinton positioned herself as a pragmatic, can-do fighter, while Mr. Sanders appealed to the party's most deeply held ideals.She battled reports that classified material was sent via her private email system. He battled suggestions that he couldn't win a general election, and that he has no real plan to implement his agenda.On Monday, some Clinton supporters said they were drawn to Mr. Sanders but, in the end, concluded his call for a political revolution would be easier said than done--a point Mrs. Clinton voiced repeatedly.Election 2016* Cruz Defeats Trump in Iowa GOP Caucus* Capital Journal: Front-Runners Give Ground as Rivals Make Mark* Cruz, Rubio Shift the GOP Conversation* Cruz's Win Powered by Evangelicals* New Hampshire Primary Is an Unpredictable One* Campaign-Finance Reports Portend Lengthy Battle"I think he's wonderful man, but I don't think what he says is realistic," said Michelle Wilson, a corporate compliance administrator from West Des Moines. She served as a precinct captain for then-Sen. Barack Obama in 2008; on Monday, she came to caucus for Mrs. Clinton.But in Clive, west of Des Moines, Carol Ferrell, 59, decided at the last minute to support Mr. Sanders. "As much as I admire Hillary Clinton, she's got a lot of baggage," she said.And Mr. Sanders inspired voters who said they were attracted to his rejection of big-money politics and his promise of a "political revolution" that would upend that status quo. He drew large, energetic crowds to arenas and a loyal online following, where backers taunted detractors to "feel the Bern."Beyond their platforms, the battle was waged over who best turned out their supporters. Mr. Sanders repeatedly warned his large and enthusiastic crowds that he would lose if they didn't show up to caucus.But Mrs. Clinton, after being outmaneuvered in 2008, relied on a network of field staffers and volunteers that her campaign has been building for months. And late Monday, Clinton aides claimed victory, saying there was a big turnout--as Mr. Sanders had hoped for--and yet she still tied him.In Van Meter, about a half-hour to the west, Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, a former Iowa governor and Clinton supporter, marveled at the turnout for his precinct."My wife got a call at five in the afternoon, asking if she was going to caucus," he said. "Then they asked, 'Is your husband home, and is he caucusing?'"Ahead of the balloting, the Sanders campaign said that a narrow defeat would do nothing to stop his forward progress, and he has the money to compete long-term.In January, Mr. Sanders raised $20 million, and with most of his donations well below the legal limit, he can go back to his donors for more."The thing that generally ends campaigns is lack of resources," said David Axelrod, who helped steer President Barack Obama's two victories. "This does not seem to be a problem for the Sanders campaign."Ahead of the balloting, Sanders strategist Tad Devine said, "We've done what we came to do, which is establish him as a serious candidate."The Clinton campaign was bracing for a loss in New Hampshire, the state that rescued Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign and revived Mrs. Clinton's 2008 effort."There are a lot of headwinds in New Hampshire," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said in an interview, noting that candidates from neighboring states, like Mr. Sanders, have almost always won New Hampshire in recent years.But the campaign feels optimistic looking ahead. Mr. Mook pointed to Mrs. Clinton's strong position in Nevada and South Carolina and in the swath of Southern states that will award a quarter of the delegates at stake on March 1.These states, where the Clinton campaign began organizing last summer, have more nonwhite voters than the states in the first two contests. Mrs. Clinton polls strongly among these voters and would continue to emphasize matters important to African-Americans, including her association with Mr. Obama, gun restrictions and the water crisis in Flint, Mich.The candidates offer Democrats with two very different visions for governing.In speeches that remained almost identical across months of campaigning, Mr. Sanders promised to break up large banks, said Wall Street is built on fraud and unapologetically vowed to impose higher taxes to provide universal health care , free tuition at public colleges and more generous Social Security benefits. At a rally Saturday, as Mr. Sanders ticked off society's problems, the crowd spontaneously began chanting, "Enough is enough!"Mrs. Clinton, for her part, highlighted her perseverance and qualifications for the presidency, including four years as secretary of state, along with what she describes as a pragmatic, effective approach to governing. She also portrayed herself as the most electable candidate whose nomination is necessary to block Republican ideas.Her policy platform includes a new program for debt-free tuition and an increase in solar panels, as well as changes in health care and Social Security that are more modest than her rival's.Her supporters, including many older women who grew up in a time of outright sex discrimination, say they were inspired by the idea of electing the first female president. And backers often say she is the most qualified candidate for the presidency they have ever encountered.On Monday night, Deidre Fudge arrived early to her West Des Moines caucus to register support for Mrs. Clinton."I'm just a little worried about Bernie and his naiveté," Ms. Fudge said. "I appreciate her experience and levelheadedness about what can actually get done."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com , Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler, Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Hillary and Bernie Recall LBJ More Than JFK
article text: Regarding Edward P. Lazear's "If Only Hillary and Bernie Would Recall JFK" (op-ed, Jan. 29): While it is true that individual Americans migrate among all five annual income quintiles, all boats don't move up and down by the same amount in a rising tide.Regarding Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, the questions for America include whether they want to limit boating or add a ton of freight to some people's boats, and not allow other vessels to sail during any tide. President John F. Kennedy understood incentives. He understood, 20-plus years before the Laffer curve, that if you want more of something, tax it less. Americans may not be able to handle a president with policies that mandate some boats get torpedoed, while others are allowed to sail on subsidized biofuel.Michael J. Perullo, CPAAtlanta---Mr. Lazear claims President Kennedy believed "a rising tide lifts all boats." However, that was only until JFK read "The Other America," Michael Harrington's 1962 expose of the millions of Americans left behind as the country prospered in the post-World War II boom. Afterward, Kennedy immediately directed his Council of Economic Advisers to look into the issue of poverty in America. Chairman Walter Heller and the council concluded that, in fact, a rising tide doesn't lift all boats.Records show that poverty was one of the last things JFK focused on before his assassination, and that he wanted to make it central to his 1964 legislative agenda. Lyndon Johnson took up this charge and launched the War on Poverty, designed to be a hand up -- not a handout -- and lift people out of poverty.Class warfare isn't the answer, but it's about time to realize that it takes a lot more than tax cuts and other incentives for the so-called "job creators" to lift today's 50 million Americans out of poverty and revitalize the country's struggling middle class. Now, if only Hillary and Bernie would recall LBJ.Tyler RossChicago---It is a testament to Democratic and media image-making that JFK is remembered primarily for his "Camelot" White House and his tragic death, not for his too-brief push for lower-tax, pro-growth, supply-side economic policies. The one stain on JFK's thousand days in the White House was his support of a disastrous attempt to overturn Fidel Castro's revolution in Cuba. That failure allowed the Castro brothers to show what happens to an economy that is built on class warfare rather than growth. Many leftist American admirers of Castro are flocking to Cuba before capitalists start renovating the dilapidated buildings in Havana and destroy its 1950s ambience. Cuba's economy needs to cross the bridge to the 1960s before making any leap into the 21st century.Why can't we learn that class war is economic hell for all classes?William HoganSavannah, Ga.---President Kennedy also said, "Ask not what your country can do for you -- ask what you can do for your country."The Democratic Party message of 2008, ever more strident now, is: "The government will see that your needs are met. Someone else will pay for this, and you need not be personally responsible." How far today's Democrats have moved from the uplifting words of JFK, and how unfortunate for our country's future.Beverly Holland ReichelSanta Monica, Calif.

article name: Federal Lawmakers Ramp Up Response to Flint Water Crisis; House committee issues subpoenas, Democratic senators seek money, and Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders plan debate in city
article text: Scott Calvert, Siobhan Hughes and Kristina Peterson contributed to this article.WASHINGTON--Federal lawmakers Wednesday ratcheted up their response to the water crisis in Flint, Mich., as a House committee subpoenaed government officials and Democratic senators urged that money be set aside to address the problem.The Democratic Party also said its two presidential hopefuls, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders (D., Vt.), would hold a debate in Flint on March 6 as a way to draw attention to the contaminated-water issue.Flint has been embroiled in a crisis for months , after the city began taking its drinking water from the Flint River, which caused lead levels to reach dangerous heights . The move was meant to be temporary as the city cut costs by switching from Detroit's water system to another water authority.Rep. Jason Chafftez (R., Utah), chairman of the House oversight committee, said Wednesday he issued subpoenas to two officials to force them to appear at a deposition with committee lawyers regarding Flint's water crisis.More Flint Coverage* Hearings Open on Flint Water Crisis* New Trouble Knocks Flint as Mortgage Firms Require Proof of Safe Water* Detroit Schools' Emergency Manager to Step Down* Lead Levels in Flint Remain Extremely High at Some Locations* State Officials in Flint Got Bottled Water Months Before Warning Not to Drink It* U.S. Cities Scrutinize Water Systems in Wake of Flint* Series of Mistakes Tainted Flint WaterThe committee had invited three officials--Miguel Del Toral, a water official at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; former EPA Regional Administrator Susan Hedman, who resigned Monday over the crisis; and former Flint emergency manager Darnell Earley--to testify at a hearing Wednesday. It was the first congressional hearing on the crisis since it came to national attention last fall.The three officials declined to appear.Nichole Distefano, an associate administrator at the EPA, told the committee in a letter last week "it would be highly unusual for the agency to send a non-supervisory regional career staff member" like Mr. Del Toral to testify before Congress, the letter stated, and Mr. Del Toral was focused on addressing the crisis in Flint.The committee had invited Mr. Del Toral because he wrote a memo to EPA colleagues in June 2015 detailing the high levels of lead in Flint's drinking water. The committee accepted his decision not to testify.However, Mr. Chaffetz said he deployed the subpoenas, which have legal force, to bring Mr. Earley and Ms. Hedman to Washington for a deposition. Whether Mr. Chaffetz would also try to compel them to appear at a public hearing hasn't been decided, according to a panel spokeswoman.An attorney representing Mr. Earley, A. Scott Bolden, said the former emergency manager would be willing to meet with and testify before the committee "subject to his constitutional rights and subject to any privileges he would enjoy." Witnesses can choose to invoke their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination, declining to answer questions, though Mr. Bolden didn't cite that provision in particular.Ms. Hedman, the former EPA regional administrator for Michigan, couldn't be reached for comment.Five other witnesses, including an official from the EPA and the director of Michigan's Department of Environmental Quality, testified Wednesday.Joel Beauvais, acting deputy assistant administrator for the EPA's office of water, defended his agency's actions before the House committee and said the first responsibility for responding to the crisis fell to state and local governments.Flint also took center stage Wednesday in the Senate debate on an energy bill, as Democrats and Republicans negotiated over a Democratic amendment providing $200 million in direct funds for Flint and as much as $600 million in loans and other financing."We're looking for some help from the federal government for a problem that was created by the state of Michigan and with thousands of victims," said Sen. Dick Durbin (D., Ill.), the second-ranking Senate Democrat.Republicans said they were concerned about the federal government spending money to tackle a non-federal problem. The Democratic proposal "puts the cart ahead of the horse in terms of letting local and state government address what is a local and state problem," said Sen. John Cornyn (R., Texas), the second-ranking Senate Republican.The issue has at times inflamed political sensitivities. Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, has apologized for the crisis, and Democrats have cited it as evidence of GOP neglect of infrastructure and public health. Republicans have framed it as a failure of government more broadly.At the House hearing, members of both parties chiefly criticized the state of Michigan but also chided the EPA for not responding more aggressively when Mr. Del Toral's memo pointed to high levels of lead in Flint's water.The EPA said there is no safe level of exposure to lead, a potent neurotoxin that is especially damaging to children because it harms development of the brain and nervous system.Rep. Dan Kildee, a Democrat who represents Flint, said at the hearing that Michigan is the main culprit, calling it a "false equivalence" to blame city and federal officials as much as the state. "This was a state failure," Mr. Kildee said.The Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan, and two EPA divisions are among the agencies working on a broad criminal investigation into the lead contamination of Flint.Write to Amy Harder at amy.harder@wsj.com and Kris Maher at kris.maher@wsj.comCorrections & Amplifications: The House Oversight Committee accepted EPA official Miguel Del Toral's decision not to testify and is not issuing a subpoena to require his presence. An earlier version of this article said the committee was issuing a subpoena for Mr. Del Toral along with two other officials. (Feb. 3, 2016)Credit: By Amy Harder and Kris Maher

article name: Clinton and Sanders Sharpen Their Rhetoric; Democrats spar over who is 'progressive,' as well as on the senator's edge in a neighboring state
article text: Jennifer Levitz contributed to this article.DERRY, N.H.--Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders stepped up their attacks before they meet for a one-on-one debate Thursday, campaigning aggressively in a state that her campaign says she may not be able to win.Trailing by double digits in New Hampshire polls, Mrs. Clinton on Wednesday rejected suggestions that she look past the state and focus instead on friendlier territory, as both campaigns sharpened their tones and sparred from afar.Mr. Sanders jabbed first on Tuesday when he said the former senator and secretary of state is a progressive "some days.""Except when she announces she's a moderate," the Vermont senator said. "Then she's not a progressive."Mrs. Clinton hit back at a get-out-the-vote event, calling her opponent's comments a "low blow" and saying she has delivered results for progressives. She said the race should focus on issues, but added that "if it's about our records, hey, I'm going to win by a landslide."The squabble over which candidate is more progressive ramped up online with a series of tweets from Mr. Sanders's account, including a long list of more moderate policy positions that Mrs. Clinton has taken in the past.Mrs. Clinton's campaign suggested that Mr. Sanders has built-in advantages in New Hampshire because he represents neighboring Vermont. Mr. Sanders parried, saying New Hampshire voters are serious about their role in the nominating process and that "to repeatedly suggest otherwise is an insult" to them.Mr. Sanders said on CNN that the Clinton campaign is financed by Wall Street and big-money interests. Mrs. Clinton countered by critiquing her rival's health-care plan.This intensifying tit-for-tat is playing out in a state where Mrs. Clinton is a decided long-shot. A Real Clear Politics average of polls shows Mr. Sanders with an 18-percentage-point advantage in Tuesday's primary, and some have suggested Mrs. Clinton should focus her resources on the states that will vote shortly after New Hampshire."Not on your life," Mrs. Clinton told supporters Wednesday. "I would never quit on New Hampshire."The Clinton campaign has tried to lower expectations in recent days, saying that Mrs. Clinton's 2008 come-from-behind win in New Hampshire is unlikely to be replicated. Jennifer Palmieri, Mrs. Clinton's communications director, said Mr. Sanders has a substantial lead but that the former secretary of state would stay in New Hampshire through the primary, trying to build support."We don't know that we can win, but she is going to be here every day," Ms. Palmieri said.The Sanders campaign pushed back against the Clinton team's attempts to play down her prospects. "They're overplaying their hand on this 'He's a neighbor' stuff,' " said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders campaign strategist. "Our view is we're up against the whole establishment again."The battle for New Hampshire and the tonal shift in the Democratic campaign come on the heels of a hard-fought contest in Iowa that saw Mrs. Clinton eke out a razor-thin win. The Sanders campaign has framed that outcome as a victory; people close to the Clintons have said they expected a better result.Some Democratic strategists said Mrs. Clinton remains in a stronger position for the long term. With the race soon moving to states with higher percentages of minority voters, Mrs. Clinton stands to do better, they said. Steve McMahon, a longtime Democratic consultant, said the Iowa result "helped Bernie, but it wasn't enough of a 'Voila!' moment to change the dynamic in South Carolina and Nevada.""That's what he needed," Mr. McMahon said.Although Mr. Sanders didn't come out of Iowa with a win, the result validated his candidacy and demonstrated to the Democratic Party that Mrs. Clinton is hardly invincible, Mr. Devine said."They'd been hearing that she is way ahead and her nomination has been a foregone conclusion," Mr. Devine said. "Now they're finding that's not the case."A goal of the Sanders campaign in New Hampshire is to gain momentum and compel Democrats in other states to take a fresh look at the contest, he said. Polls show Mr. Sanders trailing Mrs. Clinton in coming contests in South Carolina and other Southern states with large numbers of African-American voters. He described New Hampshire as a "moment of acceleration." Mr. Sanders is telling supporters that the political establishment is growing nervous about his staying power. Winning the nomination won't be easy, the senator said, but he noted that in Iowa he took on the "most powerful political organization in the country."For her part, Mrs. Clinton is positioning herself as a fighter, not a front-runner, and is quick to remind voters that she is running against a "neighbor." She urges, "New Hampshire, come with me this week."Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: Federal Lawmakers Ramp Up Response to Flint Water Crisis; House committee issues subpoenas, Democratic senators seek money, and Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders plan debate in city
article text: Scott Calvert, Siobhan Hughes and Kristina Peterson contributed to this article.WASHINGTON--Federal lawmakers Wednesday ratcheted up their response to the water crisis in Flint, Mich., as a House committee subpoenaed government officials and Democratic senators urged that money be set aside to address the problem.The Democratic Party also said its two presidential hopefuls, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders (D., Vt.), would hold a debate in Flint on March 6 as a way to draw attention to the contaminated-water issue.Flint has been embroiled in a crisis for months , after the city began taking its drinking water from the Flint River, which caused lead levels to reach dangerous heights . The move was meant to be temporary as the city cut costs by switching from Detroit's water system to another water authority.Rep. Jason Chafftez (R., Utah), chairman of the House oversight committee, said Wednesday he issued subpoenas to two officials to force them to appear at a deposition with committee lawyers regarding Flint's water crisis.More Flint Coverage* Hearings Open on Flint Water Crisis* Detroit Schools' Emergency Manager to Step Down* Lead Levels in Flint Remain Extremely High at Some Locations* State Officials in Flint Got Bottled Water Months Before Warning Not to Drink It* U.S. Cities Scrutinize Water Systems in Wake of Flint* Series of Mistakes Tainted Flint WaterThe committee had invited three officials--Miguel Del Toral, a water official at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; former EPA Regional Administrator Susan Hedman, who resigned Monday over the crisis; and former Flint emergency manager Darnell Earley--to testify at a hearing Wednesday. It was the first congressional hearing on the crisis since it came to national attention last fall.The three officials declined to appear.Nichole Distefano, an associate administrator at the EPA, told the committee in a letter last week "it would be highly unusual for the agency to send a non-supervisory regional career staff member" like Mr. Del Toral to testify before Congress, the letter stated, and Mr. Del Toral was focused on addressing the crisis in Flint.The committee had invited Mr. Del Toral because he wrote a memo to EPA colleagues in June 2015 detailing the high levels of lead in Flint's drinking water. The committee accepted his decision not to testify.However, Mr. Chaffetz said he deployed the subpoenas, which have legal force, to bring Mr. Earley and Ms. Hedman to Washington for a deposition. Whether Mr. Chaffetz would also try to compel them to appear at a public hearing hasn't been decided, according to a panel spokeswoman.An attorney representing Mr. Earley, A. Scott Bolden, said the former emergency manager would be willing to meet with and testify before the committee "subject to his constitutional rights and subject to any privileges he would enjoy." Witnesses can choose to invoke their Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination, declining to answer questions, though Mr. Bolden didn't cite that provision in particular.Ms. Hedman, the former EPA regional administrator for Michigan, couldn't be reached for comment.Five other witnesses, including an official from the EPA and the director of Michigan's Department of Environmental Quality, testified Wednesday.Joel Beauvais, acting deputy assistant administrator for the EPA's office of water, defended his agency's actions before the House committee and said the first responsibility for responding to the crisis fell to state and local governments.Flint also took center stage Wednesday in the Senate debate on an energy bill, as Democrats and Republicans negotiated over a Democratic amendment providing $200 million in direct funds for Flint and as much as $600 million in loans and other financing."We're looking for some help from the federal government for a problem that was created by the state of Michigan and with thousands of victims," said Sen. Dick Durbin (D., Ill.), the second-ranking Senate Democrat.Republicans said they were concerned about the federal government spending money to tackle a non-federal problem. The Democratic proposal "puts the cart ahead of the horse in terms of letting local and state government address what is a local and state problem," said Sen. John Cornyn (R., Texas), the second-ranking Senate Republican.The issue has at times inflamed political sensitivities. Michigan Gov. Rick Snyder, a Republican, has apologized for the crisis, and Democrats have cited it as evidence of GOP neglect of infrastructure and public health. Republicans have framed it as a failure of government more broadly.At the House hearing, members of both parties chiefly criticized the state of Michigan but also chided the EPA for not responding more aggressively when Mr. Del Toral's memo pointed to high levels of lead in Flint's water.The EPA said there is no safe level of exposure to lead, a potent neurotoxin that is especially damaging to children because it harms development of the brain and nervous system.Rep. Dan Kildee, a Democrat who represents Flint, said at the hearing that Michigan is the main culprit, calling it a "false equivalence" to blame city and federal officials as much as the state. "This was a state failure," Mr. Kildee said.The Federal Bureau of Investigation, the U.S. attorney for the Eastern District of Michigan, and two EPA divisions are among the agencies working on a broad criminal investigation into the lead contamination of Flint.Write to Amy Harder at amy.harder@wsj.com and Kris Maher at kris.maher@wsj.comCorrections & Amplifications: The House Oversight Committee accepted EPA official Miguel Del Toral's decision not to testify and is not issuing a subpoena to require his presence. An earlier version of this article said the committee was issuing a subpoena for Mr. Del Toral along with two other officials. (Feb. 3, 2016)Credit: By Amy Harder and Kris Maher

article name: Bernie's Big (Last?) Moment; Sanders must start playing to win before he gets rolled by the Clinton machine.
article text: Claremont, N.H.You can hear the whooping from the front door of the city opera house. Two stories up, on Tuesday night, an enormous crowd is packed in to hear Bernie Sanders at his first big event after the Iowa caucuses.It feels like a tent revival meeting. Bernie is keying up his crowd. Every time he brings up the banks, or "special interests," or the "billionaire class," someone in the audience pipes up with a rejoinder, followed by a roar from the crowd. "You ever heard of Goldman Sachs?" deadpans the Vermont senator. A voice shouts, "Hillary has! She goes there!" The masses scream: "BOOOOO!!!" The audience is amped; they love him. This is Bernie's moment.And likely his only one.Farther south, on that same Tuesday, another crowd of Democrats has assembled at Nashua Community College. This one isn't so electric. It looks more . . . determined. Those gathered also love Bernie. They love his "enthusiasm" and how "bold" he is and his "truth." Yet here they are, at a Hillary Clinton rally.Bernie "is unelectable," says Darius Mohsenin, a Democrat from California who has flown all the way here to check out the contenders. "I like Bernie's message. He's bringing up a lot of third-rail items." The 56-year-old landlord particularly likes the Vermonter's focus on "income inequality." Is Hillary addressing that issue? "She's hinting at it. It's embedded in her platform, but not as much." The point is, he says, "she can win."Witness the triumph of the Clinton machine. The media are playing up the Iowa results as a Clinton-Sanders "tie," pitching the possibility of a drawn-out fight for the Democratic nomination. In fact, Mrs. Clinton is hitting her stride, making electability a potent anti-Sanders message. She knows that the more voters tune in, the more they realize the stakes. So she's reminding them every chance she can that the White House and Barack Obama's legacy are on the line.That's why Mrs. Clinton is bear-hugging Mr. Obama, promising to protect and expand on his work. It's why she insists that Mr. Sanders's plan for single-payer health care will "never, ever come to pass"--her way of warning Democrats that Bernie could never, ever get elected. It's why she keeps droning on about "reality." It's why the supposedly "neutral" Mr. Obama piled on to assure that Hillary could "govern" and "start here, day one, more experienced" than Bernie.Pundits keep weighing in on Mr. Sanders's demographic problems after New Hampshire, his difficulty attracting black voters in, say, South Carolina. But electability is rapidly becoming the bigger liability.
