article name: Sanders Meets Sharpton for Breakfast in Harlem; Civil-rights leader hasn't endorsed in the presidential race
article text: The morning after Bernie Sanders's sweeping victory in the New Hampshire presidential primary , the Vermont senator took his momentum to a Harlem landmark to have tea with the Rev. Al Sharpton.Mr. Sanders arrived at the famed Sylvia's restaurant around 9:50 a.m. Wednesday and waved to a crowd chanting his name. Mr. Sharpton said the meeting lasted 20 minutes and that the senator's visit sent the right message to the black community.Mr. Sharpton said he asked Mr. Sanders, who is seeking the Democratic nomination, about the water crisis in Flint, Mich. , affirmative action and police misconduct."My concern is that in January of next year, for the first time in American history, a black family will be moving out of the White House," Mr. Sharpton said. "I do not want black concerns to be moved out with them."He said he hadn't decided on an endorsement in the 2016 race, and he will meet with Hillary Clinton next Tuesday. Mrs. Clinton's camp confirmed the meeting."Sen. Sanders coming here this morning further makes it clear that we will not be ignored," Mr. Sharpton said. "Our votes must be earned."More in Politics* Chris Christie Is Expected to Suspend Campaign* Bloomberg May See Opening in New Hampshire Primary ResultsHe added Mr. Sanders was also meeting with Kirsten John Foy, Northeast regional director of National Action Network, a civil-rights organization founded by Mr. Sharpton.Also on hand was former head of the NAACP, Ben Jealous, and State Sen. Bill Perkins, a Manhattan Democrat. Both have endorsed Mr. Sanders."Harlem represents the black community and other communities of color in general but he's going to make sure that he's in all those communities so everybody gets to have the Bern," Mr. Perkins said.Also Wednesday, Mr. Sanders appeared on the ABC television show "The View," and a CBS spokeswoman said he would appear Wednesday night on "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert."Tren'ness Woods-Black, the director of communications for Sylvia's (and granddaughter of Sylvia), said the restaurant remained open to the public during the senator's visit."We wanted to allow everyone to be able to interact and get a just up-close and personal look at who's actually running," said Ms. Woods-Black.Some, however, were disappointed Mr. Sanders didn't do more to interact with the public. After a quick wave to the crowd, the senator departed in his car after the breakfast. Yo Akalu, a 27-year-old City University of New York student, didn't believe the visit was genuine."If he really wants our votes he really needs to come into these projects, he really needs to go into these schools, he really needs to speak to these families," Ms. Akalu said. "Him coming out here to Harlem, coming straight to Sylvia's...what is that?"But Charles Mannings, a resident of Harlem for 20 years, said he thought the short visit was "inspiring." The 70-year-old retired chef said politicians tended to ignore Harlem."I'm glad to see in this particular instance that is not the case," Mr. Mannings said. "Maybe it's indicative of better things to come."Write to Zolan Kanno-Youngs at Zolan.Kanno-Youngs@wsj.comCorrections & Amplifications: An earlier version of this article incorrectly said that Bernie Sanders and Al Sharpton had breakfast together on Tuesday.Credit: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

article name: Bloomberg May See Opening in New Hampshire Primary Results; Victories by Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump could boost former NYC mayor's candidacy
article text: Hundreds of miles from the New Hampshire presidential primary, aides to former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg eyed the solid victories Tuesday by Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump as potential boosts to a Bloomberg candidacy .The results were just one more sign to Mr. Bloomberg's advisers that he may have an opening as Democrats and Republicans embraced candidates they said were unlikely to resonate with voters in a general election. Mr. Bloomberg is expected to meet with Frank Luntz, the pollster and market researcher, this week, according to a person familiar with the matter.Steve Schmidt, a Republican strategist who served as a senior adviser to Sen. John McCain during his 2008 campaign, said the field of candidates was weak and that the former mayor could win."Any combination of them in a general election would open a path for an independent candidate," said Schmidt, who isn't advising Mr. Bloomberg. "There's a big opening in the middle of the electorate, and Bloomberg is on point in that space."Bloomberg aides say they are looking far more closely at the results of Super Tuesday, on March 1, when more states will vote in the primaries and it will be easier to gauge the strength of Mrs. Clinton and others in the race.Related* Michael Bloomberg Mulling Run for President as Independent* Michael Bloomberg Acknowledges He Is Weighing Presidential BidYet, the biggest hurdle to a Bloomberg presidential bid may not hinge on the shifting fortunes of the other candidates, but on the former mayor's political brand. Mr. Bloomberg is a fiscally conservative technocrat with Wall Street roots, a liberal on many social issues and a gun-control advocate. He identified as a Democrat but first ran for mayor in 2001 as a Republican, and later ran as an independent."He would have zero chance here," said Matt Borges, the chairman of the Republican Party in Ohio, a swing state. Mr. Borges said he believed Mr. Bloomberg's positions on issues like gun control would be insurmountable.Other obstacles loom. Some conservative voters, particularly in the South, have ridiculed him for his positions on guns and for a measure in New York City, later turned aside by a court, to restrict the sale of large, sugary drinks.Mr. Bloomberg would also likely face skepticism among Democrats, both for his stout defense of big corporations and for his record on race and policing. A police tactic he embraced known as "stop-and-frisk" was criticized as unfairly targeting minorities and struck down in 2013 by a federal judge.Advisers to Mr. Bloomberg said those handicaps could be overcome. One aide broke down Mr. Bloomberg's appeal to voters this way: a political outsider unbeholden to party machinery; private-sector success running Bloomberg LP, his data and media company; three-term mayor of New York, credited with revitalizing the nation's most populous city and driving down crime."There is a degree of polarization, division and I daresay lack of focus on the major issues facing the country that is exemplified by the entire primary process to date. Including but not limited to New Hampshire," said Douglas E. Schoen, a longtime Bloomberg adviser who has conducted polls for the former mayor.Mr. Bloomberg has other advantages. He is worth more than $30 billion and has signaled he is ready to spend. One of his top political aides, Howard Wolfson, served as communications director for Hillary Clinton's 2008 campaign. He has a stable of loyal aides ready to jump in.The campaign trail could be an awkward place for Mr. Bloomberg, who frequently grew irritated with the New York City press corps for asking personal questions about his life, including his weekend travels to his vacation homes. He isn't a natural campaigner, though his aides noted he grew increasingly easy on the trail as the years passed."He was used to business groups, marketing professionals--the political media was a very different kind of thing," said Bill Cunningham, a former aide to Mr. Bloomberg.A third-party candidate has never succeeded at winning the presidency, though they have shaped the contests, with Ralph Nader in 2000 being the most recent example. Entering the race late, Mr. Bloomberg would face challenges getting on state ballots and building campaign machinery in every state.James McCann, a professor of political science at Purdue University and an expert on third-party candidacies, said Mr. Bloomberg faced an uphill battle. "It still is difficult to come in from out of the blue and get the traction you need, even when things are really seemingly divisive and there's a great deal of disenchantment, even when you're a billionaire."Write to Mara Gay at mara.gay@wsj.comCredit: By Mara Gay and Josh Dawsey

article name: The Left-Right Revolt; Sanders and Trump ride very different populist uprisings in New Hampshire.
article text: Americans keep telling pollsters they're unhappy--or worse--with their political leaders, and on Tuesday they proved it in New Hampshire by handing victories to a 74-year-old socialist and a blustery businessman with no political experience. Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump are still a long way from the White House, but their victories reveal parallel but very different popular revolts on the left and right.***The uprising on the left is perhaps most surprising given that Democrats hold the White House, and Hillary Clinton campaigned to build on President Obama's record. But in New Hampshire the revolt was ideological and personal against Mrs. Clinton and the status quo.Mr. Obama tilted before the Iowa caucuses toward Mrs. Clinton as his preferred successor, but New Hampshire shows that his Presidency has been a hot-house garden for nurturing progressives. According to the exit polls, nearly seven in 10 Democrats described themselves as liberal, up from 56% in 2008. Roughly a quarter described themselves as "very liberal," and Mr. Sanders won them two to one.Mr. Obama calls inequality the defining issue of our times, and Democrats believe him. A third of Democrats said it is the most important issue facing the country, and about 70% of those voted for Mr. Sanders.Mrs. Clinton won the New Hampshire primary in 2008, but this year Democrats seem to have rejected her on personal and character grounds. Mr. Sanders won nine of 10 voters in the exit polls who said that only Mr. Sanders or neither of the two candidates were "honest and trustworthy." The Clinton campaign has tried, as it always does, to plow through her email scandals by portraying them merely as Republican attacks. But even many Democrats don't believe her anymore.Mrs. Clinton now finds herself in a populist showdown she never anticipated and doesn't play to her strengths. She's best as a machine candidate of the unions, feminist volunteers and wealthy environmentalists. Mr. Sanders is motivating the younger liberals who were also drawn to Mr. Obama and who are voting for the Vermonter by three or more to one.The Clinton campaign will console itself that the campaign now moves to states where the electorate will have more minorities and fewer gentry liberals. And to win the nomination Mr. Sanders will have to show that he can expand his support among minorities, especially the black voters who are so important in southern primaries.The Vermont Senator's other great obstacle is that many Democrats still fear that a self-avowed socialist can't win in November. But that argument becomes less damaging as it becomes clearer that Mrs. Clinton has weaknesses that also could be fatal in the fall. As Republicans get closer to nominating the mercurial Mr. Trump, more Democrats may also conclude that even Mr. Sanders could win so why not take a chance on their true heart?Which brings us to Mr. Trump and the revolt on the right. This is less about ideology and policies than the businessman's political style and Republican disgust with Washington. The New Yorker dominated the field with some 34% of the vote as we went to press, while no other candidate broke into the high teens. The victory showed that, contrary to Iowa, Mr. Trump could translate polling leads into actual votes. And it showed that the ceiling in his support is higher than many Republicans have believed.The businessman did especially well among voters without a college degree, but his support was strong across most demographic and ideological groups. He's the choice of voters who like that he "tells it like it is" and think he can change Washington. But the exit polls also showed some signs of potential weakness. A little less than a third of his voters said they liked Mr. Trump but had reservations. And his share of voters who said he could best handle an international crisis was below his overall vote share.As for the others, Mr. Trump will be happy that no clear alternative emerged. John Kasich's investment in the Granite State--100 town halls--paid off with a second-place finish. The Ohio Governor did well among independents and especially moderates. His challenge going forward will be that there are fewer of both of those voting blocs as the primaries head to South Carolina next week and elsewhere in the South on March 1. He will have to raise money fast to be competitive, as well as show he can win over more conservative voters.Jeb Bush spent heavily in the state and has to be disappointed to finish in the mix for third or fourth place as we went to press. He has been performing better in debates and has the money to fight on in South Carolina, but he will have to show he can beat Mr. Kasich and Marco Rubio to go much beyond that.Mr. Rubio may be the most disappointed by Tuesday's result because the Florida Senator couldn't build on his Iowa surge and suffered from his debate brain-freeze on Saturday. More late deciders turned to other candidates, and some two-thirds said that debates influenced their votes.Ted Cruz also failed to capitalize on his Iowa victory, notably in failing to make inroads among voters who aren't evangelicals or very conservative. The Texas Senator will find more fertile territory in the South, but his showing in New England bodes ill for winning swing states if he is the GOP nominee in November.***All of which means that New Hampshire hasn't performed its traditional role of winnowing the field as much as usual. Chris Christie will find it hard to continue after his sixth-place finish, as will also-rans Ben Carson and Carly Fiorina. The rest have a case to fight on. But one big lesson of New Hampshire is that if the non-winners want to become the GOP nominee, they will sooner rather than later have to stop attacking each other and start educating voters about Donald J. Trump.

article name: Results in New Hampshire Point to Hillary Clinton's Weaknesses; Sanders's message is exciting his core supporters more than Clinton is energizing her base, exit polls show
article text: Democrats in the first two presidential nominating contests have delivered a clear message to Hillary Clinton about her weaknesses as a candidate. She isn't considered trustworthy, and her message of competence and experience isn't sufficiently compelling.About a quarter of Iowa's Democratic caucusgoers last week said the quality they most wanted in a nominee was honesty and trustworthiness. Among that group, voter surveys showed, Mrs. Clinton won a mere 10%.The verdict was more severe in New Hampshire on Tuesday. One-third of voters said they most wanted honesty in a nominee, and Mrs. Clinton carried 5% of those voters.The results in part reflect the months of controversy Mrs. Clinton generated by using a private email system during her time as secretary of state, questions about her family's charitable foundation, as well as speaking fees she earned from Wall Street firms that are a favorite target of liberal Democrats.Mrs. Clinton left the Obama administration in early 2013 with a positive image, Wall Street Journal/NBC News polling shows. But by last month, some 40% of registered voters viewed her unfavorably while a larger share--49%--saw her in a negative light.The results from Iowa and New Hampshire also signaled that Mrs. Clinton has yet to fashion an argument for her candidacy as powerful as the liberal vision laid out by Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont. A self-described democratic socialist, Mr. Sanders promises to end a "corrupt'' campaign-finance system that he says allows the wealthy and Wall Street buy influence and rig the economy in their favor.Mrs. Clinton also has laid out liberal goals, but her candidacy also rests on her long experience in public life and the argument that she would make the stronger general election candidate. In New Hampshire, however, Democratic primary voters said they most wanted a nominee who was "honest'' and "cares about people like me.''Some 60% of voters chose one of those two qualities, exit polls showed, and Mr. Sanders carried both groups by lopsided margins.By contrast, 38% said experience or the ability to win in November was the most important quality in a nominee. Mrs. Clinton won those groups by large margins, exit polls showed.Mr. Sanders's message is exciting his core supporters more than Mrs. Clinton is energizing her base. She carried her strongest voting group, women age 45 and older, by seven percentage points in New Hampshire, 53% to 46%, exit polls showed.Mr. Sanders, by contrast, posted prohibitively large margins among the groups that most responded to his message. Some three-quarters of Democratic primary voters under age 45 backed him in New Hampshire, including 83% of voters under 30.Young women, who many presumed would be part of the Clinton coalition, are instead turning to Mr. Sanders. He carried women under age 45 by 40 percentage points in New Hampshire, 69% to 29%.While Iowa and New Hampshire proved to be unexpectedly difficult tests for Mrs. Clinton, the race now moves to states that could prove to be friendlier terrain. The first contests took place in two of the most liberal and least racially diverse states in the nation. Next come states with larger shares of minority and centrist voters, who in opinion surveys have favored Mrs. Clinton.Credit: By Aaron Zitner

article name: Nevada Caucus Offers New Test for Democrats; Hillary Clinton hopes state's minority voters will help her rebound against Bernie Sanders
article text: LAS VEGAS--Next up for the Democratic presidential candidates is Nevada, the state that offers the first real test of whether minority voters will help Hillary Clinton stall Sen. Bernie Sanders's momentum or rally behind her rival's insurgent campaign.Hispanics and African-Americans may account for one-third of those who show up for the Western state's caucuses on Feb. 20. A Sanders victory here would expose the first cracks in the "firewall" the Clinton campaign says it has built in states that are more racially and ethnically diverse than Iowa and New Hampshire. Should the former senator and secretary of state rebound from her loss in New Hampshire , it would buttress her claim to being the sole Democrat with broad national support.Clinton allies seem relieved to be fighting on new terrain. Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D., Ill.) stopped at a Clinton campaign office in east Las Vegas on Monday, looked out at the many Hispanic and black volunteers and said: "This is what America looks like! I like Iowa. I like New Hampshire. But this is what America looks like!"Nevada's electorate is not only less white but more centrist. In 2008, liberals accounted for 56% of New Hampshire primary voters--12 points higher than in Nevada. Whites made up 94% of New Hampshire primary voters Tuesday, according to early exit polls, compared with just 65% of caucus-goers in Nevada in 2008, which was based on entrance polls.Neither campaign is certain how many people will show up for the caucuses. In 2008, about 120,000 Nevadans took part, which was about 22% of registered Democrats. The state will send 43 delegates and three alternates to the Democratic nominating convention in Philadelphia in July.The Democratic contest in Nevada will be held the same day as the Republicans' South Carolina primary. The GOP's Nevada caucuses are a few days later, and the Democrats then hold their own South Carolina primary on Feb. 27.Mindful of the stakes in Nevada, the two rivals are competing hard. The Clinton team arrived in Nevada in April, the same month she entered the race. Aides plunged into the painstaking work of culling voter lists. They set up Spanish-language training sessions and mock caucuses so that Mrs. Clinton's Hispanic supporters would know what to expect at caucus sites. In her 2008 presidential bid, Mrs. Clinton won 64% of Hispanic voters in Nevada, compared with 26% for then-Sen. Barack Obama, exit polls showed.Mr. Sanders's team didn't arrive until October, having given priority to operations in New Hampshire and Iowa and wanting to make sure the campaign had enough money.Since then, a Sanders campaign flush with cash opened a dozen offices and hired more than 90 campaign workers. His campaign has been airing television ads steadily in Nevada since December, making use of Spanish-language TV and radio. The Clinton campaign, for its part, won't say how many paid staff it has in the state. It has fewer offices but also makes use of volunteers' homes, aides said."We had to be prudent with funding state operations, and once it became clear that the campaign would be well-funded, then we were able to expand into other states," said Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager. "Do we have some ground to make up? Absolutely."Eight years ago, Nevada Democrats produced a split decision: Mrs. Clinton won the popular vote but Mr. Obama walked away with more delegates. This time, her campaign hopes to win not just the large cities but also remote precincts that offer a disproportionate share of delegates under the state's caucus rules."It's really difficult to run up the score in one place," said the Clinton campaign's Nevada director, Emmy Ruiz. "We need to have a strong showing in these [Las Vegas caucus sites], but also need to have a strong showing in Sumerlin and Pahrump and Elko."That explains what Bill Clinton was doing Saturday in tiny Pahrump, speaking at an elementary school. The town is part of Nye County, which has fewer than 8,000 registered Democrats but boasts a small cache of delegates the Clinton campaign doesn't want to pass up.Mrs. Clinton has won the support of prominent Nevada party officials and Hispanic activists. Her state campaign team includes people with deep roots in Nevada politics.Rory Reid, a Clinton supporter and son of Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid, said: "She's even better organized than she was in 2008 and therefore should be just as successful."Mr. Sanders, meanwhile, is the darling of young voters, and he could benefit by rules that allow residents to register on the day of the caucuses. The Sanders campaign is wooing teenagers and 20-somethings with events like "Bands for Bernie" concerts throughout the state.It seems to be working. Yvanna Cancela, political director of the powerful culinary workers union, said she was at a bar in Las Vegas recently and noticed that a young man sitting next to her was doodling on his cocktail napkin. "Bernie Sanders is the future," he had written.Even some older folks are feeling the Bern.Zaffar Iqbal, 44, is a physician who for the first time in his life is getting active in presidential politics, canvassing neighborhoods in support of Mr. Sanders.Too many of his patients can't afford the drugs he prescribes, and he believes Mr. Sanders's proposed government-run health-care plan would ease the cost. "Bernie has inspired me," Dr. Iqbal said in a campaign office in Las Vegas.What looks to be close a race has sparked tensions between the two camps. The culinary union, which hasn't made an endorsement, was upset to hear that Sanders supporters posed as union members to talk to hotel employees. Mr. Weaver, in an interview, said: "We certainly have nothing but the deepest respect for culinary workers and we certain have made sure that no one does that again."Paul Overberg contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Sanders and Trump Win Big But Leave Their Races Unsettled; This year, results from Iowa and New Hampshire don't do much to winnow the field for either party
article text: For years, plenty of players in the American political system have quietly wished that the outsize role of two small and quirky states--Iowa and New Hampshire--in picking presidential nominees could be reduced.Maybe this is the year that has come true.With the results now in from New Hampshire's primary, what's striking is how little those two states, the ones that often launch new front-runners and bring leaders crashing down to earth, have actually settled.Donald Trump won New Hampshire's Republican primary in convincing fashion, and he leaves the state as the clear leader and with momentum. Still, there's no single alternative to him, but rather a muddle of four candidates just below who will battle on; the field is far from winnowed. And now the campaign moves on to states where the movement conservatives and evangelicals who denied Mr. Trump victory in Iowa again hold much greater power. The picture is unsettled.On the Democratic side, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders won an impressive victory, one that will rattle plenty of party leaders who wanted former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton to cruise to the nomination unruffled and well financed. But the race moves on to two states, Nevada and South Carolina, where his core supporters--white, well-educated liberals and young voters--fade in importance and give way to a large contingent of the Hispanic and African-American voters that figure to be her strength and his Achilles' heel.So voters in states across America now have every reason to think they, too, will get a voice in deciding these nominations. Five, perhaps six Republican candidates will battle on. The names Kasich, Cruz, Rubio, Bush and Trump--and perhaps Christie as well--are linked for at least several more weeks.Among Democrats, Mr. Sanders has humbled the once inevitable candidate and emerged with two attributes so many other upstart challengers haven't had: a natural base of support and a big bank account.So these races aren't ending soon.Of course, history can't be entirely ignored, especially when it comes to Iowa and New Hampshire. No candidate has lost both states and gone on to win a party's nomination since Bill Clinton in 1992. That means Sen. Ted Cruz, who won Iowa, and Mr. Trump, after winning New Hampshire, have an advantage, and Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton are both in the game, if history is any guide.But this is an election cycle that already has shown little to no respect for traditions and precedents, and there's no reason to think traditional order will be restored now. It's better at this point to look at what New Hampshire told us about relative strengths and vulnerabilities in each field.Those who continue to doubt Mr. Trump's strength will need to look long and hard at how even his support was across all kinds of demographic lines in New Hampshire.Exit polls showed he did well with moderates and conservatives, and, for someone whose ideology is mistrusted by many on the Republican right, he did surprisingly well among very conservative voters. He did well among all age groups except, perhaps, the most elderly.He continues to do best among GOP voters with less than a college education, and soars among those who say immigration is their top issue, but what is most striking is the way his support spreads out across the GOP electorate. And he will benefit as long as the non-Trump is divided among multiple challengers.Yet here is the problem for Mr. Trump, and the opening for those four candidates clustered just behind him: Once again in New Hampshire, he didn't do as well among late-deciders than among those who made their minds up long ago.Many late-deciders indicated they broke for Mr. Kasich; the largest bloc of Trump supporters were those who said they made their minds up more than a month ago. So in New Hampshire, as in Iowa, there were signs that the core of Trump voters are very loyal, but also hints that he may not have succeeded in expanding that core as the campaign wore on.A similar dynamic emerges among the Democrats as the New Hampshire dust settles. Exit polls showed little movement among Democratic voters despite the furious campaigning and a dramatic debate between Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton. There was little difference between those who decided early and those who decided late. Mr. Sanders's support, like Mr. Trump's, was solid all along.But the troubling finding for Mr. Sanders--and the encouraging one for Mrs. Clinton--is how much of his support came from New Hampshire voters who called themselves independent. She broke even among mainstream Democrats, and her candidacy hinges on the party's mainstream now stepping up for her.Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Bernie Sanders Wins New Hampshire Democratic Primary, Defeating Hillary Clinton; New Hampshire primary results: Sanders victory boosts his momentum heading into states where he's expected to have weaker showings
article text: MANCHESTER, N.H.--Bernie Sanders soundly defeated Democratic rival Hillary Clinton in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, propelled by independents and young voters wary about the economy and skeptical that the next generation of Americans will live a better life.Once considered a fringe candidate who stood little chance against Mrs. Clinton, the Vermont senator pulled off a sweeping victory. With more than half of New Hampshire's precincts reporting, Mr. Sanders had 59% of the vote compared with 39% for Mrs. Clinton. The Associated Press called the race for Mr. Sanders at 8 p.m. ET.Mr. Sanders defeated Mrs. Clinton among women and swept all age categories except voters over 65, surveys of voters as they exited polling precincts showed. The result underscored the appeal of Mr. Sanders's argument that billionaire families and powerful companies are rigging the economy against the American middle class.At the same time, Mrs. Clinton's defeat suggested that her central message isn't resonating and that she can't count on voters to choose her because of her years of experience as a first lady, senator and secretary of state. Only 27% of Democratic voters said it was important that candidates have the "right experience," exit surveys showed.Mr. Sanders, in his victory speech, told supporters they had sent a message that would echo from Wall Street to Washington. "The government of our great country belongs to all of the people, and not just wealthy campaign contributors and their super PACs," he said.Mr. Sanders, whose win Tuesday was powered by high turnout, predicted that result would be repeated across the nation.Mrs. Clinton, who won the New Hampshire primary in 2008, declared that, "I still love New Hampshire and I always will." And seeking to use the defeat to show she is a fighter, she promised to take the battle to other states and said, "It is not whether you get knocked down that matters, it is whether you get back up."Even before the primary, Mrs. Clinton began retooling her message and said she would reexamine her campaign strategy in hopes of blunting Mr. Sanders's momentum.Mr. Sanders made deep inroads with voters outside the mainstream of Democratic politics. About 40% of those taking part in the Democratic primary were independents, and Mr. Sanders prevailed among those by a commanding 72% to 27%, the exit polls showed. The two candidates split self-identified Democrats evenly, according to the polls.Voters were clearly receptive to Mr. Sanders's populist message. Only 27% described themselves as politically moderate, while 69% called themselves liberal--a dynamic that could change as the race moves to states with more centrist Democratic voters.Asked if the economic system in America favors the wealthy, 90% of Democratic voters said yes, the exit polls showed. And by a margin of nearly 4 to 1, voters said they trusted Mr. Sanders more than Mrs. Clinton to deal with income inequality.Lisa Colavito, a nurse from Concord, said she voted for Mr. Sanders "because we need to get the money out of politics." She added, "He's a grassroots candidate, he stands by his word, and he's been consistent."Ms. Colavito said she wasn't persuaded by the prospect that Mrs. Clinton could be the first female president. "I just want a person that's good for the job," she said.Mrs. Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, had expected her to be in a stronger position at this point in the race, people familiar with their thinking said.One person familiar with internal discussions said that inside the Clinton campaign, there is debate over two points. The first is how hard Mrs. Clinton herself should attack Mr. Sanders. Among those advocating a sharper tone is her husband, who himself went after Mr. Sanders in sharp terms last weekend.The second question is whether she should reshape the way she describes her vision, away from the policy-heavy speeches she is most comfortable with, where she projects herself as an effective pragmatist, and toward a more lofty, visionary message.Mrs. Clinton's aides, at her election-night gathering, said that in coming weeks she would emphasize social-justice issues, going beyond what they see as Mr. Sanders's narrower focus on economic justice.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 news.* New Hampshire Primary -- Live Coverage* New Hampshire Exit Polls Show Anxious Voters Eager for Change* Sanders Out-Raises Clinton in Silicon Valley* Donald Trump Triumphs in New Hampshire Republican Primary* Focus in the Republican Race Will Soon Shift to South Carolina* Hillary Clinton Finds Young Female Voters' Support Elusive* New Hampshire Primary Results Live* New Hampshire Exit Polls by the Numbers* Photos From the Race in New HampshireNext up for the Democrats are caucuses in Nevada, a state with more minority voters than Iowa or New Hampshire. That would give Mrs. Clinton, who has wide support in minority communities, a chance to rebound and demonstrate that she has more broad-based national support than the senator from Vermont.First, though, she needs to come up with a more compelling rationale for her candidacy, many Clinton allies say. While Mrs. Clinton has put forward a mix of policy proposals, her supporters say she has yet to lay out a succinct explanation of why she wants to be president.By contrast, Mr. Sanders has steadily gained ground with a message that is apparently resonating with young voters in particular: Billionaires and powerful corporations are corrupting the political system and making it harder for middle-class Americans to get ahead.Now, campaign aides say, Mrs. Clinton is beginning to give voice to a message that is more positive, personal and even spiritual, talking about concepts like gratitude and the need to move forward in life."The problem is that she needs an overarching message other than 'I'm almost as far left as Bernie but not quite,' " said Douglas Schoen, a former adviser to Mr. Clinton. "She has to answer the basic question of why she wants to be president. So far she hasn't done that."In the run-up to Tuesday's New Hampshire balloting, both Mrs. Clinton and her husband have suggested they are open to a course correction.The ex-president is frustrated by his wife's slow start and unhappy she isn't polling better with female voters, people familiar with his thinking said. In an interview with MSNBC on the eve of the primary, Mrs. Clinton said: "Of course it would be malpractice not to say, 'OK, what worked? What can we do better? What do we have to do new and different that we have to pull out?' "But Mrs. Clinton's experience makes it challenging for her to present a sweeping vision for change, something for which voters have shown an appetite.Mrs. Clinton found herself in a similar position in her first presidential bid in 2008. She finished a disappointing third in Iowa, came back to win New Hampshire and was in a far tougher contest with then-Sen. Barack Obama than she initially envisioned.Many veterans of that race said that even though she ultimately lost, she made adjustments and improved as a candidate during the course of the campaign, making herself more accessible to voters. She drank a shot of whiskey with voters in Indiana and tried her hand at bowling in a TV appearance. Known as a controlled candidate, she teared up in New Hampshire when describing the stresses of the campaign trail.Anita Dunn, who worked on Mr. Obama's 2008 campaign, recalls Mrs. Clinton's improvement after losing a string of contests in March. "She didn't give up," Ms. Dunn said. "Voters responded to her because she was continuing to fight."People love comeback stories, and people want to see if you've been a front-runner and you get knocked down, how you respond," she said. "How she responded was to become a much better candidate. I think that said something about her character."Mrs. Clinton had what her aides saw as a revealing and helpful moment at a CNN forum last week, where she was asked by a rabbi how she balances the need to make a difference in the world and the need for humility.She replied with a nuanced, spiritual and personal explanation of the need to practice what she called "the discipline of gratitude.""So regardless of how hard the days are, how difficult the decisions are, be grateful," she said. "Be grateful for being a human being, being part of the universe. Be grateful for your limitations. Know that you have to reach out to have more people be with you, to support you, to advise you. Listen to your critics, answer the questions."Her aides are keen to find ways to incorporate those types of thoughts into her speeches, and over the course of the past several days, in fits and starts, a new message emerged."You have taught me again and again the only direction that matters in life is forward," she told Democrats at a party dinner Friday night. "We've got to stop bad things from happening, but I believe we've got to start good things happening again in America."Over the weekend, while she occasionally would revert to her standard, policy-heavy pitch, she repeatedly asked audiences to imagine a better world, pointing to all the things she hoped to improve.Still, with Mrs. Clinton having been on the national stage for a quarter century, it isn't clear that voters who have been cool to her will give her a second look.Mike Perry, a resident of Laconia, N.H., said Tuesday he planned to cast his vote for Mr. Sanders. "I like what he's offering," he said. "He wants to make changes, and that's what I want to hear."Mr. Perry said he didn't want to elaborate about his feelings about Mrs. Clinton, but that he strongly believed she wasn't the right candidate for the job. "I don't like her," he said. "I just don't."Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler
