article name: Hillary Clinton Cast in Underdog Role as New Hampshire Votes; With Bernie Sanders expected to win, the margin of victory will be closely watched
article text: CONCORD, N.H.--Eight years after her surprise victory here, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton enters Tuesday's New Hampshire primary as the underdog, as voters head to the polls in the second Democratic presidential nominating contest.Polls show that Mrs. Clinton is facing a stiff challenge from Sen. Bernie Sanders, a self-described democratic socialist from the neighboring state of Vermont. With Mrs. Clinton eking out only the narrowest of wins in last week's Iowa caucuses , both sides are bracing for the possibility of a long, drawn-out primary slog.A CNN/WMUR poll on the eve of the primary shows Mr. Sanders with a huge 26-point lead over Mrs. Clinton. A UMass Lowell/7News poll gives him a 16-point lead in the Granite State, while a polling average of recent surveys by the website Real Clear Politics gives him a narrower 13.3-point lead.With Mr. Sanders expected to win, the margin of victory will be closely watched. If Mrs. Clinton keeps it close, her campaign will chalk it up as a victory of sorts. But a blowout for Mr. Sanders will boost his momentum heading into states where he was expected to have weaker showings.Mrs. Clinton still holds some major advantages in the race, including a substantial lead among nonwhite voters and the institutional support of most of the Democratic Party. Mr. Sanders, by contrast, has shown a capacity for grass roots fundraising and an ability to turnout younger voters and liberals.Despite her expected loss, Mrs. Clinton cheerfully greeted voters at polling places and thanked her campaign staff. She also did some local radio interviews and picked up doughnuts at a local Dunkin' Donuts to give to her volunteers."You know, I just love the way New Hampshire does this. I like the way the people of New Hampshire take it so seriously. They focus in on the issues and they keep coming back," she said at Parker-Varney School in Manchester. "I'm just looking for a great Election Day. As many people who can turn out, express their opinions and, you know, be part of the process."After Mrs. Clinton's razor-thin victory in Iowa last week, both sides are well funded and bracing for a protracted primary campaign that few would have predicted just six months ago. Following New Hampshire, the race moves to friendlier terrain for Mrs. Clinton in the South. But before that, she began testing new messages and laying groundwork for the coming contests.Noting the palpable frustration in the electorate, she told voters at one of her campaign stops, "Anger is not a plan, and venting is not a strategy."Related Coverage* Sanders Leads in New Hampshire's Early Voting Towns, Republicans in Dead Heat* N.H. Primary: Where Each 2016 Candidate Needs to Place to Build Momentum* Clinton Camp Looks Ahead to Tough Caucus Fights* Clinton Takes Campaign Detour to Meet Flint Voters* Critics Pounce on Madeleine Albright's Exhortation to Women to Back ClintonShe spoke in recent days about the travails of being a woman in politics, saying she has a narrower path to walk, and reflected on the challenges of dealing with personal issues while living a very public life. And Mrs. Clinton etched out a hopeful entreaty, asking supporters to envision a better America and asserting that her pragmatic approach would deliver the change they are seeking."For me this election is a turning-point election in so many ways," she said. "I want you to imagine with me what it is we are trying to accomplish together."Mr. Sanders, meanwhile, stuck to the message that has taken him this far: a full-throated denunciation of big money in politics, Wall Street and income inequality. "Is that what America is supposed to be about?" he asked at one of four New Hampshire events Monday."No!" shouted someone from the theater seats."I don't think so," Mr. Sanders agreed.He asked people in the audience to share their student-debt load and their health-care deductibles to provide evidence that his plans for free college tuition and government-funded health care are both urgently needed. He also mocked people who call his ideas "radical."Both campaigns have worked to manage expectations in recent days. The Sanders team predicted a close race, and the Clinton campaign argued that Mr. Sanders held an almost-insurmountable advantage because he hails from a neighboring state.New Hampshire has been welcoming territory for the Clintons in the past. Bill Clinton declared himself the "comeback kid" after finishing second in the 1992 primary. And Mrs. Clinton's come-from-behind-win in 2008 revived her campaign after a third-place finish in Iowa.On Monday, Mrs. Clinton denied reports that she was considering a staff shake-up in the wake of what are likely to be disappointing results in the first two contests."We're going to take stock, but it's going to be the campaign that I've got," she said in an interview with MSNBC.The question is whether Mr. Sanders could parlay a primary win here into momentum elsewhere, as the campaign moves to Nevada and South Carolina, where minority voters make up a much larger share of the electorate. Polling shows Mrs. Clinton well ahead with both African-Americans and Latinos."The more people get to know Bernie, the better they like him," Sanders spokesman Michael Briggs said Monday. "Coming off a virtual tie in Iowa and--knock on wood--a win here, will give us a strong shot. I'm not sure it changes the odds altogether, but it's going to make things different."Mrs. Clinton has begun to position herself for future contests with a quick trip Sunday to Flint, Mich. , to address the water crisis in the majority-African-American city. Her message at times, though, was overshadowed in recent days by controversial statements from some of her strongest supporters.Gloria Steinem, the feminist writer and organizer, and former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright both drew criticism for separate comments that appeared to rebuke young women for supporting Mr. Sanders. At a Clinton event, Ms. Albright said, "there's a special place in hell for women who don't help each other," a line she has used for some time. In an interview with comedian Bill Maher, Ms. Steinem suggested that younger women were gravitating toward Mr. Sanders in an effort to meet men.On Sunday, Mr. Clinton grabbed a share of the spotlight when he delivered an extended and aggressive attack on the Vermont senator. The former president cast Mr. Sanders as a hypocrite and a dishonest politician and criticized the senator's supporters for launching profane and sexist attacks on Mrs. Clinton and her backers.By Monday, the former president's public remarks had been toned down, with only a brief critique of Mr. Sanders's assertion that the former secretary of state is part of "the establishment.""I have to be careful of what I say," Mr. Clinton said in Manchester.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com , Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler, Byron Tau and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: The Myths of Black Lives Matter; The movement has won over Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. But what if its claims are fiction?
article text: A television ad for Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign now airing in South Carolina shows the candidate declaring that "too many encounters with law enforcement end tragically." She later adds: "We have to face up to the hard truth of injustice and systemic racism."Her Democratic presidential rival, Bernie Sanders, met with the Rev. Al Sharpton on Wednesday. Mr. Sanders then tweeted that "As President, let me be very clear that no one will fight harder to end racism and reform our broken criminal justice system than I will." And he appeared on the TV talk show "The View" saying, "It is not acceptable to see unarmed people being shot by police officers."Apparently the Black Lives Matter movement has convinced Democrats and progressives that there is an epidemic of racist white police officers killing young black men. Such rhetoric is going to heat up as Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders court minority voters before the Feb. 27 South Carolina primary.But what if the Black Lives Matter movement is based on fiction? Not just the fictional account of the 2014 police shooting of Michael Brown in Ferguson, Mo., but the utter misrepresentation of police shootings generally.To judge from Black Lives Matter protesters and their media and political allies, you would think that killer cops pose the biggest threat to young black men today. But this perception, like almost everything else that many people think they know about fatal police shootings, is wrong.The Washington Post has been gathering data on fatal police shootings over the past year and a half to correct acknowledged deficiencies in federal tallies. The emerging data should open many eyes.For starters, fatal police shootings make up a much larger proportion of white and Hispanic homicide deaths than black homicide deaths. According to the Post database, in 2015 officers killed 662 whites and Hispanics, and 258 blacks. (The overwhelming majority of all those police-shooting victims were attacking the officer, often with a gun.) Using the 2014 homicide numbers as an approximation of 2015's, those 662 white and Hispanic victims of police shootings would make up 12% of all white and Hispanic homicide deaths. That is three times the proportion of black deaths that result from police shootings.The lower proportion of black deaths due to police shootings can be attributed to the lamentable black-on-black homicide rate. There were 6,095 black homicide deaths in 2014--the most recent year for which such data are available--compared with 5,397 homicide deaths for whites and Hispanics combined. Almost all of those black homicide victims had black killers.Police officers--of all races--are also disproportionately endangered by black assailants. Over the past decade, according to FBI data, 40% of cop killers have been black. Officers are killed by blacks at a rate 2.5 times higher than the rate at which blacks are killed by police.Some may find evidence of police bias in the fact that blacks make up 26% of the police-shooting victims, compared with their 13% representation in the national population. But as residents of poor black neighborhoods know too well, violent crimes are disproportionately committed by blacks. According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, blacks were charged with 62% of all robberies, 57% of murders and 45% of assaults in the 75 largest U.S. counties in 2009, though they made up roughly 15% of the population there.Such a concentration of criminal violence in minority communities means that officers will be disproportionately confronting armed and often resisting suspects in those communities, raising officers' own risk of using lethal force.The Black Lives Matter movement claims that white officers are especially prone to shooting innocent blacks due to racial bias, but this too is a myth. A March 2015 Justice Department report on the Philadelphia Police Department found that black and Hispanic officers were much more likely than white officers to shoot blacks based on "threat misperception"--that is, the mistaken belief that a civilian is armed.A 2015 study by University of Pennsylvania criminologist Greg Ridgeway, formerly acting director of the National Institute of Justice, found that, at a crime scene where gunfire is involved, black officers in the New York City Police Department were 3.3 times more likely to discharge their weapons than other officers at the scene.The Black Lives Matter movement has been stunningly successful in changing the subject from the realities of violent crime. The world knows the name of Michael Brown but not Tyshawn Lee, a 9-year-old black child lured into an alley and killed by gang members in Chicago last fall. Tyshawn was one of dozens of black children gunned down in America last year. The Baltimore Sun reported on Jan. 1: "Blood was shed in Baltimore at an unprecedented pace in 2015, with mostly young, black men shot to death in a near-daily crush of violence."Those were black lives that mattered, and it is a scandal that outrage is heaped less on the dysfunctional culture that produces so many victims than on the police officers who try to protect them.Ms. Mac Donald is the Thomas W. Smith fellow at the Manhattan Institute and author of "The War on Cops," forthcoming in July from Encounter Books.Credit: By Heather Mac Donald

article name: How Sanders Exposed Clinton; Hillary was 'tough' and 'masterful'--until Bernie whispered what was obvious.
article text: Democrats awoke Wednesday with a thought usually reserved for Republicans: Hillary Clinton is a disaster. The marvel is that she fooled them for so long.Picture Bernie Sanders as a small child in the court of Empress Clinton, and you have a modern twist on Hans Christian Andersen. The adoring Democratic townspeople oohed and aahed over their "tough" and "experienced" and "masterful" leader, the anointed heir to the Clinton throne. Then Bernie murmured what was obvious, and the crowd looked again.What they saw in New Hampshire was a dour, 68-year-old woman, shouting at her audience in her best impression of emotion. They saw a gaunt former president, rambling to half-empty forums, grumping about his wife's political opponent. They saw the candidate's surrogates try to snag the votes of young women by threatening them with eternal damnation. They saw a campaign in disarray, dragging carload upon carload of ethical baggage. They saw that the empress has no (or very few) clothes.No one knows whether Bernie Sanders can pull off a nomination. But what everyone does know now is that Hillary has (and is) a problem either way. Let's dispense with some spin: Bernie never had a lock on the Granite State. New Hampshire had stepped up for the Clintons twice before, in 1992 and 2008. This year Hillary went into the contest with endorsements, a huge operation and plenty of money.What she didn't have was the interest of voters. They'd had their eyes opened, and they chose to use their primary to highlight Mrs. Clinton's many and obvious political weaknesses. She may still be the favorite to hold her party's banner, but the mantle of inevitability has been stripped away.New Hampshire exposed again what a wooden candidate Hillary is. Mr. Sanders strolls on stage and makes his audience sing and cheer. Mrs. Clinton's events begin with propaganda videos about her past, followed by a tutorial on why she deserves this. They are heavy, and droning.She cannot do uplifting. She had the same likability problem in her 2000 race for the Senate, when she had to spend a fortune to beat an unknown Republican in liberal New York. The same problem popped up in 2008, against Barack Obama. Why anyone thought she would improve on a third go is a mystery.New Hampshire also uncovered the mismanagement that always attends the Clintons. Hillary wakes up every day with a new campaign. She ignores Mr. Sanders. Then she runs left. Then she attacks him. Then she softens. Her staff has endless debates, which always end up leaked to the press, about whether she needs to appear "stronger," or more "human," or "sharper," or "softer," or more "pragmatic," or more "lofty."She has a habit of unceremoniously firing campaign teams. And this scattershot approach comes from a woman who has been plotting to be president for at least a decade? All this shifting may be another reason why the public sees her as "untrustworthy."To that point, New Hampshire proved that concerns about Mrs. Clinton's ethics aren't merely a right-wing talking point. They've permeated the electorate. Some stunning numbers: Among the one-third of Democratic primary voters who said "honesty" was the top quality they wanted in a nominee, Mr. Sanders won 91% . Among the quarter who said they focused on a candidate who "cares about people like me," Mr. Sanders won 82%.Finally, New Hampshire exposed how out of touch the Clinton machine is with the modern liberal movement. Mrs. Clinton based her campaign on the tropes of a fading Democratic establishment. She figured that women would vote for her simply because she had the right anatomy. She figured that college grads and wealthier Democrats would vote for her because she had more pragmatic policies. She figured that the bulk of voters still viewed the Clinton operation as a sure ticket to the White House.In fairness, she won her age group--those 65 or older, who grew up with the Clintons. But she lost everyone else: women, men, college grads, blue-collar workers. She lost every income level except those making more than $200,000. She lost liberals. And moderates.What makes Mrs. Clinton's miscalculation notable is that the party's shift was on full, neon view before she even entered the race. It was walking around in the form of Elizabeth Warren. The worry for Mrs. Clinton is that she might be unable to heal the rifts. Barack Obama's soaring rhetoric was able to reunite his party in 2008. Hillary doesn't have his skills.Responsibility for her crushing New Hampshire defeat can't be placed on Mrs. Clinton alone. Her party leadership is in it with her. Since 2008 the Clinton juggernaut has projected Hillary as the party's only option, and Democrats bought it. They closed their eyes to her flaws and scandals, ignored the shifting progressive winds, pushed potential rivals aside, and raved about the empress's lovely clothes. Then Bernie started whispering.Write to kim@wsj.com.Credit: By Kimberley A. Strassel

article name: Hillary and Bernie vs. the Obama Economy; Plus Bloomberg's opportunity to start a third party and a Supreme rebuke to the White House.
article text: New Hampshire exit polls show a remarkable bipartisan consensus : Republican and Democratic voters agree that the Obama economy is lousy . A Journal editorial notes that while the President has been singing the praises of the tepid recovery, a full 86% of Granite State voters are either somewhat or very worried about the direction of the nation's economy. The editorial board adds that "the most persuasive repudiation of Mr. Obama's economic record is coming from Democrats.Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton are both campaigning against the economic status quo , deploring the lack of income growth, rising income inequality and unaffordable health care, among other problems."Morning Editorial ReportClick here to receive WSJ Opinion headlines and commentary via email.Daniel Henninger writes that to stop Donald Trump, his GOP opponents "will have to go after him on substance." Mr. Henninger adds , "At the core of the Trump campaign is one policy idea: imposing a 45% tariff on goods imported from China . In his shouted, red-faced victory speech Tuesday, he extended the trade offensive to Japan and Mexico ." Our columnist notes that China, Mexico and Japan "are the U.S's Nos. 1, 3 and 4 trading partners (Canada is No. 2). They are 35% of the U.S.'s trade activity with the world ."Karl Rove adds that Mr. Trump's competitors must bring up "the front-runner's greatest weakness: Americans have never elected a serial bankrupt . Populist South Carolinians may not understand why, when Mr. Trump's companies went under, such a wealthy man didn't dip into his fortune to do right by the people who were hurt. There is also Mr. Trump's claim to be a great businessman: His casinos never reported a profit ." ...Separately, a Journal editorial notes Mr. Trump's disturbing record on eminent domain authority and says that most of the Keystone XL pipeline could be built without it.Morton Kondracke sees an opening for billionaire Michael Bloomberg to create a third major political party . "Presidential election exit polls consistently show that more than 40% of voters say they are moderate (more than 30% self-identify as conservative, more than 20% as liberal). The Gallup poll shows that a record 43% say they are independent (30% identify as Democrat, 26% as Republican)," notes Mr. Kondracke."When President Obama hasn't had his way on climate, immigration and so much else, he's rewritten the law and dared critics to stop him. Well, the Supreme Court has accepted his invitation with an extraordinary rebuke. On Tuesday the High Court put a legal stay on the Administration's rules to control carbon emissions in the states," notes a Journal editorial . "Mr. Obama's six years of governance-through-executive-order make his a fragile legacy. Unilateral gambits can be reversed by the next President, and the other branches of government are finally reasserting their constitutional powers ." ...Journal contributors David Rivkin and Andrew Grossman write that "President Obama's Clean Power Plan is dead and will not be resurrected ."Also in our pages today, David Malpass tells investors not to blame recent market losses on the Fed 's modest December rate hike. Mr. Malpass argues the real problem is that despite the low interest rates of this era, money is still scarce for small commercial borrowers. "In the past five years, total U.S. credit grew only 20%, compared with at least a 40% increase in most previous expansions. To make matters worse, 80% of the increase in credit went to government and corporate bonds , leaving only 20% for the rest of the economy and only a fraction of that to the small and new businesses that are so critical for growth," says Mr. Malpass .Credit: By James Freeman

article name: Bloomberg May See Opening in New Hampshire Primary Results; Victories by Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump could boost former NYC mayor's candidacy
article text: Far from the New Hampshire primary, aides to former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg eyed the solid victories Tuesday by Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump as potential boosts to a Bloomberg candidacy .The results, Bloomberg advisers said, were a fresh sign he may have an opening, as Democrats and Republicans embraced candidates the aides said were unlikely to resonate with voters in a general election.Steve Schmidt, a Republican strategist who served as a senior adviser to Sen. John McCain during his 2008 campaign, said the field of candidates was weak and that the former mayor could win."Any combination of them in a general election would open a path for an independent candidate," said Mr. Schmidt, who isn't advising Mr. Bloomberg. "There's a big opening in the middle of the electorate, and Bloomberg is on point in that space."Bloomberg aides say they are looking far more closely at the results of Super Tuesday, on March 1, when more states will vote in the primaries and it will be easier to gauge the strength of Hillary Clinton and others in the race.Related* Michael Bloomberg Mulling Run for President as Independent* Michael Bloomberg Acknowledges He Is Weighing Presidential BidBut the biggest hurdle to a Bloomberg bid may not hinge on the shifting fortunes of the other candidates, but on the former mayor's political brand. Mr. Bloomberg is a fiscally conservative technocrat with Wall Street roots, a liberal on many social issues, and a gun-control advocate. He identified as a Democrat but ran for mayor in 2001 as a Republican, and later as an independent."He would have zero chance here," said Matt Borges, the chairman of the Republican Party in Ohio, a swing state. Mr. Borges said he believed Mr. Bloomberg's positions on issues like gun control would be insurmountable.Other obstacles loom. Some conservative voters, particularly in the South, have criticized him for his positions on guns and for a measure in New York City, later turned aside by a court, to curb the sale of large, sugary drinks.Mr. Bloomberg would also likely face skepticism among Democrats, for his defense of big corporations and his record on race and policing. A police tactic he embraced known as "stop-and-frisk" was seen as unfairly targeting minorities and its use by the city was ruled unconstitutional in 2013 by a federal judge.Bloomberg aides said those handicaps could be overcome. One aide broke down Mr. Bloomberg's appeal this way: he is a political outsider unbeholden to party machinery; he has had private-sector success running Bloomberg LP, his data and media company; and he is a three-term mayor credited with revitalizing the nation's most populous city and driving down crime."There is a degree of polarization, division and I daresay lack of focus on the major issues facing the country that is exemplified by the entire primary process to date. Including but not limited to New Hampshire," said Douglas E. Schoen, a longtime Bloomberg adviser who has conducted polls for the ex-mayor recently.Mr. Bloomberg has other potential advantages. He is worth more than $30 billion and has signaled he is ready to spend. One of his top political aides, Howard Wolfson, served as communications director for Mrs. Clinton's 2008 campaign. He has a stable of loyal aides ready to jump in.The campaign trail could be awkward for Mr. Bloomberg, who frequently grew irritated with the New York City press corps for asking personal questions about his life, including his weekend travels to his vacation homes. He isn't a natural campaigner, though his aides said he grew increasingly easy on the trail as the years passed. "He was used to business groups, marketing professionals--the political media was a very different kind of thing," said Bill Cunningham, a former aide.A third-party candidate has never succeeded in winning the presidency, though they have shaped contests, Ralph Nader in 2000 being the most recent example. Entering the race late, Mr. Bloomberg would face challenges getting on ballots and building campaign machinery in each state.James McCann, a political- science professor at Purdue University who studies third-party bids, said Mr. Bloomberg faces an uphill battle. "It still is difficult to come in from out of the blue and get the traction you need, even when things are really seemingly divisive and there's a great deal of disenchantment, even when you're a billionaire," he said.Write to Mara Gay at mara.gay@wsj.comCredit: By Mara Gay and Josh Dawsey

article name: Next Task for Clinton, Sanders: Securing the Minority Vote; Is Bernie Sanders's appeal broad enough, or will Hillary Clinton prevail with the help of blacks, hispanics?
article text: Democrats headed south and west after Sen. Bernie Sanders's resounding New Hampshire victory over Hillary Clinton, facing the twin questions of whether his appeal is broad enough to replicate his performance elsewhere--and whether her support is strong enough to reverse the tide.Lying at the crossroads of those two questions are the minority voters who have transformed the Democratic Party in the past few decades and hold the promise of sustained success in the future.Mr. Sanders's first act after his 22-point victory in predominantly white New Hampshire was to travel to Harlem in New York on Wednesday and have breakfast with high-profile civil-rights leader Rev. Al Sharpton.In an interview, Rev. Sharpton said that by coming to Harlem after "such a big victory," Mr. Sanders "wanted to send a signal" to the party's minority voters. "She has deeper ties [to the black community] and longstanding friends," Mr. Sharpton said of Mrs. Clinton, "but that doesn't mean he can't win voters."Meanwhile, the Clinton campaign arranged a conference call Wednesday with prominent African-American figures who support the former secretary of state. They cast Mr. Sanders as an arriviste who has ignored issues important to African-Americans."It's good to have new friends--I would prefer to have true friends," said Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D., N.Y.), who plans to go to South Carolina to campaign for Mrs. Clinton.Mrs. Clinton now is calling on the Clinton network of African-American supporters, looking to shore up the "firewall" her campaign says it has built in coming contests in South Carolina and other Southern states with large minority populations. The campaign is also tapping into her Hispanic network to sway Nevada voters.On primary night, the Clinton campaign understood that a defeat was coming in the Granite State. But the breadth of the loss left some of her supporters rattled and former President Bill Clinton angry, according to two people familiar with his thinking.Mr. Sanders beat her among women voters and won every age category save for voters over 65. He bested Mrs. Clinton not only among independents who participated in the primary--and by a lopsided margin--but topped her among Democratic Party members, 52% to 48%, exit polls showed.That could prove important, as the next primaries and caucuses will have far larger shares of Democrats and smaller shares of independents, who are barred entirely from party primaries in some states. Some 58% of voters in the New Hampshire primary were Democrats. By contrast, Democrats accounted for 81% of Nevada caucus-goers and 73% of South Carolina primary voters during the last competitive contests, in 2008.But Mr. Sanders's strength within the party's membership remains an open question. Mrs. Clinton carried Democratic Party members by 17 points in her narrow victory in Iowa's caucuses last week. And the Democrats in contests to come won't look like those in New Hampshire. Where 93% of New Hampshire's Democratic primary voters were white, only 43% of South Carolina primary voters and 65% of Nevada caucus-goers in 2008 were white.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 news.* New Hampshire Exit Polls Show Anxious Voters Eager for Change* Sanders Out-Raises Clinton in Silicon Valley* Donald Trump Triumphs in New Hampshire Republican Primary* Focus in the Republican Race Will Soon Shift to South Carolina* Hillary Clinton Finds Young Female Voters' Support Elusive* New Hampshire Exit Polls by the Numbers* Photos From the Race in New HampshireThe New Hampshire primary didn't test one of the most important features of the coming contests--whether Mrs. Clinton is retaining the substantial advantages she has shown among African-American and Hispanic voters in opinion polls. She led Mr. Sanders by 42 percentage points among nonwhite voters--69% to 27%--in Wall Street Journal/NBC News polling in early January.Members of the Congressional Black Caucus are planning to fan out in South Carolina in advance of the state's primary on Feb. 27, talking up Mrs. Clinton's credentials in a state where African-Americans account for more than half of the Democratic electorate."I'm going to preach and teach, tell people to get out and vote for Hillary," said Rep. John Lewis (D., Ga.), who was beaten by state troopers in Selma, Ala., in 1965 during a voting-rights protest.Rep. Gregory Meeks (D., N.Y.), the chairman of the black caucus's political-action committee, said that the group's board last week overwhelmingly voted to endorse Mrs. Clinton. Their formal announcement is expected on Thursday.Brian Fallon, a Clinton campaign spokesman, noted that the contests on March 1 include Texas, Alabama and Georgia--states with substantial "communities of color."But Mr. Sanders is ceding no ground as his campaign has gained momentum. He won the endorsement of former NAACP President Ben Jealous, and he is about to roll out an ad that shows him marching with Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1963 March on Washington, according to former South Carolina Democratic Party Chairman Richard Harpootlian."His bona fides are beyond question on civil rights, so older African-American voters as they see the TV commercial or radio ad will understand he's not some newcomer to their cause," Mr. Harpootlian said.The tug of war between the Clinton and Sanders camps is putting pressure on one of South Carolina's most prominent officials to come forward with an endorsement.Rep. Jim Clyburn, the only Democrat in South Carolina's delegation and a civil-rights leader with big sway in the state, has stayed neutral, but he may be coming off the fence soon, people familiar with the matter said."I'm feeling it," said Mr. Clyburn, declining to say whom he might endorse. "I have a wife and three daughters" and "they are telling me that I need to take a stand."Valerie Bauerlein contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Sanders Meets Sharpton for Breakfast in Harlem; Civil-rights leader hasn't endorsed in the presidential race
article text: The morning after Bernie Sanders's sweeping victory in the New Hampshire presidential primary , the Vermont senator took his momentum to a Harlem landmark to have tea with the Rev. Al Sharpton.Mr. Sanders arrived at the famed Sylvia's restaurant around 9:50 a.m. Tuesday and waved to a crowd chanting his name. Mr. Sharpton said the breakfast lasted 20 minutes and that the senator's visit sent the right message to the black community.Mr. Sharpton said he asked Mr. Sanders about the water crisis in Flint, Mich. , affirmative action and police misconduct."My concern is that in January of next year, for the first time in American history, a black family will be moving out of the White House," Mr. Sharpton said. "I do not want black concerns to be moved out with them."He said he hadn't decided on an endorsement in the 2016 race but he was meeting with Hillary Clinton next Thursday."Senator Sanders coming here this morning further makes it clear that we will not be ignored," Mr. Sharpton said. "Our votes must be earned."More in Politics* Chris Christie Is Expected to Suspend Campaign* Bloomberg May See Opening in New Hampshire Primary ResultsHe said Mr. Sanders was also meeting with Kirsten John Foy, Northeast regional director of National Action Network, a civil-rights organization founded by Mr. Sharpton.Also on hand was former head of the NAACP, Ben Jealous, and State Sen. Bill Perkins, a Manhattan Democrat. Both have endorsed Mr. Sanders."Harlem represents the black community and other communities of color in general but he's going to make sure that he's in all those communities so everybody gets to have the Bern," Mr. Perkins said.Tren'ness Woods-Black, the director of communications for Sylvia's (and granddaughter of Sylvia), said the restaurant remained open to the public during the senator's visit."We wanted to allow everyone to be able to interact and get a just up-close and personal look at who's actually running," said Ms. Woods-Black.Some, however, were disappointed Mr. Sanders didn't do more to interact with the public. After a quick wave to the crowd, the senator departed in his car after the breakfast. Yo Akalu, a 27-year-old CUNY student, didn't believe the visit was genuine."If he really wants our votes he really needs to come into these projects, he really needs to go into these schools, he really needs to speak to these families," Ms. Akalu said. "Him coming out here to Harlem, coming straight to Sylvia's...what is that?"Charles Mannings, a resident of Harlem for 20 years, said he thought the short visit was "inspiring." The 70-year-old retired chef said politicians tended to ignore Harlem."I'm glad to see in this particular instance that is not the case," Mr. Mannings said. "Maybe it's indicative of better things to come."Write to Zolan Kanno-Youngs at Zolan.Kanno-Youngs@wsj.comCredit: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

article name: Explaining Bernie's 'Socialism'; He perfects the strategy of denying the funding dilemma of the welfare state.
article text: In the 1940s, many Western societies began adopting single-payer health systems as a way to expand access to the relatively few things medical care at the time could do for patients.This was an agenda that, for obvious reason, could appeal to both consumers and providers of health care.We live in a different time. If the U.S. were to embark on a single-payer system today, as Bernie Sanders proposes, it would not be doing so to expand access--though that slogan would still be used--but for a very different reason: to deny and limit care in order to control spending.This agenda would be popular with neither patients nor providers, and therefore would be dead in the water--as liberal authorities, from the New York Times's Paul Krugman to Henry J. Aaron of the Brookings Institution, have suddenly discovered an urgency to point out to Democratic voters infatuated with Bernie Sanders.Mr. Sanders knows it too. His socialism is farcical in a country that can't afford the entitlements it already has.The one zinger that has found its mark during the current campaign has been Chelsea Clinton's claim that his plan endangers Medicare, which Mr. Sanders now brings up constantly in order to refute it. Mr. Sanders knows that seniors aren't stupid. They vote, and if they took his plan seriously, they would turn out in droves to protect Medicare from being raided by other age groups.Take another farcical element of Mr. Sanders's farcical socialism. He tweaks Hillary over $675,000 in speaking fees from Goldman Sachs. Unmentioned by the scourge of big money is Bill Clinton's far more egregious buckraking.By the estimate of IBT Media, Mr. Clinton collected between $54 million and $141 million from governments and arms manufacturers who had arms-deal approvals pending before his wife's State Department. His own disclosures indicate at least $20 million in speaking fees from banks and businesses since his wife began publicly eyeing the presidency.A Washington Post investigation finds a "substantial overlap between the Clinton political machinery and the [charitable] foundation" and that "many of the foundation's biggest donors are foreigners who are legally barred from giving to U.S. political candidates."Yet all this goes unremarked by Mr. Sanders, that ferocious denouncer of monied corruption. Why? For the same reason that Bill Clinton's reckless influence-peddling goes uniformly uncriticized inside the Democratic Party. Because that's the price of Mr. Clinton forgetting what a Clinton presidency was all about.He enacted welfare reform. He spoke enthusiastically of fully funded personal Social Security accounts. He speculated about the possibility of converting Medicare into a means-tested program of private insurance vouchers.This Bill Clinton you don't hear from anymore. One could easily forget he's not only the last, but the most prominent, of the once-numerous Blue Dog Democrats, who did not make a profession, as their party does now, of ignoring the long-term funding dilemma of the U.S. retirement programs.Mr. Sanders, far from being a radical departure, is merely a perfection of what Democrats have offered since the Clinton era, namely denial.Ignore the problem. If forced to acknowledge it, insist there's no problem because the rich will pay. In the meantime, savage every reform proposal as an attack on "unmet needs." Collect the political rents from serving as defender of every spending interest in our overcommitted republic.When pressed, even Bernie admits that some additional, unspecified "political revolution" would be necessary before his socialist plans became actionable in America. Meanwhile, what would a President Bernie do in office? You already have the answer.With the latest report of the Social Security and Medicare Trustees, the programs' unfunded liabilities, in present value terms, are $60 trillion. The worker-to-retiree ratio, which was 5.0 when Medicare was created in the mid-1960s, today is 2.5, and headed for less than 2.0 after 2030. Left out of this calculation, of course, is the growing rank of non-retired entitlement recipients whom taxpayers must also support.You don't hear about any of this from Democrats. One reason is that Bill Clinton, the most active, ubiquitous of our ex-presidents, has utterly dropped the subject in return for his party's indulgence of his fundraising that knows no limits, and no concern about propriety or conflicts of interest.You don't hear much about it from Republicans either. The Bill Clinton years may leave much to be criticized, but when both parties acknowledged a reality, there was at least a chance of doing something about it. That ended in 2000, when fully one-fifth of Al Gore's convention delegates were public-sector union representatives, placed there to quash any mention of entitlement reform in the Democratic platform.And that suits a lot of Democrats just fine, including Bernie, who, for all his exotic pretenses, is just another machine Democrat.Credit: By Holman W. Jenkins, Jr.

article name: Hillary Clinton's Wall Street Dilemma; Pushed by rival Bernie Sanders, Democratic front-runner struggles to justify money from the financial industry
article text: In the battle for the Democratic nomination, Sen. Bernie Sanders is focused on turning Hillary Clinton's support from the financial industry, one of her longtime political assets, into a weapon against her.Mr. Sanders has targeted Mrs. Clinton's close relationship with Wall Street, saying her history of taking money from big banks and hedge funds shows she isn't a progressive. The charge has helped Mr. Sanders gain traction with a Democratic electorate uneasy with the power of wealthy firms.Mrs. Clinton, who has struggled to justify the money she has received from Goldman Sachs Group, Inc., and other Wall Street firms over the years, said Wednesday during a televised CNN candidate forum in New Hampshire that she accepted fees of more than $200,000 per speech because "that's what they offered."Mr. Sanders said at the event, "I do not know any progressive who has a super PAC and takes $15 million from Wall Street."The two of them continued to trade barbs at a Democratic debate Thursday night . "You will not find that I ever changed a view or a vote because of any donation I ever received," Mrs. Clinton said in defending her ties to Wall Street. She accused Mr. Sanders of an "artful smear."Other prominent Democrats, including President Barack Obama in 2008, have combined a friendly relationship with the financial world with attacks on big-moneyed interests.But no Democrat or Republican running for president this year has received as much money from Wall Street executives for their campaigns as Mrs. Clinton has. Wall Street is the top donor to her 2016 presidential campaign and to a super PAC run by Mrs. Clinton's allies to support her candidacy. Only the super PAC supporting Republican Jeb Bush has raised more on Wall Street.More broadly, since Mrs. Clinton and former President Bill Clinton entered national politics in the early 1990s, Wall Street has contributed more than $100 million to their political campaigns, charitable foundation and personal finances, according to a review by The Wall Street Journal.Financial-services firms accounted for about 12% of the total amount raised by the Clintons during their more than two decades in politics.Some Wall Street money has helped the couple's personal finances. Goldman Sachs, J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. and other Wall Street firms have paid the Clintons more than $20 million in speaking fees over the years.Many on Wall Street say they favor Mrs. Clinton because they agree with her on a range of topics--and because they believe she will take their views into account if she pursues stepped-up regulations on financial services firms, according to interviews with more than two dozen executives.Concerns over the nomination of either Texas Sen. Ted Cruz or New York businessman Donald Trump have prompted some Republicans on Wall Street to consider Mrs. Clinton as the better alternative. Many, however, say they are leaning toward Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, who appeals to business-oriented Republicans.Clinton aides dismiss talk that Mrs. Clinton is too cozy with the financial industry. "She went to Wall Street before the crash and warned them that what they were doing could hurt the economy and called them out on it," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook told reporters Thursday. "She has introduced the strongest plan in this race...It actually deals with the swaps and derivatives that led to this crash."Mrs. Clinton's plan seeks to build on the 2010 Dodd-Frank law to strengthen oversight of the banking sector and unregulated "shadow banking" activities that played a significant role in the 2008 financial crisis. She has also proposed a tax on certain types of high-frequency trading--automated stock trading by computers that has been profitable but can cause excessive volatility--and has pitched a so-called risk fee on the biggest financial firms.Still, there is a general feeling that "she's not going to come after Wall Street," said a Clinton super PAC donor who has spoken to dozens of potential supporters.The widespread view on Wall Street, say executives, is that Mrs. Clinton, driven by pragmatic considerations, doesn't see financial firms as inherently bad and is willing to work on solutions.Mrs. Clinton's supporters say she is able to push for higher middle-class incomes without demonizing the wealthy."Even for a lot of people on Wall Street, the concept of equality resonates," said David Lichtenstein, a real estate investor who hosted a fundraiser last month for Mrs. Clinton.Mrs. Clinton's supporters say her campaign talk about reining in banks, curbing excessive risk-taking and punishing individuals for financial wrongdoing reflects a negative voter mood."She moved to the left because she needed some political cover in her fight against Sanders," said Greg Valliere, chief global strategist at asset manager Horizon Investments. "Her plan may be aggressive, but her ties to Wall Street make it unlikely that this proposal of hers will be a top priority...it's the cynical view."Clinton advisers said she would closely police Wall Street as president."People on Wall Street have been supporting her not because they think she's going to roll over on Wall Street, but because they agree with her on other issues outside of Wall Street," said Thomas Nides, a former deputy secretary of State under Mrs. Clinton and now vice chairman of Morgan Stanley.While her husband's administration was stocked with Wall Street veterans, the Clintons' connections with the finance community grew in 1999, when they bought a home in Chappaqua, an affluent suburb of New York City.At the time, Mrs. Clinton and her husband were linked with a centrist, pro-business wing of the Democratic Party that didn't seek to alienate Wall Street. Supporters described them as a celebrity couple, charming New York's financial community and blending into summers in the Hamptons, the Long Island community of beach towns where many rich New Yorkers keep homes."He was the former president and she was the former first lady," Mr. Nides said. "She was already a well-known commodity, and people wanted to be with her."As the couple expanded their Wall Street network, hedge-fund managers, bankers and wealthy investors wrote checks to the Clinton Foundation philanthropy and agreed to host fundraisers in their homes for Mrs. Clinton's budding political career. Many were pleasantly surprised to receive handwritten thank-you notes, flowers or phone calls from the couple.Now, engaged in a presidential primary, Mrs. Clinton is finding these relationships, so helpful in the past, a point of vulnerability.In the run-up to Tuesday's New Hampshire primary, Mr. Sanders has sharpened his attacks on Mrs. Clinton's ties to Wall Street. At campaign stops around the state, he paints her as an establishment figure incapable of overhauling the political system to benefit everyday American families.Campaign finance reports made public this week show Mrs. Clinton leads all others in financial support from Wall Street. Through the end of 2015, Wall Street had donated $2.9 million to Mrs. Clinton's election campaign and $55,226 to the campaign of Mr. Sanders.Among Republicans, Wall Street donors have contributed a total of about $2 million to Messrs. Cruz, Rubio and Trump.A super PAC run by Mrs. Clinton's supporters has collected an additional $14.3 million from Wall Street, a total surpassed only by the super PAC set up to back Mr. Bush, the former Florida governor. Mr. Sanders doesn't have a major super PAC supporting his campaign; a super PAC run by a nurses union has spent nearly $1 million on his behalf.Overall, Wall Street accounted for about a third of the funds the Clinton super PAC raised last year. Billionaire investor George Soros gave the pro-Clinton super PAC Priorities USA Action, $6 million in December, bringing his total donations to the group to $7 million.The newly released campaign finance filings show Mrs. Clinton raised the most money among the presidential candidates from just about every industry tracked by the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics.In all, donations from the financial-services sector make up a large and growing share of the amount of money raised in U.S. elections. Through the end of 2015, money from financial services firms made up roughly 40% of the $1 billion donated so far into the 2016 election, compared with less than 20% of the total in 2012 and 5% in 2008.Rebecca Ballhaus, Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.Write to Anupreeta Das at anupreeta.das@wsj.com and Brody Mullins at brody.mullins@wsj.comCredit: By Anupreeta Das and Brody Mullins

article name: Hillary Clinton's Wall Street Talks Were Highly Paid, Friendly; Democratic presidential candidate has been criticized by rival Bernie Sanders for her ties to financial sector
article text: In the two years between resigning as secretary of state and launching her presidential campaign, Hillary Clinton personally received $4.1 million in fees from financial institutions for closed-door talks that attendees described as friendly and light.Today, the speeches have become an issue in her campaign. Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, her rival in the Democratic primary, has repeatedly attacked her ties to Wall Street, including her large speech fees.Most of Mrs. Clinton's comments steered clear of anything that could become controversial in her fight for the Democratic nomination, say people who attended some of these events or were briefed on them. She didn't often talk about the financial crisis, but when she did, she almost always struck an amicable tone, according to these people.In some cases, she thanked the audience for what they had done for the country, the people said. One attendee said the warmth with which Mrs. Clinton greeted guests bordered on "gushy."In a discussion with Goldman Sachs Group Inc. executives and some of its asset-management clients in October 2013, she spoke sympathetically about the financial industry, according to an attendee. Asked about the poisoned national mood toward Wall Street, Mrs. Clinton didn't single out bankers or any other group for causing the 2008 financial crisis. Instead, she effectively said, "We're all in this together, we've got to find our way out of it together," according to the attendee.Mrs. Clinton has said she would look into releasing the contents of her talks, many of which were transcribed by a stenographer that she requested be present. Her team is reviewing transcripts from dozens of speeches to assess potential pitfalls of releasing them to the public, people close to Mrs. Clinton said.Some in the Clinton camp are concerned that comments not just about Wall Street, but also on the health-care law and foreign leaders could be taken out of context in an election season, they added.A campaign spokesman declined to comment on whether transcripts would be released.Mr. Sanders, in his attacks on Mrs. Clinton, has questioned why firms such as Goldman paid her $225,000 a speech. When asked at a CNN event last week to explain why she was paid these sums, Mrs. Clinton said, "I don't know, that's what they offered."The fees and other details were negotiated on behalf of Mrs. Clinton by the Harry Walker Agency, a speakers' bureau that represented her. The agency didn't respond to a request for comment. Mrs. Clinton's profile page was missing from its website as of last week.Beginning in early 2013, after leaving the State Department, Mrs. Clinton embarked on a two-year speaking career, making $21.7 million from about 100 speeches to universities, economic clubs, trade groups, investment banks, private-equity firms and several Canadian entities.About one in five dollars that Mrs. Clinton collected while giving speeches from February 2013 to April 2015 came from banks and financial institutions.She spoke at three client conferences hosted by Goldman Sachs; twice at Deutsche Bank AG; once each at events organized by Morgan Stanley, Bank of America Corp. and UBS; and also at gatherings hosted by private-equity firms KKR & Co., Apollo Management Holdings LP and GTCR LLC.The Goldman alternative investments conference, where she also addressed the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial-overhaul law, was one of the few times Mrs. Clinton directly addressed questions about the financial crisis when speaking to Wall Street firms, according to people familiar with the matter. She said Dodd-Frank was working, but that there were ways it could be strengthened, the people said.More often, Mrs. Clinton was asked about her four-year term as secretary of state, with people in the financial community curious to know what she thought of foreign leaders, U.S. foreign policy and whether she planned to run for president in 2016, said people familiar with the matter.In April 2013, Mrs. Clinton was invited by Morgan Stanley to speak to clients of its fixed-income business at a conference dinner at the Library of Congress. During a 20-minute question-and-answer session, Thomas Nides, a Morgan Stanley vice chairman who had just returned to the bank after working as Mrs. Clinton's deputy in the State Department, lobbed what people familiar with the session described as gentle questions at his former boss.Mrs. Clinton recounted the events leading to the capture of Osama bin Laden, among other topics. At the end of the event, she posed for photographs with attendees, as stipulated in her contract. Little was said about the financial crisis, according to people familiar with the conversation. The bank paid her $225,000.Although some of her paid speeches were open to the public, those she made to financial firms were confidential. The contracts sent around by Mrs. Clinton's agency to these and other firms usually included extensive stipulations. They barred audio and video recordings, as well as broadcasts.High-profile political speakers often ban recordings, but Mrs. Clinton was unusual in requiring that a stenographer be present to record and transcribe her remarks. In these cases, she had the sole right to distribute the transcripts.Many of the events hosted by the financial firms were moderated discussions or Q&A sessions; in some, Mrs. Clinton typically made prepared remarks before taking questions from the audience.In late October 2013, she sat down for an evening Q&A with Lloyd Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs. The audience at the Ritz-Carlton, Dove Mountain, right outside Tucson, Ariz., was mostly technology entrepreneurs and senior Goldman executives. Mr. Blankfein started out by asking Mrs. Clinton for a "survey of the world," according to an attendee and a person briefed on the matter.She told the audience how world leaders often asked her why politics in the nation's capital had become so gridlocked, saying it was hurting the U.S.'s reputation abroad.Credit: By Anupreeta Das and James V. Grimaldi

article name: Trump, Sanders and the American Rebellion; As institutions lose respect, voters think: Let's take a chance.
article text: What is happening in American politics?We're in the midst of a rebellion. The bottom and middle are pushing against the top. It's a throwing off of old claims and it's been going on for a while, but we're seeing it more sharply after New Hampshire. This is not politics as usual, which by its nature is full of surprise. There's something deep, suggestive, even epochal about what's happening now.I have thought for some time that there's a kind of soft French Revolution going on in America, with the angry and blocked beginning to push hard against an oblivious elite. It is not only political. Yes, it is about the Democratic National Committee, that house of hacks, and about a Republican establishment owned by the donor class. But establishment journalism, which for eight months has been simultaneously at Donald Trump's feet ("Of course you can call us on your cell from the bathtub for your Sunday show interview!") and at his throat ("Trump supporters, many of whom are nativists and nationalists . . .") is being rebelled against too. Their old standing as guides and gatekeepers? Gone, and not only because of multiplying platforms. Gloria Steinem thought she owned feminism, thought she was feminism. She doesn't and isn't. The Clintons thought they owned the party--they don't. Hedge-funders thought they owned the GOP. Too bad they forgot to buy the base!All this goes hand in hand with the general decline of America's faith in its institutions. We feel less respect for almost all of them--the church, the professions, the presidency, the Supreme Court. The only formal national institution that continues to score high in terms of public respect (72% in the most recent Gallup poll) is the military.A few years ago I gave a lecture to a class at West Point, the text of which was: You are entering the only U.S. institution left standing. Your prime responsibility throughout your careers will be to keep it respected. I then told them about the Dreyfus case. They had not heard of it. I explained how that scandal rocked public faith in a previously exalted institution, the French army, doing it and France lasting damage. And so your personal integrity is of the utmost importance, I said, as day by day that integrity creates the integrity of the military. The cadets actually listened to that part.I mention this to say we are in a precarious position in the U.S. with so many of our institutions going down. Many of those pushing against the system have no idea how precarious it is or what they will be destroying. Those defending it don't know how precarious its position is or even what they're defending, or why. But people lose respect for a reason.To New Hampshire: The rejection of the establishment's preferred candidates in both major parties is a big moment. It is also understandable, the result of 15 years of failed presidencies. It is a gesture of rebuke toward the political class--move aside.It's said this is the year of anger but there's a kind of grim practicality to Trump and Sanders supporters. They're thinking: Let's take a chance. Washington is incapable of reform or progress; it's time to reach outside. Let's take a chance on an old Brooklyn socialist. Let's take a chance on the casino developer who talks on TV.In doing so, they accept a decline in traditional political standards. You don't have to have a history of political effectiveness anymore; you don't even have to have run for office! "You're so weirdly outside the system, you may be what the system needs."They are pouring their hope into uncertain vessels, and surely know it. Bernie Sanders is an actual radical: He would fundamentally change an economic system that imperfectly but for two centuries made America the wealthiest country in the history of the world. In the young his support is understandable: They have never been taught anything good about capitalism and in their lifetimes have seen it do nothing--nothing--to protect its own reputation.It is middle-aged Sanders supporters who are more interesting. They know what they're turning their backs on. They know they're throwing in the towel. My guess is they're thinking something like: Don't aim for great now, aim for safe. Terrorism, a world turning upside down, my kids won't have it better--let's just try to be safe, more communal.A shrewdness in Sanders and Trump backers: They share one faith in Washington, and that is in its ability to wear anything down. They think it will moderate Bernie, take the edges off Trump. For thus reason they don't see their choices as so radical.As for Mr. Trump, it is not without meaning that his supporters have had eight months to measure the cost of satisfying their anger by voting for him. In New Hampshire, 35% of the electorate decided that for all his drama and uncertainty they would back him.The mainstream journalistic mantra is that the GOP is succumbing to nativism, nationalism and the culture of celebrity. That allows them to avoid taking seriously Mr. Trump's issues: illegal immigration and Washington's 15-year, bipartisan refusal to stop it; political correctness and how it is strangling a free people; and trade policies that have left the American working class displaced, adrift and denigrated. Mr. Trump's popularity is propelled by those issues and enabled by his celebrity.In winning, Donald Trump threw over the GOP donor class. Political professionals don't fully appreciate that, but normal Americans see it. They get that the guy with money just slapped silly the guys with money. Every hedge-fund billionaire donor should be blinking in pain. Some investment!This leads me to Citizens United. Conservatives applauded that Supreme Court decision because it allowed Republicans to counter the effect of union money that goes to Democrats. But Citizens United gave the rich too much sway in the GOP. The party was better off when it relied on Main Street. It meant they had to talk to Main Street.Mr. Trump is a clever man with his finger on the pulse, but his political future depends on two big questions. The first is: Is he at all a good man? Underneath the foul mouthed flamboyance is he in it for America? The second: Is he fully stable? He acts like a nut, calling people bimbos, flying off the handle with grievances. Is he mature, reliable? Is he at all a steady hand?Political professionals think these are side questions. "Let's accuse him of not being conservative!" But they are the issue. Because America doesn't deliberately elect people it thinks base, not to mention crazy.Anyway, we are in some kind of moment. Congratulations to the establishments of both parties for getting us here. They are the authors of the rebellion; they are a prime thing being rebelled against.Connected to that, something I've noticed. In Washington there used to be a widespread cliché: "God protects drunks, children and the United States of America." I'm in Washington a lot, and I've noticed no one says that anymore. They stopped 10 or 15 years ago. I wonder what that means.Credit: By Peggy Noonan

article name: GOP Groups Target Sanders; Republican super PACs say they are taking Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders seriously enough to attack him
article text: Democratic presidential contender Hillary Clinton has long been the subject of Republican attacks. It looks like rival Bernie Sanders may soon start to feel the burn, too.It's a perverse sort of compliment, really. Republican super PACs say they are now taking the Vermont senator seriously enough to attack him. The attacks focus on the fact that Mr. Sanders is a democratic socialist, though they generally leave out the "democratic" part.That would be a significant vulnerability for Mr. Sanders in a general election, but competing for liberal voters in a Democratic primary, Mrs. Clinton hasn't touched it. A Boston Globe poll last weekend found that nearly a third of Democratic voters in New Hampshire said the term "socialist" applied to them.Not necessarily so with the larger electorate. On Wednesday, the day after Mr. Sanders's resounding victory in the New Hampshire primary, Tom Donohue, president of the Chamber of Commerce, posted his "thoughts" about Mr. Sanders's victory to the Chamber's website. He declared the senator's economic views to be wholly "misguided.""Socialism is a wrong and dangerous path for America. It's failed everywhere it's ever been tried, bringing shared misery instead of shared prosperity," he wrote.That is downright quaint compared with a digital ad released Thursday from the Republican group America Rising Squared, a nonprofit organization that doesn't have to disclose its donors.The ad repeatedly uses the word "socialist" and uses ominous images of war, Soviet flags and terrorists to paint a frightening picture of America under Mr. Sanders. It shows a younger (and even wilder-haired) Mr. Sanders praising Cuba's Fidel Castro and airs recent footage of him saying, "We will raise taxes, yes we will."And on Friday, the super PAC Future45 released an ad to run on cable television nationally and in Nevada. The ad actually advertises some of the ideas that Mr. Sanders is proud of: a $15 minimum wage, a higher taxes on banks and corporations and free (the ad puts "free" into quotes) college and health care.Some GOP groups have been airing TV ads that are actually meant to boost Mr. Sanders at the expense of Mrs. Clinton. But this time, Future45 says it is aiming at the Vermont senator, fearful he will skate by for too long without criticism from the right."No one took Obama seriously at first when he ran in 2008," said Dan Conston, senior adviser to Future 45, "and we're not going to make that mistake."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton Cross Paths in Nevada; Democratic presidential candidates visit same church, aim to drum up support from African-Americans
article text: LAS VEGAS, Nev.--The two Democratic candidates for president crossed paths on the campaign trail Sunday, making back-to-back appearances at a historically black church in west Las Vegas.Locked in a tight battle for the Democratic nomination, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders have turned the bulk of their attention to shoring up support from black and Latino voters, two voting blocs that will play a key role in the next two Democratic nominating contests.The two candidates spoke to parishioners at the Victory Missionary Baptist Church on Sunday, both offering brief remarks to a crowd of more than 500 people."We thank God our church, in this political system, is singled out today to have both presidential candidates," said Pastor Robert E. Fowler Sr.Mrs. Clinton was introduced by Rep. John Lewis, a Georgia Democrat and civil-rights icon who delivered a strong endorsement.Election 2016* Bernie Sanders Strives to Win Over Skeptical Blacks in South Carolina* Clinton Seeks to Maximize Her Support Among Blacks* GOP Hopefuls Take Gloves Off at South Carolina Debate* Jeb Bush Embraces Family Ahead of South Carolina Primary"If there is one person ready to be president, day one, this woman. She's been a senator, secretary of state. Look, she is prepared, she is ready, Hillary Clinton," Mr. Lewis told churchgoers about Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders stuck to an abbreviated version of his stump speech in a brief appearance in church on Sunday. He then traveled across town to a raucous rally at a Las Vegas high school, where he predicted a victory next weekend if his supporters turned out to the polls."If people come out in large numbers on caucus day, we're going to win," he told cheering supporters.The challenge for Mr. Sanders is to improve his standing among nonwhite voters in advance of the Feb. 20 Nevada caucuses and the Feb. 27 South Carolina primary. Latinos make up about a quarter of the population in Nevada, while African-Americans make up nearly 30% in South Carolina and play an outsize role in the Democratic primary.Mr. Sanders fought Mrs. Clinton to a draw in Iowa and won a resounding victory in New Hampshire last week. But both states are whiter and more rural than the country at large.Nevada hasn't been extensively polled in recent months, lending an air of unpredictability to the third Democratic presidential contest. But a recent South Carolina poll showed Mrs. Clinton with a 47-point lead over Mr. Sanders among black voters in the Palmetto State. National polls also show Mrs. Clinton with large leads among nonwhite voters, while Mr. Sanders wins big among white voters and younger voters.The crowd to see Mr. Sanders at the high school was so large that not everyone could fit into the venue. Mr. Sanders briefly spoke to those shut out of the rally using a megaphone before delivering his stump speech inside."If we can win here in Nevada, we send a profound message to the entire country. And that message is that the people of this country will no longer accept establishment politics," Mr. Sanders said.Mr. Sanders will campaign in Michigan on Monday and in Georgia on Tuesday.Mrs. Clinton, who has been in Nevada since Saturday, also maintained a busy campaign schedule and is hosting an evening rally in Las Vegas.She is scheduled to travel to Elko and Reno on Monday, hoping to ramp up turnout in areas of the state outside of Las Vegas, the largest city.In another stop to speak to a group of illegal immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children, Mrs. Clinton said the Supreme Court was the key to protecting many of President Barack Obama's immigration efforts. She said that the death this week of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia has thrown the future of Mr. Obama's executive actions on immigration in doubt.A U.S. District Court last year blocked Mr. Obama's efforts to give millions of illegal immigrants legal status and work permits. The decision was appealed to the Supreme Court, where a tie among the remaining eight justices would keep the lower court decision in place, she said."If there is no new justice appointed, then as with other cases before the Court, the decision that was decided will stay in place. And that was a bad decision. I disagreed with it. I don't think it was the right legal interpretation, I believe President Obama had the authority to do what he did," Mrs. Clinton told a group of young people.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Byron Tau

article name: Bernie Sanders Strives to Win Over Skeptical Blacks in South Carolina; Democratic presidential candidate focuses on income support in effort to draw minority support
article text: RENO, Nev.--Hillary Clinton has had 25 years to persuade black voters she is a reliable political ally. Bernie Sanders has had about 25 days to do the same.The Vermont senator comes from an overwhelmingly white state. Since entering the presidential race in May, he has spent the bulk of his time campaigning in a pair of states that are just about as white: New Hampshire and Iowa.Now that the first phase of the race is over and the contest is moving to Southern states with large black populations, Mr. Sanders is scrambling to introduce himself to voters who have little idea who he is.It has been a rocky path.His campaign on Saturday released an ad that will air in South Carolina in advance of the Feb. 27 primary . The Democratic electorate in South Carolina is more than 50% black. The 30-second spot opens with pictures of the Rev. Martin Luther King and includes black-and-white images of civil-rights marches in the 1960s.Related* Clinton Seeks to Maximize Her Support Among Blacks* What Would Happen if Bernie Sanders Taxed Wall Street?* Hillary Clinton Questions Bernie Sanders's Loyalty to Obama* Sanders's Record, Filings Show Benefits From Super PACs, Links to Wall Street Donors* Sanders Wins New Hampshire Democratic Primary* Bernie Sanders Out-Raises Hillary Clinton in Silicon Valley"Bernie Sanders: He was there when Dr. King marched on Washington," the narrator says.Two days ago, one of the icons of the civil-rights movement, Rep. John Lewis (D., Ga.), cast doubt on Mr. Sanders's record as a fighter for racial equality.Taking part in a Hillary Clinton endorsement event with fellow members of the Congressional Black Caucus, Mr. Lewis said he "never saw" and "never met" Mr. Sanders during protests and marches. That was a blow delivered at an inopportune time: For Mr. Sanders to win the nomination he must demolish the "firewall" Mrs. Clinton's campaign says it has built on the strength of minority voters .As a student at the University of Chicago in the early 1960s, Mr. Sanders took part in protests against the school's segregated housing policies. He was in the crowd in 1963 when Rev. King gave his "I have a Dream" speech.On Saturday, Mr. Lewis tempered his comments. In a statement, he said he didn't mean to challenge Mr. Sanders's credentials. He said "the fact that I did not meet him in the movement does not mean I doubted that Sen. Sanders participated in the civil-rights movement, neither was I attempting to disparage his activism."Asked by reporters Saturday if the Clinton campaign is placing too much focus on race, Mr. Sanders bristled. He said that in 1988, when he was mayor of Burlington, Vt., he endorsed Jesse Jackson for the Democratic presidential nomination."There were very, very, very few white public officials at that point who endorsed Jackson," Mr. Sanders said in a brief news conference before boarding a flight from Reno to Denver. "But I thought what he was saying made sense. I had the courage to do that."Campaigning in more racially diverse states, Mr. Sanders is recalibrating his message. He is talking more about race relations and emphasizing proposals that speak to the deepest concerns of black voters: youth unemployment, police brutality, and crime and punishment. He is denouncing the militarization of police departments and the paucity of banks and grocery stores in black neighborhoods.More than anything else, Mr. Sanders's candidacy is about the issue of income inequality--how wealth flows to the richest sliver of American households. Liberal white voters have embraced the message and fueled his rise in the polls.Now Mr. Sanders is drawing out the point, noting that a more even distribution of wealth would boost minority households, in particular."When we talk about a rigged economy, where the rich get richer and almost everybody else gets poorer, it's important to understand that many, many people have gotten poorer," he said Saturday at a campaign forum in Reno. "It has been the African-American community, the [Native-American] community, the indigenous community, the Latino community that has suffered the most."He has had some success in attracting minority support, but progress has been uneven. On Friday night, Mr. Sanders took part in a forum on race in Minneapolis.The discussion was tense.Speakers pressed him to talk directly about the government paying reparations for slavery. They told him he was being too polite in discussing race.One woman spoke about her son who had gotten sick breathing fumes from city incinerators. "My black son--I know you're scared to say, 'black,' I know you're scared to say, 'reparations.'""Hold it, ma'am," Mr. Sanders said. "I don't think that's a fair statement.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Hillary Clinton Questions Bernie Sanders's Loyalty to Obama; In first presidential debate after split victories in Iowa and New Hampshire, candidates clash on cost of plans
article text: MILWAUKEE--Hillary Clinton pressed Bernie Sanders on the viability of his proposals for free health care and college tuition in a Democratic presidential debate Thursday, and questioned his loyalty to President Barack Obama for past statements calling the president weak and a disappointment.In a wide-ranging exchange, the first after the candidates split victories in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, the Democratic contenders agreed with each other more than they disagreed and appealed to the minority voters who will play a larger role in the next two races, in South Carolina and Nevada.READ MORE ON CAPITAL JOURNAL* Recap: How the Debate Unfolded* Clinton's Wall Street Talks Were Highly Paid, Friendly* Marco Rubio Talks Up Foreign Policy Expertise* Kasich Places Big Bet on Midwest Support* New Hampshire Exit Polls by the NumbersMrs. Clinton tethered herself to Mr. Obama, who remains enormously popular with the African-American voters she is relying on to help her campaign. She cast herself as the keeper of his legacy, repeatedly injected praise for his record and attacked Mr. Sanders for criticism he has leveled against the president."The kind of criticism we've heard from Sen. Sanders about our president I expect from Republicans--I do not expect from someone running for the Democratic nomination," she said. "That is a low blow," he replied, saying he has worked closely with Mr. Obama. But he added: "Last I heard, we lived in a democratic society. Last I heard a U.S. senator had the right to disagree with the president. So I have voiced criticisms."Mrs. Clinton said that disagreement was fine but Mr. Sanders went too far suggesting a primary challenge to him in 2011, calling him weak and a disappointment. The Vermont senator's final retort, harking back to the 2008 Democratic primary: "One of us ran against Barack Obama. I was not that candidate."The debate elicited few surprises and revealed no significant change in tactics by either camp that could shift the dynamics of what appears to be a highly competitive fight for the Democratic Party presidential nomination that isn't likely to be resolved for months.Mr. Sanders didn't hesitate to stand by his proposal to impose new taxes on the wealthy and Wall Street to provide new government services. However, he appeared to have no reply when the former secretary of state pointed out that his education proposal would require Republican governors to spend more money to make it happen.Mr. Sanders's plan "rests on making sure that governors, like Scott Walker [of Wisconsin], contribute $23 billion on the first day to make college free. I'm a little skeptical," she said, to loud applause.An unexpected historical figure made his way into the debate: Henry Kissinger, who served as secretary of state and national security adviser under President Richard Nixon. Mr. Sanders sought to put Mrs. Clinton on the defensive, noting that she has said she has taken advice from Mr. Kissinger and citing his role in the secret bombings of Cambodia during the Vietnam War."I happen to believe that Henry Kissinger was one of the most destructive secretaries of state in the modern history of this country," Mr. Sanders said. "I'm proud to say that Henry Kissinger is not my friend. I will not take advice from Henry Kissinger."Mrs. Clinton struck back, seeking to portray Mr. Sanders as unprepared for the world's foreign policy challenges. "Journalists have asked, who do you listen to on policy and we have yet to know who that is," Mrs. Clinton said.
