Many in Congress see it not as economists do--as the savior of the economy--but as handmaiden to the banks or an unaccountable enabler of fiscal profligacy.The Fed usually depends on the White House to protect it from congressional meddling, but in recent years it has lost legislative battles over the makeup of its board of governors and the use of its earnings. President Obama did promise to veto a Republican-backed House bill that would have subjected the Fed to invasive audits. Presumably a president Sanders, who backed a similar bill in the Senate , would have signed it.From China to oil, markets already have plenty to worry about. To that list they can now add a possible president that presides over a circumscribed central bank, escalating trade conflict or a stepped-up assault on Wall Street.Write to Greg Ip at greg.ip@wsj.comCredit: By Greg Ip

article name: Democratic Economists Say Bernie Sanders's Math Doesn't Add Up; Economists say candidate's proposals risk undercutting Democrats' reputation as 'party of responsible arithmetic'
article text: Four leading Democratic economists sharply criticized Bernie Sanders for citing "extreme claims" about the economic effects of his presidential campaign proposals, which they say risk undercutting the Democrats' reputation as "the party of responsible arithmetic."The critique of a fellow Democratic presidential candidate came in an open letter, posted online , that was signed by all three former directors of President Barack Obama's Council of Economic Advisers--essentially, the White House's economic brain trust--and one director for President Bill Clinton.The economists criticized the analysis of Gerald Friedman, a professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts-Amherst, who has defended the cost of Mr. Sanders's government-run health care plan --an estimated $14 trillion over 10 years--by saying around two-thirds of the plan would pay for itself through reduced medical costs and stronger economic growth.Mr. Friedman last month said Mr. Sanders's health-care plan could boost growth in gross domestic product to 5.3% annually, up from 2.4% in each of the past two years, and cut the U.S. poverty rate by more than half."As much as we wish it were so, no credible economic research supports economic impacts of these magnitudes," said the economists, Austan Goolsbee of the University of Chicago, Alan Krueger of Princeton, Christina Romer of the University of California at Berkeley, and Laura D'Andrea Tyson of Berkeley.Ms. Romer and Mr. Krueger have served as outside advisers to Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton in the current campaign, and Ms. Tyson advised Mrs. Clinton during her 2008 campaign.Warren Gunnels, Mr. Sanders's senior policy adviser, responded by questioning the credibility of the letter's authors."I think it's not surprising that some of the same establishment economists who told us how wonderful Nafta and unfettered free trade would be are now attacking Sen. Sanders's economic agenda," he said, referring to the North American Free Trade Agreement. He said that given the dire problems of the American middle class, "It's too late for establishment economics and establishment politics."Mr. Friedman's analysis isn't the last word on the Sanders plan, Mr. Gunnels said. "If these establishment economists don't like the study they can come up with their own opinions," he said.Mrs. Clinton has argued that several of Mr. Sanders's policy proposals aren't politically achievable, but Wednesday's broadside from the economists rests only on their economic veracity, not the politics.The economists said in their letter that they had been similarly critical of "fantastical claims" by Republicans who have argued that large tax cuts for wealthier households have paid for themselves by boosting economic growth. "We have applied the same rigor to proposals by Democrats," they wrote.The Sanders campaign, they said, undermined the credibility of progressive economic policy and made it "that much more difficult to challenge the unrealistic claims made by Republican candidates."Paul Krugman, the Nobel laureate, wrote on his blog at the New York Times that the letter was important because it suggested that Mr. Sanders was unwilling to "face up to the reality that the kind of drastic changes he's proposing, no matter how desirable, would produce a lot of losers as well as winners."Write to Nick Timiraos at nick.timiraos@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Nick Timiraos and Laura Meckler

article name: Donald Trump's Lead in South Carolina Narrows as Conservatives Turn to Ted Cruz, Poll Finds; Among Democratic candidates, Hillary Clinton maintains a wide lead over Sen. Bernie Sanders
article text: Donald Trump's lead in South Carolina has narrowed ahead of Saturday's primary, as many of the party's most conservative voters turn instead to Sen. Ted Cruz, a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll finds.The poll found that support for Mr. Trump dropped to 28% among likely Republican voters in South Carolina, down 8 points from January, while support for Mr. Cruz rose slightly to 23%. What had been a 16-point lead for Mr. Trump is now 5 points.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 news.* Additional 2016 Election Polls* South Carolina's Clyburn Endorses Clinton* Pope Francis and Trump Spar Over Immigration and Candidate's Faith* South Carolina GOP Stalwarts Fear Primary Will Only Underscore Party Rifts* Clinton's Lead Shrinks as More Women Shift to Sanders, WSJ/NBC News Poll Finds S* Critics See Racial Subtext in Obama-Rubio Photo MashupThe rest of the GOP field remained bunched at a distance from the top two contenders: Sen. Marco Rubio drew 15%; former Gov. Jeb Bush had 13%; and Gov. John Kasich and Ben Carson each had 9%.One question heading into Saturday's voting is whether the primary will establish a clear front-runner among the field's centrist, establishment-friendly candidates. But the close showings by Messrs. Rubio and Bush in the poll suggest that South Carolina voters could leave it to a future contest to winnow the field.Among Democrats, the poll showed that Hillary Clinton maintains a wide lead over Sen. Bernie Sanders, signaling that the state's primary could help stabilize her campaign after a lopsided loss in New Hampshire and a narrow win in Iowa. Democrats hold their primary in South Carolina on Feb. 27.The report of a Trump decline among South Carolina Republicans came a day after a WSJ/NBC News poll of Republican primary voters nationally found that he had lost his once-commanding lead and fallen narrowly behind Mr. Cruz . Most national polls and South Carolina surveys have been showing Mr. Trump with a double-digit lead over his rivals.The new Journal/NBC/Marist poll in South Carolina was conducted Feb. 15-17, after Mr. Trump drew attention and criticism for an especially aggressive performance during a televised debate among the GOP candidates.The poll found that the biggest change in the Republican race came from Mr. Trump losing support rather than from the other candidates making big gains. Mr. Trump's lead over Mr. Cruz declined across the board, but most notably among very conservative voters and tea party activists.Messrs. Cruz and Trump are in a close contest for support among evangelical voters, a big faction of South Carolina's GOP electorate that Mr. Cruz has been wooing assiduously. Mr. Trump is drawing 29% of evangelicals and Mr. Cruz 26%, the poll found.With so many of the second-tier candidates running neck-and-neck for third and fourth places, the primary may leave the field in a muddle."With the race tightening, it looks like South Carolina may not be any better than Iowa and New Hampshire in clarifying the race," said Lee M. Miringoff, director of the Marist College Institute for Public Opinion.Among Democrats, Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Sanders by 60% to 32% among people likely to vote in the Democratic primary. That lead is nine points narrower than in January.Mrs. Clinton's position is anchored in a big advantage among the state's large African-American population, especially older black voters.Among African-Americans over 45, Mrs. Clinton outpolled Mr. Sanders by 78% to 12%. Among younger African-Americans, Mrs. Clinton's edge was narrower, 52% to 35%.Mr. Sanders leads Mrs. Clinton among white voters, 51% to 46%. Other voting groups that back him by large margins include voters under 45 and first-time voters.But those groups don't make up as large a voting bloc as the minority population that is favoring Mrs. Clinton."Clinton is positioned to carry South Carolina by racking up huge numbers among African-Americans, who are expected to make up about 60% of the Democratic primary electorate," said Mr. Miringoff. "Right now, the Clinton firewall is holding firm in the state."The Journal/NBC/Marist poll surveyed 722 likely Republican voters and 425 likely Democratic voters. The margin of error was plus or minus 3.6 percentage points for the Republican group and plus or minus 4.8 points for Democratic results.Write to Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.comCredit: By Janet Hook

article name: Hillary Clinton Wins Nevada Democratic Caucuses; Former secretary of state narrowly defeats Sen. Bernie Sanders, re-establishes herself as the 2016 front-runner
article text: LAS VEGAS, Nev.--Hillary Clinton beat back a stiff challenge from rival Bernie Sanders on Saturday, winning Nevada's Democratic caucuses and re-establishing herself as the front-runner for her party's presidential nomination.The victory was a relief for the Clinton campaign and allows the former secretary of state to move on to contests in South Carolina Saturday and the states that follow with fresh momentum after being walloped in New Hampshire and winning by only the slimmest of margins in Iowa."I am so, so thrilled and so grateful to all of my supporters out there," Mrs. Clinton said at her victory rally. "Some may have doubted us but we never doubted each other."In her speech, she repeatedly invoked what Americans can accomplish together, rather than why she was the best choice for president, a shift in her campaign message. "Let's do this together," she said. "The future that we want is within our grasp."Going forward, a top Clinton aide said, Mrs. Clinton would be talking more about the need for America to build a better society collectively, and on Saturday, Mrs. Clinton promised to roll out new ideas to encourage national service. "It can't be just about what we're going to give you. It has to be about what we're going to build together," she said.Mr. Sanders, in conceding the loss in Nevada, made clear he's determined to fight on in the primary race. "Taking on the establishment, whether it is the financial establishment, whether it is the political establishment, whether it is the media establishment, is not easy," he told his supporters."We have come a very long way in nine months," he said, promising a historic political upset by the time the party gathers for its July convention in Philadelphia. "We have the momentum."Mrs. Clinton had long been considered the favorite in Nevada. But Mr. Sanders' 22-point victory margin in the Granite State's primary gave him a major boost, and an infusion of donations allowed him to put staff on the ground and television ads on the air.The caucuses, hosted at 250 schools, casinos and community centers around the state, determined how the state's 35 pledged delegates to the national convention will be awarded. A total of 2,383 are needed to win at this summer's Philadelphia convention, underscoring the long road ahead.Clinton supporters, packed into a ballroom at Caesars Palace hotel on the Las Vegas Strip, erupted at reports that she has been declared the winner here, with spontaneous chants of "Hillary! Hillary!" The Clinton party was one floor above the ballroom where a couple of hours earlier nearly 300 Las Vegas shift workers and hotel employees gathered for a caucus that gave Mrs. Clinton a solid victory.Entrance polls showed Mrs. Clinton winning among women, voters age 45 and older, Democrats and those who consider themselves politically moderate. She also won majority support among those looking for someone with the right experience, and those who cared most about someone who can win in November."I just believe she's the right person," said Susan Castronova, age 50, of Henderson, Nev. "She's got the knowledge, and she's got the experience."Mr. Sanders continued to show strength with the heart of his coalition: younger voters, liberals and independents. He also won among those looking for a candidate who is "honest and trustworthy" and those who cared most that a candidate.Many voters said they had been bombarded with phone calls, emails and door knocks, particularly from the Clinton campaign.Tracy Leavitt, a 58-year-old disabled former child-care employee, said she received regular calls and visits from Clinton volunteers at her home in Pahrump, and just one call from the Sanders campaign. Still, while standing in line Saturday, she decided to back Mr. Sanders."I like how he's in your face, saying this is what I'm going to do," Ms. Leavitt said. "I want someone like him who is different."Now the campaign shifts to the South, where Mrs. Clinton's strength with black voters puts her in a strong position to pick up a string of quick wins. South Carolina votes next Saturday, and well over half of the voters are expected to be African-American. Polls show her ahead.Then come 11 states on March 1, and both campaigns see her with an advantage in the southern states of Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Texas and Tennessee. The Sanders campaign sees potential victories in Colorado, Minnesota, Oklahoma and Massachusetts, as well as in his home state of Vermont.For Mrs. Clinton, strength with black voters is critical to her path to victory, and at the caucuses her support among them held strong. Entrance polls showed her winning this group by a 3-to-1 margin.Sentiment was overwhelmingly pro-Clinton at a North Las Vegas precinct in the heart of the region's African-American community. Voters there said they appreciated her long support and said they didn't know Mr. Sanders as well.Kathy Willis, 62, appeared to have absorbed a major message from the Clinton campaign: that she would continue President Barack Obama's legacy. "You don't want to overturn the things Obama has done, especially health care," she said.Even with the Clinton victory, the tight race in Nevada shows how competitive the Democratic presidential contest has become.Initially, Mrs. Clinton was seen as such a strong candidate that few Democrats even considered running this year. And when he entered the race, Mr. Sanders was viewed as a message candidate who might nudge her toward more liberal positions, but who didn't stand a real chance at winning the nomination.The Clinton campaign and its backers long dismissed his strength in Iowa and New Hampshire, noting that they are two of the whitest states in the nation, and have particularly liberal voters participating in their nominating contests.But Mr. Sanders's Nevada finish, where about a third of voters were Hispanic or African-American, is a sign that his campaign is likely to remain competitive for some time.Byron Tau, Reid Epstein, Alexandra Berzon and Alejandro Lazo contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com , Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler, Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: The Young and the Economically Clueless; Millennials are flocking to Sanders, and in the GOP they favor Trump. Why are young people voting against their own interests?
article text: Bernie Sanders, the 74-year-old self-described democratic socialist, is surprising even himself with his primary-season success against Hillary Clinton, fueled by a staggering 83% majority of the under-30 vote in New Hampshire and 84% in the Iowa caucuses.As this newspaper reported on Tuesday, voters in the millennial bracket, 18- to 34-year-olds, will for the first time equal the baby-boomer share of the electorate, at 31%. These young voters appear to be falling headlong for the Vermont senator's plaintive narrative of economic "unfairness." His throwaway prescriptions for redistributing income and wealth are being echoed by an increasingly nervous Mrs. Clinton--despite such policies' having been jettisoned during her husband's administration in the 1990s.Then again, Republican front-runner Donald Trump's vague promises that he will "make America great again" aren't much more comforting--except to the masses of Americans responding to his populist diatribes against free trade and immigrants. He too scored well with the young in New Hampshire, though, winning 38% of the 18-29 support, more than double his closest competitor for that group, Ted Cruz, at 17%.These young voters seem not to realize that the economic policies they find so resonant are the least likely to promote the growth and the social mobility they desire. They deserve to be lead from the discredited backwater of equalizing outcomes, forward with policies that instead help eliminate barriers frustrating their access to opportunities.The millennials can't be faulted for being anxious about their economic prospects. They are coming of age in the weakest economy in generations. The underemployment rate (measuring those working a job for which they're overqualified and underpaid) for young adults below age 30 is 60%. The overall employment-to-population ratio of 77.4% for those in the prime-of-working-life 25-54 age bracket translates into 1.5 million jobs below the 20-year average.The college graduate living in his parents' basement and working a marginal job to service a student loan is by now an archetype of the Obama era. And while the headline unemployment numbers are down, and the administration congratulates itself on a tepid "recovery" that was almost exclusively dependent on Fed-engineered financial-asset inflation, there is every reason to be skeptical about the health of the labor market. The labor-participation rate languishes at its lowest level in 40 years, and credit creation, government and private investment aren't faring much better.Both Democrats and some Republicans keep blaming it all on "Wall Street" (Bernie Sanders's all-purpose boogeyman) for "getting away with murder" (Donald Trump on hedge funds). Don't they realize that the financial markets are the lubricant of the entire economy--that Wall Street's capacity to provide liquidity and to broker capital is the lifeblood of American companies? History will probably judge the misguided post-crisis regulations like Dodd-Frank and retribution against Wall Street to have sown the seeds of the next financial crisis. For now, the vilification of Wall Street in the presidential campaign is irresponsible.The sluggish growth of jobs and the economy has a lot more to do with the transitioning from American manufacturing and services to information technology than with the 2008 financial crisis and its supposed perpetrators. And the Fed alone can't do much more to promote its employment-and-inflation mandates.Why? Because the economy is facing complex structural headwinds for both: Artificial intelligence and self-learning algorithms are efficiency-creating and cost-reducing, and soon they will be displacing service professionals and Ph.Ds just as they have factory workers. The Bank of England projects that 45% of jobs done by people in the U.K. will eventually be performed by robots. ArkInvest expects the U.S. to shed 75 million jobs in the next two decades.And yes, the new tech-economy wealth is increasingly concentrating in the hands of relatively few innovators and financiers, leaving the middle class and its consumer demand lagging behind. What is the appropriate role of government in redressing this?Why wouldn't young voters want "free stuff" paid for by the rich, as the Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton narrative promises? Because the no-free-lunch axiom is still true: Mr. Sanders's socialized education, health care and other policies would cost up to $20 trillion, according to analysts, requiring tax collections to increase up to 47%. And have we not at least learned from the collapse and dismantling of socialism over the past quarter century that governments lack the incentives and resources to effectively allocate and manage capital in the microeconomy? The eldest of the millennials were in elementary school when the Soviet Union collapsed, so they might be forgiven for their unfamiliarity with the failure of socialist economics. But Bernie Sanders was the mayor of Burlington, Vt., and Hillary Clinton the first lady of Arkansas--what's their excuse for revanchist economics?The economic culture of the U.S. is different than that of any country in the world. Americans have always admired each other's economic success and striven for the chance to achieve it for themselves--by building, not taking the wealth from their neighbors' pockets. Donald Trump is unabashedly proud of his success--no wonder he's so popular. As a political leader, though, he needs to up his economic game quickly from "There's going to be a bubble popping" and "Nobody can solve it like me."Real solutions demand real leadership, not polarizing Twitter-length rhetoric. An America-appropriate policy response to the inequality challenge needs to be focused on equalizing opportunities, not outcomes. At the very least, removing barriers to social mobility will require tax, regulatory and educational reforms to give people the qualifications and liberty to improve their lives in the new economy.At this point in the presidential campaign, all the ideas for stimulating growth are coming from the Republican side: Marco Rubio has discussed the transformational challenges of the tech economy, and he has proposed alternatives to traditional campus-based higher education (online college and flexible vocational training); innovative student-loan programs; and corporate tax and regulatory reforms. Jeb Bush and John Kasich are also reform-minded, including promoting initiatives to ease the burden on small businesses that power job growth.Yet millennials, who would most benefit from a real economic recovery, replacing the false one of the past several years, so far seem intent on voting against their interests. There is still hope. We're moving past the peak of the "authenticity" phase of the campaign cycle, when voters unfamiliar with the field of candidates are initially drawn simply to candidates who seem willing to bluntly speak their minds. John Kasich's strong performance in New Hampshire might herald the transition to a more constructive phase, when voters--including millennials--are readier to listen to a more nuanced, realistic economic message. If not, today's young voters may not like the world they inherit, and members of the aging generation risk eventually finding themselves short of the Social Security benefits they thought they had coming.Mr. Arbess, the founder of Xerion Investments, is a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and co-founder of No Labels, promoting political bipartisanship.Credit: By Daniel J. Arbess

article name: Bernie Sanders's Path to Democratic Nomination Impeded by Nevada Result; Vermont senator looks forward to Super Tuesday contests on March 1 as next best chance for a victory against rival Hillary Clinton
article text: LAS VEGAS--Sen. Bernie Sanders's path ahead in the Democratic presidential primary was already challenging, and it was made more so by his defeat Saturday in the Nevada caucuses.Hillary Clinton now claims victory in two of the first three contests , and she's favored to win the Feb. 27 South Carolina primary, too. Mr. Sanders, who won the New Hampshire primary, won't see his next best chance for a second victory until March 1, when 11 states host primaries and caucuses.In his remarks in Nevada, Mr. Sanders briefly noted that he's traveling to South Carolina on Sunday, but then he quickly pivoted to the next round of primaries with nearly 900 delegates up for grabs."We're going to be competing in 11 states all across this country on Super Tuesday," Mr. Sanders said. "And I believe that on Super Tuesday, we have got an excellent chance to win many of those states."On Monday, he will go to Massachusetts and on Tuesday he goes to Virginia, both contests that will follow South Carolina.His campaign is already running paid TV ads in Minnesota, Colorado and Oklahoma, as well as Massachusetts, four states where advisers see their best chances for victory. Minnesota and Colorado are caucus states, which tend to attract the more liberal voters that he appeals to, his advisers said.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 news.* LIVE BLOG: The Latest From the Races in South Carolina, Nevada* Hillary Clinton Wins Nevada Democratic Caucuses* Ace Beats Six: Hillary Clinton Wins Nevada Delegate in Card Draw Tie-Breaker* In GOP Primary, South Carolina Lives Up to Mudslinging Reputation* South Carolina's Clyburn Endorses Clinton* Pope Francis and Trump Spar Over Immigration and Candidate's Faith* Critics See Racial Subtext in Obama-Rubio Photo MashupMr. Sanders also holds a huge advantage in his home state of Vermont, another March 1 state.Also voting the same day are Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee and Arkansas, all contests that will feature a significant number of African-American voters. That should provide an advantage to Mrs. Clinton, whose support in the black community was reaffirmed in Nevada, where entrance polls showed three-fourths of African-Americans backed her. She's expected to see similar support in South Carolina.Mr. Sanders's campaign manager Jeff Weaver said Saturday that the campaign will compete in the Palmetto State even though they know the Vermont senator is the underdog. "We're going to go down and we're going to fight in South Carolina. It's obviously an uphill fight for us there," he said. "Then we're going to go to Super Tuesday."After that, the Sanders campaign sees potential victories on March 5 in Kansas and Nebraska and on March 6 in Maine--all three caucus states. Sanders aides are also focused on the big prize of Michigan, where a primary is set for March 8. Mr. Weaver referred to the contest there as a "a big showdown."Mr. Weaver also noted that under Democratic Party rules, delegates are allocated proportionately, meaning that if a race is close, both candidates win substantial delegates.There are no winner-take-all states in the Democratic primary race, which prevents one candidate from pulling far away from a competitor. At the same time, though, this system makes it very hard to catch up once a candidate falls behind.When challengers are forced to drop out, it is usually because they run out of money, and Mr. Sanders shows no signs of that. He collected more than $6 million in the 24 hours after winning the New Hampshire primary. On Saturday, the Vermont senator asked his backers to continue to lend their financial support, saying that "taking on the establishment" isn't easy.Still, he'll need to notch some quick wins if he is to seriously threaten Mrs. Clinton. "He has the money and resources to keep going, but he needed Nevada to fuel his momentum because he will lose South Carolina," said Chris Kofinis, a Democratic strategist who is neutral in the race."Realistically, this hill became very high to climb," Mr. Kofinis said. "Short of a stunning loss [by Mrs. Clinton] on Super Tuesday, we're seeing the limits of his candidacy."Byron Tau contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton Vie for Rural Nevadans' Votes; Sparsely populated areas have outsize role in state's caucuses
article text: ELKO, Nev.--Hours away from the glam and glitter of Las Vegas, a fierce contest between Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton is playing out in the mountains and deserts of Nevada.State caucus rules give rural counties outsize weight in the delegate-allocation process, a directive aimed at ensuring candidates don't just campaign in the cities.Consequently, the road to victory in Saturday's Democratic caucuses runs through places like Elko, a small mountain mining community that is the closest thing to a major city in northeast Nevada, and Pahrump, a desert town of about 36,000 that boasts a handful of casinos, a couple of brothels--and Clinton and Sanders campaign field offices.And both campaigns are working these sparsely populated communities, phoning supporters daily and driving to remote houses on dirt roads that aren't on the maps to knock on doors and see if the people who answer might need a lift to caucus sites.Mr. Sanders brought his pitch to Elko on Friday, a picturesque mountain town of 20,000 people that lies more than 300 miles north of Las Vegas in a conservative part of the state. He was following Mrs. Clinton, who flew in earlier in the week. Republican candidates, who hold their caucuses Tuesday, were expected to start arriving in northern Nevada over the next few days."Tomorrow, the eyes of America and the eyes of much of the world are going to focus on Nevada," Mr. Sanders said at a rally. "And the issue is not just who wins the Democratic nomination. The issue is whether Nevada will play a leading role in moving this country toward a political revolution which transforms this country--whether the people of Nevada will say enough is enough."I'm here today in Elko to ask your support in the Democratic caucus tomorrow. Let us go forward together," he said.With polls showing the race as a dead heat, Mr. Sanders spent the day before the caucuses stumping in Elko and Reno before returning to Las Vegas for a large rally. Mrs. Clinton made stops in both Reno and Elko earlier in the week.Though the overwhelming majority of the state's people live in and around Las Vegas, campaigns ignore the rural areas at their own peril. In the 2008 Democratic race between Mrs. Clinton and Barack Obama, she won the state but Mr. Obama collected more delegates in part because of a stronger organization and presence in the rural areas."She won the popular vote, but she did not win the caucus because caucuses are based on delegates," said Joan Kato, a former aide to Mr. Obama's 2008 campaign who now serves as the state director for Mr. Sanders. Nevada has 23 delegates up for grabs in this year's caucuses.That was a mistake her campaign didn't plan to repeat. She has offices in Elko, Pahrump, and Carson City, and organizers across the state. Mr. Sanders has 12 field offices, though his campaign started organizing in Nevada months after Mrs. Clinton arrived.The Clinton campaign says its staffers logged 1,250 miles across rural Nevada last summer, sending senior campaign leaders into communities like Ely, Winnemucca, Hawthorne, and Tonopah for a listening tour that helped shape the campaign's rural strategy.Former President Bill Clinton also visited Pahrump this month and spoke to a few hundred people at a local elementary school.Gabe Alvare, a 24-year-old Clinton volunteer visiting from New York City, spent hours knocking on doors of known supporters on Wednesday in Pahrump, making sure they planned to show up for the caucus. He had stopped at many of the same houses a few days earlier. He offered Clinton yard signs, but there were no takers. Nye County is predominately Republican, and some of the people seemed reluctant to post a yard sign that might antagonize neighbors.At the wheel of the GMC pickup truck in which Mr. Alvare traveled was Clinton volunteer Frank Dix, 73, who lives in Pahrump and feels a special loyalty to the Clinton family."I'm partial to strong women," Mr. Dix said. "Hillary dealt with Bill. That's what my wife says about me. She says, 'I had to be strong, because otherwise Frank would run all over me.' "Navigating can be a challenge. The recession hit Pahrump hard, and construction on some roads seemed to stop before completion."We go where the houses are, not where the roads are," Mr. Dix said.There is no surefire way to get people to turn up at the caucus sites. One person mentioned that softball practice posed a potential conflict. A woman said her husband was planning to go, but he hasn't been feeling good lately.There have been some reassuring moments for Messrs. Alvare and Dix. Helaine Jennings, a 69-year-old retiree, answered her door and said she was all-in for Mrs. Clinton. When Mr. Alvare asked if she needed a ride, she declined. "We have two legs," she said. "It's very close."At a spartan office nearby, the Sanders campaign was also working to get out the vote. Volunteers were making calls and planning a mock caucus session so attendees would know what to expect on Saturday.Rick Bandell, a 75-year-old retiree, said he was thrilled to call one home and persuade an entire family to show up in support of Mr. Sanders."I got four people in one call," he said. "They're going to caucus for Bernie. It's very unusual. I'd be happy to just to get one."Republicans outnumber Democrats in Nye County, which includes Pahrump, by about 3 to 2, and the GOP complexion of the town is evident. At Mom's Diner, next to the Clinton campaign office, 10 Pahrump supporters of GOP candidate Ted Cruz were meeting for lunch and plotting strategy.What was also clear was that people of Pahrump were dialed in to the race.At the Lakeside Casino and RV Park, 63-year-old Leanette Robertson paused from her video-poker game to discuss the Sanders-Clinton contest. She favors Mrs. Clinton but wasn't sure she would be able to go to the caucuses because she had family visiting."She's got a broad spectrum of issues she's supporting," Ms. Robertson said of Mrs. Clinton. "It's not just the money issue. Bernie seems to be focused on one issue: the 1% of the 1%."Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Byron Tau

article name: Nevada Union's Silence Clouds Caucus; Clinton, Sanders battle for support of culinary workers after group forgoes endorsement
article text: LAS VEGAS--Eight years ago, Nevada's powerful Culinary Union mobilized to support its chosen candidate, Barack Obama, helping to boost turnout in the Democratic presidential caucuses and build credibility for what was still a long-shot campaign.This time around, casino workers and their family members are up for grabs.Leading into Saturday's Democratic caucus, the Culinary Union has withheld an endorsement, adding to the uncertainty around voter turnout and the outcome. It has also pushed the campaigns of Democratic candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders to go to aggressive lengths to find and court the union workers who cook, wash dishes, waitress and clean rooms in this tourism mecca.Mr. Sanders came to the union offices last year even before he announced he was running for president, and he showed up this week at a protest outside a hospital, which Mrs. Clinton also attended. Earlier, his representatives went into employee dining halls at casinos and talked to workers while wearing union pins, a tactic the union said was inappropriate. Mr. Sanders' campaign chalked the issue up to a misunderstanding.Mrs. Clinton in November appeared at an organizing rally outside a hotel co-owned by Donald Trump to support a union-organizing campaign there. She has met union members at several casinos in the last week."Both have shown a lot of support to come speak to us," said Nelson Lucero, a barista at the New York New York casino, who said he hadn't settled on a candidate. "I think that's really important."With 57,000 members, the culinary workers' union, which is overwhelmingly Hispanic and Democratic, dominates state politics to an extent nearly unmatched elsewhere.In past campaigns, the union made up much of the ground game for the candidates it supported. Part of its strength comes from being able to freely visit workers and talk to them about politics in the employee-only backhouses of casinos.That was a factor in the 2008 and 2012 presidential races, as well as in Democratic Sen. Harry Reid's tight re-election campaign in 2010. The union also played a role in ousting several Republican state legislators, according to state political experts.A variety of factors this year led the executive board of the Culinary Union's parent union, Unite Here, to vote in January not to endorse a candidate. The union has said that the primary factor in that decision was contract negotiations that are taking up time and resources."We made the decision to focus on union business over political business," said Yvanna Cancela, the union's political director.One key issue, according to several people familiar with the matter, was a dispute with the Obama administration over some aspects of the Affordable Care Act. The union fought the so-called Cadillac tax, a 40% excise-tax increase on high-cost health-care plans, including those covering Culinary Union members. Mr. Obama signed into law a two-year delay on the tax late last year, but he had refused the union's demands that the tax be removed altogether.Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders both supported the removal, but union officials wanted more evidence they would work against it, people familiar with the matter said.The union learned that it "should expect more from politicians than campaign promises," one person familiar with its thinking said.The AFL-CIO, the national union organization of which Unite Here is a part, also said this week that it wouldn't endorse a candidate in the Democratic primary.For the Culinary Union, the nonendorsement allows it to avoid some of the awkward infighting that occurred eight years ago, when it endorsed Mr. Obama. Mrs. Clinton won the largest number of votes in the caucuses, but Mr. Obama won the most delegates.Chad Neanover, a prep cook at the Margaritaville restaurant on the Las Vegas Strip, said he faced resistance when he talked to co-workers about Mr. Obama."I was having people who were 100% die-hard for Hillary," he said. "It was uncomfortable that so many people were upset over it."The union's decision not to endorse a candidate could have implications for state Democrats in the fall. Some close to the Culinary Union say that with the union sitting out recent elections, they sense enthusiasm for politics could be down.But Ms. Cancela said the union plans to heavily re-engage ahead of the general election to support the Democratic nominee.It has started preparing by launching an organizing drive to gain citizenship for its members, so that they will be able to vote, and to register 12,000 additional members to vote. "They've already committed to working really hard in the general," said Mr. Reid. "That's when we need it."Write to Alexandra Berzon at alexandra.berzon@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Alexandra Berzon and Peter Nicholas

article name: Ip's Take: How Sanders, Trump Threaten Market Confidence; The Wall Street Journal's financial regulation newsletter for Thursday, February 18, 2016
article text: Ip's Take: How Sanders, Trump Threaten Market ConfidenceU.K. Finance Sector Has Most at Stake in EU Membership TalksFed's Kashkari: To Have 'Actionable Plan' for Breaking Up Big Banks by Year's EndThe Real Crisis Is for Bank Bonds, Not BanksChina's ICBC Offices in Spain Raided in Money-Laundering ProbeHow Sanders, Trump Threaten Market ConfidenceMarkets don't usually pay a lot of attention to presidential elections. For all the campaign theatrics, presidents from both parties, once in office, tend to hew to economic orthodoxy, whether on free trade or the independence of the Federal Reserve.This would be a good year to jettison those assumptions.Much as the global financial crisis tripped up economists in 2008, so too has the presidential campaign made a mockery of political soothsaying.Only now are investors grappling with the possibility that Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders, a self-declared democratic socialist and leader of a "political revolution," or Republican Donald Trump, a reality-TV personality who devises policy on the fly, could actually be president. Either would foreshadow unprecedented uncertainty and potential upheaval in government policy.The risk lies not just in their policies, which are radical enough. Mr. Sanders would break up the big banks, introduce universal government-funded health care and raise the federal minimum wage to $15. Mr. Trump would slap steep tariffs on imports from China and Mexico and build a wall along the Mexican border to keep out immigrants.The greater risk is that both men represent a rejection of economic orthodoxy. They don't especially care that mainstream economists pan their proposals. Neither, apparently, do their growing ranks of supporters. A public whose inflation-adjusted incomes have been ratcheting downward since 1999 and overwhelmingly believes the country is on the wrong track may feel it has little to lose from unorthodox ideas.Is that so bad?Thus far, there is no coherent economics evident in the policies of Mr. Trump. Asked to name an economic adviser, his campaign cites billionaire hedge-fund manager Carl Icahn. Illegal immigrants from Mexico are central villains in his narrative of American decline, though their ranks have been falling since 2007.Mr. Sanders puts more thought into his policies and has found some economists to back them. Nonetheless, his ideas are driven less by economic evidence than a deeply entrenched, ideological view of a world stacked in favor of business and the rich.Messrs. Sanders and Trump didn't achieve their popularity in a vacuum. Many in Congress and the broader public share their populist distrust of globalization and finance. That imperils the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership, and the institution about which markets care most: the Federal Reserve. Many in Congress see it not as economists do--as the savior of the economy--but as a handmaiden to the banks or an unaccountable enabler of fiscal profligacy.The Fed usually depends on the White House to protect it from congressional meddling, but in recent years it has lost legislative battles over the makeup of its board of governors and the use of its earnings. President Obama did promise to veto a Republican-backed House bill that would have subjected the Fed to invasive audits. Presumably a president Sanders, who backed a similar bill in the Senate, would have signed it.From China to oil, markets already have plenty to worry about. To that list they can now add a possible president that presides over a circumscribed central bank, escalating trade conflict or a stepped-up assault on Wall Street.Key Developments in Washington, on Wall Street, and BeyondU.K. Finance Sector Has Most at Stake in EU Membership TalksIt is ironic that Prime Minister David Cameron's negotiations on European Union membership should run into last-minute trouble over his attempts to secure protections for the City of London from the consequences of future eurozone integration.After all, the City itself has hardly been clamoring for these protections, having long since made its peace with the idea of EU regulation. Even officials in London and Brussels privately consider the demands to be largely window-dressing designed to cover up an otherwise largely threadbare list of U.K. reform demands. More to the point, there is no British industry with more at stake from a failed renegotiation that leads to a British EU exit.After all, the City itself has hardly been clamoring for these protections, having long since made its peace with the idea of EU regulation. Even officials in London and Brussels privately consider the demands to be largely window-dressing designed to cover up an otherwise largely threadbare list of U.K. reform demands. More to the point, there is no British industry with more at stake from a failed renegotiation that leads to a British EU exit.EU Diplomats Warn of Disagreements on U.K. Demands Ahead of SummitFed's Kashkari: To Have 'Actionable Plan' for Breaking Up Big Banks by Year's EndMinneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari, who on Tuesday pressed for a greater effort in breaking up big U.S. banks, said he hopes to gather information for a plan and submit it to the public by the end of the year. Mr. Kashkari, in an interview Wednesday on CNBC, acknowledged progress in regulating big banks since the 2008 financial crisis, but questioned whether regulators would have used those new powers to deal with that crisis.Transcript of Neel Kashkari's Interview With WSJ Reporters and Editors: 25% Capital Requirement May Be Right for BanksBreak Up the Big Banks? Do This FirstThe Real Crisis Is for Bank Bonds, Not BanksEurope clearly has unresolved issues to address in its fragmented banking system. But this is hardly news. The issue lies more with the securities and the investors that hold them than the balance sheets of the banks that issued them.The big risk that investors have woken up to isn't that these bonds can be bailed-in if a bank hits trouble--it is that interest payments on them can be skipped under certain circumstances. In turn, falling prices have raised concerns that banks won't exercise their option to redeem them at the first opportunity, requiring a further repricing downwards.China's ICBC Offices in Spain Raided in Money-Laundering ProbeSpanish authorities raided the headquarters of the Industrial & Commercial Bank of China Ltd. in Spain, detaining five directors Wednesday under the orders of a judge investigating one of the world's largest lenders for alleged money laundering.Spanish and European law-enforcement officials are probing the Chinese bank's Spanish unit for the alleged laundering of at least [euro]40 million ($44.4 million) that suspected criminal organizations had deposited at the lender, Europol, Europe's law-enforcement coordinating body, said in a statement.Boeing Chief Defends StrategyBoeing Chief Executive Dennis Muilenburg on Wednesday defended the aerospace company's accounting practices and corporate strategy in the wake of weeks of volatile stock movements. The company's shares have slumped almost 20% this year on concerns about its cash generation and competitive position, and took another hit last week following a media report that the Securities and Exchange Commission was probing its financial projections.For Foundation Capital, Deals Proved ElusiveFormer Wall Street executive Dean Barr thought he had the next big thing: Instead of investing in hedge funds, put money into companies that manage them. It didn't work out. Seven years after launching, Foundation Capital Partners LLC has closed down, with the Greenwich, Conn.-based company having never closed a deal, according to people familiar with the matter.Hedge Funds Deliver Evidence in Porsche Executives' TrialA decade-old takeover battle involving Volkswagen AG is coming to a head at a trial in Stuttgart, Germany, with fresh evidence delivered by hedge funds that lost billions of dollars shorting the company's shares during an aborted takeover. The criminal trial concerns alleged stock manipulation by executives at Porsche SE, the holding company that owned the sports-car maker when it tried to buy the much larger Volkswagen in 2008.Jacob Schlesinger and the reporters and the editors of WSJ Pro Financial Regulation welcome your questions. Send an email to AskFinReg@wsj.com.How Slightly Negative Rates Can Tear Into Bank ProfitsThe consensus on negative interest rates is becoming increasingly negative. For banks, there is growing concern from analysts that even slightly negative rates can seriously suppress profits.That's a big issue in the eurozone, where the European Central Bank began pushing some of its policy rates below zero in June 2014. In a research note published Wednesday, Morgan Stanley MS +2.31% analysts suggested that another 0.10 percentage point cut in the ECB's deposit rate would erode bank profits by 5-10%. So, a small step further into negative territory can cause profits to slump by considerably more.THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 188:30 a.m.Sean McKessy, head of the SEC's whistleblower office, and William Hicks, associate director of the agency's Atlanta office, talk about SEC whistleblower actions at Emory University Law School.FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 198:45 a.m.SEC Chairwoman Mary Jo White speaks at the Practising Law Institute/SEC annual "SEC Speaks" conference in Washington, D.C.THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 258:15 a.m.-5 p.m.The Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta and Louisiana State University's Graduate School of Banking hold the 2016 Banking Outlook Conference in Atlanta.Financial Fines Declined in 2015The tally of public financial penalties imposed in the U.S. in 2015 amounted to $18.6 billion, down from the levels seen in 2013 and 2014, said the Committee on Capital Markets Regulation, adding that financial institutions continue to face historically unprecedented fines.Dodd-Frank Boosted Fed's Rule-Making PaceThe Federal Reserve's rule-making activity increased as much over the four years after the Dodd-Frank law was enacted in 2010 as it did during the decade and a half prior to the law's creation, says the Mercatus Center at George Mason University, a free-market-oriented think tank.The SEC said former Deutsche Bank research analyst Charles Grom issued a stock rating that was inconsistent with his personal view, a violation of SEC rules. Mr. Grom will settle the case by paying a $100,000 penalty and will be suspended from the securities industry for one year. Mr. Grom neither admitted nor denied the SEC's findings.Four leading Democratic economists sharply criticized Bernie Sanders, citing "extreme claims" about the economic effects of his presidential campaign proposals, which they say risk undercutting the Democrats' reputation as "the party of responsible arithmetic."House Republicans are asking the Obama administration to take a close look at a Chinese firm's deal to buy the Chicago Stock Exchange. The 134-year-old exchange, which handles a tiny fraction of U.S. equity trading, said this month it would be acquired by Chongqing Casin Enterprise Group in a transaction that would close in the second half of the year. In a letter organized by Rep. Robert Pittenger (R., N.C.) , 46 House Republicans asked the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States, or Cfius, to conduct a "full and rigorous investigation into this proposed acquisition," saying the buyer could have ties to the Chinese government. Cfius reviews the purchase of U.S. businesses on national security grounds, and U.S. regulators tend to view financial infrastructure as highly sensitive.Japan's government has put off a plan to let its $1.1 trillion public pension fund buy and sell stocks directly, following criticism that the move could lead to excessive state influence on the market.Send us your tips, suggestions and feedback. Matthews ; Victoria McGrane ; Ryan Tracy ; Aruna Viswanatha ; Lingling Wei .Follow us on Twitter:@JMSchles , @amacker , @AAndriotis , @MaryLuWSJ , @v_dendrinou , @jeaneaglesham , @TokyoWoods , @cmatthews9 , @vgmac , @ryanjtracy , @aviswanatha , @Lingling_Wei

article name: Massachusetts Democrats Mobilize for a Close Fight; Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton are locked in a tight race in the Super Tuesday state
article text: BOSTON--The activists who propelled Elizabeth Warren to the U.S. Senate in 2012 are now mobilizing for Super Tuesday, but this time their allegiance is divided between Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders.Ms. Warren, who gained a loyal following by targeting income inequality and Wall Street, is staying neutral, and her office declined to comment on the Democratic presidential primary. But her populist message resonates with many Sanders and Clinton supporters here, while most elected Democrats in Massachusetts have endorsed the former senator and secretary of state."It will be a battle here," said Philip Johnston, a former Democratic state party chairman and a member of Ms. Warren's finance committee who supports Mr. Sanders. A poll released Monday by Emerson College Polling Society showed the race a dead heat.Mrs. Clinton's win Saturday in Nevada has put her solidly in the front-runner position, and she is expected to win again this coming weekend in South Carolina. Several other Southern states favorable to Mrs. Clinton vote along with Massachusetts on March 1, raising the stakes for Mr. Sanders here and in a handful of states outside the South.Monday at a Boston union hall, Mr. Sanders addressed whether he has a path to victory. "The short three-letter answer is 'yes,' " he said to loud cheers from sign-waving supporters arrayed behind him on the stage. "What this is about is a slog...state by state by state."Both campaigns have been marshaling forces for months. The Sanders team opened five field offices in the state, while the Clinton side has six. Each is running TV ads and launching dueling turnout operations: The Clinton campaign has "campus teams" at 11 colleges and universities and a leadership council with 192 labor, political and community leaders. The Sanders camp says it has "team captains" in 351 Massachusetts cities and towns, illustrating its "hyperlocal" strategy.Local activists backing Mrs. Clinton emphasize her experience, electability and her ability to accomplish things over the long haul. Mr. Sanders's supporters cite similar qualities but say his proposals are "more ambitious and maybe more aspirational," said John Walsh, a former Democratic state party chairman."Hillary is a doer, Hillary is telling you to eat your broccoli," said Kate Donaghue, a Democratic state committeewoman who canvassed 45 consecutive days for Ms. Warren and is now expending shoe leather for Mrs. Clinton.Ms. Donaghue, 61 and a semiretired software engineer, is pressing on even after recently breaking her wrist during a slip on ice while door-knocking for Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders snagged Joe Caiazzo, who is 28 and led Ms. Warren's get-out-the-vote operation on Cape Cod and the islands. Mr. Caiazzo now has a statewide leadership role for Mr. Sanders and says the candidate's message reminds him of Massachusetts' most famous political family."At the end of the day, I'm a Kennedy guy," said Mr. Caiazzo, who on a recent evening was at campaign headquarters overseeing rows of volunteers working the phones. "This is the bullpen," he said. "This is where the magic happens."When Ms. Warren declined to enter the presidential field, many of her grassroots supporters went to Mr. Sanders, said Ben Wikler, the Washington director of MoveOn.org, a liberal group that launched the Run Warren Run campaign in late 2014.A Harvard Law School professor and consumer-finance watchdog, Ms. Warren joined Democratic female senators in signing a 2013 letter urging Mrs. Clinton to run for president. But she is the only one of the group who hasn't endorsed Mrs. Clinton, and their relationship has been complicated .Ms. Warren, for instance, criticized Mrs. Clinton's 2001 Senate vote for a bankruptcy bill that would have made it harder to erase personal debts through bankruptcy--a position that was at odds with what she had advocated as first lady. That measure, which was supported by banks and credit card companies, failed. Asked in a 2008 presidential primary debate whether she regretted that 2001 vote, Mrs. Clinton said, "Sure I do, but it never became law."In a 2004 television interview, Ms. Warren attributed the reversal to new pressures Mrs. Clinton felt from financial companies."She has taken money from the groups, and more to the point, she worries about them as a constituency," Ms. Warren said. The Clinton campaign declined to comment on her relationship with Ms. Warren.The state is longtime Clinton country. Both Bill and Hillary Clinton have raised a lot of money here, and Mrs. Clinton beat then-Sen. Barack Obama handily here in the 2008 presidential primary.And in 1998, Mr. Clinton chose Worcester, Mass., to make his first public appearance after his confession of an improper relationship with a White House intern. Thousands lined the streets to cheer his motorcade."There's something to be said about loyalty," said Worcester Mayor Joseph Petty, a supporter of Mrs. Clinton's who had just spoken at the opening of her campaign office at the Carpenter's Local Union #107 in his city on a recent Saturday.But some experts believe Ms. Warren's notable silence has benefited Mr. Sanders."Just the mere fact that she has stayed out has sent a pretty strong message to [her backers] that they can support Sanders with her blessing," said Massachusetts Sen. Jamie Eldridge, one of a minority of state legislators backing the Vermont senator.As Mr. Sanders path to the presidential nomination has grown steeper, Mr. Johnston and some other local Sanders allies were also starting to sketch out their candidate's potential legacy."What I find remarkable is that win or lose, Bernie Sanders has had a remarkable effect on Hillary Clinton," Mr. Johnston said Sunday. "If you heard her speech last night, she sounded just like Bernie."Write to Jennifer Levitz at jennifer.levitz@wsj.comCredit: By Jennifer Levitz

Several other Southern states favorable to Mrs. Clinton vote along with Massachusetts on March 1, raising the stakes for Mr. Sanders here and in a handful of states outside the South.Monday at a Boston union hall, Mr. Sanders addressed whether he has a path to victory. "The short three-letter answer is 'yes,' " he said to loud cheers from sign-waving supporters arrayed behind him on the stage. "What this is about is a slog...state by state by state."Both campaigns have been marshaling forces for months. The Sanders team opened five field offices in the state, while the Clinton side has six. Each is running TV ads and launching dueling turnout operations: The Clinton campaign has "campus teams" at 11 colleges and universities and a leadership council with 192 labor, political and community leaders. The Sanders camp says it has "team captains" in 351 Massachusetts cities and towns, illustrating its "hyperlocal" strategy.Local activists backing Mrs. Clinton emphasize her experience, electability and her ability to accomplish things over the long haul. Mr. Sanders's supporters cite similar qualities but say his proposals are "more ambitious and maybe more aspirational," said John Walsh, a former Democratic state party chairman."Hillary is a doer, Hillary is telling you to eat your broccoli," said Kate Donaghue, a Democratic state committeewoman who canvassed 45 consecutive days for Ms. Warren and is now expending shoe leather for Mrs. Clinton.Ms. Donaghue, 61 and a semiretired software engineer, is pressing on even after recently breaking her wrist during a slip on ice while door-knocking for Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders snagged Joe Caiazzo, who is 28 and led Ms. Warren's get-out-the-vote operation on Cape Cod and the islands. Mr. Caiazzo now has a statewide leadership role for Mr. Sanders and says the candidate's message reminds him of Massachusetts' most famous political family."At the end of the day, I'm a Kennedy guy," said Mr. Caiazzo, who on a recent evening was at campaign headquarters overseeing rows of volunteers working the phones. "This is the bullpen," he said. "This is where the magic happens."When Ms. Warren declined to enter the presidential field, many of her grassroots supporters went to Mr. Sanders, said Ben Wikler, the Washington director of MoveOn.org, a liberal group that launched the Run Warren Run campaign in late 2014.A Harvard Law School professor and consumer-finance watchdog, Ms. Warren joined Democratic female senators in signing a 2013 letter urging Mrs. Clinton to run for president. But she is the only one of the group who hasn't endorsed Mrs. Clinton, and their relationship has been complicated .Ms. Warren, for instance, criticized Mrs. Clinton's 2001 Senate vote for a bankruptcy bill that would have made it harder to erase personal debts through bankruptcy--a position that was at odds with what she had advocated as first lady. That measure, which was supported by banks and credit card companies, failed. Asked in a 2008 presidential primary debate whether she regretted that 2001 vote, Mrs. Clinton said, "Sure I do, but it never became law."In a 2004 television interview, Ms. Warren attributed the reversal to new pressures Mrs. Clinton felt from financial companies."She has taken money from the groups, and more to the point, she worries about them as a constituency," Ms. Warren said. The Clinton campaign declined to comment on her relationship with Ms. Warren.The state is longtime Clinton country. Both Bill and Hillary Clinton have raised a lot of money here, and Mrs. Clinton beat then-Sen. Barack Obama handily here in the 2008 presidential primary.And in 1998, Mr. Clinton chose Worcester, Mass., to make his first public appearance after his confession of an improper relationship with a White House intern. Thousands lined the streets to cheer his motorcade."There's something to be said about loyalty," said Worcester Mayor Joseph Petty, a supporter of Mrs. Clinton's who had just spoken at the opening of her campaign office at the Carpenter's Local Union #107 in his city on a recent Saturday.But some experts believe Ms. Warren's notable silence has benefited Mr. Sanders."Just the mere fact that she has stayed out has sent a pretty strong message to [her backers] that they can support Sanders with her blessing," said Massachusetts Sen. Jamie Eldridge, one of a minority of state legislators backing the Vermont senator.As Mr. Sanders path to the presidential nomination has grown steeper, Mr. Johnston and some other local Sanders allies were also starting to sketch out their candidate's potential legacy."What I find remarkable is that win or lose, Bernie Sanders has had a remarkable effect on Hillary Clinton," Mr. Johnston said Sunday. "If you heard her speech last night, she sounded just like Bernie."Write to Jennifer Levitz at jennifer.levitz@wsj.comCredit: By Jennifer Levitz

article name: Young and Black in South Carolina: How Will They Vote? Most African-American students back Bernie Sanders, according to interviews; Hillary Clinton still expected to win primary thanks to support from older black voters
article text: COLUMBIA, S.C.--A striking pattern is emerging in the Democratic presidential primary, with Bernie Sanders energizing young voters and Hillary Clinton relying on African-American backers to create an insurmountable edge for her candidacy.Those data points raise a question: How will those who are both young and black vote in Saturday's South Carolina primary?"Most of my friends are for Bernie," said Edith Dunlap, a student at Clemson University who blames President Bill Clinton's administration for increasing the country's prison population--including members of her own family. "None of us really trust Hillary or understand what her vision would be."Mrs. Clinton is ahead in the polls here largely because of her support from black voters, a strength that helped propel her to victory in Saturday's Nevada caucuses and one expected to bring her a win in Saturday's primary here.But Mr. Sanders has gained a deep following among black college students, according to more than three dozen interviews across five universities with students, professors, university administrators and longtime political observers.While Mrs. Clinton leads 68% to 21% among black voters, which make up more than 50% of turnout in South Carolina, her lead shrinks to 52% to 35% among black voters under 45, according to the latest WSJ/NBC News poll.Many of the college students interviewed by The Wall Street Journal said they argue with their pro-Clinton parents and grandparents as they embrace Mr. Sanders's calls for free college tuition and more aggressive actions to curb Wall Street excesses.Marcurius Byrd, a first-year law school student at the University of South Carolina, won his mother over to Mr. Sanders's side but his father is still backing Mrs. Clinton, for now."Hillary just doesn't inspire the change that is necessary to build on [President Barack] Obama's legacy and really keep us moving forward," he said. "My dad is just getting introduced to Bernie Sanders."The Clinton name is potent in South Carolina, which delivered a decisive 1992 victory for Mr. Clinton that he credits with sending him to the White House. A Southern Democrat who appealed to blue-collar voters, Mr. Clinton had a long relationship with civil-rights leaders in the state and presided over a period of economic prosperity here that older black voters remember.Black legislators also recall fondly that Mr. Clinton knew every word to "Lift Every Voice and Sing," dubbed the "black national anthem." Many older voters simply say they don't know Mr. Sanders and question his commitment to their communities. "Clinton was our first black president," said Blossom Lordman, a 42-year-old waitress in Greenville. "He was the black president before Obama."Yet when Mr. Clinton returned to the state in 2008, he caught flak for comments that seemed dismissive of Jesse Jackson and Mr. Obama. The Clintons and black lawmakers have moved on from that moment, as the Congressional Black Caucus endorsed Mrs. Clinton this month.At the University of South Carolina, many students are kicking the tires of the Clinton legacy and questioning its impact on neighborhoods and families, said Bobby Donaldson, a history and African-American Studies professor who leads a dorm of 229 students.His colleague, Todd Shaw, a black political scientist, said his students are also largely backing Mr. Sanders. "Clinton is increasingly selling herself as the next chapter of the Obama administration," Mr. Donaldson said. "It's Sanders who is saying we will champion the audacity of hope."Many of their elders don't understand the impulse. They agree with Mrs. Clinton's frequent suggestion she can accomplish more--and question the commitment of Mr. Sanders to their communities. Fletcher Smith, a longtime state representative who recently introduced Mr. Clinton, said he had tried to reason with younger voters."The young people didn't have to suffer like we did," Mr. Smith said. "They didn't go through everything we've been through. We've been through a whole lot with the Clintons, and we haven't seen a whole lot from Bernie."To be sure, many college students are also embracing Mrs. Clinton.Angel Risher wore her Miss Allen University sash and tiara to recent rallies for both the Clinton and Sanders camps. The student at Allen, a private, historically black institution, said she is picking Mrs. Clinton, inspired by Bill Clinton's half-hour synopsis of his wife's accomplishments.Herbert Johnson III, a 20-year-old junior at Allen from St. George, S.C., said he was supporting Mrs. Clinton because of her brand and association with Mr. Clinton. "She's got that feeling like she'd be a good president."Yet at campuses across the state, Mr. Sanders is generating more excitement, according to students and activists. During a recent event at the University of South Carolina, dozens of hands went into the air when students were asked if they had seen Mr. Sanders, while several had attended a Clinton event.Joe Fretwell, the student body president at Furman University and a Clinton supporter, said it often made sense to canvass in predominantly black neighborhoods around campus because Mr. Sanders was so popular among students."Every time I get on Facebook I see him," said Wallace Moore, a sophomore at Allen University.Both campaigns are trying to woo black college students in the state, yet it remains uncertain how many of the students are registered to vote--and how many will actually go to the polls.Mr. Sanders has young volunteers going door to door and is advertising on black radio, said Gilda Cobb-Hunter, a prominent black Democratic state legislator. "I believe the Clinton campaign had taken the state and the voters in this state for granted up until a few weeks ago," she said. "They're lucky that we're one week out," she added, limiting Mr. Sanders's time to make even further inroads with voters.Write to Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.comCredit: By Josh Dawsey and Valerie Bauerlein

article name: Bernie Sanders's Free Tuition Failed a Cost Test in Past; Cities and states couldn't afford programs of the type championed by the Democratic presidential candidate
article text: WASHINGTON--Eighteen-year-old Bernie Sanders didn't pay tuition for his freshman year at Brooklyn College in 1959, nor did any other of the college's roughly 17,000 full-time undergraduates.New York City's public colleges didn't charge tuition back then. Students at University of California campuses and a number of other colleges around the country had a similar deal back then. Although free tuition helped tens of thousands of working-class students afford bachelor degrees, the policy was eventually scrapped as costs escalated.Now, Mr. Sanders wants to reinstate free tuition, but on a scale that dwarfs anything that came before. Public colleges should be like public high schools, the Vermont Democrat argues: no charge for instruction."In 2016, in many respects, a college degree is the equivalent of what a high-school degree was 50 or 60 years ago, in terms of going out and getting a good job," Mr. Sanders said on MSNBC earlier this month.The tuition proposal is one of the reasons Mr. Sanders's presidential bid has a big following on campuses, though his plan has been derided by his opponents as pie-in-the-sky or wasteful. Earlier this month, after the MSNBC session, the campaign of Democratic rival Hillary Clinton put out a press release headlined "Millionaires don't need free college." She said any tuition assistance should be targeted to the poor or middle class.A look at the history of the free-tuition movement gives a sense of what is politically feasible today, as families struggle with $1.2 trillion of student debt and difficulty affording college at all. Free-tuition colleges flourished at a time when student enrollment was small "and there was great optimism and interest in supporting higher education" among state lawmakers, said University of California at Berkeley education researcher John Aubrey Douglass.Not charging for instruction was less a matter of ideology than practicality, say economic and education historians. As the industrial revolution reshaped 19th and early 20th century America, city and state legislatures sought to increase the number of teachers, engineers, agricultural experts and other professionals who could help local industries and farms.The University of California dates to 1868 and initially focused on agriculture, mining and medicine. The City University of New York started as the Free Academy of New York in 1849, which educated immigrants, and morphed into a broader university. For many years, the State University of New York's "normal" schools, which trained future teachers, also didn't charge tuition.Even those state colleges that had tuition charged minimal amounts. In 1933, the average in-state undergraduate tuition, plus fees, was about $1,100 in today's dollars, according estimates by Harvard University economists Claudia Goldin and Lawrence Katz. By 2015, the College Board said, in-state tuition in four-year public colleges had jumped to $9,410.State colleges could charge so little because relatively few people went to college. In 1959, when Mr. Sanders studied at Brooklyn College, 2.2 million students attended public colleges nationally, the Education Department estimates. Enrollment now is 15.3 million. The cost of educating so many more students outstripped the willingness--or ability--of city and state legislatures to pay the tab.The City University of New York started charging for tuition in 1976 after the city teetered on the brink of bankruptcy, and the university ran out of money.The city's finances had become a shambles, said a study by the New York Fed in 1976, because of a huge increase in spending on social services as the city's manufacturing sector collapsed and its middle class exodus accelerated. Social Services jumped to 23% of the city's budget in 1975 from 13% in 1965. Spending on education--at all levels--also took a bigger bite out of city finances.In 1975, undergraduate enrollment at Brooklyn College, one of CUNY's largest campuses, had almost doubled to 30,000 undergraduates from the time Mr. Sanders attended college there.The University of California dropped free tuition in a less dramatic fashion. Over time, it charged students increasingly high "fees"--about $2,800 in 1975, adjusted for inflation--until it finally embraced the term "tuition" during the economic downturn of the early 1990s, said Mr. Douglass. Undergraduate enrollment at that college tripled between 1960 and 1990 to 125,000 students.In both New York and California, free tuition packed a powerful political punch and was only discarded under economic duress. Even during New York City's financial crisis, the city initially rejected termination of free tuition, wrote Judith Glazer Raymo, an emeritus professor at Long Island University, in a history of free tuition."The struggle to adopt tuition might jeopardize support from middle-class students" who might go elsewhere if they had to pay, she wrote.That broad base of support is a big reason Mr. Sanders wants universal free tuition at state schools instead of targeting middle- and lower-income students. Think of Social Security, said Warren Gunnels, Mr. Sanders's policy director."It's not important that Bill Gates gets a Social Security check," he said. If you limit the program, "after a while, people complain that it's just a welfare program" and political support evaporates, he said.But making the program universal drives up costs, which the Sanders campaign estimates at $750 billion over 10 years.Mr. Sanders would pay for that by taxing the sales of securities, a plan that would be bound to encounter fierce resistance from Wall Street. Economists argue that such a tax would depress stock prices somewhat and drive up interest rates on bonds.For Mr. Gunnels, the combination of free tuition and a financial transaction tax is part of what Mr. Sanders calls the "political revolution" necessary to bring about change."When the Senate and House hold a vote, [a President Sanders] would be able to look out at the mall and see one million or two million college students marching," Mr. Gunnels said.Nothing like that was needed to bring free tuition into existence early on--and student protests weren't sufficient to stop the programs from eventually being scrapped. Free tuition was replaced with the current system, and that system has helped produce a vast increase in enrollment, an expansion of state university facilities, and heavy student debt.Returning to free tuition, even if it were possible, would create its own problems, argued Roger Geiger, a Pennsylvania State University education professor. Free tuition would explode enrollment at state schools that are already having trouble handling current enrollment.Weak liberal arts colleges would be forced out of business by low-cost competition and elite ones would depend even more on wealthier students who could afford to pay tuition. "This would cause more inequality," he said, the opposite of what Mr. Sanders seeks.No way, responds Mr. Gunnels, the Sanders policy chief. With millions of students scrambling to pay college loans, he said, "the idea that making public colleges and universities tuition-free would somehow increase inequality is absurd."As for Mr. Sanders, he finished his undergraduate degree at the private University of Chicago, one of the nation's most elite schools. His campaign declined to comment on his college decisions and how they were paid for.Shortly after he graduated, the school doubled its tuition to help pay for a building spree at the university and a big increase in enrollment.Credit: By Bob Davis

article name: Bernie Sanders's Campaign And One Big Idea, or Not
article text: Regarding Joseph Epstein's "Bernie and the 'Lunatic of One Idea'" (op-ed, Feb. 17): Mr. Epstein wrote the book "Envy" in the Oxford University Press series on the seven deadly sins. In that book he says something profoundly true and relevant to the Bernie Sanders one-idea socialist appeal: "All one can say for certain is the feeling of envy isn't likely to increase one's capacity for happiness. Quite the reverse."Rosemary L. MathewsSanta Fe, N.M.---Although I am not a Bernie Sanders supporter, I question Mr. Epstein's criticism of Mr. Sanders's sole position. Consider Isaiah Berlin's famous essay on the hedgehog and the fox, articulating the idea that sometimes the hedgehog is more effective than the multifaceted fox since he knows just one defining idea. Sometimes having one good idea can be enough.Marc ChafetzWashington
