article name: Bernie Sanders Fans Go Online to Volunteer, Crash--and Date; Young, tech-savvy volunteers create apps and websites to track his popularity, prod donors and find places to sleep
article text: CAMDEN, S.C.-- On Sunday, a makeshift family of Bernie Sanders volunteers rose early. They dispersed toward Virginia, Georgia and other Super Tuesday states, stirred by a love for Mr. Sanders's scrappy idealism and aided by a website that connected them to Sanders supporters with spare rooms and couches.Mr. Sanders had lost the day before by 48 points to Hillary Clinton in South Carolina's Democratic primary, a blow to the dozen volunteers who had arrived from across the country to knock on doors for the Vermont senator, then crash at an empty-nester's sprawling house they found on the website BernieBNB.com .The young, tech-savvy fans who have flocked to Mr. Sanders have created a constellation of apps and websites to track his popularity, prod new donors and even send pizza to campaign offices.Three months ago, New Yorker Will Lockhart knew Mr. Sanders only as "that guy who yells in the Senate." Soon, ubiquitous social media chatter convinced Mr. Lockhart, a 25-year-old physics graduate student, to download a phone-bank app for calling voters and turn to other apps to find ways to get to South Carolina."If Bernie wins," Mr. Lockhart said, "it's because of the Internet."While other campaigns have hired top digital strategists, promote official mobile apps and maintain a substantial social media presence, none have been supported by a distributed network of volunteer coders and online denizens like Mr. Sanders's has.Independent of the senator's campaign apparatus, his backers have created a variety of websites and apps--from Bernie selfie filters to mobile games like Flappy Bern, a take on the addictive iPhone game Flappy Bird.Some, like Bernie BNB, serve to connect Mr. Sanders's supporters in real life, reminiscent of 2004 Democratic presidential hopeful Howard Dean's Meetup.com groups. Others are political twists on relatively new technology, akin to Franklin Delano Roosevelt's use of radio to build popular support for the New Deal in the 1930s.Mrs. Clinton has nearly four times as many Twitter followers as Mr. Sanders has, while GOP favorite Donald Trump has almost twice as many followers on Instagram. Yet an online search for dating, room-hosting and transportation apps developed by supporters of Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Trump, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio turned up little comparable to what Sanders backers have created.In New York City, the loss in South Carolina was an immediate topic of conversation at Jeremiah Pegues's first date Saturday with a young woman he had met on Bernie Singles, he said."People are uniting around the one thing you usually do not mention on a date," Mr. Pegues said. "Because people so freely talk about their political persuasion they will get their religious affiliations out of the way, too."Susan Aiken, a mother of three grown sons who posted her house in rural Camden, S.C., on Bernie BNB, discovered that hosting a diverse, young crowd was renewing. "Our future is set," said Ms. Aiken, who plans to go out on the road campaigning herself.The rotating cast of volunteers spent anywhere from a night to a week with her, sharing cooking duties and swapping stories from the campaign trail late into the night.Like most new technological phenomena, the Internet of Bernie has a few quirks. Sanders backers can use Bernie BNB to find six places to stay in Raleigh, N.C., in the run-up to the state's March 15 primary, but would have to book one without the benefit of pictures or reviews."What I would consider my vetting system is that these people are Bernie supporters," said Erica Calegari of San Francisco. After a quick phone call, she stayed for a couple of nights with a male host in Columbia, S.C., a leap of faith she said she wouldn't normally take with a stranger.Bernie Singles, meantime, has been beset by Trump "trolls" who mock and harass the Sanders fans looking for dates. As many as 100 new members a day have registered with a version of the name Donald Trump. They fill the chat rooms with questions such as "How do you propose to pay for Mr. Sanders's promises?"On Sunday, Bernie Singles members were trying to boost each other's spirits, musing over an illustration of Hillary Clinton wearing a backward baseball cap and holding a skateboard, a dig at what some see as her disconnect from young voters. "Hillary trying to be one with the kids but Bernie is everywhere," said one user, Cecilia R., who uploaded the image to a chat room.Write to Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.com and Douglas MacMillan at douglas.macmillan@wsj.comCredit: By Valerie Bauerlein and Douglas MacMillan

article name: Sanders Campaign Evolves From Small Startup to Election Machine; Vermont senator's once-struggling operation ramps up fundraising, spending
article text: WASHINGTON--Once a simple pleasure, a walk outdoors for Bernie Sanders and his wife Jane is now a complicated logistical challenge with an entourage in tow.A Secret Service detail accompanies the couple everywhere, and finding time between frenetic rounds of flights, rallies and phone calls is no small feat."When there is a break in the schedule, he'll bolt for a walk," Mrs. Sanders said in an interview. "It was in the low teens in Wisconsin (on a recent campaign stop) and we said, 'Hey, we can either eat lunch or go for a walk.' So we went for a walk."Not so long ago the Sanders campaign had the feel of a startup inching its way toward relevance. Nearly a year after launching, it has evolved into a more professionalized operation that looks and feels like a modern presidential campaign, with all the complications that entails. Money is pouring in--and rushing out the door.After holding out for months following his April 2015 entry into the primary race, Mr. Sanders agreed over the summer to hire a polling expert--although he didn't start paying for surveys until the fall. A voter modeling firm that worked for Barack Obama's 2008 campaign now helps the campaign reach targeted voters."At the beginning, when they were talking about it (polling) we were like, 'We don't want polling,'" Mrs. Sanders said. "And then we finally said, 'OK, if you feel you need it for the ads, that's fine, but we're going to approve the ads. You're not going to say anything we don't want to say.' "The campaign has been spending more heavily on TV ads and staff than at any point in the race. In January, the Sanders campaign spent about $35 million--$15 million more than was spent by rival Hillary Clinton, marking the first time Mr. Sanders has outspent the former secretary of state. It was the first fundraising period when the Sanders campaign spent more than it raised; Mr. Sanders raised $21 million in January.Mr. Sanders's spending on ads leapt to $14 million in January, up from on average $3.5 million a month in the previous quarter.Overall, Mrs. Clinton's campaign has outspent Mr. Sanders, according to the most recent filings: She paid out $97 million through the end of January, to his $81 million.There is no sign donations are drying up, though; the campaign said Monday that it raised more than $42 million in February alone, its biggest monthly haul to date.It is unclear how far Mr. Sanders's money and organization will carry him. He was walloped in South Carolina on Saturday and Clinton aides are confident that after 11 states vote on Tuesday they will be well on their way to an insurmountable lead in delegates. Still, veterans of presidential campaigns say they are impressed by what Mr. Sanders has built so far.David Plouffe, campaign manager for Mr. Obama's 2008 campaign and now a supporter of Mrs. Clinton, said in an interview: "He's run an amazing campaign. Who would have imagined that he would have put together this kind of an organization?"A newcomer to national politics, the junior senator from Vermont has presided over a dramatic expansion of a campaign apparatus that initially struggled to keep up with the large crowds and attention he commanded.Tad Devine, a senior Sanders adviser, said this wasn't a case in which the candidate had been plotting a presidential run for years. Preparations were minimal. A week before Mr. Sanders declared his candidacy on April 30th, Mr. Devine said he met privately with Mr. Sanders and his wife and came away unsure about their intentions."When I left I didn't know which way it was going to go," he said, adding that on the day of the announcement, "There was no account, no real money, no headquarters and no organization."Last summer, Mr. Sanders was seen trundling through airports waiting for his group to be called by Southwest Airlines gate agents. His motorcade consisted of a single rental car driven by an aide. Now he flies on chartered jets and rides inside the cocoon of Secret Service vehicles.Some of the dynamics remain unchanged. Mr. Sanders still feels he has no need for a speechwriter and typically writes most of the material he uses in stump speech.Atop the campaign hierarchy are the same small group of advisers who have been with him for years. "The core of the campaign remains the same," Mrs. Sanders said. "A half dozen of us" are involved in the "major decisions and strategy and plans."But layers of aides have been added. The campaign's spending has substantially expanded in recent months. In January, it spent $2.5 million on more than 560 staffers in nearly every state, compared with spending on average of $1.9 million a month in the final quarter of 2015.He didn't start spending a substantial amount on polling until December, when he paid out about $250,000 to a San Francisco-based firm for "research/polling." In January, he paid the firm, Tulchin Research, more than double that amount--a total of about $600,000, disclosure records show.Mr. Sanders has also increased his reliance on outside consultants. His most recent filing showed his campaign paid at least nine consulting firms nearly $1 million in January, up from a total of about $600,000 in the last three months of 2015.In his first filing after announcing his campaign, he reported paying just four of those consulting firms a total of less than $30,000.In the fall, Mr. Sanders hired HaystaqDNA, a predictive analytics firm that helps campaigns target their messages, and in January he began ramping up payments to the company. Of the $730,000 the campaign has paid the firm since October, about $500,000 was paid out in January. HaystaqDNA was also contracted by Mr. Obama's campaign in 2008.As much as Mr. Sanders talks about creating a political "revolution," the new aides are following the conventions of modern campaigning.In a tiny office in remote Pahrump, Nev., before the state's caucuses on Feb. 20, sat a paid Sanders campaign field organizer. When asked about the race, he said he needed permission to talk. He got on his cellphone to make the request--and was told to stay silent.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Make Last Push for Super Tuesday Voters; Vermont senator needs win in Massachusetts to dent rival's momentum
article text: Hillary Clinton talked to voters in Minneapolis on Super Tuesday , while Bernie Sanders was back in his home state of Vermont to cast his vote before 8 a.m.Mr. Sanders accompanied by his wife, Jane, took selfies with voters in Burlington, Vt. "I will tell you after a lot of thought, I voted for me for president," a smiling Mr. Sanders told one man after taking a selfie with him.Meanwhile, Mrs. Clinton dropped by a coffee shop and local market in Minneapolis to greet local residents and encourage them to turn out for the state's caucuses Tuesday night. She planned to spend the evening in Miami.Tuesday marks the busiest day on the primary calendar and one with the largest number of convention delegates up for grabs. For Democrats, 859 delegates will be allocated, more than a third of the 2,383 needed to clinch the Democratic nomination. The polls will start closing at 7 p.m. ET.Mr. Sanders, who held a rally outside Boston Monday night, needs a win in Massachusetts to dent Mrs. Clinton's momentum and counterbalance the victories that she is expected to secure in the South.Read More in Capital Journal* Clinton and Trump Hold Edge Going Into Super Tuesday* Mapping Out 'Trump Country' on Super Tuesday* Early Voting Seen as a Boost for Front-Runners in Super Tuesday Polls"Your state led the American Revolution," Mr. Sanders told several thousand people gathered in Milton High School's gymnasium outside Boston. "Now it is time for Massachusetts to lead a political revolution!"Bill Clinton also led a rousing get-out-the-vote rally in Worcester, Mass., for his wife late Monday night, imploring hundreds of supporters to "drag everybody you can to the polls.""You said I would give 'em hell here tonight," he cracked, when he took the podium after a warm introduction. "I would rather just give 'em Hill."He continued his campaigning on Tuesday, drawing thousands of people at a polling station in New Bedford, Mass. A local election official said turnout appeared to be higher than normal.In contesting a state that borders his home state of Vermont, Mrs. Clinton is trying to deny her rival a liberal beachhead and to build on her growing delegate lead."If she wins by even a little, I think she can claim to really shut Bernie Sanders down," said Scott Ferson, a Democratic strategist in Boston who isn't working for either campaign. The question, he said, would become: "If Bernie can't win in Massachusetts, where does he win?"Clinton campaign officials have said the state's demographics, liberal profile and proximity to Vermont play to Mr. Sanders's strengths. Polls show Mrs. Clinton with a single-digit lead. But Jennifer Palmieri, Mrs. Clinton's communications director, said the state presents a challenge for the former senator and secretary of state.The "optics of who wins Massachusetts is very important," said Democratic state Sen. Dan Wolf, a Sanders backer and founder and chief executive of regional airline Cape Air. "People are watching to see what Massachusetts does, and therefore we will be center stage tomorrow."The division in Massachusetts is rippling through families, like Diane and Paul Kelsch, a married couple who live in Quincy, Mass. At the Sanders rally, Ms. Kelsch, 67, said she planned to vote for Mrs. Clinton, whom she viewed as "more competent."But Mr. Kelsch, 69, said he plans to vote for Mr. Sanders because he likes the candidate's ideas on health care, education and more. "I call it enlightened socialism," he said.Mrs. Clinton and her husband have longtime ties to the state, and she notched a double-digit win over then-Sen. Barack Obama in the 2008 Massachusetts presidential primary. This year, she has made an aggressive play for the state during the final sprint to voting.Mr. Sanders has said he still sees a path to the nomination, predicting that he would collect "a very good share" of the more than 800 delegates to be awarded on Tuesday. To accomplish that, he would need to win more than his home state of Vermont, the only Super Tuesday state where polls show him with a decisive lead.While Mrs. Clinton enjoys backing from most elected officials in the state, the army of Massachusetts Democratic activists who helped elevate Elizabeth Warren to the U.S. senate in 2012 are more divided. Ms. Warren, who sounds the same populist themes as does Mr. Sanders, has stayed neutral in the race but is nonetheless affecting voters."I think of Bernie as a bigger, better Elizabeth," said Tony Badman, 70, a retired data-program manager who lives in Marlborough and is door-knocking, sign-waving and calling voters to generate support for Mr. Sanders."I just have a belief that Bernie Sanders--along with the millions of people who he is inspiring--is the way to bring about the changes that are necessary in what can best be described as an establishment that has gone completely wrong," he said.While Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders had hit pause on their quarrel over who is the true progressive in this race, Mrs. Clinton on Monday told voters: "I am a progressive who likes to make progress."Garrett Sullivan, 61, a longtime Clinton supporter from Springfield, said she has proposed the right mix of policies, including plans to rein in college debt and to bolster struggling cities.He is less familiar with Mr. Sanders but said, "I don't support his agenda.""I don't think we should go further to the left," he added.Write to Jennifer Levitz at jennifer.levitz@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Jennifer Levitz and Colleen McCain Nelson

article text: BOSTON--Hillary and Bill Clinton crisscrossed Massachusetts on Monday, and Sen. Bernie Sanders made one last pitch in the state, in a set of appearances that showed the practical and symbolic importance of the voting here on Super Tuesday.Mr. Sanders needs a win in Massachusetts to dent Mrs. Clinton's momentum and counterbalance the victories she is expected to secure in the South.
