article name: Bernie Sanders Plays Down Long Odds; The Democrat says he sees a path to win and keeps up his swipes against front-runner Clinton
article text: Democratic presidential contender Bernie Sanders said Sunday that he has a pathway to win the nomination, playing down a stinging defeat in South Carolina that reflected heavy losses among African-American voters and tested the viability of his campaign."We got decimated," Mr. Sanders said Sunday on NBC. But he said that "we're looking to the future--not looking back," and that while "it's going to be a tough fight, I think we can pull it off."African-American voters made up 61% of the electorate in South Carolina, and Hillary Clinton, the Democratic front-runner, won 86% of their support, according to exit polls. That propelled her Saturday to a landslide win of 74% to 26% for Mr. Sanders, a Vermont senator.Mr. Sanders on CBS predicted his campaign would do well in several states holding Democratic contests on Tuesday, including Minnesota, Colorado, Oklahoma, Massachusetts and Vermont.Looking further ahead, Mr. Sanders said he could win the delegate-rich states of California, Michigan and New York.Sunday in Oklahoma City, Mr. Sanders fired up the crowd with his signature brand of economic populism, calling for a higher minimum wage, increased Social Security benefits, paid family leave, government-guaranteed health care for all and tuition-free college. He begged voters to turn out at the polls."The only way we make changes is when millions of people stand up and fight back," Mr. Sanders told an audience filled with cheering young people.Support among younger votes was a bright spot in the South Carolina contest for Mr. Sanders, who predicted that his left-of-center politics would prove appealing as the contest heads beyond the four early nominating states."Tuesday, we're going to have over 800 delegates being selected," Mr. Sanders said on CBS. "I think we're going to win a very good share of those delegates. The important point is that people throughout this country are resonating to our message."Mr. Sanders continued to press his case against Mrs. Clinton, hitting her for being backed by a super PAC, which allows unlimited donations from large contributors, and calling on her to release transcripts of paid speeches made to Goldman Sachs Group. "It has to be an unbelievably great speech," Mr. Sanders jabbed.In seeking to sharpen the contrast with Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Sanders also turned his attention to foreign policy. That subject fueled then-Sen. Barack Obama's rise to the White House in 2008, when he relentlessly attacked Mrs. Clinton for voting to authorize the 2003 U.S. invasion of Iraq when she was a senator from New York.Mr. Sanders, who opposed the invasion, continues to hammer Mrs. Clinton for that vote as well as her later support, while she was secretary of state, for military intervention in Libya. In both cases, the U.S. intervention helped topple dictators but failed to create stable political systems in the aftermath."You can't just go forward with regime change--you've got to be thinking about the day after," Mr. Sanders said on NBC. "I think her approach to foreign policy and mine are just quite different."Mrs. Clinton has said she made a mistake in voting in 2002 to authorize the Iraq invasion, but she also has said that she understands the complexities of the Middle East better than Mr. Sanders.Mr. Sanders on Sunday picked up support from Democratic Rep. Tulsi Gabbard of Hawaii, a member of National Guard. Ms. Gabbard, who becomes the fourth Democratic lawmaker in Congress to endorse the Vermont senator, quit her post as the vice chair of the Democratic National Committee in order to back Mr. Sanders.Ms. Gabbard said it was important to have a commander in chief "who exercises good judgment" so that "we don't continue to find ourselves in these failures that have resulted in chaos in the Middle East."Write to Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.com and David Harrison at david.harrison@wsj.comCredit: By Siobhan Hughes and David Harrison

article name: Super Tuesday Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Leading in Texas, Georgia and Tennessee; Bernie Sanders expected to do well in some Super Tuesday states, including his home state of Vermont
article text: Hillary Clinton has built substantial leads over Sen. Bernie Sanders in Texas, Georgia and Tennessee ahead of Super Tuesday voting this week, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll finds.Eleven states and one U.S. territory hold Democratic primaries or caucuses on Tuesday. Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Sanders by 34 percentage points in Georgia, 26 points in Tennessee and 21 points in Texas, the survey findsHer lead is built in large part on commanding margins among African-American voters.Republican Poll* Trump Leads in Tennessee, Georgia; Cruz Ahead in TexasMrs. Clinton has a 54-point advantage in Georgia among African-Americans, who make up a majority of the likely Democratic voter pool, the poll finds. Mrs. Clinton has a 68-point advantage among African-Americans in Tennessee, where the poll finds that group accounting for about 30% of likely voters.Mrs. Clinton's lead is smaller among white voters in those states. She essentially divides that group in Georgia, carrying 50% to Mr. Sanders' 47%.The survey finds that in Texas, Latinos make up a slightly larger share of likely voters than do whites. Mrs. Clinton holds a 5-point lead over Mr. Sanders among Latino likely voters in the survey, while carrying whites by 17 percentage points and African-Americans by 58 points.Mr. Sanders is expected to do well in some Super Tuesday states, including his home state of Vermont. His campaign is eyeing wins in two states, Minnesota and Colorado, that hold caucuses, a forum in which a relatively small group of motivated supporters can swing the outcome.The strengths Mr. Sanders has carried into prior nominating contests are apparent in the new Journal/NBC/Marist poll. He wins among independent voters who say they'll participate in Democratic primaries in the three states surveyed, and he carries voters under age 45 in Tennessee and Texas. Those voter groups helped propel Mr. Sanders to a resounding win in New Hampshire and what essentially was a tie in Iowa.More* Hillary Clinton Wins South Carolina Democratic Primary* Hillary Clinton Defends Obama Record in Alabama Stop* Five Percent Growth? Bernie Sanders Campaign Defends Disputed Economic Analysis* Sanders Claims Archrival Hillary Clinton Is Cloning the Bern* Bloomberg Would Lose Big to Sanders and Trump--WSJ/NBC PollBut the new polls also suggest the depth of Mr. Sanders' challenge. Many of the 11 Super Tuesday states have large minority populations and relatively few independents in the Democratic voting pool, factors that favor Mrs. Clinton.For Mr. Sanders, the Texas polls show that he has made some inroads into the Latino community even has he continues to struggle with black voters. Mrs. Clinton narrowly edges out Mr. Sanders among likely Latino voters, 52% to 47%.The Journal/NBC/Marist poll of Georgia included 461 likely Democratic primary voters and had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.6 percentage points.The Texas survey included 381 likely Democratic voters and had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. In Tennessee, 405 likely Democratic primary voters were surveyed, and the survey had a margin of error of plus or minus 4.9 percentage points.Texas and Georgia were surveyed between Feb. 18 and Feb. 23. Tennessee was polled between Feb. 22 and Feb. 25.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Byron Tau

article name: As South Carolina Votes, Hillary Clinton's Southern Firewall Appears Poised to Pass First Test; Strong showing by Democratic front-runner, who holds big lead in polls, could hint to more struggles for Bernie Sanders
article text: COLUMBIA, S.C.--Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders made their final pitches to voters in South Carolina, where a strong showing by Mrs. Clinton, who has a double-digit lead in the polls, could hint at more struggles for Mr. Sanders.South Carolina Democratic Party officials are expecting a good turnout during Saturday's voting. Democratic Party Chairman Jamie Harrison said this week he is expecting between 350,000 and 400,000 voters to cast ballots. South Carolina polls will close at 7 p.m. EST.Mrs. Clinton held an outdoor rally in Columbia on Friday night, where she pledged to build on President Barack Obama's legacy. "We have work to do, but I'm excited about what we can do together," she told the crowd.She said the South Carolina primary is personally important to her and that she wants to send "a strong signal" Saturday that the state is ready for change.Former President Bill Clinton joined his wife on the trail Friday evening, calling their time in South Carolina a homecoming and telling voters that they can "change the future of this country by voting for Hillary."Mrs. Clinton, whose Southern firewall appears poised to pass its first test, has an eye on the Southern states that will vote on Super Tuesday, including Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee, Texas, Arkansas and Virginia.Her strength in the region, particularly among its many African-American Democratic voters, has been magnified by the Sanders campaign's decision not to try to match her investment here and elsewhere. Officials in some Super Tuesday states say they still are looking for indications that he is competing in the so-called SEC primary.A march outside a downtown Nashville coffee shop on Saturday will feature a half-dozen, life-size Bernie Sanders cutouts, but otherwise, there has been little sign of Mr. Sanders himself in Tennessee, Democrats said."You kind of get the feel that he doesn't think it's worthwhile coming," said Randall Rice, head of the Tennessee Democratic County Chairs Association, who is neutral in the race. "The Bernie group has come in and set up offices, but he's not been here as far as I know. Hillary has been here a few times."Mrs. Clinton will be back in Tennessee on Sunday.Mr. Sanders told supporters at a Friday night rally at the Township Auditorium in Columbia that "the people have the power in this country."Rapper Killer Mike said South Carolinians, and particularly black South Carolinians, shouldn't feel pressured to support Mrs. Clinton because others say they should, be it their mother ("Walk past her, walk to the polls") or their preacher ("Ask him what would Jesus really do.").Mr. Sanders is headed to Minnesota and Texas on Saturday to trumpet his free-college-tuition plan, and he won't be in South Carolina when the election results are announced.Justin Bamberg, one of a handful of black legislators who endorsed Mr. Sanders in South Carolina, said he wishes the Vermont senator could stay for a victory party, but, "realistically speaking, how can you get everywhere? You can't."Tharon Johnson, a Democratic strategist who served as the Southern regional director for Mr. Obama's 2012 campaign, said the reason Mr. Sanders isn't spending as much time in South Carolina as Mrs. Clinton "is because he now knows you have to develop a broad coalition of support in these Southern states, particularly where there's a high minority voting-age population."Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said the senator's best hope of winning South Carolina hinged on nabbing victories in Iowa, New Hampshire and Nevada, the first three contests.Mr. Sanders won the New Hampshire primary, came close in Iowa and lost Nevada. Absent an early trifecta of wins, Mr. Devine said the Sanders campaign now needs to focus on playing the long game and looking ahead to later contests."We still believe we have the best message, and while we had the advantage of having Iowa and New Hampshire the first and second states, she has the advantage of having so many states from the South so early in the process," Mr. Devine said. "She'll gain from that. Once that's over, the ball comes back to our court and we start to move into a number of states" where they expected to do well.But between then and now, Mrs. Clinton is likely to secure lopsided victories that illustrate her ability to attract the diverse coalition necessary for a Democratic candidate to win the general election. She also will rack up a slew of delegates in the process.More in Capital Journal* What to Watch for in South Carolina* Christie Embraces Trump as Billionaire and Rubio Trade Insults* GOP Debate Barrage May Be Too Late for Trump's Rivals* Rubio Presses Attack on 'Con Artist' Trump* IRS: Audit Scenario Claimed by Trump Is 'Rare'* Who's Winning the Delegate Race?* When Losing Presidential Candidates EndorseAlabama state Sen. Linda Coleman-Madison said Mrs. Clinton has a strong following among African-American voters there. The former senator and secretary of state has visited multiple times, and she and former President Bill Clinton will be back in the state on Saturday.African-American voters in Alabama generally have only a vague sense of Mr. Sanders, she said, so the senator's absence in the state ahead of Super Tuesday doesn't help. Some of Mr. Sanders's field organizers visited her office a while back, and she said she told them, "Quite frankly, I don't really know who he is."Mr. Sanders's wife, Jane, disputed suggestions that she and her husband haven't spent time in the South or have written off South Carolina or the region, attributing that narrative to what she called Clinton campaign "spin." Mr. Sanders appeared at campaign events in the state on Sunday, Tuesday and Friday, she noted."They spend a lot of time spinning, and so that's not accurate," she said. We've gone to Alabama--we were down there for the 50th anniversary of Selma."This week, though, Mr. Sanders spent most of his time outside of the South, venturing to Massachusetts, Missouri, Illinois, Michigan, Ohio and Oklahoma.Clinton campaign officials also asserted that Mr. Sanders had expended significant resources in South Carolina, hiring a large staff and making major ad buys."A win in South Carolina for us would be quite meaningful because despite the fact that in recent days Sen. Sanders has focused his travel on Super Tuesday states, it's clear he contested South Carolina very fiercely for a very long time," said Brian Fallon, Mrs. Clinton's press secretary. "One could make a judgment that they treated South Carolina as a testing ground for whether they could broaden his appeal and expand his support into a more diverse electorate."Mr. Fallon said he is confident Mrs. Clinton would emerge from Tuesday's contests with an advantage in pledged delegates. Mr. Sanders has focused the bulk of his recent efforts on five states--Vermont, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Colorado and Oklahoma--that represent only about one-third of the delegates that will be awarded on Super Tuesday."If he is not going to contest states that have a greater percentage of African-Americans and Latinos in them, then the math just won't work for him," Mr. Fallon said.Arian Campo-Flores contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com , Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Valerie Bauerlein and Peter Nicholas

article name: Bernie Supporters Not Clueless, Have Reasons
article text: Daniel J. Arbess wonders why, in supporting Bernie Sanders, young people are "voting against their interests" ("The Young and the Economically Clueless," op-ed, Feb. 20). Millennials' support of Bernie Sanders (and to a lesser extent Donald Trump) makes sense given the following: A college degree now costs upward of $200,000. To obtain this needed credential in today's economy, students must assume large amounts of debt at high interest rates with no clear certainty of being able to repay.The future cost of health care -- with larger deductibles and copays -- will be difficult for them to afford, not to mention the continuing need to subsidize an ever-expanding Medicare population. Then there's the growing obligation of public pension programs that generously support elders at their expense, not to mention the prospect that Social Security as currently structured may not be there for them at retirement.Virtually all the gains of the admittedly weak economic growth since 2008 have gone to the top 10%, and there is no assurance that even if somehow the growth rate increases, our current "winner take all" economic system won't continue to leave them behind. They don't have faith in a system that has taxpayers bailing out the financial sector (with its excessive compensation) with absolutely no financial or legal accountability, but which does nothing to help individuals struggling with student loans and mortgage foreclosures.Given these considerations, one could argue that a vote for free university education, universal health care, accountability for Wall Street and a much more progressive tax code is very much in the millennials' best interest.Walter B. RoseSan Anselmo, Calif.---Millennials are making the statement that politics as usual won't work in the future.Howard LandisNaples, Fla.---History books are filled with examples of narrow-minded "thinkers" who cannot feel the pulse of the people. The outcome is always the same: revolution. Maybe that's the real reason why so many millennials are doing what they are doing. They are starting to believe in a revolution. They are not clueless.Carlos MontesTroy, N.Y.

article name: Clinton Works for a Win in South Carolina; Sanders insists his campaign hasn't ceded the state's Democratic primary to his rival
article text: KINGSTREE, S.C.--Hillary Clinton has been crisscrossing South Carolina, with as many as four events a day, showing diligence in the state and loyalty to its African-American voters who could bolster her chances in Saturday's Democratic primary.In contrast, her rival, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, is spending much of his time this week courting college-age voters in Ohio and Oklahoma, an itinerary that could amount to ceding the South and its powerful black voting blocs to Mrs. Clinton. African-American voters will likely make up more than half of the electorate in South Carolina's Democratic primary.Mrs. Clinton's focus has mostly been on criminal justice reform and income inequality. "We've got work to do to help more people be able to knock down those barriers that stand in their way," she said. "And that includes taking on systemic racism which is still a problem in America."The Sanders campaign is running an energetic ground game in South Carolina, with hundreds of volunteers knocking on doors, piling into the campaign's half-dozen offices and spending hours a week calling voters.Volunteer Judy Milburn Lake likes to say that "to see Bernie is to love him," and she's disappointed that many South Carolinians haven't had the chance to eyeball Mr. Sanders, who has spent comparatively little time here in the campaign's closing weeks.Ms. Lake, a retired elementary school counselor from Myrtle Beach, said she hopes the volunteer efforts help hold Mrs. Clinton to only a single-digit victory here. "I think if people would have seen him and talked to him, it would've made a difference," Ms. Lake said.The senator from Vermont remains relatively unknown to a lot of voters in this state. And with just a day remaining before the primary, many said they were backing Mrs. Clinton by default.Yvette Duckson, a team leader at the Husqvarna plant in Orangeburg, said she plans to vote for the former secretary of state in part because she doesn't know much about Mr. Sanders."I think he could have spent a little more time down here if he wanted us to know who he is," she said.Mr. Sanders hasn't abandoned the state. He was in Greenville on Sunday and then Columbia on Tuesday for a CNN town hall event. He held a news conference on poverty with two prominent black legislators early Wednesday before setting off to Kansas City, Mo.At the news conference, Mr. Sanders rejected suggestions that he is favoring Super Tuesday states over South Carolina. "No, no, no, no, no," Mr. Sanders said. "We are fighting here in South Carolina as hard as we can."Polls show a decided advantage for the former secretary of state. In a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll last week, Mrs. Clinton held a 28-percentage-point lead over Mr. Sanders among likely Democratic voters in South Carolina.Todd Shaw, associate professor of political science and African-American studies at the University of South Carolina, said Mr. Sanders faces a strategic dilemma this week in dividing his time between South Carolina and the states that will hold the next primaries and caucuses. Although a win appears out of reach in South Carolina, he can't ignore the state "because that might look as if you're writing off the black vote," he said."He's walking a tightrope here because he needs to demonstrate here that he's taking South Carolina seriously because of the large African-American vote here," Mr. Shaw said. "At the same time, of course he has to keep his eye on the prize of the states that may actually net him a victory or at least a close call."Mr. Sanders is expected to come back to South Carolina Friday afternoon for two events.On Thursday, Mrs. Clinton had the Palmetto State to herself. And, while Mr. Sanders hopscotched from Ohio to Illinois to Michigan, the entire Clinton family deployed across South Carolina. Mrs. Clinton and former President Bill Clinton each had a full day's worth of campaign rallies planned, and daughter Chelsea Clinton appeared at her own event in Charleston.Mr. Sanders is trying to use surrogates to reach voters in his absence. His wife Jane spoke to several dozen Sanders backers at an education forum on Tuesday in Columbia, where she greeted supporters and made the case for free college tuition and educational opportunities for all.An ad with director Spike Lee endorsing "my brother, Bernie Sanders" is running on black radio. Actor Danny Glover has been stumping for the Vermont senator in multiple South Carolina cities, telling voters that Bernie Sanders "belongs to us."But Sanders supporters privately acknowledge feeling burned when Mr. Sanders said in his Feb. 20 concession speech in Nevada, "On to Super Tuesday," ignoring the primary here that will occur between those two events."Obviously, Hillary is going to win," said Dick Harpootlian, a Sanders supporter and former state Democratic Party chair. "The question is, 'What's the margin going to be? Does he narrow the margin down enough to be credible with the African-American community?' "Black voters would be critical to Mr. Sanders's chances in the long run, in the primary trek and the Nov. 8 general election, he said.Clinton fans say they hope South Carolina is the beginning of the end for Mr. Sanders's campaign.Todd Rutherford, the S.C. House Minority Leader, said Mr. Sanders has little support among black voters over age 25. Mr. Rutherford said he tried and failed to find an older black Sanders supporter to participate in a debate. "They're like unicorns," Mr. Rutherford said.Mrs. Clinton's continued presence in the state won over undecided voter Felisa McDavid, an elementary school principal who was among hundreds of members of black sorority Alpha Kappa Alpha members at a Wednesday campaign event. Ms. McDavid said she had initially been drawn to Mr. Sanders's focus on income inequality but Mrs. Clinton on Wednesday "spoke to my heart." She also said she hadn't seen much of Mr. Sanders: "I would think that if he does have a good following here, he'd capitalize on that," she said.Other Clinton supporters said Mr. Sanders probably was wise to spend much of his time elsewhere this week because he was unlikely to make inroads in the Palmetto State."It doesn't matter if Bernie Sanders comes to South Carolina," said Charmaine Washington, a freshman at Morris College in Sumter. "I would have voted for Hillary Clinton even if he would have come here."Write to Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.comCredit: By Valerie Bauerlein and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Hillary's Drive-By Attack on Guns; Her claim that a 2005 law supported by Sanders gave gun manufacturers 'immunity' is pure fiction.
article text: In a fundraising email Wednesday, Hillary Clinton said that "families from Sandy Hook are in court suing the manufacturer of the gun that killed their children, challenging the law that gives gun-makers legal immunity. I voted against that law. Senator Sanders voted for it." The email continued a line of attack that Mrs. Clinton and her surrogates have used for weeks against Bernie Sanders, her rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.The law Mrs. Clinton is talking about is the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act, which passed Congress in 2005 with bipartisan support. The onslaught against Mr. Sanders appears to be working: He has announced that he will sponsor legislation to repeal the law he once supported.As someone whose life has focused on tort law, not politics, I feel it is important to correct misconceptions about gun-manufacturer liability.Putting rhetoric aside, this much is clear: Traditional liability law still applies to gun manufacturers. The Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act specifically states that makers of firearms are liable for any defect in their products, such as if a gun misfires and harms someone, or if it does not work at all and fails at the moment it is lawfully needed.The notion that Congress gave gun manufacturers inappropriate immunity from lawsuits is a fiction. Instead the 2005 law stands for the unremarkable premise that when a business makes or sells a lawful product, but the product is used in an unlawful way, it is not the fault of the maker or seller. It is the fault of the criminal.The law also makes clear that gun manufacturers and sellers can be sued if they did something unlawful that led to the criminal act or injury. The bill does not protect retailers, for instance, if they sell a gun to someone they could have reasonably suspected was going to commit a crime. Nor does the legislation provide cover for anyone who violates laws regarding the sale or marketing of guns. These things are within the manufacturers' or dealers' control.Although some in the gun industry hailed the enactment of the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act, all it did was clarify existing law. Congress passed the act for the very practical purpose of curbing frivolous and agenda-driven lawsuits. In the late 1990s and early 2000s, some cities and antigun activist sought to subject gun manufacturers to liability for gang violence and other crimes. For instance, in 1998 Chicago sued 18 manufacturers for injunctive relief and over $400 million in damages for alleged harms associated with gun violence.If successful, this litigation would have undermined the long-standing principle of tort law that a manufacturer is not subject to liability when its product is put to an unlawful use by another. The cost of this unfair liability would affect myriad products.About 1,500 murders are committed every year with knives, according to the FBI . But it makes no sense, legally or socially, to hold knife manufacturers responsible for these deaths. Should someone hit by a drunken driver be able to sue the company that manufactured the driver's car? Keep in mind that car makers would pass these costs on to consumers by raising prices for everyone. No matter how carefully a manufacturer designs and builds its products, it is impossible to completely eliminate the possibility for harm at the hands of someone who criminally misuses that product.Nevertheless, abusive lawsuits attempting to expand manufacturers' liability have become common. They are most often filed by a plaintiff or agenda-driven group that wants to regulate an industry but has failed to persuade either Congress or state legislatures. Instead they sue and ask judges to impose their preferences.President Clinton's labor secretary, Robert Reich, labeled these types of lawsuits "regulation through litigation." Writing in the American Prospect in 2000, he concluded that federally sponsored lawsuits, such as those against gun and tobacco companies, were "end runs around the democratic process."Congress has historically stepped in to stop such abusive litigation and address liability issues of national importance. In 1994 lawmakers approved the General Aviation Revitalization Act to stop lawsuits for design defects against aircraft manufacturers whose planes flew without problems for more than 18 years. The legislation has been viewed by industry groups, legal scholars, and the Government Accountability Office as vital to restoring the industry's viability.In 1998 Congress passed the Biomaterials Assurance Access Act to prevent suppliers of raw materials used in medical devices from being sued for defects in those devices. In 2001 Congress passed the Teacher Protection Act to shield teachers and administrators when they properly follow school procedures in disciplining students. Legislators understood that the classroom should be a place for education, not unfounded litigation.By passing these laws in bipartisan fashion, Congress sent a strong message that unsound liability should not be condoned. That the same principle holds for manufacturers of guns ought to be kept in mind during this contentious campaign season.Mr. Schwartz is chairman of the public-policy group of Shook, Hardy & Bacon LLP in Washington, D.C.Credit: By Victor E. Schwartz

article name: Bernie Supporters Not Clueless, Have Reasons; A vote for free university education, universal health care and a much more progressive tax code is very much in the millennials' best interest.
article text: Daniel J. Arbess wonders why, in supporting Bernie Sanders, young people are "voting against their interests" ("The Young and the Economically Clueless ," op-ed, Feb. 20). Millennials' support of Bernie Sanders (and to a lesser extent Donald Trump) makes sense given the following: A college degree now costs upward of $200,000. To obtain this needed credential in today's economy, students must assume large amounts of debt at high interest rates with no clear certainty of being able to repay.The future cost of health care--with larger deductibles and copays--will be difficult for them to afford, not to mention the continuing need to subsidize an ever-expanding Medicare population. Then there's the growing obligation of public pension programs that generously support elders at their expense, not to mention the prospect that Social Security as currently structured may not be there for them at retirement.Virtually all the gains of the admittedly weak economic growth since 2008 have gone to the top 10%, and there is no assurance that even if somehow the growth rate increases, our current "winner take all" economic system won't continue to leave them behind. They don't have faith in a system that has taxpayers bailing out the financial sector (with its excessive compensation) with absolutely no financial or legal accountability, but which does nothing to help individuals struggling with student loans and mortgage foreclosures.Given these considerations, one could argue that a vote for free university education, universal health care, accountability for Wall Street and a much more progressive tax code is very much in the millennials' best interest.Walter B. RoseSan Anselmo, Calif.Millennials are making the statement that politics as usual won't work in the future.Howard LandisNaples, Fla.History books are filled with examples of narrow-minded "thinkers" who cannot feel the pulse of the people. The outcome is always the same: revolution. Maybe that's the real reason why so many millennials are doing what they are doing. They are starting to believe in a revolution. They are not clueless.Carlos MontesTroy, N.Y.

article name: Democratic Rivals' Black Outreach Efforts Fall Short in South Carolina; Presidential campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders haven't visited many barber shops, a staple of 2008 race
article text: COLUMBIA, S.C.--Eight years after Barack Obama's outreach to barber shops and beauty salons helped him secure a decisive win in South Carolina's Democratic primary, many hairstylists and other shop owners in this state say the presidential campaigns don't come calling any more.Barber-shop walls that were once adorned with Obama posters sit bare just a few days before the Saturday primary, and numerous salon owners who became de facto surrogates for the 2008 presidential candidates said they have never been contacted by the Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders campaigns."Obama's idea to use this barber shop and beauty shop component was really ingenious," said Quincy T. Mills, a Vassar College professor who wrote the book "Cutting Along the Color Line: Black Barbers and Barber Shops in America."This year, many voters say the Democratic contenders have fallen short in their outreach efforts in African-American neighborhoods, where churches, barber shops and beauty salons are traditional centers of the community. That could be contributing to a decline in interest in the race.Read More* High-Profile Clinton, Sanders Surrogates Battle in South Carolina* Five Percent Growth? Sanders Campaign Defends Disputed Economic AnalysisIn the first quarter of the 2008 campaign, more than 80% of African-Americans said they were very interested in the race that featured the presidential debut of then-Sen. Obama. In 2012, 71% counted themselves as among the most interested voters, the Wall Street Journal/NBC News polls show. In January, just 58% of African-Americans said they were highly interested in the Clinton-Sanders showdown.To be sure, a fair amount of that slide could be tied to the fact that the president isn't on the ballot this year, or on the campaign trail. But these voters and shop owners said neither campaign is pushing hard enough to change that dynamic.Barber Chauncey Harris still keeps his "Barack Obama '08" button stashed in his drawer at work, a reminder of the frequent visits Obama volunteers paid to his shop eight years ago.Mr. Harris, a master barber at Next Up Barber & Beauty in Columbia, had planned to support Mrs. Clinton in 2008, but Mr. Obama's campaign won his vote with personal attention "that made me feel good and changed my mind."This year, "nobody came," Mr. Harris said. He will cast his vote for Mrs. Clinton on Saturday, but mostly because he likes her husband, former President Bill Clinton, and he said he doesn't know much about Mr. Sanders.As the former secretary of state and the Vermont senator work to win the African-American vote, which is expected to represent more than half of the primary electorate, both campaigns said they are focusing on hair salons and barber shops.The Clinton campaign held an open house at a salon in Orangeburg on Tuesday night, and a Sanders television ad features a barber who is backing him. The Clinton and Sanders teams both have sent some high-profile surrogates, as well as campaign staffers and volunteers, to barber shops to make their pitches.This outreach is "really important because of the important conversations we have in the barber shops and the beauty shops, especially in the African-American community," said Symone Sanders, the senator's national press secretary. "This is an opportunity to take Sen. Sanders's message right where people are."But interviews with owners and employees at 10 salons and barber shops, including several that were politically active in 2008, revealed that none had been contacted by either campaign this year.Vassar's Mr. Mills said barber shops have been an influential gathering space in the black community for more than a century. After slavery ended, barbers commonly became local leaders, and their shops became "a sort of refuge," he said. And now, they offer "a waiting public," where people are getting their hair done, waiting their turn or simply sitting there to talk."Obama understood that because he frequented a black barber shop in Chicago," Mr. Mills said. "So, Obama understood these spaces in a way that Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton do not."Cindy Collins, state president of the century-old black hairdressers' group, the National Beauty Culturists' League, said, "When you go to the salon, you always talk to your hairdresser. We're like psychologists."Ms. Collins, who sees some of the same clients she began working with as a "shampoo girl," or apprentice, 35 years ago, still has pictures at Columbia's Salon Chon from a 2008 visit from Erika Alexander, a Clinton surrogate and actress best known for a role on "The Cosby Show." Ms. Collins said she has had no calls or visits from the Clinton or Sanders camps this election cycle.Keith Amos, owner of the Sports Talk Barbershop, has a photo of Mr. Obama hanging on the wall behind his chair. But after frequent visits from campaign volunteers in 2008, Mr. Amos, who remains an undecided voter, said he is still waiting to hear from either Democratic campaign this year."Obama brought the campaign to us," he said, adding that he thinks Mrs. Clinton has taken the African-American vote for granted this year.Actor Sean Patrick Thomas, one of the stars of the "Barbershop" movies, recently visited more than a dozen Columbia barber shops and salons to make the case for Mrs. Clinton, who holds a commanding lead in national polls among African-American voters."It's a fantastic spot to reach people within the black community, especially in the South, because we're really into our grooming," Mr. Thomas said in an interview. "You'd be amazed how fast that can spread the word."The Clinton campaign also worked to build support and mobilize volunteers with a Tuesday night event at Master's Hair Studio in Orangeburg. A band, a buffet and red, white and blue balloons greeted visitors who stopped by the open house. Most of the nearly 50 chairs sat empty, but eventually, 14 people trickled in to hear about Mrs. Clinton's policy proposals.Rick Wade, a prominent South Carolina politician and former Obama administration official, told the audience that Mr. Obama also started with small gatherings at barber shops, and it became "a movement that changed America."For its part, Mr. Sanders's campaign is spotlighting in a TV ad Mike Williams, who owns A Cut Above Barber Club in Summerville. Mr. Williams, 30 years old, said he likes everything Mr. Sanders stands for and thinks the senator's policy agenda would be better for his family.While Mr. Williams agreed to appear in the ad, he often keeps his political opinions to himself at work. And Sanders campaign signs and literature are nowhere to be found at his barber shop. "That's not because I'm not fired up. It's a place of business," Mr. Williams said. "People from all political parties come here, and I don't want to ruffle anybody's feathers."Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson And Valerie Bauerlein

article name: Obama's Best Day in Office? Today the President will encourage economic growth, plus he won't be able to close Gitmo and the math problems facing Cruz and Sanders.
article text: Could this be the best day of the Obama presidency? At 4:45 today in the Oval Office, the President is scheduled to sign the Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015. Buried within this customs bill is a permanent extension of the Internet Tax Freedom Act , which since 1998 has protected Internet access service and email from a flood of new taxes imposed by America's roughly 10,000 state and local revenue collectors. The law has been in place since 1998, but always as a temporary measure--until today.Readers can debate the President's finest moments. Certainly ordering the raid that killed Bin Laden is a contender, but some would argue it was more of a no-brainer than the tough call described by Hillary Clinton. There was the day the President signed the sequester and Washington momentarily moved toward fiscal sanity. And there was the time he signed the JOBS Act to allow more companies to go public. Perhaps readers will nominate others. But for now let's savor a rare advance for economic growth and innovation from the Obama White House.As for Tuesday, the news wasn't as good. President Obama said he's going to try again to close the terrorist detention camp at Guantanamo Bay in Cuba. "It's not going to happen--at least not if Mr. Obama follows the law," notes a Journal editorial . "Polls show the American people oppose closing Gitmo by about two to one, politicians in both parties oppose closing it, and the past seven years have taught that the camp plays an important role in keeping America safe .""Justice Antonin Scalia's death leaves the Supreme Court in a tough spot, but it is one for which the institution is prepared," write Josh Blackman and Ilya Shapiro . "Due to death, retirement or resignation--or recusal in individual cases--the high court has often been short-handed. Since World War II there have been 15 periods when the court had eight justices , and each time the court managed its docket without a hitch ."Our columnist William Galston says that two numbers make it difficult for Bernie Sanders and Ted Cruz to earn their respective parties' nominations. For Mr. Sanders, 22 is the percentage of black votes he earned in Nevada's Democratic Caucus, suggesting he will be unable to win future contests. Meanwhile, Mr. Cruz won just 27% of the evangelical vote in South Carolina's Republican primary, despite a pitch largely aimed at this constituency.Credit: By James Freeman

article name: Bad Math for Cruz and Sanders
article text: The two most important numbers to emerge from last Saturday's contests are 22 and 27.The former is the percentage of the African-American vote Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders received in losing Nevada's Democratic caucuses by six points to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. By contrast, according to the entrance polls, Mr. Sanders split the white vote with Mrs. Clinton.This leaves Mr. Sanders with a large strategic challenge. While African-Americans made up only 13% of caucus-goers in Nevada, they are likely to form more than half of the Democratic primary electorate in South Carolina on Saturday.Following a timely endorsement from South Carolina Rep. James Clyburn, the highest-ranking African-American in the House of Representatives, this crucial bloc of voters appears poised to deliver a solid majority to Mrs. Clinton. And African-Americans make up a substantial share of the Democratic base throughout the South, including 51% in Alabama and Georgia and 48% in Louisiana. Latinos make up about 30% of the Democratic primary vote in Texas and California. But in the other contests between now and mid-March, their share is certain to be much lower.Surprisingly, Mr. Sanders was not able to garner strong majorities among groups where he was expected to do well. Despite his class-based program and strong ideological appeal, he could gain no better than an even split with Mrs. Clinton among caucus-goers without college degrees and with incomes under $50,000. Even among caucus-goers who regard themselves as "very liberal," he won by a narrow margin of 52% to 47%, not nearly enough to counterbalance Mrs. Clinton's 22-point edge among self-styled moderates.Voters who want policies more liberal than President Obama's went for Mr. Sanders by 77% to 21%, compared with the 75% to 22% edge Mrs. Clinton received from voters who want to continue on Mr. Obama's course. Unfortunately for Mr. Sanders, the "let us continue" faction of the party outnumbered its "to the left, march" counterpart by nine percentage points.Unless these dynamics change dramatically in the next few days, the vote in South Carolina, where Mrs. Clinton currently enjoys a double-digit advantage, should restore her standing as the strong front-runner for her party's presidential nomination.The second crucial number--27--is the percentage of the evangelical vote Texas Sen. Ted Cruz received in South Carolina. This result goes to the heart of Mr. Cruz's meticulously scripted strategy for winning his party's nomination by establishing a dominant position among evangelicals as well as committed conservatives.Mr. Cruz did reasonably well among very conservative primary voters, receiving 35%, ahead of Donald Trump's 29% and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio's 19%. But among evangelical voters, Mr. Cruz lost to Mr. Trump by six points while gaining only a modest advantage over Mr. Rubio. He also lost evangelicals to Mr. Trump in New Hampshire.If this pattern of weak evangelical support continues, it is hard to see Mr. Cruz's path to victory, because his sharply etched profile limits his appeal outside his base. In South Carolina, for example, only 17% of "somewhat conservative" voters and 7% of moderates supported him, and his showing among nonevangelical voters was a meager 13%.And despite his outsider stance since arriving in Washington, he lost to Mr. Trump by a staggering 50 points, 63% to 13%, among the 48% of South Carolina Republicans who want a president from outside the establishment. Even if Mr. Cruz prevails in Texas on March 1, the rationale for his candidacy has been weakened, perhaps fatally.Although Ohio Gov. John Kasich has run a strong, positive campaign, gaining many admirers along the way, he is almost certainly too moderate--at least as conservatism has been redefined during the past two decades--to gain a plurality of his party's base.A Quinnipiac poll released Tuesday suggests that Mr. Kasich will be hard-pressed to prevail against Mr. Trump even in his home state of Ohio, where he was re-elected as governor with 64% of the vote in November 2014.If lifelong Republicans are to block Mr. Trump's hostile takeover of their party, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush's withdrawal from the race leaves them with only one realistic option: Marco Rubio. The question is whether they can coalesce around him in time to stop Mr. Trump, and whether they are willing to undertake the no-holds-barred effort needed to unmask him. We will soon learn if Republican leaders will mount a real fight or meekly surrender.A surprising number of Republicans have told me privately, and some are now saying publicly, that they cannot support Mr. Trump as their party's nominee. Last week, William Kristol, the editor of the conservative magazine the Weekly Standard, floated the possibility of backing an independent conservative candidacy. This would not be the strangest thing to happen in a very strange election year.Credit: By William A. Galston

article name: Setback in Nevada Slows Sanders's Stride; Coming contests will test the Vermont senator's efforts to broaden his coalition
article text: GREENVILLE, S.C.--Bernie Sanders faces a narrow path to the Democratic presidential nomination after a defeat in the Nevada caucuses blunted his momentum and highlighted the steep challenge of broadening his coalition.Hillary Clinton won Nevada by 5 percentage points Saturday, but her victory was arguably bigger than that, coming as the Vermont senator was building his case as a credible challenger. The former secretary of state now has claimed victory in two of the first three contests, and is favored to win Saturday's South Carolina primary. Mr. Sanders, who walloped her in the New Hampshire primary, won't see his next best chance for a victory until March 1, when 11 states host primaries and caucuses.Mrs. Clinton's Nevada win settled her nervous backers, just as the race shifts to the South, long considered to be her firewall, primarily because of her strong support from African-American voters. Mr. Sanders spent Sunday in South Carolina, but already appears to be pivoting to the next round of primaries with nearly 900 delegates up for grabs."We're going to be competing in 11 states all across this country [March 1] on Super Tuesday," Mr. Sanders said after conceding Nevada. "And I believe that on Super Tuesday, we have got an excellent chance to win many of those states."On Sunday, Mr. Sanders said he isn't skipping over South Carolina, but after holding a rally in Greenville, S.C., Sunday night, the Vermont senator will head to Massachusetts for a rally on Monday and then to Virginia on Tuesday. In Greenville, where Mr. Sanders was introduced by actor Danny Glover, he drew a crowd of more than 5,000.Mrs. Clinton plans to hold events in South Carolina on Tuesday and Wednesday. The Clinton campaign also began airing an ad narrated by actor Morgan Freeman in South Carolina, and it plans to deploy civil-rights attorneys and mothers who lost children to gun violence across the state to make the case for her candidacy.The March 1 terrain offers Mr. Sanders some opportunities. His campaign is running TV ads in Minnesota, Colorado, Oklahoma and Massachusetts, states where it sees its best chance for victory. Minnesota and Colorado are caucus states, which tend to attract the more liberal voters that he appeals to, his advisers said. He also holds a huge advantage in his home state of Vermont.But also voting the same day are Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee and Arkansas, all contests that will feature significant numbers of African-American voters. That should provide an advantage to Mrs. Clinton, whose support in the black community was reaffirmed in Nevada, where entrance polls showed three-fourths of African-Americans backed her. She's expected to see similar support in South Carolina.Sanders aides have said for months that the campaign must expand its support base and find ways to appeal to black voters. On Sunday, he spoke at a black church in Columbia, S.C.But Nevada's results revealed little progress overall, and Mr. Sanders said his rival's advantage with African-American voters there was a concern. "We did badly with the African-American vote," Mr. Sanders told CNN on Sunday. "But I think the more the African-American community hears our message...I think you're going to see us making progress there as well."One open question is Mrs. Clinton's advantage with Latino voters, who are a key part of the electorate in places including Texas, another March 1 state. Entrance polls showed Mr. Sanders winning this group, but the Clinton campaign questioned that finding given the overall results.After Super Tuesday, the Sanders campaign sees potential victories on March 5 in Kansas and Nebraska and on March 6 in Maine--all three caucus states. Sanders aides are also focused on the big prize of Michigan, where a primary is set for March 8. Campaign manager Jeff Weaver also noted that under Democratic Party rules, delegates are allocated proportionately, meaning that if a race is close, both candidates win substantial delegates.There are no winner-take-all states in the Democratic primary race, which prevents one candidate from pulling far away from a competitor. At the same time, though, this system makes it very hard to catch up once a candidate falls behind.When challengers are forced to drop out, it is usually because they run out of money, and Mr. Sanders shows no signs of that. He collected more than $6 million in the 24 hours after winning the New Hampshire primary, though campaign finance reports show he also dramatically increased his spending in January. On Saturday, the Vermont senator asked his backers to continue to lend their financial support, saying that "taking on the establishment" isn't easy.Still, he'll need to notch some quick wins if he is to seriously threaten Mrs. Clinton. "He has the money and resources to keep going, but he needed Nevada to fuel his momentum because he will lose South Carolina," said Chris Kofinis, a Democratic strategist who is neutral in the race."Realistically, this hill became very high to climb," Mr. Kofinis said. "Short of a stunning loss [by Mrs. Clinton] on Super Tuesday, we're seeing the limits of his candidacy."While Nevada delivered a much-needed win to the former secretary of state, potentially slowing Mr. Sanders's rise and settling uneasy Clinton supporters, her campaign officials say the Vermont senator remains a strong candidate."He is a real force," said Jennifer Palmieri, Mrs. Clinton's communications director. "We're grateful for this win, but we know we've got 47 more states."Mrs. Clinton has introduced new themes in her basic stump speech that seem partly a reaction to the challenge posed by Mr. Sanders. For months, she talked up detailed proposals aimed at helping middle-class families meet expenses--policies that were within the mainstream of Democratic politics, but far less sweeping than those of Mr. Sanders.In her victory speech in Nevada and continuing at a rally late Saturday night in Houston, Mrs. Clinton made the point that government's role isn't simply to reward Americans with lavish programs. "This can't be just about what we're going to give you," she told the crowd at Texas Southern University. "It has to be about what we will build together."Peter Nicholas contributed to this articleWrite to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Hillary Clinton's Win Slows Bernie Sanders's Momentum; Her victory in the Nevada Democratic caucuses gives a boost as the campaign moves to states in the South
article text: Vote totals don't give the full measure of Hillary Clinton's victory in Nevada . In winning Saturday's caucuses, Mrs. Clinton has slowed the momentum of Sen. Bernie Sanders at a critical point, as he was threatening to build credibility as a national candidate.That shift is more important than the margin of victory. Mr. Sanders' campaign has been fueled by ardent, liberal supporters drawn by his call for a political revolution' against the wealthy and Wall Street. Had he built on his sweeping New Hampshire victory with a second win, Mr. Sanders could have made a stronger case for acceptance among the broader Democratic electorate and threatened to erase the many advantages Mrs. Clinton brings to the campaign.Instead, Mrs. Clinton has now won two of the first three nominating contests just as the race turns next week to favorable terrain in South Carolina, where African-American voters make up a majority of the state's Democratic voting pool. Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Sanders by 50 percentage points among African-American--73% to 23%--in a national Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll of Democratic primary voters released this week.The states that follow South Carolina will be equally difficult places for Mr. Sanders to regain momentum. The March 1 Super Tuesday states include others with large African-American populations and ideologically moderate voters, among them Alabama, Georgia, Tennessee and Virginia. Together, they offer far more delegates than do liberal Massachusetts and Vermont, where Mr. Sanders is likely to do well.Mr. Sanders' campaign had started as a quixotic endeavor but had lately become a true threat. He gained 1 million campaign donations faster than any candidate in history, eroding Mrs. Clinton's presumed fundraising edge. Mr. Sanders outraised the Clinton campaign in January, a substantial surprise, given the donor network that Mrs. Clinton and her husband have tended for decades.A second advantage for Mrs. Clinton--her lead among the party's superdelegates--was starting to come under stress. Superdelegates are elected officials and other Democratic Party insiders who can vote for any candidate they wish at the national nominating convention.As the voice of the party establishment, Mrs. Clinton had already secured support from about half the superdelegates, Associated Press reporting found. But liberal groups and others in the party had started to argue that these party insiders should endorse whoever wins the popular vote, rather than throw the nomination to Mrs. Clinton, for example, should Mr. Sanders outpoll her.Nevada appears to have blunted the threat. Results from the state also suggest that Mrs. Clinton has stabilized her coalition of supporters. Women, who are essential to her campaign, favored her by 16 percentage points, according to preliminary results from surveys of caucus-goers, which were reported by media outlets. That marks a substantial change from the New Hampshire primary, in which she lost women by 11 points.Less clear is how Mrs. Clinton fared among Hispanic voters, as preliminary survey results suggested that Mr. Sanders had carried that group. That result, if it held, would mean little in South Carolina, where Hispanic voters accounted for a mere 1% of voters in the last competitive Democratic primary, in 2008. But it could allow Mr. Sanders to win delegates in the big, Super Tuesday state of Texas.Still, the Nevada results leave Mr. Sanders with the big task he has had to navigate from the start: How to broaden a coalition of young, liberal supporters to become a force in the broader party--especially given Mrs. Clinton's eagerness to try to head him off by tacking to the left on policy, herself.Credit: By Aaron Zitner

article name: Hillary Clinton Wins Nevada Democratic Caucuses; Former secretary of state narrowly defeats Sen. Bernie Sanders in third contest of the 2016 presidential race
article text: LAS VEGAS, Nev.--Hillary Clinton beat back a stiff challenge from rival Bernie Sanders on Saturday, winning a close race in Nevada's Democratic presidential caucuses."I am so so thrilled and so grateful to all of my supporters out there," she said at a victory rally. "Some may have doubted us but we never doubted each other."With 81% of precincts reporting, Mrs. Clinton had a 52.1% lead compared with 47.8% for the Vermont senator.The victory was a major relief for the Clinton campaign and allows the former secretary of state to move on to contests in South Carolina next Saturday and the states that follow with fresh momentum after being walloped in New Hampshire and winning by only the slimmest of margins in Iowa.Mrs. Clinton had long been considered the favorite in Nevada. But Mr. Sanders' 22-point victory margin in New Hampshire gave him significant momentum. An infusion of donations also allowed him to put staff on the ground and television ads on the air.Mr. Sanders said in a statement that he had called to congratulate Mrs. Clinton. "I am very proud of the campaign we ran. Five weeks ago we were 25 points behind and we ended up in a very close election. And we probably will leave Nevada with a solid share of the delegates," Sanders said in a statement."I am also proud of the fact that we have brought many working people and young people into the political process and believe that we have the wind at our back as we head toward Super Tuesday. I want to thank the people of Nevada for their support that they have given us and the boost that their support will give us as we go forward," Sanders said.In the hours before the caucuses started, Mrs. Clinton visited the Harrah's employee cafeteria in Las Vegas late Saturday morning about 20 minutes after Mr. Sanders passed through the same room. "Hillary! Hillary! Hillary!" the room cheered as she entered.Her husband, former President Bill Clinton, was nearby at the Caesars Palace hotel on the Las Vegas strip. "We're doing everything we can," he said. "We got a good response."Las Vegas hotel workers, many in uniform, swarmed a Democratic caucus site in a Caesars Palace ballroom, one of six at-large caucus locations in the city aimed at making it easier for shift workers to take part in the contest.Waiting to get into the ballroom, Michael Jaumotte, a food service worker at Caesars, said he was backing Mr. Sanders. "I like that he's not taking donations from big corporations," he said. A group of housekeepers from the Bellagio Hotel arrived together wearing their brown uniforms and "Hillary" stickers.Walking into his polling precinct at a middle school in Henderson, Nev., Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid said he would vote uncommitted, to stay neutral in the race. "Everyone knows the caucus setup here in Nevada are my doing," said Mr. Reid, who was instrumental in moving the Nevada caucuses to the forefront of the nominating process."I want to make sure that Clinton and Sanders know that I've been fair. If I got involved on one side or another, it would be easy for them to say, you know he's trying to affect the caucuses unfairly," he said, adding that he would offer an endorsement after the caucuses are over.Both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders made a point of spending at least part of their time in the days before the caucuses in the mountains and deserts of Nevada, away from the glam and glitter of Las Vegas.Mr. Sanders spent Friday stumping in Elko and Reno before returning to Las Vegas for a large rally. Mrs. Clinton made stops in both Reno and Elko earlier in the week.State caucus rules give rural counties outsize weight in the delegate-allocation process, a directive aimed at ensuring candidates don't just campaign in the cities.Consequently, the road to victory in Saturday's Democratic caucuses runs through places like Elko, a small mining community that is the closest thing to a major city in northeast Nevada, and Pahrump, a desert town of about 36,000 that boasts a handful of casinos, a couple of brothels--and Clinton and Sanders campaign field offices.And both campaigns worked these sparsely populated communities, phoning supporters daily and driving to remote houses on dirt roads that aren't on the maps to knock on doors and see if the people who answer might need a lift to caucus sites.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 news.* Immigration Set to Stay Center Stage in Primaries* Trump Leaves Trade Mark on GOP* Nevada Union's Silence Clouds Caucus* South Carolina's Clyburn Endorses Clinton* Pope Francis and Trump Spar Over Immigration and Candidate's Faith* South Carolina GOP Stalwarts Fear Primary Will Only Underscore Party Rifts* Clinton's Lead Shrinks as More Women Shift to Sanders, WSJ/NBC News Poll Finds* Critics See Racial Subtext in Obama-Rubio Photo MashupMr. Sanders brought his pitch to Elko on Friday, a picturesque mountain town of 20,000 people that lies more than 300 miles north of Las Vegas in a conservative part of the state. He was following Mrs. Clinton, who flew in earlier in the week. Republican candidates, who hold their caucuses Tuesday, were expected to start arriving in northern Nevada over the next few days.But the Vermont senator finished up his Nevada campaign late Friday in Henderson , Nev., the second largest city in the state. He didn't predict victory in his speech, but instead forecast Saturday as a key date in his hopes for the presidency."It could well be that 10, 20, 30 years from now people will look back on what happens in Nevada and say this was the beginning of the political revolution," Mr. Sanders said.Though the overwhelming majority of the state's people live in and around Las Vegas, campaigns ignore the rural areas at their own peril. In the 2008 Democratic race between Mrs. Clinton and Barack Obama, she won the state but Mr. Obama collected more delegates in part because of a stronger organization and presence in the rural areas."She won the popular vote, but she did not win the caucus because caucuses are based on delegates," said Joan Kato, a former aide to Mr. Obama's 2008 campaign who now serves as the state director for Mr. Sanders. Nevada has 23 delegates up for grabs in this year's caucuses.That was a mistake her campaign didn't plan to repeat. She has offices in Elko, Pahrump and Carson City, and organizers across the state. He had stopped at many of the same houses a few days earlier. He offered Clinton yard signs, but there were no takers. "Hillary dealt with Bill. That's what my wife says about me. She says, 'I had to be strong, because otherwise Frank would run all over me.' "Navigating can be a challenge. The recession hit Pahrump hard, and construction on some roads seemed to stop before completion."We go where the houses are, not where the roads are," Mr. Dix said.There is no surefire way to get people to turn up at the caucus sites. One person mentioned that softball practice posed a potential conflict. "It's not just the money issue. Bernie seems to be focused on one issue: the 1% of the 1%."Reid J. article name: South Carolina, Nevada Vote on Presidential Candidates; Hillary Clinton edges out Bernie Sanders in Nevada caucuses, while South Carolina Republicans continue voting in their primary
article text: GOP Rivals Make Final Push in South Carolina as Voters Head to PollsDemocratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton speaks in Las Vegas after winning the Nevada Democratic caucuses. With 81% of the precincts reporting, the former secretary of state had a 52.1% lead compared with 47.8% for Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.Mrs. Clinton's supporters in Las Vegas cheer before she was projected by the media as the caucus winner.Caucus-goers register at the Del Sol Academy of the Performing Arts in Las Vegas. Mrs. Clinton's lead in Nevada shrank as some women voters switched to Mr. Sanders.Saturday gave voters in the Western and Southern U.S. their first chance to pass judgment on this year's presidential candidates, with the South Carolina Republican primary and the Nevada Democratic caucuses. Almost 59,000 absentee ballots were turned in by Friday, according to a spokesman for the state's election commission. That was more than the 2008 and 2012 results combined. Above, a voter casts his ballot at Our Savior Lutheran Church in Columbia, S.C.Nevada state caucus rules gave rural counties outsize weight in the delegate-allocation process to ensure candidates didn't just campaign in the cities. Above, voters are shown waiting in a long lines early in Las Vegas to caucus for their preferred presidential candidate at Rancho High School.The Republican primary polls in South Carolina were due to close at 7 p.m. Eastern standard time. Above, voters are shown waiting early Saturday to cast ballots at an American Legion Hall in Cayce, S.C.Sen. Sanders and his wife Jane, left, greeted voters at a caucus site in Las Vegas.South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley is shown voting in Lexington, S.C. The remaining Republican presidential candidates were looking to make up ground on the party's front-runner businessman Donald Trump. Ms. Haley had previously endorsed Florida Sen. Marco Rubio.Former Florida governor and Republican presidential candidate Jeb Bush, left, gets a hug from his mother Barbara Bush, after visiting a polling station in Greenville, S.C.Donald Trump was the top pick of 28% of likely Republican primary voters in South Carolina, according to a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll held in the final days before Saturday's election, but that was down 8 percentage points from a January survey. Above, voters cast ballots at the fire department in Mauldin, S.C.People were out in support of their preferred Democratic candidate outside a caucus location at Caesars Palace, in Las Vegas. Nevada has 23 delegates up for grabs in this year's caucuses.South Carolina awards 29 delegates to the statewide winner of the GOP primary and another three to the winner of each of its seven congressional districts. Above, a voter casts her ballet at Hand Middle School in Columbia.Ballots were cast in the Horse Gall voting station, which was in the garage of precinct volunteer David Smith in Varnville, S.C. There are 76 registered voters in the Horse Gall precinct.
