article name: Hillary Clinton's Lead Shrinks as More Women Shift to Bernie Sanders, WSJ/NBC News Poll Finds; Sanders cut Clinton's once-commanding national lead in Democratic race by more than half, poll finds
article text: Sen. Bernie Sanders has cut Hillary Clinton's once-commanding national lead in the Democratic primary race by more than half over the last month, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds.Mrs. Clinton, the former secretary of state, drew support from 53% of people who expect to vote in Democratic primaries, while 42% picked Mr. Sanders. That 11-point spread is much closer than the 25-point advantage Mrs. Clinton enjoyed a month ago, when the poll found her ahead by 59% to 34%.The new poll found that Mrs. Clinton holds a solid but diminished lead among her core group of supporters: women. She continues to dominate among minorities, a crucial voting bloc in coming contests in Nevada and the South."The race is tightening,'' said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who helped conduct the survey with Democrat Fred Yang. At the same time, he said, Mrs. Clinton retains "structural advantages...that put her in a competitive position to be the Democratic nominee."The poll points to a long-term challenge for Mrs. Clinton in the continued rise of negative feelings about her among the broader electorate. Half of the people surveyed said they felt negatively about her, a record high for her. More than half said they would feel uncertain or pessimistic if she won the White House.Peter D. Hart, a Democratic pollster who helped conduct the survey, said that Mrs. Clinton's biggest obstacle in 2016 isn't Mr. Sanders, but her own difficulty in winning the trust and affection of voters."She is running against herself," Mr. Hart said. "When it comes to competence, temperament...she laps the field. Voters just need to like her."The poll, conducted Feb. 14-16, signaled continuing progress for Mr. Sanders in the aftermath of voting in Iowa, where Mrs. Clinton barely eked out a victory, and in New Hampshire, where the Vermont senator won decisively.Mr. Sanders's gains over the past month were due in large part to rising support among younger women. Mrs. Clinton remains ahead among women overall, but Mr. Sanders slashed her lead by 19 percentage points, to 58%-39%. Mr. Sanders leads among women under age 50, while Mrs. Clinton holds a far larger lead among those 50 and older.A bigger challenge for Mr. Sanders has been his underperformance among minority voters. He made some gains among nonwhite voters in the new poll, but Mrs. Clinton still leads among those voters by 29 percentage points, 62% to 33%. In January, she had led by 42 points.More Democratic voters express reservations about Mr. Sanders's key weaknesses than about Mrs. Clinton's. About one quarter said they were concerned about his lack of foreign policy experience, and 23% said his policy proposals were out of the mainstream.Mrs. Clinton's ties to Wall Street--a central line of attack by Mr. Sanders--were a concern to 22% of Democratic voters. Questions about Mrs. Clinton's honesty and judgment related to her use of a private email server while in the government were of little consequence within the party: Only 7% of Democratic primary voters said they were concerned about it.Mr. Sanders is winning over change-oriented young women such as LaurrenNirider, 25, a poll participant in Richland, Wash."I'm 100% behind having a woman president. But I'm not going to support someone just because she's a woman," said Ms. Nirider, who backs Mr. Sanders. "Compared to Hillary Clinton, he's going to be able to move the country in a more forward direction. He's rattling the cages a little more."Nancy D. Pemberton, 65, a college teacher in Tryon, N.C., said she thought Mr. Sanders was too inexperienced and his policies unrealistic. She saw Mrs. Clinton as better equipped for the office.More on Election 2016* In Poll, Bloomberg Prospects Look Dim* Additional 2016 Election Polls* Bill Clinton Charges Where Campaign Hesitates* Pope Calls Trump 'Not Christian' on Immigration* Ted Cruz Overtakes Donald Trump in Latest Republican Presidential Poll* Americans Divided on Considering Obama High Court Nominee* Democrats Vie for Nevada's Minorities"She can get the job done, and that is the most compelling thing that I am looking at," said Ms. Pemberton. "It couldn't hurt to have a woman in there."The poll asked voters of both parties to consider hypothetical candidate matchups and found that Mr. Sanders, at least for now, seemed better equipped than Mrs. Clinton to beat a GOP opponent in the fall.Mr. Sanders outpolled businessman Donald Trump by 16 points--53% to 37%--and Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas by 50% to 40%.Mrs. Clinton also beat Mr. Trump in a one-on-one matchup, 50% to 40%, but only tied Mr. Cruz, 46% to 46%.Mr. Hart warned, however, that such polls this early in a campaign are poor predictors of general election matchups when a candidate is as little known as Mr. Sanders.Gauging the public's attention to the campaign, the poll found that Democratic voters show less interest in the election than do Republicans. Asked to rate their interest on a scale of one to 10, 77% of Democratic primary voters rated themselves a nine or 10, compared with 87% of Republican primary voters.If the election came to a Clinton-Trump face-off, many voters would see the choice as between two unfavorable options. Mrs. Clinton topped Mr. Trump, 50% to 40%, among registered voters. But only 34% said their vote would be a sign of support for their chosen candidate, while 47% said it would be a signal that they didn't want the other candidate to be elected.Asked whether they viewed the candidates in a favorable or unfavorable light, voters had sharply negative views of three candidates: Mrs. Clinton and Messrs. Cruz and Trump. Some 59% of voters viewed Mr. Trump negatively.Views of only two candidates--Mr. Sanders and Ohio Gov. John Kasich--were more positive than negative.None of the candidates in either party inspired great confidence in voters: Asked how they would feel if each were elected president, no candidate sparked more than 21% of voters to say they would feel "optimistic and confident."Mr. Yang, the Democratic pollster, said the 2016 campaign "seems to be shaping up as a race to the bottom, with the more likely dynamic being why the other person shouldn't be president."Write to Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.comCredit: By Janet Hook

article name: Bernie Sanders Keeps Up Heat on Hillary Clinton; Renewed criticism of Wall Street speeches comes as Democratic presidential front-runner's team points to widening delegate lead
article text: PORTLAND, Maine--Sen. Bernie Sanders and his top aides showed no sign they would dial back their harsh words for Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton on Wednesday, and promised to press ahead in the face of her growing delegate lead.At a rally here ahead of Maine's caucuses this Sunday, Mr. Sanders pressed Mrs. Clinton to release transcripts of her paid speeches to Wall Street firms and mocked the idea that anything she said could have been worth the six-figure speaking fees she collected. He also reminded his audience that Mrs. Clinton once had been considered "the inevitable nominee.""Guess what? She's not so inevitable today," he said. He celebrated the four states he won in voting on Tuesday without mentioning the seven states--most of them much bigger--that she carried.Mr. Sanders has the money to press on as long as he wants, though Democrats may grow impatient with him out of fear that he will damage the woman who may ultimately represent them in November.Read More in Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Clinton Wins Leave Diminished Room for a Comeback by Sanders* Capital Journal: After Super Tuesday, Republicans Face Moment of Truth* After Three Super Tuesday Wins, Ted Cruz Sees a Two-Horse Race* Recap: Super Tuesday"Given the current trajectory, there may come a point when he will have to make a judgment about whether he can still win and how aggressively on the attack he wants to be if he can't," said David Axelrod, who helped steer President Barack Obama's two victories.The Clinton campaign argued that the contest was fast growing out of Mr. Sanders's reach. After Tuesday's voting, her lead among delegates chosen by voters grew to nearly 200, a bigger margin than Mr. Obama ever enjoyed in his protracted 2008 battle for the presidential nomination against Mrs. Clinton."Over the upcoming weeks, we intend to steadily add to Hillary Clinton's already sizable lead in delegates, and as we do, it will become harder and harder mathematically for Sen. Sanders to ever catch up," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook wrote in a "state of the race" memo.After Tuesday's voting, Mrs. Clinton was assured of at least 581 pledged delegates, who are chosen by voters, with Mr. Sanders claiming at least 388. The Mook memo contrasts Mr. Sanders's biggest win in his home state of Vermont, where he netted 16 delegates, to Mrs. Clinton's biggest victory of the night, in Texas, where she took 78.Mrs. Clinton also has a huge lead among super delegates, party leaders who can vote for anyone. When those are included, her total tops 1,000, almost halfway to the number needed to clinch the nomination.Tad Devine, a senior strategist for Mr. Sanders, said their campaign would make up ground as the race shifts to states with more favorable demographics. Mrs. Clinton's blow-out wins across the South were built on strong support from African-American voters, whereas coming states have larger share of white voters, who support Mr. Sanders in greater numbers.However, after losing the white vote in Nevada, Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday rebounded, capturing 57% of the white vote in Virginia and essentially tying with Mr. Sanders among white voters in Massachusetts. She also won the Democratic white vote in Tennessee and Georgia.Mr. Devine also floated another, seemingly long-shot path to victory. He said that under Democratic Party rules, pledged delegates aren't required to support the candidate they were chosen to represent. He said they are only required to reflect the sentiment of the voters, which he said could change if Mrs. Clinton doesn't "win consistently" through the campaign.Mr. Sanders's next opportunity comes this weekend with caucuses in Nebraska, and Kansas, as well as Maine. He is also targeting Michigan's primary on Tuesday."We have to win a lot of places, beginning this weekend, and that's what we intend to do," Mr. Devine said.Mr. Mook wrote that Mr. Sanders may win in the weekend's caucuses, but said Mrs. Clinton will more than make up any deficit with a victory in Louisiana, which votes Saturday. If Mr. Sanders wins in Michigan on Tuesday, Mr. Mook said, Mrs. Clinton will offset that with a bigger win in Mississippi, whose primary is the same day."The end result is that Sen. Sanders will spend millions of dollars in Michigan but not make any net gain in pledged delegates because he isn't competing in states like Mississippi," Mr. Mook predicted.But if the race was all but over, it wasn't obvious in Maine, where a line of Sanders supporters snaked for blocks along downtown streets in near-freezing weather waiting to crowd into a local theater to hear him speak."The states that are coming up are lot more favorable than some of the ones on Super Tuesday. and he has a really good shot," said Evan O'Day-Senior, 30 years old.The crowd numbered 2,400, though almost all the faces were white, a sign that Mr. Sanders is still struggling to expand his coalition despite his campaign's promises, repeated on Wednesday, to do just that.Given Mrs. Clinton's advantage, some Democrats were itching for Mr. Sanders to tone down his attacks."If his goal is to simply deliver a message, he should think twice before criticizing the likely nominee who is on the verge of entering what promises to be a brutal general election campaign that will require Democrats to be unified," said Democratic strategist Ben Labolt, a former Obama aide.Sanders aides explicitly rejected any suggestion that he is a "message candidate," and the senator showed no signs of toning down his criticism.In Portland, he cited a trio of speeches Mrs. Clinton gave to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. for $225,000 apiece and renewed his call that she release the transcripts. She has said she will do so when all candidates, including Republicans, do the same with their paid speeches."I urge Secretary Clinton to share that extraordinary speech with the American people," Mr. Sanders said. "Tell us what you said behind closed doors to Goldman Sachs." At that, a deafening cheer spread through the theater.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

Bernie Sanders and his top aides showed no sign they would dial back their harsh words for Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton on Wednesday, and promised to press ahead in the face of her growing delegate lead.At a rally here ahead of Maine's caucuses this Sunday, Mr. Sanders pressed Mrs. Clinton to release transcripts of her paid speeches to Wall Street firms and mocked the idea that anything she said could have been worth the six-figure speaking fees she collected. He also reminded his audience that Mrs. Clinton once had been considered "the inevitable nominee.""Guess what? She's not so inevitable today," he said. He celebrated the four states he won in voting on Tuesday without mentioning the seven states--most of them much bigger--that she carried.Mr. Sanders has the money to press on as long as he wants, though Democrats may grow impatient with him out of fear that he will damage the woman who may ultimately represent them in November."Given the current trajectory, there may come a point when he will have to make a judgment about whether he can still win and how aggressively on the attack he wants to be if he can't," said David Axelrod, who helped steer President Barack Obama's two victories.Read More in Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Clinton Wins Leave Diminished Room for a Comeback by Sanders* Capital Journal: After Super Tuesday, Republicans Face Moment of Truth* After Three Super Tuesday Wins, Ted Cruz Sees a Two-Horse Race* Recap: Super TuesdayThe Clinton campaign argued that the contest was fast growing out of Mr. Sanders's reach. After Tuesday's voting, her lead among delegates chosen by voters grew to nearly 200, a bigger margin than Mr. Obama ever enjoyed in his protracted 2008 battle for the presidential nomination against Mrs. Clinton."Over the upcoming weeks, we intend to steadily add to Hillary Clinton's already sizable lead in delegates, and as we do, it will become harder and harder mathematically for Sen. Sanders to ever catch up," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook wrote in a "state of the race" memo.After Tuesday's voting, Mrs. Clinton was assured of at least 581 pledged delegates, who are chosen by voters, with Mr. Sanders claiming at least 388. The Mook memo contrasts Mr. Sanders's biggest win in his home state of Vermont, where he netted 16 delegates, to Mrs. Clinton's biggest victory of the night, in Texas, where she took 78.Mrs. Clinton also has a huge lead among super delegates, party leaders who can vote for anyone. When those are included, her total tops 1,000, almost halfway to the number needed to clinch the nomination.Tad Devine, a senior strategist for Mr. Sanders, said their campaign would make up ground as the race shifts to states with more favorable demographics. Mrs. Clinton's blow-out wins across the South were built on strong support from African-American voters, whereas coming states have larger share of white voters, who support Mr. Sanders in greater numbers.However, after losing the white vote in Nevada, Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday rebounded, capturing 57% of the white vote in Virginia and essentially tying with Mr. Sanders among white voters in Massachusetts. She also won the Democratic white vote in Tennessee and Georgia.Mr. Devine also floated another, seemingly long-shot path to victory. He said that under Democratic Party rules, pledged delegates aren't required to support the candidate they were chosen to represent. He said they are only required to reflect the sentiment of the voters, which he said could change if Mrs. Clinton doesn't "win consistently" through the campaign.Mr. Sanders's next opportunity comes this weekend with caucuses in Nebraska, and Kansas, as well as Maine. He is also targeting Michigan's primary on Tuesday."We have to win a lot of places, beginning this weekend, and that's what we intend to do," Mr. Devine said.Mr. Mook wrote that Mr. Sanders may win in the weekend's caucuses, but said Mrs. Clinton will more than make up any deficit with a victory in Louisiana, which votes Saturday. If Mr. Sanders wins in Michigan on Tuesday, Mr. Mook said, Mrs. Clinton will offset that with a bigger win in Mississippi, whose primary is the same day."The end result is that Sen. Sanders will spend millions of dollars in Michigan but not make any net gain in pledged delegates because he isn't competing in states like Mississippi," Mr. Mook predicted.But if the race was all but over, it wasn't obvious in Maine, where a line of Sanders supporters snaked for blocks along downtown streets in near-freezing weather waiting to crowd into a local theater to hear him speak."The states that are coming up are lot more favorable than some of the ones on Super Tuesday. and he has a really good shot," said Evan O'Day-Senior, 30 years old.The crowd numbered 2,400, though almost all the faces were white, a sign that Mr. Sanders is still struggling to expand his coalition despite his campaign's promises, repeated on Wednesday, to do just that.Given Mrs. Clinton's advantage, some Democrats were itching for Mr. Sanders to tone down his attacks."If his goal is to simply deliver a message, he should think twice before criticizing the likely nominee who is on the verge of entering what promises to be a brutal general election campaign that will require Democrats to be unified," said Democratic strategist Ben Labolt, a former Obama aide.Sanders aides explicitly rejected any suggestion that he is a "message candidate," and the senator showed no signs of toning down his criticism.In Portland, he cited a trio of speeches Mrs. Clinton gave to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. for $225,000 apiece and renewed his call that she release the transcripts. She has said she will do so when all candidates, including Republicans, do the same with their paid speeches."I urge Secretary Clinton to share that extraordinary speech with the American people," Mr. Sanders said. "Tell us what you said behind closed doors to Goldman Sachs." At that, a deafening cheer spread through the theater.Credit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: A Big Push for Flawed Front-Runners; Bernie could cause trouble for Hillary at the convention. And Trump is no 'unifier.'
article text: Super Tuesday was a huge day for the Democratic and Republican Party front-runners. Both took big steps toward winning their respective nominations--but even as they piled up delegates, they still face challenges.Hillary Clinton swept seven of the night's 11 Democratic contests, winning 61.4% of the day's vote. She started that morning with 91 delegates from February's contests and ended the evening at 581. This doesn't include her support from so-called superdelegates--elected politicians and various Democratic Party pooh-bahs who are automatically entitled to vote for any candidate they want at the national convention.Bernie Sanders raised $42 million in February--and did it the easy way. Mrs. Clinton must trudge across the country to fundraisers, soliciting $2,700 a donor. Sen. Sanders need only send an email or tweet to get $30 each from millions of Americans.But money alone won't sway the Democratic contest. Leading among the 712 superdelegates by 457 to 22, Mrs. Clinton will be the nominee unless she or someone close to her is indicted over her private email server. Still, Mr. Sanders's fundraising shows the Democratic Party's left-wing grass roots are unlikely to roll over anytime soon for the former secretary of state.So what does Bernie want? He will arrive at the Philadelphia convention in July with a chunk of delegates and authentic enthusiasm. He doesn't seem to be angling for the vice-presidency. Instead, he appears to be a true believer who wants to kill the superdelegate process and demand explicitly democratic-socialist platform planks on income inequality and government regulation. These could be troublesome for Team Clinton.Donald Trump also had much to celebrate. The Republican front-runner started the day with 82 delegates and, by carrying seven of the 11 Republican contests, has added 237 to bring his total to 319 of the 728 chosen so far.Mr. Trump took 2.9 million of the 8.5 million votes cast, roughly 34.4%. Sen. Ted Cruz garnered 2.5 million votes, 29.3%. Sen. Marco Rubio got 1.9 million, votes, 22%. Ohio Gov. John Kasich, Dr. Ben Carson and the other 14 candidates trailed with 1.2 million votes, 14.4%.In other words, almost two of three Republicans are still not voting for the celebrity hotelier. He is winning--but not yet winning like a candidate who has consolidated his lead and unified the party.Mr. Trump's performance on Super Tuesday is similar to how he did in February, when he carried contests with 34.2% of the nearly 1.3 million votes cast, compared with 20.7% for Mr. Cruz, 20% for Mr. Rubio and 16% for the other 14 candidates.The good news for Mr. Trump is that his opposition remains divided and GOP rules help increase his share of delegates in states like Texas and Vermont, where Mr. Rubio failed to reach the statewide 20% required to win delegates. Mr. Trump's support also tends to be more uniform, allowing him to run first in more congressional districts where even a 35%-40% plurality gives him two of the three district delegates.From listening to their victory statements this week, both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump seem aware of their challenges. In her third successive election-night teleprompter speech, Mrs. Clinton mimicked Mr. Sanders's angry left-wing populism. She denounced disloyal corporate executives who move businesses abroad "to avoid paying their fair share of taxes," and asked what original Tea Party patriots would say about "student loan companies that overcharge young people."Mrs. Clinton also aimed her speech at the general election, suggesting that if Democrats aren't enthusiastic about her, they should remember "the stakes in this election have never been higher. And the rhetoric we're hearing on the other side has never been lower."Mr. Trump wisely eschewed his normal election night rants and offered (for him) a relatively high-toned, shrewd presentation, saying the idea of a conservative third party would only help Mrs. Clinton. And he claimed, "I'm a unifier."Right now that's a wish, not reality. Mr. Trump's campaign has left the GOP riven and embittered. Even on Tuesday, in his heal-the-breach approach, he mocked one challenger ("little Marco Rubio") and brushed off pro-lifers critical of his support for Planned Parenthood by calling them "so-called conservatives." In Trump World this may qualify as unifying, but not anywhere else.Both candidates are deeply flawed--but also front-runners. Unless something dramatic and unexpected happens, they also appear likely to be their respective parties' nominees.Mr. Rove helped organize the political-action committee American Crossroads and is the author of "The Triumph of William McKinley: Why the 1896 Election Still Matters" (Simon & Schuster, 2015).Credit: By Karl Rove

article name: Sanders Plans for the Long Run; The Vermont senator may face increasingly long odds but is determined to collect delegates and rally progressives
article text: No matter the results from Super Tuesday, Sen. Bernie Sanders plans to fight on for the Democratic presidential nomination, with opportunities for victory this weekend and plenty of money to fuel a long battle with front-runner Hillary Clinton.The Sanders campaign has targets throughout the spring but he faces long odds overall. Still, he appears determined to continue, at a minimum, rallying progressives and picking up delegates where he can, even if Mrs. Clinton mounts a steady march to the nomination.And even if he loses, Sanders aides and allies say he has already won. He's succeeded in pushing the issues he cares most about to the center of the debate. He's pushed Mrs. Clinton to the left on several points. And he is sure to emerge from this contest with strength at this summer's Democratic National Convention and as a higher-profile figure in the national debate."The Clinton campaign is going to want it to be over, and the Democratic establishment is going to want the race to be over," said Tad Devine, Mr. Sanders's chief strategist. "The voters don't want it to be over."The Vermont senator has also proved that it's possible to fund a presidential run on small donations. Mr. Sanders raised more than $42 million in February alone, his highest monthly haul. That gives him plenty of money to move forward.Mrs. Clinton was poised to emerge from Tuesday's voting with a growing lead in the delegate race, but Democratic rules award delegates proportionally, meaning both candidates are likely to win a healthy slice even in states that they lose.Mr. Sanders reminded his supporters of these rules in a speech celebrating victory in his home state of Vermont early Tuesday evening."Tonight you're going to see a lot of election results come in, and let me remind you of what the media often forgets about. This is not a general election. It's not winner take all," he said. "If you get 52%, you get 48%, you roughly end up with same amount of delegates in a state. By the end of tonight we are going to win many hundreds of delegates."Ahead of the results, his campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, emphasized that the process was designed to be drawn out."We're going to accumulate a lot of delegates and we're going to go forward. This campaign is going all the way to the convention," he said in an interview Tuesday. "As long as you can fund your campaign, the process continues."But while the delegate system makes it hard for the leader to put a challenger away, it also makes it hard for someone who falls behind to catch up."At a certain point it does become mathematically difficult or worse to catch up, and he has to decide--does he stay in to keep pushing a message and frame the debate, or does he get out to try and unify the party and help be a part of the preparations for the general election?" said Mo Elleithee, executive director of the Georgetown Institute of Politics and Public Service and a former Clinton aide.Mr. Sanders also may reason that if Mrs. Clinton stumbles, he would be able to benefit.Sanders aides say his next chances for a good showing will come this weekend with caucuses in Kansas and Nebraska on Saturday and, particularly, in Maine on Sunday. All three states are largely white, and he's done much better with white voters than he has with minorities. Caucuses also tend to attract the most liberal, motivated voters, which could give him an edge.Also voting Saturday is Louisiana, where half the Democratic primary voters were African-American in 2008, giving Mrs. Clinton an advantage that could offset Sanders gains elsewhere.After that, the Sanders campaign foresees a "showdown" in Michigan, which hosts a Clinton-Sanders debate on Sunday and its Democratic primary on Tuesday.Mr. Weaver said Mrs. Clinton's past support for certain trade deals, and kind words early on for the pending Trans-Pacific Partnership, would be a major issue in Michigan, an industrial state that has suffered from free trade and globalization.But the former secretary of state will enter Michigan with advantages of her own. She has given extraordinary attention to the water crisis in Flint, where a cost-cutting move wound up poisoning the water supply with lead. Mr. Sanders has also spoken out on the issue, but public polls show Mrs. Clinton with a double-digit lead in the state.Also voting next Tuesday will be Mississippi, another Southern state rich with African-American voters and expected to be a Clinton stronghold. If Mr. Sanders does manage to win in Michigan, Mrs. Clinton will probably counter with Mississippi.Mr. Devine acknowledged his candidate will have to improve his standing with African-American voters in order to win the nomination."We're going to work hard at it," he said. Mr. Sanders and his aides have been making similar vows for months and he is still struggling to win African-American support.The Sanders campaign faces a tough challenge in Florida's March 15 primary. With a dozen media markets, it is an expensive state for TV ads, and state rules don't let independents--who tend to favor Mr. Sanders--participate.The race is likely to stretch through the spring, Mr. Devine said. He sees possible victories on the West coast in late April and early May, and he said Mr. Sanders also may make a play for New York, a delegate-rich state that votes April 19.But even if Mr. Sanders doesn't win the nomination, supporters say he achieved more than anyone predicted when he entered the race last summer as an asterisk in the polls."You'll see more and more candidates learning to talk like Sanders," predicted Robert Borosage, co-director of the liberal group Campaign for America's Future.In the intervening months, Mrs. Clinton has come out against a trade deal she once appeared to support, and has embraced a $12 federal minimum wage, which is less than the $15 minimum that Mr. Sanders backs but still a significant increase. She's also put forth major spending programs to subsidize college costs and rebuild infrastructure.And either way, Mr. Sanders is likely to remain a major figure on the national stage."He is serious about creating this political revolution and that means mobilizing tens of millions of people across America," Mr. Weaver said. "The political revolution goes on. It's bigger than just Bernie Sanders and this campaign."Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary Clinton Dominates Super Tuesday Races; Mrs. Clinton wins in Texas, Arkansas, Alabama, Tennessee, Georgia and Virginia; Bernie Sanders takes Vermont, Oklahoma
article text: Hillary Clinton won sweeping primary victories in Texas and throughout the South on Super Tuesday, a sign that the Democratic presidential front-runner was vaulting to a commanding lead in the race for the nomination and leaving rival Bernie Sanders diminishing space to stage a comeback .Mr. Sanders captured his home state of Vermont and Oklahoma . But Mrs. Clinton easily won the delegate-rich Southern states ofVirginia , Georgia , Alabama , Tennessee and Arkansas , as well as Texas , the Associated Press projected--a testament to the continued loyalty of African-American voters who are a sizable share of the Democratic electorate."What a Super Tuesday!" Mrs. Clinton said in celebration from Florida, during a speech that touched on general-election themes. In an unmistakable reference to the slogan of Republican front-runner Donald Trump, who was having his own strong night, she said, "America has never stopped being great. We have to make America whole."Mrs. Clinton easily won in Virginia, an important battleground in the general election. With more than 80% of precincts counted, she had nearly 65% of the vote, versus about 35% for Mr. Sanders, according to the Associated Press.In another general-election battleground, Colorado, caucuses were just convening as results from the eastern half of the nation rolled in Tuesday night. A line of voters snaked through the hallway of Denver North High School in the city's Highland neighborhood."A lot of people here know what she is capable of and know she is capable of leading the country," said Linda Garcia, who caucused for Mrs. Clinton at Denver North.But Sanders supporters said they hoped their candidate could press forward. "I hope he has a chance. It's always tough for somebody who is preaching a lot of change to come up against the big money," said Steve Eagleburger, a supporter of Mr. Sanders. "I guess we'll see after tonight."Read More in Capital Journal* LIVE BLOG: Super Tuesday Results* Trump Piles Up Wins on Super Tuesday* Sanders Plans for the Long Run* Clinton's Embrace Of Party Establishment Contrasts With Republican Candidates* Exit Polls Show Wider Partisan Divide in Super Tuesday Presidential VotingThe tight race in Massachusetts was also being closely watched. The outcome in the solidly Democratic state could foreshadow the direction of a party that has been divided between Mr. Sanders's idealism and Mrs. Clinton's pragmatism.Mr. Sanders, a senator who addressed supporters in Vermont shortly after polls closed there, appeared to be preparing his backers for a disappointing night. He explained that even with a loss, his campaign would win delegates under the party's allocation rules, and he emphasized the long road ahead."At the end of tonight, 15 states will have voted; 35 states remain," Mr. Sanders said. "And let me assure you that we are going to take our fight for economic justice, for social justice, for environmental sanity, for a world of peace, to every one of those states."Coming into Super Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton was a heavy favorite to expand her delegate lead over her rival and perhaps take a daunting lead for the Democratic nomination. Such an outcome, which would make Mrs. Clinton the prohibitive favorite. Mr. Sanders's role would be reframed as an important voice on the left, rather than a threat.At stake were 878 pledged delegates to the summer convention, the biggest single-day prize in the Democratic race and more than one-third of the 2,383 delegates needed to capture the nomination. Eleven states were in play, plus American Samoa and a contingent of Democrats living abroad.Midway through the evening, Mrs. Clinton had added 314 delegates, giving her 405 pledged delegates, which are awarded by voters. In addition, she has support of 457 superdelegates, who can vote for anyone they choose, according to a tally by the Associated Press.Mr. Sanders had added 122 delegates, giving him 187, plus 22 superdelegates.Exit polls across the Super Tuesday map pointed to a widening ideological divide for the nation. The results indicated more Democrats were characterizing themselves as liberal, and fewer calling themselves moderates.Mr. Sanders came into Super Tuesday after a 48-point loss in South Carolina last Saturday, his second defeat in a row. The loss pointed to a structural weakness in his campaign: difficulty making inroads with African-American voters who have yet to warm in large numbers to his message about income inequality and the unfairness of the campaign-finance system.Though Mr. Sanders is flush with campaign money, his advisers decided not to air TV ads in some of the Super Tuesday states with large minority populations, given his low odds of prevailing there. The Sanders campaign focused his TV advertising instead on other Super Tuesday states that looked more promising, including Colorado, Minnesota, Virginia and Oklahoma.Mr. Sanders needed to put some wins on the board and undercut perceptions that his rival was the inevitable nominee. His easy win in Vermont was expected; he won re-election in 2012 with 71% of the vote.With 57% of the Oklahoma vote counted, Mr. Sanders had 52% compared with 40% for Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders also invested heavily in Minnesota and Colorado, visiting both states repeatedly. Mr. Sanders drew 18,000 people in a rally in Denver last month and thousands more at a rally at Colorado State University on Sunday.Still, the senator's challenge has been converting that enthusiasm into votes.Turnout on the Democratic side has flagged compared with the 2008 election, when Mrs. Clinton ran against then-Sen. Barack Obama. In the New Hampshire primary last month, Democratic turnout was 13% lower than in 2008, and in South Carolina, it was 31% lower.That could present a challenge to Democrats in the general election, as turnout in the raucous Republican primaries has been higher.With Mrs. Clinton buoyed by back-to-back wins since Mr. Sanders's win in New Hampshire, the Vermont senator faced the challenge of persuading voters that he could still prevail. That has proved a tough sell in certain quarters.Dan Frosch contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton Spar Over Trade in Midwest; Vermont senator attacks Nafta and Pacific deal, and Democratic presidential front-runner promises more job creation
article text: EAST LANSING, Mich.--Trade and manufacturing took center stage as the Democratic presidential race moved to Michigan on Thursday, with Sen. Bernie Sanders talking up his longtime opposition to free trade agreements and Hillary Clinton's campaign promising policies that would support job creation.Mr. Sanders, looking for a win in the industrial heartland, repeated his claim that Mrs. Clinton had supported "disastrous" trade agreements and suggested that her opposition to the pending Trans-Pacific Partnership wasn't sincere.The former secretary of state plans to respond in a speech at an auto supplier in Detroit on Friday. Advisers said that Mrs. Clinton would propose ways to create jobs by boosting manufacturing, and that she was willing to back trade agreements only if they met her standards."The answer can't be to shut down all trade," said Jake Sullivan, Mrs. Clinton's senior policy adviser. He said the key is backing "smart and fair trade, where American workers get a level playing field with the rest of the world."The candidates have been debating these points for months, but the issues are taking on new urgency with the approach of Tuesday's primary in Michigan, a state long reliant on manufacturing that has suffered steep job losses.The issue is sure to be litigated when Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton debate on Sunday in Flint, Mich.Mr. Sanders is banking on a win in Michigan for fresh momentum after losing seven of the 11 states that voted on Tuesday and falling well behind in the delegate count. His top aides refer to the Michigan contest as a "showdown" that will influence the course of the race.On Thursday, Mr. Sanders fired the first salvo. At a news conference here, surrounded by union workers, he said he had consistently opposed trade deals and suggested that Mrs. Clinton can't be trusted to stop them if elected president.Mr. Sanders said that trade agreements such as Nafta, signed by Mrs. Clinton's husband, former President Bill Clinton, have eliminated jobs in the U.S. as corporations have moved operations to countries that pay lower wages.Read More in Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Clinton Wins Leave Diminished Room for a Comeback by Sanders* Capital Journal: After Super Tuesday, Republicans Face Moment of Truth* After Three Super Tuesday Wins, Ted Cruz Sees a Two-Horse Race* Recap: Super TuesdayHe rattled off various trade agreements that Mrs. Clinton backed and that he had opposed. "On the issue of trade, Secretary Clinton's views and mine are very different," Mr. Sanders said.He also pointed to Mrs. Clinton's original kind words for the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation deal that is one of the Obama administration's key priorities. As secretary of state, Mrs. Clinton called it the "gold standard," but she came out against it once it was completed in October, six months into her presidential campaign."She was very reluctant to come out in opposition," Mr. Sanders said. "She is running for president. She concluded it was a good idea to oppose the TPP, and she did."The Sanders campaign also is airing a TV ad in Michigan that says Mr. Sanders has been steadfast in opposing trade deals "while others waffle."Mrs. Clinton has said she evaluates trade agreements on a case-by-case basis, supporting some but not others. As a senator from New York, Mrs. Clinton opposed a Central American Free Trade Agreement but supported deals with Australia, Singapore and several other nations.Mr. Sullivan didn't answer directly when asked whether, if elected president, Mrs. Clinton would try to make changes to the Asian deal to get it approved. He said that she believes "we need to have a very serious conversation about the future of trade." He said that should include how to prevent a "race to the bottom" among trading partners, and that Mrs. Clinton wants a "hard think" about what it would take to construct trade agreements that raise working standards.Clinton aides said that in her Friday speech, she would present a broad vision for bolstering U.S. jobs. Mr. Sullivan said she would lay out a "new bargain for a new economy" that extends to coal country and cities such as Detroit.She has already laid out several small-scale proposals for bolstering manufacturing, including tax breaks to encourage investment in hard-hit areas and better enforcement of trade agreements.Mr. Sullivan charged that Mr. Sanders didn't have a manufacturing plan of his own, and said he was wrong to oppose reauthorization of the Export-Import Bank, which provides financing to support some major domestic manufacturers. On that issue, Mr. Sanders aligned with conservatives in opposing what he called "corporate welfare to multinational corporations."The Clinton campaign also called in backing from Michigan's Sen. Debbie Stabenow. The senator said that Mrs. Clinton "totally gets it" when it comes to manufacturing and jobs. "You don't have an economy, you don't have a middle class, unless somebody makes something," she said.Credit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Bernie Sanders's Plan Would Raise Taxes by 34%, Analysis Finds; Candidate concentrates increases on high-income households, but every bracket would pay more
article text: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders's tax plan is just as revolutionary as he promises--raising federal tax revenue by 34% and cutting the after-tax incomes of the wealthiest households nearly in half, according to an analysis released Friday.Mr. Sanders's plan, designed to pay for a significant expansion of government spending, is the largest and most dramatic of all the presidential candidates' and the least likely to find support from either party in Congress. That is saying something in a year when Republicans are proposing unprecedentedly large tax cuts and structural changes.Mr. Sanders's proposals would increase federal taxes by $15.3 trillion over the next decade, according to the Tax Policy Center. Mr. Sanders concentrates his tax increases on high-income households, which would face sharply higher levies on their wages, business income, capital gains and estates, as well as more limits on their deductions. The top 0.1%--those with incomes of $3.7 million under an expanded definition--would pay an average federal tax rate of 63.7% in 2017, up from 34.2%.The middle 20% of households would face an average tax increase of $4,692 in 2017 and lose 8.5% of after-tax income. The lowest-income households would lose, too, but they would come out even by 2025."Sanders is clearly betting that people are willing to pay for his expansive new welfare state," said Leonard Burman, director of the Tax Policy Center, who was a Treasury Department official under President Bill Clinton. "There's a giant tax increase, mostly on the rich, but everyone would pay more."In a statement released late Friday, the campaign said the analysis was wrong and incomplete because it didn't include the benefits Americans would get from Mr. Sanders's proposals for single-payer health care, expanded Social Security benefits, free public college tuition and better U.S. infrastructure."The Tax Policy Center chose to analyze Sanders's tax plan in a vacuum without taking into account the savings the American people would gain under his Medicare-for-all plan. That is misleading," said Warren Gunnels, the campaign's policy director. "Without estimating the benefits American people would gain under these initiatives, the Tax Policy Center's report is inaccurate and one-sided."The top effective marginal tax rate on wages would increase to 64.2% from 43.1%, and Mr. Sanders would raise the top rate on capital gains to 62% from 24.1%, while making it harder for wealthy individuals to defer or avoid capital gains taxes. He also would limit U.S. companies' ability to defer U.S. taxes on their foreign income, impose new taxes on financial transactions and create a new tax on carbon, with a rebate for consumers.New payroll taxes on employers and on all workers would pay for what Mr. Sanders calls Medicare for all and for paid family leave. The $15.3 trillion estimate appears to leave Mr. Sanders several trillion dollars short of paying for his promises, and that is assuming the tax increases don't inhibit economic growth.The center said Mr. Sanders's tax plan "would substantially reduce incentives to save and invest in the U.S." and would discourage lower-earning spouses from entering the workforce.Mr. Sanders's plan stands in contrast with that of his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton. She proposes raising taxes on high-income households to pay for new spending and is offering targeted tax breaks and a forthcoming tax cut for middle-income households. For every $1 she is proposing to raise in taxes, Mr. Sanders wants to raise $14.24."Her experience in government and in politics for a long time tells her that those are the kinds of things she could get done. Bernie Sanders clearly wants to change things radically," Mr. Burman said.The center has now completed its estimates of the tax plans of the five leading presidential candidates--the two Democrats, along with Republicans Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio. The center hasn't analyzed Republican John Kasich's plans because it lacks sufficient detail. In the general election, Mr. Burman said, the center will attempt to analyze the economic effect of tax changes along with the combined effect of tax and spending proposals.The center is a joint project of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute, and it used a bipartisan panel of reviewers to examine the Sanders plan.Its economists are generally skeptical of the idea that tax changes can prompt major economic responses. But Mr. Sanders's plan is so big that it might be different, the report said."The proposed tax changes on both labor and capital income are very large compared with any tax policy changes since World War II, so the empirical evidence of relatively small effects cited earlier may not apply," the report said. "The lack of prior historical experience for changes of this magnitude makes the macroeconomic effects of Sanders's plan especially uncertain, but there is a risk that the very large tax increases could significantly weaken the U.S. economy."Write to Richard Rubin at richard.rubin@wsj.comCredit: By Richard Rubin

article name: Democrats on Campaign Trail in N.H. Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton appeal to voters before Tuesday primary
article text: Democratic presidential candidate Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont speaks at the Franklin Pierce University Fieldhouse in Rindge, N.H., on Saturday.Democratic presidential candidate former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton greets a resident as she knocks on doors Saturday in Manchester, N.H.Bernie Sanders greets attendees after a campaign rally at the Franklin Pierce University Fieldhouse in Rindge, N.H.Hillary Clinton greets audience members at a 'Get Out the Vote' campaign rally in Concord, N.H., on Saturday.Attendees listen to Bernie Sanders at a campaign stop at the Franklin Pierce University Fieldhouse.Hillary Clinton greets patrons at Belmont Hall and Restaurant in Manchester, N.H., on Saturday.

article name: Hillary Clinton's New Gambit: Auto Bailout vs. Wall Street Ties; Pressed on financial-industry ties, Clinton attacks Democratic rival Bernie Sanders for refusing to back bailout package that helped car industry
article text: WASHINGTON--After long playing defense over her close ties to Wall Street, Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton tried to shift the terms of the argument Sunday night, using the stage of a debate in Michigan to blast her challenger for opposing financial-industry bailout funds that were also used to keep afloat the auto industry in 2009.The former secretary of state's paid speeches to, and contributions from, the financial industry were once again a prominent issue in her seventh debate with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, taking up about 10 minutes of the two-hour session Sunday night in Flint, Mich. Most of the back-and-forth covered well-trodden ground.But Mrs. Clinton added a new twist, attacking Mr. Sanders for refusing to back the federal government's $700 billion bailout package, which was originally intended for financial institutions but ended up also giving a lifeline to the struggling domestic car industry."If everybody voted the way he did, I believe the auto industry would have collapsed," said Mrs. Clinton. She called her opponent a "one-issue candidate" who failed to make the difficult choice of saving four million middle class jobs and saving the industry that dominates the economy of Michigan, which holds its primary contest Tuesday.More on Election 2016* Flint Democratic Presidential Debate--Recap* Democrats Eye Next Fights* Clinton, Sanders Head Into Seventh Democratic Primary Debate* Clinton's Louisiana Win Helps Offset Two Caucus Defeats* Trump Leads Rivals in Michigan, Trails Clinton in General Election Test, Poll Finds* Flint Begins Replacing Lead Pipes* 2016 Election PollsMr. Sanders defended his decision to vote against the auto bailout, saying he was opposing federal funds to the financial industry. "I will be damned if it was the working people of this country who had to bail out the crooks on Wall Street," he said.This is the first of two Democratic debates this week. The candidates are scheduled to meet again on Wednesday night in Miami, ahead of the March 15 Florida primary.Unlike with the Republican candidates, Wall Street regulation has been one of the key issues dominating the Democratic contest, with Mr. Sanders repeatedly charging that Mrs. Clinton has taken too much money from the financial sector in speaking fees and campaign contributions to be able to police the industry effectively.Defending her Wall Street donations once again Sunday night, Mrs. Clinton repeated her response that President Barack Obama accepted significant contributions from Wall Street and then and passed the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act imposing strict new restrictions on the financial industry.Mr. Sanders yet again pressured Mrs. Clinton to release transcripts of her paid speeches to Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and other Wall Street firms. She gave a trio of speeches to Goldman for $225,000 apiece.Mrs. Clinton said she will do so when all candidates, including Republicans, do the same with their paid speeches."I'll be happy to release as long as everybody does else, too," said Mrs. Clinton.The U.S. government intervened in January 2009 to bail out General Motors Co. and what was then called Chrysler Group LLC, in a move intended to avert a collapse of the two automakers and prevent the loss of millions of jobs.Congress voted to release $350 billion to aid automakers as part of the Treasury Department's $700 billion bailout fund intended for the financial industry.Credit: By Donna Borak

article name: Hillary Clinton's Louisiana Win Helps Offset Two Caucus Defeats; Democratic rival Bernie Sanders wins contests in Kansas and Nebraska
article text: Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders rebounded from a string of tough defeats with victories in Kansas and Nebraska on Saturday, but he lost to front-runner Hillary Clinton in Louisiana , a split decision that is unlikely to erode her commanding lead in delegates.As in previous contests, Mr. Sanders, a senator from Vermont, prevailed in states that are predominantly white, while Mrs. Clinton dominated in a Southern state where African-Americans account for a substantial share of Democratic voters.Mr. Sanders was winning Nebraska 55% to 45% with about 80% of precincts reporting, according to the Associated Press, and he won the Kansas vote by 68% to 32%. In Louisiana, Mrs. Clinton had nearly 70% of the vote to 24% for Mr. Sanders, with 90% of precincts reporting"We have the momentum," Mr. Sanders said in a statement released after the Kansas Democratic Party announced he had won. "We have a path toward victory. Our campaign is just getting started and we are going all the way to the Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia."What he doesn't have are the delegates--or at least enough of them.Heading into Saturday's contests, Mrs. Clinton held a lead of 604 to 408 in pledged delegates. She also has the support of 458 "superdelegates"--party leaders and officials free to back the candidate of their choosing. Mr. Sanders has the backing of 22 superdelegates. A candidate needs 2,383 delegates to clinch the Democratic nomination.Because delegates are awarded proportionally based on results, it is difficult for a trailing candidate to leapfrog ahead.Recognizing that dynamic, Brad Woodhouse, president of a pro-Clinton super PAC called Correct the Record, said in a statement: "With today's results, Hillary Clinton cemented her delegate lead over Bernie Sanders. While Sanders may claim a win or two, anyone looking at the delegate count can see the truth: his odds of taking the nomination are next to nil."This past Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton won seven states concentrated in the South, piling up a lead of nearly 200 pledged delegates. Mr. Sanders won his home state of Vermont and also Oklahoma, Minnesota and Colorado.At an earlier point in the race, such an outcome would have been seen as a triumph for Mr. Sanders, a 74-year-old self-described democratic socialist who started off the race a heavy underdog. But his narrow defeat in Iowa on Feb. 1, followed by his 22-point victory in New Hampshire the following week, raised expectations that he could go toe-to-toe with Mrs. Clinton.Having survived the early scare, the Clinton family seems palpably relieved. Campaigning in Nebraska on the eve of the caucuses, Bill Clinton barely mentioned Mr. Sanders."We've just been through an amazing stretch that has totally changed this race in the Democratic primary," the former president said at a rally in Omaha on Friday. He added: "It's been a challenging time because the Republicans have spent the last three-plus years trying to take her down. They're basically pleading, 'Please, don't make us run against her!' "The trio of states holding contests Saturday underscored how difficult it is for Mr. Sanders to mount a comeback. His campaign targeted Kansas and Nebraska, airing TV ads in both states. Together, those states offer a total of 58 delegates--just seven more than Louisiana, where in the 2008 Democratic primary, about half of Democratic voters were African-American. Mr. Sanders's campaign ran radio spots in Louisiana but stayed off TV, an aide said.The Clinton campaign is now making the case that she has already amassed a daunting delegate advantage.Her aides sent out an email Saturday morning reiterating the point that her delegate lead over Mr. Sanders exceeds the lead that Barack Obama held over her at any point in the hard-fought 2008 Democratic primary.Dismissing that argument, the Sanders campaign said it is trailing because the Democratic primary calendar was "front-loaded"--filled with early contests in states friendly to Mrs. Clinton.Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager, said the Vermont senator expects to do well in any number of states that come later on, including Arizona, Alaska and Hawaii later this month, and Wisconsin, New York and Pennsylvania in April."There are still so many states to come," Mr. Weaver said. "If the states at the back of the calendar were instead at the front, we'd be having a very different conversation now."Three more contests will be held over the next three days: Maine on Sunday, followed by Michigan and Mississippi on Tuesday. Mr. Sanders sees Michigan as an important prize, and he has campaigned hard in the state.Hoping to endear himself to voters who have seen their manufacturing base suffer, Mr. Sanders has trumpeted his opposition to free-trade agreements and cast Mrs. Clinton as an unreliable ally of working-class families that have lost jobs to international trade pacts.Mrs. Clinton, too, has poured time and money into Michigan. She has made the water crisis in Flint a rallying cry of her candidacy, insisting that the Democratic debate Sunday take place in Flint to showcase the city's troubles.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: How Progressives Drive Income Inequality; The Obama years proved that transfer payments reduce incentives to work and lower incomes. Yet Clinton and Sanders are eager to go the same route.
article text: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are promising all types of programs to make America a more equal country. That's no surprise. But when you look at performance and not rhetoric, the administrations of political progressives have made the distribution of income more unequal than their adversaries, who supposedly favor the wealthy.The Census Bureau releases annual updates on income distribution in the U.S., publishing three technical statistical measures--the Gini index, the mean logarithmic deviation of income (mean log deviation for short), and the Theil index--each of which represents inequality levels on a scale of 0 to 1 (zero signifies perfect equality and 1 indicates perfect inequality). By all three measures, inequality rose more under Bill Clinton than under Ronald Reagan. And it wasn't even close. While the inequality increase as measured by the Gini index was only slightly more during Clinton's two terms, the Theil index and mean log deviation increased two and three times as much, respectively.Barack Obama's administration follows this pattern, despite the complaints he and his supporters have made about his predecessor. The mean log deviation increased 37% more under Mr. Obama than under President George W. Bush, although when this statistic was released, Mr. Obama had only six years as president compared with Mr. Bush's eight. The Gini index rose more than three times as much under Mr. Obama than under Mr. Bush. The Theil index increased sharply during the Obama administration, while it fell slightly under Bush 43.Sure, no president intends to raise inequality. And the spin doctors for Messrs. Clinton and Obama may insist that it wasn't their fault.But consider their policies. Both Democratic presidents presided over bubble economies fueled by easy monetary policy. There is no better way to make the rich richer than to run policies that push up the price of financial assets. Cheap money is a boon to those who have access to it. Interest rates were also too low under Bush 43, but that bubble was in housing, and the effects were therefore more evenly distributed than under Mr. Clinton's stock-market bubble or Mr. Obama's credit bubble.Money matters, but so do other policies, such as the long, historic sweep of the expanding welfare state. In 1968, government transfer payments totaled $53 billion or roughly 7% of personal income. By 2014, these had climbed to $2.5 trillion--about 17% of personal income. Despite the redistribution of a sixth of all income, inequality measured by all three of the Census Bureau's indexes is far higher today than in 1968.Transfer payments under Mr. Obama increased by $560 billion. By contrast private-sector wages and salaries grew by $1.1 trillion. So for every $2 in extra wages, about $1 was paid out in extra transfer payments--lowering the relative reward to work. Forty-five million people received food stamps in mid-2015, an increase of 46% since the end of 2008. Similarly, 71.6 million individuals were enrolled in Medicaid and the Children's Health Insurance Program, an increase of 13.3 million since October 2013.In 2008, during the deepest recession in 75 years, 13.2% of Americans lived below the government's official poverty line. The Great Recession officially ended in June 2009, but in 2014, after five years of economic expansion, 14.8% of Americans were still in poverty. The economy was better, and there were a lot more handouts, but still poverty rose.The structure of American households shows how this happened. From 2008 through 2014, the most recent year for which we have data, the number of two-earner households declined. These two-earner households have become the backbone of the American middle class.Research by the Hamilton Project and the Urban Institute show that when families with children making between $20,000 and $50,000 attempt to have a second earner go back to work, the effective tax rate on the extra earnings--including lost government benefits such as food stamps, the earned-income tax credit, and medical support payments--is between 50% and 80%. This phaseout of the ever increasing array of benefits has created a "working-class trap" instead of a "poverty trap" that is increasing inequality and keeping the income of these households lower than they might otherwise be.While the number of two-earner households declined during the first six years of the Obama presidency, the number of single-earner households rose by 2.6 million and the number of households with no earners rose by almost five million. In other words, two thirds of the increase in the number of families under Mr. Obama was accounted for by households with no one working. This is the reason the middle class has shrunk, and the reason inequality has increased. And unless we increase the number of people wanting to work and the number of jobs through economic growth, inequality will only increase.The flip side of the progressive agenda to redistribute income to those with less is to raise taxes on the "rich." The data show that it is also an ineffective way to reduce inequality.President Clinton increased the top tax rate on higher earners--yet inequality rose during his administration, and faster than under the tax-cutting Ronald Reagan. The same happened under President Obama. Tax rates went up on upper-income earners. Inequality rose too, and more than under his tax-cutting predecessor.A recent Brookings Institution study--whose authors include Peter Orszag, President Obama's director of the Office of Management and Budget--found that boosting the top tax rates even more, as Sen. Sanders suggests, would have little or no effect on inequality. The paper explored the effects of raising the highest marginal income-tax rate to 50% from 39.6%. Assuming no behavioral effects, the expected revenue was then distributed directly (and in theory costlessly) to the bottom 20% of income earners.The $95 billion in extra taxes and transfers reduced the Gini Coefficient by only 0.003. To put that in perspective, that reversed only one fifth of the increase in inequality during the Obama presidency.There was a catch. When the authors assumed that there might be a behavioral response by higher income taxpayers, inequality fell--but for the wrong reasons. Less work, saving, investing and more tax sheltering reduced the taxable income of higher earners and therefore meant less revenue to redistribute. So the rich got poorer, by their own choice, but the poor got less in benefits. A true lose-lose situation.None of this should really be surprising. If the socialist ideal of "from each according to his ability, to each according to his need" worked in practice, the Berlin Wall might still be standing. Of course, one of the reasons it came down is that a new ruling class emerged to take from the productive and give to those in need, siphoning off a cut of the swag along the way. Ruling classes always have sticky fingers.Redistribution through the political process is not costless--even in a perfect world there would be a large bureaucracy to feed. Special-interest elites also emerge when so much money is being moved around. They take their cut, introducing even more inefficiency into the system.Presidential contenders who boast of their plans to reduce inequality might ponder the fact that providing more free things is not the answer. Even free college and free health care are paid with taxes that discourage people from increasing their work, savings and entrepreneurship.Attacking the rich and running against inequality may be a sensible political strategy. But in the end the programs to implement this strategy make the problem worse. Yet advocates come back and demand the same programs. That is perilously close to the definition of insanity attributed to Einstein: doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results.The repeated failure of political promises has another downside--increasing voter alienation and cynicism. The appeal of redistribution is understandable, but voters who think the progressives running today are going to reduce inequality are falling into the same trap as people entering fifth or sixth marriages--the triumph of hope over experience.Mr. Lindsey, a former Federal Reserve governor and assistant to President George W. Bush for economic policy, is president and CEO of the Lindsey Group. He is the author of "Conspiracies of the Ruling Class," out on March 8 from Simon & Schuster.Credit: By Lawrence B. Lindsey

article name: Hillary Clinton Triumphs in Delegate-Rich Super Tuesday States; Front-runner's wins leaves Bernie Sanders diminished room for a comeback
article text: Hillary Clinton won sweeping primary victories in Texas and throughout the South on Tuesday, a sign that the Democratic front-runner was vaulting to a commanding lead in the race for the presidential nomination--and leaving rival Bernie Sanders diminishing space to stage a comeback.The former senator and secretary of state easily won the delegate-rich states of Virginia , Georgia , Alabama , Tennessee and Arkansas , as well as Texas , propelled by African-American and other minority voters who are a sizable share of the Democratic electorate in those states.She also took a narrow victory over Mr. Sanders in Massachusetts , another state with a delegate bonanza. With that win, Mrs. Clinton showed she could take a state traditionally in the party's liberal wing from Mr. Sanders--and one that is next door to his home state of Vermont.Mr. Sanders won primaries in Vermont and Oklahoma as well as caucuses in Colorado and Minnesota ."What a super Tuesday!" Mrs. Clinton said in celebration from Florida, during a speech that touched on general-election themes. In an unmistakable reference to the slogan of Republican front-runner Donald Trump, who was having his own strong night, she said, "America has never stopped being great. We have to make America whole."Mrs. Clinton's dominant performance on the biggest day of the primary season amounted to a decisive resurgence for a candidate who lost one bid for the presidency in 2008 after being the early favorite.This time around, initially favored to win everywhere, Mrs. Clinton captured Iowa on Feb. 1 by the barest of margins over Mr. Sanders, then lost New Hampshire by 22 points the next week. That slow start prompted consternation by some Democrats, casting her as a flawed candidate who they said had yet to lay out a compelling rationale for being president.But Mrs. Clinton retooled her message over the past few weeks, speaking in more personal terms about the need to break down barriers that keep all Americans from advancing. Those changes paid off Tuesday, and with the nomination now in sight, she began to look ahead to a possible showdown with Mr. Trump."Instead of building walls, we're going to break down barriers and build ladders of opportunity and empowerment so every American can live up to his or her potential," Mrs. Clinton told cheering supporters in Miami, referring to the wall Mr. Trump has promised to build between the U.S. and Mexico. "Because then and only then can America live up to its full potential."Mrs. Clinton's margins of victory Tuesday ranged from about 30 percentage points in Virginia--an important battleground in the general election--to 60 points in Alabama.In another general-election battleground, Colorado, won by Mr. Sanders, a line of voters snaked through the hallway of Denver North High School in the city's Highland neighborhood."A lot of people here know what she is capable of and know she is capable of leading the country," said Linda Garcia, who caucused for Mrs. Clinton at Denver North.But Sanders supporters said they wished their candidate could press forward. "I hope he has a chance. It's always tough for somebody who is preaching a lot of change to come up against the big money," said Steve Eagleburger, a supporter of Mr. Sanders. "I guess we'll see after tonight."The race in Massachusetts, won by Mrs. Clinton with just over 50% of the vote, was also being closely watched. The outcome in the solidly Democratic state could foreshadow the direction of a party that has been divided between Mr. Sanders's idealism and Mrs. Clinton's pragmatism.Read More in Capital Journal* Clinton, Trump Turn Super Tuesday Into Delegate Hauls* CAPITAL JOURNAL: After Super Tuesday, Republicans Face Moment of Truth* SEIB VIDEO: Is Trump's Momentum Unstoppable After Super Tuesday Wins?* Donald Trump Notches More Wins, but Ted Cruz's Victories Promise Long Race* After Two Wins, Ted Cruz Sees a Two-Horse Race* Republican Divide About Trump Grows* Sanders Plans for the Long Run* Clinton's Embrace Of Party Establishment Contrasts With Republican Candidates* Exit Polls Show Wider Partisan Divide in Super Tuesday Presidential VotingMr. Sanders, addressing supporters in Vermont shortly after polls closed there, appeared to be preparing his backers for a disappointing night. He explained that even with a loss, his campaign would win delegates under the party's allocation rules, and he emphasized the long road ahead ."At the end of tonight, 15 states will have voted; 35 states remain," Mr. Sanders said. "And let me assure you that we are going to take our fight for economic justice, for social justice, for environmental sanity, for a world of peace, to every one of those states."At stake were 878 pledged delegates to the summer convention, the biggest single-day prize in the Democratic race and more than one-third of the 2,383 delegates needed to capture the nomination. Eleven states were in play, plus American Samoa and a contingent of Democrats living abroad.Late in the evening, Mrs. Clinton had added 373 delegates , giving her 464 pledged delegates, which are awarded by voters. In addition, she has support of 457 superdelegates, who can vote for anyone they choose, according to a tally by the Associated Press.Mr. Sanders had added 189 delegates, giving him 254, plus 22 superdelegates.Mr. Sanders came into Super Tuesday after a 48-percentage-point loss in South Carolina last Saturday, his second defeat in a row. The loss pointed to a structural weakness in his campaign: difficulty making inroads with African-American voters who have yet to warm in large numbers to his message about income inequality and the unfairness of the campaign-finance system.Though Mr. Sanders is flush with campaign money, his advisers decided not to air TV ads in some of the Super Tuesday states with large minority populations, given his low odds of prevailing there. The Sanders campaign focused his TV advertising instead on other Super Tuesday states that looked more promising, including Colorado, Minnesota, Virginia and Oklahoma.Mr. Sanders needed to put some wins on the board and undercut perceptions that his rival was the inevitable nominee. His easy win in Vermont was expected; he won re-election in 2012 with 71% of the vote.With 89% of the Oklahoma vote counted, Mr. Sanders had 52% compared with 41% for Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders also invested heavily in Minnesota and Colorado, visiting both states repeatedly. Mr. Sanders drew 18,000 people in a rally in Denver last month and thousands more at a rally at Colorado State University on Sunday.Still, the senator's challenge has been converting that enthusiasm into votes.Turnout on the Democratic side has flagged compared with the 2008 election, when Mrs. Clinton ran against then-Sen. Barack Obama. In the New Hampshire primary last month, Democratic turnout was 13% lower than in 2008, and in South Carolina, it was 31% lower.That could present a challenge to Democrats in the general election, as turnout in the raucous Republican primaries has been higher.Dan Frosch contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary Clinton Faces a Test Wooing Bernie Sanders Backers; Interviews suggest some of the Vermont senator's fans wouldn't support the front-runner
article text: LINCOLN, Neb.--It is rare for the crowd to boo at a Bernie Sanders rally. When it happens, it is usually at the point he invokes the name of his opponent in the Democratic presidential race, Hillary Clinton.With Mrs. Clinton holding a substantial lead in the race for convention delegates, many Sanders loyalists are grappling with an uncomfortable question: If he loses, would they back her?Interviews with a number of Sanders supporters present an unclear picture. Some say they wouldn't vote for the former senator and secretary of state if she wins the party nomination. Others say they would, reluctantly. Still others see strengths in Mrs. Clinton and would unconditionally back her for the White House.The Democratic primary fight has been nowhere near as divisive as the Republican one. Still, in a campaign stop Monday in Grand Rapids, Mich., Mrs. Clinton made clear she is aware of what might lie ahead as she talked about the hard-fought 2008 race against Barack Obama and her work in helping the nominee pull in her supporters once he wrapped up the nomination that June.That effort wasn't entirely successful--one pro-Clinton group held out and defiantly campaigned for Republican nominee John McCain."I had a lot of passionate supporters who did not feel like they wanted to support then-Sen. Obama. I worked as hard as I could. I nominated him at the convention. I made the case, because he and I shared a lot of the same views," she said. "I would hope to be able to enlist Bernie in helping me reach out to his supporters if I am so fortunate to be the nominee."Mr. Sanders, a Vermont senator, has given every indication he would endorse Mrs. Clinton if she wins the nomination. He says he likes and respects her and has set limits on how negative he is willing to go.But it isn't clear how many of his die-hard supporters would fall in line. A February Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed half the Sanders supporters have a positive view of Mrs. Clinton, but 31% have a negative one. About four in 10 Sanders supporters say they worry about Mrs. Clinton's "ties to Wall Street and millions in speaking fees."At a speech in Lincoln last week, Mr. Sanders elicited boos when he mentioned Wall Street donations collected by a pro-Clinton super PAC.Kathleen Worcester, a 42-year-old who came to hear Mr. Sanders at a rally last week in Portland, Maine, said she is unsure of what she would do if her candidate doesn't win. Mrs. Clinton "seems like a moderate conservative to me," she said.Clinton aides say she has long been mindful that, as a nominee, she would need the support of Sanders backers, many of whom see her as the embodiment of the establishment politics they hope the senator would vanquish.At times, she has been sharply critical of Mr. Sanders--the two candidates interrupted and talked over each other at a testy debate Sunday night in Flint, Mich. --but she has also tried to direct her barbs at Republicans in hopes of unifying Democrats behind a common enemy."We have differences, but those differences pale in comparison to what we see going on with the Republicans right now," she said in Grand Rapids.And she has offered overt outreach, particularly to the young voters who overwhelmingly favor Mr. Sanders. "I want you to know," she tells those voters, "even if you don't support me, I support you."For now, Mr. Sanders is doing nothing to endear the front-runner to his supporters. "There are many people, including my opponent, who want you to think kind of small," he said at a recent campaign stop.Marcus Johnson, 24, one of about 10,000 people who came to hear Mr. Sanders speak at Michigan State University last week, said he would never vote for Mrs. Clinton and would consider backing the Green Party candidate if Mr. Sanders doesn't win the nomination."Honestly, I think she's a Republican," he said.Others are open to supporting her, though some say unenthusiastically."It would be a definite vote against the GOP and not for Hillary," said Harriet Scureman, 71, of Norwalk, Conn. "There isn't anything Hillary does or says that inspires me or makes me think she will make a difference."On the other hand, Katherine Steinfield, 22, a senior at Michigan State who prefers Mr. Sanders, said Mrs. Clinton, as a woman, has had to overcome obstacles that Mr. Sanders never faced. "I think she's impressive, too," she said.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary Clinton Widens Delegate Lead, but Bernie Sanders Shows Strength; Vermont senator's Michigan victory gives him a jolt ahead of March 15 contests
article text: Even as Hillary Clinton continued to pad her lead in the delegate count, Bernie Sanders's victory in Michigan showed strength for the first time in a large, racially diverse state far from his home base of New England.The Vermont senator and Mrs. Clinton split Michigan's 147 delegates, 65 to 58 for Mr. Sanders. But the former secretary of state won Mississippi by a wide margin, gaining 29 of the 33 delegates. She now has 1,221 delegates , more than half the 2,302 she needs to win the nomination, the Associated Press reports.
