Mr. Sanders has 571.Clinton campaign officials on Wednesday continued to project confidence, noting that even though Mrs. Clinton narrowly lost Michigan, she netted more delegates in Tuesday's contests by winning big in Mississippi."From the beginning, we have approached this nomination contest as a battle for delegates," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said. "So, while Sen. Sanders has placed big bets on pulling out wins in certain individual states, we have sought to compete everywhere in every state with the goal of amassing the most delegates possible.""Last night really showed why that approach makes sense," Mr. Mook added.Mrs. Clinton's win in Mississippi completed a clean sweep of the Deep South powered by her overwhelming popularity among African-American voters in the region. But Mr. Sanders, in winning his most populous state this primary season, made inroads with black voters in Michigan, according to exit polls, winning 30% of the state's African-American primary vote.The victory gives Mr. Sanders a jolt of momentum at an important moment in the race. He and Mrs. Clinton face off Wednesday night in a debate in Florida.Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said Michigan sent an important message about Mr. Sanders's viability."It's a big win," Mr. Devine said. It's going to give a lot of people who weren't sure that Bernie could really prevail in this process a lot of hope that he will. Interest in his candidacy will rise and support of his candidacy both from voters and financial supporters will increase as a result of it."Nearly 700 convention delegates are at stake in the next round of voting on March 15, and the Sanders camp hopes the Michigan result will reverberate in two other large Midwestern states that vote then: Ohio and Illinois.The other three states to vote next Tuesday are Florida, Missouri and North Carolina.A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed the Democratic race tightening nationally, with Mrs. Clinton's lead over Mr. Sanders narrowing to nine points among Democratic primary voters. In February, the former secretary of state led by 11 points, and in January, she led by 24 points in the poll.Both candidates had fought hard in Michigan. Trailing in delegates and written off by some Democrats, Mr. Sanders visited the state repeatedly and aired TV ads for the past three weeks in hopes of proving he could go toe-to-toe with Mrs. Clinton in a large industrial state.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Capital Journal: Angry White Males Propel Donald Trump--and Bernie Sanders* Tenor of Campaign Takes a Toll: WSJ/NBC Poll* Democrats Draw a Diverse Voting Pool in Exit Polls* Clinton's Lead Over Sanders Narrows Slightly in WSJ/NBC Poll* Michigan Turnout Shows Split on ClintonDespite Mrs. Clinton's blowout win in Mississippi , the Michigan loss is a serious setback given the time she spent campaigning in the state. Mrs. Clinton put the water crisis in the city of Flint front-and-center, using her national platform to get more money and assistance for a city plagued by polluted drinking water.On the trail, her husband, former President Bill Clinton, repeatedly invoked her response to the Flint crisis as evidence she has the temperament and judgment to be president. The appeal fell short, with Mr. Sanders winning the bulk of counties across the state, although Mrs. Clinton won the counties in the populous Detroit region."There are similarities between Michigan and parts of Ohio and Illinois that have experienced high levels of deindustrialization due to policies that Secretary Clinton has supported over and over again," said Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager.That line of attack has been taken by Mr. Sanders himself, highlighting Mrs. Clinton's early support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement with Pacific Rim nations and for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was signed by her husband in the 1990s.Bob Davis contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: Democratic Presidential Candidates Eye Next Fights After Split Weekend Wins; Bernie Sanders says he still has a path to victory; Hillary Clinton plays up her lead in delegate totals
article text: FLINT, Mich.--A split in the outcome of Democratic contests over the weekend did little to change the contours of the race between Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders, and polls showed the former secretary of state is poised to soon build on her delegate lead in larger states.Mr. Sanders scored victories in the Nebraska and Kansas caucuses on Saturday and in Maine on Sunday , where he held a 64% to 36% advantage with four-fifths of precincts reporting.But his wins in smaller states didn't dent Mrs. Clinton's lead among pledged delegates. She won big in Saturday'sprimary in Louisiana , beating the Vermont senator by 48 percentage points and continuing her domination in Southern states where minority voters make up a larger share of the electorate.More on Election 2016* Flint Democratic Presidential Debate--Recap* Clinton, Sanders Head Into Seventh Democratic Primary Debate* Clinton's Louisiana Win Helps Offset Two Caucus Defeats* Trump Leads Rivals in Michigan, Trails Clinton in General Election Test, Poll Finds* Flint Begins Replacing Lead PipesMr. Sanders's opportunities to change this dynamic are dwindling. The next votes will be cast Tuesday in Michigan, as well as Mississippi.A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll shows Mrs. Clinton with a double-digit lead in Michigan. Mrs. Clinton is the preferred candidate of 57% of likely Democratic primary voters, while 40% back the Vermont senator, according to the poll, which was released Sunday.The candidates squared off in a debate Sunday in Flint , which has been buffeted by a crisis from lead-poisoned water . Mr. Sanders said he was "shattered" by what he heard about the water crisis in town-hall meetings."It was beyond belief that children in Flint, Michigan, in the United States of America in the year 2016 are being poisoned. That is clearly not what this country should be about," he said.He repeated his call for Republican Gov. Rick Snyder to resign. For the first time, Mrs. Clinton agreed and added that if he doesn't resign, he should be recalled. That was a shift; in the past, she mocked that solution as inadequate."It is raining lead in Flint," Mrs. Clinton said Sunday, urging the state to take money from its "rainy day" fund to help. "The state is derelict in not coming forward with the money that is required."After notching wins in weekend caucuses, the Vermont senator declared he still has a path to victory, vowing to take his campaign all the way to the Democratic convention in July. Mrs. Clinton, though, noted that she actually won more delegates in Saturday's contests."We will net delegates and we're feeling good about the coming contests," Mrs. Clinton told CBS on Sunday.Mrs. Clinton solidified her position last week as the Democratic front-runner with a sweep of delegate-rich states on Super Tuesday. Her delegate lead now exceeds the largest margin then-Sen. Barack Obama ever held during his march to the Democratic nomination in 2008. Making up ground will be a steep challenge for Mr. Sanders, in part because delegates are awarded proportionally.Still, Sanders campaign officials have argued the calendar was "front-loaded" with states that were essentially friendly terrain for Mrs. Clinton.They have projected confidence that he can win more of the later contests.The Democratic candidates have long trained their sights on the Michigan primary, with Sanders campaign officials characterizing the contest as a "big showdown." But to win there, the Vermont senator would need to broaden his coalition and win more support from minority voters--something he so far hasn't done.On Sunday, Mr. Sanders predicted he would gain traction, particularly with younger minority voters."What we are seeing in many cases is not just a racial divide but a generational divide," Mr. Sanders said on CNN. "We are doing better and better with younger people whether they're black, Latino or white.""Truth is, we have not done well in the deep South, but I am absolutely certain that our numbers will continue to get better," he added.While Mrs. Clinton has carried minority voters by wide margins, she noted on Sunday that she also has won more support from white voters than her opponent."I have gotten more votes than anybody running on either side," she told CBS. "And we have gotten it from a wide, broad base....In the Democratic primary election, I have gotten more white voters, except for the state of Vermont. All told, I have had more support from white voters."Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders pressed their cases in Michigan, scheduling events across the state ahead of the primary. The former secretary of state spoke at three Detroit-area churches on Sunday, and Mr. Sanders planned a trio of campaign rallies in the state on Monday.On Sunday morning, Mrs. Clinton continued to take aim at Republican front-runner Donald Trump and his promise to "make America great again." She told parishioners in Detroit that the country never stopped being great but that she would make the country whole again.Brent Kendall and Laura Meckler contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders Head Into Seventh Democratic Primary Debate; Pressure is on Sanders to change the dynamics of the contest
article text: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders will meet in Flint, Mich. on Sunday for the seventh Democratic primary debate of the 2016 presidential-election cycle, facing off after both notched victories over the weekend.Mrs. Clinton looks increasingly well positioned to win the nomination in the coming weeks after winning the majority of states and delegates in Tuesday's 11 state nominating contests and posting convincing victories in Louisiana, South Carolina and Nevada in February.Mr. Sanders, who has seen his momentum stall since winning New Hampshire in early February, won Saturday caucuses in Nebraska and Kansas. He has vowed to continue his campaign, though his path to winning the Democratic nomination is increasingly narrow.Heading into Saturday's contests, Mrs. Clinton held a lead of 604 to 408 in pledged delegates. She also has the support of 458 "superdelegates"--party leaders and officials free to back the candidate of their choosing.This is the first of two debates this week. The candidates are scheduled to meet again on Wednesday in Miami. Two more debates are scheduled after that with dates and times still to be determined.Here's what each candidate needs to do in Sunday's meeting:Hillary ClintonMrs. Clinton has shone on the debate stage in previous appearances, coming across as polished and substantive. She is likely to be equally well prepared Sunday.After running up big margins among black voters in a number of crucial states Mrs. Clinton has again assumed the mantle of front-runner in the Democratic race. In short, the pressure is now on Mr. Sanders to change the dynamics of the race with his performance.Mrs. Clinton will need to avoid major pitfalls or stumbles. She also needs to be ready to answer questions from the moderators about the FBI investigation into her private email server while serving at the State Department. And she has struggled to answer Mr. Sanders's attacks on Wall Street.She is at her strongest when talking about foreign affairs, after serving as Secretary of State for three years. On domestic policy, she is more vulnerable to Mr. Sanders's attacks--particularly on her long financial relationship with Wall Street donors. She will need to parry those attacks and convince Democratic primary voters that she can be trusted to regulate.In the absence of major stumbles or unexpected developments in the controversies over her use of private email, Mrs. Clinton remains well positioned to clinch the nomination in the coming weeks.Bernie SandersMr. Sanders has failed to make any dent in Mrs. Clinton's huge level of support from African-American voters--and the result has been a series of losses in largely southern states with black populations while picking up traction in mostly white states.His single biggest challenge remains improving his numbers with those voters."What we are seeing in many cases is not just a racial divide but a generational divide," Mr. Sanders said on CNN's "State of the Union." "We are doing better and better with younger people whether they're black, Latino or white.""Truth is, we have not done well in the deep south but I am absolutely certain that our numbers will continue to get better," he added.Nationally televised debates still remain one of the best ways to do that. He will have to make the case that he, not Mrs. Clinton, is best positioned to address issues of racial inequality and discrimination and that his policies will have tangible benefits for many black voters.He also will have to grapple with the fact that Democratic primary voters--especially African-Americans--by and large want to continue with President Barack Obama's policies, according to many polls. Mr. Sanders, on the other hand, has built his campaign around calling for what he calls a "political revolution"--calling for radical change on health-care policy and Wall Street regulation.He will have to reassure many Democrats that he intends to build on Mr. Obama's legacy, not tear it down.Brent Kendall contributed to this article.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Byron Tau

article name: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton Win in Louisiana but Lose Caucuses; Ted Cruz and Bernie Sanders each notch a pair of victories
article text: Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas won the Republican caucuses in Kansas and Maine on Saturday, while front-runner Donald Trump took the Louisiana primary.On the Democratic side, Sen. Bernie Sanders won the caucuses in Kansas and Nebraska , while front-runner Hillary Clinton took the primary in Louisiana.With all of the Kansas vote counted on the Republican side, Mr. Cruz, of Texas, had 48%, versus 23% for Mr. Trump, according to the Associated Press. Sen. Marco Rubio had nearly 17% of the vote, and Ohio Gov. John Kasich had nearly 11%. Kansas allocates its 40 convention delegates on a proportional basis to candidates who earn at least 10%.The state, one of four to vote in the Republican contests on Saturday, was expected to be favorable ground for Mr. Cruz because evangelicals make up about one-third of the total population. Mr. Cruz had made Kansas his first campaign destination after he won three states, to Mr. Trump's seven, in the Super Tuesday contests.In Maine, Mr. Cruz had 46% of the vote, while Mr. Trump had 33%. Mr. Kasich was in third place with 12%.In Louisiana, Mr. Trump had nearly 48% of the vote in the early stages of counting. The Republican contest in Kentucky had yet to be called.With the Kansas and Maine victories, Mr. Cruz has won six states, the second-most after Mr. Trump's 11. Mr. Rubio has one just one state, Minnesota.Mr. Sanders's wins in the Democratic caucuses could help slow Mrs. Clinton's ability to widen her delegate lead over the Vermont senator. Mr. Sanders had 55% in Nebraska versus 45% for Mrs. Clinton. In Kansas, the state party called the race for the senator with 90% of precincts counted; no breakdown of the vote was immediately available.The race in Louisiana was called early in the night, with Mrs. Clinton holding a 50-point lead, 71% to 21%. The state awards 51 Democratic delegates.Read More on Campaign Wire* At CPAC, Rubio Warns of 'Hijacked' Conservative Movement* Trump Reverses His Stance on Torture* RNC Chair Says Contested GOP Convention Is 'Highly Unlikely'* Bernie Sanders's Plan Would Raise Taxes by 34%, Analysis Finds* Hillary Clinton Proposes Tax Hit for Companies Moving Jobs, Production OverseasFor Republican challengers still hoping to block the party's front-runner, every state affords an opportunity to keep delegates out of the hands of Mr. Trump because the states aren't winner-take-all contests.What is more, these states give the businessman's more-experienced competitors an advantage because they are Republican-only nominating contests: Much of Mr. Trump's support has come from unaffiliated voters in states like New Hampshire where non-Republicans can vote in the primary.In Kentucky, Republicans for the first time were holding presidential caucuses rather than a primary--a change that had been made to help favorite son Sen. Rand Paul in his presidential bid, but he has since dropped out.The state awards delegates proportionately, but only to candidates who earn at least 5% of the vote.With 36% of precincts reporting, Mr. Trump had 40% of the vote, while Mr. Cruz had 31%. Mr. Rubio had 13.5%, and Mr. Kasich had 13%.Democrats won't hold their Kentucky nominating contest until May 17, when the state holds its primary election.Write to Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.comCredit: By Janet Hook

article name: Bernie Sanders's Plan Would Raise Taxes by 34%, Analysis Finds; Candidate concentrates increases on high-income households, but every bracket would pay more
article text: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders's tax plan is just as revolutionary as he promises--raising federal tax revenue by 34% and cutting the after-tax incomes of the wealthiest households nearly in half, according to an analysis released Friday.Mr. Sanders's plan, designed to pay for a significant expansion of government spending, is the largest and most dramatic of all the presidential candidates' and the least likely to find support from either party in Congress. That is saying something in a year when Republicans are proposing unprecedentedly large tax cuts and structural changes.Mr. Sanders's proposals would increase federal taxes by $15.3 trillion over the next decade, according to the Tax Policy Center. Mr. Sanders concentrates his tax increases on high-income households, which would face sharply higher levies on their wages, business income, capital gains and estates, as well as more limits on their deductions. The top 0.1%--those with incomes of $3.7 million under an expanded definition--would pay an average federal tax rate of 63.7% in 2017, up from 34.2%.The middle 20% of households would face an average tax increase of $4,692 in 2017 and lose 8.5% of after-tax income. The lowest-income households would lose, too, but they would come out even by 2025."Sanders is clearly betting that people are willing to pay for his expansive new welfare state," said Leonard Burman, director of the Tax Policy Center, who was a Treasury Department official under President Bill Clinton. "There's a giant tax increase, mostly on the rich, but everyone would pay more."The top effective marginal tax rate on wages would increase to 64.2% from 43.1%, and Mr. Sanders would raise the top rate on capital gains to 62% from 24.1%, while making it harder for wealthy individuals to defer or avoid capital gains taxes. He also would limit U.S. companies' ability to defer U.S. taxes on their foreign income, impose new taxes on financial transactions and create a new tax on carbon, with a rebate for consumers.New payroll taxes on employers and on all workers would pay for what Mr. Sanders calls Medicare for all and for paid family leave. The $15.3 trillion estimate appears to leave Mr. Sanders several trillion dollars short of paying for his promises, and that is assuming the tax increases don't inhibit economic growth.The center said Mr. Sanders's tax plan "would substantially reduce incentives to save and invest in the U.S." and would discourage lower-earning spouses from entering the workforce.The Sanders campaign didn't respond immediately to a request for comment on Friday. The campaign has said many households would fare better because they would be receiving expanded federal benefits, such as free college tuition and government-provided health care. The center's analysis doesn't include those benefits.Mr. Sanders's plan stands in contrast with that of his Democratic rival, Hillary Clinton. She proposes raising taxes on high-income households to pay for new spending and is offering targeted tax breaks and a forthcoming tax cut for middle-income households. For every $1 she is proposing to raise in taxes, Mr. Sanders wants to raise $14.24."Her experience in government and in politics for a long time tells her that those are the kinds of things she could get done. Bernie Sanders clearly wants to change things radically," Mr. Burman said.The center has now completed its estimates of the tax plans of the five leading presidential candidates--the two Democrats, along with Republicans Donald Trump, Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio. The center hasn't analyzed Republican John Kasich's plans because it lacks sufficient detail. In the general election, Mr. Burman said, the center will attempt to analyze the economic effect of tax changes along with the combined effect of tax and spending proposals.The center is a joint project of the Brookings Institution and the Urban Institute, and it used a bipartisan panel of reviewers to examine the Sanders plan.Its economists are generally skeptical of the idea that tax changes can prompt major economic responses. But Mr. Sanders's plan is so big that it might be different, the report said."The proposed tax changes on both labor and capital income are very large compared with any tax policy changes since World War II, so the empirical evidence of relatively small effects cited earlier may not apply," the report said. "The lack of prior historical experience for changes of this magnitude makes the macroeconomic effects of Sanders's plan especially uncertain, but there is a risk that the very large tax increases could significantly weaken the U.S. economy."Write to Richard Rubin at richard.rubin@wsj.comCredit: By Richard Rubin

article text: Voters in the Granite State cast their ballots in the nation's second presidential-nominating contestRepublican presidential candidate Donald Trump waves to his supporters at his primary night party in Manchester, N.H. article name: Hillary Clinton Widens Delegate Lead, but Bernie Sanders Shows Strength; Vermont senator's Michigan victory gives him a jolt ahead of March 15 contests
article text: Even as Hillary Clinton continued to pad her lead in the delegate count, Bernie Sanders's victory in Michigan showed strength for the first time in a large, racially diverse state far from his home base of New England.The Vermont senator and Mrs. Clinton split Michigan's 147 delegates, 65 to 58 for Mr. Sanders. But the former secretary of state won Mississippi by a wide margin, gaining 29 of the 33 delegates. She now has 1,221 delegates , more than half the 2,302 she needs to win the nomination, the Associated Press reports. Mr. Sanders has 571.Clinton campaign officials on Wednesday continued to project confidence, noting that even though Mrs. Clinton narrowly lost Michigan, she netted more delegates in Tuesday's contests by winning big in Mississippi."From the beginning, we have approached this nomination contest as a battle for delegates," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said. "So, while Sen. Sanders has placed big bets on pulling out wins in certain individual states, we have sought to compete everywhere in every state with the goal of amassing the most delegates possible.""Last night really showed why that approach makes sense," Mr. Mook added.Mrs. Clinton's win in Mississippi completed a clean sweep of the Deep South powered by her overwhelming popularity among African-American voters in the region. But Mr. Sanders, in winning his most populous state this primary season, made inroads with black voters in Michigan, according to exit polls, winning 30% of the state's African-American primary vote.The victory gives Mr. Sanders a jolt of momentum at an important moment in the race. He and Mrs. Clinton face off Wednesday night in a debate in Florida.Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said Michigan sent an important message about Mr. Sanders's viability."It's a big win," Mr. Devine said. It's going to give a lot of people who weren't sure that Bernie could really prevail in this process a lot of hope that he will. Interest in his candidacy will rise and support of his candidacy both from voters and financial supporters will increase as a result of it."Nearly 700 convention delegates are at stake in the next round of voting on March 15, and the Sanders camp hopes the Michigan result will reverberate in two other large Midwestern states that vote then: Ohio and Illinois.The other three states to vote next Tuesday are Florida, Missouri and North Carolina.A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed the Democratic race tightening nationally, with Mrs. Clinton's lead over Mr. Sanders narrowing to nine points among Democratic primary voters. In February, the former secretary of state led by 11 points, and in January, she led by 24 points in the poll.Both candidates had fought hard in Michigan. Trailing in delegates and written off by some Democrats, Mr. Sanders visited the state repeatedly and aired TV ads for the past three weeks in hopes of proving he could go toe-to-toe with Mrs. Clinton in a large industrial state.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Capital Journal: Angry White Males Propel Donald Trump--and Bernie Sanders* Tenor of Campaign Takes a Toll: WSJ/NBC Poll* Democrats Draw a Diverse Voting Pool in Exit Polls* Clinton's Lead Over Sanders Narrows Slightly in WSJ/NBC Poll* Michigan Turnout Shows Split on ClintonDespite Mrs. Clinton's blowout win in Mississippi , the Michigan loss is a serious setback given the time she spent campaigning in the state. Mrs. Clinton put the water crisis in the city of Flint front-and-center, using her national platform to get more money and assistance for a city plagued by polluted drinking water.On the trail, her husband, former President Bill Clinton, repeatedly invoked her response to the Flint crisis as evidence she has the temperament and judgment to be president. The appeal fell short, with Mr. Sanders winning the bulk of counties across the state, although Mrs. Clinton won the counties in the populous Detroit region."There are similarities between Michigan and parts of Ohio and Illinois that have experienced high levels of deindustrialization due to policies that Secretary Clinton has supported over and over again," said Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager.That line of attack has been taken by Mr. Sanders himself, highlighting Mrs. Clinton's early support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement with Pacific Rim nations and for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was signed by her husband in the 1990s.Bob Davis contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: Sanders Surprise; Michigan wasn't even supposed to be close.
article text: (Note: We'll be off tomorrow, returning Friday.) Maybe they thought he was related to local sports hero Barry Sanders. OK, that's implausible, but would you have believed us if we'd told you yesterday that Bernie Sanders was going to win the Michigan primary? Not if you checked the polls: The Real Clear Politics average, consisting of three surveys in the past week, put inevitable Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton up by 21.4 points; her narrowest margin in the trio of surveys was 13.The actual result: Sanders 49.8%, Mrs. Clinton 48.3%. Close, but a cigar.Mrs. Clinton, meanwhile, trounced Sanders in Mississippi , 82.6% to 16.5%--almost as wide a margin as his a week ago in the People's Republic of Vermont . But that was entirely expected. Mrs. Clinton has been sweeping the South, where the Democratic electorate is heavily black. In Mississippi , exit polls found blacks made up 71% of the electorate and went for Mrs. Clinton 89% to 11%.But in Michigan , only 23% of whose electorate is black, Sanders did better: 31% of the black vote vs. 65% for Mrs. Clinton. That could augur well for next week's primaries in Illinois and Ohio. And FiveThirtyEight's Nate Silver observed not long before midnight:Although there are a lot of reasonably good Clinton states on March 15--according to both polls and demographics--we then have a stretch of states that look quite strong for Sanders. These include Idaho, Utah, Arizona, Alaska, Washington, Hawaii, Wisconsin and Wyoming, all of which vote from March 22 to April 9.So if [Mrs.] Clinton underperforms her polls on March 15 in states such as Ohio as she did tonight in Michigan--and pollsters probably ought to be checking their turnout models carefully after tonight -- she could have a really long few weeks ahead, even though Sanders's delegate math remains highly challenging.To the extent that Sanders remains a viable candidate, we'd say it is because of two factors of demography--one a strength of his, the other a weakness of Mrs. Clinton's. The strength has been much remarked upon: Sanders's overwhelming support, outside the South anyway, from young voters.Michigan follows the pattern: Under-30 voters favored him 81% to 18%; over-65 voters backed her, 68% to 31%. Every way the pollsters break it down, there is a clear inverse correlation between age and Sanders support.In January Peggy Noonan argued that Sanders's appeal to the young is in large part ideological. For voters under 30, the events of 2008 would have played a significant part in informing their views of capitalism. Meanwhile they (and perhaps those up to a decade older) have little or no memory of the Cold War to turn them against socialism. And if Donald Trump loves the poorly educated , Bernie Sanders loves--or at least has put himself in a position to capitalize on--the miseducated:Let's say you're 20 or 30, meaning you'll be voting for a long time. What in your formative years would have taught you about the excellence of free markets, low taxes, "a friendly business climate"? A teacher in public high school? Maybe one--the faculty-lounge eccentric who boycotted the union meetings. And who in our colleges teaches the virtues of capitalism?Mrs. Clinton's weakness is one we've discussed before : Even among Democrats, she is on the distaff side of a gender gap. In Michigan she outpolled Sanders 51% to 46% among women, but he beat her 55% to 43% among men. That was enough to give him the victory even though women made up 56% of the Democratic electorate.Part of this gap is likely an artifact of the age distribution: Women tend to live longer than men, and thus (at least in the general population) tend increasingly to outnumber men of their cohort as time passes. But Mrs. Clinton and her supporters have also made heavy-handed appeals to female solidarity.The inevitable nominee herself achieved self-parody when she declared in a February debate : "Honestly, Sen. Sanders is the only person who I think would characterize me, a woman running to be the first woman president, as exemplifying the establishment."Honestly! Even Claire Underwood doesn't try to portray herself as an outsider. Fiction has to be believable. Nonfiction only has to be true.We've noted that such appeals seem to hold no interest for younger women, and we've argued that men of all ages are likely to find them off-putting. What's more, while there is no doubt a subset of the female population that sees "the first woman president" as a major selling point, it's not as if anyone is unaware of Mrs. Clinton's sex. What does it accomplish to belabor the point?Yet belabor it Mrs. Clinton and her supporters, including in the media, do. The latest kerfuffle arose in this past Sunday's debate when, as Vox's German Lopez describes it, Sanders "came off as a man shouting down a woman. And the live audience did not like it one bit."What happened? As Lopez acknowledges, she interrupted him, and he objected: "Excuse me, I'm talking."The Washington Post's Janell Ross has a lengthy explainer of why Sanders was wrong to object to Mrs. Clinton's womanterruption:Why, at this late date and this many debates into the 2016 presidential election cycle, has Sanders made demonstrably little to no effort to alter the way he interacts with the woman he at least strongly suspected he would be running against him from the day he declared his campaign? He has almost certainly had the same advice and information that every male candidate gets about the need to be constantly mindful about coming across like a chauvinist or a bully when on a debate stage facing a female competition.As Rich Lowry observes understatedly: "The debate flap demonstrates how feminism is caught between its dual insistence that women are indistinguishable from men and at the same time due special consideration because they're uniquely vulnerable to slights, intended or unintended."We suppose the debate, which was held in Michigan, couldn't actually have hurt Sanders that much, seeing as how he did manage to win there when everyone expected him to lose. It's only a matter of time before somebody calls him piggish for upsetting Mrs. Clinton on International Women's Day .Other Than That, the Story Was Accurate "Due to an oversight involving a haphazardly-installed Chrome extension during the editing process, the name Donald Trump was erroneously replaced with the phrase 'Someone With Tiny Hands' when this story originally published."--Wired.com, March 9Fox Butterfield, Is That You? You can come in with 16 quarters, eight dimes, and four nickels--we can give you a five-dollar bill. Or we can give you five singles. Or two singles, eight quarters, and 10 dimes. You'd be amazed at the variety of the options you have."--from "First Citiwide Change Bank II ," aired Oct. 8, 1988* "Bill Clinton in Evanston: Hillary Clinton 'Best Change-Maker' He's Ever Known"--headline, Chicago Tribune , March 9Life Imitates 'Saturday Night Live'--II* Al Franken: "I believe the '80s are gonna have to be different. I think that people are going to stop thinking about themselves, and start thinking about me, Al Franken. That's right. I believe we're entering what I like to call the Al Franken Decade. Oh, for me, Al Franken, the '80s will be pretty much the same as the '70s. I'll still be thinking of me, Al Franken. But for you, you'll be thinking more about how things affect me, Al Franken. When you see a news report, you'll be thinking, 'I wonder what Al Franken thinks about this thing?' 'I wonder how this inflation thing is hurting Al Franken?' And you women will be thinking, 'What can I wear that will please Al Franken?' or 'What can I not wear?' You know, I know a lot of you out there are thinking, 'Why Al Franken?' Well, because I thought of it, and I'm on TV, so I've already gotten the jump on you. So, I say let's leave behind the fragmented, selfish '70s, and go into the '80s with a unity and purpose. That's what I think. I'm Al Franken."--from "Weekend Update ," aired Dec. 8, 1979* "How Al Franken Paved the Way for Donald Trump"--headline, National Journal , March 8, 2016Won't Get Fooled Again "WHO: Sexual Transmission of Zika More Common Than Thought"--headline, Associated Press, March 8Hey, Kids! What Time Is It? "Marla Maples on Joining 'Dancing With the Stars': 'It's My Time' "--video title, ETOnline.com, March 8Question and Answer--I* "10 Things We Learned at the 'O Brother, Where Art Thou?' Reunion"--headline, USA Today , Sept. 30, 2015* "Jeb's Brother Joins Ted Cruz's Campaign in Florida"--headline, Townhall.com , March 8, 2016Question and Answer--II* "Mr Eastwood; Your Task This Weekend if You Choose to Accept It"--headline, SluggerOToole.com , March 9* "It's Time to Rid the DNC of DINOs, Starting With the Chair"--headline, Truth-Out.org , March 8It's Always in the Last Place You Look "Looking for Satan in All the Wrong Places"--headline, Mosaic, March 9News You Can Use "Moms, Don't Tell Disabled Kids 'I Wish You'd Never Been Born' "--headline, Federalist, March 9High-Steaks Election The results of yesterday's Republican primaries weren't especially surprising: Donald Trump won Michigan and Mississippi ; Ted Cruz Idaho ; Trump also took the caucus in Hawaii , birthplace of Barack Obama. Mitt Romney's exhortation to anti-Trump Republicans to vote strategically didn't yield much, especially in Michigan, where Ted Cruz edged out John Kasich, both of whom were between 24% and 25% of the vote to Trump's 36.6%. And Marco Rubio pretty much collapsed.A bit of a yawn, albeit one that probably wasn't followed by a sound sleep for Trump opponents. So we thought we'd follow the Puffington Host's lead and cover it in our entertainment section, namely the amusing last item of our column.One Trump foe who must be sighing with relief is the New York Times's David Brooks --not because he's pleased with the result but because he got yesterday's column, titled "It's Not Too Late!," out just in the nick of time. Here's his lead:It's 2 a.m. The bar is closing. Republicans have had a series of strong and nasty Trump cocktails. Suddenly Ted Cruz is beginning to look kind of attractive. At least he's sort of predictable, and he doesn't talk about his sexual organs in presidential debates!Well, Republicans, have your standards really fallen so low so fast? Are you really that desperate? Can you remember your 8 p.m. selves, and all the hope you had about entering a campaign with such a deep bench of talented candidates?What a vulgar and disgusting analogy. But anyway, you get the point--Brooks hates both Trump and Cruz, who increasingly look like the only two candidates standing. A reader reminds us that in 2006 Brooks declared his allegiance to a notional third party: "There are two major parties on the ballot, but there are three major parties in America. There is the Democratic Party, the Republican Party and the McCain-Lieberman Party."That would be Sens. John McCain of Arizona and Joseph Lieberman of Connecticut. The latter had just been defeated by a left-wing primary challenger and was seeking re-election as an independent. He won and served one more term, retiring in 2013. But in 2008 the "McCain-Lieberman Party" took over the GOP, which nominated McCain as president and featured a prime-time convention speech from Lieberman. That didn't work out so well in November, for which we're pretty sure Brooks blames Sarah Palin. The McCain-Lieberman Party was supposed to have a more selective appeal.It also occurred to us that back in 1997 Brooks penned an article for the Weekly Standard titled "A Return to National Greatness." No wonder he can't stand Trump: "Make America Great Again" was Brooks's idea!Brooks's colleague Thomas Friedman , meanwhile, is taking Trump seriously as a general election candidate. "He is still sitting with three aces that he hasn't played yet," Friedman avers: his ability to move to the center, his hard line on terrorism, and his willingness to "go after Hillary Clinton in ways you never heard before." (For the record, we've heard a lot.)"But," Friedman cautions, "Trump is also holding two jokers with those aces."All we can say is, if you can ever get into a poker game with Friedman, do it. The guy doesn't even know that five aces beats every other hand.The Times editorial board manages to find something new to complain about:You would think that if the leader of a country friendly to America likened a serious contender for the American presidency to two of the premier villains of the 20th century, it would set off an uproar.But Donald Trump has so debased the tone of the presidential race that there was hardly a murmur when President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico did just that this week. Not only was there no way Mexico would pay for Mr. Trump's wall along the border, but that sort of demagogy, Mr. Peña Nieto said, was "how Mussolini got in, that's how Hitler got in."When decent men like Reagan and the Bushes ran the Republican Party, you could liken them to Hitler and be taken seriously. What has the world come to?As usual, Trump declared victory in Florida, giving a long, rambling speech-cum-news-conference in Jupiter (he needed gravitas). He served reporters and attendees what he said were "Trump Steaks" but actually, as Florida man Greg Pollowitz points out, came from a West Palm Beach butcher called Bush Brothers . No joke.It got us to thinking: Might Trump have beaten Marco Rubio on Sunday if he'd promised to make Puerto Rico a steak ?Follow @jamestaranto on Twitter.Join Fans of Best of the Web Today on Facebook.Subscribe to the Best of the Web email with one click.(Carol Muller helps compile Best of the Web. Hosch, Debbie Wells, Doug Thomson, Jay Weiser, Ray Hull, Michael Smith, Nathan Whitlock, Rebecca Billings, Robert Lamoureux, Ray Burnham, Richard Belzer, Scott Lautenbaugh, Bruce Goldman, Mark Finkelstein, Charles Rosett and David Hallstrom. article name: Angry White Males Propel Donald Trump--and Bernie Sanders; Many presidential primary voters feel free trade has marginalized their jobs and prospects
article text: Tuesday's primary elections underscored an emerging, central reality of the 2016 presidential campaign: This is the year of the angry white male.Those white males are the voters who propelled Donald Trump to convincing victories Tuesday in Michigan and Mississippi, as they have elsewhere. And they may determine whether he can roll on next week in a series of big industrial states.Here's what is less noticed: Dissatisfied white males also helped propel Sen. Bernie Sanders to a stunning victory over Hillary Clinton in the Democratic contest in Michigan, and may keep him in the game for many weeks to come.All of this further suggests they may be the swing voters who decide the general election in November, when the critical question could well be whether Democrats can win enough of them to supplement their big advantages among women and minority voters.The effect was most obvious in watching Mr. Trump roll up two more big wins Tuesday. In Michigan, 52% of the Republican primary electorate was male, exit polls indicated. Mr. Trump won them going away, 43% to 23% for Ohio Gov. John Kasich. Meantime, he lost among women, 30% for Sen. Ted Cruz to 28% for Mr. Trump.The story was similar in Mississippi. Mr. Trump won men by 20 percentage points, exit polls indicated. There, he won women, but by a mere 9 percentage points.So, the more male the Republican electorate, the better for Mr. Trump. Also, the angrier as well.In Mississippi, 41% of Republicans described their feelings toward the federal government as "angry"--and Mr. Trump won a whopping 57% of them. Meanwhile in Michigan, 32% of Republican voters said they were angry at the federal government, and Mr. Trump won 48% of them, compared with 24% for Mr. Cruz.And what are these folks angry about? Here's a pretty good clue:When voters were asked in Michigan whether trade with other countries creates jobs or takes away jobs, just over half of GOP respondents said it takes away jobs--this is in the Republican Party that once was the bastion of strong belief in free trade. And among those who see trade as a job killer, Mr. Trump won going away, 42% to 23% for Mr. Cruz.Here's a bit more evidence that the Trump army is made up of people angry over the belief the economy has left them behind: Among white college graduates in Michigan, he lost to Mr. Kasich. But among whites without a college degree, he won by almost 20 percentage points.Perhaps more interesting, angry white males are sustaining the Sanders campaign, not just the Trump campaign.In Michigan, they kept him nearly even with Mrs. Clinton, offsetting her big advantage among women and among minorities. Among women, exit polls indicate, he finished just behind Mrs. Clinton. But among men, he won easily, 54% to 44%.Like Mr. Trump, he seemed to do especially well among those who consider themselves stuck outside the economic mainstream. Among those who considered income inequality the top issue, he beat Mrs. Clinton 60% to 39%. And among those who think trade takes away jobs, he won 56% to 43%.Together, in other words, Messrs. Trump and Sanders are collapsing what had become, in the 1990s, something of a bipartisan consensus in favor of free trade. And angry white males, many of whom feel trade has marginalized their jobs and prospects, are leading the way.In the end, it may well be that these voters are sufficient to propel Mr. Trump to the GOP nomination; we may well know for sure after primaries next week in the big industrial states of Ohio, Illinois and Missouri. But they probably aren't enough to carry Mr. Sanders to the Democratic nomination.Which would set up a fascinating battle in the fall. In a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll, Mrs. Clinton beats Mr. Trump in a hypothetical general-election matchup, 51% to 38%. But among white men? He wins comfortably, 53% to 35%.Could he hold on to such an advantage, and build up elsewhere? Or would she eat into and undermine his clearest pillar of strength? On such questions may November's outcome be decided.Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Behind Hillary's Lock on Black Support; If Bernie Sanders can't shake her big lead with African-Americans, he's essentially done.
article text: The dynamic of the Democratic presidential contest is clear, and Sen. Bernie Sanders cannot prevail unless he changes it. He can win in states with below-average shares of African-American voters. But in the states with substantial African-American electorates, he loses badly to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. In recent days, she has received 81% of the African-American vote in Georgia, 83% in Texas, 84% in Virginia, 86% in South Carolina, 89% in Tennessee, 90% in Arkansas and 91% in Alabama. Adding to Mr. Sanders's challenge, Mrs. Clinton also racked up 71% of the Latino vote in Texas, an ominous sign for his prospects in Florida on March 15.Margins of this magnitude cry out for explanation. Yes, Mrs. Clinton has a civil-rights record stretching back decades, but so does Mr. Sanders. No doubt her frequent visits to African-American churches and civic organizations, which have made her a familiar and trusted figure in this community, are part of the story. But more than that: Bill Clinton's two terms were years of rapid progress for African-Americans, who hope that a second Clinton presidency can deliver more of the same.During Mr. Clinton's eight years in office, median household income rose to $57,700 from $50,700, a sturdy 14%. Among African-Americans, it rose by even more, to $40,800 from $31,000--32%. While the overall poverty rate fell by 3.5 percentage points, it fell for African-Americans by 10.9 points, the most since the 1960s, reflecting in part a surge of African-American women into the labor force. The national homeownership rate rose by 3.7 percentage points, but by an even larger 5.2 points for African-American families.Key social trends during the Clinton years were strongly positive as well. The teen pregnancy rate (ages 15 to 19) fell by 25% overall and by 29% for Africans-Americans, while births in that age group declined by 21% overall, and by 30% for African-Africans. The abortion rate for the 15-19 age group fell by 28% for African-Americans and by 32% overall.Meanwhile, American communities became safer places to live. According to the Bureau of Justice Statistics, during the Clinton presidency Americans as a whole became 54% less likely--and African-Americans 57% less likely--to be victims of violent crimes other than homicide, and the probability that African-Americans would be either homicide victims or perpetrators fell by nearly half.To be sure, some aspects of the Clinton agenda remain controversial within the African-American community--none more than the 1994 Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act. This lengthy and complex legislation expanded the death penalty to cover drug-trafficking crimes; added 50 new federal offenses (among them a federal "three strikes and you're out" law); made drug testing mandatory for those on probation for federal crimes; provided nearly $10 billion for prison construction while eliminating federal funding for inmate education; and financed the hiring of 100,000 additional police officers.Given today's debate on criminal justice, some may be surprised to discover that two-thirds of the Congressional Black Caucus voted in favor of the bill. They may be even more surprised to learn that this vote represented the culmination of decades of advocacy by African-American leaders for tougher law-and-order policies.Consider the passage in 1986 of the Anti-Drug Abuse Act that toughened federal mandatory-minimum-sentencing law for drug offenders (including those caught with marijuana) and established a 100-1 disparity in punishments for crack cocaine compared with the powdered form of the drug.The Congressional Black Caucus supported the Anti-Drug Abuse Act, and most African-American members of the House co-sponsored it. In his signing remarks, President Reagan singled out Rep. Charles Rangel among the handful of congressional leaders on the bill. Two years later, President Reagan signed the Anti-Drug Control Act, which toughened narcotics penalties, imposed the death penalty for certain drug-related crimes and established the office headed by the "drug czar." Of the 15 members of the Congressional Black Caucus who participated in the final vote on the bill, 10 supported it.Americans across partisan, ideological and racial lines now are rethinking the country's sentencing policies and police practices. This is entirely appropriate--and necessary. But it is worth remembering that, as so often happens, today's problems are in part the product of yesterday's solutions. No one, not even presidential candidates, should be judged by past commitments made in very different circumstances.By overwhelmingly supporting Hillary Clinton despite the changed climate for criminal-justice reform, African-Americans are signaling their willingness to make such distinctions. Unless Bernie Sanders, who voted for the 1994 act as well as several other tough-on-crime bills in the 1990s, can find another way of driving a wedge between Mrs. Clinton and her African-American supporters, he has little hope of winning his party's nomination.Credit: By William A. Galston

article name: Hillary Clinton Challenges the Gun Lobby; Taking on the NRA marks contrast with her previous campaign and rival Bernie Sanders
article text: DURHAM, N. C.--Hillary Clinton is making gun violence a central theme of her campaign, becoming the first leading presidential candidate to directly confront the National Rifle Association without the cover of a hunting license.She is holding town halls with a group known as the Mothers of the Movement, composed of mothers of victims of "gun violence, police and racially charged incidents," including Sybrina Fulton, mother of Trayvon Martin, a black teenager fatally shot by a white neighborhood-watch volunteer in 2012.In Ohio, six leaders of the group, all of whom lost children in high-profile shootings or police altercations, are set to campaign on her behalf again this weekend in Akron, Cleveland and Columbus, ahead of Tuesday's Democratic primary."She's the only candidate trying to do something about gun violence," said Gwen Carr, whose son, Eric Garner, died in New York in police custody in 2014. "People are beginning to understand that this is a real grave situation."The former secretary of state's confrontational stance toward the NRA is a shift from her first presidential run, and it could encourage candidates running for Congress or state legislative positions to follow.In 2008, she tried to ease gun owners' concerns by associating with them, much as her male counterparts have done in the past. While the men often talked about hunting trips or pose in camouflage, Mrs. Clinton shared her memories of learning to shoot a gun when she was a child.Mrs. Clinton's calculation is that attitudes toward expanded background checks and new regulation of gun-show sales have changed enough in the aftermath of a succession of mass shootings to lower the political risks.Yet her positions are already drawing the ire of the NRA, an organization with more than five million single-issue voters who are renowned for punishing politicians who cross them--including presidential candidates."She lies about the issue in a way to make it seem reasonable, to really advance a radical gun-control agenda," said NRA spokeswoman Jennifer Baker, who accused Mrs. Clinton of oversimplifying a complex set of laws and exploiting victims of gun violence.If Mrs. Clinton wins the nomination, the showdown over guns could influence the outcome in several critical swing states won by President Barack Obama in 2012 that also have pro-gun constituencies, including Colorado, New Hampshire and Virginia.Mrs. Clinton touts in her stump speech the fact that she is challenging the gun lobby, knitting it into her broad pitch that she, as president, will be the champion of those who feel helpless in the face of big corporations, government and cultural mores."I will take on the gun lobby," she said to a packed gymnasium at Durham's Hillside High School on Thursday. She pledged to fight special interests in Washington, including Wall Street and pharmaceutical companies. "But you know what the strongest lobby is? It's the gun lobby, which intimidates people, threatens elected officials."It is time my friends, we stand together and say enough," she said. "I stand with the families of Sandy Hook," she added, referring to a 2012 school shooting in Newtown, Conn., that killed 20 children and six adults.Registered voters overall are more concerned the government would go too far in restricting gun rights, 52%, than fail to do enough to regulate access to firearms, at 44%, a December Wall Street Journal-NBC News poll found. But the survey also showed a deep partisan divide, with 74% of Democratic primary voters saying they were worried government would do too little and 73% of Republicans worried the government would do too much.That partisan edge makes the issue a useful foil in Mrs. Clinton's primary battle with Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, who has tried both distancing himself from and explaining his own record on guns, which includes voting to prevent gun makers from being held liable for products they sell.Mr. Sanders, who represents a pro-gun state and who only recently became a Democrat, has highlighted his "D- minus" rating with the NRA in some debates. In a March 6 debate in Michigan he took a different tack, casting his vote in free-market, economic terms."If they are selling a product to a person who buys it legally, what you are really talking about is ending gun manufacturing in America," Mr. Sanders said.His response prompted an NRA tweet saying he was "spot-on" in his argument.The Sanders campaign didn't immediately respond to request for comment.Crimes involving guns have been trending down for years, yet highly publicized mass killings are on the rise.A Federal Bureau of Investigation study found an average of 16.4 active-shooter incidents a year between 2007 and 2013, up from an average of 6.4 a year from 2000 to 2006.Activists on both sides of the gun issue agree the political climate shifted significantly after the Newtown shooting."Everything changed after Newtown," said Adam Winkler, a law professor at the University of California, Los Angeles, who has studied gun issues. "Everybody thinks nothing's changed since no new federal laws were enacted, but the politics have changed a lot."After that shooting, a gun-safety group co-founded by then-New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg combined with another organization to form Everytown for Gun Safety, which focused on influencing elections rather than changing congressional policy, spokeswoman Erika Soto Lamb said."For a long time, there was only the gun lobby," Ms. Soto Lamb said. "There was only the NRA and no organized effort on the other side. Now there's a counterbalance."In November, Jeremy McPike had Everytown's backing when he won a Virginia state Senate seat in a suburban Washington district that is adjacent to the NRA's Fairfax headquarters."It once was a cardinal sin to talk about guns in Virigina," Mr. McPike said. "But it's the right message when you can fight for common sense."While Mr. McPike won, the NRA takes some credit for helping to defeat Everytown's other Virginia state Senate candidate in a Richmond-based district."The majority of Americans support the Second Amendment, and people who support the Second Amendment vote," the NRA's Ms. Baker said.Mrs. Clinton frequently acknowledges that it will be difficult to strengthen gun laws in Congress."I know the politics are hard," she said recently at the Columbia meeting with the mothers of the movement in February. "But we can't go on like this."In rural Kingstree, S.C., Ben McGill, a retired military law enforcement officer, pressed Mrs. Clinton at a recent town hall on what she could actually accomplish.Mr. McGill said he was frustrated with gun violence in his small town and elsewhere, as his elderly aunt and uncle had been injured in a shooting last month in Baltimore.Mr. McGill said in an interview that his relatives were on the mend, and he thinks Mrs. Clinton's focus on guns worth a try. "Everything is possible," Mr. McGill said. "It may be a difficult path, but it's doable."Corrections & Amplifications: In a speech, Hillary Clinton made reference to a 2012 school shooting in Newtown, Conn., that killed 20 children and six adults. An earlier version of this article misspelled the town's name. (3/11)Laura Meckler contributed to this article.Write to Valerie Bauerlein at valerie.bauerlein@wsj.comCredit: By Valerie Bauerlein

article name: U.S. Election Turmoil Fuels Economic Uncertainty, WSJ Survey Says; More than 80% of economists see downside risks to economy if Trump or Sanders elected, survey says
article text: Try making an accurate economic forecast for 2017 when the U.S. president could be anyone from Bernie Sanders to Donald Trump.Just as the 2016 race has stymied political prognosticators, it is also confounding economists. More than three-fourths of forecasters in a new Wall Street Journal survey say the presidential election has introduced more uncertainty than is typical from a change at the White House.Markets rebounded over the past month as economic reports bolstered the case that continued--though moderate--economic growth seems likely. The average survey respondent estimates the economy will grow about 2.4% this year and next and that the unemployment rate will fall to 4.6% in 2017.Related* Explore the Survey* More Economists See Fed Waiting Until June to Raise Rates* Economists See a Slight Decline in the Still-Elevated Odds of U.S. RecessionA new president promising dramatic and immediate changes could quickly upend that."It's stunning to me the markets aren't more worried about it," said Diane Swonk, founder of DS Economics, an economic risk-management firm. The rhetoric on the campaign trail is full of "pretty startling stuff -- isolationism, nationalism, reduced trade flows. We know what that does economically."The average survey respondent in February's WSJ survey saw 2.3% growth and employment at 4.7%.The business, financial and academic economists in the survey say they are particularly alarmed by the rhetoric coming from insurgent campaigns of real estate tycoon Donald Trump, who is leading the Republican field, and Bernie Sanders, the self-proclaimed democratic socialist senator from Vermont who, though he has gathered fewer delegates than Hillary Clinton, continues to win states in the Democratic primary.More than four-fifths of economists rate the possible election of either Mr. Sanders or Mr. Trump as an outcome that may force them to lower their economic forecasts. About half the survey's respondents rate them as "significant" risks.Indeed, part of the appeal of Messrs. Trump and Sanders to voters is that they've rejected the orthodox approach that Washington has typically taken toward economics. Many voters are aiming to disrupt this status quo. In turn, economists don't know what to make of proposals to curtail trade, sharply restrict immigration or dramatically overhaul the tax code."The uncertainty is so great that it is hard to know how to react to it," said Lou Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson ICAP, a firm that specializes in forecasting high-frequency economic data, Federal Reserve policies, and the amount of debt the Treasury will issue.The Wall Street Journal surveyed 64 economists from March 4 to March 8, though not every one answered every question. Their current economic forecasts aren't all rosy: On average they see about a 20% risk of recession in the next year, down slightly from 21% in the previous survey. They forecast the economy will be too fragile for the Federal Reserve to raise rates before June. They predict the economy will add fewer jobs this year than in 2014 and 2015.The respondents work for businesses, research firms, trade associations, universities and financial institutions both large and small. Their common bond is they are rewarded for accurate forecasts.They believe their task would be easiest with the election of Republican Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, Sen. Marco Rubio (R., Fla.) or former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. A plurality of respondents don't see forecasting risks if these candidates are elected.A plurality of economists rated Senator Ted Cruz (R., Texas) as posing "somewhat" but not a "significant" risk if he assumes office. While Mr. Cruz embraces many standard Republican policies, he also led an insurrection that closed the government for several weeks in 2013 and that many believe harmed the economy.Regardless of who wins, some forecasters believe the economy will be little changed next year, as macroeconomic policies take time to work their way into the economy and as many big changes must go through Congress before being enacted."Presidents cannot change policy quickly enough to affect 2017," said Ram Bhagavatula, an economist at fund manager Combinatorics Capital."Congress will do little no matter who is elected," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors.Many of the dramatic changes being proposed in the campaign would reshape the economy in myriad ways if they were ever enacted, confounding forecasts even for people who believe they're the right policy.Economists generally believe free trade raises economic growth, for example, explaining their trepidation around Messrs. Trump and Sanders, who have pledged to roll back trade deals. But even an economist who believes tariffs would protect domestic employment also must account for an increase in inflation due to higher import prices. Even if one believed reversing immigration would help the economy, it would certainly shrink the size of the U.S. labor force.Regardless of politics, it is difficult to puzzle through all the economic implications.Uncertainty over what will happen come November can be damaging to the economy, too. Higher uncertainty may lead businesses to be unsure where to invest and may dent consumer sentiment, too.About a third of respondents believe uncertainty surrounding the election is already having "somewhat" negative effects."The issue is that many candidates are 'talking down' the economy, affecting confidence," said Thomas Costerg, senior economist for the British bank Standard Chartered.Write to Josh Zumbrun at Josh.Zumbrun@wsj.comCredit: By Josh Zumbrun

article name: Hillary Clinton Stops Short of Ruling Out Wall Street Aides; Former secretary of state has been on the defensive from attacks by Bernie Sanders for her close ties to Wall Street
article text: WASHINGTON--Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton on Wednesday said she would work to "end the revolving door" between Washington and Wall Street--but stopped short of ruling out continuing her party's recent tradition of turning to the financial industry for Treasury secretaries."I think it's important also to look at what we want to accomplish," said the former secretary of state, during her debate with her challenger, Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders.She then went on to boast of what she considered the economic success during the administration of her husband, President Bill Clinton, during the 1990s, a time when Mr. Clinton relied heavily on Wall Street officials to staff his administration.Mrs. Clinton was asked during the Miami debate whether she agreed with criticism from liberals in her party that her husband and President Barack Obama had "relied too heavily on advisers who represent the world view of the big banks"--in particular that three of their last four Treasury secretaries had ties to Citigroup Inc."I do agree that we have to end the revolving door," Mrs. Clinton said, adding that she supports a bill introduced last year by Wisconsin Democratic Sen. Tammy Baldwin, called The Financial Services Conflict of Interest Act.That bill, co-sponsored by Massachusetts Democratic Sen. Elizabeth Warren--one of the leading liberal critics of Wall Street--would ban government workers from accepting bonuses from former employers when entering government, and would extend the period they would need to wait to lobby government after leaving office. But it wouldn't ban outright the entrance of financial services officials from entering government jobs.Mrs. Clinton's comments come as she has been on the defensive from attacks by Mr. Sanders for her close ties to Wall Street. And there has been extensive speculation among her finance-industry backers whether the Wall Street-bashing tone of the Democratic campaign would make it hard for her, if she were to win the presidency, to follow her husband and Mr. Obama in tapping big banks for her top economic positions.Her carefully calibrated comments Wednesday night would seem to leave the door open.During the debate ahead of next Tuesday's Florida primary contest, Mrs. Clinton pledged to appoint individuals who would put the "interests of consumers" first and those who will "do more to make sure Main Street flourishes."Liberal Democrats, particularly Ms. Warren, have criticized the Obama administration repeatedly for nominating a number of Wall Street alumni to high posts at the Treasury Department and Federal Reserve, arguing it sends the wrong message about giving financial institutions too much influence over policy.The current Treasury Secretary, Jacob Lew, had worked at Citigroup, as had Nathan Sheets, who heads the department's highest international position. Mr. Obama also tapped Stanley Fischer, another former Citigroup executive, to serve as the Fed's vice chairman.Mrs. Clinton said she would "very much reach out and ask for advice as to who should be appointed, including to Sen. Warren."Throughout the two-hour debate, Mrs. Clinton was once again pressed to defend herself for giving paid speeches to, and taking contributions from, the financial industry, raising questions about her ability to be tough on the biggest banks."Look, clearly, clearly, the secretary's words to Wall Street has really intimidated them, and that is why they have given her $15 million in campaign contributions," Mr. Sanders said sarcastically.Mr. Sanders continued that he was proud that " the gentleman who is head of Goldman Sachs, now, he didn't give me $225,000 for speaking fees, he said I was dangerous and he's right. I am dangerous for Wall Street."Write to Donna Borak at donna.borak@wsj.comCredit: By Donna Borak

article name: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders Spar Over Immigration; Democratic rivals debate long-ago votes and the intricacies of each other's record
article text: MIAMI--Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders faced off Wednesday, a day after he scored a crucial win in the Michigan presidential primary, sparring over immigration and making direct appeals to Latino voters ahead of next week's contest in Florida.The Democratic contenders delved into the details of immigration law, invoking long-ago votes and critiquing the intricacies of each other's record. Mr. Sanders reflected on his immigrant heritage, and both candidates cited spots in the other's record that are out of step with Latino voters and immigration rights activists.Mrs. Clinton was questioned about the right way to handle the influx of Central American children at the southern border. Mr. Sanders was under fire for his opposition to the 2007 immigration bill that would have legalized people in the U.S. illegally.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Hillary Clinton Widens Delegate Lead, but Bernie Sanders Shows Strength* Sanders Coalition Shows Strength in Michigan* Capital Journal: Angry White Males Propel Donald Trump--and Bernie Sanders* Tenor of Campaign Takes a Toll: WSJ/NBC Poll* Democrats Draw a Diverse Voting Pool in Exit Polls* Clinton's Lead Over Sanders Narrows Slightly in WSJ/NBC Poll* Michigan Turnout Shows Split on ClintonUnder aggressive questioning from Univision anchor Jorge Ramos, Mrs. Clinton promised not to deport children who are already living in the U.S., and to target for deportation criminals and those who pose a risk. Mr. Sanders also pledged not to send children away.But the former secretary of state stuck to her position that children newly entering the country illegally should be sent back if they don't meet qualifications for asylum or other programs that would allow them to stay legally.The eighth Democratic presidential debate yielded few revelations, often covering well-trod ground. Although the candidates disagreed sharply on several issues, their tone was less combative than in Sunday's match-up in Michigan, in part because several of the questions came from audience members.Mrs. Clinton was pressed to explain why many voters still have doubts about whether they can trust her. In Michigan, about 60% of voters said they viewed Mrs. Clinton as honest and trustworthy, compared with 80% who said the same of Mr. Sanders, according to ABC exit polls. In Mississippi, where Mrs. Clinton won 82% of the vote, 75% said Mrs. Clinton was trustworthy, compared with 70% for Mr. Sanders."Obviously, it's painful for me to hear that, and I do take responsibility," Mrs. Clinton said. "When you're in public life, even if you believe that it's not an opinion that you think is fair or founded, you do have to take responsibility."She said that would work to demonstrate that people could count on her, adding that she's not a natural politician like her husband or President Barack Obama.For his part, Mr. Sanders tried to clarify the difference between an "establishment politician," which he has dubbed Mrs. Clinton, and a "career politician" like himself. He said the difference is what he has focused his career on, citing his independence from Wall Street and the pharmaceutical and fossil fuel industries."You've got to look at what the career is about," Mr. Sanders said. "This is a career that has stood up to every special interest in this country."During the immigration discussion, the candidates were asked a question by a woman who identified herself as a Guatemalan immigrant whose husband, the father of her children, had been deported. She asked the candidates what they would do to stop deportations and reunite families. Mrs. Clinton praised the woman for having the "courage" to ask the question and called for more Americans to hear such stories so they could learn the "human cost" of deportation policies.Mrs. Clinton also took several opportunities to refocus the discussion on Mr. Sanders's 2007 vote against the comprehensive immigration bill."Our best chance was in 2007 when [the late Sen.] Ted Kennedy led the charge," she said. "I voted for that bill. Sen. Sanders voted against it."Mr. Sanders has said during this campaign that he opposed the bill because a guest worker program included was akin to slavery. But the debate moderators showed a video of him from the time, where he cites concerns that the new workers will drive down wages.Mr. Sanders replied that he worked to improve the program and was able to support the 2013 version of the bill.Mrs. Clinton shot back with a list of immigrant advocates who backed the 2007 version, saying they never would have supported "modern slavery." "That was one of the many excuses used not to vote for the 2007 bill," she said.Mrs. Clinton also pointed to two 2006 votes Mr. Sanders cast while he was in the House, running for the Senate. One would have allowed the indefinite detention of immigrants pending deportation. The second was a largely symbolic measure meant to protect the Minutemen, a self-styled, private patrol that aimed to prevent illegal crossings on the southern border.Mr. Sanders didn't respond directly to the assertion on indefinite detentions. He said the Minuteman bill simply "codified existing legislation."During Wednesday's debate, both candidates declined to label GOP front-runner Donald Trump a "racist" in response to a direct question about his references to Mexican immigrants as rapists and drug dealers.Still, they hurled several other criticisms Mr. Trump's way. Mrs. Clinton attacked his "trafficking in prejudice and paranoia," and said, to loud applause, "You don't make America great by getting rid of everything that made America great." She added that she had been the first to call out Mr. Trump, saying that when he began with the offensive rhetoric, she said "basta."Mr. Sanders recalled Mr. Trump's efforts in the so-called birther movement to "delegitimize the president."He noted that his own father was born in Poland, yet "nobody has ever asked me for my birth certificate," and that was probably because of the "color of my skin.""The American people are never going to elect a president who insults Mexicans, who insults Muslims, who insults women, who insults African-Americans," he said.The debate came on the heels of Mr. Sanders's unexpected, narrow win in Michigan , a victory that provided him with a burst of momentum and all but guaranteed that the Democratic primary wouldn't end anytime soon.Now, Democrats are bracing for a prolonged fight that could stretch through the spring and into early summer.As Mr. Sanders tried to make the most of his moment, calling his Michigan win a "major political" upset, Mrs. Clinton sought to reassert herself as the front-runner. She retains a commanding lead in pledged delegates.Mrs. Clinton, faced with questions about her use of a private email server during her time as secretary state, said: "I made a mistake," adding that "it wasn't prohibited."Mrs. Clinton's records management during her tenure at the State Department has spawned lawsuits, a Federal Bureau of Investigation inquiry, an internal State Department probe, an intelligence community review and congressional inquiries.During the debate, Mrs. Clinton dismissed questions about whether she would end her campaign if investigations into her records eventually resulted in an indictment. "Oh, for goodness--I'm not even answering that question," Mrs. Clinton said.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Laura Meckler and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Democrats Settle in for Long Presidential Contest; Clinton's delegate lead grows even as Sanders wins Michigan; Trump aims for quick end to Republican race
article text: MIAMI--Sen. Bernie Sanders's upset win in Michigan this week left Democrats bracing for a long and costly primary fight and another round of split decisions in five contests next week.The first post-Michigan showdown between front-runner Hillary Clinton and Mr. Sanders came at the eighth Democratic debate here Wednesday evening, aimed at a Latino audience, where they challenged each other's records on immigration, education and jobs.Mrs. Clinton had to defend the government's handling of the 2014 influx of Central American children at the southern border, while Mr. Sanders was under fire for his opposition to a 2007 bill to rewrite immigration laws.While Florida is friendlier territory for Mrs. Clinton, the Vermont senator hopes to build on his narrow victory in Michigan, riding his populist economic and trade themes into neighboring industrial states Ohio and Illinois, which hold primaries Tuesday.Still, while Mr. Sanders has both money and momentum, Hillary Clinton has math on her side. The former secretary of state extended her commanding delegate lead Tuesday after minimizing her Michigan loss while trouncing her Democratic rival in Mississippi. She now has 1,221 delegates, more than half the number needed to secure the nomination; Mr. Sanders has 571.As Democrats settle in for a long haul reminiscent of the 2008 primary, the Republican contest could be nearing its conclusion if Donald Trump prevails next week in Ohio and Florida, two winner-take-all contests that could give the businessman an insurmountable delegate lead.The prospect of a protracted battle for the Democratic nomination and sooner-than-expected end to the GOP contest underscores the unpredictability of this election cycle. At the start of the year, most political experts were predicting reverse paths to the party's presidential nominations, with Clinton expected to dominate her race while a crowded field of Republicans slugged it out."It's a big win," Tad Devine, a senior strategist for the Sanders campaign, said of the Michigan victory that slowed Mrs. Clinton's momentum. "It's going to give a lot of people who weren't sure that Bernie could really prevail in this process a lot of hope that he will."On Tuesday, Democratic primary voters will cast ballots in North Carolina, Florida, Illinois, Missouri and Ohio.Mr. Sanders's aides are taking a realistic approach that aims to maximize his delegate haul in states he has his best chances of winning. That means, for instance, that Florida may be beyond their reach since independents can't participate, said Mr. Devine.Broad support from those unaffiliated voters helped Mr. Sanders win Michigan, while Mrs. Clinton won among registered Democrats. Also, the state allows early voting, meaning many Florida Democrats cast ballots before Mr. Sanders picked up new momentum with victory this week.Illinois and Ohio present better opportunities; both have more flexible rules regarding independent-voter participation in party primaries.
