In addition, Mr. Sanders's opposition to trade agreements is likely to resonate in those states.Michigan was the first big, industrialized northern state to weigh in on the primary. Its median household income of $49,000 and percentage of people who are 25 and older with a bachelor's degree, 26%, are in line with those in Ohio and Illinois. The states also have deep roots and history in blue-collar manufacturing.Though Mr. Sanders's message proved potent, Clinton advisers said they don't plan a major course change. They will work to highlight Mrs. Clinton's views on trade and her plans to create better-paying jobs."We're going to have to work even harder to amplify Secretary Clinton's economic argument," said Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook.The bigger concern for the Clinton campaign is the extension of a nomination race that they remain convinced she will ultimately win because of her lead in the delegate count.A long contest costs a lot of money, and she will continue to have to guard against Mr. Sanders's attempts to press her to embrace his more liberal positions, which the Clinton campaign worries would hurt her in the general election."From the beginning, we have approached this nomination contest as a battle for delegates," Mr. Mook said. "So, while Sen. Sanders has placed big bets on pulling out wins in certain individual states, we have sought to compete everywhere in every state with the goal of amassing the most delegates possible."Much like the Democratic presidential campaign in 2008, this race now could stretch into the early summer. In that campaign, Mrs. Clinton won 23 contests before eventually conceding to then-Sen. Barack Obama.Bill Burton, a Democratic strategist and former Obama aide, said Mrs. Clinton's Michigan speed bump reminded him of Mrs. Clinton's come-from-behind victory in New Hampshire in 2008 that caught the Obama campaign by surprise.At the time, top Obama advisers remained focused on methodically executing a plan focused on amassing delegates. He said Mrs. Clinton's campaign was wise to do the same this year.Dan Pfeiffer, a senior aide on the Obama 2008 campaign, said there are similarities between the situation Mrs. Clinton finds herself in now and that of Mr. Obama in 2008, but her delegate lead is larger than his was at a similar point in the race."The math made it virtually impossible for Clinton to catch Obama at this point in '08 and the same is true now. Everything that happens from this point on is interesting, but it is not particularly instructive," he said.Democratic strategist Mark Mellman said that, as in 2008, this Democratic race will be close and hard fought, but "it's not going be as close and it's not going to be as hard fought."Though the delegate math looks daunting for Mr. Sanders, his campaign advisers say he can close the gap. For one, the superdelegates, who are party officials and elected leaders, now backing Mrs. Clinton may switch allegiances if she loses their states."If you want to be the nominee of your party you not only have to win early you have to win often," Mr. Devine said. "You cannot go on a losing streak and expect that all the people, especially the superdelegates who've come to you in droves, are going to stay with you in droves."Dante Chinni contributed to this article.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary's Michigan Droop; Bernie Sanders's upset shows Clinton's campaign weakness.
article text: Progressive journalists and other sophisticates are gloating about the turmoil Donald Trump has fomented within the Republican Party, and they'd better enjoy the feeling while it lasts. Hillary Clinton's thunderclap defeat in the Michigan primary shows the Democrats are saddled with a weak candidate who has a sack load of political liabilities as heavy as Mr. Trump's.Bernie Sanders's 50% to 48% triumph is one of the more remarkable upsets since the dawn of political polling. The final Real Clear Politics polling average gave Mrs. Clinton a 21.4-percentage-point lead in the state, and no poll taken in the last month gave her less than an 11-point advantage. Michigan is a hard state to survey, but no poll has a 25-point margin of error.Such late swings don't happen unless pollsters miscalculate the size and composition of the electorate, which suggests either a Sanders surge or a slow-motion collapse in Mrs. Clinton's rank-and-file support. It's likely both, which exposes the underlying enervation in Hillary World.The Vermont socialist campaigned hard against trade and the economic status quo, and according to exit polls he beat Mrs. Clinton 56% to 40% among voters "very worried" about the economy. For the first time he also cut into her lead among African-Americans. She won blacks 9 to 1 in Mississippi, a pattern that has emerged across the South.Her margin was 2 to 1 in Michigan, which is commanding. But Mr. Sanders showed he can peel off enough of this core constituency to win a state and expand the diversity of his coalition beyond white liberals and young people. Imagine if Hillary had won over enough Phish drum circles to carry Burlington, Vt.Democrats allocate their delegates proportionately, and the brutal math is that Mr. Sanders must win primaries by much larger average margins than 2% to close his current deficit. Still, his people's revolution could embarrass Mrs. Clinton again next week in other industrial Midwest states like Ohio and Illinois.Mrs. Clinton's Wolverine State loss also revealed the resistance and apathy that are her campaign bodyguards. Mr. Sanders beat her by 4 to 1 among people who wanted an "honest and trustworthy" nominee and edged her out among those who said they favored a president who "cares about people like me."On the stump, Mrs. Clinton seems to take it for granted that she has the race sewn up. She is the anti-inspiring placeholder for the Democratic machine of unions, feminists, the green lobby and minorities that want to hold on to power after President Obama. But voters rarely like to be told to take their medicine: Democracy is supposed to be at least a little raucous and disorganized.All of this explains why John Kasich and Marco Rubio beat her handily in the polling on November matchups, and even Ted Cruz comes close. Democrats take solace that the GOP will nominate Donald Trump, who loses to Mrs. Clinton in nearly all surveys. But they shouldn't be too confident.In the latest NBC/Wall Street Journal poll, 67% of registered voters say they couldn't support Mr. Trump--but 56% say they couldn't vote for Mrs. Clinton. Some 51% of voters view Mrs. Clinton negatively, by far the highest share since her husband ran in 1992. Mr. Trump could be a disaster for Republicans, but he also is less well known as a political actor and so has more upside if he ever decides to act like a President. Mrs. Clinton has been around so long that she will have a hard time changing perceptions.The truth is that both parties are on the cusp of nominating candidates who are disliked by large swaths of the public. A Clinton-Trump matchup would quickly become a brutal race to the bottom, if we're not there already, and at the end somebody has to be President. In a year when anything can happen, and has, Trump Schadenfreude could become Clinton buyer's remorse.

article name: A Bernie Breakthrough in Michigan; Plus more Trump wins and one for Cruz.
article text: Donald Trump won three more GOP nominating contests on Tuesday, while Sen. Ted Cruz won in Idaho and finished second to Mr. Trump in Hawaii, Michigan and Mississippi. Mr. Trump continues to succeed in a four-candidate Republican race , but new polls show he is alienating an increasing share of the nation's overall electorate . "In the Wall Street Journal/NBC survey, his net negative rating is now up to minus-39%," notes a Journal editorial . "A new Washington Post/ABC poll found that only 45% of Republicans consider him "honest and trustworthy" and only 51% say they'd be satisfied with him as the nominee."The editorial adds that in the Michigan exit polls and the two national surveys, "Mr. Trump nearly always loses a hypothetical one-on-one matchup with each of the other GOP contenders." And Mr. Trump trails Hillary Clinton by 13 percentage points in the WSJ/NBC survey.Morning Editorial ReportClick here to receive WSJ Opinion headlines and commentary via email.But will Mrs. Clinton be the Democratic nominee? On Tuesday her coronation was interrupted by the voters of Michigan, who handed Bernie Sanders a surprising victory in the state's Democratic primary. According to exit polls the Vermont senator won 30% of the black vote, enough to score a breakthrough win in the big, diverse state. Given his remarkable fundraising prowess--last month he raked in $42 million compared to Mrs. Clinton's $30 million--and the possibility she will be indicted, it's still too early to call the Democratic race.Mrs. Clinton did win in Mississippi last night, powered by her usual overwhelming support from black voters. Why are African-American Democrats so enamored of Mrs. Clinton? Our columnist William Galston says it's because blacks thrived during her husband's presidency . "During Mr. Clinton's eight years in office, median household income rose to $57,700 from $50,700, a sturdy 14%. Among African-Americans, it rose by even more, to $40,800 from $31,000--32%. While the overall poverty rate fell by 3.5 percentage points, it fell for African-Americans by 10.9 points, the most since the 1960s...""The conventional wisdom on the left is that the GOP brought the Trump phenomenon on itself," writes Jason Riley . Media pundits like to pretend that the party has been stoking anti-immigrant sentiment, but Mr. Riley notes that Mr. Trump "wasn't really invited to this party. He crashed it . And judging from the primary election results so far--he's winning pluralities, not majorities--most Republicans want him to leave ."From the campaign trail in Florida, the Journal's Allysia Finley reports , "The Trump disciples I encounter aren't angry so much as they are agitated by what they perceive to be America's fall from greatness. They complain about the country's slow-growing economy, aimless leaders, lawless government and uncontrolled southwestern border . And they sincerely believe that only Mr. Trump can fix these problems."Whether or not he could fix them, he would certainly enjoy significant authority. Our columnist Holman Jenkins points out that "contrary to what you may have read elsewhere, President Trump would have considerable power to provoke trade wars to create an instant opportunity for his negotiating acumen."Yet surprisingly, Mr. Trump's 10-paragraph health plan released last week includes an "endorsement of foreign pharmaceutical importation," notes a Journal editorial . "His campaign promises to 'remove barriers to entry into free markets,' because 'allowing consumers access to imported, safe and dependable drugs from overseas will bring more options to consumers.'"A separate editorial observes that "the U.S. has decided to sanction Chinese telecom giant ZTE for trade violations with Iran. This provides reason to hope that at last the Obama Administration may also crack down on Chinese firms benefiting from other illicit conduct such as cybertheft ."And in case you haven't been keeping up with the gender politics of ice , you may wish to delve into a new study on a "feminist glaciology framework for global environmental change research ," which was naturally funded with your tax dollars.Credit: By James Freeman

article name: Primaries Test Bernie Sanders's Strength Against Hillary Clinton in Large, Diverse States; Democratic contests in Michigan and Mississippi could be among Sanders's last, best chances to slow Clinton's momentum
article text: Tuesday's Democratic primaries in Michigan and Mississippi kick off a pivotal stretch for Sen. Bernie Sanders that will test whether he can win large, diverse states and keep within striking distance of Hillary Clinton for the presidential nomination.Lagging far behind Mrs. Clinton in the battle to accumulate pledged delegates, the Vermont senator comes to Tuesday's contests needing to show strength as the race turns toward the industrial Midwest. The primaries Tuesday, and five more contests next week, could prove to be Mr. Sanders's last, best chance to slow Mrs. Clinton's momentum and salvage his candidacy.Mr. Sanders has notched wins in eight of the first 20 Democratic contests, but his victories generally have come in small states with overwhelmingly white electorates or that use a caucus format that attracts grass roots activists, who have migrated to his campaign.The result is a commanding lead for Mrs. Clinton in the tally of pledged delegates.Though the stakes in Michigan are particularly high for Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Clinton is under pressure to show strength outside the South, where strong support from African-American voters has propelled most of her victories.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Hillary Clinton's Lead Over Bernie Sanders Narrows Slightly in WSJ/NBC Poll* Michigan Turnout Shows Split on Clinton* What to Watch in Tuesday's Nominating ContestsA win in Michigan this week or in Ohio or Florida next Tuesday could help Mr. Sanders chip away at that margin and make the argument that he can win in states that hold traditional primaries and that have ethnically diverse populations.Losses in those states, on the other hand, would solidify Mrs. Clinton's position as the de facto nominee.A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed the Democratic race tightening nationally, with Mrs. Clinton's lead over Mr. Sanders narrowing to nine points among Democratic primary voters. In February, the former secretary of state led by 11 points, and in January, she led by 24 points, according to the poll.Gaining ground in national polls will mean little, though, if Mr. Sanders can't secure wins in more diverse and delegate-rich states, said Steve Elmendorf, a Democratic strategist who is backing Mrs. Clinton."The fundamental problem that Sanders has is that he has not proven he can win in the diversity of the Democratic Party," Mr. Elmendorf said. "On March 15, you're in four large, diverse states that seem hard for him to win. After that, I just don't see what the path is."The Sanders game plan is to notch a win in Michigan that would reverberate in a pair of Midwestern states that vote on March 15: Ohio and Illinois, Sanders aides said."There are similarities between Michigan and parts of Ohio and Illinois that have experienced high levels of deindustrialization due to policies that Secretary Clinton has supported over and over again," said Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager.That line of attack has been taken by Mr. Sanders himself, highlighting Mrs. Clinton's early support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement with Pacific Rim nations and for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was signed by her husband, Bill Clinton, in the 1990s.The Sanders campaign made a big bet on Michigan, airing TV ads in the state for the past three weeks, and Mr. Sanders has made multiple trips to the state.The senator has expended limited resources in several states that Mrs. Clinton won by wide margins, essentially ceding swaths of the South to his Democratic rival. But the Vermont senator's campaign has long targeted Michigan as a key battleground, predicting a "showdown" there and counting on the state to serve as a launchpad to next week's primaries.At the polls Tuesday in Ferndale, Mich., voters split between the two Democratic candidates. Elizabeth and Gerald Collins both backed Mrs. Clinton."I think she has the best chance to win," Mrs. Collins, 51, said. "I like where she stands on many of the issues."Mr. Collins, 58, said he believes people just aren't ready yet for Mr. Sanders and his ideas.But Josh Hartwig, 29, disagreed, casting his vote for Mr. Sanders because he supports the "common man."Mrs. Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, campaigned aggressively across Michigan in recent days. The former secretary of state made the Flint water crisis a central campaign issue, and she revived the debate about the 2009 bailout of the auto industry , highlighting Mr. Sanders's vote against legislation that rescued auto makers and shored up the nation's banks."If everybody had voted the way he did, I believe the auto industry would have collapsed, taking four million jobs with it," Mrs. Clinton said of Mr. Sanders during their debate on Sunday.Clinton campaign officials have long argued the Democratic nomination would be decided in March. And after scoring eight victories on Super Tuesday and winning Louisiana, the biggest prize this past weekend, the former secretary of state entered Tuesday's primaries well positioned to continue to build on her delegate lead. The goal, Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook has said, is to compete everywhere and methodically amass delegates, making it mathematically impossible for Mr. Sanders to catch up.The Sanders campaign believes the race is still winnable, saying the map gets more favorable from here. The calendar was "front-loaded" with Southern states loyal to Mrs. Clinton and her husband, formerly the Arkansas governor, Mr. Weaver said."Secretary Clinton was the first lady of Arkansas for many years," he said. "Her base is in the South and she's done very, very well in the South."The good news, as far as the Sanders campaign is concerned, is that the road ahead is heavy on contests in the north and the west.Before Michigan began counting votes in its primary Tuesday, the Democratic contenders already turned their attention to the next big prizes in their presidential race, with Hillary Clinton skipping over to Ohio and Bernie Sanders headed to Florida.With next week's Florida primary in their sights, the Democratic presidential campaigns held dueling conference calls over which candidate would be best for the Latino community.The Sanders campaign has been on the defense because of the Vermont senator's 2007 opposition to a comprehensive immigration bill that would have provided undocumented immigrants with a path to citizenship."It is clear Hillary is the only one we can trust to lead 12 million people out of the shadows," Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D., Ill.), told reporters on a call organized by the Clinton campaign.Mr. Sanders's campaign sought to broaden the subject beyond immigration to who best understands and would improve the lives of Latino voters.Mr. Weaver, the Sanders campaign manager, said the Vermont senator is the "son of an immigrant himself, who came to this country not speaking English, who saw firsthand and lived firsthand the experience of immigrant communities."Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Clash in Flint Democratic Debate; Sparks fly over auto bailout and trade at seventh Democratic presidential debate, held in Michigan
article text: FLINT, Mich.--The Democratic presidential contenders clashed sharply over economic policy in a debate Sunday , with front-runner Hillary Clinton attacking rival Bernie Sanders for his opposition to a federal auto bailout and Mr. Sanders charging that Clinton-backed trade deals had helped destroy American cities like Detroit.Both issues resonate deeply in Michigan, which hosts its presidential primary on Tuesday. The state is home to the large domestic auto makers that benefitted from the 2009 bailout, but it has also lost jobs to trade as companies moved positions overseas.It was their seventh showdown, and the sharpest clash yet, with the candidates repeatedly interrupting one another and accusing each other of hypocrisy. Mrs. Clinton holds a commanding lead in delegates , even after weekend caucus wins for Mr. Sanders in Nebraska , Kansas and Maine . Mrs. Clinton won Saturday's Louisiana primary , which had the biggest delegate count.More on Election 2016* Flint Democratic Presidential Debate--Recap* Democrats Eye Next Fights* Clinton, Sanders Head Into Seventh Democratic Primary Debate* Clinton's Louisiana Win Helps Offset Two Caucus Defeats* Trump Leads Rivals in Michigan, Trails Clinton in General Election Test, Poll Finds* Flint Begins Replacing Lead Pipes* 2016 Election PollsAsked about a possible future confrontation with Republican front-runner Donald Trump, Mrs. Clinton said she would not "get into the gutter" with whomever the Republicans nominate and predicted that Mr. Trump's "bigotry, his bullying, his bluster are not going to wear well on the American people."The Vermont senator stayed on the offense against Mrs. Clinton. He blasted her record, demanded she release transcripts of her Wall Street speeches and sharply critiqued her husband's record as president in the 1990s.Mr. Sanders has been attacking Mrs. Clinton for days over trade, but Mrs. Clinton's hit on the auto bailout was a potent counter.The assistance for the industry was included in the Troubled Asset Relief Program, a $700 billion measure that is also credited with keeping the nation's financial system from collapsing. The Senate vote to release the second half of those funds came in the waning days of the George W. Bush administration, and auto companies and their backers said the companies would have gone under without that rescue package."The money was there and had to be released in order to save the American auto industry," said Mrs. Clinton, a former New York senator. "I voted to save the auto industry. He voted against the money."Mr. Sanders defended his vote, saying he objected to the Wall Street bailout money. He said he wasn't willing to give taxpayer money to those companies because of what he called their own recklessness, greed and illegal behavior."Let the billionaires themselves bail out Wall Street," he said. "I will be damned if it was the working people of this country who had to bail out the crooks on Wall Street."The exchange seemed to surprise Mr. Sanders, and his campaign within minutes sought to soften and clarify his position. Mr. Sanders supported the auto funds but not the Wall Street rescue. Since they couldn't be separated, he opposed the bill.In the debate, Mrs. Clinton replied that leaders have to make tough decisions and that had his side prevailed, the auto industry would have collapsed. And she said the exchange proved her point that Mr. Sanders is a "one-issue candidate."Mr. Sanders didn't disagree, but said his "one issue is trying to rebuild a disappearing middle class. That's my one issue."Mr. Sanders took an aggressive posture from the start, particularly on her support for some free-trade agreements, such as Nafta, which eased trade rules with Mexico and other nations and was signed by former President Bill Clinton and backed by Mrs. Clinton when she was first lady."You didn't need a Ph.D. in economics to understand that American workers should not be forced to compete against people in Mexico making 25 cents an hour," he said.It was one in a string of attacks on Mr. Clinton's policies. He also went after the Clintons on welfare and Wall Street deregulation legislation that he signed.In each case, Mrs. Clinton replied that "if we're going to argue about the 1990s," then she preferred to talk about that era's robust job creation and broadly rising incomes.On economics, their differences were largely defined by how much support the government should give to American corporations, including the auto bailout but also the Export-Import Bank.Mrs. Clinton went after Mr. Sanders for opposing re-authorization of the bank, which provides financial support to help large and small U.S. companies export their goods. Mr. Sanders said the entire enterprise amounts to "corporate welfare."The debate was staged in Flint, a venue pushed by Mrs. Clinton to bring attention to a crisis there where a cost-cutting move wound up poisoning the water supply with lead .Mr. Sanders repeated his call for Republican Gov. Rick Snyder to resign, and for the first time, Mrs. Clinton agreed and added that if he doesn't resign, he should be recalled. In the past, Mrs. Clinton has dismissed that political solution as inadequate. She added that more funding as well as accountability from others was needed.In a series of tweets sent during the debate, Mr. Snyder defended his record in Michigan and said he is taking responsibility for the Flint crisis. He outlined some of the steps he has taken to solve the problem, and said it was the result of a "failure of government at all levels that could be described as a massive error of bureaucracy."The pair also returned to one of their long-time disputes, tangling over whether gun manufacturers and sellers should be protected from lawsuits.In the past, Mrs. Clinton has hit Mr. Sanders for supporting the 2005 law that provided gun makers legal immunity. In January, Mr. Sanders announced a shift in his views, voicing support for legislation that would remove gun manufacturers' protections from liability.On Sunday, though, Mr. Sanders offered a more nuanced view, suggesting that gun makers should not be held responsible for the actions of those who legally purchase firearms."What people are saying is that if somebody who is crazy or a criminal or a horrible person goes around shooting people, the manufacturer of that gun should be held liable," Mr. Sanders said. "If that is the case, then essentially, your position is there should not be any guns in America, period."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com , Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler, Colleen McCain Nelson and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Clinton, Sanders Face Off in Democratic Debate
article text: Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders meet in Milwaukee for their sixth debate, days after Sen. Sanders's resounding win in New HampshireSen. Bernie Sanders and former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton square off Thursday during the sixth Democratic presidential primary debate of the 2016 election cycle.'I think that the best analysis that I've seen based on Sen. Sanders's plans is that it would probably increase the size of federal government by about 40%,' Hillary Clinton said during the presidential primary debate.'I'm proud to say that Henry Kissinger is not my friend,' Sen. Bernie Sanders said in criticizing Hillary Clinton for receiving advice from former Secretary of State Kissinger.Demonstrators infiltrated the Student Union at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee on Thursday in support of increased minimum wage and immigrant justice before the Democratic presidential debate in Milwaukee.Sen. Bernie Sanders appears at the 'PBS NewsHour' democratic debate, where he called the campaign finance system 'corrupt' and that the economy 'rigged.'Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton participates in the 'PBS NewsHour' Democratic presidential candidate, where she accused Sen. Bernie Sanders of 'trying to start all over again' on health-care reform.The University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee hosts Thursday night's debate.Democratic presidential candidates Sen. Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton take the stage before their presidential primary debate at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee on Thursday.People show support outside the Democratic presidential debate Thursday, the final debate before the Nevada caucuses scheduled for Feb. 20.Supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders gather outside the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee student union before the Democratic presidential primary debate Thursday.[Interactive content available online]

article name: Sanders Puts Emphasis on Delegate Math; Vermont senator's campaign shifts strategy to maximize Democratic delegates
article text: On the eve of a five-state showdown Tuesday Bernie Sanders's campaign has dropped its focus on winning marquee states in favor of scooping up delegates anywhere it can find them, hoping to show he still has a chance of overcoming Hillary Clinton's large lead and capturing the Democratic presidential nomination.Mr. Sanders's shift in strategy is a response to the hard realities of delegate math: Despite an upset victory in Michigan last week that cheered his supporters he is losing ground to Mrs. Clinton and in danger of reaching the point where it is impossible to catch up.Two states where the Sanders campaign concedes he will have a tough time winning Tuesday are Florida and North Carolina. Rather than cede them to Mrs. Clinton and focus on winning a trio of Midwestern states where his prospects are brighter, Mr. Sanders late last week expanded his television advertising in certain Florida and North Carolina markets, his advisers said. The idea is to pluck a few extra delegates in the face of an expected Clinton victory in both states."The goal Tuesday is to win as many delegates as we can. And if we can win states, too, that's a big plus," said Tad Devine, a Sanders campaign strategist. "Now we have to build a foundation of delegates. A lot of delegates are in play [on Tuesday]. We can get a lot of them, we think. The advertising in some of these [Florida and North Carolina] markets may make the difference."That is different than the approach Mr. Sanders has taken in the past. When 11 states were up for grabs on March 1, Mr. Sanders did scant advertising and spent little time in Southern states where his rival was favored. He focused instead on capturing a handful of states--including Colorado, Minnesota and Oklahoma--and demonstrating he could beat Mrs. Clinton outside his home base of New England.But the limitations of targeting a few high-profile states have become clear. Delegates are awarded proportionally based on results and because of Mrs. Clinton's lopsided victories in Southern states she has taken a commanding lead.Take the case of Michigan. For all the attention paid to Mr. Sanders's upset victory there, the tight margins in the race--he won by 1.5 percentage points--meant he netted just seven more pledged delegates than Mrs. Clinton. Meanwhile, Mrs. Clinton won 26 more delegates than Mr. Sanders in Mississippi, which she won in a landslide. So, when the voting was all done that night, Mr. Sanders won the headline while Mrs. Clinton expanded her lead by 19 delegates.She now has 766 pledged delegates compared with 551 for Mr. Sanders, according to the Associated Press. Add in the "superdelegates"--Democratic officials free to support whomever they choose--and her lead is 1,231 to 576. A total of 2,383 delegates are needed to clinch the nomination.For Mrs. Clinton, the dynamics are the opposite of what she faced in her 2008 race against then-Sen. Barack Obama. Mr. Obama jumped to a formidable delegate lead in the early going. She was never able to close the gap despite impressive wins in Pennsylvania and other states later in the calendar. Now, Mrs. Clinton is benefiting from the same delegate formulas that were her undoing eight years ago.Tom Nides, a deputy to Mrs. Clinton when she served as secretary of state and now a fundraiser for her campaign, said: "We're basically following the Obama math in 2008. Obama did well enough in some states and really well in other states and he made the math completely impossible for Hillary to get the nomination."An analysis by the nonpartisan Cook Political Report shows that Mr. Sanders would need to win 61% of the remaining pledged delegates and uncommitted superdelegates to catch up to Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders said he isn't deterred, noting superdelegates are free to change their minds. They might do just that if they see him winning and come to believe he's the best bet to defeat the Republican nominee--possibly Donald Trump--in the fall, he said.In an appearance Sunday on CNN, Mr. Sanders said "if we do well in a number of states and if the general sentiment becomes that Bernie Sanders is the candidate who will defeat Donald Trump" superdelegates might "swing over" to his campaign.Polling shows Mrs. Clinton with substantial leads in the three other states that vote on Tuesday: Ohio, Illinois and Missouri, according to a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll.Privately, both campaigns said they believe the race to be tighter. Mr. Sanders's victory in Michigan underscored the strength of his anti-free trade message, a message likely to resonate in neighboring Ohio and Illinois. He also has sought to energize his supporters and perhaps cut into Mrs. Clinton's lead among African-Americans by taking aim at Chicago's Democratic mayor, Rahm Emanuel.Mr. Sanders noted that the Chicago mayor has endorsed Mrs. Clinton and said: "I do not want Mayor Emanuel's endorsement if I win the nomination."Mrs. Clinton jabbed at Mr. Sanders's record and policy positions, highlighting the Vermont senator's opposition to the auto bailout at a rally in Youngstown and questioning his push for single-payer health care at a church near Cleveland on Sunday. "I sure don't want to start over like my opponent does," Mrs. Clinton said, underscoring her support for the Affordable Care Act.Clinton aides don't expect Mr. Sanders to withdraw any time soon. But some in her circle are eager to move on. Whatever happens on Tuesday, they said they would like Mr. Sanders to forego his attacks on the party front-runner.Alan Patricof, a Clinton fundraiser, said: "I'm tired of his message." He added: "He throws a lot of slings and arrows."Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: A New Tool for Avoiding Big-Bank Failures: 'Chapter 14'; Bernie Sanders is right, Dodd-Frank doesn't work, but his solution is wrong. Here's what would work.
article text: For months Democratic presidential hopeful Bernie Sanders has been telling Americans that the government must "break up the banks" because they are "too big to fail." This is the wrong role for government, but Sen. Sanders and others on both sides of the aisle have a point. The 2010 Dodd-Frank financial law, which was supposed to end too big to fail, has not.Dodd-Frank gave the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. authority to take over and oversee the reorganization of so-called systemically important financial institutions whose failure could pose a risk to the economy. But no one can be sure the FDIC will follow its resolution strategy, which leads many to believe Dodd-Frank will be bypassed in a crisis.Reflecting on his own experience as overseer of the U.S. Treasury's bailout program in 2008-09, Neel Kashkari, now president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, says government officials are once again likely to bail out big banks and their creditors rather than "trigger many trillions of additional costs to society."The solution is not to break up the banks or turn them into public utilities. Instead, we should do what Dodd-Frank failed to do: Make big-bank failures feasible without tanking the economy by writing a process to do so into the bankruptcy code through a new amendment--a "chapter 14."Chapter 14 would impose losses on shareholders and creditors while preventing the collapse of one firm from spreading to others. It could be initiated by the lead regulatory agency and would begin with an over-the-weekend bankruptcy hearing before a pre-selected U.S. district judge. After the hearing, the court would convert the bank's eligible long-term debt into equity, reorganizing the bankrupt bank's balance sheet without restructuring its operations.A new non-bankrupt company, owned by the bankruptcy estate (the temporary legal owner of a failed company's assets and property), would assume the recapitalized balance sheet of the failed bank, including all obligations to its short-term creditors. But the failed bank's shareholders and long-term bondholders would have claims only against the estate, not the new company.The new firm would take over the bank's business and be led by the bankruptcy estate's chosen private-sector managers. With regulations requiring minimum long-term debt levels, the new firm would be solvent. The bankruptcy would be entirely contained, both because the new bank would keep operating and paying its debts, and because losses would be allocated entirely to the old bank's shareholders and long-term bondholders.An examination by one of us (Emily Kapur) of previously unexplored discovery and court documents from Lehman Brothers' September 2008 bankruptcy shows that chapter 14 would have worked especially well for that firm, without adverse effects on the financial system.Here is how Lehman under chapter 14 would have played out. The process would start with a single, brief hearing for the parent company to facilitate the creation of a new recapitalized company--a hearing in which the judge would have minimal discretion. By contrast, Lehman's actual bankruptcy involved dozens of complex proceedings in the U.S. and abroad, creating huge uncertainty and making it impossible for even part of the firm to remain in business.When Lehman went under it had $20 billion of book equity and $96 billion of long-term debt, while its perceived losses were around $54 billion. If the costs of a chapter 14 proceeding amounted to an additional (and conservative) $10 billion, then the new company would be well capitalized with around $52 billion of equity.The new parent company would take over Lehman's subsidiaries, all of which would continue in business, outside of bankruptcy. And the new company would honor all obligations to short-term creditors, such as repurchase agreement and commercial paper lenders.The result: Short-term creditors would have no reason to run on the bank before the bankruptcy proceeding, knowing they would be protected. And they would have no reason to run afterward, because the new firm would be solvent.Without a run, Lehman would have $30 billion more liquidity after resolution than it had in 2008, easing subsequent operational challenges. In the broader marketplace, money-market funds would have no reason to curtail lending to corporations, hedge funds would not flee so readily from prime brokers, and investment banks would be less likely to turn to the government for financing.Eventually, the new company would make a public stock offering to value the bankruptcy estate's ownership interest, and the estate would distribute its assets according to statutory priority rules. If the valuation came in at $52 billion, Lehman shareholders would be wiped out, as they were in 2008. Long-term debtholders, with $96 billion in claims, would recover 54 cents on the dollar, more than the 37 cents they did receive. All other creditors--the large majority--would be paid in full at maturity.Other reforms, such as higher capital requirements, may yet be needed to reduce risk and lessen the chance of financial failure. But that is no reason to wait on bankruptcy reform. A bill along the lines of the chapter 14 that we advocate passed the House Judiciary Committee on Feb. 11. Two versions await action in the Senate. Let's end too big to fail, once and for all.Ms. Kapur is an attorney and economics Ph.D. candidate at Stanford University. Mr. Taylor, a professor of economics at Stanford, co-edited "Making Failure Feasible" (Hoover, 2015) with Kenneth Scott and Thomas Jackson, which includes Ms. Kapur's study.Credit: By Emily C. Kapur And John B. Taylor

article name: Clinton and Sanders Are Wrong on Fracking; The fracking-based natural gas revolution has resulted in the U.S. becoming the only nation in the world to reduce its CO footprint over the past 10 years.
article text: In addition to the economic and scientific hypocrisy of opposing fracking as outlined in your editorial "Clinton Against American Energy " (March 8), I find it ironic that the environmental opposition to fracking ignores the fact that the fracking-based natural gas revolution has resulted in the U.S. becoming the only nation in the world to reduce its CO footprint over the past 10 years. Instead of opposing fracking, we should be encouraging even more fracking and natural-gas consumption as we map a cost-competitive path to lower carbon emissions over the next few decades.Frank MurphySt. LouisOf course Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are against fracking. When properly regulated by states, fracking has shown it is perfectly safe and doesn't pollute. But there remains the theoretical possibility that fracking will be unregulated and may pollute. So we should ban fracking with the good intention of avoiding any possibility of polluting? The consequences may be much higher energy prices which like a regressive tax would impact the poor the most. But this doesn't matter. These are progressive policies and to progressives it is only good intentions that matter. The consequences are irrelevant.Stephen R.S. MartinCave Creek, Ariz.The reason fracking is supported by Democrats like Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper--who holds a master's degree in geology--is because hydraulic fracturing, with proper regulation, can be done safely. The Environmental Protection Agency has found that fracking doesn't contaminate groundwater resources.Secretary Clinton's assertion that her stipulations would greatly restrict fracking is blatantly untrue, unless she plans to implement much stricter standards.Isaac OrrThe Heartland InstituteSt. Paul, Minn.

article name: Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton Crisscross Tuesday's Big States; The Vermont senator attacks his rival, while she tries to pivot toward November
article text: CLEVELAND--Sen. Bernie Sanders continued to attack rival Hillary Clinton ahead of a critical day of balloting , while Mrs. Clinton suggested voters on Tuesday could deliver a knockout blow that would allow her to pivot toward the general election.The two Democratic presidential candidates spent Monday campaigning in four of the five states that host primaries on Tuesday. The marquee contests were in Ohio and Florida, with both campaigns predicting a tight race in the former and an easy Clinton win in the latter.Also casting ballots Tuesday are voters in Illinois, Missouri and North Carolina.Monday, the candidates adopted very different tones. Mrs. Clinton, who holds a commanding lead in delegates, barely alluded to Mr. Sanders as she urged supporters in Chicago to turn out to vote."Do not rest," she said. With success on Tuesday, she said, the campaign would "be able to start talking about not only unifying the Democratic Party, but also unifying our country."In Ohio, Mr. Sanders was on the offense. He mocked Mrs. Clinton's paid speeches to Wall Street firms, saying they must be "Shakespearean" to garner $225,000 apiece; suggested she told bankers one thing and tells voters another about regulating Wall Street; and said her support for trade agreements makes her complicit in the loss of hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs."I proudly stood with the workers. Secretary Clinton stood with the big-moneyed interests," the Vermont senator said in Youngstown, the first of five rallies in four states planned for the day.In Tuesday's top two races, the political dynamics were very different.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 News.* Live Coverage: Tuesday's Primaries* Theranos Founder to Host Clinton Fundraiser* Democrats Play It Safe With Primary Predictions* In Illinois, Clinton and Sanders Vie for Obama LegacyIn Ohio, Mr. Sanders was hoping to repeat last week's victory in neighboring Michigan, another state filled with working-class, white voters dependent on manufacturing and skeptical of free trade. On the trail, he repeatedly pointed to Mrs. Clinton's support for "disastrous" trade agreements that he said have "cost this country millions of decent-paying jobs."The campaign was also working to turn out young people and was buoyed by an Ohio court ruling last week that allows 17-year-olds who will be 18 by the general election to cast primary ballots.At his Cleveland office, Mr. Sanders's Ohio director, Jeff Rusnak, kept track of 50 colleges in the state, their student populations and spring-break dates. The chart shows a challenge: Some 168,000 students, including those at flagship Ohio State University, are on break this week.Mr. Rusnak, a local political consultant, wasn't even hired until about a month ago, but now the campaign has offices in all the state's major cities, and he was working to activate a strong volunteer base that grew online before professionals arrived in the state. The key issue, he said, is trade. "No state, other than Michigan, has been more affected," he said.Mrs. Clinton responded by intensifying her criticism of a sweeping trade agreement with Pacific Rim nations and calling for tougher rules for auto imports. But she also said that trade "done right" could help thousands of companies in the state."We need a president who is not just opposed to trade," Mrs. Clinton said at a Democratic Party dinner Sunday. "We need a president who knows how to compete against the rest of the world and win."Over the weekend, she crisscrossed the state, offering pep talks to campaign volunteers, dropping references to local issues and companies, visiting African-American churches, touring manufacturing facilities and, on Saturday night, stopping by an Irish pub in downtown Youngstown for a beer and a barstool campaign pitch."It's the best Guinness I've ever had. A Youngstown Guinness!" she said.East of Cleveland, in suburban Lake County, Mrs. Clinton was getting help from an informal club of about 10 women who became friends during the 2004 election and regroup every two years to volunteer on Democratic campaigns. Two of them, wearing "Women for Hillary" buttons over lunch in Mentor last week, said they haven't been contacted by the campaign and have been left to draw a game plan on their own. They said there seems to be more activity among local Sanders backers."I'm a nervous wreck. I really want her to be our nominee and I feel there is more work being done on the other side," said Leslie Bruckman, 60, of Waite Hill.Aaron Pickrell, the Clinton campaign's Ohio state director, said the campaign hasn't been able to reach every supporter. "We have a lot of strong supporters out there. When you're ramping up as quickly as we have, you get out of the way and let supporters do their thing," he said.In Florida, Tuesday's biggest primary prize, the Clinton supporters were more confident. It has many of the older voters that tend to favor her, and early voting began before Mr. Sanders got a boost from his Michigan win. Plus, Florida doesn't allow independents to vote in party primaries, which hurts Mr. Sanders who has appealed to them in prior primaries.Mrs. Clinton also enjoys strong support from Latino voters, some of whom draw a line from Mr. Sanders's brand of socialism and promise of a revolution to repressive Latin American regimes."He'd like to have a socialist revolution, which in South Florida we know something about because we've been through some in Nicaragua, Venezuela and Cuba," said Philip Levine, mayor of Miami Beach, who is backing Mrs. Clinton.The Sanders campaign is hoping to avoid a blowout, which would allow Mrs. Clinton to pad her delegate lead and make up for any losses elsewhere. At a Sanders rally last week in Tampa, some 9,000 people chanted his name and constantly interrupted his speech with cheers."It's amazing to be involved and watching this history happen," said Amanda Schribner, 18, of Valrico, Fla. She said she was planning to make phone calls for Mr. Sanders ahead of the election, but like others at the event, she hadn't had contact with the campaign and didn't know where to go. Still, her vote was assured. "I voted on the first day of early voting," she said.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler And Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: The Military-Free 2016 Contenders; Trump, Cruz, Clinton, Sanders and the rest all share one trait: None has served in the armed forces.
article text: For months the presidential candidates of both political parties have been telling the world about their experience, their wisdom, their love of country. But there is one thing the remaining contenders don't bring up. It is the blank line on all of their résumés:Of the candidates still in the race, not one has served a single day in the military. Not Hillary Clinton, not Bernie Sanders, not Donald Trump, not Ted Cruz, not Marco Rubio, not John Kasich. (And not Ben Carson, who dropped out earlier this month.)There is no requirement for a president to have spent time in the armed forces. In this era of the all-volunteer military, it is perhaps unremarkable that the remaining candidates are lifelong civilians.It once was rare for a November election to occur without at least one of the major-party candidates having a military background. It was a plus: something voters could identify with and admire. When, in 2012, Barack Obama ran against Mitt Romney, it was the first time in 68 years--since Franklin D. Roosevelt ran for re-election against Thomas E. Dewey in 1944--that neither candidate had served in the armed forces.One of the many sacrifices that military men and women make is to delay--and in some cases relinquish--the arrival of the day when they will be able to climb the civilian career ladder. Those who opt not to serve are, in that respect, given a leg up: a head start.With that in mind, during this 2016 campaign I have made it a point, every night, to do some reading--to escape for a few minutes from the candidates' focus-grouped attack lines, and the bellicose social-media posts of paid strategists, and the rehearsed cable-interview zingers. I have instead been reading the citations that, through U.S. history, have accompanied the presentation of the Medal of Honor. They are easy to find, if you look: either online or in books. Maybe not as easy to find as campaign blather, but still readily available."Although painfully wounded as he charged the first machinegun, he launched a vigorous singlehanded grenade attack, destroyed the entire hostile gun position and moved relentlessly forward toward the other emplacement despite his wounds. . . . His indomitable fighting spirit and decisive valor in the face of almost certain death reflect the highest credit upon Cpl. Hauge. . . . He gallantly gave his life in the service of his country."Those words are about Louis James Hauge Jr., a Marine corporal from Ada, Minn., who, at age 20, lost his life at Okinawa on May 14, 1945.Presidential campaigns, by their nature, are self-centered enterprises. If they were boiled down to a single phrase, it would be: "Choose me." So it feels like an antidote to instead read each night about some Americans for whom "Choose me" was an alien thought: Americans who, in the defining moments of their lives, chose to think only of others.Thus, family members of Fred W. Stockham, a World War I Marine gunnery sergeant from Detroit who died in Bois-de-Belleau, France, in 1918, were told, via his Medal of Honor citation, that "G/Sgt. Stockham, upon noticing that the gas mask of a wounded comrade was shot away, without hesitation removed his own gas mask and insisted on giving it to the wounded man, well knowing that the effects of the gas would be fatal to himself. He continued with undaunted courage and valor to direct and assist in the evacuation of the wounded, until he himself collapsed from the effects of the gas, dying as a result thereof a few days later."The names on those citations, most of us have never heard. The bearers of those names didn't seem to feel a hunger for applause. James W. Robinson Jr., of Hinsdale, Ill., was an Army infantry sergeant who, while trying to rescue a wounded comrade in Vietnam in April 1966, "was himself wounded in the shoulder and leg. . . . His rifle ammunition expended, he seized 2 grenades and, in an act of unsurpassed heroism, charged toward the entrenched enemy weapon. Hit again in the leg, this time with a tracer round which set fire to his clothing, Sgt. Robinson ripped the burning clothing from his body and staggered indomitably through the enemy fire . . . as he fell dead upon the battlefield. His magnificent display of leadership and bravery saved several lives and inspired his soldiers to defeat the numerically superior enemy force."Will the day again arrive when military service is regarded as an attribute for a would-be presidential candidate? Or is the election of 2016 merely a sign of things to come: of an American political future in which those who serve are seen as separate from those who run?Mr. Greene's books include "Duty: A Father, His Son, and the Man Who Won the War" (William Morrow, 2001).Credit: By Bob Greene

article name: Democrats Play It Safe With Primary Predictions; Since Michigan, the campaigns of Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton have been trying to ensure they don't fall short of their own primary forecasts
article text: CHICAGO--To hear the two Democratic presidential campaigns tell it, neither Hillary Clinton nor Sen. Bernie Sanders will win Tuesday's primaries .Although polls show the former secretary of state with a comfortable lead in at least some of the states that hold the next contests, the race is closer than those surveys suggest, Clinton campaign officials say. The demographics of the Midwestern states that vote on Tuesday are tailor-made for Mr. Sanders, they add.For his part, the Vermont senator has declined to predict which of the five states holding primaries he will win.Since Mr. Sanders scored an upset victory in last week's Michigan primary , both campaigns have been more willing to forecast losses than wins, trying to ensure they don't fall short of their own pre-election predictions.The political parlor game of managing expectations has ratcheted up several notches in recent days, lest anyone repeat the mistakes of Michigan, where polls showed Mrs. Clinton with a comfortable lead. It's a delicate balance, though, as both candidates continue to project confidence that they can win the Democratic nomination while shying from raising the stakes in any one state with definitive declarations.David Axelrod, a former White House and campaign adviser to President Barack Obama, said the Michigan surprise served as a reminder that campaigns should lay out achievable objectives, at least publicly."They kind of let expectations get away from them," he said of Clinton's loss in Michigan. "You want to set the mark you know you can beat."Lesson learned, it seems, as Clinton campaign aides have played down her prospects in an assortment of states during the past several days. Jennifer Palmieri, Mrs. Clinton's communications director, said the demographics of Ohio, Illinois and Missouri, which hold primaries on Tuesday, are similar to Michigan's profile, which could provide a boost to Mr. Sanders."The history of this primary has shown that he comes in at an advantage" in those Midwestern states, Ms. Palmieri said. "That's not an excuse. That's what our experience has been."In 2008, when Mrs. Clinton faced Mr. Obama in the race for the Democratic nomination, she argued that the candidate who won the Ohio primary would be best positioned to win the White House. The state has been one of the main battlegrounds in presidential elections in recent decades. Mrs. Clinton triumphed in the Buckeye State in 2008, but her campaign is making no such claim this time around."She was wrong. She was mistaken," Ms. Palmieri said of Mrs. Clinton's previous assertion that Ohio was a must-win primary.Mr. Sanders has continued to make the case that he can narrow Mrs. Clinton's lead in convention delegates. But on Sunday, he stopped short of predicting victory in any of Tuesday's primaries, which include Florida and North Carolina, as well.Pressed to name a state he could win decisively in the next round of voting, Mr. Sanders told CNN, "I think we're going to have a good day on Tuesday."He added that he expected success in several states that hold contests in the weeks ahead.Tad Devine, a senior adviser to Mr. Sanders, has been blunt in assessing the primary map, saying recently that Florida could be out of reach.If Florida allowed independents to vote in the primary rather than restricting it to Democratic Party members, "we'd light the whole place up and be very aggressive in trying to win here," Mr. Devine said. "But we'll be realistic. While we have a lot of resources, we want to spend them wisely."Chris Kofinis, a Democratic strategist, said the campaigns' reasons for keeping expectations in check are simple. "You want to mobilize and motivate every supporter you can," he said. And "after Michigan, no one wants to be wrong."Mrs. Clinton collected more delegates overall than Mr. Sanders in last week's primaries by winning Mississippi by a large margin while narrowly losing Michigan. But the unexpected defeat dominated news coverage for days and bolstered Mr. Sanders's campaign.Because expectations are higher for Mrs. Clinton than for Mr. Sanders, long the underdog in the race, the Clinton campaign has been more assertive in trying to lower them. It has walked a fine line as the candidate and her aides predict long-term success while warning of possible setbacks in the short-term.Campaigning in Chicago on Monday, Mrs. Clinton told voters that with their support, she could begin the work of unifying the Democratic Party.When asked two days earlier whether she would win Ohio, Mrs. Clinton demurred. "We're going to work hard," she said. "We're going to work really, really hard."Peter Nicholas contributed to this article.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton Crisscross Tuesday's Big States; The Vermont senator attacks his rival, while she tries to pivot toward November
article text: CLEVELAND--Sen. Bernie Sanders continued to attack rival Hillary Clinton ahead of a critical day of balloting, while Mrs. Clinton suggested voters on Tuesday could deliver a knockout blow that would allow her to pivot toward the general election.The two Democratic presidential candidates spent Monday campaigning in four of the five states that host primaries on Tuesday. The marquee contests were in Ohio and Florida, with both campaigns predicting a tight race in the former and an easy Clinton win in the latter.Also casting ballots Tuesday are voters in Illinois, Missouri and North Carolina.Monday, the candidates adopted very different tones. Mrs. Clinton, who holds a commanding lead in delegates, barely alluded to Mr. Sanders as she urged supporters in Chicago to turn out to vote."Do not rest," she said. With success on Tuesday, she said, the campaign would "be able to start talking about not only unifying the Democratic Party, but also unifying our country."In Ohio, Mr. Sanders was on the offense. He mocked Mrs. Clinton's paid speeches to Wall Street firms, saying they must be "Shakespearean" to garner $225,000 apiece; suggested she told bankers one thing and tells voters another about regulating Wall Street; and said her support for trade agreements makes her complicit in the loss of hundreds of thousands of manufacturing jobs."I proudly stood with the workers. Secretary Clinton stood with the big-moneyed interests," the Vermont senator said in Youngstown, the first of five rallies in four states planned for the day.In Tuesday's top two races, the political dynamics were very different.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 News.* Theranos Founder to Host Clinton Fundraiser* Democrats Play It Safe With Primary Predictions* In Illinois, Clinton and Sanders Vie for Obama LegacyIn Ohio, Mr. Sanders was hoping to repeat last week's victory in neighboring Michigan, another state filled with working-class, white voters dependent on manufacturing and skeptical of free trade. On the trail, he repeatedly pointed to Mrs. Clinton's support for "disastrous" trade agreements that he said have "cost this country millions of decent-paying jobs."The campaign was also working to turn out young people and was buoyed by an Ohio court ruling last week that allows 17-year-olds who will be 18 by the general election to cast primary ballots.At his Cleveland office, Mr. Sanders's Ohio director, Jeff Rusnak, kept track of 50 colleges in the state, their student populations and spring-break dates. The chart shows a challenge: Some 168,000 students, including those at flagship Ohio State University, are on break this week.Mr. Rusnak, a local political consultant, wasn't even hired until about a month ago, but now the campaign has offices in all the state's major cities, and he was working to activate a strong volunteer base that grew online before professionals arrived in the state. The key issue, he said, is trade. "No state, other than Michigan, has been more affected," he said.Mrs. Clinton responded by intensifying her criticism of a sweeping trade agreement with Pacific Rim nations and calling for tougher rules for auto imports. But she also said that trade "done right" could help thousands of companies in the state."We need a president who is not just opposed to trade," Mrs. Clinton said at a Democratic Party dinner Sunday. "We need a president who knows how to compete against the rest of the world and win."Over the weekend, she crisscrossed the state, offering pep talks to campaign volunteers, dropping references to local issues and companies, visiting African-American churches, touring manufacturing facilities and, on Saturday night, stopping by an Irish pub in downtown Youngstown for a beer and a barstool campaign pitch."It's the best Guinness I've ever had. A Youngstown Guinness!" she said.East of Cleveland, in suburban Lake County, Mrs. Clinton was getting help from an informal club of about 10 women who became friends during the 2004 election and regroup every two years to volunteer on Democratic campaigns. Two of them, wearing "Women for Hillary" buttons over lunch in Mentor last week, said they haven't been contacted by the campaign and have been left to draw a game plan on their own. They said there seems to be more activity among local Sanders backers."I'm a nervous wreck. I really want her to be our nominee and I feel there is more work being done on the other side," said Leslie Bruckman, 60, of Waite Hill.Aaron Pickrell, the Clinton campaign's Ohio state director, said the campaign hasn't been able to reach every supporter. "We have a lot of strong supporters out there. When you're ramping up as quickly as we have, you get out of the way and let supporters do their thing," he said.In Florida, Tuesday's biggest primary prize, the Clinton supporters were more confident. It has many of the older voters that tend to favor her, and early voting began before Mr. Sanders got a boost from his Michigan win. Plus, Florida doesn't allow independents to vote in party primaries, which hurts Mr. Sanders who has appealed to them in prior primaries.Mrs. Clinton also enjoys strong support from Latino voters, some of whom draw a line from Mr. Sanders's brand of socialism and promise of a revolution to repressive Latin American regimes."He'd like to have a socialist revolution, which in South Florida we know something about because we've been through some in Nicaragua, Venezuela and Cuba," said Philip Levine, mayor of Miami Beach, who is backing Mrs. Clinton.The Sanders campaign is hoping to avoid a blowout, which would allow Mrs. Clinton to pad her delegate lead and make up for any losses elsewhere. At a Sanders rally last week in Tampa, some 9,000 people chanted his name and constantly interrupted his speech with cheers."It's amazing to be involved and watching this history happen," said Amanda Schribner, 18, of Valrico, Fla. She said she was planning to make phone calls for Mr. Sanders ahead of the election, but like others at the event, she hadn't had contact with the campaign and didn't know where to go. Still, her vote was assured. "I voted on the first day of early voting," she said.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler And Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: In Illinois, Clinton and Sanders Vie for Obama Legacy; Democratic candidates promote themselves as best able to take up president's mantle
article text: Voters in President Barack Obama's home state of Illinois will help decide Tuesday which of the two Democratic candidates should be the heir to his political legacy.With polls showing the race tightening, both former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders have pitched themselves as best positioned to defend and expand on the president's achievements. Mrs. Clinton points to her service in the Obama administration, her commitment to preserving the president's signature health-care law and her desire to improve race relations.Though he has repeatedly called for a "political revolution" against the current establishment, Mr. Sanders has praised Mr. Obama's handling of the financial crisis. His youth-driven campaign and enthusiastic small-donor base have drawn comparisons with Mr. Obama's presidential campaigns.Republican voters vote on Tuesday too, though most of the campaign attention is focused on Ohio and Florida, do-or-die home-state races for Florida Sen. Marco Rubio and Ohio Gov. John Kasich, who trail badly in the delegate count to front-runner Donald Trump.In many ways, Illinois is a microcosm for the broader U.S. electorate. The state has a racial makeup very similar to the country at large, with substantial populations of Hispanic and black voters. It has one of the country's largest urban centers in Chicago, as well as substantial blocs of rural and suburban voters.As a result, experts say the state is something of a bellwether for the rest of the country--offering a preview of how different demographic groups might lean in November. "The racial composition of the population and the electorate are almost spot-on for what they are for the U.S. as a whole," said William Frey, a demographics expert with the Brookings Metropolitan Policy Program.Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton both made visits to the state on the eve of the primary, holding rallies in Chicago. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz barnstormed across the state hoping to blunt Mr. Trump's momentum with a day full of campaign stops. Illinois was an epicenter of protests against Mr. Trump that turned violent last week when he was forced to cancel a Chicago speech.Polls on the Democratic side point to a tightening race. A recent Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll of the state showed Mrs. Clinton leading 51% to 45%. An online CBS News poll showed Mr. Sanders winning 48% to 46%.Clinton campaign officials said the demographics in the Midwestern states that vote Tuesday play to Mr. Sanders's strengths. His surprise victory in last week's Michigan primary suggests Mrs. Clinton could be at a disadvantage in states such as Illinois, campaign officials said. They believe she can still win more delegates overall Tuesday even if Mr. Sanders notches one or more wins in Midwestern states.On the GOP side, polls show that Mr. Trump has a lead in the state. The Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll released Sunday showed him ahead of Mr. Cruz, his nearest competitor, by 9 points. But on the Republican side, Illinois awards most of its delegates by congressional district--meaning all of the Republican campaigns could potentially earn delegates from the contests."The lion's share of the Republican vote in the state is in the suburbs of Chicago," said Brad McMillan, the executive director of the Institute for Principled Leadership in Public Service at Bradley University and a former Republican congressional staffer.Credit: By Byron Tau

article name: Sanders Puts Emphasis on Delegate Math; Vermont senator's campaign shifts strategy to maximize Democratic delegates
article text: On the eve of a five-state showdown Tuesday Bernie Sanders's campaign has dropped its focus on winning marquee states in favor of scooping up delegates anywhere it can find them, hoping to show he still has a chance of overcoming Hillary Clinton's large lead and capturing the Democratic presidential nomination.Mr. Sanders's shift in strategy is a response to the hard realities of delegate math: Despite an upset victory in Michigan last week that cheered his supporters he is losing ground to Mrs. Clinton and in danger of reaching the point where it is impossible to catch up.Two states where the Sanders campaign concedes he will have a tough time winning Tuesday are Florida and North Carolina. Rather than cede them to Mrs. Clinton and focus on winning a trio of Midwestern states where his prospects are brighter, Mr. Sanders late last week expanded his television advertising in certain Florida and North Carolina markets, his advisers said. The idea is to pluck a few extra delegates in the face of an expected Clinton victory in both states."The goal Tuesday is to win as many delegates as we can. And if we can win states, too, that's a big plus," said Tad Devine, a Sanders campaign strategist. "Now we have to build a foundation of delegates. A lot of delegates are in play [on Tuesday]. We can get a lot of them, we think. The advertising in some of these [Florida and North Carolina] markets may make the difference."That is different than the approach Mr. Sanders has taken in the past. When 11 states were up for grabs on March 1, Mr. Sanders did scant advertising and spent little time in Southern states where his rival was favored. He focused instead on capturing a handful of states--including Colorado, Minnesota and Oklahoma--and demonstrating he could beat Mrs. Clinton outside his home base of New England.But the limitations of targeting a few high-profile states have become clear. Delegates are awarded proportionally based on results and because of Mrs. Clinton's lopsided victories in Southern states she has taken a commanding lead.Take the case of Michigan. For all the attention paid to Mr. Sanders's upset victory there, the tight margins in the race--he won by 1.5 percentage points--meant he netted just seven more pledged delegates than Mrs. Clinton. Meanwhile, Mrs. Clinton won 26 more delegates than Mr. Sanders in Mississippi, which she won in a landslide. So, when the voting was all done that night, Mr. Sanders won the headline while Mrs. Clinton expanded her lead by 19 delegates.She now has 766 pledged delegates compared with 551 for Mr. Sanders, according to the Associated Press. Add in the "superdelegates"--Democratic officials free to support whomever they choose--and her lead is 1,231 to 576. A total of 2,383 delegates are needed to clinch the nomination.For Mrs. Clinton, the dynamics are the opposite of what she faced in her 2008 race against then-Sen. Barack Obama. Mr. Obama jumped to a formidable delegate lead in the early going. She was never able to close the gap despite impressive wins in Pennsylvania and other states later in the calendar. Now, Mrs. Clinton is benefiting from the same delegate formulas that were her undoing eight years ago.Tom Nides, a deputy to Mrs. Clinton when she served as secretary of state and now a fundraiser for her campaign, said: "We're basically following the Obama math in 2008. Obama did well enough in some states and really well in other states and he made the math completely impossible for Hillary to get the nomination."An analysis by the nonpartisan Cook Political Report shows that Mr. Sanders would need to win 61% of the remaining pledged delegates and uncommitted superdelegates to catch up to Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders said he isn't deterred, noting superdelegates are free to change their minds. They might do just that if they see him winning and come to believe he's the best bet to defeat the Republican nominee--possibly Donald Trump--in the fall, he said.In an appearance Sunday on CNN, Mr. Sanders said "if we do well in a number of states and if the general sentiment becomes that Bernie Sanders is the candidate who will defeat Donald Trump" superdelegates might "swing over" to his campaign.Polling shows Mrs. Clinton with substantial leads in the three other states that vote on Tuesday: Ohio, Illinois and Missouri, according to a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll.Privately, both campaigns said they believe the race to be tighter. Mr. Sanders's victory in Michigan underscored the strength of his anti-free trade message, a message likely to resonate in neighboring Ohio and Illinois. He also has sought to energize his supporters and perhaps cut into Mrs. Clinton's lead among African-Americans by taking aim at Chicago's Democratic mayor, Rahm Emanuel.Mr. Sanders noted that the Chicago mayor has endorsed Mrs. Clinton and said: "I do not want Mayor Emanuel's endorsement if I win the nomination."Mrs. Clinton jabbed at Mr. Sanders's record and policy positions, highlighting the Vermont senator's opposition to the auto bailout at a rally in Youngstown and questioning his push for single-payer health care at a church near Cleveland on Sunday. "I sure don't want to start over like my opponent does," Mrs. Clinton said, underscoring her support for the Affordable Care Act.Mr. Sanders has said he voted for a bill in 2008 designed to rescue the auto industry. Mrs. Clinton's reference is to another bill that included funds for bailing out Wall Street banks and also contained money to help the auto industry. Mr. Sanders opposed that bill.Clinton aides don't expect Mr. Sanders to withdraw from the race anytime soon. But some in her circle are eager to move on. Whatever happens on Tuesday, they said they would like Mr. Sanders to forego his attacks on the party front-runner.Alan Patricof, a Clinton fundraiser, said: "I'm tired of his message." He added: "He throws a lot of slings and arrows."Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Bernie Sanders Scores Upset in Michigan Democratic Primary; Hillary Clinton captured Mississippi, completing a clean sweep of the Deep South with a heavy turnout of African-American voters
article text: Bernie Sanders proved his grit in the Democratic presidential race on Tuesday, defeating Hillary Clinton in Michigan and showing strength for the first time in a large, racially diverse state far from his home base of New England.Mrs. Clinton easily captured Mississippi, completing a clean sweep of the Deep South powered by her overwhelming popularity among African-American voters in the region. But Mr. Sanders, in winning his most populous state this primary season, made inroads with black voters in Michigan, according to exit polls, winning 30% of the state's African-American primary vote.With 92% of precincts counted in Michigan, Mr. Sanders had 50% of the vote to 48% for Mrs. Clinton. The state will award, proportionally, 130 pledged delegates to the summer Democratic convention.The win gives Mr. Sanders a jolt of momentum at an important moment in the race. He and Mrs. Clinton face off Wednesday in a debate in Florida. Nearly 700 convention delegates are at stake in the next round of voting, next Tuesday, and the Sanders camp hopes the Michigan result will reverberate in two other large Midwestern states that vote then: Ohio and Illinois.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Capital Journal: Angry White Males Propel Donald Trump--and Bernie Sanders* Tenor of Campaign Takes a Toll: WSJ/NBC Poll* Democrats Draw a Diverse Voting Pool in Exit Polls* Clinton's Lead Over Sanders Narrows Slightly in WSJ/NBC Poll* Michigan Turnout Shows Split on ClintonThe other three states to vote next Tuesday are Florida, Missouri and North Carolina.Both candidates had fought hard in Michigan. Trailing in delegates and written off by some Democrats, Mr. Sanders visited the state repeatedly and aired TV ads for the past three weeks in hopes of proving he could go toe-to-toe with Mrs. Clinton in a large industrial state."Not only is Michigan the gateway to the rest of the industrial Midwest, the results there show that we are a national campaign," Mr. Sanders said in a statement. "We already have won in the Midwest, New England and the Great Plains, and as more people get to know more about who we are and what our views are, we're going to do very well."Mrs. Clinton's blowout win in Mississippi--she led Mr. Sanders by some 67 percentage points with 94% of precincts reported--means she could end the night with a wider delegate lead over her rival.Still, the Michigan loss is a serious setback given the time she spent campaigning in the state. Mrs. Clinton put the water crisis in the city of Flint front-and-center, using her national platform to get more money and assistance for a city plagued by polluted drinking water. On the trail, her husband, former President Bill Clinton, repeatedly invoked her response to the Flint crisis as evidence she has the temperament and judgment to be president. The appeal fell short, with Mr. Sanders winning the bulk of counties across the state, although Mrs. Clinton won the counties in the populous Detroit region."There are similarities between Michigan and parts of Ohio and Illinois that have experienced high levels of deindustrialization due to policies that Secretary Clinton has supported over and over again," said Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager.That line of attack has been taken by Mr. Sanders himself, highlighting Mrs. Clinton's early support for the Trans-Pacific Partnership agreement with Pacific Rim nations and for the North American Free Trade Agreement, which was signed by her husband in the 1990s.Mr. Sanders had notched wins in eight of the first 20 Democratic contests coming into Tuesday, but his victories generally had come in small states with overwhelmingly white electorates or that use a caucus format that attracts grass-roots activists, who have migrated to his campaign.The result is a commanding lead for Mrs. Clinton in the tally of pledged delegates. Coming into Tuesday, not counting the so-called superdelegates that aren't awarded by voters, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Sanders 694 delegates to 477. Mississippi awarded 36 delegates.After Mrs. Clinton addressed supporters in Cleveland Tuesday night, and before the Michigan winner was announced, her communications director, Jennifer Palmieri, told reporters she would increase her delegate lead. "Our strategy is built around accruing delegates," she said.A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed the Democratic race tightening nationally, with Mrs. Clinton's lead over Mr. Sanders narrowing to nine points among Democratic primary voters.
