In February, the former secretary of state led by 11 points, and in January, she led by 24 points in the poll.The senator has expended limited resources in several states that Mrs. Clinton won by wide margins. But his campaign long counted on Michigan to serve as a launchpad to next week's primaries.Tuesday in Ferndale, Mich., voters split between the two Democrats. Elizabeth and Gerald Collins both backed Mrs. Clinton. "I think she has the best chance to win," Mrs. Collins, 51, said. "I like where she stands on many of the issues."Mr. Collins, 58, added that he believes people aren't ready for Mr. Sanders and his ideas.Josh Hartwig, 29, disagreed, casting his vote for Mr. Sanders because, he said, he supports the "common man."Clinton campaign officials have long argued the Democratic nomination would be decided in March. And after scoring eight victories on Super Tuesday and winning Louisiana this past weekend, Mrs. Clinton entered Tuesday well positioned to build on her delegate lead. The goal, Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook has said, is to compete everywhere and methodically amass delegates, making it mathematically impossible for Mr. Sanders to catch up.The Sanders campaign believes the race is winnable, saying the map only gets more favorable. The calendar was "front-loaded" with Southern states loyal to Mrs. Clinton and her husband, formerly the Arkansas governor, Mr. Weaver said."Secretary Clinton was the first lady of Arkansas for many years," he said. "Her base is in the South and she's done very, very well in the South."Before Michigan began counting votes, the Democratic contenders already had turned their attention to the next big prizes in their presidential race, with Mrs. Clinton skipping over to Ohio and Mr. Sanders headed to Florida.With next week's Florida primary in their sights, the Democratic presidential campaigns held dueling conference calls over which candidate would be best for the Latino community.The Sanders campaign has been on the defense because of the Vermont senator's 2007 opposition to a comprehensive immigration bill that would have provided undocumented immigrants with a path to citizenship."It is clear Hillary is the only one we can trust to lead 12 million people out of the shadows," Rep. Luis Gutierrez (D., Ill.) told reporters on a call organized by the Clinton campaign.Mr. Sanders's campaign sought to broaden the subject beyond immigration to who best understands and would improve the lives of Latino voters.Mr. Weaver, the Sanders campaign manager, said the senator is the "son of an immigrant himself, who came to this country not speaking English, who saw firsthand and lived firsthand the experience of immigrant communities."Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Sanders Coalition Shows Strength in Michigan; Vermont senator's voter base could make for other close races in the Midwest
article text: The Bernie Sanders coalition--a mix of young voters, liberals and independents--is still a potent force in the Democratic primary race.With his unexpected win in Michigan's primary on Tuesday, Mr. Sanders proved his voting base still has power, just as the nominating calendar is about to turn to similar Midwestern states, including Ohio, Illinois and Wisconsin.Mr. Sanders's voting base had little visibility in Mississippi on Tuesday, where Hillary Clinton won an overwhelming victory on the strength of African-American voters, who made up more than 60% of the voter pool.But in Michigan, where black voters accounted only for about one-quarter of the electorate and gave Mrs. Clinton less of a boost, the Sanders coalition held far more sway.Mr. Sanders carried a commanding 8 in 10 voters under age 30, according to preliminary results of surveys of voters after they cast ballots. He won more than two-thirds of voters under age 45. And while Mrs. Clinton won a lopsided share of African-American voters, Mr. Sanders won nearly 6 in 10 white voters, according to exit polls reported by CNN and other media.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Hillary Clinton's Lead Over Bernie Sanders Narrows Slightly in WSJ/NBC Poll* Michigan Turnout Shows Split on Clinton* What to Watch in Tuesday's Nominating ContestsA similar coalition could make for equally close races in other Midwest states with roots in manufacturing, where the voter pools look more like those of Michigan than of other states that have voted so far.Its white, non-Hispanic population, at 76% of all residents, looks similar to the 80% share of white residents in Ohio, 78% Pennsylvania and 82% Wisconsin. The percentage of people who are 25 or older with a bachelor's degree, at 26%, is in line with those three states. The median household income in Michigan, at $49,000, is also close to those in the three nearby states, which all sit between $49,000 and $53,000. And, of course, each of the states has deep roots and history in blue-collar manufacturing.Mr. Sanders has already won one upper Midwest state, Minnesota, where Democrats held caucuses rather than a primary.The Tuesday night results have a message for both Democratic candidates. For Mrs. Clinton it is that her campaign needs a rationale and message as compelling as Mr. Sanders's call for a "political revolution'' against the wealthy and Wall Street, which has caught the imagination of the party's liberals and young voters.For Mr. Sanders, it is that winning the nomination in a racially diverse party is difficult without winning support from nonwhite voters.Mr. Sanders's weak support among African-Americans has severely hampered him in the South, but he may find diverse states outside the South to be friendlier ground. He won 30% of African-American voters in Michigan, his best showing in any state for which there are exit polls and a far larger share than the single-digit support he had drawn in several Southern primaries.As in other Southern states, Mrs. Clinton's victory in Mississippi rested on support from nearly 9 in 10 African American voters, exit polls showed.In a noteworthy development, men accounted for less than 40% of Democratic primary voters in Mississippi, the exit polls found, with women making up 61% of the electorate. That was a slightly higher share than the average of 58% that women have accounted for in prior nominating contests this year. Mrs. Clinton won convincingly among both men and women.Donald Trump carried Mississippi's Republican primary. Like Mrs. Clinton, he has won the contests in Southern states, including those in Georgia, South Carolina, Tennessee and Virginia.As in prior contests, Mr. Trump's support was strongest among voters without a college degree and those on the lower end of the income scale. But he swept almost every other group, as well, even expanding the coalition that had delivered other Southern states to him.In winning the South Carolina primary, Mr. Trump had lost to Florida Sen. Marco Rubio among college graduates while carrying those without a college degree by large margins. In Mississippi on Tuesday, Mr. Trump won among voters at all levels of education.In winning Georgia, Mr. Trump had lost to Mr. Rubio among voters with household incomes above $100,000. In Mississippi, he won among voters at all income levels.Mr. Trump won among Republican Party members and independents who cast ballots. He carried evangelical Christians and non-evangelicals, foiling Sen. Ted Cruz, who had hoped to build a leading position among evangelicals.Mr. Cruz, a favorite of social conservatives, carried voters who rated themselves "very conservative,'' as he had in prior contests, and by a large margin he won among voters who say it's important that they share the nominee's values. But those voters did not make up large shares of the electorate.Write to Dante Chinni at Dante.Chinni@wsj.comCredit: By Aaron Zitner and Dante Chinni

article name: Tea in Harlem: Sanders Meets With Sharpton
article text: The morning after Bernie Sanders's sweeping victory in the New Hampshire presidential primary, the Vermont senator took his momentum to a Harlem landmark to have tea with the Rev. Al Sharpton.Mr. Sanders arrived at the famed Sylvia's restaurant around 9:50 a.m. Wednesday and waved to a crowd chanting his name. Mr. Sharpton said the meeting lasted 20 minutes and that the senator's visit sent the right message to the black community.Mr. Sharpton said he asked Mr. Sanders, who is seeking the Democratic nomination, about the water crisis in Flint, Mich., affirmative action and police misconduct."My concern is that in January of next year, for the first time in American history, a black family will be moving out of the White House," Mr. Sharpton said. "I do not want black concerns to be moved out with them."He said he hadn't decided on an endorsement in the 2016 race, and he will meet with Hillary Clinton next Tuesday. Mrs. Clinton's camp confirmed the meeting."Sen. Sanders coming here this morning further makes it clear that we will not be ignored," Mr. Sharpton said. "Our votes must be earned."He added Mr. Sanders was also meeting with Kirsten John Foy, Northeast regional director of National Action Network, a civil-rights organization founded by Mr. Sharpton.Also on hand was former head of the NAACP, Ben Jealous, and State Sen. Bill Perkins, a Manhattan Democrat. Both have endorsed Mr. Sanders."Harlem represents the black community and other communities of color in general but he's going to make sure that he's in all those communities so everybody gets to have the Bern," Mr. Perkins said.Also Wednesday, Mr. Sanders appeared on the ABC television show "The View," and a CBS spokeswoman said he would appear Wednesday night on "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert."Tren'ness Woods-Black, the director of communications for Sylvia's (and granddaughter of Sylvia), said the restaurant remained open to the public during the senator's visit."We wanted to allow everyone to be able to interact and get a just up-close and personal look at who's actually running," said Ms. Woods-Black.Some, however, were disappointed Mr. Sanders didn't do more to interact with the public. After a quick wave to the crowd, the senator departed in his car after the breakfast. Yo Akalu, a 27-year-old City University of New York student, didn't believe the visit was genuine."If he really wants our votes he really needs to come into these projects, he really needs to go into these schools, he really needs to speak to these families," Ms. Akalu said. "Him coming out here to Harlem, coming straight to Sylvia's . . . what is that?"But Charles Mannings, a resident of Harlem for 20 years, said he thought the short visit was "inspiring." The 70-year-old retired chef said politicians tended to ignore Harlem."I'm glad to see in this particular instance that is not the case," Mr. Mannings said. "Maybe it's indicative of better things to come."Credit: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

article name: Democrats' Battle Shifts --- As race moves to friendlier ground for Clinton, Sanders works to broaden his appeal
article text: Democrats headed south and west after Sen. Bernie Sanders's resounding New Hampshire victory over Hillary Clinton, facing the twin questions of whether his appeal is broad enough to replicate his performance elsewhere -- and whether her support is strong enough to reverse the tide.Lying at the crossroads of those two questions are the minority voters who have transformed the Democratic Party in the past few decades and hold the promise of sustained success in the future.Mr. Sanders's first act after his 22-point victory in predominantly white New Hampshire was to travel to Harlem in New York on Wednesday and have breakfast with high-profile civil-rights leader Rev. Al Sharpton.In an interview, Rev. Sharpton said that by coming to Harlem after "such a big victory," Mr. Sanders "wanted to send a signal" to the party's minority voters. "She has deeper ties [to the black community] and longstanding friends," Mr. Sharpton said of Mrs. Clinton, "but that doesn't mean he can't win voters."Meanwhile, the Clinton campaign arranged a conference call Wednesday with prominent African-American figures who support the former secretary of state. They cast Mr. Sanders as an arriviste who has ignored issues important to African-Americans."It's good to have new friends -- I would prefer to have true friends," said Rep. Hakeem Jeffries (D., N.Y.), who plans to go to South Carolina to campaign for Mrs. Clinton.Mrs. Clinton now is calling on the Clinton network of African-American supporters, looking to shore up the "firewall" her campaign says it has built in coming contests in South Carolina and other Southern states with large minority populations. The campaign is also tapping into her Hispanic network to sway Nevada voters.On primary night, the Clinton campaign understood that a defeat was coming in the Granite State. But the breadth of the loss left some of her supporters rattled and former President Bill Clinton angry, according to two people familiar with his thinking.Mr. Sanders beat her among women voters and won every age category save for voters over 65. He bested Mrs. Clinton not only among independents who participated in the primary -- and by a lopsided margin -- but topped her among Democratic Party members, 52% to 48%, exit polls showed.That could prove important, as the next primaries and caucuses will have far larger shares of Democrats and smaller shares of independents, who are barred entirely from party primaries in some states. Some 58% of voters in the New Hampshire primary were Democrats. By contrast, Democrats accounted for 81% of Nevada caucus-goers and 73% of South Carolina primary voters during the last competitive contests, in 2008.But Mr. Sanders's strength within the party's membership remains an open question. Mrs. Clinton carried Democratic Party members by 17 points in her narrow victory in Iowa's caucuses last week. And the Democrats in contests to come won't look like those in New Hampshire.Where 93% of New Hampshire's Democratic primary voters were white, only 43% of South Carolina primary voters and 65% of Nevada caucus-goers in 2008 were white. The New Hampshire primary didn't test one of the most important features of the coming contests -- whether Mrs. Clinton is retaining the substantial advantages she has shown among African-American and Hispanic voters in opinion polls.Members of the Congressional Black Caucus are planning to fan out in South Carolina in advance of the state's primary on Feb. 27, talking up Mrs. Clinton's credentials in a state where African-Americans account for more than half of the Democratic electorate."I'm going to preach and teach, tell people to get out and vote for Hillary," said Rep. John Lewis (D., Ga.), who was beaten by state troopers in Selma, Ala., in 1965 during a voting-rights protest.Rep. Gregory Meeks (D., N.Y.), the chairman of the black caucus's political-action committee, said that the group's board last week overwhelmingly voted to endorse Mrs. Clinton. Their formal announcement is expected on Thursday.Brian Fallon, a Clinton campaign spokesman, noted that the contests on March 1 include Texas, Alabama and Georgia -- states with substantial "communities of color."But Mr. Sanders is ceding no ground as his campaign has gained momentum. He won the endorsement of former NAACP President Ben Jealous, and he is about to roll out an ad that shows him marching with Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1963 March on Washington, according to former South Carolina Democratic Party Chairman Richard Harpootlian."His bona fides are beyond question on civil rights, so older African-American voters as they see the TV commercial or radio ad will understand he's not some newcomer to their cause," Mr. Harpootlian said.The tug of war between the Clinton and Sanders camps is putting pressure on one of South Carolina's most prominent officials to come forward with an endorsement.Rep. Jim Clyburn, the only Democrat in South Carolina's delegation and a civil-rights leader with big sway in the state, has stayed neutral, but he may be coming off the fence soon, people familiar with the matter said."I'm feeling it," said Mr. Clyburn, declining to say whom he might endorse. "I have a wife and three daughters" and "they are telling me that I need to take a stand."---Valerie Bauerlein contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Clinton, Sanders Locked in Tie
article text: DES MOINES, Iowa -- Battling for the Democratic presidential nomination, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders were locked in razor-tight contest for Iowa's delegates and the momentum that comes with a win in the nation's first contest.Throughout the night, less than a percentage point separated the pair, with Mrs. Clinton in the lead. With 96% of precincts reporting, her advantage was just 49.9% of the delegates versus 49.6% for Mr. Sanders, according to tabulations from the Iowa Democratic Party."Tonight while the results are still not known it looks like we are in a virtual tie," Mr Sanders told cheering supporters. He added, "I think the people of Iowa have sent a very profound message." His cheering supporters replied, "Feel the Bern!"Mrs. Clinton, addressing her own supporters in Des Moines, said, "It is rare that we have the opportunity we do now: to have a real contest of ideas, to really think hard about what the Democratic Party stands for." She added that she was "breathing a big sigh of relief," though she didn't declare victory.The results amounted to a virtual tie, and mean that Iowa will send roughly an equal number of delegates for each candidate to the party's national convention this summer, where the nominee will be officially selected. They also offer a dose of good news for both campaigns. Mr. Sanders can say that he battled the prohibitive front-runner to a tie, while Mrs. Clinton avoids what would have been an embarrassing defeat.The upstart Vermont senator, whose entry to the Democratic presidential race barely registered, has both new money and new momentum. In January, Mr. Sanders raised $20 million, and with most of his donations well below the legal limit, he can go back to his donors for more."The thing that generally ends campaigns is lack of resources," said David Axelrod, who helped steer President Barack Obama's two victories. "This does not seem to be a problem for the Sanders campaign, which continues to do prodigious grass-roots fundraising."Earlier, in a sweltering school lunchroom in Windsor Heights, a suburb of Des Moines, Clinton backers wooed their neighbors with offers of bottled water. A few miles away, in Clive, Sanders supporters ran out of seats so stood against the wall, beneath Sanders signs reading, "A Future to Believe In.""She has the experience, she has the knowledge, she is qualified, she will get things done," said Vicky Daniel, who caucused for Mrs. Clinton in Windsor Heights. She flew back to Iowa from her winter home in Florida to participate, and when Mrs. Clinton was announced the winner in her caucus, "I said, `yes, yes, yes.'"But in Clive, west of Des Moines, Carol Ferrell, 59, decided at the last minute to support Mr. Sanders. "As much as I admire Hillary Clinton, she's got a lot of baggage," she said.Mrs. Clinton's showing was an improvement over her third-place finish in Iowa eight years ago, which made clear that her once-inevitable campaign faced a serious threat from another challenger, then-Sen. Barack Obama.The Clinton campaign said it was well positioned for a long slog, and Mr. Sanders vowed to press on no matter the results.Both candidates were traveling overnight to New Hampshire to begin a weeklong sprint to the Granite state primary, where Mr. Sanders is 18 points ahead of Mrs. Clinton, according to a Real Clear Politics average of polls.Mrs. Clinton, a former senator and secretary of state, is ahead in the states that come after that, and nationally. But the Sanders campaign believes a win in New Hampshire on top of a strong showing in Iowa would compel voters to give his campaign a second look."We've done what we came to do, which is establish him as a serious candidate," Sanders strategist Tad Devine said Monday, before the caucuses.The Clinton campaign was bracing for a loss in New Hampshire, the state that rescued Bill Clinton's 1992 campaign and revived Mrs. Clinton's 2008 effort."There are a lot of headwinds in New Hampshire," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said, noting that candidates from neighboring states, like Mr. Sanders, have almost always won New Hampshire in recent years.But Mr. Mook said he feels optimistic looking ahead. He pointed to Mrs. Clinton's strong position in Nevada and South Carolina and in the swath of Southern states that will award a quarter of the delegates at stake on March 1. These states, where the Clinton campaign began organizing last summer, have more nonwhite voters than the states in the first two contests. Mrs. Clinton polls strongly among these voters and would continue to emphasize matters important to African-Americans, including her association with Mr. Obama, gun restrictions and the water crisis in Flint, Mich.Former Maryland Gov. Martin O'Malley, who has lagged far behind his competitors and had dwindling resources, suspended his campaign for the Democratic nomination after earning scant support in Iowa.Over dozens of trips to Iowa high schools and diners, in small discussions and big rallies, the two leading candidates engaged in a vigorous and sometimes sharp debate as Mrs. Clinton positioned herself as a pragmatic, can-do fighter, while Mr. Sanders appealed to the party's most deeply held ideals.She battled reports that classified material was sent via her private email system. He battled suggestions that he couldn't win a general election, and that he has no real plan to implement his agenda.Still, he inspired voters who said they were attracted to his rejection of big-money politics and promise of a "political revolution." He drew crowds to arenas and a loyal online following, where backers taunted detractors to "feel the Bern."In speeches that remained almost identical across months of campaigning, Mr. Sanders promised to break up large banks, said Wall Street is built on fraud and unapologetically vowed to impose higher taxes to provide universal health care, free tuition at public colleges and more generous Social Security benefits. At a rally Saturday, as Mr. Sanders ticked off society's problems, the crowd spontaneously began chanting, "Enough is enough!""He has an extraordinary amount of conviction," said Zachery Love, a 19-year-old University of Iowa student, one of more than 4,000 people to turn out for a Sanders concert and rally Saturday night.Mrs. Clinton, for her part, highlighted her perseverance and qualifications along with what she describes as a pragmatic, effective approach to governing. She also portrayed herself as the most electable candidate whose nomination is necessary to block Republican ideas.Her policy platform includes a new program for debt-free tuition and an increase in solar panels, as well as change in health care and Social Security that are more modest than her rival's.Her supporters, including many older women who grew up in a time of outright sex discrimination, say they are inspired by the idea of electing the first female president. And backers often say she is the most qualified candidate for the presidency they have ever encountered.On Monday night, Deidre Fudge arrived early to her West Des Moines caucus to register support for Mrs. Clinton. "I'm just a little worried about Bernie and his naivete," Ms. Fudge said. "I appreciate her experience and level-headedness about what can actually get done."Credit: By Laura Meckler, Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Clinton and Sanders Are Wrong on Fracking
article text: In addition to the economic and scientific hypocrisy of opposing fracking as outlined in your editorial "Clinton Against American Energy" (March 8), I find it ironic that the environmental opposition to fracking ignores the fact that the fracking-based natural gas revolution has resulted in the U.S. becoming the only nation in the world to reduce its CO2 footprint over the past 10 years. Instead of opposing fracking, we should be encouraging even more fracking and natural-gas consumption as we map a cost-competitive path to lower carbon emissions over the next few decades.Frank MurphySt. Louis---Of course Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are against fracking. When properly regulated by states, fracking has shown it is perfectly safe and doesn't pollute. But there remains the theoretical possibility that fracking will be unregulated and may pollute. So we should ban fracking with the good intention of avoiding any possibility of polluting? The consequences may be much higher energy prices which like a regressive tax would impact the poor the most. But this doesn't matter. These are progressive policies and to progressives it is only good intentions that matter. The consequences are irrelevant.Stephen R.S. MartinCave Creek, Ariz.---The reason fracking is supported by Democrats like Colorado Gov. John Hickenlooper -- who holds a master's degree in geology -- is because hydraulic fracturing, with proper regulation, can be done safely. The Environmental Protection Agency has found that fracking doesn't contaminate groundwater resources.Secretary Clinton's assertion that her stipulations would greatly restrict fracking is blatantly untrue, unless she plans to implement much stricter standards.Isaac OrrThe Heartland InstituteSt. Paul, Minn.

article name: Delegate Math Gets More Daunting for Bernie Sanders; Hillary Clinton's lead is bolstered with several wins
article text: Notching wins in at least four big contests Tuesday, Hillary Clinton is on track to become the Democratic presidential nominee, with a delegate lead large enough to withstand whatever challenge rival Bernie Sanders mounts before the voting wraps up in June.Mrs. Clinton captured the biggest prize of the night, winning Florida by more than 30 percentage points. She also easily won North Carolina and Ohio and edged her rival in Illinois. Under party rules that award delegates proportionally based on results, Mrs. Clinton expanded her lead as the race reached the halfway point in terms of delegates.Mrs. Clinton had already built an advantage that looked insurmountable barring a collapse of her candidacy, delegate experts said. She led Mr. Sanders 768 to 554 in pledged delegates, coming off the 29 separate contests that preceded Tuesday's elections. Throw in the superdelegates--Democratic leaders and elected officials who are free to back whomever they choose--and her lead stood at 1,235 to 580.With Tuesday's partial results, Mrs. Clinton added at least 253 pledged delegates to her tally, while Mr. Sanders added 124 delegates. A total of 2,383 delegates overall are needed to clinch the nomination."It would take something not really seen in modern politics" for Mr. Sanders to overtake her, said David Wasserman, a delegate analyst for the nonpartisan Cook Political Report.The hard realities of delegate math have put Mr. Sanders in a deep hole. Mrs. Clinton, a former senator and secretary of state, vaulted to a lead through landslide victories in Southern states with large swaths of African-American voters. Mr. Sanders has scored some upsets, but he hasn't defeated her by sufficiently large margins in delegate-rich states to keep pace.An analysis by Mr. Wasserman shows that the Vermont senator, in advance of the voting on Tuesday, needed to win 61% of the remaining delegates and superdelegates who are as yet uncommitted to catch up to Mrs. Clinton.Sanders aides contend they are trailing because Deep South contests happened to be clustered in the early part of the calendar. They contend Mrs. Clinton was bound to do well in the South because she and her husband are well-known there.Looking down the road, the Sanders campaign sees a series of states where he could prevail and make up ground, such as New York next month and California and New Jersey in June. "We have time to pick up a lot of delegates in those places," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders strategist.But for Team Sanders, the second half of the calendar is no cakewalk. A total of 28 contests remain, with 2,020 delegates up for grabs. More than half the delegates will come from just five states: California, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Washington, and New York, which Mrs. Clinton served as senator.In her 2008 presidential campaign, Mrs. Clinton won four of them, losing only Washington to then-Sen. Barack Obama.A hopeful sign for Mr. Sanders is that Mrs. Clinton isn't doing as well this time among white male voters. But she is winning solidly among minorities, who figure to carry great weight in those states. Blacks and Hispanics accounted for more than one-third of the Democratic electorate in California and New Jersey in 2008, exit polls showed."She's following exactly the strategy the campaign had," said Tom Nides, a Clinton fundraiser and a top deputy to Mrs. Clinton at the State Department. "They wanted by March 15 to be mathematically in position to guarantee the nomination and I think we're moving very quickly to that position."Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCorrections & Amplifications: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton competed in Democratic primaries Tuesday. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated the party's name in the caption of a video. (March 16, 2016)Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: How Sanders Exposed Clinton
article text: Democrats awoke Wednesday with a thought usually reserved for Republicans: Hillary Clinton is a disaster. The marvel is that she fooled them for so long.Picture Bernie Sanders as a small child in the court of Empress Clinton, and you have a modern twist on Hans Christian Andersen. The adoring Democratic townspeople oohed and aahed over their "tough" and "experienced" and "masterful" leader, the anointed heir to the Clinton throne. Then Bernie murmured what was obvious, and the crowd looked again.What they saw in New Hampshire was a dour, 68-year-old woman, shouting at her audience in her best impression of emotion. They saw a gaunt former president, rambling to half-empty forums, grumping about his wife's political opponent. They saw the candidate's surrogates try to snag the votes of young women by threatening them with eternal damnation. They saw a campaign in disarray, dragging carload upon carload of ethical baggage. They saw that the empress has no (or very few) clothes.No one knows whether Bernie Sanders can pull off a nomination. But what everyone does know now is that Hillary has (and is) a problem either way. Let's dispense with some spin: Bernie never had a lock on the Granite State. New Hampshire had stepped up for the Clintons twice before, in 1992 and 2008. This year Hillary went into the contest with endorsements, a huge operation and plenty of money.What she didn't have was the interest of voters. They'd had their eyes opened, and they chose to use their primary to highlight Mrs. Clinton's many and obvious political weaknesses. She may still be the favorite to hold her party's banner, but the mantle of inevitability has been stripped away.New Hampshire exposed again what a wooden candidate Hillary is. Mr. Sanders strolls on stage and makes his audience sing and cheer. Mrs. Clinton's events begin with propaganda videos about her past, followed by a tutorial on why she deserves this. They are heavy, and droning.She cannot do uplifting. She had the same likability problem in her 2000 race for the Senate, when she had to spend a fortune to beat an unknown Republican in liberal New York. The same problem popped up in 2008, against Barack Obama. Why anyone thought she would improve on a third go is a mystery.New Hampshire also uncovered the mismanagement that always attends the Clintons. Hillary wakes up every day with a new campaign. She ignores Mr. Sanders. Then she runs left. Then she attacks him. Then she softens. Her staff has endless debates, which always end up leaked to the press, about whether she needs to appear "stronger," or more "human," or "sharper," or "softer," or more "pragmatic," or more "lofty."She has a habit of unceremoniously firing campaign teams. And this scattershot approach comes from a woman who has been plotting to be president for at least a decade? All this shifting may be another reason why the public sees her as "untrustworthy."To that point, New Hampshire proved that concerns about Mrs. Clinton's ethics aren't merely a right-wing talking point. They've permeated the electorate. Some stunning numbers: Among the one-third of Democratic primary voters who said "honesty" was the top quality they wanted in a nominee, Mr. Sanders won 91%. Among the quarter who said they focused on a candidate who "cares about people like me," Mr. Sanders won 82%.Finally, New Hampshire exposed how out of touch the Clinton machine is with the modern liberal movement. Mrs. Clinton based her campaign on the tropes of a fading Democratic establishment. She figured that women would vote for her simply because she had the right anatomy. She figured that college grads and wealthier Democrats would vote for her because she had more pragmatic policies. She figured that the bulk of voters still viewed the Clinton operation as a sure ticket to the White House.In fairness, she won her age group -- those 65 or older, who grew up with the Clintons. But she lost everyone else: women, men, college grads, blue-collar workers. She lost every income level except those making more than $200,000. She lost liberals. And moderates.What makes Mrs. Clinton's miscalculation notable is that the party's shift was on full, neon view before she even entered the race. It was walking around in the form of Elizabeth Warren. The worry for Mrs. Clinton is that she might be unable to heal the rifts. Barack Obama's soaring rhetoric was able to reunite his party in 2008. Hillary doesn't have his skills.Responsibility for her crushing New Hampshire defeat can't be placed on Mrs. Clinton alone. Her party leadership is in it with her. Since 2008 the Clinton juggernaut has projected Hillary as the party's only option, and Democrats bought it. They closed their eyes to her flaws and scandals, ignored the shifting progressive winds, pushed potential rivals aside, and raved about the empress's lovely clothes. Then Bernie started whispering.Credit: By Kimberley A. Strassel

article name: Election 2016: Clinton, Sanders Clash Over Cost of Plans --- Former secretary of state also questions the senator's loyalty to President Obama
article text: MILWAUKEE -- Hillary Clinton pressed Bernie Sanders on the viability of his proposals for free health care and college tuition in a Democratic presidential debate Thursday, and questioned his loyalty to President Barack Obama for past statements calling the president weak and a disappointment.In a wide-ranging exchange, the first after the candidates split victories in the Iowa caucuses and New Hampshire primary, the Democratic contenders agreed with each other more than they disagreed and appealed to the minority voters who will play a larger role in the next two races, in South Carolina and Nevada.Mrs. Clinton tethered herself to Mr. Obama, who remains enormously popular with the African-American voters she is relying on to help her campaign. She cast herself as the keeper of his legacy, repeatedly injected praise for his record and attacked Mr. Sanders for criticism he has leveled against the president."The kind of criticism we've heard from Sen. Sanders about our president I expect from Republicans -- I do not expect from someone running for the Democratic nomination," she said. "That is a low blow," he replied, saying he has worked closely with Mr. Obama. But he added: "Last I heard, we lived in a democratic society. Last I heard a U.S. senator had the right to disagree with the president. So I have voiced criticisms."Mrs. Clinton said that disagreement was fine but Mr. Sanders went too far suggesting a primary challenge to him in 2011, calling him weak and a disappointment. The Vermont senator's final retort, harking back to the 2008 Democratic primary: "One of us ran against Barack Obama. I was not that candidate."The debate elicited few surprises and revealed no significant change in tactics by either camp that could shift the dynamics of what appears to be a highly competitive fight for the Democratic Party presidential nomination that isn't likely to be resolved for months.Mr. Sanders didn't hesitate to stand by his proposal to impose new taxes on the wealthy and Wall Street to provide new government services. However, he appeared to have no reply when the former secretary of state pointed out that his education proposal would require Republican governors to spend more money to make it happen.Mr. Sanders's plan "rests on making sure that governors, like Scott Walker [of Wisconsin], contribute $23 billion on the first day to make college free. I'm a little skeptical," she said, to loud applause.An unexpected historical figure made his way into the debate: Henry Kissinger, who served as secretary of state and national security adviser under President Richard Nixon. Mr. Sanders sought to put Mrs. Clinton on the defensive, noting that she has said she has taken advice from Mr. Kissinger and citing his role in the secret bombings of Cambodia during the Vietnam War."I happen to believe that Henry Kissinger was one of the most destructive secretaries of state in the modern history of this country," Mr. Sanders said. "I'm proud to say that Henry Kissinger is not my friend. I will not take advice from Henry Kissinger."Mrs. Clinton struck back, seeking to portray Mr. Sanders as unprepared for the world's foreign policy challenges. "Journalists have asked, who do you listen to on policy and we have yet to know who that is," Mrs. Clinton said. "Well, it ain't Henry Kissinger, that's for sure," Mr. Sanders said.While the exchange seemed an unusual detour, the Sanders campaign followed it with a memo to reporters detailing its view on Kissinger's policies.The debate opened with a tense exchange over one of the pair's sharpest policy differences -- Mr. Sanders's proposal to create a single-payer health-care system that would replace private insurance with a government-funded system.Mr. Sanders said it is imperative for the U.S. to guarantee health care as a right, not a privilege. Mrs. Clinton questioned his assertion that a typical American family will see $500 more in taxes while saving $5,000 in health-care costs."The numbers don't add up," she said. "That's a promise that cannot be kept."Mr. Sanders responded by speaking of a general imperative. "Here is the reality, folks. There is one major country on Earth that does not guarantee health care to all people," he said.Mrs. Clinton replied that the U.S. system is fundamentally different from European countries, which have government systems, and that the Affordable Care Act was meant to build on the employer-based system in place.Mrs. Clinton suggested that her opponent was promising more than he could deliver as president and would plunge the country back into another protracted debate over health care: "We have a special obligation to make clear what we stand for, which is why we should not make promises we can't keep."She said she has specified what her proposals would cost -- $100 billion a year. "Once I'm in the White House, we will have enough political capital" to close tax loopholes and raise taxes on wealthy Americans -- steps that would pay for her programs, she said.In reply, Mr. Sanders seized on her prediction that she will be the next president. "Secretary Clinton, you're not in the White House yet," he said.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Sanders Urges Treasury to Set Tax Restrictions on Inversion Deals; The presidential candidate's proposed tax rules would threaten Pfizer's merger with Allergan
article text: WASHINGTON--Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders is urging the Treasury Department to impose new tax rules that could halt Pfizer Inc.'s proposed merger with Allergan PLC , or at least make it more expensive.In a letter sent Friday from his Senate office, Mr. Sanders asked Treasury Secretary Jack Lew to prevent Pfizer and other companies that take foreign tax addresses from borrowing against stockpiled foreign earnings without paying U.S. taxes. He also wants Treasury to limit "earnings stripping," the intercompany maneuvers companies use after taking a non-U.S. address to load up their U.S. operations with subsidiaries and shift profits to low-tax foreign countries."Large multinational corporations should not be able to avoid paying U.S. taxes when children in America go hungry,"wrote Mr. Sanders , a Vermont senator. "Blocking this inversion would not only be sound fiscal policy, it would also act as a strong deterrent to other companies that are contemplating similar tax scams."Joan Campion, a Pfizer spokeswoman, declined to comment.Inversions are transactions in which U.S. companies take foreign addresses, typically by merging with a smaller foreign firm. Stopping them has become a populist cause for Democrats , and both Mr. Sanders and front-runner Hillary Clinton have detailed legislative plans to curb the transactions. Most Republicans, by contrast, favor a broader revamp of the tax system that lowers the corporate tax rate and lightens the tax burden on U.S. companies' foreign income.That disagreement led to stalemate in Congress. In that breach, the Treasury Department has been imposing regulations --and companies have been looking for ways around them.Pfizer, which announced the planned merger and move to Ireland headquarters in November 2015, would become the largest U.S. company to exit the country. The company says its adjusted tax rate after the merger will be 17% to 18%, down from about 24% now. The scheduled closing date is the second half of 2016.Under current law, U.S. companies owe U.S. taxes on their world-wide income. They get tax credits for payments to foreign governments. They then owe the U.S. the remainder of the 35% tax rate, but only when they bring the money home. That leads companies to stockpile low-taxed profits abroad and look for ways to escape the U.S. tax net.As of Dec. 31, Pfizer had approximately $160 billion in accumulated offshore profits on which it hasn't paid U.S. taxes. After the inversion, future profits outside the U.S. wouldn't face any U.S. tax, but the company couldn't simply distribute the built-up past earnings to shareholders without paying the U.S. tax. It could, however, use what's known as a "hopscotch loan" to use those profits indirectly.The Treasury Department has issued two notices that make it harder for companies to benefit from inversions, including restrictions on so-called hopscotch loans. But those rules only apply in cases where shareholders of the U.S. company own at least 60% of the combined firm. The Pfizer deal is structured so that Pfizer shareholders own 56%.Mr. Sanders is relying on an argument promoted by Stephen Shay of Harvard University . In Tax Notes last month, Mr. Shay, along with two other law professors, outlined how the government could use existing regulatory authority to limit such loans. Mr. Shay was the top international tax lawyer at Treasury earlier in the Obama administration.A Treasury spokesman said Friday that the department has received the letter and will respond as appropriate.The Treasury Department has said it is working on the formal regulations that would implement the notices it released in 2014 and 2015. Mr. Lew said in November that the government was exploring more ideas and intended to take further actions in the coming months. The government has struggled to find effective constraints within its existing legal authority while at the same time avoid burdening what it sees as legitimate business transactions.Write to Richard Rubin at richard.rubin@wsj.comCredit: By Richard Rubin

article name: Hillary's and Bernie's Pie-in-the-Sky Social Security Proposals; Promising better benefits and higher taxes, including on investments.
article text: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton have squared off in what progressive author James W. Russell recently called "the Democratic Party's increasingly central debate over expansion of Social Security." Challenged by Mr. Sanders to join him in promising "never to cut Social Security," Mrs. Clinton tweeted a response: "I won't cut Social Security. As always, I'll defend it, & I'll expand it. Enough false innuendos." Nevertheless, the reforms they propose would change the program in fundamental but different ways.Both candidates want massive tax increases, but not by increasing the payroll tax rate, the traditional means for buttressing Social Security finances. Instead, they would put all the financial burden on high-income earners. Mr. Sanders would eliminate, over 17 years, the $118,500 ceiling on which payroll taxes are levied. He also would immediately apply a 6.2% tax on investment income to households with incomes above $250,000. Mrs. Clinton is more circumspect but has recently spoken in favor of both approaches .The maximum earnings subject to the payroll tax would be raised, but--and this is significant--without increasing the benefits eventually paid out to those who pay more in. Moreover, for the first time, non-wage income would be taxed.What sets Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders apart is how they increase benefits. Mrs. Clinton would raise retirement payments for widows as well as provide Social Security credits for individuals who take time out of the workforce to care for a child or an infirm adult. Mr. Sanders would increase the basic benefit for most retirees, raise cost-of-living adjustments, and institute a new minimum benefit for long-career low earners. Overall, Mr. Sanders's proposed benefit increases are nearly three times as large as Mrs. Clinton's.But Mrs. Clinton's benefit increases are more "progressive." I analyzed both proposals using the Policy Simulation Group's microsimulation models, which are used by the Social Security Administration, Government Accountability Office and Labor Department. Under Mrs. Clinton's plan, about 57% of the total dollar increase in benefits would flow to the bottom two-fifths of households, with 21% received by the top two quintiles of households. Under Mr. Sanders's plan, 35% of total benefit increases flow to the bottom two-fifths of households while 44% go to the top two-fifths.These differences derive from the not-entirely-progressive provisions of Mr. Sanders's benefit increases. For instance, Social Security currently replaces 90% of an individual's first $10,272 in average pre-retirement earnings, with lower replacement rates for earnings above that level. Mr. Sanders raises the annual earnings covered by that 90% replacement rate to about $11,800. This boosts benefits progressively for individuals with earnings above $10,272, but individuals with earnings below $10,272 receive no benefit increase. Mr. Sanders also institutes a minimum benefit of 125% of the poverty threshold for workers with 30 years of earnings, but those with shorter careers--who are usually poorer--receive less. Higher cost-of-living adjustments also tend to benefit wealthier, longer-lived retirees.Despite increased taxes, neither proposal would shore up Social Security's long-term funding deficits. These currently range from $10 trillion to $15 trillion over the next 75 years, according to various government estimates.The Sanders plan, according to Social Security Administration actuaries, would close about 82% of the program's long-term deficit as scored by the Social Security's Trustees. But it would fix only about half of the larger shortfall as projected by the Congressional Budget Office.Mrs. Clinton's more restrained benefit increases would probably let her approach 75-year solvency under the assumptions made by the Social Security Trustees, but still fall well short of addressing larger projected shortfalls estimated by the CBO, or by a recent Technical Panel appointed by the bipartisan Social Security Advisory Board. In any event, both presidential contenders would raise the effective top marginal tax rate by 12 percentage points.SSA actuaries assume that upper-income individuals would not work less in response to higher payroll taxes--but the SSA and the CBO do assume that if employers must pay 6.2% tax on their employees' earnings above $118,500, they will reduce employee wages to cover the extra costs. Those lost employee earnings would no longer be subject to federal income taxes, state income taxes, or Medicare payroll taxes. In short, while Social Security might gain $2.4 trillion over 10 years, the rest of the budget would lose nearly half a trillion dollars in revenues over that time.It's unclear how popular either proposal would be in the general election. Americans don't want Scandinavian levels of taxation and certainly not, in Mr. Sanders's case, to pay higher benefits to mostly higher-income households.A well-designed but fiscally conservative Social Security reform could compete with either plan. For instance, a flat poverty-level retirement benefit paid to all, coupled with expanded access to 401(k)s, could eliminate poverty in old age, increase retirement saving, and make Social Security solvent at almost one-third lower cost than Mr. Sanders's plan, eliminating the 12.4% payroll tax on retirees who continue to work.Mr. Biggs is a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. In 2008-09 he served as principal deputy commissioner of the Social Security Administration.Credit: By Andrew G. Biggs

article name: Bernie Sanders Keeps Up Pressure; Hillary Clinton Looks to Pad Delegate Lead; Vermont senator goes on the offensive, with Ohio being key battleground among Tuesday's five primaries
article text: RALEIGH, N.C--Sen. Bernie Sanders ramped up criticism of Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton heading into Tuesday's primary contests , but it was unclear how long he could sustain such attacks if her delegate lead keeps growing.Mr. Sanders was promising to take his campaign all the way to the party convention this summer, whatever Tuesday's outcome. But he may face increasing pressure from Democrats not to harm their likely nominee if he continues to go after Mrs. Clinton for her ties to Wall Street, her record of support for free-trade agreements and the backing she receives from an outside super PAC.Mrs. Clinton, who alternates between sharp attacks of her own and above-the-fray calls for unity, suggested Tuesday she isn't bothered by the swipes and is instead focused on building her delegate lead."I absolutely respect Sen. Sanders," the former secretary of state and New York senator said after greeting voters here. "He has a right to run his campaign in any way he chooses. And I'm proud of the campaign that he and I have run because we've actually focused on the issues."Coming into Tuesday's voting, Mrs. Clinton had a commanding lead: Her 768 pledged delegates, those chosen by voters, was 214 more than Mr. Sanders. Including so-called superdelegates, who are party leaders who can vote for anyone, she had 1,235--more than double her rival's take and more than half the number needed for the nomination, according to a tally by the Associated Press.Five states were voting on Tuesday, including marquee contests in Ohio and Florida, as well as Illinois, Missouri and North Carolina.Mrs. Clinton's advantage was on display Tuesday in Miami, home to large populations of Hispanic and African-American voters who have gravitated to her campaign."I like that she's a smart, charismatic woman," said Bridgette Thornton, a 37-year-old African-American attorney, who cast her ballot at a Miami church. "It was a difficult choice for me, but I'm a practical person. Hillary has a better shot at winning the presidential election."Both campaigns saw Mr. Sanders's chances as better in Ohio, where he has hammered home his anti-free-trade views in recent days. Mrs. Clinton has tried to recast her trade message, but the attempt fell flat with at least some voters."The Clinton history with trade policies, that really just killed our area," said Fred Woke, a 57-year-old radio announcer who voted for Mr. Sanders in Niles, in northeastern Ohio.Mr. Sanders hopes his arguments similarly resonate in coming battlegrounds. "In the states that are coming down the pike, we have great opportunities to win many of them, so we're feeling really good," Mr. Sanders told reporters in Chicago on Tuesday.Earlier in the race, Mr. Sanders vowed to avoid negative attacks, but he has amped up his critique in the weeks since voting began. On the stump leading into Tuesday's voting, he suggested Mrs. Clinton is in the pocket of Wall Street and connected her support for free-trade agreements to an exodus of manufacturing jobs across the Midwest.The challenge for both Democrats is that Donald Trump, should he win the Republican nomination, would be an unconventional opponent who could pick up some of Mr. Sanders's populist arguments.That has some Clinton backers anxious for Mr. Sanders to ease up.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for Election 2016 News.* Live Coverage: Tuesday's Primaries* In Illinois, Clinton and Sanders Vie for Obama Legacy* More GOP Suits Seek Records From Clinton's Term at State Department* Donald Trump Looks to Cinch Fast Track to GOP Nomination* Ted Cruz Pins Hopes on a Convention Fight* Obama Warns 2016 Campaign Marring U.S. Reputation"The message of Sanders campaign has become personal attacks," said Robert Zimmerman, a superdelegate from New York who backs Mrs. Clinton. "It's not only wrong, it's dangerous politically if he keeps up that tone. It could hurt plans for party unity and empower Republicans."Steve Elmendorf, a political consultant who backs Mrs. Clinton, agreed there will come a point when Mr. Sanders needs to let up, but he said it isn't for Clinton supporters to say when. "When it becomes clear you cannot win, then you should unite behind the nominee of the party and try to beat the Republicans," Mr. Elmendorf said. "It's for him to decide when he can't win."In 2008, Mrs. Clinton herself continued to compete in presidential-primary contests against then-Sen. Barack Obama even though he remained ahead in the delegate race the entire time."Even if he doesn't think he will win the nomination, he's trying to amass as many delegates as he can," said Joe Trippi, a Democratic strategist. Delegates would give Mr. Sanders leverage at the party's convention and demonstrate the strength of his movement, Mr. Trippi said, adding, "I don't see him relenting."Sanders aides see a narrow path to the nomination and say the senator will continue to fight for it. They see potential wins in Arizona next week, followed by New York in April and on the West Coast in May and June. Each Sanders win accentuates Mrs. Clinton's vulnerabilities, his aides say, and could persuade superdelegates that Mr. Sanders would be the strongest Democratic candidate this fall.His fervent supporters, who continue to fill arenas, also hope he presses forward."I think that you need to fight the fight 'til the end," said Cindy Figh, 50, a massage therapist from Lithia, Fla., who shaved the name "Bernie" into her hair and came to see the senator speak last week in Tampa. "I just think that there's a chance that he can pull it off."She rejected any suggestion that Mr. Sanders might damage Mrs. Clinton, whom she plans to support if she wins the nomination. "I think that this is part of politics," Ms. Figh said. "We're in the big-boy playground now, and sometimes your ball gets taken away."Steve Schale, a Democratic consultant in Florida who voted for Mrs. Clinton though he was hoping to work for Vice President Joe Biden in this race, said he doesn't worry that the Sanders attacks will damage Mrs. Clinton, partly because Democrats are sure to unify if Mr. Trump is the nominee."You want to get Democrats over the Sanders-Clinton thing, give them five seconds to think about Trump being within five feet of the nuclear codes," Mr. Schale said.He said he saw no mathematical way for Mr. Sanders to overcome Mrs. Clinton's delegate lead, and said a protracted primary fight would occupy time that the Clinton campaign could be using to prepare for the general election."If Hillary Clinton has to go debate Bernie Sanders in New York, and compete in Indiana and California, that means the campaign is not spending time thinking about building organizations in Ohio and Colorado and Florida," he said.President Barack Obama has suggested that he, too, could bring the Democratic Party together once the primary battle concludes. Mr. Obama previously had raised the prospect of making an endorsement in the Democratic primary, but he has since backed off that idea, saying last week that Democratic voters are doing a fine job."It's been a good conversation," Mr. Obama said. "And my most important role will be to make sure that after the primary is done I'm bringing everybody together so that we focus on winning the general election."Arian Campo-Flores and Heather Haddon contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: The Zero-Sum Worlds of Trump and Sanders; Both presidential candidates support long-discredited economic policies.
article text: Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders might seem unlikely economic soul mates, but they share a mistaken reliance on zero-sum thinking and long-discredited economic policies.Mr. Trump's anti-immigration and anti-trade positions make him essentially a disciple of mercantilism--a protectionist economic theory refuted by Adam Smith in 1776. Bernie Sanders proudly calls himself a socialist and advocates vast increases in taxes and government power. The history of the past century, from the Soviet Union's fall to the impending collapse of Venezuela, amply shows that a socialist economy isn't only "rigged"--to borrow one of Mr. Sanders's favorite words--it doesn't work.Messrs. Trump and Sanders have been led astray by zero-sum thinking, or the assumption that economic magnitudes are fixed when they are in fact variable.If the world is zero-sum, then the number of jobs is fixed, as is gross domestic product. In Mr. Trump's mind, if there are more Mexican workers in the U.S., then American workers must lose their jobs. In the real, positive-sum world where Mr. Trump doesn't live, Mexican workers also consume, thus increasing GDP and creating new jobs.Moreover, the reason that firms hire immigrant workers is to lower costs, and this leads to lower prices for consumers, allowing them to purchase additional goods--adding new jobs to the U.S. economy. But in a fixed world prices do not change, so this effect is ignored.Similar arguments apply to Mr. Trump's analysis of Chinese imports. In a world of fixed GDP and prices, imports of goods from China merely replace goods that otherwise would have been produced by American workers. In the real world, imports reduce prices and increase GDP, so workers, who are also consumers, benefit from imports of lower-cost goods and increase their consumption of other goods.Mr. Sanders's economics is also zero-sum, although he emphasizes a different aspect of the fallacy. In a zero-sum world, taxes don't matter much because people work the same amount anyway, so there are no losses from reduced effort in response to higher taxes. Similarly, in a zero-sum world methods of production are given, so there are no responses to changing prices--higher minimum wages don't lead to layoffs, for example. (In the real world, we saw Wal-Mart's recent store closings following wage increases.) In the Bernie Sanders universe, the size of the economy is fixed so there is plenty to redistribute no matter how misguided the economic policies.Zero-sum thinking persists because it is superficially appealing. Mr. Trump's policies would in theory benefit Americans and increase jobs. Mr. Sanders's policies would make the poor better off. In the actual, positive-sum world we live in, their policies--building a fence along the Mexican border, disrupting labor markets by deporting millions of productive workers, huge tariffs on imported goods, much higher income taxes and minimum wages--would, if adopted, lead to an economic depression that would make the 1930s look prosperous.Mr. Rubin, an economics professor at Emory University and a senior fellow at the Classical Liberal Institute at New York University, is the author of "Darwinian Politics: The Evolutionary Origin of Freedom" (Rutgers Press, 2002).Credit: By Paul H. Rubin

article name: South Carolina, Nevada Vote on Presidential Candidates; Hillary Clinton edges out Bernie Sanders in Nevada, while Donald Trump wins South Carolina; Republican candidate Jeb Bush suspends campaign
article text: GOP Rivals Make Final Push in South Carolina as Voters Head to PollsBusinessman and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump--flanked by his daughter Ivanka, far left, and wife Melania, far right--waits to speak to his supporters in Spartanburg, S.C., after his victory in the South Carolina Republican primary.Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, left, greets supporters with her husband and former President Bill Clinton at a Nevada Democratic caucus rally on Saturday.Florida Sen. Marco Rubio, accompanied by his family, waves to his supporters in at a rally in Columbia, S.C., after the Republican primary. Mr. Rubio posted a second-place finish in the primary.Following the results of the South Carolina Republican primary, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush, accompanied by his wife, Columba, said he was suspending his campaign for the presidential nomination at a rally in Columbia, S.C.South Carolina Governor Nikki Haley, left, greets Mr. Rubio before his speech in Columbia, S.C., following the South Carolina Republican primary.After the South Carolina Republican primary, presidential candidate Sen. Ted Cruz (R., Texas) addresses supporters at a rally in Columbia, S.C.Mr. Sanders speaks to his supporters in Henderson, Nev., after Mrs. Clinton was projected as the winner. 'Taking on the establishment, whether it is the financial establishment, whether it is the political establishment, whether it is the media establishment, is not easy,' he told his supporters.Republican presidential candidate and Ohio Governor John Kasich addresses the crowd in Wakefield, Mass., at a 'watch party' for results from the South Carolina Republican primary.In Spartanburg, S.C., Mr. Trump's supporters celebrate the positive early results of the South Carolina Republican primary.Mrs. Clinton's supporters in Las Vegas cheer before she was projected by the media as the caucus winner.Caucus-goers register at the Del Sol Academy of the Performing Arts in Las Vegas. Mrs. Clinton's lead in Nevada shrank as some women voters switched to Mr. Sanders.Saturday gave voters in the Western and Southern U.S. their first chance to pass judgment on this year's presidential candidates, with the South Carolina Republican primary and the Nevada Democratic caucuses. The previous votes were held in New Hampshire and Iowa. Above, a precinct official counts votes of caucus-goers at Rancho High School in Las Vegas.GOP officials predicted a high turnout in South Carolina, and absentee voting backed up that expectation. Almost 59,000 absentee ballots were turned in by Friday, according to a spokesman for the state's election commission. That was more than the 2008 and 2012 results combined. Above, a voter casts his ballot at Our Savior Lutheran Church in Columbia, S.C.Republican voters wait to cast ballots at an American Legion Hall in Cayce, S.C.Mr. Sanders and his wife Jane, left, greet voters at a caucus site in Las Vegas.Ms. Haley is shown voting in Lexington, S.C. The remaining Republican presidential candidates were looking to make up ground on Mr. Trump the party's front-runner. Ms. Haley had previously endorsed Mr. Rubio.Mr. Bush, left, gets a hug from his mother, former first lady Barbara Bush, after visiting a polling station in Greenville, S.C.Mr. Trump was the top pick of 28% of likely Republican primary voters in South Carolina, according to a Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll held in the final days before Saturday's election, but that was down 8 percentage points from a January survey. Above, voters cast ballots at the fire department in Mauldin, S.C.People were out in support of their preferred Democratic candidate outside a caucus location at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas. Nevada has 23 delegates up for grabs in this year's caucuses.South Carolina awards 29 delegates to the statewide winner of the GOP primary and another three to the winner of each of its seven congressional districts. Above, a voter casts her ballot at Hand Middle School in Columbia.Ballots were cast in the Horse Gall voting station, which was in the garage of precinct volunteer David Smith in Varnville, S.C. There are 76 registered voters in the Horse Gall precinct.

article name: Bernie Sanders's Team Still Sees Path to 'Win This Game' After Poor Results; Clinton campaign says she has 'nearly insurmountable' lead
article text: WASHINGTON--Coming off a bad night, Sen. Bernie Sanders's top aides professed no concern in the face of an increasingly difficult path to the Democratic nomination, saying the race is only half over and their candidate will win the contests to come."We agree that we're behind but we also think we're going to win this game. We see a path to get there," said chief strategist Tad Devine. "The back end of this process is as favorable to Bernie as the front end was to Hillary."Fresh off its wins Tuesday, the Hillary Clinton campaign struck a confident tone, calling Mrs. Clinton's lead in delegates to the national convention "nearly insurmountable" and said Mr. Sanders would have to win huge states by lopsided margins to catch up.The Sanders campaign said it sees opportunities for victories next week in Arizona's primary and in a string of caucuses in the coming weeks, including Idaho and Utah, where the Vermont senator plans to campaign in the coming days.Aides hope he can surpass Mrs. Clinton with big wins in New York in April and California in June.It will be a steep and perhaps impossible climb. Losses Tuesday in Florida, Ohio, North Carolina and Illinois made Mr. Sanders's already large deficit even deeper. He also trails by 0.2 percentage point in the night's fifth state, Missouri, which the Associated Press has deemed too close to call. The Sanders campaign said it hadn't decided whether to ask for a recount.Mrs. Clinton's lead among pledged delegates, those chosen by the voters, has grown to 314--with her claiming a total of 1,132 to his 818 .That is more than double any lead that then-Sen. Barack Obama enjoyed in 2008. Democratic Party rules allocate delegates proportionately, meaning it is very difficult for a candidate to catch up once he or she has fallen significantly behind, because even the loser wins a share of the pie in each contest.Mrs. Clinton's advantage is even more imposing when superdelegates, who can vote for anyone they like, are included in the totals. In that case, she has 1,599 to Mr. Sanders's 844 , according to a tally by the Associated Press. A total of 2,383 is needed to clinch the nomination.In a public memorandum Wednesday, Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook allowed that Mr. Sanders may win several upcoming contests, but he said it won't matter."Looking ahead to the rest of March, Sen. Sanders is poised to have a stretch of very favorable states vote, including five caucuses next week, which he is likely to win," he wrote. "But our pledged delegate lead is so significant that even a string of victories by Sen. Sanders over the next few weeks would have little impact on Sec. Clinton's position in the race."To erase the Clinton delegate lead, Mr. Mook said, the Vermont senator would need to score double-digit victories of his own in states like New York, California and Pennsylvania, which account for 45% of the remaining delegates--and even that may not be enough.The Sanders team said its strategy was focused on winning pledged delegates in contests to come. The campaign's Mr. Devine also sketched out a novel plan to look for delegates in caucus states that have already voted, saying the rules allow campaigns to add to their totals as the process moves to the county and then to the state level. He also said pledged delegates aren't required to vote for the person they were elected to represent if the race changes."The numbers are not set in stone," he said.Mr. Devine also argued that superdelegates--party leaders who can vote for whomever they like--can be persuaded to back Mr. Sanders if they see Mrs. Clinton lose contests this spring and can be persuaded Mr. Sanders is the stronger general election candidate.That, too, may be a tough case given that party leaders are the very people Mr. Sanders regularly derides as part of the "establishment" he seeks to overturn.It also will be a challenge if Mrs. Clinton maintains the lead among the pledged delegates who are selected by voters. Liberal groups including MoveOn.org have pushed to reduce the power of superdelegates, but their point is that the party leaders shouldn't overrule the voters.As the campaign presses forward, some Democrats could grow annoyed if Mr. Sanders continues his pointed barbs at Mrs. Clinton. But Sanders campaign manager Jeff Weaver said he thinks the criticism is valid."I anticipate the tone will remain the same," he said. "There are important differences between Secretary Clinton and Bernie Sanders. It's incumbent upon us and them to point out where those differences are."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Bernie Sanders Seeks to Dent Hillary Clinton's Delegate Lead as Race Moves West; Vermont senator is looking for a second wind going into Tuesday's contests in Arizona, Idaho and Utah
article text: Sen. Bernie Sanders entered Tuesday's Democratic contests in urgent need of both lopsided wins and a strategy for broadening his coalition beyond the young and largely white group of voters who have boosted him so far.With about half the primary season over, Tuesday's contests in Arizona, Idaho and Utah marked the first test for the Vermont senator in what his campaign has argued would be more favorable terrain in Western states.But Mr. Sanders is limping into this leg of the race.Hillary Clinton swept through the South, then won all five states that held primaries last week. While Mr. Sanders has predicted that he would prevail in the second half of the Democratic primary fight, a look at the calendar reveals limited opportunities for the Vermont senator to eat into Mrs. Clinton's lead, which stands at more than 300 among pledged delegates and 440 among superdelegates.Mr. Sanders could score several victories in Western states and beyond. But narrowing Mrs. Clinton's delegate lead, which was built in part on substantial victory margins in the South, will require him to notch landslides that produce big shares of the available delegates.An examination of the 28 contests stretching from now until mid-June shows opportunities for Mrs. Clinton to hold her lead or even build on it. As a presidential candidate in 2008, she faced off against then-Sen. Barack Obama in each of those states. She won 12 contests; Mr. Obama won 16.But her 12 victories came in states and one territory, Puerto Rico, that in the 2016 primaries account for more than 1,400 delegates. By contrast, the 16 contests she lost in her last campaign offer only about 600 delegates this year.How Mrs. Clinton fared in 2008 is instructive, because she is holding the vast majority of states she won last time around. She carried states such as Ohio, Texas, Tennessee, Massachusetts and Arkansas both in 2008 and this year.To assess how the next phase of the race suits Mrs. Clinton, consider California. The state's June primary will allocate the biggest prize of the entire race, 475 delegates. In 2008, Mrs. Clinton won California easily, defeating Mr. Obama by eight points.Exit polls from that contest show an electorate that would seem amenable to Mrs. Clinton's 2016 candidacy, with African-American and Hispanic voters accounting for 37% of the electorate. Mrs. Clinton has shown she performs best in states with large minority voting blocs.Mr. Sanders's campaign has remained focused on every opportunity to make up ground. On Tuesday, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, touted the campaign's win in the primary among Democrats Abroad--a contest that netted the Vermont senator five more delegates than Mrs. Clinton."This is the result we needed," Mr. Weaver wrote in a fundraising email. "Now the map shifts in our favor, and we're going to begin clawing back delegates in state after state until we capture the lead on June 7th," the last major day of primary voting.Mr. Sanders has done well in states that are more liberal and mostly white, and he will find that in many Western states. What's more, several of the next contests are caucuses, which have yielded favorable results for Mr. Sanders.Stan Greenberg, a veteran Democratic pollster, said the race increasingly appears to be settled, making it difficult for Mr. Sanders to change the basic dynamic. The Vermont senator's failure to win any contest last week could prove to be a defining moment in this campaign, Mr. Greenberg said."He lost momentum at that point, and we entered the endgame," he said. "Unless there's a huge surprise, it's not going to happen."More in Election 2016* Five Things to Watch in Tuesday's Election Contests (March 22)* Brussels Attacks Will Jolt 2016 U.S. Presidential Race (March 22)* Sanders Strives for Comeback in Arizona Primary (March 21)* Clinton Denounces Trump Before Pro-Israel Lobby Group (March 21)David Wasserman, a delegate analyst for the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, wrote recently that Mr. Sanders could string together several victories in the West and then stall in the more diverse Northeastern states that follow. "If there is bad news for Clinton, it's that the next month of primaries could give the false impression that Sanders is on track for a big comeback," Mr. Wasserman wrote.Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook has described the former secretary of state's delegate lead as "nearly insurmountable." Mrs. Clinton, speaking Tuesday in Everett, Wash., also touted her lead."I have gotten 2.6 million more votes than Bernie Sanders,'' she said. "I have a bigger lead in pledged delegates, the ones you win from people voting, than Barack Obama had at this time in 2008. So we are on the path to the nomination."In Arizona , which held its Democratic primary Tuesday, many voters still were standing by Mr. Sanders.Jordan West, 24, a preschool teacher from Phoenix, said Mr. Sanders is best able to make a difference in the lives of the less fortunate. "He's a compassionate person," Ms. West said. "I think we need a compassionate leader. There's a lot of hate."But even some of the Vermont senator's most enthusiastic backers aren't convinced that he can overcome Mrs. Clinton's lead."I think he should stay in it as long as possible," said Ayla Carlsted, a 28-year-old Sanders supporter who lives in the Phoenix area. "He's making so much change and he needs to make as much change as he possibly can. I don't necessarily think he's going to beat Hillary."Byron Tau and Laura Meckler contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Peter Nicholas

article name: An Empty Obama-Clinton-Sanders Plan on Drug Costs; Requiring drug-by-drug data on R&D spending shows a misunderstanding of how my industry works.
article text: President Obama's latest budget includes proposals--echoed or one-upped on the presidential-campaign trail by Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton--that would require pharmaceutical companies to release data on the cost of research and development (R&D) and the extent of discounts offered to insurers for each drug brought to market. Yet the key numbers already are disclosed freely--and we know how to get better value from medicines and improve their affordability to patients.The company I lead, Lilly, discloses its annual R&D spending in audited financial statements every year, like other public companies. Lilly's number for 2015 was $4.8 billion--part of the $50 billion invested in R&D each year by the members of our industry association alone. That's more than 20% of all R&D spending by all U.S. businesses. Seen against that staggering total, the proposal to mandate the nearly impossible task of assembling drug-by-drug R&D-spending figures misses the whole point.Pharmaceutical companies' R&D feeds innovation from the earliest identification of leads through to clinical trials, real-world data collection and the refinement of existing treatments. It includes the cost of myriad failures--part of every scientific enterprise--along with further research on approved medicines, right up to their patent expirations. Money made on the sale of today's new medicines feeds all of the indispensable streams in this complex ecosystem.Averages are easy enough to come by--a new academic study in the Journal of Health Economics says it takes about $2.6 billion in R&D investment per new medicine launched. Calculating a precise number for an individual product is quite another matter. Consider Lilly's investment of billions of dollars in R&D related to Alzheimer's disease over the last quarter century. Since there are several candidates in our pipeline that emerged from past work, to which future product and in what proportion should these costs be allocated? And to what end?The key insight is beyond dispute. Developing medicines is risky, expensive and time-consuming, and everyone would be better off if it were less so. Rather than meaningless disclosure mandates, policy efforts instead should encourage whatever can be done, without compromising patient safety, to shave precious weeks off development and regulatory-approval timelines.There are effective ways to do that. For example, pooling access to potential new molecules and sharing "pre-competitive" research on promising treatment paths could avoid costly duplication.
