"It is not true."The current head-to-head polls bear him out. In the Real Clear Politics polling average, Mr. Sanders leads Mr. Trump by 17.5 points and Mr. Cruz by 8.4. Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Trump by 11.2 and Mr. Cruz by only 2.9. Mr. Sanders is tied with John Kasich, while Mrs. Clinton loses to the Ohio Governor by 6.5 points.Most Americans still don't know much about what Mr. Sanders believes, including his desire to return to 1930s tax rates and his sympathy for Communist regimes during the Cold War. His belief in undiluted socialism would be vetted in a general election campaign in a way it hasn't been in the Democratic primaries.Then again, Mrs. Clinton has helped to validate many of those positions by moving so far left herself. And in Mr. Trump the Republicans may nominate a candidate who is building negative approval ratings that no candidate has been able to recover from and win the White House.Mrs. Clinton remains the all-but-certain Democratic nominee, not least because of her lead in "superdelegates." These are current or former elected officials and other Democratic grandees who are formally unpledged to any candidate before the convention. AP currently has them going 469 for Mrs. Clinton and only 29 for Mr. Sanders.For all the talk about an open convention that could deny Mr. Trump the GOP nomination, the Democratic establishment has done far more to rig the nominating process to favor elites. One reason Mr. Sanders gets no respect is because Democratic elites prefer a nominee who disguises her socialism better than he does.

article name: Bernie Sanders Gets Boost From Saturday Sweep but Trails in Delegate Count; Sanders beats Clinton by significant margins in Alaska, Hawaii and Washington Democratic caucuses
article text: Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders's resounding victories in three weekend caucuses gave his campaign a much-needed boost but did little to slow Hillary Clinton's march to the Democratic Party's presidential nomination.His wins in the Washington, Alaska and Hawaii caucuses, coupled with his strong fundraising, strengthen Mr. Sanders's argument for remaining in the Democratic race.But his path to the nomination remains contingent on big victories in the roughly two dozen states and territories that have yet to vote--and on persuading roughly 500 party officials and activists known as superdelegates to abandon Mrs. Clinton and back him at the July convention in Philadelphia."We think we do have a path toward victory," Mr. Sanders said Sunday on CNN. "We've won the last five out of six contests, all of them in landslide victories. What we have said from day one is the South is the most conservative part of America. We did not do well there...We're out of the South, we're heading to the West Coast which is the most progressive part of America. We think we're going to do very well there."The Sanders campaign acknowledges that it is fighting an uphill battle, but Mr. Sanders cited his momentum in arguing that "a lot of these superdelegates may rethink their position."The campaign moves on to Wisconsin next. Mrs. Clinton announced Saturday she would campaign in Madison, Milwaukee, La Crosse and Green Bay in advance of that state's April 5 primary. Mr. Sanders has campaign stops scheduled in Appleton, Milwaukee, Kenosha and La Crosse this week.After Wisconsin, the next big contest is in late April in New York, a delegate-rich state that carries symbolic meaning for both campaigns. Mrs. Clinton represented the state in the Senate between 2001 and 2009 and has based her campaign there. Mr. Sanders was born in Brooklyn and makes frequent references to his childhood upbringing.In Alaska, Mr. Sanders beat Mrs. Clinton by 64 percentage points, in Washington by 46 points, and in Hawaii by 40.Mrs. Clinton didn't campaign heavily in the three states, expecting that Mr. Sanders would win. In the run-up to the contest in Alaska, she called into a radio station and recalled a period after college when she briefly worked at a fish cannery in the state.Related* Bernie Sanders Wins Hawaii, Washington, Alaska CaucusesMrs. Clinton has built her delegate lead on nonwhite and older voters, winning in states across the South where black voters make up a significant proportion of the electorate. Though Mr. Sanders trails in delegates the map is potentially friendlier for him in April and May when a number of northeastern states head to the polls.Mr. Sanders won at least 55 of the delegates at stake on Saturday, while Mrs. Clinton won at least 20. That means he still trails Mrs. Clinton 1,004 delegates to 1,712 delegates, including superdelegates, according to the Associated Press.Mr. Sanders entered March trailing Mrs. Clinton by fewer than 30 delegates after their virtual tie in Iowa and his victory in New Hampshire. But in the March 1 contests, Mr. Sanders won only 347 of the delegates while Mrs. Clinton picked up 518. She swept all five states on March 15 --Florida, Illinois, Missouri, North Carolina and Ohio--and added to her delegate lead.Democrats award delegates in all contests on a proportional basis. Mr. Sanders would need to win almost two-thirds of the remaining pledged delegates to clinch the nomination.After a busy March in which Democratic voters in about 30 states and territories cast ballots or caucused, the pace of contests in April and May slows down significantly.After Wisconsin, Wyoming will hold a caucus on April 9. New York's primary is April 19, while Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island hold Democratic contests on April 26.Mr. Sanders is expected to be competitive in many of those races. His campaign won victories in northeastern states of Vermont, New Hampshire and Maine, plus Michigan.Ben Leubsdorf contributed to this article.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Byron Tau

article name: Bernie Sanders Wins Hawaii, Washington, Alaska Democratic Caucuses; Vermont senator's victories cut into front-runner Hillary Clinton's delegate lead
article text: Bernie Sanders swept Saturday's Democratic caucuses, cutting into front-runner Hillary Clinton's formidable lead in delegates.Following the Vermont senator's victories in Alaska and Washington, the Associated Press declared Mr. Sanders the winner of the Hawaii Democratic caucuses.Washington was by far the day's biggest prize, with a total of 101 pledged delegates up for grabs, more than twice that of the other two states combined.In Washington, Mr. Sanders won 72.7% of the vote, while Mrs. Clinton took 27.1%. In Alaska, Mr. Sanders led Mrs. Clinton 81.6% to 18.4%, while in Hawaii, Mr. Sanders garnered 69.8% to Mrs. Clinton's 30%.Mr. Sanders spoke to tens of thousands of supporters in Washington heading into the caucuses.Both Mrs. Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, also campaigned in the state in the run-up to the caucuses. Clinton campaign officials seemed to recognize that it was facing long odds. In 2008, Mrs. Clinton lost Washington to then-Sen. Barack Obama. The campaign's goal was to keep Mr. Sanders's victory margin and delegate pickup as low as possible.Earlier in the day, Mr. Sanders won in Alaska, which offered just 16 pledged delegates. Still, despite the state being the day's smallest prize, neither the Vermont senator nor Mrs. Clinton wrote off the caucuses.In the run-up to the contest, the former secretary of state called into a radio station and talked about a time after graduating from college when she briefly worked at a fish cannery in Alaska."And think about this," she reportedly told the station, "I'm the only candidate who's ever actually worked in Alaska. So, hooray!"Mr. Sanders, meanwhile, opened a handful of offices in the state, hoping to string together enough victories that might give superdelegates a reason to rethink their allegiance to Mrs. Clinton.Meanwhile, Hawaii is an impractical place for a candidate visit because of its distance from the mainland. Neither Mrs. Clinton nor Mr. Sanders traveled there in advance of the caucuses.But Mr. Sanders aired TV ads aimed at introducing himself to Hawaii voters, and he also showcased the endorsement of a native daughter, U.S. Rep. Tulsi Gabbard (D., Hawaii).In February, Ms. Gabbard said she resigned her spot as Democratic National Committee vice chairwoman so she could campaign for Mr. Sanders.Hawaii has only 25 pledged delegates at stake, but it is one of a series of Western states that the Sanders campaign viewed as winnable and important to mounting a comeback against Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders has a steep uphill battle to gain enough delegates to become the nominee. Mrs. Clinton entered Saturday's contests with a lead of more than 300 among pledged delegates.As Mr. Sanders lost ground to Mrs. Clinton in earlier contests, his campaign asked voters for patience. His advisers have argued that the second half of the primary season, which started this week, would take the race to more favorable terrain--namely, Western states that are more amenable to Mr. Sanders's candidacy and message.While Mr. Sanders's victories in Idaho and Utah on March 22 showed strength in Western states with small Hispanic or African-American populations, Mrs. Clinton has tended to dominate in states with large minority populations.Hawaii's population is more than one-third Asian-American, along with sizable white and native Hawaiian populations. Alaska is almost 15% Native American. And in Washington state, Yakima and Grant counties have large Hispanic populations of 40% or more.Under Democratic rules, delegates are awarded proportionally based on results, not winner take all, so Mr. Sanders not only needs to win the states, but win by large margins, to close the delegate gap with Mrs. Clinton.Meanwhile, a new skirmish over the Democratic debate schedule was brewing, with the two camps unable to reach agreement on dates and locations for the final matchups. Both campaigns consented to face off two more times, once in April and again in May. But several weeks after that pledge was made, the Democratic National Committee still describes all the details of the ninth and 10th debates as "to be determined."Party officials say they are waiting for the Clinton and Sanders teams to decide timing and locations. Clinton campaign officials say they are waiting to hear from the DNC. And Sanders aides say they just want to make sure the debates happen.Team Sanders wants to hold the next debate in New York, a delegate-rich state that will hold its primary on April 19. The Clinton camp has declined, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager Jeff Weaver said, and has advocated for a debate in Pennsylvania, where primary voters will go to the polls on April 26.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Election 2016: Washington and Alaska Democrats Gather for Caucuses; Three western states give Bernie Sanders a chance to close the gap with Hillary Clinton
article text: Democratic voters caucusing in Washington, Alaska and Hawaii on Saturday give Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders a chance to pick up more state wins and modestly close the gap with front-runner Hillary Clinton in the delegate race.His impressive wins over front-runner Hillary Clinton in Idaho and Utah showed strength in Western states with small Hispanic or African-American populations, blocs where Mrs. Clinton tends to dominate. Another advantage for Mr. Sanders: Saturday's contests are caucuses, not primaries--and he's won seven of nine caucuses so far.But the results of Saturday's caucuses, which had already begun in Washington and Alaska and were to convene later in Hawaii, are difficult to predict because they include some wrinkles in the demographic and geographic sense. Hawaii's population is more than one-third Asian-American, along with sizable white and native Hawaiian populations. Alaska is almost 15% Native American. And within the states there are wide demographic differences at the county level that may yield different results.There also has been little opinion polling ahead of the races.Here's a look at the factors and places to watch in each state.WashingtonThere will be 101 delegates on the line, but most interesting are the demographic questions Washington presents Saturday. It holds a mix of educated young white voters, which are a strength for Mr. Sanders, but it also has dense, populous counties, which have been good to Mrs. Clinton. In the 2012 general election, every county in the state voted for Barack Obama.Read More on Capital Journal* Cruz Gets More Delegates in State He Lost* How Trump's Hard Line on Trade Could Backfire* Democratic Presidential Contest Sparks Tensions on College CampusesKing County, home to more than two million people, will be a bellwether, because it holds the state's largest city, Seattle, and the University of Washington, the state's largest university. The question is whether it votes more like a big city or more like a college town. If it does the latter, Mr. Sanders is likely in for a very big day. One other big campus, Microsoft's, is based here. Mr. Sanders has become a favorite of the tech industry.Snohomish and Pierce counties are the big suburban counties to the north and south of King. Mrs. Clinton likely needs to do well in them if she wants a decent delegate total out of the state. These kinds of counties have generally been good for her, but Snohomish and Pierce have younger populations and the strong tech presence in them could be a challenge for her.Yakima and Grant counties both have large Hispanic populations, each is 40% or more Hispanic. Up to now, Mr. Sanders has largely struggled in such places. Washington offers him a chance to show that he can break through in some Hispanic communities. These two counties will be a test. If Mrs. Clinton wins here, it's a sign her strength with these voters carries to different states.HawaiiIt will proportionally award 25 delegates on Saturday and it went overwhelmingly for Mr. Obama in 2008. He won more than 75% of the vote in every county of his home state, which makes it difficult to get a read on for 2016. While neither Mr. Sanders nor Mrs. Clinton have particularly strong ties to the state, many analysts assume the Vermont senator will do well here because of the state's relatively small African-American and Hispanic populations. It is also one of the most politically liberal states in the union.Honolulu County is the most densely populated in the island chain, holding 70% of its population, and is home to the state capital. If trends from other states hold, that should be a positive for Mrs. Clinton. But Honolulu isn't like other big city counties. It's remarkably diverse, less than 20% of its population is white, non-Hispanic, but the core of its diversity is an enormous Asian-American population. More than 40% of the population is Asian.Considering the primary in California, another state with a large Asian population, is still to come, the vote out of Honolulu could be revealing.AlaskaIt will proportionally award 16 delegates on Saturday, the fewest of the three contests. It doesn't have large African-American or Hispanic populations, which should favor Mr. Sanders. In 2008, the state gave Mr. Obama a huge win, while Mrs. Clinton won less than 25% of the vote. The Clinton team, hoping to prevent those kinds of numbers, has opened a campaign office in Anchorage.Getting a read on the geography of the vote in Alaska will be difficult. Results in Alaska aren't reported by county, but rather by state districts.Write to Dante Chinni at Dante.Chinni@wsj.comCredit: By Dante Chinni

article name: Democratic Presidential Contest Sparks Tensions on College Campuses; Pro-Sanders coalition and smaller group backing Clinton remain deeply at odds at some colleges
article text: Morgan Johnson, a founder of "Buckeyes for Bernie" at Ohio State University, recently received an unwanted invitation from other college Democrats. The pitch to Bernie Sanders supporters: Come on over to Camp Clinton."They are already trying to facilitate what they're calling a 'unity talk,'" said Ms. Johnson, a 21-year-old junior. "I can guarantee that the majority of our supporters--we're not yet interested."Indeed, while Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has a considerable lead in the contest for delegates, Mr. Sanders's army of campus supporters is holding firm. The Vermont senator himself has said he is staying in the race through the Democratic National Convention in July.Meanwhile, the two contingents of young, primarily first-time voters--the larger pro-Sanders coalition versus the smaller pro-Clinton group--remain deeply at odds at some colleges."I definitely feel very, very outnumbered," said Chloe Atwater, 20, a Clinton supporter who is vice president of the University of Kentucky College Democrats. Ms. Atwater, a junior, said she gets in frequent verbal showdowns with Sanders supporters. "I feel like the culture has reached a fever pitch," she said.The tension is arising partly because while Mrs. Clinton is the front-runner nationally, Mr. Sanders consistently wins among the youngest voters. And Mr. Sanders's youth base could be valuable to the Democratic nominee, whoever that is, in November. By 2012, when President Barack Obama won his second term, 18- to 29-year-olds had grown to 19% of the turnout.Mrs. Clinton has won 57.7% of the vote overall, but only 29.1% of the vote among ages 17-29, according to new data from the Republican polling firm Public Opinion Strategies, which aggregated all the exit polls where possible so far. The former Secretary of State leads among older voters.The numbers are striking given that Mr. Sanders, 74, barely registered among young Democrats in surveys measuring interest in potential presidential candidates last year, said John Della Volpe, director of polling at Harvard University's Institute of Politics. "This is a phenomenon," he said. "There was no conversation a year ago between millennials and Sanders."The Sanders campaign, Mr. Della Volpe said, tapped into several themes that millennials rank as important: integrity, authenticity and fresh ideas.Mr. Sanders's campus supporters also point to the senator's focus on economic inequality and campaign-finance reform, and to his proposal for free tuition at public colleges."There is a millennial draw to that," said Bridget Silha, 19, a student at Michigan State University. But the statewide campus organizer for Sanders supporters said her own health issues and experience with out-of-pocket medical costs also led her to Mr. Sanders. She believes he would better tackle problems like high pharmaceutical prices."He's not going to give up without a fight," she said.The Clinton campaign says it is trying to reach as many students as possible. It said it has more than 100 campus groups, deploys surrogates to engage millennial audiences, and aggressively reaches out on digital media.While campaigning, Mrs. Clinton has directly addressed young voters, telling them that even if they don't support her, she will support them.Mrs. Clinton's campus backers stress her experience and what they see as her more achievable goals, including her college-affordability plan."I've always looked up to her," said Erica Borsack, 21, a Colgate University senior who is co-president of Colgate for Hillary and is particularly concerned about equal pay for women.While rivalries are friendly on some campuses, clashes are breaking out on others as the race goes on.Among Mr. Sander's campus supporters, one perception is that Clinton college supporters are "just voting for her because they think she is going to win," said Elizabeth Lee, 21, a Middlebury College junior and the founder of College Students for Bernie, a national network of about 200 campus organizations.Clinton backers can find themselves on the defensive."The people who Bernie finally woke up and made care about politics feel that they're entitled to go after you," said Kevin Sabo, 24, a Clinton supporter who is also the political director of California College Democrats.Mr. Sabo, a senior at the University of California, Berkeley, said he is concerned about Mr. Sanders's electability but also believes Mrs. Clinton would get more done once in office.He and his housemates, three Sanders supporters and two Clinton backers among them, argued into the morning recently over the race, he said. "It got pretty intense even in my own house," he said.Ms. Lee, the founder of College Students for Bernie, said she believes that most Sanders supporters would eventually support Mrs. Clinton if she is the nominee.But they aren't ceding ground yet."It's very much like we're still competing against each other," she said. "It's not an unequal relationship where they extend their welcome and we'll take them up on it."Dante Chinni contributed to this article.Write to Jennifer Levitz at jennifer.levitz@wsj.comCredit: By Jennifer Levitz

article name: In Campaign 2016, What's Old Is News Again; Clinton and Sanders are stuck in the 1990s. Trump seems very 1980s. Cruz attaches himself to Reagan. Kasich, well, he's Kasich.
article text: American politics rarely switches into reverse gear, generationally speaking, but this election will likely prove an exception, amid so many other departures from normality. On the exit of Marco Rubio (date of birth: May 28, 1971), both parties are primed to nominate candidates who are older than Barack Obama (Aug. 4, 1961) and close to George W. Bush (July 6, 1946). More to the point, the debate has a backward-looking register that does not attest to much reflection about the future.The ancient mariners of the Democratic Party, Hillary Clinton (Oct. 26, 1947) and Bernie Sanders (Sept. 8, 1941), have spent the balance of the campaign litigating the 1990s. The former House representative has assailed the former first lady for Nafta, Wall Street deregulation, welfare reform, the crime bill and other remnants of the era aside from neon leggings and the "Macarena."Mrs. Clinton answered his sniping in a Detroit speech this month. She said the defining U.S. challenge is how to "create the good jobs of the future," and "I don't think we can answer that question by refighting battles from 20 years ago."But then she warned the audience that her ideas "might sound quaint" and spoke affectionately about the union-dominated, corporatist economy of the 1950s. She did also happen to mention the '90s, twice, when "the typical family's income rose by $10,000. Some of you remember that."Perhaps the only historical period the Democrats don't want to dissect is the past decade. They repudiate the economic results of Mr. Obama's governance but not his policies, so the post-2008 years are an awkward subject. But voters have been as drawn to a 74-year-old socialist as they've been underwhelmed by the charismatic Mr. Rubio's "new American century" because their prospects seem so diminished.Mrs. Clinton recently got in trouble for a gaffe about Nancy Reagan and AIDS, which recalled the 1980s, the decade when the political character of Donald Trump (June 14, 1946)--and his taste--was formed. He's trailed by the ghosts of the past: Leona Helmsley, Le Club restaurant, Spy magazine, the 2004 Israeli Day Parade, Roy Cohn, "Fat Tony" Salerno.Mr. Trump says he will make America great again--an inherently nostalgic slogan. For the businessman and his followers, the modern economy isn't an opportunity but a disaster, and he promises to revert to the 20th-century model."I love the old days, you know," Mr. Trump said in February in Las Vegas. "You know what I hate? There's a guy, totally disruptive, throwing punches. We're not allowed to punch back anymore. I love the old days. You know what they used to do to guys like that when they were in a place like this? They'd be carried out on a stretcher."Meanwhile, the political class is helpless to make sense of such statements, or Mr. Trump's rise, without the crutch of historical analogies. Mr. Trump is a new George Wallace, or Benito Mussolini, or Charles Lindbergh; he demands Nazi salutes; the year is 1968, or 1939, or even 1914.Ted Cruz (Dec. 22, 1970) is a younger man selling an older man's agenda, namely, the one that belonged to Ronald Reagan (Feb. 6, 1911). The Texas senator often talks about "the children of Reagan," and he doesn't mean Maureen, Michael, Patti and Ron--his universal solvent for any problem is to ask: WWRD? But the Gipper, himself, didn't appeal to the authority of, say, Chester A. Arthur (Oct. 5, 1829).John Kasich (May 13, 1952) can't go three sentences without mentioning his 1983-2001 tour in the House and his 2011-present Ohio governorship. "I've done it twice, folks. I'll do it thrice for the United States of America," he frequently says. Mr. Kasich is also fond, for reasons known only to him, of name-dropping forgotten political relics like Tim Penny, Trent Lott and Bono.Of course, potential presidents are supposed to talk about what they have achieved in a lower office, such as governor. All campaigns must inevitably dredge through former times, or at least they used to when voters more highly valued experience and qualifications.And yet. Both parties are converging on tribunes who would become a septuagenarian in the White House. When politics assumes such a retrospective and sentimental cast, and so many liberals and conservatives pine for the recovery of a lost order, weird things happen.Mr. Rago is a member of the Journal's editorial board.Credit: By Joseph Rago

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Keeps Up Heat on Clinton
article text: PORTLAND, Maine -- Sen. Bernie Sanders and his top aides showed no sign they would dial back their harsh words for Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton on Wednesday, and promised to press ahead in the face of her growing delegate lead.At a rally here ahead of Maine's caucuses this Sunday, Mr. Sanders pressed Mrs. Clinton to release transcripts of her paid speeches to Wall Street firms and mocked the idea that anything she said could have been worth the six-figure speaking fees she collected. He also reminded his audience that Mrs. Clinton once had been considered "the inevitable nominee.""Guess what? She's not so inevitable today," he said. He celebrated the four states he won in voting on Tuesday without mentioning the seven states -- most of them much bigger -- that she carried.Mr. Sanders has the money to press on as long as he wants, though Democrats may grow impatient with him out of fear that he will damage the woman who may ultimately represent them in November."Given the current trajectory, there may come a point when he will have to make a judgment about whether he can still win and how aggressively on the attack he wants to be if he can't," said David Axelrod, who helped steer President Barack Obama's two victories.The Clinton campaign argued the contest was fast growing out of Mr. Sanders's reach. After Tuesday's voting, her lead among delegates chosen by voters grew to nearly 200, a bigger margin than Mr. Obama ever enjoyed in his 2008 battle for the nomination against Mrs. Clinton."Over the upcoming weeks, we intend to steadily add to Hillary Clinton's already sizable lead in delegates, and as we do, it will become harder and harder mathematically for Sen. Sanders to ever catch up," Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook wrote in a "state of the race" memo.After Tuesday's voting, Mrs. Clinton was assured of at least 581 pledged delegates, who are chosen by voters, with Mr. Sanders claiming at least 388. The Mook memo contrasts Mr. Sanders's biggest win in his home state of Vermont, where he netted 16 delegates, to Mrs. Clinton's biggest victory of the night, in Texas, where she took 78.Mrs. Clinton also has a huge lead among super delegates, party leaders who can vote for anyone. When those are included, her total tops 1,000, almost halfway to the number needed to clinch.Tad Devine, a senior strategist for Mr. Sanders, said their campaign would make up ground as the race shifts to states with more favorable demographics. Mrs. Clinton's blow-out wins across the South were built on strong support from African-American voters, whereas coming states have larger share of white voters, who support Mr. Sanders in greater numbers.However, after losing the white vote in Nevada, Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday rebounded, capturing 57% of the white vote in Virginia and essentially tying with Mr. Sanders among white voters in Massachusetts. She also won the white vote in Tennessee and Georgia.Mr. Sanders's next opportunity comes this weekend with caucuses in Nebraska and Kansas, as well as Maine. He is also targeting Michigan's primary on Tuesday."We have to win a lot of places, beginning this weekend, and that's what we intend to do," Mr. Devine said.Mr. Mook wrote that Mr. Sanders may win in the weekend's caucuses, but said Mrs. Clinton will more than make up any deficit with a victory in Louisiana, which votes Saturday. If Mr. Sanders wins in Michigan on Tuesday, Mr. Mook said, Mrs. Clinton will offset that with a bigger win in Mississippi, whose primary is the same day."The end result is that Sen. Sanders will spend millions of dollars in Michigan but not make any net gain in pledged delegates because he isn't competing in states like Mississippi," Mr. Mook predicted.But if the race was all but over, it wasn't obvious in Maine, where a line of Sanders supporters snaked for blocks along downtown streets in near-freezing weather waiting to crowd into a local theater to hear him speak."The states that are coming up are lot more favorable than some of the ones on Super Tuesday, and he has a really good shot," said Evan O'Day-Senior, 30 years old.The crowd numbered 2,400, though almost all the faces were white, a sign Mr. Sanders is still struggling to expand his coalition despite his campaign's promises, repeated on Wednesday, to do just that.Given Mrs. Clinton's advantage, some Democrats were itching for Mr. Sanders to tone down his attacks. "If his goal is to simply deliver a message, he should think twice before criticizing the likely nominee who is on the verge of entering what promises to be a brutal general election campaign that will require Democrats to be unified," said Democratic strategist Ben Labolt, a former Obama aide.Sanders aides explicitly rejected any suggestion that he is a "message candidate," and the senator showed no signs of toning down his criticism.Credit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Sanders's Free Tuition Failed Cost Test in Past
article text: WASHINGTON -- Eighteen-year-old Bernie Sanders didn't pay tuition for his freshman year at Brooklyn College in 1959, nor did another 8,000 undergraduates.New York City's public colleges didn't charge tuition back then for students who attended full-time during the day. Students at University of California campuses and a number of other colleges around the country had a similar deal. Although free tuition helped tens of thousands of working-class students afford bachelor degrees, the policy was eventually scrapped as costs escalated.Now, Mr. Sanders wants to reinstate free tuition, but on a scale that dwarfs anything before. Public colleges should be like public high schools, the Vermont Democrat argues: no charge for instruction.The tuition proposal is one of the reasons Mr. Sanders's presidential bid has a big following on campuses, though his plan has been derided by his opponents as pie-in-the-sky or wasteful. Earlier this month, the campaign of Democratic rival Hillary Clinton put out a press release headlined "Millionaires don't need free college." She said any tuition assistance should be targeted to the poor or middle class.A look at the history of the free-tuition movement gives a sense of what is politically feasible today, as families struggle with $1.2 trillion of student debt. Free-tuition colleges flourished at a time when student enrollment was small.Not charging for instruction was less a matter of ideology than practicality, say historians. As the industrial revolution reshaped 19th and early 20th century America, city and state legislatures sought to increase the number of teachers, engineers, agricultural experts and others who could help local industries and farms.The University of California dates to 1868 and initially focused on agriculture, mining and medicine. The City University of New York started as the Free Academy of New York in 1849, which educated immigrants, and morphed into a broader university. For many years, the State University of New York's "normal" schools, which trained future teachers, also didn't charge tuition.Even those state colleges that had tuition charged minimal amounts. In 1933, the average in-state undergraduate tuition, plus fees, was about $1,100 in today's dollars, according estimates by Harvard University economists Claudia Goldin and Lawrence Katz.State colleges could charge so little because relatively few people went to college. In 1959, when Mr. Sanders studied at Brooklyn College, 2.2 million students attended public colleges nationally, the Education Department estimates. Enrollment now is 15.3 million. The cost of educating so many more students outstripped the willingness -- or ability -- of legislatures to pay the tab.The City University of New York started charging for tuition in 1976 after the city teetered on the brink of bankruptcy, and the university ran out of money.In both New York and California, free tuition packed a powerful political punch and was only discarded under economic duress. Even during New York City's financial crisis, the city initially rejected termination of free tuition, wrote Judith Glazer Raymo, an emeritus professor at Long Island University, in a history of free tuition.That broad base of support is a big reason Mr. Sanders wants universal free tuition at state schools instead of targeting middle- and lower-income students. Think of Social Security, said Warren Gunnels, Mr. Sanders's policy director.If you limit the program, "after a while, people complain that it's just a welfare program" and political support evaporates, he said.But making the program universal drives up costs, which the Sanders campaign estimates at $750 billion over 10 years. Mr. Sanders would pay for that by taxing the sales of securities, a plan bound to encounter fierce resistance from Wall Street.Credit: By Bob Davis

article name: Politics & Ideas: Bad Math for Cruz and Sanders
article text: The two most important numbers to emerge from last Saturday's contests are 22 and 27.The former is the percentage of the African-American vote Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders received in losing Nevada's Democratic caucuses by six points to former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton. By contrast, according to the entrance polls, Mr. Sanders split the white vote with Mrs. Clinton.This leaves Mr. Sanders with a large strategic challenge. While African-Americans made up only 13% of caucus-goers in Nevada, they are likely to form more than half of the Democratic primary electorate in South Carolina on Saturday.Following a timely endorsement from South Carolina Rep. James Clyburn, the highest-ranking African-American in the House of Representatives, this crucial bloc of voters appears poised to deliver a solid majority to Mrs. Clinton. And African-Americans make up a substantial share of the Democratic base throughout the South, including 51% in Alabama and Georgia and 48% in Louisiana. Latinos make up about 30% of the Democratic primary vote in Texas and California. But in the other contests between now and mid-March, their share is certain to be much lower.Surprisingly, Mr. Sanders was not able to garner strong majorities among groups where he was expected to do well. Despite his class-based program and strong ideological appeal, he could gain no better than an even split with Mrs. Clinton among caucus-goers without college degrees and with incomes under $50,000. Even among caucus-goers who regard themselves as "very liberal," he won by a narrow margin of 52% to 47%, not nearly enough to counterbalance Mrs. Clinton's 22-point edge among self-styled moderates.Voters who want policies more liberal than President Obama's went for Mr. Sanders by 77% to 21%, compared with the 75% to 22% edge Mrs. Clinton received from voters who want to continue on Mr. Obama's course. Unfortunately for Mr. Sanders, the "let us continue" faction of the party outnumbered its "to the left, march" counterpart by nine percentage points.Unless these dynamics change dramatically in the next few days, the vote in South Carolina, where Mrs. Clinton currently enjoys a double-digit advantage, should restore her standing as the strong front-runner for her party's presidential nomination.The second crucial number -- 27 -- is the percentage of the evangelical vote Texas Sen. Ted Cruz received in South Carolina. This result goes to the heart of Mr. Cruz's meticulously scripted strategy for winning his party's nomination by establishing a dominant position among evangelicals as well as committed conservatives.Mr. Cruz did reasonably well among very conservative primary voters, receiving 35%, ahead of Donald Trump's 29% and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio's 19%. But among evangelical voters, Mr. Cruz lost to Mr. Trump by six points while gaining only a modest advantage over Mr. Rubio. He also lost evangelicals to Mr. Trump in New Hampshire.If this pattern of weak evangelical support continues, it is hard to see Mr. Cruz's path to victory, because his sharply etched profile limits his appeal outside his base. In South Carolina, for example, only 17% of "somewhat conservative" voters and 7% of moderates supported him, and his showing among nonevangelical voters was a meager 13%.And despite his outsider stance since arriving in Washington, he lost to Mr. Trump by a staggering 50 points, 63% to 13%, among the 48% of South Carolina Republicans who want a president from outside the establishment. Even if Mr. Cruz prevails in Texas on March 1, the rationale for his candidacy has been weakened, perhaps fatally.Although Ohio Gov. John Kasich has run a strong, positive campaign, gaining many admirers along the way, he is almost certainly too moderate -- at least as conservatism has been redefined during the past two decades -- to gain a plurality of his party's base.A Quinnipiac poll released Tuesday suggests that Mr. Kasich will be hard-pressed to prevail against Mr. Trump even in his home state of Ohio, where he was re-elected as governor with 64% of the vote in November 2014.If lifelong Republicans are to block Mr. Trump's hostile takeover of their party, former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush's withdrawal from the race leaves them with only one realistic option: Marco Rubio. The question is whether they can coalesce around him in time to stop Mr. Trump, and whether they are willing to undertake the no-holds-barred effort needed to unmask him. We will soon learn if Republican leaders will mount a real fight or meekly surrender.A surprising number of Republicans have told me privately, and some are now saying publicly, that they cannot support Mr. Trump as their party's nominee. Last week, William Kristol, the editor of the conservative magazine the Weekly Standard, floated the possibility of backing an independent conservative candidacy. This would not be the strangest thing to happen in a very strange election year.Credit: By William A. Galston

article name: Hillary & Bernie, Tax Fantasists; Soak-the-rich proposals ignore history and wouldn't raise nearly enough money to fund big spending plans.
article text: Here is a question to ask Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders: What is the best tax rate to impose on high-income earners to ensure there is enough government revenue to pay for your trillion-dollar promises to voters?Perhaps they think it is 83%, a rate that economists Thomas Piketty and Emmanuel Saez hypothesized in 2014 in a widely circulated paper . Or maybe it is 90%, which Sen. Sanders told CNBC last May was not out of the question. "Our job is not to think small," Mr. Sanders elaborated in the Huffington Post a month later. "It is to think big."Progressives have often reminded us that the U.S. had such rates in the past. From 1936 to 1980, the highest federal income-tax rate was never below 70%, and the top rate exceeded 90% from 1951 to 1963. Under Ronald Reagan, the top federal rate declined to 28% by 1988 and has never reached 40% since.The discussion of these rates can easily create the impression that the federal government collected far more money from "the rich" before the Reagan administration. And it can also leave another impression: There would be no downside to raising rates to 1950s levels, given that decade's prosperity.Neither impression would be correct. The effective tax rates actually paid by the highest income earners during the 1950s and early '60s were far lower than the highest marginal rates. Few taxpayers reached the top brackets, the code was rife with loopholes, and capital gains were taxed at much lower rates.In the 1960s, for example, the average rate paid by the top 0.1% of tax filers--the top 10th of the top 1%--ranged from 26.5% to 29.5%, according to a 2007 study by Messrs. Piketty and Saez. Even during the 20 years after the Reagan tax cuts, the top 10th of the top 1% paid an average rate of 23.7% to 33%--essentially the same as in the 1960s. In the decade following 2001, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the average rate for this elite group never exceeded 32%.Nostalgia aside for a world that never existed, few people paid the top tax rates of the 1950s and early 1960s. Of course, when they did, the top marginal rates applied only to income above a very high threshold. The top ordinary income rate married couples faced in 1960, 91%, applied only to income above $2.5 million in today's dollars.Suppose a President Clinton or Sanders tried to raise effective tax rates paid by a significant number of upper-income earners through very high top rates. What then? Real damage, according to Mr. Piketty. In a 2009 debate with the Cato Institute's Chris Edwards in the Economist, Mr. Piketty said, "I firmly believe, that imposing a 70% or 80% marginal rate on large segments of the population (say, 25% of the population, or even 10%, or even a few percentage points) would lead to an economic disaster." In other words, sayonara increased tax revenue.Even without disaster, however, it is unclear whether higher rates on the upper echelons of the top 1% would bring in more revenue. I've compared the Piketty-Saez estimates of average federal income-tax rates paid by the top 10th of the top 1% with the revenue collected at the federal level from the same group. The result? From the mid-1960s through the '80s, trends in the average tax rates paid at the top compared with their tax revenues are mirror images. When average tax rates went up from 27.6% in 1965 to 34% in 1975, revenues went down, from 0.6% to 0.5% of the sum of GDP plus capital gains. When average tax rates declined to 23.7% over the second half of the 1970s and the '80s, tax revenues from the top went up, reaching 0.8% of GDP plus capital gains in 1990.This makes intuitive sense. Of all Americans, it is the wealthy who are more likely to take advantage of legal ways to reduce their payments when rates rise. Plus, their work and investment decisions are more sensitive to the after-tax payoff.Admittedly, in the early 1990s, Presidents George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton raised average tax rates at the top, and revenue from the top 0.1% eventually skyrocketed. But the flood of revenue overwhelmingly reflected not the increase in rates but the stock market's takeoff beginning in late 1994, which resulted in a corresponding rise in income from capital gains and stock options.Consider: If the higher top tax rates had caused the growth in revenue, then revenues should have fallen when Mr. Clinton cut the top tax rate on capital gains to 20% from 28% in 1997. But revenues from the top 0.1% kept pouring in.Proposals to soak the rich by raising their tax rates are unlikely to yield the revenue windfall that Mr. Sanders or Mrs. Clinton are dangling before voters. Leveling with the American people means either scaling back their agendas or admitting that they will have to raise the money from tax hikes on middle-class voters.Mr. Winship is a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.Credit: By Scott Winship

article name: Candidates' Zero-Sum Worldview Is Wrong; Trump and Sanders also must share a degree of hubris that makes them believe that they can perform better in a zero-sum world than any predecessor.
article text: Paul Rubin addresses "The Zero-Sum Worlds of Trump and Sanders " (op-ed, March 21) that underpins their policy proposals and reflects an odd intellectual kinship. Both candidates view economic matters in a win-lose framework where macro factors such as jobs or wealth are fixed rather than dynamic. Donald Trump aims to make America great again by adopting mercantilist protectionist measures (antitrade or anti-immigrant) that invariably backfire, while Sen. Bernie Sanders aims to make America a more just nation by adopting socialist income-redistribution schemes that invariably fail.Given the consistently dismal historical records of mercantilism and socialism in recent centuries, Messrs. Trump and Sanders also must share a degree of hubris that makes them believe that they can perform better in a zero-sum world than any predecessor. Mr. Rubin mentions just a few of the variables and feedback loops that complicate the web of connections between higher tax rates and individual work effort or between higher trade barriers and consumer prices. There are hundreds of millions of workers, consumers and taxpayers making decisions that can override or magnify the top-down directives of Mr. Trump or Sen. Sanders. Although Sen. Sanders comes across as much humbler than Mr. Trump, there is an underlying assumption in his zero-sum world that he can oversee the bureaucratic forces and technical experts who will make top-down resource decisions that are far superior to billions of individual bottom-up decisions.A simplistic zero-sum worldview is dangerous, but it takes an unhealthy dose of leadership hubris to maximize its destructive power.Gary DanielsSarasota, Fla.Mr. Rubin incorrectly attributes zero-sum thinking to Messrs. Trump and Sanders. Instead, he should consider their approach to the rule of law. Mr. Trump insists that our country is the property of its legal citizens. He insists that people obey the law on immigration, entitlements, identity theft and fraud, and he insists that other countries must accept our trade as we do theirs. He will build a wall to keep people out. Mr. Sanders denies property rights like Lenin, Stalin, Mao, Castro and Chávez before him, and he consciously intends to repeat their mistakes. Like his predecessors, he will have to build a wall to keep people in.Bart BesselingFoster City, Calif.Prof. Rubin and his fellow economists too often identify what is easy to measure. But what may matter the most to most Americans isn't so easy to measure: the cost to a family whose breadwinner is unable to work full-time or at all, of having to train your newly arrived foreign replacement for your own job, the trauma of having a loved one murdered or raped by an illegal who was allowed to remain here after being processed for a violent crime or a terrorist attack facilitated by our open borders. Most important, how do such costs affect our unique American culture? There are no benefits to measure, with costs too painful to consider.Martin GansKentfield, Calif.

article name: Sanders vs. the Machine
article text: The voters finally get their first say in Iowa on Monday, and thank heaven. We'll finally be able to count votes for the presidential nominations, rather than dissect polls that have been notably inaccurate in recent elections.The Republican caucuses will test whether Donald Trump can translate his large crowds and celebrity into actual voters who will sit in a cold gymnasium for hours; whether the Christian right has the clout to deliver the victory that Ted Cruz has long predicted; or whether Marco Rubio's recent momentum will make him the leading alternative to the top two heading into New Hampshire next week. In any event the Iowa vote won't come close to deciding the GOP nominee.The Iowa stakes are far higher for the Democrats because Bernie Sanders needs to win to show he can be a viable national candidate. The Vermont socialist has been getting plenty of media attention, and his fund raising from small donors has been impressive, including $20 million in January. His campaign says 1.3 million people have made 3.25 million donations to the Sanders campaign, which speaks to his populist appeal on the political left.His problem is that while the Republican "establishment" is largely a fiction, there really is a Democratic establishment -- and it's lined up for Hillary Clinton. This Democratic machine includes public unions, especially the teachers who endorsed Mrs. Clinton much earlier than they normally do. It includes the lobbies of the cultural left, such as Planned Parenthood that has endorsed Mrs. Clinton despite Mr. Sanders' progressive bona fides. It even includes President Obama, who publicly tilted to Mrs. Clinton in a Politico interview only days before the Iowa voting.This machine is all coming together in Iowa to knock Mr. Sanders out in the first round. Even if he wins next week in New Hampshire, an Iowa defeat will show how hard it would be for Mr. Sanders' idealistic irregulars to beat the Democratic machine in the rest of the country. But if he does win in Iowa, it will be a bigger upset than anything on the Republican side.

article name: Poll: Clinton, Trump Lead in N.Y. Primaries; Both Clinton and Sanders would beat any GOP candidate in the state in November, poll shows
article text: Democrat Hillary Clinton and Republican Donald Trump have significant leads ahead of the primaries in their home state of New York next month, a poll released Thursday showed.Mrs. Clinton, a former U.S. senator from New York, tops her Democratic rival, U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont, 54% to 42% among likely Democratic primary voters, according to the Quinnipiac University poll.Related Coverage* Read Full Poll Results* Presidential Candidates Converge in New YorkMr. Trump, a Manhattan real-estate developer, leads with 56% among likely GOP primary voters, followed by Sen. Ted Cruz of Texas with 20% and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio with 19%, the poll showed."The home-court advantage helps both party's front-runners in the presidential primaries in New York," said Maurice Carroll, assistant director of the Quinnipiac University Poll.New York's primaries will be held April 19.Among Democrats, women favored Mrs. Clinton over Mr. Sanders, while white primary voters were divided with 48% for Mrs. Clinton and 47% for Mr. Sanders. Mrs. Clinton continues to dominate Mr. Sanders with black voters, beating him 66% to 31% in the state.We Want to Hear From YouHave something to say about an article in Greater New York? Email us, along with your contact information, at gnyltrs@wsj.com . Letters will be edited for brevity and clarity. Please include your city and state.In the GOP, Mr. Trump holds double-digit leads among both genders.The poll found both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders would beat any of the Republican candidates in the November general election.Quinnipiac surveyed 693 likely Democratic primary voters and 457 likely GOP primary voters. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3.7 percentage points on the Democratic side and plus or minus 4.6 percentage points on the Republican side.Write to Zolan Kanno-Youngs at Zolan.Kanno-Youngs@wsj.comCredit: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs

article name: Bernie Sanders Targets Hillary Clinton's Superdelegates; Campaign team hopes to spread doubt about rival's electability
article text: If you lose a state but never really tried to win it, should it count as a loss?The Bernie Sanders campaign, trailing Hillary Clinton in delegates, is trotting out alternatives for scoring the race for the Democratic nomination. Don't focus so much on the states Mr. Sanders largely ceded to the former secretary of state; look at the states where he fought hard, his aides are saying.By that standard, the Sanders team believes he is doing much better than the delegate count would suggest. As it stands now, Mrs. Clinton is leading in pledged delegates 1,243 to 980. When superdelegates are thrown in, her lead grows to 1,712 to 1,011.Recognizing that Mrs. Clinton had huge advantages in Southern states on Super Tuesday, March 1, the Sanders campaign says it largely wrote them off. Instead, the campaign focused its energies on more promising states--Minnesota, Colorado and Oklahoma, among them--in hopes of notching some victories and showing Mrs. Clinton was beatable."Those eight states where we didn't compete on Super Tuesday have resulted in almost all of her pledged delegate advantage right now," Sanders senior strategist Tad Devine told reporters this week in a conference call.When Mr. Sanders competes with her head-to-head, he does better, Mr. Devine said. "We have a very good chance of beating her in every single place where we compete with her," he said.A problem with that argument is that the race comes down to who has the 2,383 delegates needed to clinch the nomination, not who scored the most impressive or surprising wins.But Sanders advisers hope their reasoning will make an impression on superdelegates: the party leaders and elected officials who are free to support whomever they choose. The idea is if Mr. Sanders can spread doubt among superdelegates about Mrs. Clinton's electability and persuade them he is the one with the momentum, then perhaps they'll abandon Mrs. Clinton.Sanders supporters are frustrated by the delegate math. Having come from nowhere, Mr. Sanders is now on a roll. He won landslide victories last week in Hawaii, Washington and Alaska. Next week is the Wisconsin primary and the Clinton campaign seems to be bracing for another loss. Mrs. Clinton flew home from Wisconsin on Tuesday night to campaign in New York.But unless Mrs. Clinton loses handily in some of the delegate-rich states coming up--New York, California, Pennsylvania and New Jersey--she'll remain on a glide path to the nomination.Eight years ago, Mrs. Clinton found herself in the same position as Mr. Sanders. Powered by huge support among black voters, then-Sen. Barack Obama rolled up a lead that he never relinquished. Much like the Sanders campaign is doing now, the Clinton campaign in 2008 questioned Mr. Obama's electability and made the case to superdelegates that she was the safer bet.Still, the Clinton campaign is having none of Mr. Sanders's argument. After the Sanders campaign conference call, Clinton aide Jesse Ferguson tweeted: "Summary of Sanders spin today: Voters only count for real or mean anything when they vote for Sanders."Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: The Trump-Sanders China Syndrome; The charge of currency manipulation was always off-base, but now it's starting to look ludicrous.
article text: Presidential candidates Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, with a phalanx of lawmakers behind them, continue to bash China as a "currency manipulator." Both men claim that Beijing is engaged in a permanent strategy to keep the yuan weak and prop up its trade surplus. But the reality was never that simple, and the charge is ludicrous at present.Beijing began pegging its currency to the U.S. dollar over two decades ago, as part of its plan to integrate the Chinese economy into a global marketplace in which transactions were overwhelmingly priced in dollars. It stuck by this strategy even during the height of the Asian financial crisis, in 1998, when much of the world was expecting it to devalue. This earned it great praise from the U.S. government. "China, by maintaining its exchange rate policy," pronounced President Clinton's Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, "has been an important island of stability in a turbulent region."But once market pressures reversed, and capital began flowing into China, U.S. lawmakers suddenly decided that currency stability was bad: They wanted the yuan to rise, while China continued to keep it fixed. In a 2006 op-ed for this newspaper, Sens. Charles Schumer and Lindsey Graham declared that "one of the fundamental tenets of free trade is that currencies should float." Such a tenet, remarkably, was unknown to either Adam Smith or John Maynard Keynes, neither of whom ever supported any such thing.Fast forward to 2016, and capital is now flowing out of China at a prodigious rate. In an effort to slow the resulting fall in its currency, China's central bank has been selling vast amounts of dollars and buying up yuan. At $3.2 trillion, China's reserves still seem enormous. But they are down $790 billion from their 2014 peak, and $325 billion in the past four months.At this pace of decline, China's reserves will fall to $2.8 trillion in July. To put this in perspective, China, using the International Monetary Fund's framework for reserve-adequacy measurement, needs to hold between $2.8 trillion and $4.2 trillion in reserves to safeguard against a balance-of-payments crisis. Once reserves fall below an adequate precautionary level, China is at risk of being unable to pay for essential imports or its dollar debts. The IMF estimate could be overly cautious, given China's relatively low level of external debt, but it could also be too sanguine in that some significant portion of China's reserves, estimated to be around a third, is believed to be tied up in nonliquid assets--and unavailable in a crisis. These include China's capital commitment to the new Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.So what can China do to stanch the rapid decline in reserves?The country has for years been pursuing what has been called the "Impossible Trinity": controlling interest and exchange rates while leaving the capital account significantly open. Chinese residents are permitted to send up to $50,000 overseas annually and this is enough to allow trillions in outflows. China could impose tighter capital controls to prevent this, as Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda recently urged it to do. This would allow it to operate safely with fewer reserves. The adequate level of precautionary reserves falls to between $1.7 trillion and $2.6 trillion when adjusted for capital controls. But this would put a halt to China's plans to transform the yuan into a major reserve currency--something it will be reluctant to do.China could also raise interest rates, which might encourage capital inflows and discourage outflows, but this would hurt growth in an already sinking economy.Finally, China could let the exchange rate fall significantly, but this would increase the debt burden on Chinese companies. Outstanding dollar credit to Chinese nonfinancial companies is estimated to be around $1 trillion. Too great a fall in the yuan, coupled with slowing economic growth, could precipitate a corporate solvency crisis.That China has no good options, and only a choice among painful ones, reflects the underlying structural problem in the Chinese economy--one that will take many years to fix. The economy was tooled to support grossly overoptimistic expectations of foreign demand for Chinese exports. Retooling it to encourage domestic demand will require time and a willingness by the Chinese government to allow businesses to die so that more promising ones may live.It also shows that American charges that China's currency was massively undervalued were based on the flawed assumption that capital would want, indefinitely, only to get into China and not out. It's a sure bet no one in Washington will be calling for China to float its currency again anytime soon.Mr. Steil is director of international economics at the Council on Foreign Relations and the author of "The Battle of Bretton Woods" (Princeton University Press, 2013). Ms. Smith is an analyst at the council.Credit: By Benn Steil and Emma Smith

article name: Clinton-Sanders Feuding Escalates as Key Contests Loom; Sanders advisers demand Clinton apologize for saying they were 'lying' about money she has gotten from oil and gas industry
article text: SYRACUSE, N.Y.--Feuding between Hillary Clinton and her rival for the Democratic nomination, Bernie Sanders, escalated to new levels this past week, with the Vermont senator's campaign advisers demanding she apologize for saying they were "lying" about money she has gotten from the oil and gas industry.Campaigning nonstop, both candidates are showing flashes of fatigue and impatience as the race barrels toward a series of key contests later this month in the delegate-rich states of New York and Pennsylvania. The sour tone could make it more difficult for the party to unify after the race is settled. A Wall Street Journal-NBC poll last month showed one-third of Sanders supporters can't see themselves voting for Mrs. Clinton in the fall if she becomes the nominee.Mrs. Clinton holds a commanding lead in delegates, but she has lost five of the past six contests, and her campaign concedes she will be hard-pressed to win Wisconsin, where the primary is Tuesday. She is heading back there Saturday after three days of campaigning in New York. Fearing Wisconsin might be a lost cause, her staff once had considered making no more trips to the state and instead focusing on coming contests.An indication of the contest's current tenor came at what began as a routine a campaign stop in Purchase, N.Y., on Thursday that ultimately produced one of the tensest moments Mrs. Clinton has had on the trail.A group of Sanders supporters interrupted her speech, chanting, "If she wins, we lose." As they walked out, Mrs. Clinton said: "The Bernie people came to say that. We're very sorry you're leaving."Later, on the rope line, a Greenpeace organizer asked about her campaign contributions from the fossil-fuel industry. Mrs. Clinton shook her finger at the woman, 26-year-old Eva Resnick-Day, and angrily said: "I am so sick of the Sanders campaign lying about that. I'm sick of it."Ms. Resnick-Day said in an interview she was surprised by Mrs. Clinton's retort. In past encounters with Greenpeace activists, Mrs. Clinton has been cordial in discussing her record, Ms. Resnick-Day said.A Clinton senior adviser, Jennifer Palmieri, said Mrs. Clinton was annoyed because she believed her record had been distorted. She has long supported renewable energy and is not beholden to the fossil-fuels industry, she said."Does it annoy her when people misrepresent her record? It does. And that's what you saw" on the rope line, Ms. Palmieri said.Steve Schmidt, a senior strategist in Republican John McCain's 2008 presidential bid, described Mrs. Clinton's reaction as the sort of "tell" one sees in a poker game--a reflection of Mrs. Clinton's frustration that Mr. Sanders is hanging on."What it shows is Bernie Sanders is getting under her skin," Mr. Schmidt said.Republicans circulated the video in hopes that it would produce a backlash that damages Mrs. Clinton."The finger in the face, hammering away with it, is not a good look, usually, in politics," said Bill Cunningham, a political consultant who has worked for Republicans and Democrats alike.Yet the incident also provided a rare window into the emotions of Mrs. Clinton, who seldom veers off script and has faced criticism for lacking authenticity. Some voters might sympathize with her for a human reaction to what she saw as an unfair attack, other analysts said.Democratic political consultant Steve McMahon, who isn't aligned in the race, said the exchange would only humanize Mrs. Clinton."If you believe your opponent is lying about your record consistently and maliciously, this kind of a reaction is perfectly understandable and perfectly natural," he said.Clinton aides say what money the campaign has gotten from oil and gas interests is largely coming from workers who happen to like the former secretary of state. Employees in the oil and gas industry have donated $307,561 to the Clinton campaign, of a total of $160 million she has raised to date, according to the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics.The industry has given an additional $25,701 to outside groups backing the campaign, which have raised more than $55 million on her behalf. And registered lobbyists with clients in the oil and gas industry have raised more than $600,000.Mr. Sanders's campaign has received $53,760 from oil and gas industry employees.The oil and gas industry is far from Mrs. Clinton's largest backer. Wall Street, for example, has given more than $21 million to her campaign and outside groups supporting her.No apology from the Clinton campaign appears in the works. "Apologize for what? No." Ms. Palmieri said.Erica Orden and Rebecca Ballhaus contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders to Speak at Sharpton Conference in April; The Democratic presidential hopefuls will discuss civil rights issues at the National Action Network event
article text: Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders will speak at the Rev. Al Sharpton's National Action Network conference next month in New York.The two candidates, vying for the Democratic Party's nomination for president, will appear in midtown Manhattan during the second weekend in April to talk about civil rights and criminal-justice issues, among other matters, according to a preliminary schedule for the conference.Mrs. Clinton, the frontrunner, has won among black voters so far, though Mr. Sanders has tried to make inroads by rolling out endorsements and visiting college campuses.President Barack Obama has previously attended the conference but isn't slated to do so this year, according to a preliminary agenda.Mrs. Clinton will speak April 13, while Mr. Sanders will speak two days later, according to the preliminary agenda.Mr. Sanders met with Mr. Sharpton for a tea at Sylvia's restaurant in February; Mrs. Clinton similarly met with him about a week later.Credit: By Josh Dawsey

Bernie Sanders was the victor in Kansas and Nebraska, but front-runner Hillary Clinton took Louisiana's primary

article name: Bernie Sanders's Cash Keeps Flowing; Candidate's $44 million haul from donors in March ensures race will continue for months
article text: Sen. Bernie Sanders continues to rake in contributions for his presidential run despite remaining a clear underdog in the race for the Democratic nomination, all but ensuring his battle with Hillary Clinton will continue for months.Mr. Sanders's latest fundraising haul --$44 million in March--was amassed as his path to the nomination narrowed substantially, leaving him with a daunting deficit in convention delegates. Such a feat amounts to defying political gravity, campaign-finance experts say: When candidates start losing primaries, as Mr. Sanders did during the first half of the month, the flow of donations typically slows significantly.But Mr. Sanders's fundraising has continued apace, fueled largely by small-dollar online donors. Now, after wins in a string of Western states in late March, the Vermont senator hits April with both money and fresh momentum. He holds a narrow lead over Mrs. Clinton for Tuesday's Wisconsin primary, according to a RealClearPolitics average of polls, and the New York primary two weeks later looms as a pivotal showdown.The importance of the New York contest for both campaigns is evident in the haggling this past weekend over where and when the candidates might debate ahead of the April 19 vote.Mr. Sanders's fundraising totals have grown each month this year, hitting $21.3 million in January and $43.5 million in February. Mrs. Clinton hasn't yet released her take from last month, but Mr. Sanders raised more than she did in January and February.Although Mr. Sanders has won five of the past six contests, Mrs. Clinton still holds a commanding lead in delegates that her campaign argues is nearly insurmountable. Mr. Sanders now needs decisive victories in delegate-rich states such as New York, California, Pennsylvania and New Jersey to make up ground, and he may also need to convince party officials known as "superdelegates" to abandon Mrs. Clinton and support him. Absent those outcomes, Mrs. Clinton appears likely to emerge as the Democratic nominee, but Mr. Sanders could make that an expensive proposition.Mr. Sanders "is not suffering the fate that candidates usually suffer when they're running behind," said Lawrence Noble, general counsel at the Campaign Legal Center, a group that aims to reduce the influence of money in politics. "The narrative that it's impossible to beat Hillary Clinton has not stopped [Sanders supporters] because I don't think they believe it," Mr. Noble said.In interviews, many Sanders supporters said they were motivated by the senator's pledges to address income inequality and overhaul the campaign-finance system, and they plan to continue lending financial support until the end. Only 3% of Mr. Sanders's fundraising total has come from donors who have given the legal maximum of $2,700, and many backers have signed up to automatically contribute a modest sum each month.Aislinn Melchior, a professor from Tacoma, Wash., who has made several small contributions, said of Mr. Sanders: "I am willing to do whatever I can to help out his candidacy, even if it's doomed."Kenneth Pennington, digital director for the Sanders campaign, said the senator's supporters understand that building a grass-roots movement doesn't happen overnight."They're in this fight for the long haul," he said. "That means when we win, our supporters respond in large numbers. When we lose, our supporters step up to help us win in the long run."The practical effect of Mr. Sanders's fundraising has been to extend the race, allowing the Vermont senator to continue his campaign likely until the Democratic National Convention in July. With contributions pouring in, Mr. Sanders can afford to match Mrs. Clinton dollar for dollar, forcing the former New York senator and secretary of state to continue to spend heavily on a primary campaign just as she hoped to be pivoting to the general election.Anthony Corrado Jr., professor of government at Colby College in Maine, said it is virtually unprecedented for a candidate who is trailing in the polls this late in the primary season to continue to raise funds at this rate."This is usually the point where you see all the money break toward the front-runner," he said.Perhaps more notable is the fact that Mr. Sanders has built a fundraising juggernaut with a record-setting share of small donations, Mr. Corrado said.President Barack Obama set the high-water marks for attracting small-dollar contributions in 2008 and again in 2012, but Mr. Sanders has raised more money from small donors at this point in the campaign than any previous candidate in history, he said.At the end of February, 56% of Mr. Sanders's fundraising had come from individuals who had contributed a total of $200 or less, Mr. Corrado said. Only 21% of Mrs. Clinton's haul through February came from donors who contributed $200 or less, he said. At the same point in the 2008 cycle, Mr. Obama had raised 28% of his total from those small donors.Clinton campaign officials have said that early in the year, many of their supporters didn't view this as a competitive race or feel a sense of urgency. Josh Schwerin, a Clinton spokesman, said a recent surge in contributions put the campaign over the one-million-donor mark a few weeks ago. Sanders campaign officials said they have received contributions from about two million donors."We've seen tremendous growth in our online grass-roots fundraising over the past few months, with more than half the money we raised in February and March coming in online," Mr. Schwerin said.Despite an increase in online donations, Mrs. Clinton continues to devote a substantial amount of time to closed-door fundraisers, events that take her off the campaign trail. During the past week, she attended a fundraiser in New Jersey, two in Massachusetts, two in New York and another in Illinois.Meantime, more than 94% of Mr. Sanders's fundraising has been done online. For Team Sanders, the key number is $27--the oft-repeated figure that represents the average contribution to his campaign. Campaign-finance reports show thousands of individuals contributing that amount to the senator's cause.Brittany Hodge, a 25-year-old rap musician from Homestead, Fla., has donated a total of $511 to the Sanders campaign in small increments, inspired by campaign email pleas for support."I find myself watching the election coverage and getting really into it, and I'll find myself donating $10 three times in one day," Ms. Hodge said. "Whether he wins or he loses, both of those kind of motivate me to make donations."Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Spar Over Debates; Campaigns say sticking points remain before a deal to meet before the New York primary
article text: Democratic presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders sounded hopeful that they could break an impasse and hold a debate before the New York primary on April 19, though their campaigns made clear Sunday that sticking points remain unresolved."I want it. Look, I'm confident that there will be" a debate, Mrs. Clinton said on NBC. But as the day wore on, a standoff continued.The Sanders campaign said Sunday afternoon that it had accepted an invitation to take part in a prime-time debate next Sunday on NBC. However, the Clinton campaign hasn't agreed to show up.A Clinton spokesman said the former senator and secretary of state is open to two other possibilities: a debate on the cable news channel NY1 on April 14, or on ABC's "Good Morning America" the following day. Mr. Sanders's campaign dislikes both those options.On the night of the 14th, the Sanders campaign says it has a rally planned in New York City and has already gotten the necessary park permits. As for "Good Morning America," the Sanders campaign said it would prefer a prime-time network debate that is bound to draw a larger audience.In an interview with CNN on Sunday, Mr. Sanders said his preference is to debate at a time when "people are going to be watching it," and he added: "I think we can work that out."It hasn't been easy. Earlier in the weekend, a debate looked to be in doubt. The Clinton campaign had issued a statement contending it had offered three possible dates for another debate--and all were rejected by Team Sanders.The Sanders camp replied that one of those dates was Monday, when the NCAA men's basketball championship game would be on and relatively few viewers would be likely to tune in.As the impasse has played out, the Sanders campaign has begun to voice frustration. Sanders media spokesman Michael Briggs said that the Vermont senator was available to debate any day between April 10 and April 13."He looks forward to a debate on any of those nights. Does she really have fundraisers on each of those nights?" Mr. Briggs said in a statement.The candidates have taken part in eight debates thus far and had said they would hold two more--one this month and one in May.Each has a different agenda when it comes to additional debates. Mrs. Clinton holds a commanding lead in convention delegates and has no wish to commit a televised gaffe that might give the Sanders campaign new life.At one point last month it seemed she was prepared to walk away from any more debates. Her campaign manager, Robby Mook, said her priority was campaigning in states that have yet to hold contests.Joel Benenson, a pollster and senior strategist for Mrs. Clinton, has suggested that Mr. Sanders might have to drop his attacks on Mrs. Clinton if there were to be more debates.In an interview Sunday, Mr. Benenson didn't mention any such conditions and expressed optimism that differences would be resolved."I assume they want a debate and we want a debate and it'll get worked out," Mr. Benenson said.He added that "debates have been very good for Hillary Clinton. She loves debating and probably has done more debates than any presidential candidate in history" between her 2008 and 2016 presidential bids.Mrs. Clinton eight years ago was in a position comparable to that of Mr. Sanders now. She was trailing then-Sen. Barack Obama in delegates and was eager for more debates, looking for a game-changing moment.In an interview she gave to a South Dakota newspaper in May 2008--one month before she withdrew from the race--she said a presidential candidate should be willing to debate "anytime, anywhere" given the supreme importance of the job.For the Sanders campaign, a debate isn't of much value if few viewers see it. Trailing in pledged delegates, Mr. Sanders wants the largest possible audience and a forum that might shake up the race and pry so-called superdelegates--party officials who are free to support any candidate--from the Clinton camp.So, an NBC News debate next Sunday would be an attractive forum for the Vermont senator."This is by far the largest possible audience. That's what we want. I hope she does, too," Mr. Briggs said.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas
