article name: Sanders Steps Up Clinton Attacks
article text: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa. -- Sen. Bernie Sanders, closing out his campaign in Iowa, took a strategic gamble in hopes of notching a victory over Hillary Clinton in the state's Democratic caucuses Monday night: He went negative.The Sanders campaign ran a new TV spot that implies Mrs. Clinton is in the pocket of Wall Street. And after refusing to talk about the Democratic front-runner's use of a private email server as secretary of state, Mr. Sanders on Sunday called her email practices a "very serious issue" that could render her unelectable.Similarly, a Clinton campaign that had once ignored the 74-year-old democratic socialist is now casting him as a pie-in-the-sky dreamer whose ideas are utterly impractical."I don't want to over-promise and under-deliver. I'd rather under-promise and over-deliver," she said at a rally here. She added: "I know what it's going to take."This wasn't the way many thought the Democratic primary would conclude before the balloting began.When he jumped in the race in May, Mr. Sanders looked to many Democratic officials like a candidate who wanted a forum to talk about income inequality in America and who didn't really believe he could win. But the Vermont senator's success at raising money and attracting young voters has upended the race. The Sanders campaign announced Sunday it had raised $20 million in January alone.On the eve of the caucuses, Iowa was up for grabs. Given the stakes, both the Clinton and Sanders campaigns are offering some sharp assessments of the opposition.Assessing the new tone, Matthew Dowd, a former strategist to President George W. Bush, said: "It's been ratcheted up. Hillary understands that if she wins Iowa, she basically begins to end the race. Bernie realizes that the whole premise of his race is contingent on winning Iowa, and he's trying to do whatever he possibly can at this point to get over the hump."Spotlighting a vulnerability, Mr. Sanders is making the case that Mrs. Clinton is beholden to Wall Street. Speaking to reporters at a Bloomberg Politics breakfast last week, he mentioned that Mrs. Clinton had just attended a fundraising event at a Philadelphia investment firm."That's how she has raised money throughout her political career," he said. "Millions of dollars from Wall Street and from other very powerful special interests."The combative posture poses risks for Mr. Sanders -- something his team acknowledges. He has pledged to usher in a more uplifting style of politics. He has said he would inspire voters and thus expand turnout on Election Day much as Barack Obama did eight years earlier.Recognizing the potential damage to the Sanders brand, his aides say there are lines he won't cross: He won't air the classic political attack ad complete with ominous music and unflattering pictures of Mrs. Clinton."He's not going to go there; it's not in the cards," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders campaign strategist.So, instead, some of Mr. Sanders's ads leave it to voters to connect the dots. The latest spot features Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and its role in the 2008 financial collapse. No pictures of Mrs. Clinton's face appear in the ad; her name is never mentioned. Yet she is the star.Mrs. Clinton and her husband have a long history of dealings with Goldman. Together, they have collected nearly $3 million in speaking fees from the company since 2005.In the spot, a narrator says that "millions in campaign contributions and speaking fees" enabled Wall Street firms to engage in reckless practices.In an interview with NBC News over the weekend, Mrs. Clinton said her opponent's method is to discredit her through "insinuation and implication.""That's disappointing," she added, "because he's always prided himself on being a candidate, a politician -- he's been in politics a really long time -- not to go negative."As the campaign unfolds Mr. Sanders has flashed increasing irritation at some of the criticism lodged by Team Clinton. Clinton allies have said that Mr. Sanders's socialist views would be exploited by Republicans in a general election.On Sunday, Mr. Sanders tried to turn the tables. Asked by ABC News if he would get "slapped" with the socialist label should he win the party's nomination, he pointed to recent disclosures that top secret information passed through Mrs. Clinton's private email server.Having memorably told Mrs. Clinton in a debate in October that Americans were "sick and tired of hearing about your damn emails," he said Sunday: "Look at the front pages in terms of what Secretary Clinton is getting slapped with."Mrs. Clinton dismissed the latest controversy over her email as an "interagency dispute" that pales next to the larger issues on voters' minds.For all the sparring, both campaigns are also taking pains to put out a positive message. But their core arguments are very different.Mrs. Clinton says that her strength is persevering in the face of setbacks. A biographical video that plays for crowds ahead of her appearances ends with Mrs. Clinton saying, "I don't quit" -- a theme of her campaign since it launched last April. She says she has the experience and stamina to both accomplish her goals and beat the Republican nominee this fall.Mr. Sanders is laying out a broader vision of a country that seeks to overturn a political system that favors the richest Americans.He is calling for a bottom-up "revolution" that will compel Washington officials to act in the interests of a struggling middle class.A huge rally he held Saturday in the college town of Iowa City captured the campaign's mood.As he finished his remarks, the rock band Vampire Weekend took the stage and invoked an optimistic spirit of America at its best.The band played Woody Guthrie's "This Land is Your Land," and were joined by Mr. Sanders and his wife, Jane, who, together with the crowd sang along: "From the redwood forests to the Gulf Stream waters, this land was made for you and me."---Colleen McCain Nelson contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Clinton, Sanders Agree to Brooklyn Debate on April 14 After Protracted Negotiations; Debate date comes five days ahead of New York primary
article text: WASHINGTON--Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton agreed Monday to debate April 14 in Brooklyn, ending protracted and sometimes contentious negotiations about when and where the two Democratic presidential candidates would share a stage.The Clinton and Sanders campaigns had disagreed on details large and small about the next Democratic matchup, with officials from both camps complaining the other was playing games. The two campaigns each proposed and rejected several dates before agreeing on a prime-time debate to be hosted by CNN in partnership with Time Warner Cable News NY1.Read More* Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Spar Over Debates (April 3)* Clinton and Sanders Squabble Over New York Debate Dates (April 2)The ninth Democratic debate will come five days before New York holds its Democratic primary on April 19. Mr. Sanders had pushed for a New York debate, arguing that voters in the delegate-rich state should see the two candidates face off before heading to the polls.Mrs. Clinton had said in recent days that she was confident a debate would be scheduled, and her campaign urged April 14 as an option that should be amenable to both candidates.Mr. Sanders resisted, saying he had a rally planned that evening in New York City and already had secured the necessary park permits. The Vermont senator's campaign celebrated the agreement Monday evening but continued to jab at the former secretary of state.Michael Briggs, Mr. Sanders's spokesman, said in a statement that "it's great for the people of New York that will there will be a debate in Brooklyn, something that the Clinton campaign has long opposed."He added that Mr. Sanders's rally was rescheduled to "accommodate Secretary Clinton's jam-packed, high-dollar, coast-to-coast schedule of fundraisers all over the country."The Clinton campaign didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Clinton, Sanders Spar Over Who Would Be Stronger in General Election; In final pleas to Wisconsin Democrats, candidates issue similar warning: a vote for the other risks defeat in the fall
article text: MILWAUKEE--In final pleas to Wisconsin Democrats, Hillary Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders issued a similar warning: A vote for the other risks defeat in the general-election showdown with Republicans.Campaigning in Wisconsin ahead of Tuesday's primary, both candidates cast themselves as better positioned to win in November.Mrs. Clinton suggested that Mr. Sanders is a gamble--a candidate who is new to the national stage and hasn't endured the scrutiny he would likely face if he were to capture the party nomination."I think we need a nominee who's been tested and vetted already," the former secretary of state said at a Democratic dinner in Milwaukee over the weekend. "For 25 years they've thrown everything they could at me, but I'm still standing."Mr. Sanders said the enthusiasm he has generated on the trail is a recipe for keeping the White House in Democratic hands. Citing polls showing him outpacing Mrs. Clinton in head-to-head matchups with GOP front-runner Donald Trump, Mr. Sanders said in his speech at the dinner: "There is one campaign that has created an enormous amount of excitement and enthusiasm. And that is our campaign."Anticipating a tough night Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton has dropped in and out of Wisconsin in recent days. With 86 pledged delegates awarded proportionally, the state isn't likely to significantly alter the race's trajectory. Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Sanders in pledged delegates by 1,243 to 980, with 21 contests remaining in the Democratic nomination fight.For his part, Mr. Sanders has hunkered down in Wisconsin, hoping for his seventh victory in the last eight contests.Polls show Mr. Sanders with a small lead in the state. Wisconsin is favorable terrain for the Vermont senator, as independents--among whom he typically outperforms Mrs. Clinton--are free to vote in the open primary, giving an edge to Mr. Sanders. Exit polls from Wisconsin's 2008 Democratic primary showed that Mrs. Clinton's most loyal supporters, African-Americans, were only 8% of those who voted."We know it [Wisconsin] is close. We know it's competitive," said Mrs. Clinton's senior strategist and pollster, Joel Benenson, on CNN Monday. "Our goal is to maintain our sizable advantage in pledged delegates."Clinton aides have been skeptical of her spending too much time in the Badger State, particularly with the delegate-rich New York primary coming April 19. A loss in Mrs. Clinton's adopted home state would be an embarrassment she appears determined to avoid. On Monday, she attended an event with New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo celebrating an agreement raising the state's minimum wage in New York City and its suburbs.Mr. Sanders campaigned in Janesville, Wis., where he criticized Mrs. Clinton over her support of free-trade agreements. "I'm not a candidate who goes to the unions, goes to workers and then leaves and goes to a fundraiser with Wall Street," Mr. Sanders said.Seeking to blunt that line of attack, which Mr. Sanders has deployed in the past, Mrs. Clinton in her Milwaukee speech laid out her views on trade, noting she has come out against President Barack Obama's proposed 12-nation deal known as the Trans-Pacific Partnership. "I opposed it because I couldn't look in the eye of any American workers and say this deal will raise your wages," she said.When secretary of state, Mrs. Clinton had a more favorable view of TPP, calling it the "gold standard" of trade deals.The candidates found one area of agreement in the run-up to Tuesday: the state's GOP governor, Scott Walker. Mr. Walker angered Democrats and unions by pushing through measures ending most collective bargaining rights for public employees."If you want to know what kind of president I would be, think about all of the things that Gov. Walker does and I will do exactly the opposite," Mr. Sanders said in Milwaukee.Mrs. Clinton said she would use her clout as a Democratic president to help defeat Mr. Walker should he run for re-election in 2018. "I will have your back against Gov. Walker and the tea party legislature here in Wisconsin," she said at the party dinner.The two candidates also agreed Monday to another debate, on April 14 in New York City, ending protracted and sometimes contentious negotiations about when and where they would share a stage again.The Clinton and Sanders campaigns had disagreed on details large and small about the next Democratic match-up. The two campaigns each proposed and rejected several dates before agreeing on a prime-time debate to be hosted by CNN in partnership with NY1 News.The ninth Democratic debate will come five days before New York holds its Democratic primary.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: New York a Coveted Apple for Sanders, Clinton; A Sanders win would slow Clinton's march to nomination; loss would prove devastating
article text: NEW YORK--A New York primary that once looked like a sure thing for Hillary Clinton looms as a pivotal showdown in the Democratic presidential race, with rival Bernie Sanders hoping to embarrass her in her adopted state with a strong showing that would raise doubts about her electability.Both campaigns see New York as a prize with one of two potential outcomes: A Clinton victory that deprives Mr. Sanders of one of his best remaining chances to cut into her delegate lead, or a Sanders upset that would advance his argument to superdelegates that she is a risky bet in the general election.With 247 delegates up for grabs, New York carries the largest cache of the convention representatives of any state left on the calendar save for California. Mrs. Clinton now leads in pledged delegates by 1,243 to 980. If Mr. Sanders can't come out New York with a heavy majority of the state's delegates, the race effectively would be over, Clinton aides said."There's very little evidence to date of their ability to win the big, diverse states like New York by the type of margin they would truly need to overcome the delegate edge," said Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon.Mindful of the stakes, each candidate figures to compete ahead of the April 19 contest in New York with an intensity not seen since Iowa and New Hampshire. Though the Wisconsin primary is Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton peeled away from the Badger State for three straight days of campaigning in New York that will culminate Friday with a pair of campaign stops in Syracuse.Related* Trump Rivals Jump on Abortion Comments* Kasich's Case for Staying in the RaceHer campaign rolled out a new 30-second TV spot that will air in New York and her husband on Thursday held several rallies in Manhattan. Earlier in the week, Bill Clinton took part in private meetings with African-American and Hispanic leaders who could help boost turnout in minority neighborhoods that favor Mrs. Clinton.One attendee was Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr. In an interview, Mr. Diaz said the meeting with a small group of elected officials and business leaders covered both policy and political strategy. "They're taking New York state seriously. They're not taking anything for granted," he said.Both candidates boast ties to the state that they will highlight in the run-up to the vote. Mrs. Clinton represented New York for eight years in the Senate and owns a home in Chappaqua; Mr. Sanders grew up in the state.At a rally Thursday at the State University of New York at Purchase, in the same county as her home, Mrs. Clinton, said: "It is so good to be home....Westchester is more than a county to me. It's a community where Bill and Chelsea and I moved back in 1999," she said, rattling off some local restaurants she enjoys.At the university event, she had a brief, tense conversation with a Greenpeace activist on the rope line who asked about contributions she's gotten from the fossil fuel industry. Mrs. Clinton, pointing her finger at the woman, said: "I am so sick, I am so sick of the Sanders campaign lying about this.""I was honestly surprised by her reaction today. I wasn't expecting that," said 26-year-old Eva Resnick-Day, who said neither she nor Greenpeace has any affiliation with the Sanders campaign.Appearing in Harlem on Wednesday, Mrs. Clinton showcased her ties to New York officials. She was accompanied at a stop at a cake shop by Rep. Charlie Rangel, who took aim at Mr. Sanders in a conversation with reporters. He congratulated the Vermont senator on making income inequality a priority."Now I need some help as to what else he's made a priority," Mr. Rangel said.Mr. Rangel has been at the center of several ethics controversies over the years. In 2010 President Barack Obama suggested Mr. Rangel retire "with dignity" rather than seek re-election--advice Mr. Rangel didn't take.Mr. Sanders was raised in a 3_ room apartment in Brooklyn and despite having lived in Vermont for decades he has retained his New York accent. His campaign is planning events that will highlight his origins, including trips to his old neighborhood and even the running tracks where he competed as a high school athlete in the 1950s."It's going to be difficult for us to win in her home state. But that's what we're going to try to do," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders strategist. "And I do think that if we can find a way to defeat her it would be a gigantic signal that Hillary Clinton is a weak front-runner."A Quinnipiac University poll released Thursday showed Mrs. Clinton beating Mr. Sanders in the state 54% to 42%. Still, the poll offered some hopeful news for the Vermont senator: New Yorkers seem to like him better.A total of 49% had an unfavorable view of Mrs. Clinton, compared with 45% who viewed her favorably. For Mr. Sanders, 54% had a favorable view, versus only 30% who had a negative opinion of him.Unlike some other states, New York holds a closed Democratic primary, meaning independents can't participate. That's not good for Mr. Sanders. "When he doesn't have the independent voters, it's tougher for him," said Bruce Gyory, a Democratic consultant with no ties to either campaign.Mrs. Clinton may also be helped by the preponderance of women voters, he added. In New York statewide Democratic primaries, women typically constitute 56%-58% of the turnout, with big proportions of those highly educated, relatively affluent and middle-aged. In other states, Mr. Gyory noted, Mr. Sanders hasn't performed as well with women in that demographic as he has with younger women.Colleen McCain Nelson and Thomas MacMillan contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Erica Orden

article name: Wisconsin Voters Challenge Front-Runners; Exit polls show GOP groups swung to Cruz, while Sanders drew on his liberal base
article text: Wisconsin dealt a setback to the presidential campaign's front-runners, Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump, but for different reasons in each party.Democratic voting patterns mirrored those of many prior contests, with Mrs. Clinton building large margins among African-Americans and Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders carrying younger voters, independents and liberals. In a state heavy on liberals and light on minority voters, the voting pool included far more of Mr. Sanders's base voters than traditional Clinton supporters.The Republican story was different: Voting groups that had given only tepid support to Sen. Ted Cruz swung more squarely behind him in Wisconsin, enabling him to overcome Mr. Trump.Mr. Trump, for example, had built big margins in prior contests among lower-income voters and those without college degrees. In Wisconsin, Mr. Cruz narrowly won those groups or tied his top rival, according to surveys of voters as they left their polling places.Mr. Trump had carried self-described conservative voters in Michigan, another big Midwestern state, which he won last month. But in Wisconsin, those voters backed Mr. Cruz, exit polls reported by CNN and other media showed.The Wisconsin exit polls suggested that Mr. Trump may have a growing problem with women. He won only 36% of their vote on Tuesday, while Mr. Cruz captured 48%.Mr. Trump's support among women was actually a slight improvement over the results from two other Midwestern states, Michigan and Ohio. But as the GOP field winnows, a 36% share of women would signal a weakness in his support.Mr. Cruz's 48% share of women in Wisconsin suggests that he may be consolidating support among those voters.Republican voters were asked to weigh in on one of the overriding questions of the GOP primary race: What should happen if no candidate wins a majority of delegates before the party's national convention?Under party rules, the only way to clinch the presidential nomination is to win support from more than half of the 2,472 convention delegates. But more than half of Republican voters in Wisconsin--some 56%--said that if no one meets that standard, then the candidate with the most primary votes should claim the nomination, according to exit polls reported by various media.By contrast, some 42% of Wisconsin Republicans endorsed the party's regular procedures and said the convention delegates should pick whomever they think would be the best nominee.Not surprisingly, supporters of Mr. Trump favored the scenario that would best suit their candidate, as did Mr. Cruz's backers. Mr. Trump's supporters were most likely to say that the candidate with the most primary votes should become the nominee, while Mr. Cruz's supporters were more likely to say that a contested convention should be decided by the delegates.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Think Tank: Political Strategists on What to Watch and What's at Stake in Wisconsin* Trump Faces Great Test Against Wisconsin's Conservative Political Network* Trump Loses Some Self-Confidence on Trail* Politics Counts: Trump, Clinton Margins of Victory Have Declined as Race Progresses* Sanders's Cash Keeps FlowingIn the Democratic race, each candidate drew on familiar voting blocs. Mr. Sanders retained his hold on young voters, carrying 81% of those ages 18 to 29, according to exit polls reported by CNN and other media.Mr. Sanders won 71% of independents who cast ballots in the primary while tying Mrs. Clinton among Democratic Party members. He carried 60% of voters who rated themselves "very liberal."The party's youngest and most liberal voters, as well as independents, have been pillars of Mr. Sanders's support in prior contests.Mrs. Clinton retained her hold on nonwhite voters, particularly African Americans.Those familiar voting patterns left Mrs. Clinton at a disadvantage. She won 74% of black voters, but they accounted for less than a tenth of the electorate--half the share that African-Americans accounted for in Ohio, the Midwestern state that Mrs. Clinton won last month.Some 84% of voters in Wisconsin's Democratic primary were white, exit polls showed, compared with 74% in Ohio.Some 66% of Wisconsin voters described themselves as liberal, a larger share than in 2008, during the last competitive Democratic primary. That year, only 47% rated themselves liberal. The share of Democratic voters calling themselves moderate or conservative fell from 53% to 32% over eight years. Those changes in the party helped Mr. Sanders.Wisconsin's Democratic electorate on Tuesday was also far more liberal than that of two other Midwestern states that voted recently, Michigan and Ohio. In Michigan, which Mr. Sanders won last month, 57% of voters rated themselves as liberal, while 59% of Democratic voters in Ohio called themselves liberal.Credit: By Aaron Zitner and Dante Chinni

article name: Bernie Sanders Notches Victory in Wisconsin Primary; Vermont senator gains further momentum against Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton ahead of New York contest
article text: Bernie Sanders on Tuesday defeated Hillary Clinton in Wisconsin's Democratic primary, extending his recent string of victories and adding momentum heading into a pivotal showdown in two weeks in New York state.The Associated Press declared the Vermont senator the winner less than an hour after the polls closed. With more than 99% of precincts reporting, Mr. Sanders led Mrs. Clinton 56.5% to 43.1%.Speaking at rally in Wyoming--site of a Saturday Democratic caucus--Mr. Sanders told the audience about his solid victory in Wisconsin, prompting chants of "Bernie! Bernie!"He thanked voters in Wisconsin and noted his victories have been coming "with overwhelming, landslide numbers."Read More on Election 2016* Wisconsin Primary: Live Coverage* Clinton, Sanders Agree to Debate Before New York Primary* Trump's Path to the Nomination NarrowsMrs. Clinton didn't make a public appearance but sent out a tweet congratulating Mr. Sanders. "To all the voters and volunteers who poured your hearts into this campaign: Forward!" Mrs. Clinton said.Trailing in pledged convention delegates, Mr. Sanders was hoping a resounding win in Wisconsin would affirm he remains a viable candidate with a chance to wrest the nomination away from Mrs. Clinton, a former New York senator and secretary of state. He has now won seven of the past eight nominating contests, his best stretch since the race began.The Sanders camp now hopes party officials known as "superdelegates" will see these results and conclude he would be the stronger candidate in the November election. Most superdelegates are now backing Mrs. Clinton, but they are free to change their minds at any point and support someone else.At the same time, Mr. Sanders faces daunting delegate math and also more pointed questions about how he would achieve the sweeping goals he has laid out. As Wisconsin voters cast ballots, some prominent Democrats chided him over a recent interview in which he struggled to explain how he would break up large banks.Heading into the Wisconsin primary, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Sanders in pledged delegates by 1,243 to 980. With superdelegates thrown in, her lead stood at 1,712 to 1,011. A total of 2,383 delegates are needed to clinch the nomination.Mr. Sanders has had trouble closing the gap. Democrats award delegates on a proportional basis, making it hard for him to cut into her lead short of blowout victories in big states. Preliminary tallies show he shrank Mrs. Clinton's lead by only 60 delegates after winning six of seven contests before Wisconsin.Polling had shown Mr. Sanders with a small lead in Wisconsin. With its liberal tradition and a format that allows independents to vote in the Democratic primary, the state looked like favorable terrain for Mr. Sanders.Exit polls showed that Mr. Sanders won handily among independents, who comprised more than a quarter of the electorate. Mr. Sanders won 71% of independents; Mrs. Clinton, 28%.Voting patterns from earlier contests held true in Wisconsin. As ever, Mr. Sanders did best with young voters. He won 81% of voters between the ages of 18-29, while Mrs. Clinton won only 17% of that age group.Mr. Sanders won white voters by 58% to 40%. Whites amounted to 84% of the electorate, and African-Americans just 9%--an unfavorable breakdown for a Clinton campaign that relies heavily on minority voters.Clinton aides anticipated a loss and seemed to be focused on New York, which has about three times as many delegates at stake. She campaigned up and down the state last week, and after a quick trip to Wisconsin on Saturday, she left and didn't return. As Wisconsin voters cast ballots, Mrs. Clinton appeared at a town-hall style event in Brooklyn with Chirlane McCray, wife of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio.Mrs. Clinton didn't mention Wisconsin, focusing instead on the next contest and a potential November opponent: Republican Donald Trump."The fellow who's from New York? I wish he'd get out of one of his towers and actually walk the streets," Mrs. Clinton said, addressing a crowd at Brooklyn's Medgar Evers College. "Peddling prejudice and paranoia is not the New York way."Mr. Trump's campaign didn't respond to a request for comment.Mr. Sanders hoped Wisconsin would be a sweet coda to a recent spate of victories. He has now shown he can beat Mrs. Clinton head-to-head whether vying for votes or campaign dollars. In March, Mr. Sanders outraised Mrs. Clinton by nearly $15 million .Having moved from a long-shot candidate to a viable threat to Mrs. Clinton's candidacy, Mr. Sanders's policy stances have gotten more attention. In an interview with New York's Daily News, members of the editorial board questioned him on how precisely he would break up the large banks that he says pose a grave threat to the economy.Mr. Sanders told the editorial board he didn't know if the Federal Reserve has the authority to break up the banks. He added, "I think the administration can have it."Asked later if he was saying the president could "order" the breakup, Mr. Sanders said: "No, I did not say we would order...The president is not a dictator."Mr. Sanders also said the Treasury secretary would determine if certain banks were "too big to fail," and if that was deemed to be the case, "they will be broken up."Mr. Sanders also was asked about a judge's ruling last week that quashed an attempt by federal regulators to label MetLife Inc. "too big to fail."He said, "It's something I have not studied, honestly..."Austan Goolsbee, who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Obama administration and is a Clinton supporter, tweeted Tuesday: "The guy seems clueless on his own #1 issue."Barney Frank, a former Massachusetts congressman and an architect of the Dodd-Frank law imposing stricter financial regulations following the 2008 economic collapse, said the transcript "just reinforces that he hasn't given much thought to this other than banks are bad." Mr. Frank also supports Mrs. Clinton.As in other states, Mr. Sanders drew large, enthusiastic crowds in Wisconsin. He spent election day morning in Milwaukee, having breakfast with the state's former lieutenant governor, Barbara Lawton. Later, he flew to Wyoming for his rally in Laramie.Pat Libecki, 60, who works in a bank, said she voted for Mr. Sanders in Wisconsin."I think we need a change and I liked his answers to the issues that we're having in this country," she said.Colleen McCain Nelson and Erica Orden contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Ted Cruz, Bernie Sanders Get Big Wins in Wisconsin Primaries; Victories assure heated battles all the way to the final primaries in June
article text: MILWAUKEE--Both parties' presidential front-runners lost the Wisconsin primary Tuesday as GOP Sen. Ted Cruz beat Donald Trump and Democratic Sen. Bernie Sanders bested Hillary Clinton, virtually assuring heated battles all the way to the final primaries in June, including California.The results increase the odds that Republicans will have a contested party convention in July and force Mrs. Clinton to fight longer than anyone expected to clinch her party's nomination."Tonight is a turning point. It is a rallying cry," Mr. Cruz told supporters in Milwaukee after he finished ahead of Mr. Trump and Ohio Gov. John Kasich. "We have a choice, a real choice."The GOP result was a hard-won victory for anti-Trump forces who had seen the Wisconsin primary as their last, best hope to slow the front-runner's momentum toward the Republican nomination.Mr. Trump's campaign issued a defiant statement in response to the outcome, saying Mr. Cruz was a tool of an establishment dead set against him."Ted Cruz is worse than a puppet," the statement said. "He is a Trojan horse, being used by the party bosses attempting to steal the nomination from Mr. Trump."The Texas senator's victory followed one of the rockiest weeks of Mr. Trump's campaign. Trailing in the polls and under concerted attack from Republican leaders in the state, Mr. Trump also weathered a series of controversies over abortion and other issues that threatened to undercut his standing with women voters.Wisconsin will award its 18 at-large delegates to Mr. Cruz as the statewide winner. He's likely to also win a vast majority of the 24 delegates divided among the state's eight congressional districts, though district-by-district results weren't yet available.Mr. Cruz's strong showing will make it more difficult for Mr. Trump to wrap up the 1,237 delegates needed for the GOP nomination before the primary season ends on June 7, when California allocates the largest number of delegates.Next up on the GOP calendar is the April 19 primary in New York, Mr. Trump's home state, where polls show him with a commanding lead of more than 30 percentage points over Mr. Cruz, who in some surveys runs behind Ohio Gov. John Kasich.New York awards 95 delegates, most of which are allotted proportionately by congressional district. Mr. Trump plans to campaign on Long Island on Wednesday."Trump has more support than anyone else in New York and always had," said state assemblyman Bill Nojay of Pittsford, in north-central New York. "If the vote was held today, we expect he would win every single congressional district."A week later, a swath of other East Coast states vote--Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island. Mr. Cruz's best hope is in states further ahead in the calendar--Indiana on May 3 and Nebraska on May 10.Wisconsin--with its GOP electorate dominated by the kind of working-class, white voters who have been drawn to Mr. Trump elsewhere--was long seen as fertile ground for the New York businessman. But it turned into a hotbed of anti-Trump sentiment."We have to stop Trump," said Mary Czarra, 65 years old, of Menomonee Falls, who voted for Mr. Cruz even though she preferred Mr. Kasich. "He insulted our governor, for crying out loud. You can't do that if you're a Republican here."Read More on Election 2016* Wisconsin Primary: Live Coverage* Clinton, Sanders Agree to Debate Before New York Primary* Trump's Path to the Nomination NarrowsMr. Cruz was endorsed by Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, still a hero to the state's conservatives even though his 2016 presidential campaign fizzled.Mr. Trump lambasted Mr. Walker and others in the state party establishment who opposed him, and their assault on the front-runner backfired among voters like Jim White, 62, of Milwaukee."I see the GOP fighting this guy all the way, and I don't like it," Mr. White said. "My feeling is this is about to destroy a lot of people; they won't vote ever again if Trump loses."Holding out hope for a come-from-behind victory, Mr. Trump spent the past week stumping across the state, even skipping his grandson's bris Sunday to greet voters at a Milwaukee diner."He cannot downplay the significance of Wisconsin, because he moved here for the final week," said Brian Fraley, a Republican operative based in the Milwaukee suburb of Brookfield. "He went to every corner of the state. He was everywhere and he worked it hard, so he can't say that little Wisconsin didn't mean much. If it didn't mean much, he wouldn't be investing time and energy here."Wisconsin's primary had been seen as a tough test for Mr. Cruz because he has struggled in other Midwestern industrial states including Michigan and Illinois. Most of his victories over Mr. Trump have come in states that hold caucuses--time-consuming events that play to his grass-roots organizational strength. Wisconsin's primary also is open to Democrats and independents, not just registered Republicans.Mr. Trump has done better in open primaries, while Mr. Cruz improves where balloting is limited to the party faithful. But with an equally competitive Democratic race between Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders for their party's nomination, it was unclear if Mr. Trump could pull away cross-party voters.Before Tuesday, Mr. Trump had 737 delegates, Mr. Cruz had 475. Even if Mr. Cruz ended up winning all 42 delegates from Wisconsin, it was unlikely there are enough bound delegates left for him to reach 1,237 before the convention.For Mr. Trump, locking up the nomination during the primary season is possible but increasingly difficult, raising the chances that Republicans will choose their nominee in Cleveland, in a contested convention.Messrs Cruz and Trump have played down suggestions that another candidate would be nominated if the convention deadlocked, and warned that grass-roots Republicans would rebel if that happened.Mark Meckler, a tea-party activist who hasn't endorsed any candidate, agreed. "As for the chatter about a contested convention, if neither Cruz nor Trump are the nominee, the Republican Party will end in a fiery crash and Hillary Clinton will be our next president," he said. "Many in the grass-roots movement say they will simply not vote."The next several primaries are in East Coast states where Republicans are likely to be less receptive to Mr. Cruz's religious, antiestablishment brand of conservatism than they are in Wisconsin."This is the last state in which Ted Cruz has any ability to win a state through the rest of April, and in some of them, he's going to be fighting for second place," said Sarah Huckabee Sanders, a Trump adviser and daughter of former presidential rival Mike Huckabee. "Moving forward, the momentum will all be on Trump's side."In the run-up to Wisconsin, a series of controversies damaged his already-shaky standing among women. He admitted it was a mistake to have retweeted an unflattering photo of Mr. Cruz's wife Heidi. And he offered contradictory responses to questions about the sensitive abortion rights issue.He seemed to be trying to lessen the damage by bringing his wife, Melania, onto the campaign trail on the eve of the Wisconsin primary.Yet his mistakes helped Mr. Cruz pick up the endorsement of the National Right to Life Committee, the leading national antiabortion rights group.After a vote Saturday by its board of directors, the group said: "Sen. Cruz is the only candidate for president who has always been pro-life, who has a 100% pro-life voting record with National Right to Life, who can win the Republican nomination, and who can defeat pro-abortion Hillary Clinton in November."In an MSNBC interview Tuesday, Mr. Trump denied the week has reflected badly on his support for women. "As far as women are concerned, nobody respects women more than I do, not even close," he said.Beth Reinhard contributed to this article.Corrections & Amplifications: Sarah Huckabee Sanders is a Donald Trump campaign adviser and the daughter of former presidential rival Mike Huckabee. An earlier version of this article didn't include her married name. (April 5, 2016)Write to Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.com and Reid J. Epstein at Reid.Epstein@wsj.comCredit: By Janet Hook and Reid J. Epstein

article name: Democratic Superdelegates Pressured to Shift Stance After String of Sanders Wins; Vermont senator's recent victories have left some Democrats defending their decision to back Hillary Clinton at party's convention
article text: Along with his takeout from the vegan chain Native Foods Café, Democratic Rep. Jared Polis of Colorado received this note: "The constituency has spoken. Use your power wisely. Feel the Bern."Mr. Polis, a superdelegate who has endorsed Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton, acknowledged the pressure on him to change his position in a state where Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont handily won the Democratic caucuses. "Even my food takeout is lobbying me for #FeelTheBern," Mr. Polis tweeted late last month.Mr. Sanders's recent victories in Colorado, Hawaii, Washington, Alaska and elsewhere have left some other Democrats defending their decision to back Mrs. Clinton at the party's convention in Philadelphia this July.And more could feel the pressure if Mr. Sanders continues to rack up wins. He won the Wisconsin Democratic presidential primary on Tuesday, according to the Associated Press, notching his seventh win in the last eight nominating contests. Democratic lawmakers in Wisconsin including Rep. Gwen Moore and Sen. Tammy Baldwin backed Mrs. Clinton. All Democratic members of Congress are superdelegates.Sen. Brian Schatz, a Hawaii Democrat who backs Mrs. Clinton, said he has had some "robust conversations" with constituents after Mr. Sanders won the state's Democratic caucuses on March 26, but doesn't plan to shift his stance."A lot of my strongest supporters are on both sides of the presidential campaign, but I have no doubt we'll be able to hang together and come back together during the convention," Mr. Schatz said Monday, adding a vigorous primary would strengthen the process. "I am not one of those people who has great heartburn about a contest going all the way to the convention."As of Monday, Mrs. Clinton was leading the Democratic race in pledged delegates 1,243 to 980. When superdelegates are thrown in, her lead grows: 1,712 to 1,011. A total of 2,383 delegates are needed to clinch the Democratic nomination.Mr. Sanders's campaign has said that those superdelegates--party leaders and elected officials free to back whomever they choose--should pay attention to Mr. Sanders's momentum and abandon Mrs. Clinton."A lot of these superdelegates may rethink their position with Hillary Clinton," Mr. Sanders said on CNN in late March. "I think their own constituents are going to say to them, hey, why don't you support the people of our state, vote for Sanders?"So far, that doesn't seem to be happening. Mrs. Clinton has the backing of far more congressional lawmakers than Mr. Sanders and none have defected after Sanders victories."I am supporting Hillary Clinton and I will continue to do that," Sen. Jeanne Shaheen, a New Hampshire Democrat and superdelegate, said last week in her home state, whose primary Mr. Sanders won in early February.The Clinton campaign has said that the former secretary of state's victories in primaries demonstrate that more Democratic voters support her than Mr. Sanders, whose wins have largely come in caucus states with fewer participants."For most of the campaign, Senator Sanders has criticized the role that superdelegates play in the nominating process, but as he now campaigns without a clear path [to] the nomination that relies on the voters, he's aggressively courting their support," Robby Mook, Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager, said in a memo Monday.Superdelegates supporting Mr. Sanders have occasionally found themselves in the reverse situation. Rep. Raul Grijalva, an Arizona Democrat and co-chairman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, was the first member of Congress to endorse Mr. Sanders. Last month, Mrs. Clinton won the Arizona primary. A superdelegate, Mr. Grijalva is still backing Mr. Sanders.Mr. Grijalva said he isn't facing a backlash from his district over his endorsement, though he has questions about the role of superdelegates. While they remain part of the system, however, Mr. Grijalva said he would continue to support Mr. Sanders. "My resolve is as strong as his, which is to keep going," he said.Write to Kristina Peterson at kristina.peterson@wsj.comCredit: By Kristina Peterson

article name: Bernie Sanders Seeks to Extend Winning Streak With Wisconsin Primary; Rival and front-runner Hillary Clinton appears to be looking ahead to New York's Democratic contest
article text: Bernie Sanders on Tuesday looked to extend his recent string of primary victories with a win in Wisconsin, while his rival Hillary Clinton appeared to be looking ahead to the next Democratic contest in New York.The Vermont senator hoped a victory Tuesday would supply fresh momentum heading into the New York contest, on April 19, and that a resounding-enough win might even persuade party officials known as "superdelegates" that he would be the stronger general-election candidate. But he faced criticism by some Democrats over a recent interview in which he struggled to explain how he would break up large banks and achieve other parts of his ambitious agenda.Polling had shown Mr. Sanders with a small lead in Wisconsin. With its liberal tradition and a format that allows independents to vote in the Democratic primary, the state looked like favorable terrain for Mr. Sanders.Clinton aides anticipated a loss and seemed to be focused on New York, which she represented in the U.S. Senate and which has about three times as many delegates at stake. She campaigned up and down the state last week, and after a quick trip to Wisconsin on Saturday, she left and didn't return. As Wisconsin voters cast ballots, Mrs. Clinton appeared at a town-hall style event in Brooklyn with Chirlane McCray, wife of New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio.Read More on Election 2016* Wisconsin Primary: Live Coverage* Clinton, Sanders Agree to Debate Before New York Primary* Trump's Path to the Nomination NarrowsShe didn't mention Wisconsin, focusing instead on the New York primary and a potential future opponent: Republican presidential front-runner Donald Trump."The fellow who's from New York? I wish he'd get out of one of his towers and actually walk the streets," Mrs. Clinton said, addressing a crowd at Medgar Evers College. "Peddling prejudice and paranoia is not the New York way."Mr. Trump's campaign didn't immediately respond to a request for comment.However treacherous the path forward might be, Wisconsin stood to be a sweet coda to what has been Mr. Sanders's most successful stretch since the race began. A victory in Wisconsin would give Mr. Sanders victories in seven of the last eight contests. Though he trails Mrs. Clinton in pledged delegates, he has shown he can still beat her head-to-head whether they are vying for votes or campaign dollars. In March, Mr. Sanders out raised Mrs. Clinton by nearly $15 million.Having moved from a long-shot candidate to a viable threat to Mrs. Clinton's candidacy, Mr. Sanders has been facing more pointed questions about how he would achieve the goals he has laid out. In an interview with the New York Daily News, members of the editorial board questioned him on how precisely he would break up the large banks that he says pose a grave threat to the U.S. economy.Mr. Sanders told the newspaper he didn't know if the Federal Reserve has the authority to break up the banks. He added, "I think the administration can have it."Asked later if he was saying the president could "order" the break up, Mr. Sanders said: "No, I did not say we would order...The president is not a dictator."Would the banks break themselves up?, Mr. Sanders was asked.Mr. Sanders said the Treasury secretary would determine if certain banks were "too big to fail," and if that was deemed to be the case, "they will be broken up."Mr. Sanders also was asked about a judge's ruling last week that quashed an attempt by federal regulators to label MetLife Inc. "too big to fail."He said "it's something I have not studied, honestly..."Austan Goolsbee, who served as chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers in the Obama administration, tweeted Tuesday : "The guy seems clueless on his own #1 issue."Barney Frank, a former Massachusetts congressman and an architect of the Dodd-Frank law imposing stricter financial regulations following the 2008 economic collapse, said the transcript "just reinforces that he hasn't given much thought to this other than banks are bad."Both Messrs. Goolsbee and Frank are Clinton supporters.As in other states, Mr. Sanders drew large, enthusiastic crowds in Wisconsin. He spent election day morning in Milwaukee, having breakfast with the state's former lieutenant governor, Barbara Lawton.Menomonee Falls, Wis., resident Pat Libecki, 60, who works in a bank, said she voted for Mr. Sanders."I think we need a change and I liked his answers to the issues that we're having in this country," she said.Heading into the Wisconsin primary, Mrs. Clinton led Mr. Sanders in pledged delegates, 1,243 to 980. With superdelegates thrown in, her lead stood at 1,712 to Mr. Sanders's 1,011. A total of 2,383 delegates are needed to clinch the nomination.Mr. Sanders has had trouble closing the gap. Democrats award delegates on a proportional basis, making it hard for him to cut into her lead short of blowout victories in large, delegate-rich states.Preliminary tallies show he shrunk Mrs. Clinton's lead by only 60 delegates after winning six of the last seven contests before Wisconsin.Part of Mr. Sanders's argument is that he would be a stronger nominee in the general election matchup in the fall. While most superdelegates are backing Mrs. Clinton, he hopes that if he continues winning primary contests they will begin to abandon her candidacy.David Wasserman, a delegate expert for the nonpartisan Cook Political Report, says Mr. Sanders will need to capture 57% of the remaining delegates to erase Mrs. Clinton's lead.Colleen McCain Nelson and Erica Orden contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Hillary Clinton's Lead Over Bernie Sanders Narrows Slightly in WSJ/NBC Poll; Latest WSJ/NBC survey says Clinton's lead inches back to nine points from 11 points in February
article text: Hillary Clinton's national lead over Sen. Bernie Sanders narrowed slightly to nine points among Democratic primary voters, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll finds .Mrs. Clinton draws support from 53% of voters who said they would participate in a Democratic primary, while Mr. Sanders has 44%, the poll finds. Mrs. Clinton's lead was 11 points in February and 24 points in January, according to the poll.The new poll reflects the strengths each candidate has shown in the primary and caucus voting so far. Mrs. Clinton's strongest support groups include women age 50 and older--she wins 73% of that group--as well as nonwhite voters, and ideologically moderate and conservative voters.Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Sanders by 48 points among women age 50 and older, by 29 points among nonwhite voters and by 26 points among moderates and conservatives.She holds a 24-point lead over Mr. Sanders among women, while he holds a 14-point lead among men.Strongest support groups for Mr. Sanders include younger voters; he takes 60% of those under age 50.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Michigan Turnout Shows Split on Clinton* Trump Faces Test in Michigan, Mississippi Primaries* What to Watch in Tuesday's Nominating Contests* Trump Upends Status Quo on Foreign Policy* GOP Lawmakers Lament Loss of Cohesion in Elections* What Are the Odds? Kasich Now Less of a Longshot Than RubioMr. Sanders leads Mrs. Clinton by 28 points among white men, by 14 points among liberals and by 24 points among independents who say they'll vote in the Democratic primary.The survey was released on the day Democrats vote in primaries in Michigan and Mississippi.Before Tuesday's voting, Mrs. Clinton had won 12 primaries and caucuses, compared with eight won by Mr. Sanders. She had support from 1,130 convention delegates to 499 for Mr. Sanders. Those totals include support from party insiders known as superdelegates, who can change their allegiance and back any candidate regardless of how their home states voted. A candidate needs 2,383 delegates to secure the presidential nomination.The survey, conducted March 3-6, interviewed 410 people and has a margin of error of plus or minus 4.84 percentage points.Write to Aaron Zitner at aaron.zitner@wsj.comCredit: By Aaron Zitner

article name: Bernie Sanders Outlines Plan to Pare Down Big Banks; Proposal gives power to break up banks to Treasury secretary, but lets firms decide how
article text: Bernie Sanders's awkward explanation of how he would break up the nation's biggest banks reverberated on the campaign trail Wednesday, with his Democratic presidential opponent Hillary Clinton chiding him for a hazy plan."He hadn't done his homework and he'd been talking for more than a year about doing things that he obviously hadn't really studied or understood," Mrs. Clinton said on MSNBC Wednesday, a day after Mr. Sanders trounced her in the Wisconsin primary.The Vermont senator's full interview with the New York Daily News, however, shows he offered a clearer vision than the political backlash suggests.Much of the criticism has centered on an exchange in which he was repeatedly questioned about the authority the government could use to pare down the biggest banks. Mr. Sanders said a bill he introduced in May 2015 would give the Treasury secretary authority to break up big banks but leave it up to the institutions to figure out how to restructure."It is their decision as to what they want to do and how they want to reconfigure themselves," Mr. Sanders said during the April 1 interview, which was publicly released on Monday. "That's not my decision."Mike Konczal, a fellow at the liberal Roosevelt Institute, who published a blog post on Mr. Sanders's interview , said the confusion stems from a faulty assumption."When people say, 'We have to break up the banks,' they do not have a specific way to restructure. They in fact have a destination and leave it to the banks to get there," he said.Under Mr. Sanders's plan, the Financial Stability Oversight Council, headed by the Treasury secretary, would have 90 days to compile a list of banks deemed to be too-big-to-fail. The list would automatically include institutions like J.P. Morgan Chase & Co., Goldman Sachs, Citigroup Inc., Bank of America Corp. and Morgan Stanley, a point he reiterated during the interview. The firms are among the eight identified as institutions that could pose a threat to the financial stability of the country.After drawing up the list, the Treasury secretary, in consultation with the firm's regulator, would have one year to make sure the banks break themselves up so that a failure wouldn't require a taxpayer bailout to avoid a big blow to the U.S. or global economy.Mr. Sanders's proposal differs from the 2010 Dodd-Frank regulatory-overhaul law in two significant ways. His plan would give the authority to break up the banks directly to the administration through the Treasury secretary, and it leaves the decision on how to break up the banks to the institutions themselves, not the Federal Reserve.Today, that power rests with the Fed, which can start the breakup process only after a number of triggers.Critics still picked apart Mr. Sanders's plan.Tony Fratto, a partner at consulting firm Hamilton Place Strategies, which advises large banks, said the senator's plan essentially was "moving the authority from one sophisticated economic agency to another sophisticated economic agency."Under the Dodd-Frank law, banks with $50 billion or more in assets are required to draw up credible bankruptcy plans, or "living wills." Failing to write a reliable plan opens the way for regulators to cap the size of the firm or limit its activities.Results of those living wills will serve as a litmus test on whether the Fed will exert that authority. Both the Fed and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. are assessing which big banks drafted credible plans, and their verdicts are expected to be released soon."The tools are there," said Cornelius Hurley, the director of Boston University's Center for Finance, Law and Policy and a former Fed official. "They could break them up, but they don't have the willpower."The banks could also be required to slim down if the FSOC now headed by Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew, identifies a firm as systemically important. If the council's 10 voting members--mostly heads of regulatory agencies--decide that is the case, a firm is placed under the Fed's supervision, and its size or activities could be limited.But last week's ruling by a federal district judge upending FSOC's designation of MetLife Inc. as "systemically important" puts a legal question mark over the council's authority, especially when it comes to big insurers.Notwithstanding the court challenge, the council has power to break up an institution if it decides by a majority vote that the firm presents a "grave threat" to financial stability--a power the council has yet to exert.Write to Donna Borak at donna.borak@wsj.comCredit: By Donna Borak

article name: War of Words Escalates in Democratic Race; Sanders says Clinton is unfit to be president and a headline said she said the same about him
article text: NEW YORK--The Democratic race between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders detoured Thursday from high-minded debate over issues into a he-said-she-said squabble ahead of the presidential primary fight for New York, a contest with outsize importance to both candidates.For Mr. Sanders, the state is a must-win if he is to have any chance of catching the Democratic front-runner. For Mrs. Clinton, a loss in her adopted home state in the April 19 primary would be deeply embarrassing.Those stakes help explain the sharp exchanges in recent days as both campaigns launched aggressive New York campaigns, including new television ads with messages tailored to different parts of the state.Mr. Sanders charged that Mrs. Clinton wasn't qualified to be president--but only, he said, because she said the same about him. But Mrs. Clinton hadn't called him unqualified; she declined to answer when pressed on the matter in an earlier TV interview."If Secretary Clinton thinks that just because I'm from a small state in Vermont...they're going to beat us up and...we're not going to fight back...they can guess again," he told reporters in Philadelphia on Thursday.Mrs. Clinton called the whole thing "silly," even as her campaign sought to raise money off the claim that the former first lady, senator and secretary of state isn't prepared for the White House. In a second fundraising email Thursday, her campaign emphasized that she never called him unqualified.Later Thursday, in an interview with CBS, Mr. Sanders repeated that he was only making charges against Mrs. Clinton because he believed she leveled them first toward him. He said he will "certainly" support her if she's the Democratic nominee, but when asked directly if he believes she is "unqualified to be president," he replied, "Well, does Secretary Clinton believe that I am unqualified to be president?"Mrs. Clinton has 1,280 pledged delegates, the type awarded by voters, to Mr. Sanders's 1,030. When superdelegates--party leaders who can support anybody they like--are included she has 1,749 to his 1,061. A total of 2,383 are needed to win the nomination.After New York awards 291 delegates, there are just three large states left--California, New Jersey and Pennsylvania--and Mr. Sanders needs to win all four with large margins if he is to have any chance to catch her.Mrs. Clinton, who represented New York for eight years in the Senate and still calls the state home, begins with some clear advantages. New York primaries bar independent voters, who typically favor Mr. Sanders. And the electorate is expected to be about a third nonwhite, a group that has voted for Mrs. Clinton in previous contests.Recent public polling shows Mrs. Clinton with about a 10-point lead, but Mr. Sanders has shown he can catch up as voting approaches and more people get to know him."Everybody in New York knows who Hillary Clinton is, so if you're undecided about her, then you probably don't want to vote for her," said Bill Cunningham, a political consultant who is unaffiliated with either campaign.Each side has tailored one campaign for the New York metropolitan area, which could account for as much as 70% of the electorate, and another for the rest of New York, known as upstate.On Thursday, Mrs. Clinton rode the subway alongside Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr. and began airing five television ads. "I am so proud to have represented this state for eight years. I'm a proud New Yorker," she said before boarding the subway.Mrs. Clinton's New York City strategy centers on increasing turnout among black and Hispanic voters. On Sunday, she visited three African-American churches in Brooklyn, where she spoke about the importance of tackling "systemic racism" and the need for gun restrictions.On Tuesday, she held an event in the Crown Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn that focused on African-American women, and included a panel featuring Gwen Carr, the mother of Eric Garner. Mr. Garner, an African-American, died in 2014 after being held in an apparent police chokehold on Staten Island while unarmed. His death sparked a protests and political turmoil in New York.One of three Clinton ads airing in the New York metro area is narrated by actor Morgan Freeman and is focused on victims of police violence and on her relationship with President Barack Obama. A second ad celebrates New York's diversity and hits Republican Donald Trump for his comments about Muslims and plans to build a wall along the Mexican border, another spot meant to motivate minority voters.Upstate, her events and TV ads focus on her work to boost economic development when she was in the Senate, including advocating for the Buffalo Niagara Medical Campus and its thousands of high-tech jobs. On Friday, she will travel to Buffalo for an economic round table, and campaign in Rochester.Mr. Sanders, a Brooklyn native, is emphasizing his own New York roots. He pushed for a debate in Brooklyn, scheduled for next week. He drew 18,000 people to a rally in the Bronx last week and plans a large rally in Manhattan's Washington Square Park next week. Aides also note that eastern upstate New York borders Vermont, so people there have heard about him for years.In a New York City metro area that is home to some of the richest and the poorest Americans, Mr. Sanders will focus on income inequality, and on Mrs. Clinton's ties to Wall Street, said Tad Devine, his senior strategist.The Sanders campaign is airing a TV spot featuring Erica Garner, Mr. Garner's daughter.One Sanders advantage is support of the Working Families Party, the state's minor but powerful leftist party. "They are very good at grass roots ground game," said Steve Greenberg, a New York polling expert.Thursday's tiff over whether Mrs. Clinton is qualified or not began when the New York Daily News published an interview with Mr. Sanders. The Clinton campaign circulated the entire transcript and on Wednesday.Mrs. Clinton was asked three times on MSNBC's "Morning Joe" whether, in light of the interview, she thinks he is qualified to be president."I think the interview raised a lot of really serious questions," she said. "I will leave it to voters to decide who of us can do the job that the country needs."The Washington Post, writing about the interview, included a headline that said she had questioned whether he was qualified. Mr. Sanders seized on that."When you have headlines in the Washington Post--quote 'Clinton questions whether Sanders is qualified to be president,' my response is, well you know, if you want to question my qualifications let me suggest this, then maybe the American people might wonder about your qualifications, Madam Secretary," he said Thursday.He suggested her past support for trade agreements, her vote to authorize the Iraq war and support from Wall Street interests disqualified her for the job.Asked about his comments on Thursday, Mrs. Clinton told reporters in New York City, "Well it's kind of a silly thing to say. But I'm going to trust the voters of New York who know me and have voted for me three times."Mrs. Clinton needs to drive up her support among women, particularly suburban women, a campaign adviser said. Mr. Sanders's comment could help with that, said George Arzt, a New York City Democratic political consultant who is unaffiliated in the race."I think there are many people who view Hillary--whether they like her or not--as the most experienced and qualified in the field," he said. "There are many women who believe that the 'unqualified' title has been used too often against women looking for better jobs."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Erica Orden at erica.orden@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Erica Orden

article name: New York's Vote Matters for a Change; Trump tries to recover from his Wisconsin deflation, while Sanders finally gets aggressive.
article text: In Wisconsin and in the weeks leading up to it Donald Trump got wounded. Big animals get wounded and come back. The question is whether he's a big animal or something smaller that skittered around the forest and finally picked the wrong fight.Wisconsin almost certainly foreclosed his chance to walk into Cleveland with enough delegates to win on the first ballot. The convention will be open, and contested.There's nothing easy about Mr. Trump. He leaves his supporters' hearts in their mouths. He leaves his enemies happy then self-doubting, triumphant then fatalistic. But what we have witnessed the past few weeks is his deflation, a real one, and the worst kind: It was all his fault. It wasn't the anti-Trump forces and it wasn't Ted Cruz, it was his lax, louche indiscipline.But now we cut to New York. We are about to witness something of a Trump reinflation.The other night he drew some 10,000 people to a rally in Bethpage, Long Island, which the Daily News called "riotous" and Newsday called "rousing." I lived in Long Island from age 5 to 16 and go there often. My friends and their children are a generation or two from Brooklyn and Queens, and Brooklyn and Queens were one or two generations from the old country. Long Islanders carry within them, still and more than they know, a love for America tinged by family lore of the immigrant experience--an old and patriotic sense that gets mixed up, in the current way, with a nationalistic sense. Republicans who were amusing themselves on social media the night of the rally--as word spread of turnout they were sending out pictures of Joey Buttafuoco--look down on those rally-goers at their peril. They will be part of the base of whatever takes the place of the current Republican Party.Mr. Trump, in the video I saw, was masterly. "We don't win anymore," he said. "We don't fight like people from Long Island. We don't fight like people from New York." He laid into Mr. Cruz: "Remember when he started lecturing me on 'New York values' like we're no good?" That was the authentic sound of working New York: "Like we're no good."And it felt fresh, because no one really campaigns for the presidency in New York anymore. Its primaries are in April, usually after everything's been settled. In the general election New York's in the bag for the Democrats, so why should they expend the energy or Republicans the time?Candidates for president only come here for major media interviews and for money. They pick Manhattan up and shake it like a big pink piggy bank--$60K at the downtown breakfast, $600K at the uptown cocktail party. They enter the homes of the great and powerful--the spacious rooms, high ceilings, plump sofas, shiny floors, important art, views of Central Park--and they think: "Boy, they sure got it good. Maybe the economy isn't so bad!"The rich of New York thus hold an outsized place in the Republican and Democratic imagination. But the not-rich--the middle, the hanging-on and the poor--have no place at all.Republicans especially, the past 20 or so years, have no sense of them. They know the hedge-funders and the rooms with the Rothkos. Their vision of everything else comes from old movies like "Dog Day Afternoon." They're surprised we're not all running around in the streets shouting "Attica! Attica!"What Republicans especially fail to appreciate is that New York more than ever is full of legal immigrants. If you sit on the side of a street fair in non-hipster Brooklyn--in Bay Ridge, for instance--you'll see all the world passing by: people from China, Ireland, Lebanon, Poland, South and Central America, Asia, Africa, Arabia. They are young. They're expending all their energy doing what people do to establish themselves--finding the job, keeping it, paying the rent, finding someone to love, making a family, making it all work.So far they have no time for politics--but they will. They're not aligned--but they will be. They are open to persuasion. They will consider your argument. All you have to do is be there and talk to them. If the Republican Party were thinking long-term, it would. Maybe when the party is reconstituting itself--trying to rebuild a damaged or destroyed party, or inventing a new one--they'll recognize these people too as a potential part of their base.In any case Mr. Trump is expected to win big. He's 31 points ahead in the polls. Is there any chance he can discipline himself and sustain the discipline, create a real campaign, professionalize his operation? Would it make a difference? Or are his reputation and his mess set so firmly in concrete nothing can change his outcome?On the Democratic side Bernie Sanders has turned tough. He seems to have come face to face with the fact that he really wants to win. He said Hillary Clinton is not "qualified" to be president because of her support for the Iraq War, "disastrous" trade policies, and taking Wall Street money. His campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, upped the ante by saying if Mrs. Clinton hits back unfairly, "they're going to see how a real New Yorker fights back."God bless New York for stripping the passive from the passive-aggressive campaign they were waging against each other until this week.I saw Mrs. Clinton at Harlem's Apollo Theater last week. The audience was appropriately enthusiastic but not wild. Soon after, I watched the Sanders rally in the Bronx--a crowd of at least 15,000 that was wild. A Hillary supporter I spoke to at the Apollo confessed she was there to reignite her excitement. In her life she was surrounded by Bernie supporters. It leaves you feeling defensive.If he dings her bad or wins in New York it will be a real setback for Mrs. Clinton, and an embarrassment.Everything on both sides is still so in play.Washington Republicans continue their fantasy of the white knight who comes to Cleveland and saves the day--the magical unifying figure who electrifies the convention and wins on the fourth ballot. But how would the large majority of Republicans who've voted for Mr. Trump or Mr. Cruz feel about that? Not good!Again, if Mr. Trump wins, a significant part of the party splits off. If he doesn't, a significant part of the party likely isn't there in November. I was asked this week if Trump always intended to break the party. I don't think so; I think he set out to win. But whether he wins or not he has succeeded in demonstrating to the party that it is and was broken. He made the information unavoidable.A friend with whom I'd been discussing the convention, a former Romney bundler, this week sent me a gift: handsome two-inch heels, heavily padded on the sole so if there is trouble you could run in them. The outside fabric is rough camouflage, the kind a soldier would wear in the field.That's a fellow whose fantasy of what the convention will be like is probably closer to the mark.Credit: By Peggy Noonan

article name: Unqualified vs. Un-Democratic; Danger: Clinton and Sanders contents under pressure.
article text: The pillow fight that has been the Democratic nomination contest took a savage turn this week, as Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders traded up for water balloons. Their little scuffle probably won't leave any marks, but it sure is entertaining.The former first lady apparently had enough after losing seven of the last eight primaries, and she lashed out at an activist on a rope line that "I am so sick of the Sanders campaign lying about me." She told Politico in a passive-aggressive interview that the Vermont socialist is "a relatively new Democrat, and, in fact, I'm not even sure he is one." On MSNBC's "Morning Joe," Mrs. Clinton even said she had "a lot of questions" about whether "this guy is ready to be President of the United States?"Mr. Sanders stopped being polite and started getting real, or at least snippy. "Well, let me just say in response to Secretary Clinton: I don't believe that she is qualified if she is, through her super Pac, taking tens of millions of dollars in special interest funds," he said in Philadelphia. "I don't think you are qualified if you get $15 million from Wall Street through your super Pac." Oh dear.If such umbrage-taking is what passes for negativity between Democrats, perhaps these scamps would benefit from a time-out. The truth is that Mrs. Clinton has moved so far left to accommodate Mr. Sanders's revolution that there are few policy differences to litigate. She'll move to single-payer health care a bit slower, create free college through loan forgiveness rather than a huge tax increase, and so forth. Since Mr. Sanders won't talk about Mrs. Clinton's emails, they're left with the non-drama of minor insults.

article name: Trump and Sanders Rallies Highlight a Political Odd Couple; Events for Trump and Sanders show how different the two populist candidates really are
article text: ONALASKA, Wis.--The 2016 presidential campaign has unfolded as the year of the angry, disillusioned voter. Many analysts see this dynamic on both sides of the aisle, inviting odd-couple comparisons between Republican Donald Trump and Democratic candidate Bernie Sanders.Both men are defying their party's establishment, delivering populist messages, and drawing unusually large and passionate crowds of people upset with the status quo. Exit polls in Wisconsin's primary on Tuesday showed they both drew heavily from voters who want the country to take a less active role in world affairs and who are worried about trade taking U.S. jobs away.Mr. Sanders himself invited one point of comparison between himself and the celebrity New York businessman recently by invoking a signature Trumpism: He bragged about the "YUUUUUGE" crowds he has been drawing.But that's just about where the similarity ends, if a visit to recent rallies held by the two candidates in Wisconsin is any indication.Traveling from a Trump rally in Janesville, Wis., to a Sanders event here in Onalaska was like a trip from Venus to Mars, and the contrast helps illustrate the vast difference in the political forces that their expectation-defying campaigns are unleashing.Ask Sanders supporters what brought them to the rally and their first word was likely to be "Bernie." There is a real personal draw for Sanders supporters.And while there are things they are very angry about--the upper-income 1%, the corrupt campaign-finance system, Democratic Party bosses--they look to their candidate with hope."I'm pretty excited about his ideas," said Gloria Kelbel, a 53-year-old high-school counselor from Hillsboro, Wis., who said the Onalaska event was the first political rally she had ever attended.Ask Trump supporters why they braved long lines and often drove long distances to be there, they were likely to talk about the troubling state of the world and the political system. They are angry both at the elites who ignore them and the underclass that is displacing them."I want someone who gives a damn about the American worker," said Shawn Rickelman, 31, an unemployed trucker from Rockford, Ill.Both rallies saw thousands of people thronging large venues and waiting for hours for the main event. But there were chairs for the Trump crowd; people stood for Sanders. As a result, the biggest hazard at the Sanders rally was heat exhaustion. Two people needed medical attention. At the Trump rally, the hazard was outside, among the dueling protest groups: One anti-Trump protester got pepper-sprayed.The long wait for the candidates was filled with emblematic soundtracks. While Mr. Sanders played revolution-themed rock and folk, Mr. Trump's playlist was, like him, idiosyncratic, ranging from the Rolling Stones ("You Can't Always Get What You Want") to Elton John ("Tiny Dancer") to opera ("Nessun Dorma" from act 3 of Puccini's "Turandot").Mr. Sanders delivered a stump speech that was so familiar when he asked who knew what the average contribution to the campaign was, many people did and shouted back "$27!" in unison. The topics they applauded, including decriminalizing marijuana and opposition to fracking, would never be cheered for at a Trump rally.Mr. Trump is famously unscripted, so no one ever knows for sure what will come out of his mouth--or out of the mouths of his supporters.Reading his audience like the skilled entertainer he is, Mr. Trump was able to rouse the previously calm Wisconsin audience into a jeering crowd at the mention of illegal immigrants. And to Mr. Trump's own surprise, the crowd booed the mention of a local GOP luminary, House Speaker Paul Ryan. Some called Mr. Ryan "RINO," the conservative label for "Republicans in Name Only."Among all the differences, the two Wisconsin rallies did, however, identify one common enemy: Both Trump supporters and Sanders supporters booed Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker, who is a foe of the state's labor unions and endorsed Mr. Trump's GOP rival, Sen. Ted Cruz.Write to Janet Hook at janet.hook@wsj.comCredit: By Janet Hook
