article name: Democratic Presidential Debate Puts Spotlight on Brooklyn Navy Yard; Thursday's debate between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders will take place within the former U.S. military shipyard
article text: The Democratic presidential debate on Thursday will mark another star turn for Brooklyn's Navy Yard, a former U.S. military shipyard that is now home to hundreds of businesses and the occasional fashion event.The refurbishment of the Navy Yard--a 300-acre industrial park with more than 4 million square feet of leasable space on the waterfront between the Williamsburg and Manhattan bridges--was a priority under former New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg . Efforts have continued under his successor, Bill de Blasio.Thursday night's debate between Democratic candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders is scheduled to take place at an event space within the Navy Yard called Duggal Greenhouse.The three-year-old venue has previously hosted some high-wattage gatherings, including Lady Gaga's album release party with artist Jeff Koons, an Alexander Wang fashion show and rehearsals for pop star Beyoncé."I think it's a great time for us to have the local and national spotlight," said David Ehrenberg, president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corp., which manages the yard for the city.The Navy Yard is undergoing its largest expansion to date, and officials hope the developments will bring a surge of jobs.Mary Lovci, vice president of Duggal Greenhouse, said the debate is a "unique, special occasion" for the space.Owned by 80-year-old Baldev Duggal, the founder of a global graphics business, "this space was his vision and his dream," she said.Ms. Lovci said the space was sought by CNN, which is co-hosting the debate that is scheduled to begin at 9 p.m.The event location has drawn some criticism from Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams, who said the debate should be held somewhere that will put the spotlight on poverty in New York City."The Brooklyn Navy Yard is a success story," Mr. Adams said. "We can't continue to stay in the environments of success stories."Mike VilenskyWrite to Mike Vilensky at mike.vilensky@dowjones.comCredit: By Mike Vilensky

article name: Verizon's Political Strike; Sanders and Clinton join picket lines on behalf of the rotary-phone era.
article text: As Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders chase each other further to the left, it was only a matter of time before somebody decided to capitalize on their competition. The Democrats have now helped inspire the largest domestic strike in years--and it's pure political performance art.On Wednesday, more than 36,000 Verizon workers on the East Coast walked off the job after their unions rejected the telecom's latest contract offer in a 10-month negotiation. The Communication Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers wanted a public spectacle, and did they ever get one.Mr. Sanders joined a picket line in Brooklyn and began, "Brothers and sisters, thank you for your courage and standing up for justice against corporate greed." He went on to accuse Verizon of "trying to destroy the lives of working Americans," and that was the subtle part. Mrs. Clinton demanded that the company "do the right thing" and tender "a fair offer to their workers."The Democrats are not exactly Bobby Kennedy communing with Cesar Chavez and destitute grape pickers. How's this for "fair"? The walk-offs enjoy an average annual pay and benefits package of $130,000. Management is offering a 6.5% cash wage increase, the same health coverage as its other domestic employees and an industry-competitive 401(k) match.Yet Verizon and the unions have largely agreed about compensation. The unions preferred to make a political statement about expanding the ranks of the Americans lucky enough to have decent-paying jobs, which apparently means showing solidarity with an increasingly obsolete business model.Some 99% of the strikers work for Verizon's legacy "wireline" business, or its traditional fixed phone service plus its fiber optic Internet service. This unit generates only 7% of Verizon operating income, down from 60% in 2000--wireless is more profitable--and as more customers ditch land lines, it is only natural that these old-fashioned networks will require fewer workers to operate and maintain.But Verizon isn't even looking to shed jobs. It is merely seeking more flexibility to manage its workforce, such as consolidating under-used call centers and the ability to hire more outside contractors. "Nostalgia for the rotary-phone era won't save American jobs," Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam wrote in a LinkedIn post.Mr. McAdam also called Mr. Sanders's rhetoric "contemptible," publishing a detailed rebuttal. Credit is due to the rare executive willing to defend economic reality and stand up to political intimidation.

article name: Notable & Quotable: Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam; On Bernie Sanders's 'outrageous' views about big corporations.
article text: From a LinkedIn post by Verizon CEO Lowell McAdam, April 13:I read with interest Jeff Immelt's spirited response to Sen. Bernie Sanders putting GE on his hitlist of big corporations that are "destroying the moral fabric" of America.In fact, I feel his pain. Verizon is in Sanders's bull's-eye, as well. The senator's uninformed views are, in a word, outrageous. Here's why.His first accusation--that Verizon doesn't pay its fair share of taxes--is just plain wrong. As our financial statements clearly show, we've paid more than $15.6 billion in taxes over the last two years--that's a 35% tax rate in 2015, for anyone who's counting. . . . The senator has started to fudge his language--talking of taxes not paid in some unspecified "given year"--but that doesn't make his contention any less false.Sen. Sanders also claims that Verizon doesn't use its profits to benefit America. Again, a look at the facts says otherwise. In the last two years, Verizon has invested some $35 billion in infrastructure--virtually all of it in the U.S.--and paid out more than $16 billion in dividends to the millions of average Americans who invest in our stock.

article name: After Hillary Beats Bernie, She'll Need Him; Clinton may be uninspiring, but her competence could be what 2016 voters want.
article text: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton will be the Democratic Party's presidential nominee, and there is nothing that Sen. Bernie Sanders can do about it.The Vermont senator's campaign is reportedly planning an all-out assault on the democratic legitimacy of the party's 712 superdelegates, who make up about 15% of the total. But on what basis? As of today, Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Sanders by 250 among delegates won in primaries and caucuses. She has received 2.4 million more popular votes than he has. A recent synthesis of exit polls shows that of 27 demographic categories, Mr. Sanders has the edge in three. Despite his recent winning streak, she has prevailed in more states, and his string of victories has narrowed her edge by only 79 delegates.That's the good news for Mr. Sanders, and it is about to end. Between now and the end of April, Democrats will hold primaries in six states--New York, Maryland, Connecticut, Delaware, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island. Unless a late Sanders surge reverses Mrs. Clinton's lead, she will win the majority--perhaps all--of these states, and her lead among delegates and in the popular vote will expand significantly. By the end of April, she will have upward of 90% of the delegates she needs to claim the nomination.The pace of the campaign slows significantly in May, with fewer than 200 delegates at stake. Unless Mr. Sanders wipes her out on June 7 in California and New Jersey--and there is no evidence that he will--she will end the nominating contest with more than enough delegates to claim victory, including a majority of delegates earned in primaries and caucuses as well as a margin of millions in the popular vote.So how exactly will the Sanders forces make the case that Mrs. Clinton's nomination would violate the people's will?Recently, Mr. Sanders has been arguing that he would make a stronger general-election candidate, and he has a fair amount of survey evidence to back his claim. But using this argument to sway the superdelegates would be an appeal to their judgment, not to democratic legitimacy.Besides, it won't work. Democrats who have been around the track a few times understand that while Mrs. Clinton has been subjected to unrelenting scrutiny for a quarter of a century, Mr. Sanders's record has been left virtually untouched. The Clinton campaign has been reluctant to antagonize voters whose support they will need in the general election, and Republicans are holding their fire in the vain hope that they will have the opportunity to run against Mr. Sanders in the fall.The real question is how well Mrs. Clinton will do in November. The answer depends on a few things she can control and many more that she cannot. She can try--within limits--to placate Mr. Sanders's backers at the nominating convention. She could decide to choose a populist-tinged figure--Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown, for example--as her running mate. If the Democrats emerge from their convention unified and energized, Mrs. Clinton's fall prospects will rise--all the more so if Mr. Sanders campaigns vigorously on her behalf.Because every presidential election comes down to a choice, the identity of the Republican nominee will make a big difference. Although Donald Trump is the ultimate wild card, there is no evidence that he would prevail in a general election. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz is focused, strategic and well-organized, but his hard-edge conservatism would make it difficult for him to expand his support beyond his party's base. Ohio Gov. John Kasich runs well ahead of Mrs. Clinton in national surveys, but rank-and-file Republicans appear in no mood to nominate someone from their party's moderate-conservative wing.Mrs. Clinton is not a visionary, and her candidacy has done little to inspire Democrats not already committed to her. She is cautious and self-controlled, not a risk-taker. By her own admission, she is not a natural politician. Contradicting Mario Cuomo's famous maxim, she campaigns in prose.On the other hand, few have ever questioned her intelligence or work ethic. She understands how politics and policy-making really work. She believes that political leaders should under-promise and over-perform--an eminently defensible thesis in this era of rock-bottom public trust.In most democracies, the head of government is separate from the head of state. In the U.S., they are fused in a single office. Our presidents are called on to perform both as prime ministers and as symbols of the nation. Rarely are they equally skilled at both tasks.Hillary Clinton has the qualities of a first-rate prime minister. At a time when the American people are yearning for an end to political dysfunction and a return to government that works effectively on their behalf, what she offers will probably be enough to prevail in November.Credit: By William A. Galston

article name: SEC Alleges 'Ponzi-Like' Fraud at Ski Resort Praised by Sanders, Other Politicians; Sens. Bernie Sanders, Patrick Leahy saw company as helping corner of Vermont through visa program
article text: A Vermont ski resort accused of "Ponzi-like" fraud by the Securities and Exchange Commission had been championed by Sen. Bernie Sanders and other politicians as a way of helping to revitalize a northern corner of the state.The SEC on Thursday filed a civil lawsuit alleging a "massive eight-year fraudulent scheme" involving a series of real-estate developments by Jay Peak ski resort and a federal program known as EB-5 that offers green cards to foreign investors.Mr. Sanders, who is running for the Democratic presidential nomination, had praised the resort's use of the EB-5 program, as did Sen. Patrick Leahy and Gov. Peter Shumlin, both Democrats, and other politicians.The Sanders campaign didn't immediately respond to requests for comment Friday.Mr. Leahy said in a statement Thursday that he was "shocked and saddened" by what investigators had found. "I have supported the EB-5 Regional Center Program because it can generate significant investment and create real jobs in rural areas...But there is no question that the program is in dire need of reform," he said. At a Friday news conference, Mr. Leahy said the charges could help persuade lawmakers to support changes to the EB-5 program.Vermont's financial regulation department also sued the resort and two of its executives, alleging violations of state fraud laws. Mr. Shumlin said at a Thursday news conference announcing the case: "We all feel betrayed.""The dream that we could finally create hundreds and hundreds of jobs in a part of the state that has been struggling for jobs, is something that any reasonable person would wish to pursue...obviously this is an extraordinary disappointment," the governor said, according to a video of the news conference posted on the Burlington Free Press website.In an interview Friday, the top federal prosecutor in Vermont, Eric Miller, said his was investigating "whether or not there have been any violations of federal criminal law in connection with the EB-5 projects in the Northeast Kingdom."Messrs. Sanders and Leahy had attended a 2012 news conference during which Jay Peak announced more than $500 million in EB-5 investments, according to news reports at the time. The announcement came days after President Barack Obama signed a three-year extension of the visa program, which Mr. Leahy helped usher through."Perhaps the most important reasons I support this program are standing right here in this room," Mr. Leahy spoke at the 2012 event, identifying three executives from the company by name, among others, according to remarks posted on his website.Mr. Sanders also praised the program at the 2012 news conference: "The most popular sport in America is complaining about the federal government. What you are seeing here is a marriage and partnership between private business and federal, state and local government."Jay Peak; its owner, Ariel Quiros; and its president, William Stenger, "systematically looted" more than $50 million of $350 million raised from foreign investors to fund various projects, the SEC said in a lawsuit filed in federal court . It described the scheme as "Ponzi-like" and said new investors' funds were being used to fund deficits on earlier projects. The court on Thursday froze the company's assets and appointed a receiver to control its funds.Mr. Stenger previously told a Vermont news website, vtdigger.org , that he had followed the terms of his agreement with investors and said he apologized for poorly communicating with them.A lawyer identified by the SEC as defense counsel in the case didn't respond to requests for comment Friday.Messrs. Quiros and Stenger couldn't immediately be reached for comment.Mr. Quiros has given $30,000 to the Vermont State Democratic Committee since 2012, according to public records.Jay Peak posted a notice on its website that said its day-to-day operations wouldn't be affected by the investigation .The SEC accused Mr. Quiros, 58 years old, of misappropriating the funds to finance $22 million of his purchase of the resort, back a personal line of credit and purchase a $2.2 million luxury condo at Trump Place in New York, among other uses. Mr. Quiros also used $4.2 million to pay the company's income taxes, the SEC said. The lawsuit accuses Mr. Stenger, 66, of helping facilitate that misappropriation by improperly moving funds and creating a "web of transfers" to hide that projects were subsequently experiencing shortfalls.At the Friday news conference, Mr. Leahy said he considered Mr. Stenger a friend and said he was disappointed by the allegations.Mr. Leahy "has no real relationship with Mr. Quiros and has met him only briefly on a few occasions," a spokeswoman for the senator said.Investors had been told their funds would be used only to finance one of six projects related to the ski resort, or for the creation of a biomedical research center, the SEC said.The purported $110 million center appears to be "nearly a complete fraud," the SEC said. Investors have provided nearly three-quarters of the funds, and the men claimed in offering documents in 2012 and 2013 that they were in the process of obtaining Food and Drug Administration approval for certain products, but hadn't actually begun the process and haven't submitted any products for FDA review, the SEC said.The SEC said the two men continued to travel to solicit new investors, including in the last few months to Vietnam, Dubai, Istanbul, Hong Kong, Singapore and South America, without mentioning the "significant shortfall in funds" they need to finish the research facility.The SEC said it is seeking financial penalties and a return of profits, in addition to court orders on the two man that bar them from some activities.Write to Aruna Viswanatha at Aruna.Viswanatha@wsj.comCredit: By Aruna Viswanatha

article name: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders Both Backed Crime Law Critics Blame for Unfair System; The Democrats attribute what they call unfairness in the criminal-justice system on a 1994 law they both supported.
article text: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders, embroiled in a contentious New York primary, have been calling for changes to a criminal-justice system they say unfairly targets minorities. But both supported the landmark 1994 law that critics say helped foster the system they now attack.The eruption of the 22-year-old crime law into the 2016 presidential campaign highlights a striking shift in the nation's priorities and political landscape over the past two decades. That is creating particular challenges for Mrs. Clinton, the spouse of a president who approved the law two decades ago."I'm sorry for the consequences that were unintended and have had a very unfortunate impact on peoples' lives," Mrs. Clinton said during Thursday's Democratic debate in New York.Mr. Sanders said during the debate that "what we have got to do is rethink the system from the bottom on up."A testy exchange in Philadelphia recently between President Bill Clinton and a protester from the Black Lives Matter movement highlighted the issue. The protester blamed the crime law for the rise in incarceration, primarily of young black men, that critics say has left millions of people struggling to recover economically and socially.Jeremy Travis, president of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice, said anger over the criminal justice system's impact on minority communities is well-placed. "We've sort of blithely gone along all these years and let our prison population get bigger and bigger, and the impact has been felt most acutely by communities of color, particularly African-American men," said Mr. Travis, who directed the Justice Department's research arm in the Clinton years.But Mr. Travis said it is simplistic to blame Mr. Clinton and the 1994 crime bill for the growth in the prison population. "I am not sure there is a singular villain in this drama," he said.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Clinton, Sanders Hit Hard in New York Debate* Hill Republicans to Bolster Trump's Delegate Push* Candidates Court New York Republicans* Poll: Clinton Leads Sanders in New York by 17 PointsFormer House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who pushed for even tougher measures at the time, said the environment was completely different in the early 1990s. "It's easy to forget what was going on," Mr. Gingrich said. "Look at the current Chicago shooting and murder rate--that was across the whole country." Chicago has recently seen a jump in homicides.Mr. Gingrich, a Republican, defended Mr. Clinton's initial response to the Philadelphia protester, in which he pointed out that many of the crime wave's victims were black. "The people being killed in Philadelphia and New York were overwhelmingly minorities," Mr. Gingrich said.The term "super-predator" also entered the lexicon at the time, describing a group of young people who ostensibly were particularly remorseless. Many have since questioned the concept, and Mrs. Clinton recently expressed regret for using the term.The issue is becoming especially heated as Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders appeal for minority votes. But the Clinton crime bill was only one of the era's tough laws spawned by fear of crime. By 1994, the prison population was already growing, in part because of changes to state laws that increased the severity of sentences.Congress had also enacted laws with a similar impact, including the Sentencing Reform Act of 1984, which abolished parole in the federal system, and the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1986, which created mandatory minimum drug sentences.From 1980 to 1993, according to Justice Department estimates, the total corrections population--those on probation, parole, in state and federal prisons or in jail--rose from 1.8 million to 4.9 million. The prison population alone nearly tripled, to 969,300 from 329,800.That reflected the national mood. By 1994 the nation was inundated with news footage of yellow crime-scene tape, blanket-covered bodies and grieving families, primarily in inner-city minority neighborhoods, as battles erupted over control of the crack cocaine trade.The FBI estimated that over 72,000 people, nearly half of them African-American, were murdered between 1991 and 1993. Politically, "soft on crime" became an epithet to be avoided at all costs.In contrast, the past two decades have seen plummeting crime rates, along with the rise of competing national priorities, especially terrorism and the economy. At the same time, black leaders, and officeholders across the political spectrum, have become alarmed at the high incarceration rate and at relations between police and minorities.As a result, the view is now widespread among Democrats and liberals that the 1994 law was deeply flawed.Ronald Weich, dean of the University of Baltimore School of Law, said the legislation had attracted a clash of competing interests, creating "this ill-considered parade of ideas often not vetted through the committees of jurisdiction." Mr. Weich was then counsel to Sen. Edward Kennedy (D., Mass.), a key player on criminal justice issues who supported the final measure.The finished product had good and bad points, Mr. Weich said, and Mr. Clinton urgently sought its passage as he headed into tough midterm elections. "President Clinton needed a crime bill," Mr. Weich said. "His health care bill was failing in separate committees of the Congress."Mr. Clinton wanted 100,000 more police officers on the street. Democrats including Mr. Kennedy sought gun-control provisions. Republicans wanted stiffer penalties. Then-Sen. Joe Biden (D., Del.) and others championed the Violence Against Women Act.Many of these provisions, including an assault-weapons ban, became part of the crime law, as did a measure giving some sentencing relief to minor participants in drug enterprises.But the law also created new criminal offenses and expanded the federal death penalty. More significantly, it provided grants for states that required prisoners serve more time by reducing parole and early release, an approach supporters called "truth in sentencing."More than two dozen states and the District of Columbia changed their laws as a result, said Thomas Blomberg, dean of the College of Criminology and Criminal Justice at Florida State University. "The 1994 crime bill facilitated the continued growth in the use of prison by providing major funding for new prison construction," he said.Rep. Bobby Scott (D., Va.) supported certain parts of the law but opposed it overall. While the 1986 mandatory minimum law was the catalyst for today's incarceration rate, he said, the 1994 bill continued the trend."On balance, it was a lock-em-up bill," he said.Twenty-two years later, the effect of the period's tough-on-crime laws can be measured in a variety of ways. The Justice Mapping Center and others have assessed the impact of high incarceration rates on specific neighborhoods and how it increased social costs for families.One of the most recent comprehensive looks at incarceration, "The Growth of Incarceration in the United States" by the National Research Council, the operating arm of the National Academy of Sciences, in 2014 confirmed that criminal justice efforts have generally targeted minority communities."As a consequence, the effects of harsh penal policies in the past 40 years have fallen more heavily on blacks and Hispanics, especially the poorest," the report said . "In 2010, the imprisonment rate for blacks was 4.6 times that for whites."Moreover, 71.2 million people, nearly 30% of all adults, are included in the master criminal file maintained by the FBI. A spokesman said the file grows by an average of 10,000 to 12,000 first-time arrestees each day.Another impact, said Thena Robinson Mock, a project director at the Advancement Project, a civil rights group examining discipline procedures, is the so-called school-to-prison pipeline.Funding from the 1994 bill helped finance a rise in police officers assigned to schools and "issues that were school behavior became criminal behavior," she said. "Although it passed in '94, we are still living with the collateral consequences of this."Write to Gary Fields at gary.fields@wsj.comCredit: By Gary Fields

article name: Family Splits Over Primary Endorsements; Gwen Carr, Eric Garner's mother, is working with Hillary Clinton while her granddaughter supports Bernie Sanders
article text: Gwen Carr was at a "Black Lives Matter" protest last summer in honor of her son, Eric Garner , when a young woman approached her and handed her a business card with presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's name on it."'Madam Secretary said if there's anything you need, please reach out,'" Ms. Carr recalled the aide from Mrs. Clinton's campaign saying.In the months since, Ms. Carr, whose son was unarmed when he died after being placed in a chokehold by a New York City police officer during an arrest on Staten Island in 2014, has become a frequent fixture on the campaign trail with Mrs. Clinton, appearing at rallies and talking to voters.In a twist that mirrors a generational divide among many Democrats, her granddaughter, Erica Garner, has endorsed Mrs. Clinton's opponent, U.S. Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont.Ms. Garner has joined Mr. Sanders at campaign events and appeared in an ad for him.Ms. Garner isn't registered with any party, so she won't be able to vote in Tuesday's primary, according to the city Board of Elections.The intense wooing and dispatching of Ms. Carr and Ms. Garner by Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders illustrates the pivotal role of black voters in the Democratic primary, where African-Americans are expected to play a crucial role in a tightening race. It also reflects the anxieties of black voters, who won't see President Barack Obama on the ballot for the first time in nearly a decade.Mr. Garner's death--and a Staten Island grand jury's decision not to indict the officer involved--sparked protests across New York City and around the country. Now, ahead of Tuesday's primary in New York, the Democratic candidates are hoping Ms. Carr's and Ms. Garner's endorsements will help sway voters.Ben LaBolt, a longtime adviser to Mr. Obama and a Democratic strategist, said the Garner family and others like them could help motivate voters not only in the primary but in the general election as well."For a Democrat to succeed in the general they've got to turn out many of President Obama supporters as possible," Mr. LaBolt said. "The Garners serve as an emotional clarion call to address the issue and to understand the severe impact that this has had on families across the country."Mrs. Clinton's campaign pursued Ms. Carr for months, calling her at home in New York numerous times before inviting her to a private meeting in Chicago with the former first lady and other mothers whose children had died in gun violence or high-profile encounters with police.In Chicago, Ms. Carr said Mrs. Clinton sat with the mothers for more than two hours, listening to them tell stories about their children and offer her policy ideas. Also at the table: the mothers of Trayvon Martin, Michael Brown and Tamir Rice."She listened to us, asked us what we think she could do to help. She wrote it down. She didn't have her staff write it down. She did it herself," Ms. Carr said."The other mothers and I, we all looked at each other and sort of said, 'I thought nobody cared.'"Ms. Garner, 25, said she decided to consider Mr. Sanders after Mrs. Clinton was endorsed by New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio last year. She said she feels betrayed by Mr. de Blasio, who has tempered his criticism of police since thousands of officers turned their backs on him in the weeks after the grand jury declined to indict the officer involved in Mr. Garner's arrest.The officers were angry because the mayor, talking about the Garner case, said he and his wife had to teach their biracial son to be careful when interacting with police.Ms. Garner said the mayor stood with black voters and put his biracial son on display to win election in 2013, but "turned his back on us" after drawing criticism from police officers.A spokeswoman for Mr. de Blasio said the mayor "respects her views and concerns."Ms. Garner said she soon reached out to a Sanders campaign aide on Twitter. "I said, 'What can I do to help?'"We Want to Hear From YouHave something to say about an article in Greater New York? Email us, along with your contact information, at gnyltrs@wsj.com . Letters will be edited for brevity and clarity. Please include your city and state.The response, she said, was almost immediate. Since then, she has stumped for Mr. Sanders in Chicago, South Carolina, North Carolina, Ohio and elsewhere, with her 6 year-old daughter in tow.Ms. Garner and Ms. Carr said they didn't talk about their dueling endorsements with one another, and preferred to keep politics and family separate.Christina Greer, a political-science professor at Fordham University, said endorsements from Ms. Garner and Ms. Carr lend legitimacy to the presidential candidates' campaigns."This sends a message to black voters: 'We're with you,'" she said.Write to Mara Gay at mara.gay@wsj.comCredit: By Mara Gay

article name: The Wall Street I Have Known; Bernie Sanders should ask people like me--refugees from collectivist paradises--about income inequality.
article text: It takes an immigrant like me to parse the poison that Bernie Sanders is peddling to the naive youth of this country. It takes someone who has experienced socialism's failures firsthand--as I did, initially as a small child, later as a young adult--to see why Sen. Sanders is succeeding: We elders, immigrants and native-born alike, have failed to teach our children and grandchildren about the economic history and false promises of the myriad forms of socialism that infest our world.More than 75 years ago, I landed at Ellis Island as a 6-year-old child. My family had fled the despotism of National Socialism that had been foisted onto the gullible (albeit literate) German people. We were far from the only victims of collectivism. As all of us know but some refuse to admit, collectivism destroyed the economies of places like China, Russia and Cuba, and ruined the lives of millions of people.Nine years after I arrived in America, the new state of Israel came into existence, making Jews like me both proud and curious. When I was 18, imbued with idealistic fervor, I decided to help the young nation grow and prosper by working the soil. Off I went to further the goals of social justice by joining a kibbutz, or communal farm. There the painful reality of the maxim Karl Marx popularized, "from each according to his ability, to each according to his needs," hit home.As an example of kibbutz ideology: Does it make sense for a person running the washing machines in the laundry to be receiving exactly the same pay and living benefits as someone who might be the community doctor after going to medical school? That may sound like an extreme example, but the same principles apply throughout the economic structure of a collectivist economy. Unlike Chinese or Russian collectivism, Israel's was voluntary--but insane nonetheless.I left Israel three years later, in 1954, because I was an American citizen and the time had come for me to serve my country. I was drafted and inducted into the U.S. Army. After two years of active duty, stationed back in my native Germany, I realized that my future lay in the capitalist U.S., not in Israel.I came to see that I needed a college degree to get ahead in the competitive society of my home country. Because I had to work during the day to support myself and my family, I attended classes in the evening, taking eight years to get a bachelor's degree in finance and an M.B.A. While going to night school, I got my first Wall Street job.My Wall Street is the real Wall Street--not the imaginary one that Bernie Sanders demonizes daily. My Wall Street is a place filled with opportunities to succeed, even for an immigrant like me without any connections or relatives in the business. Here, I could reach the pinnacle of my profession based on merit.Unlike a certain politically ambitious Brooklynite-turned-Vermonter, I did not have to denigrate others to advance my career. To the contrary, I found wonderful mentors who were happy to reward me for hard work. Much of the job was difficult and far from fun. But I rose--and occasionally fell a bit--based on what I produced, not how many people I could get to toe some party line.My experience is far from unique. I have many colleagues who left supposed paradises, socialist countries like China, Russia and Greece, and now strive to succeed on Wall Street. They're seeking not a handout but a piece of the American Dream, just as I did. When I entered the business Wall Street was a far clubbier place than today. It has increasingly become a meritocracy open to people of every background.Sen. Sanders ought to ask some of the immigrants who work on Wall Street what they think about the opportunities that this country affords, rather than going to college campuses and attacking the financial industry to further his own political ends. He should ask some recent immigrants from India and the emerging world what the true meaning of income inequality is.Bernie Sanders and I are poster children for what poor Jews from Brooklyn or Germany can accomplish in this great land of opportunity. So I ask him: Please stop tearing down the country that has been so good to both of us.Mr. Rosenberg has worked on Wall Street for more than 50 years, most of that time at Loews Corp., where he is now the chief investment strategist.Credit: By Joe Rosenberg

article name: Hillary Clinton Leads Bernie Sanders in New York by 17 Points Ahead of Primary, Poll Finds; Back-to-back polls suggest former secretary of state is on cusp of pivotal victory next Tuesday
article text: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has built a sturdy, double-digit lead over Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders in New York ahead of Tuesday's presidential primary there, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC New York/Marist poll finds.Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Sanders by 17 percentage-points, 57% to 40%, among likely Democratic primary voters, a result in line with her 14-point advantage in a Journal/NBC News/Marist poll released earlier in the week .The back-to-back poll results suggest that Mrs. Clinton is on the cusp of a pivotal victory that would help her regain momentum after a string of embarrassing defeats and that would deliver a blow to Mr. Sanders as the two Democrats gear up for the final stretch of voting.Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders are set to square off in a televised debate Thursday night in Brooklyn, N.Y., their next-to-last such meeting before the nominating contest concludes in early June.At this point, it looks like Mr. Sanders needs a big moment to reset the race. But the new poll shows that most primary voters already have settled on a candidate, with roughly 70% of each candidate's supporters saying they strongly back their pick.Age, more than race, appears to be the defining feature in what looks like a winning coalition for Mrs. Clinton. She outpaces Mr. Sanders by a more than two-to-one margin among likely Democratic primary voters age 45 and older. He has a three-to-one advantage among likely primary voters 29 and younger.Mrs. Clinton also dominates the Vermont senator in and around New York City, a critical advantage, because that is where most of the voters live. The two are essentially tied upstate.The Journal/NBC New York/Marist poll was conducted April 10-13 and included 591 likely Democratic primary voters. The margin of error was plus or minus four percentage points.Write to Patrick O'Connor at patrick.oconnor@wsj.comCredit: By Patrick O'Connor
