article text: WASHINGTON -- In nearly every speech, Bernie Sanders reminds voters that he doesn't have a super PAC, doesn't want money from Wall Street and rejects establishment politics.Yet the Vermont senator has benefited from at least $1.5 million in backing from super PACs and from political groups that don't have to fully disclose their donors, according to filings with the Federal Election Commission.As a member of Congress, he regularly attended retreats with Wall Street lobbyists and other donors, and as a candidate for the Senate, he benefited from money that indirectly came from them. Last year, he directly accepted about $55,000 in Wall Street contributions for his Democratic presidential campaign, FEC filings show.To be sure, former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has raised far more from Wall Street donors, taking in $2.9 million last year, and the super PACs helping her collected $14.3 million from financial firms, about 30% of their total haul, according to an analysis from the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics. She has helped raise money for her primary super PAC, while Mr. Sanders hasn't raised funds for outside groups.Mrs. Clinton says outside contributions supporting her campaign don't influence her judgment. Mr. Sanders says that, for him, such contributions don't exist. "I'm the only candidate up here . . . who has no super PAC," he said Thursday during a Democratic debate.He may not have formed one of his own, but Mr. Sanders is getting help from National Nurses United for Patient Protection, a super PAC that gets its money from the nation's largest nurses' union, with nearly 185,000 members.The union doesn't have to disclose its donors, but a spokesman said the super PAC money comes exclusively from members' dues. Representatives from the union have frequently joined the senator at events, and this week launched a bus tour across South Carolina ahead of the state's Feb. 27 primary. At an Iowa campaign stop, Mr. Sanders thanked the group for being "one of the sponsors" of his campaign.Sanders spokesman Michael Briggs said labor unions have long worked for candidates. "You're talking about nurses, nurses, one of the most trusted professions in the country," he said, "versus millionaires and billionaires on Wall Street."The battle over the influence of special interests began in earnest in New Hampshire. On Monday, Mrs. Clinton drew attention to Mr. Sanders's 2006 race for the Senate, when he benefited from $200,000 in contributions from the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, known as the DSCC, which is charged with electing Democrats -- and accepts significant contributions from Wall Street interests."Sen. Sanders took $200,000 from Wall Street firms, not directly but through the Democratic Senate Campaign Committee," she told a rally in Manchester.Sanders campaign manager Jeff Weaver responded by pointing to much larger Wall Street contributions benefiting Mrs. Clinton. He said the money from the DSCC comes from many places, including individuals, labor and environmental groups. "To say that every nickel that Bernie received came from Wall Street is beyond preposterous," said Mr. Weaver.Five of the top 20 givers to the DSCC in the 2006 election cycle were Wall Street firms, two were law firms and the rest were senators' political committees.Mr. Sanders has also regularly attended the DSCC's retreats, either during the winter in Florida or during summer on Martha's Vineyard, including one as recently as July. Guests are donors who have donated the maximum amount to the party, or raised more than $100,000. Many attendees are lobbyists, lawyers and members of the financial industry.Several donors who have attended said Mr. Sanders fully participated, and didn't take the opportunity to tell Wall Street lobbyists that, as he says on the stump, their industry's business model is fraud."He was just like any other senator hobnobbing with lawyers and lobbyists from D.C.," said Rebecca Geller, a Washington attorney who attended with her husband, a financial services lobbyist. Ms. Geller, who has donated to Mrs. Clinton's campaign, said Mr. Sanders was happy to take photos with her family. "My kids have fond memories of him hanging out by the hot tub."Credit: By Laura Meckler and Rebecca Ballhaus

article name: Cardinal Bernie; Sanders won't like what a papal encyclical says about socialism.
article text: In the 1600s the sculptor Bernini had Pope Urban VIII as his benefactor. Today Bernie Sanders wants to claim Pope Francis. In the pope's second foray into American presidential politics--the first was to suggest Donald Trump is not a Christian--Francis met with the Democratic Party's socialist underdog on Saturday.Mr. Sanders's audience was granted after he participated in a Vatican conference celebrating the 25th anniversary of Pope John Paul II's encyclical Centesimus Annus. In his remarks on the encyclical, Mr. Sanders used his Vatican pulpit to declare that "the issue of wealth and income inequality" is "the great moral issue of our time."The irony is that Senator Sanders seems to be completely unaware that Centesimus Annus was one of the most pro-market documents ever to come out of the Vatican. While it certainly carries warnings about a capitalism unbounded by law and a healthy culture, it also spoke eloquently of the "human rights to private initiative, to ownership of property and to freedom in the economic sector." It also recognized that the ultimate source of wealth is not material but the human mind.As for socialism, the encyclical was unsparing. Pope John Paul II agreed with earlier popes that socialism fails as a political system because it is rooted in the denial of freedom. So perhaps it's useful for Mr. Sanders to spend time with Centesimus Annus, assuming he reads enough to see its denunciations of socialism and appreciation for what human creativity can accomplish in a free-market economy.

article name: Bernie Sanders Releases 2014 Federal Tax Return; Release fulfills promise Vermont senator made during debate with Hillary Clinton
article text: Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders fulfilled a debate promise, releasing a seven-page federal tax return from 2014 on Friday evening.The Vermont senator has been feuding with former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton over transparency. Mr. Sanders has called on Mrs. Clinton to provide transcripts of her paid speeches to big Wall Street banks like Goldman Sachs, which she was refused to do. She has challenged Mr. Sanders to release years of back tax information.Mr. Sanders agreed in Thursday's Brooklyn debate to provide his 2014 returns, calling them "very boring."Mrs. Clinton has released eight years of full tax information on her website. Republican front-runner Donald Trump has provided no tax information, while Sen. Ted Cruz and Ohio Gov. John Kasich have released partial returns for several years.Mr. Sanders produced a two-page summary of his 2014 tax information in June. Friday's release gave a fuller account of his federal taxes for the same year. He didn't release any state-level tax information.The 2014 return added context to Mr. Sanders's charitable contributions and his wife's business income.The returns show that Mr. Sanders gave $8,350 to charity. The returns don't list the recipients.The return also showed Jane Sanders earning $4,900 for her work as a commissioner on the Texas Low-Level Radioactive Waste Disposal Compact Commission.The family earned $156,411 in wages and collected an additional $39,281 in Social Security benefits. They paid $27,653 for an effective tax rate of 13.5%.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Byron Tau

article name: Bernie Sanders Faces a Daunting Task: Win Black Votes; Lack of support in key group threatens to sink Democrat's presidential campaign against rival Hillary Clinton
article text: Coming off a lopsided loss in New York , Sen. Bernie Sanders's campaign team pointed to an enduring problem that could sink his struggling presidential bid if it isn't fixed: his failure to win over more African-American voters.Black voters in New York on Tuesday were nearly a quarter of the Democratic electorate and favored Hillary Clinton by a 50-point margin, exit polls showed, locking in a victory that gives her a nearly insurmountable lead in delegates."I am hopeful going forward we will do better," said Tad Devine, a senior campaign adviser to Mr. Sanders. "And we know we must. We're not going to win New Jersey unless we improve our numbers with African-American voters."Meanwhile, some Democrats worry the increasingly harsh tone of the campaign could make it tougher to unify the party for the general election, but it isn't clear the feuding will end anytime soon.During the course of his campaign, Mr. Sanders has tried to make inroads with African-Americans, showcasing endorsements from black celebrities, intellectuals and civil-rights activists. But the outreach isn't paying dividends at the polls.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Analysis: Presidential Front-Runners Get Breathing Room After New York Vote* Hillary Clinton Ends Sanders's Winning Streak With N.Y. Win* New Yorkers Cast Their Ballots With Mixed Feelings* Both Parties' Voters Distrust Wall Street in Exit Polls* Voters Report Irregularities at Poll Sites* For New Yorkers, a Rare Primary of Consequence* Fight Over Delegate Rules Escalates for Both Parties* Recap: New York PrimaryIf the trend persists, Mr. Sanders could see his hopes of a comeback extinguished. Aside from California and Pennsylvania, the two states that offer the most delegates through the rest of the calendar are Maryland and New Jersey. In the 2008 Democratic primary, blacks accounted for 23% of Democratic voters in New Jersey, 37% in Maryland.The Sanders campaign is trying again to reach out to black voters. On Wednesday, it released two new TV ads that will air in Maryland targeting black voters. One spot features African-American actor Danny Glover vouching for Mr. Sanders's commitment to civil rights. "I think Bernie is with us," Mr. Glover says.The day after the New York primary was fairly quiet. Mr. Sanders went home to Burlington, Vt. Mrs. Clinton held a forum about gun violence in Philadelphia that featured former Attorney General Eric Holder and several African-American women who have lost children in shootings or police custody.Mrs. Clinton's 16-point win in New York left both campaigns with a new set of strategic decisions to make. In the run-up to the New York primary, Mr. Sanders said repeatedly that he would win the state. Inside the campaign, aides anticipated a loss in New York, though they believed the margin would be closer, Mr. Devine said.With Mrs. Clinton netting 33 more delegates in New York--and five states, including Maryland, voting next Tuesday--the Sanders campaign must rethink the path needed to close the gap with Mrs. Clinton, he said.The hurdle is daunting. David Wasserman of the nonpartisan Cook Political Report estimated that Mr. Sanders needs to capture 59% of the remaining pledged delegates to erase Mrs. Clinton's lead."We're going to have to win, and we're going to have to win big," Mr. Devine said. "New York was a setback in terms of the scope of her victory. ... We're trying to figure out a realistic way to win this."For her part, Mrs. Clinton must decide when to shift focus from Mr. Sanders to her likely showdown with the Republican nominee in the fall. People familiar with her campaign's thinking on that question said not to expect Mrs. Clinton to move into a general-election posture before the five contests next Tuesday.Another question for both campaigns is what to do about a tone that has become caustic. Robert Reich, a Sanders supporter who served as labor secretary under former President Bill Clinton, posted a message on Facebook calling on both campaigns to knock it off."We will need to join together to ensure one of them becomes president," he wrote. "It's important we not jeopardize that future joint effort through excessive divisiveness now."A similar dynamic played out in 2008, when Mrs. Clinton lost the nomination to then-Sen. Barack Obama. Sending a message to her disappointed supporters, Mrs. Clinton quit the race and then campaigned with her rival in a New Hampshire town called Unity. Mr. Obama hired members of her defunct campaign team in a step toward reconciliation.Mr. Sanders says he is determined to fight until the final contest in Washington, D.C., on June 14.On Wednesday, the Sanders campaign sent out a fund-raising appeal based on a report in Politico that a Clinton campaign aide used an obscenity in discussing Mr. Sanders."Let's send our own message back to the Clinton campaign in a language they're certain to understand," wrote Sanders campaign manager Jeff Weaver, requesting a donation.Clinton allies believe Mr. Sanders is the one instigating the attacks. A Senate colleague of Mr. Sanders, Democratic leader Harry Reid of Nevada, said Mr. Sanders should tone down his rhetoric."He's never had a negative campaign, he's said, and he's never run a negative ad, and I think he's losing touch with that," Mr. Reid said when asked whether Mr. Sanders's attacks were damaging Mrs. Clinton.Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Hillary Clinton Wins New York's Democratic Primary; Front-runner's home-state victory makes it more unlikely Bernie Sanders can catch her in the delegate chase
article text: Hillary Clinton decisively won her home-state New York primary Tuesday, shutting down one of the few remaining chances for rival Bernie Sanders to slow her march to the Democratic presidential nomination.Mr. Sanders had pointed to New York, where he was born, as a place where he could take a bite out of Mrs. Clinton's formidable lead in convention delegates. He campaigned hard in what became a sharp-edged fight for the state, delivering his call for a political revolution to thousands of people who crowded a series of outdoor rallies.But Mrs. Clinton, who represented the state for eight years in the Senate, racked up impressive vote totals in New York City, with its diverse electorate, and in its populous suburban counties. Mr. Sanders, a Vermont senator, performed better upstate.With 95% of precincts reporting, Mrs. Clinton had a commanding 58% of the vote to Mr. Sanders's 42%."The race for the Democratic nomination is in the home stretch, and victory is in sight!" Mrs. Clinton told cheering supporters Tuesday in New York City, appearing on stage with her husband, former President Bill Clinton, who campaigned heavily on her behalf.She focused sharply on the general election ahead, said almost nothing critical of Mr. Sanders and began what may be a long process of unifying the party around her. "To all the people who supported Sen. Sanders, I believe there is much more that unites us than divides us," she said.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Analysis: Front-Runners Get Breathing Room After N.Y. Vote* Donald Trump Wins N.Y. GOP Primary* New Yorkers Cast Primary Votes With Mixed Feelings* N.Y. Voters Report Irregularities at Poll Sites* For New Yorkers, a Rare Primary of Consequence* Both Parties' Voters Distrust Wall Street in Exit Polls* The Damage Bernie's Hillary Bashing May Do* Fight Over Delegate Rules Escalates* Recap: New York Primary* Who's Winning the Delegate Race?Speaking ahead of the results Tuesday evening, Mr. Sanders conceded nothing, telling a crowd at Penn State University that his campaign was challenging the notion that change isn't possible and "this is the way it always will be.""And that is why we're going to win this election," he said.Mr. Sanders also took several now-familiar shots at Mrs. Clinton, and earlier in the day, aides said his recent sharp tone wasn't likely to change even with a New York loss. But if Mrs. Clinton backs off him, they said, he may do the same.The delegate math is steeply against Mr. Sanders. He came into the New York contest having won eight of the past nine contests and drawing tens of thousands of people to his rallies. But his delegate gain from those mostly small-state victories was modest.Heading into New York's voting, Mrs. Clinton had an advantage of 244 pledged delegates, the type chosen by voters, according to preliminary Associated Press tallies.Overall, she had 1,289 pledged delegates, and when you include superdelegates--party leaders who can support anyone--supporting her, Mrs. Clinton's total jumped to 1,758 to his 1,076. A total of 2,383 delegates is needed to claim the nomination.Mrs. Clinton has won most of the large, diverse states, and the Vermont senator's recent wins have done little to cut into a yawning delegate deficit. Now just three large states remain on the Democratic calendar--Pennsylvania next week, and California and New Jersey in June.The victory was a relief for Mrs. Clinton, who campaigned hard to avoid what would have been an embarrassing loss, even one that may not have prevented her from winning the nomination.Mr. Sanders faced tough odds from the outset, in part because the state has a large proportion of nonwhite voters, who have generally favored Mrs. Clinton. In addition, New York barred independents, who have been friendly to Mr. Sanders, from voting in party primaries, and it required voters who wanted to switch party affiliation to do so six months ago.But ahead of the results, top Sanders advisers said the senator had no plans to take the pressure off his Democratic rival as long as she keeps up her critiques of the Vermont senator."We have received a lot of innuendo and dismissiveness and demeaning comments from the Clinton campaign--from the secretary herself and from her surrogates," Jane Sanders, the candidate's wife and a close adviser, said in an interview. "He's not going to sit by and just not respond."Clinton advisers are hoping the New York victory will allow the former secretary of state to turn her attention away from the primary race and to the fall contest. For many weeks, Mrs. Clinton has taken shots at her GOP opponents, but Mr. Sanders's strength has forced her to keep much of her focus on the primary."You have to unify the party, and you don't want to prematurely look past someone who has earned a lot of votes and put up a strong fight," one senior adviser said. "The timing is everything."During the campaign for New York, the Vermont senator ramped up his attacks on his rival. He aired a TV ad contrasting his rival's high-paid Wall Street speeches with her opposition to raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. (Mrs. Clinton supports a $12 federal floor.)Mr. Sanders also said her positions made her unqualified for the presidency, though he quickly backed away from that assertion .Mrs. Clinton also was tough, particularly on the issue of gun restrictions, suggesting Mr. Sanders isn't being truthful about his record and accusing him of personally blocking a lawsuit by families of children killed in the 2012 school massacre in Newtown, Conn.Sanders senior adviser Tad Devine said Mrs. Clinton and her supporters have the power to change the tenor of the race. "If the Clinton campaign stops their attacks, that will go a long way to changing the tone," he said after the race was called.Clinton communications director Jennifer Palmieri said Tuesday night that in light of Mrs. Clinton's dominant position, Mr. Sanders "has to decide if he's going to stay on this destructive path where he's making personal character attacks...Or will he return to running the campaign on issues?"One Sanders adviser said that even if the senator doesn't win the nomination, he hopes that picking up as many delegates as possible would give him leverage to press his agenda at the Philadelphia convention."Does Bernie think he can win? He thinks he can win, yes--and he [also] is trying to get delegates to push his issues," said Larry Cohen, a longtime labor leader and a Sanders adviser.Both campaigns worked to turn out supporters. At an elementary school in the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn, home to many liberal Democrats, Michael DeMaio, a 48-year-old restaurant manager, at one point backed Mrs. Clinton but now said he would vote for Mr. Sanders."I'm down with his revolution idea," he said. "I just feel like things need to be changed from the bottom up."Brian Ezra, a real-estate developer, typified the more practical-minded Clinton voter."It seems like the more sensible decision," he said, citing her experience, particularly on foreign policy. "I like a lot of the ideas Sanders has--I really do. But I think Clinton is the smarter choice."Erica Orden contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Bernie Sanders Undaunted by Hillary Clinton's Delegate Lead; A New York victory for Clinton would make it more unlikely for Sanders to catch her in the delegate chase
article text: NEW YORK--Regardless of the final results of Tuesday's Democratic primary in New York, one thing seemed certain: Bernie Sanders has no intention of backing off.A Hillary Clinton victory in her home state would make it all the more unlikely that Mr. Sanders can catch her in the delegate chase. But the Sanders team made clear that he would continue to compete and wouldn't back off his pointed critique of Mrs. Clinton as long as she keeps after him. That prospect of a drawn-out battle worries some of Mrs. Clinton's supporters who see her as the inevitable nominee and want to begin unifying the party around her."We have received a lot of innuendo and dismissiveness and demeaning comments from the Clinton campaign--from the secretary herself and from her surrogates," Jane Sanders, the candidate's wife and a close adviser, said in an interview. "He's not going to sit by and just not respond."Mr. Sanders came into the New York contest having won eight of the past nine contests. But his delegate gain from those mostly small-state victories was modest: He gained a net 84 pledged delegates, the type chosen by voters who are committed to a particular candidate. Mrs. Clinton still has an advantage of 244 such delegates, according to preliminary Associated Press tallies.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Live Coverage: New York Primary Results* New York Voters Report Irregularities at Poll Sites* For New Yorkers, a Rare Primary of Consequence* Clinton, Sanders Make Closing Arguments to New Yorkers* Who's Winning the Delegate Race?* The Damage Bernie's Hillary Bashing May Do* Fight Over Delegate Rules Escalates for Both Parties* Delaware Primary Attracting More Attention Than Usual* Why the Presidential Front-Runners Need a New York WinGoing into New York's voting, Mrs. Clinton had 1,289 pledged delegates, and when you include superdelegates--party leaders who can support anyone--her total jumps to 1,758 to his 1,076. A total of 2,383 delegates is needed to claim the nomination.Mr. Sanders put huge emphasis on New York, advertising heavily and insisting that the two rivals debate in Brooklyn . His advisers repeatedly predicted victory, hoping to deliver a stinging upset to a woman who had represented New York for eight years in the Senate.For their part, Clinton advisers were hoping a solid New York victory would allow the former secretary of state to turn her attention away from the primary race and to the fall contest. At a campaign stop Monday night, Mrs. Clinton said she was "hoping to wrap up the Democratic nomination" in New York, before quickly catching herself and adding, "But! But. But I'm not taking anything for granted." The Clinton campaign is anxious to put in place staff in battleground states. But officials are also sensitive to any suggestion that they are trying to push Mr. Sanders out of the race.For many weeks, Mrs. Clinton has taken shots at her GOP opponents, but Mr. Sanders's strength has forced her to keep much of her focus on the primary."You have to unify the party, and you don't want to prematurely look past someone who has earned a lot of votes and put up a strong fight," one senior adviser said. "The timing is everything."One Sanders adviser said the senator is looking to pick up as many delegates as possible even if he loses. A large delegate total would give him leverage to press his agenda at the Philadelphia convention, including changes to the campaign finance system and language in the party's platform."Does Bernie think he can win? He thinks he can win, yes--and he [also] is trying to get delegates to push his issues," said Larry Cohen, a longtime labor leader and a Sanders adviser.Mr. Cohen predicted that Mr. Sanders would keep up the pressure on Mrs. Clinton until the final primary contests in June, while keeping true to his pledge to support her if she is the nominee.In New York, both candidates landed blows , but Mr. Sanders in particular ramped up his attacks. He aired a TV ad contrasting his rival's high-paid Wall Street speeches with her opposition to raising the federal minimum wage to $15 an hour. (Mrs. Clinton supports a $12 federal floor.)Mr. Sanders also said her positions made her unqualified for the presidency, though he quickly backed away from that assertion . In his stump speech, he took what had been a passing reference to her paid speeches and expanded it into a mocking, extended polemic. And on Monday, his campaign accused Mrs. Clinton of colluding with the Democratic National Committee to evade campaign-finance laws.Mrs. Clinton also was tough, particularly on the issue of gun restrictions, suggesting Mr. Sanders isn't being truthful about his record and accusing him of personally blocking a lawsuit by families of children killed in the 2012 school massacre in Newtown, Conn.Sanders senior adviser Tad Devine said Mrs. Clinton and her supporters have the power to change the tenor of the race. He said it was possible Mr. Sanders would continue his tough approach until the last voting in June."If they want a nice tone in this campaign, I would suggest they lead by example," he said.The Sanders campaign faced serious headwinds due to New York rules that barred independents, who have often favored Mr. Sanders, from participating in the primaries.On Tuesday, Mr. Sanders came face-to-face with the challenge while strolling through Midtown Manhattan. Mike Cantalupo, age 21, called out to ask Mr. Sanders what he thought about this "closed primary system." He then confessed that he is a registered independent who was late trying to change his status in order to vote for Mr. Sanders."Oh, here it is. Here it is. This is the problem," Mr. Sanders said.Both campaigns worked to turn out supporters. At an elementary school in the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn, home to many liberal Democrats, Michael DeMaio, a 48-year-old restaurant manager, at one point backed Mrs. Clinton but now said he would vote for Mr. Sanders."I'm down with his revolution idea," he said. "I just feel like things need to be changed from the bottom up."Brian Ezra, a real-estate developer, typified a more practical-minded Clinton voter."It seems like the more sensible decision," he said, citing her experience, particularly on foreign policy. "I like a lot of the ideas Sanders has--I really do. But I think Clinton is the smarter choice."Erica Orden contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: New York Primary Sets Up Final Stages of 2016 Election; Hillary Clinton, Donald Trump remain front-runners; state amounts to a must-win for Sen. Bernie Sanders
article text: Amid a raucous battle in their home state, New Yorkers Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump and their rivals prepare to pivot to the final stretch of the campaign.Mrs. Clinton has held a substantial lead in the Democratic race for weeks, meaning Tuesday's New York primary amounts to a must-win for Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders. Aides say his pointed rhetoric against the former secretary of state is likely to continue, despite calls in some quarters for him to pull back.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* New York Primary: Live Coverage* Donald Trump Is Poised to Pad Delegate Lead, but Still Faces Long Road* For New Yorkers, a Rare Primary of Consequence* Voters Report Irregularities at Poll Sites* New York Primaries: Five Things to Watch* Fight Over Delegate Rules Escalates for Both PartiesMr. Sanders came into the New York contest having won eight of the last nine contests, and drawing tens of thousands of people to his rallies across the state. But his delegate gain from those mostly small-state victories was modest.Mrs. Clinton has won most of the large, diverse states, and the Vermont senator's recent wins have done little to cut into a yawning delegate deficit. After Tuesday, just three large states remain on the Democratic calendar--Pennsylvania next week , and California and New Jersey, which don't vote until June.On the Republican side, Texas Sen. Ted Cruz is expected to come in a distant third behind Ohio Gov. John Kasich in New York, losing another big cache of delegates to Mr. Trump after beating him in a string of smaller states over the past month, from Utah to Wisconsin to Wyoming. He now must compete in five East Coast states next Tuesday favorable to Mr. Trump--Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania and Rhode Island. But he is counting on winning enough delegates in May to deprive the front-runner of the majority needed to clinch the nomination outright on the first ballot at the GOP convention."Trump was expected to win his home state," said Cruz spokeswoman Alice Stewart of the New York contest. "What we are about is picking up delegates."Losing New York would make it mathematically impossible for Mr. Cruz in the remaining primaries to get to the needed 1,237 bound delegates before the July convention. But he can still pick up enough delegates to keep Mr. Trump from hitting that magic number before they get to Cleveland.Mr. Cruz scheduled his election-night rally for Philadelphia, and will then head across Pennsylvania to Hershey, signaling some hope of picking up a share of the state's 71 delegates, which will include 54 not bound to any specific candidate. But Mr. Trump has been running up big leads on the East Coast, generally too liberal to be Cruz country.Mr. Cruz's supporters--and other anti-Trump Republicans--see their next big chance for a statewide win in Indiana on May 3 and Nebraska May 10. Both are more-conservative states with large evangelical populations. Their primaries are closed, the kind of all-Republican affairs that tend to favor Mr. Cruz over Mr. Trump, who has benefited in states that allow crossover voting by Democrats and independents."Both Indiana and Nebraska represent big opportunities" to block Mr. Trump, said Katie Packer, chairman of the anti-Trump group, Our Principles PAC. "The voters there look more like Iowa and Wisconsin than they do New York."The battle for Indiana's 57 delegates is already stirring. Mr. Trump is holding a rally in Indianapolis Wednesday. Mr. Cruz appears at a state GOP dinner Thursday and his wife Heidi is making five appearances over two days later this week.Nebraska is a winner-take-all primary, which awards all 36 of the delegate slots to the candidate with the highest statewide vote total.Mr. Cruz has won the neighboring states of Iowa, Colorado and Wyoming. The state's popular junior senator, Ben Sasse, has been a vocal leader of the anti-Trump movement and announced that he had cast an early ballot for Mr. Cruz.The biggest target for Mr. Cruz and his rivals is California, which votes June 7, the last day of the primary season. The state will award the nation's largest bounty of delegates. Of the state's 172 delegates, 13 are awarded to the candidate with the most statewide votes. The rest are allocated to the winner in each congressional district.Statewide, most polls show Mr. Trump in the lead: The Real Clear Politics average of recent polls gave Mr. Trump 40.4% of the GOP primary vote in California to Mr. Cruz's 31.4 and Mr. Kasich's 15.8.But with so many delegates awarded by congressional district, the campaigns are preparing to fight over the state as an amalgam of mini-primaries. Mr. Cruz has already been to California to campaign. He has two senior advisers who are former chairmen of the California Republican Party. His Cuban family roots could give him a leg up among the state's large population of Hispanic voters, although Mr. Cruz tends not to dwell on his ethnic background.Mr. Trump's campaign is going through a shake-up, as newly hired Republican operatives Paul Manafort and Rick Wiley take more responsibility from campaign manager Corey Lewandowski. Stuart Jolly, the national field director who was close to Mr. Lewandowski, resigned Monday. Mr. Jolly had never worked on a campaign before and had been asked to report to Mr. Wiley.Mr. Wiley is among the Trump officials headed to the Republican National Committee meeting this week in Florida, where officials will discuss potential rules changes to the party's convention in Cleveland.In addition to Messrs. Manafort and Wiley, the campaign is starting to hire other experienced staffers and dispatch them to states with upcoming primaries.A small band of Mr. Trump's supporters on Capitol Hill, who have begun meeting weekly, has aired concerns about the campaign's lack of expertise on convention delegates and lean budget for field operations and paid advertising."That was a rough bump, but that transition now has been made," said Rep. Duncan Hunter of California. "The Trump campaign has gone from an insurgency campaign to a more what you would think of as a normal political campaign."A Trump spokeswoman, Hope Hicks, didn't provide any details about the staff changes. "The campaign continues to grow as Mr. Trump remains the definitive front-runner for the Republican nomination," she said.Even though Mr. Trump leads in delegates and is the only candidate who could win without a contested convention, his campaign doesn't employ a scheduler--a role that in other national campaigns often requires multiple staffers. Those duties are passed off to Mr. Trump's secretaries.But with so many delegates awarded by congressional district, the campaigns are preparing to fight over the state as an amalgam of mini-primaries. Mr. Cruz has already been out to California to campaign. He has two senior advisors who are former chairmen of the California Republican party.Reid Epstein and Kristina Peterson contributed to this article.Credit: By Janet Hook, Beth Reinhard and Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Make Their Closing Arguments to New Yorkers; Front-runner reaches out to minorities and women; Vermont senator attracts massive crowds before Tuesday primary
article text: NEW YORK--Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton closed out the race for New York with an aggressive outreach to women and nonwhite voters, as she labored to put rival Bernie Sanders in the rearview mirror.Polls showed the former New York senator with a solid lead in her adopted state ahead of Tuesday's primary, though her aides cautioned the race may be tighter than those surveys would suggest. Mr. Sanders is drawing the most energetic signs of support, with 28,000 flocking to a rally in Brooklyn on Sunday, and 27,000 in Manhattan last week.More on Election 2016Capital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Live Coverage: New York Primary* Clinton's Lead Narrows Among Democratic Primary Voters, Poll Says* New Yorkers Head to the Polls on Primary Day* Trump Pushes for Big Win in New York* New York Primaries: Five Things to Watch* Republican Voters Want Say in Choosing Nominee, Poll Finds"I never count any chickens before they hatch," Mrs. Clinton said from the trail.With just a few large states left to vote, Mr. Sanders needs a victory here Tuesday if he is to have any chance of catching up to Mrs. Clinton's substantial delegate lead.Both candidates focused their final days around New York's five boroughs, where most of Tuesday's Democratic votes are expected to be cast. In Queens, Mrs. Clinton visited a group of mostly Hispanic carwash workers who recently formed a union, and she tried her first bubble tea as she greeted Asian voters at a food court in Flushing.On Monday evening, Mrs. Clinton greeted a mix of workers--from South Asia, Latin America, Africa and the Middle East--at the restaurant Colors, formed by people who worked at the restaurant that once sat atop the World Trade Center.Her strongest support has come from African-American voters. At weekend events, both Mrs. Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, were accompanied by members of the Congressional Black Caucus, who repeatedly vouched for her.Clinton aides said the issue of gun violence was particularly important in motivating black voters to the polls, and the former secretary of state hit on the topic repeatedly.At a rally aimed at women on Monday in Manhattan, Mrs. Clinton cited Mr. Sanders's support for a bill that gave gun manufacturers immunity from lawsuits. She and then-Sen. Barack Obama voted against it, she said. "Bernie Sanders voted for it!""Sen. Sanders talks a lot about the greed and recklessness of Wall Street," she said. "But what about the greed and recklessness of the gun manufacturers?"Mr. Sanders said in a CNN interview Monday that lawsuits, including one filed by parents of children killed in Newtown, Conn., should be allowed to proceed, but he isn't sure if they have merit. "If I sell you a legal product, am I liable for the crazy thing that you do with it? I think not," he said.It isn't a topic he typically addresses on the stump. At a huge rally Sunday, he made only oblique reference to the matter. "Our job is to give kids jobs, not guns," he said.Mr. Sanders has worked to cut into Mrs. Clinton's support among nonwhite voters, and his aides say he has made progress with younger African-Americans. In New York, he held events devoted to racial issues and showcased endorsements from prominent black leaders, including entertainer Harry Belafonte. On Monday, he held a roundtable discussion on Puerto Rican issues, including his view that creditors must be forced to accept lower payments to resolve the island's debt crisis.But on the eve of the New York vote, Mr. Sanders seemed to be relying more on a shock-and-awe strategy, staging huge outdoor rallies that demonstrated the grass-roots enthusiasm that his campaign has generated.Mr. Sanders spoke to thousands of supporters in Long Island City on Monday at his final rally before the New York primary. He was introduced by actor Danny Glover as "the next president of the United States." Mr. Sanders said that "if we get a large voter turnout tomorrow, we're going to win here in New York."Earlier on Monday, Mr. Sanders led a somewhat chaotic procession through the streets of Queens, where he ambled along greeting everyone from teenage twin boys to a woman who emerged from a beauty salon, dye still in her hair.The Clinton events were generally smaller and tamer, but the campaign covered twice the ground as it deployed the former president, who put particular focus on turning out minority voters.Mr. Clinton spoke at three African-American churches on Sunday in Queens and on Long Island. Sitting in the pews at Antioch Baptist Church in Queens were six black women who lost family and loved ones to gun violence. He then led a trio of outdoor rallies in some of New York City's most diverse neighborhoods.He touched several issues of particular importance to the black community. He said police forces should more closely mirror the racial and ethnic makeup of the neighborhoods they patrol. He highlighted rising incomes for African-Americans when he was president. And Mr. Clinton called for tougher gun laws and shorter prison sentences for nonviolent offenders.At a housing complex in Queens, he was introduced by Rep. John Lewis of Georgia, a leader of the civil-rights movement who was beaten during a 1965 march across the Edmund Pettus Bridge in Selma, Ala.Mr. Lewis dramatically cast the election in terms of racial progress. "I gave a little blood on that bridge in Selma, Alabama, for the right to vote," Mr. Lewis said.Erica Orden contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Peter Nicholas

article name: Bernie Sanders, Hillary Clinton Spar Ahead of New York Primary; Democrats exchange tough words in whirlwind campaigning across New York City
article text: NEW YORK--The Democratic presidential candidates returned to the campaign trail Sunday in New York City for a two-day sprint to Tuesday's primary here, with Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders exchanging tough words across town.By day's end, Mrs. Clinton and her husband, the former president, had between them touched all five boroughs, plus suburban spots in Westchester County and Long Island, blanketing the metro area that will deliver as much as 70% of Tuesday's vote. Along the way she danced to Latin rhythms at a campaign block party.Mr. Sanders, meanwhile, addressed a record-breaking crowd in a Brooklyn park. He also appeared at a public housing complex, released a plan for affordable housing and spoke at a Harlem church service.Mr. Sanders, a Vermont senator, needs a big win in New York if he is to have any chance of closing Mrs. Clinton's lead in delegates. For Mrs. Clinton, who polls show is maintaining a double-digit lead, it would be deeply embarrassing to lose in her adopted home state where she served as a senator.Both candidates were back in New York after more than a day away from the state--Mr. Sanders to the Vatican for a conference and a brief greeting with Pope Francis, and Mrs. Clinton for fundraisers including a high-dollar event at the California home of actor George Clooney.The day began with both candidates appearing on Sunday talk shows. Speaking on ABC, Mrs. Clinton sought to clarify her position when she said she backed a minimum-wage increase modeled after New York's $15-an-hour plan, which will be phased in and sensitive to local economic conditions."We have to evaluate it as we go," she said. "If the Congress passes that, of course I would sign it."The racial diversity of the Clinton coalition was on display Sunday as she began her day at a suburban African-American church, then campaigned in the largely Dominican neighborhood of Washington Heights, in northern Manhattan. Most of the politicians who preceded her spoke in Spanish to a crowd that included many people who spoke little English."It doesn't look like a Whole Foods checkout line," one man at the rally, Evan Shapiro, 48, said approvingly. An adjunct professor at New York University, he also attended a huge Sanders rally near his school last week and said he was dismayed by the lack of diversity.After Mrs. Clinton's brief remarks, peppy merengue music played and the former secretary of state began bouncing to the beat. As her hands waved in the air, state Sen. Adriano Espaillat took them into his own and then twirled around her.From there, she traveled to the Brooklyn neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant, where a largely African-American crowd chanted "Madam President!"She took several shots at Mr. Sanders. "It's easy to diagnose the problem. You've got to be able to solve the problem," she said. She lingered over the issue of gun control, a subject where the Clinton campaign believes Mr. Sanders is vulnerable.Speaking on Staten Island, where many victims of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks lived, Mrs. Clinton struck a rare but vigorous bipartisan tone, saying people in both parties worked together without question after the attacks. She singled out then-President George W. Bush for helping get the city needed funds. "I publicly say, 'Thank you, President George W. Bush.'"Mr. Sanders on Sunday released an affordable housing plan that would expand a federal trust fund created in 2008 to finance such projects. He also called for promoting homeownership by expanding government-backed lending programs that allow borrowers to make small or no down payments.Several other proposals overlap with those that Mrs. Clinton unveiled earlier this year. Both candidates support tougher curbs on predatory lending and expanded counseling for first-time home buyers.At the center of Mrs. Clinton's plan, unveiled in February, is a $25 billion housing investment program that would build more affordable rental housing and boost homeownership for low-income Americans by matching up to $10,000 in savings for a down payment.Later in the day, Mr. Sanders addressed more than 28,000 people under the bright sun in Brooklyn's Prospect Park, in what the campaign said was a record turnout. He laid into Mrs. Clinton on the familiar issues of fracking for energy, trade, her 2002 vote to authorize the Iraq war and the minimum wage. He said her $12 wage-floor proposal was "not bad, but not good enough. We need to raise the minimum wage to 15 bucks an hour."Many of Mr. Sanders's events are large rallies, but on Saturday night he joined at roundtable at a Brooklyn church, where he spoke in unusually personal terms about how his fight for the poor relates to his own Brooklyn childhood, saying that there was "constant tension" between his parents over money.His said that a modest salary was "pretty good" for his father, who emigrated from Poland at age 17. But he explained, "My mother was born in this country and her dreams were bigger.""What I learned at a very young age was when you're a kid and hear your parents yelling at each other is a very difficult and confusing thing," he said.Nick Timiraos contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Erica Orden at erica.orden@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Erica Orden

article name: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders Hit Hard in New York Debate; Democratic candidates clash on topics from Israel to Wall Street in possibly their most heated debate
article text: NEW YORK--Facing a pivotal Democratic primary next week in New York , Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders clashed in a debate Thursday in Brooklyn over questions of judgment and their readiness for assuming the presidency.The showdown was one of Mr. Sanders's last chances to change the trajectory of the primary race, and, egged on by a boisterous audience, he took an aggressive posture, often interrupting his rival and talking over the moderators--as did Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders hit the Democratic front-runner on a variety of familiar fronts: taking direct aim at her ties to Wall Street, her past decision-making and her more moderate policy agenda.Mrs. Clinton spent much of the evening talking up her record and that of President Barack Obama. She also cast herself as the only real Democrat in the race who has worked to help the party and other candidates.Noting that she has won more votes than Mr. Sanders and built a national campaign, she said her candidacy is one "that will not only capture the Democratic nomination but a campaign that will defeat whoever the Republicans end up nominating."The pair disagreed sharply about Israel, with Mr. Sanders suggesting Mrs. Clinton was favoring Israel in its long-running dispute with the Palestinians."Long term there will never be peace in that region unless the United States plays a role, an evenhanded role," he said. He said that in addressing the leading U.S. lobby for Israel, Mrs. Clinton hadn't even discussed the needs of the Palestinian people.Mrs. Clinton said she does sympathize with Israelis who she said are constantly under terrorist attack, saying the nation has a right to defend itself. As president, though, she said she would be fair and cited her work as secretary of state."I'm the person who held the last three meetings between the president of the Palestinian Authority and the prime minister of Israel," she said, adding there were "only four of us in the room."The Vermont senator backed off earlier comments suggesting that the former secretary of state wasn't qualified to be president but condemned her decisions to vote for the Iraq war and to accept millions of dollars in support from super PACs. "Does Secretary Clinton have the experience and the intelligence to be a president? Of course she does," he said. "But I do question her judgment."Mrs. Clinton said the senator's recent interview with the New York Daily News editorial board revealed a lack of understanding of foreign policy and the financial industry, and that Mr. Obama's selection of her as the nation's top diplomat illustrates his faith in her leadership. "Talk about judgment and talk about the kinds of problems he had answering questions about even his core issues," she said. "I think you need to have the judgment on day one."Mr. Sanders came to the ninth Democratic debate in urgent need of a win. His path to the nomination has narrowed significantly as Mrs. Clinton has built a commanding lead in pledged delegates.A loss in Tuesday's New York primary would leave Mr. Sanders with little hope of catching Mrs. Clinton, and a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll showed her leading by 17 percentage points among likely New York Democratic primary voters.In the debate, Mr. Sanders blasted Mrs. Clinton's claim that she can rein in Wall Street banks after accepting fees and campaign donations from these interests. "Do we really feel confident about a candidate saying she's going to bring change in America when she's so dependent on big-money interests? I don't think so," he said.Asked to name an example of where Wall Street money influenced Mrs. Clinton's judgment, Mr. Sanders cited the decision not to break up the banks after the financial crisis plunged the U.S. into the worst economic downturn since the Great Depression.But Mrs. Clinton, who wasn't in Congress at the time, shot back: "He cannot come up with any example because there is no example."She said that the legislative response to the banking crisis was the Dodd-Frank law, passed while she was secretary of state, and that as a senator from New York she was critical of the financial sector and called out their bad behavior."Secretary Clinton called them out," Mr. Sanders replied sarcastically. "Oh my goodness they must have been really crushed by this." He asked if that was "before or after" she received large payments for speeches to Wall Street firms.Mr. Sanders has been pressing her to release transcripts of those speeches. Mrs. Clinton repeated her promise to release her transcripts when all other candidates who gave paid speeches do the same.She also asked Mr. Sanders why he hasn't released his tax returns. He said he would release his 2014 return Friday but cautioned that it would be "very boring" and prove he is one of the least-wealthy members of the U.S. Senate.Mr. Sanders, who is mounting an aggressive effort to court African-American voters, must cut into the constituency that has vaulted Mrs. Clinton to a big delegate lead in the Democratic presidential campaign. While that is now focused on Tuesday's primary, it could reverberate in states that will cast ballots a week after New York on April 26.African-Americans accounted for more than one-third of Democratic voters in Maryland, for example, during the 2008 primary fight between Mrs. Clinton and then-Sen. Barack Obama. About 20% of those who cast ballots in the party's Pennsylvania primary that year were minorities, and about 15% who voted in the New York primary that year were black, according to exit polls.In a bid to reintroduce himself, Mr. Sanders is airing two TV spots in New York featuring prominent African-Americans and showcasing endorsements from civil-rights activists.He also took aim at former President Bill Clinton over a recent clash with black protesters who objected to the crime-and-punishment practices in the 1990s. It is unclear how effective that tactic may be, given that Mr. Clinton's approval rating among all African-Americans is 89%, according to a February Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Recap: Thursday's Democratic Debate in Brooklyn* Hillary Clinton Leads Bernie Sanders in New York by 17 Points Ahead of Primary, Poll Finds* How Hillary Clinton's Tone Has Shifted on Fracking* Racial Issues Take Center Stage for Sanders, Clinton in New York* Sanders, Clinton Work to Mobilize Labor Supporters* Prosecutors Won't Charge Trump Campaign Manager With Battery* Oregon's Merkley Becomes First Senator to Endorse Sanders* John Kasich Sees a Path Through the NortheastPressed during the debate, Mrs. Clinton said she was sorry for some of the unexpected ramifications of the crime bill, saying they had "unfortunate impact" on families. Mr. Sanders also supported the legislation.The two candidates then shifted to a caustic exchange over gun-control laws. Moderator Wolf Blitzer asked Mrs. Clinton about her statement on the trail that Vermont, with little gun control regulation, has per capita the greatest number of guns involved in crimes in New York. Was she "seriously" blaming Vermont for New York's gun violence? "Of course not," Mrs. Clinton said, prompting a chuckle from Mr. Sanders."It's not a laughing matter," Mrs. Clinton said. She said Mr. Sanders has taken the position that gun makers should be shielded from lawsuits over use of firearms."We hear a lot from Sen. Sanders about the greed and recklessness of Wall Street...but what about the greed and recklessness of the gun manufacturers and dealers in America?" Mrs. Clinton said.Mr. Sanders pressed her on why she made the claim that Vermont bears responsibility for gun violence in New York."The facts are that most of the guns that end up committing crimes in New York come from out of state," Mrs. Clinton replied. "They come from states that don't have the kind of serious efforts to control guns that we have in New York."Hours before the Brooklyn debate, Mr. Sanders appeared at the National Action Network convention hosted by the Rev. Al Sharpton, and said Republican governors around the country are using voter-suppression tactics reminiscent of the "Jim Crow days."Making inroads into Mrs. Clinton's advantage among African-Americans won't be easy. Another Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll released earlier this week showed her with a 40-point lead among black Democrats in New York.Mrs. Clinton built her lead of 251 pledged delegates largely through decisive victories in Deep South states with large black populations, states that Mr. Sanders largely ignored. In Alabama, she took 91% of the black vote.An analysis by Public Opinion Strategies, a Republican polling firm, showed that in 21 states that have already voted, she won upward of 77% of African-Americans, compared with about 22% for Mr. Sanders.Hoping to counter Mr. Sanders's efforts, the Clinton campaign held a conference call with three Congressional Black Caucus members on Thursday during which they cast him as a late arrival to issues important to the black community.Rep. Hakeem Jeffries, who represents parts of New York City, said the Vermont senator hasn't done enough to address the racial disparity in his state's prison population. Vermont imprisons blacks at nearly 13 times the rate of whites, according to data compiled by the Sentencing Project, a group that advocates for improvements in the criminal-justice system. That is among the most pronounced disparities in the country, according to the group's research."On the issue of criminal-justice reform, Bernie Sanders has been all talk and no action," Mr. Jeffries said.Vaughn Carney is an African-American attorney in Vermont who said that he has voted for Mr. Sanders many times over the years, but that Mr. Sanders always seemed more comfortable talking about broad issues of economic class and income inequality than about race."His feeling is that economics is the answer, and government is the answer, and that's going to solve all the racial issues," said Mr. Carney, a Clinton supporter. "I don't buy that."A Sanders campaign spokesman didn't respond to a question about Vermont's prison population.The Clintons have had decades to forge ties to African-Americans, first in Arkansas, later in the White House, and then in Mrs. Clinton's eight years as a senator from New York. By contrast, Mr. Sanders has lived most of his life in a state that is 95% white.Still, he says he is well acquainted with the struggles of African-Americans. At the Thursday event, he drew applause when he noted that in 1988, as a mayor in Vermont--"an almost all-white state then"--he supported Rev. Jesse Jackson's Democratic presidential bid. "That wasn't a popular thing to do," he said.Most of Mr. Sanders's success in the presidential race has come in predominantly white states. Some African-Americans at Mr. Sanders's huge rally in Manhattan's Washington Square Park Wednesday evening said they couldn't understand why Mr. Sanders hadn't caught on more with nonwhite voters."He's always been on the right side of history," said Olivier Plummer, 18 years old, of New York's Queens borough, who plans to cast his first ballot for Mr. Sanders. He carried a sign saying that he supports the Vermont senator because "black lives always mattered--not just when it became election year."While the candidates are also engaged in a continuing dispute over who has the stronger immigration record--an effort to appeal to Latino voters--it is in the black community where Mr. Sanders has the most work to do. One of his TV ads, produced by director Spike Lee, features prominent civil-rights activists endorsing Mr. Sanders. "People of color have a deeply vested interest in what Bernie Sanders brings to us in this election," singer Harry Belafonte says. A second spot features Erica Garner, whose father, Eric, died in 2014 after a police confrontation on Staten Island. His death sparked a series of protests and political turmoil in New York.Mrs. Clinton has her own connection to the Garner family: She has received the endorsement of Mr. Garner's mother, Gwen Carr.Rebecca Ballhaus, Erica Orden and Gary Fields contributed to this article.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson, Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: Bernie and the 'Lunatic of One Idea'
article text: In his poem "Esthetique du Mal," Wallace Stevens refers, in a memorable and useful phrase, to a "lunatic of one idea." The phrase refuses to leave my mind whenever I hear Bernie Sanders -- and I have heard quite a lot of him in past weeks -- campaigning or debating or making, most recently, victory speeches. Mr. Sanders's one idea is what he takes to be the stark economic injustice of too few people having too much money, and through the power of their money having tilted American life in a way that is vastly unfair, unjust, flat-out morally wrong. He has repeated this one idea so often, and with such ardor in its expression, as to make Johnny One-Note look like Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.Mr. Sanders's synecdoche for his idea is Wall Street. Everything wrong with American life can be charged up, in his telling, to a small neighborhood in lower Manhattan. Something old-fashioned there is about blaming Wall Street for all the country's deficiencies. But, then, lunatics of one idea, basking in the pleasure of Manichaeism, like to focus all their enmity on one target.For the old American Communist Party this enemy was "the bosses." But a street with a symbolic name is even better. Wall Street was viewed as villainous long before Mr. Sanders. For a span it was replaced by Madison Avenue, understood as a hive of hucksters inflaming our desires for things we didn't need. Bernie Sanders has now brought back Wall Street, with as he claims its big-money ability to rig elections and hence destroy all possibility of the good society that socialism, left to its own inner devices, would surely achieve. One idea, and one idea only; it isn't that complicated.Lunatics of one idea have been immensely influential, though it is far from certain that this influence has been beneficial. Think of Karl Marx, whose one idea -- not so far removed from Mr. Sanders's -- was the class struggle. This is an idea that ended in the formation of the Soviet Union and seven decades of pointless suppression, suffering and murder on a scale never before known.Think of Sigmund Freud, whose one idea was that sex is at the absolute center of human existence, eclipsing all else in its importance for the development of human character. This is an idea that has skewed thinking about human nature for more than a century, and, even though Freud's thought is now no longer assigned intellectual respectability, the hangover from it continues nonetheless to influence Western culture. One idea -- that's all that it takes.Being a one-idea lunatic makes life a lot simpler. For one thing, it permits one to eliminate any interfering complexity from the intrusion of other or contradictory ideas, not to mention common sense. The one idea -- class struggle, sexual determinism, evil Wall Street, vile Madison Avenue -- becomes talismanic. Merely utter the words in which the idea is encased and all becomes plain: inner meaning, outward significance, morality, plan of action. That the one idea may not comport with reality is beside the point. As the Spanish philosopher Jose Ortega y Gasset said, create a concept and reality leaves the room. But let that pass.More interesting than Bernie Sanders's threadbare idea is how it has caught on with the young. In generous readings, is it their idealism that puts the young on his side? Is it his relentless moralizing that attracts them? Mr. Sanders is, as they say in social psychology, a contrast gainer -- next to Hillary Clinton, with all her cumbersome political baggage (all of it Louis Vuitton, of course), he looks good. Yet when he utters his mantra at large gatherings, "Are you ready for a political revolution?" one wonders: Does this generation that has grown up with a greater sense of entitlement and protection than any other in history really want the revolution Mr. Sanders is selling? Can they have so little sense of the past not to know that the promise of socialism -- "democratic socialism," the senator would interject here -- has ended up in gulags and brutal cultural upheaval?Perhaps the appeal of Bernie Sanders for the young goes no further than the simplicity of his one idea. The nice thing about being a one-idea man or woman is that through it one can dismiss the complications of politics as a business of deals, compromises, limited expectations and partial gains. Why bog down in the grubby details of political life, when you can ride a single idea all the way home to utopia. As Bernie himself says, the middle class has for too long supported Wall Street; now it's time for Wall Street to support the middle class. If you believe that, or believe that it is going to happen, you qualify, prima facie, as a one-idea lunatic of your own. May you live and be well, as the Jews used to say about the czar, but not too close to me.---Mr. Epstein's books include "Masters of the Games: Essays and Stories on Sport" (Rowman & Littlefield, 2015).(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Bernie Sanders's Campaign And One Big Idea, or Not" -- WSJ February 27, 2016)Credit: By Joseph Epstein

article name: Bernie Sanders's Legacy; After 87 months of Obama, why are young liberals asking for 'change'?
article text: With Hillary Clinton and the party machinery back on track to a now-tarnished coronation, it's worth assessing what Bernie Sanders's campaign accomplished. I still can't take the Vermont Socialist himself seriously, not with Larry David as his doppelgänger. But the Sanders phenomenon--embraced by a strong majority of liberals between the ages of 17 and 50--deserves attention.Reporters have exhaustively plumbed the habitats and mental states of "the Trump voter." Sen. Sanders's supporters, by contrast, have floated through the primaries in a mist of keywords--millennials, college students, young professionals, actresses, "white people."One has to ask: Are they all actually socialists? I doubt it.It's no surprise Donald Trump in his New York victory speech about the "corrupt" Republican Party called Sen. Sanders a fellow "outsider." The two great disrupters are remarkably similar, a kind of Tweedledon and Tweedleburn on trade and a "system" that's "broken" and "failing" their supporters.If one word attaches to the Sanders camp, it is "change." But change what?This isn't meant to deride their desire for change, which is undoubtedly authentic, but only to ask how it's possible that so many under-50 liberals have settled on Bernie Sanders as a change agent after living daily through more than 87 straight months of a Democratic president elected on a platform of "Hope and Change"?As to Mrs. Clinton, President Obama's presumed heir, The Wall Street Journal poll this week finds "just 22% of registered voters give her high marks for being able to bring real change to the country."What, exactly, is Barack Obama, Hillary Clinton or even Bernie Sanders supposed to deliver that an infinity of politicians and public officials before them haven't already delivered?If change has any concrete meaning for Sen. Sanders's supporters, it must have something to do with what the government or public sector does.However imperfect, the federal budget embodies what the U.S. government is.First the numbers. The 2015 federal budget spent about $3.8 trillion, or 21% of the U.S. economy. Year in and year out, that $3 trillion to $4 trillion underwrites programs.As listed at federalsafetynet.com, the programs delivering welfare include: the negative income tax, SNAP (supplemental nutrition), housing assistance, SSI, Pell Grants, TANF (temporary assistance for needy families), child nutrition, Head Start, job training programs, WIC (food for women and children), child care and Liheap (energy subsidies).Entitlement programs include Social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, unemployment insurance and the Affordable Care Act.Education: A website called CollegeScholarships.org lists "Grants from the U.S. Government: Free Money from Uncle Sam."Why are 25-year-old liberals crying out for "change," if you are spending $4 trillion every year on all this stuff? There's hardly anything significant left to deliver, other than results, so maybe something is wrong with the delivery system.Let's get local. Anyone want to guess what this year's budget is for New York City's hapless school system? It is $27.6 billion.Writing in the Los Angeles Daily News a few years ago, Tim Rutten tried to discern a total-spending figure for the Los Angeles Unified School District. Answer: No one knows. It's too big and too complicated: "In all, LAUSD receives money earmarked to aid more than 140 categories of students."This week, the New York Times described the split over Bill and Hillary Clinton between older blacks, who support them, and younger blacks who don't. Said one new-generation activist from Philadelphia: "We do not believe that freedom for black Americans will come through politicians."The War on Poverty began in 1965. A half-century later, after uncountable trillions spent, you've still got Baltimore, Chicago, East Brooklyn and East St. Louis. Who wouldn't be angry about black lives?A $15 minimum wage isn't change. It's a fly on the elephant's back.That sound welling out of Sanders rallies is, in no small part, a cri de coeur for accountability. Bernie, a skilled pol, reprogrammed the anger against "corporate greed," but at least you can show up at a shareholders meeting to gripe. With the public sector, it is impossible to identify who they are, other than "Washington."At least some of Sen. Sanders's agitated supporters may be starting to recognize that after all these years, the federal government has achieved a steady state of sludge. Hillary Clinton sounds like the most knowledgeable technocrat in America, and none of these young people want much of anything to do with her.Sen. Sanders said he was leading a political revolution. But he won't be its vessel, nor will Mrs. Clinton. It will take someone who can recognize that social change isn't going to happen until you disaggregate these public blobs. And in the private sector, let young companies have enough capital to breathe.Anyone inside Bernie Sanders's neo-socialist orbit suggesting that less blob and more capital might work better runs the risk of being called a "conservative."So figure out how to rebrand conservatism, liberalism, progressivism and even socialism as something more like them. Maybe they could call it artisanalism.Write to henninger@wsj.comCredit: By Daniel Henninger

article name: Election 2016: Democrats Vie for Nevada's Minorities --- Clinton and Sanders seek to mobilize nonwhite voters as caucuses near
article text: LAS VEGAS -- Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders will face his biggest test so far in his run for the White House this week, when voters in one of the most ethnically and racially diverse states will make their choice in the Democratic presidential conteston Saturday.Nevada -- a sprawling Western state with important blocs of Latino, black and Asian-American voters -- is the next stop for Mr. Sanders and Hillary Clinton. For Mr. Sanders, a win in the Silver State would be an opportunity to show he has appeal among the nonwhite voters who make up a significant part of the Democratic electorate. He has long trailed Mrs. Clinton in the polls among black and Hispanic voters. For Mrs. Clinton, a win here would be an important show of force and bolster her argument that she can put together a winning coalition against a Republican nominee."We're going to get a good sense of what Latinos, African-Americans, and Asians are thinking. Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are working tirelessly to reach out to these communities," said Ruben Kihuen, a Nevada state senator running for U.S. Congress and a supporter of Mrs. Clinton.The state is more than a quarter Latino and has a sizable black population. It also has a large Asian-American community, the fastest-growing minority group in the country. Non-Hispanic whites now represent less than half of the population of Las Vegas.The state's diversity and the increasingly close battle between the two Democratic candidates have set off a fierce fight to persuade and mobilize nonwhite voters. Two Nevada polls this month show the contest in a dead heat, though the state is traditionally difficult to survey effectively.Mrs. Clinton's campaign brought in Rep. John Lewis, a civil-rights icon and a longtime Democratic member of Congress from Georgia to help boost turnout among the black community. He made his case for Mrs. Clinton at several campaign stops this week, including at a historically black church and a community center in a low-income neighborhood. "I'm going to continue to travel as long as there's a campaign," said Mr. Lewis, calling Mrs. Clinton the best-prepared candidate to be president.The campaign also has brought in Dolores Huerta, a civil-rights leader and labor activist who co-founded the National Farm Workers Association with Cesar Chavez in the 1960s. The campaign is on television in Spanish and has hosted events in Spanish aimed at familiarizing Latino voters with the caucus process.Mr. Sanders's campaign has been equally aggressive, particularly in the Latino community. The campaign brought Mr. Chavez's nephew, Federico Chavez as a surrogate. The campaign is dispatching a group of illegal immigrants who were brought to the U.S. as children to knock on doors across the state. The campaign is on television with an endorsement from Lucy Flores, a former state legislator running for U.S. Congress.Both candidates attended church services Sunday at a large historically black church in Las Vegas and addressed the congregation."I am not a single-issue candidate and this is not a single-issue country," Mrs. Clinton said, referring to Mr. Sanders's sharp focus on Wall Street and campaign-finance issues. "Because if we were going to achieve everything about banks and money and politics, would that end racism?"Sanders campaign state director Joan Kato said they are ceding no ground. "We're doing outreach in all those communities," she said.Mrs. Clinton's campaign strategy relies on maintaining her well of support with nonwhite voters after her narrow win in Iowa and big loss in New Hampshire. Both of those states are whiter and more rural than the country at large.Still, her campaign began lowering expectations ahead of the caucuses here. "There's an important Hispanic element to the Democratic caucus in Nevada. But it's still a state that is 80% white voters," campaign spokesman Brian Fallon said on MSNBC after New Hampshire.The comment drew a rebuke from Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid. Mr. Reid told reporters on Tuesday that he had complained to the Clinton campaign about the comment. Mrs. Clinton later rejected the comment in a television interview.Steven Horsford, a Democrat who was the first black Congressman from Nevada and former majority leader of the state senate, said the explicit racial appeals may not work among younger nonwhite voters who are looking for a more comprehensive agenda. Mr. Horsford, now a Washington, D.C., marketing consultant, was voted out of office amid a Republican wave in Nevada in 2014."Both campaigns have more work to do to speak to a broad constituency and not put everybody in categories -- all African-American voters are not the same," said Mr. Horsford, who hasn't endorsed a candidate.Enlarge this image.Credit: By Byron Tau and Alexandra Berzon

article name: Rigged: A Word Moves From Shipping to Politics; When Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders say the system is 'rigged,' their usage derives from a venerable shipping term
article text: If one thing unites the rhetoric of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, it is their critique that "the system"--whether political or economic--is "rigged" by the powers that be.In stump speeches, Mr. Trump has taken on the Republican Party's national apparatus by claiming that the process for selecting delegates for the presidential nominating convention is "rigged." He further stated in a Wall Street Journal opinion piece that "our unfair trade, immigration and economic policies...have also been rigged against Americans."On the Democratic side, many supporters of Mr. Sanders see the selection of superdelegates by party leaders as "rigging" the nomination process in favor of Hillary Clinton. Mr. Sanders also complains about an economic system that is "rigged" against the middle class, and Mrs. Clinton has followed suit, acknowledging in a February debate that "yes, the economy is rigged in favor of those at the top."Where did all of this "rig"-marole come from? Back in the 16th century, writers chiefly used "rigged" to describe sailing vessels fully equipped to go to sea. "Rigging" a ship involved fitting it with all the necessary ropes and cables to support the masts and control the sails."Rigged" eventually took on a less positive meaning: put together hastily or as a temporary measure. That slapdash sense came through especially in the forms "rigged up" or "jury-rigged." ("Jury" originally referred to a ship's temporary "jury mast," erected to replace one that had broken off. Confusion with the expression "jerry-built" led to a blended version, "jerry-rigged.")Meanwhile, an even less flattering meaning of "rigged" emerged, having to do with fraudulent manipulation. That usage likely stems from a slangy use of the word "rig" meaning "trick, swindle," dated by the Oxford English Dictionary to 1640 and etymologically unrelated to the nautical meaning.Stock markets were the first systems to be called unfairly "rigged." An 1826 article in the Times of London described efforts to "rig" joint-stock companies by manipulating their prices. The Egyptian Trading Co. was dubbed "one of the very best 'rigged' Companies that ever were introduced into the share-market."From the financial world, the word spread to other kinds of corrupt practices. By the early 20th century, "rigged" could be used in sports for match-fixing and in politics for election-fixing. "Vote-rigging" became a popular label for electoral fraud.Party conventions, too, have often been painted as "rigged" long before Messrs. Trump and Sanders. Perhaps most famously, former president Harry Truman resigned as a delegate to the Democratic National Convention in 1960 because he claimed the proceedings were rigged to hand the nomination to John F. Kennedy.After Truman held a press conference warning that the convention looked like "a prearranged affair," Democratic National Chairman Paul M. Butler responded that the nomination would be "free, open, unrigged and, I hope, unbossed." We can expect the 2016 conventions to face just as much scrutiny about whether they are rigged or unrigged.Credit: By Ben Zimmer

article name: Democrats Avoid Jabs at Each Other, Keep Focus on Policy; Ahead of contests Tuesday, Bernie Sanders adopts more conciliatory tone; Hillary Clinton targets GOP's Donald Trump
article text: PROVIDENCE, R.I.--Facing a tough series of contests this week, Bernie Sanders gave a fresh signal that he is ready to scale down his attacks on rival Hillary Clinton, dropping his argument that she is beholden to Wall Street banks by dint of large speaking fees she has gotten over the years.Mr. Sanders said he still believes he can win the nomination, but he conceded the path is difficult. The Vermont senator trails Mrs. Clinton by 275 pledged convention delegates, and the five states that vote Tuesday could leave him deeper in the hole. The biggest prize is Pennsylvania, with 189 delegates at stake. A new Wall Street Journal/NBC News/Marist poll showed Mrs. Clinton 15 percentage points ahead of Mr. Sanders in Pennsylvania, a state where she has been showcasing her family ties.Asked on CNN if he still has a viable path to the nomination, Mr. Sanders said: "Well, I'm not going to tell you that it's easy, but I think we do."Mrs. Clinton and her husband, perhaps with an eye toward unifying the party once the nomination fight ends, largely avoided swipes at Mr. Sanders in advance of Tuesday's contests.Apart from Pennsylvania, voters will cast ballots in Connecticut, Delaware, Maryland and Rhode Island. The terrain seems to favor Mrs. Clinton.
