At a recent televised town hall meeting, she noted that she's in the stronger negotiating position by virtue of her lead.Hilary Rosen, a Clinton supporter who has worked on past Democratic conventions, said she doesn't anticipate big fights at the convention."There might be a few points of contention for the platform. But I think what Sanders and his people will find in Hillary Clinton is an open mind, a commitment to progressive values, combined with a desire to win in November," she said.Ben Kesling contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Laura Meckler

article name: The Trump-Sanders China Syndrome
article text: Presidential candidates Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, with a phalanx of lawmakers behind them, continue to bash China as a "currency manipulator." Both men claim that Beijing is engaged in a permanent strategy to keep the yuan weak and prop up its trade surplus. But the reality was never that simple, and the charge is ludicrous at present.Beijing began pegging its currency to the U.S. dollar over two decades ago, as part of its plan to integrate the Chinese economy into a global marketplace in which transactions were overwhelmingly priced in dollars. It stuck by this strategy even during the height of the Asian financial crisis, in 1998, when much of the world was expecting it to devalue. This earned it great praise from the U.S. government. "China, by maintaining its exchange rate policy," pronounced President Clinton's Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin, "has been an important island of stability in a turbulent region."But once market pressures reversed, and capital began flowing into China, U.S. lawmakers suddenly decided that currency stability was bad: They wanted the yuan to rise, while China continued to keep it fixed. In a 2006 op-ed for this newspaper, Sens. Charles Schumer and Lindsey Graham declared that "one of the fundamental tenets of free trade is that currencies should float." Such a tenet, remarkably, was unknown to either Adam Smith or John Maynard Keynes, neither of whom ever supported any such thing.Fast forward to 2016, and capital is now flowing out of China at a prodigious rate. In an effort to slow the resulting fall in its currency, China's central bank has been selling vast amounts of dollars and buying up yuan. At $3.2 trillion, China's reserves still seem enormous. But they are down $790 billion from their 2014 peak, and $325 billion in the past four months.At this pace of decline, China's reserves will fall to $2.8 trillion in July. To put this in perspective, China, using the International Monetary Fund's framework for reserve-adequacy measurement, needs to hold between $2.8 trillion and $4.2 trillion in reserves to safeguard against a balance-of-payments crisis. Once reserves fall below an adequate precautionary level, China is at risk of being unable to pay for essential imports or its dollar debts. The IMF estimate could be overly cautious, given China's relatively low level of external debt, but it could also be too sanguine in that some significant portion of China's reserves, estimated to be around a third, is believed to be tied up in nonliquid assets -- and unavailable in a crisis. These include China's capital commitment to the new Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank.So what can China do to stanch the rapid decline in reserves?The country has for years been pursuing what has been called the "Impossible Trinity": controlling interest and exchange rates while leaving the capital account significantly open. Chinese residents are permitted to send up to $50,000 overseas annually and this is enough to allow trillions in outflows. China could impose tighter capital controls to prevent this, as Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda recently urged it to do. This would allow it to operate safely with fewer reserves. The adequate level of precautionary reserves falls to between $1.7 trillion and $2.6 trillion when adjusted for capital controls. But this would put a halt to China's plans to transform the yuan into a major reserve currency -- something it will be reluctant to do.China could also raise interest rates, which might encourage capital inflows and discourage outflows, but this would hurt growth in an already sinking economy.Finally, China could let the exchange rate fall significantly, but this would increase the debt burden on Chinese companies. Outstanding dollar credit to Chinese nonfinancial companies is estimated to be around $1 trillion. Too great a fall in the yuan, coupled with slowing economic growth, could precipitate a corporate solvency crisis.That China has no good options, and only a choice among painful ones, reflects the underlying structural problem in the Chinese economy -- one that will take many years to fix. The economy was tooled to support grossly overoptimistic expectations of foreign demand for Chinese exports. Retooling it to encourage domestic demand will require time and a willingness by the Chinese government to allow businesses to die so that more promising ones may live.It also shows that American charges that China's currency was massively undervalued were based on the flawed assumption that capital would want, indefinitely, only to get into China and not out. It's a sure bet no one in Washington will be calling for China to float its currency again anytime soon.---Mr. Steil is director of international economics at the Council on Foreign Relations and the author of "The Battle of Bretton Woods" (Princeton University Press, 2013). Ms. Smith is an analyst at the council.Credit: By Benn Steil and Emma Smith

article name: Hillary & Bernie, Tax Fantasists
article text: Here is a question to ask Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders: What is the best tax rate to impose on high-income earners to ensure there is enough government revenue to pay for your trillion-dollar promises to voters?Perhaps they think it is 83%, a rate that economists Thomas Piketty and Emmanuel Saez hypothesized in 2014 in a widely circulated paper. Or maybe it is 90%, which Sen. Sanders told CNBC last May was not out of the question. "Our job is not to think small," Mr. Sanders elaborated in the Huffington Post a month later. "It is to think big."Progressives have often reminded us that the U.S. had such rates in the past. From 1936 to 1980, the highest federal income-tax rate was never below 70%, and the top rate exceeded 90% from 1951 to 1963. Under Ronald Reagan, the top federal rate declined to 28% by 1988 and has never reached 40% since.The discussion of these rates can easily create the impression that the federal government collected far more money from "the rich" before the Reagan administration. And it can also leave another impression: There would be no downside to raising rates to 1950s levels, given that decade's prosperity.Neither impression would be correct. The effective tax rates actually paid by the highest income earners during the 1950s and early '60s were far lower than the highest marginal rates. Few taxpayers reached the top brackets, the code was rife with loopholes, and capital gains were taxed at much lower rates.In the 1960s, for example, the average rate paid by the top 0.1% of tax filers -- the top 10th of the top 1% -- ranged from 26.5% to 29.5%, according to a 2007 study by Messrs. Piketty and Saez. Even during the 20 years after the Reagan tax cuts, the top 10th of the top 1% paid an average rate of 23.7% to 33% -- essentially the same as in the 1960s. In the decade following 2001, the Congressional Budget Office estimates that the average rate for this elite group never exceeded 32%.Nostalgia aside for a world that never existed, few people paid the top tax rates of the 1950s and early 1960s. Of course, when they did, the top marginal rates applied only to income above a very high threshold. The top ordinary income rate married couples faced in 1960, 91%, applied only to income above $2.5 million in today's dollars.Suppose a President Clinton or Sanders tried to raise effective tax rates paid by a significant number of upper-income earners through very high top rates. What then? Real damage, according to Mr. Piketty. In a 2009 debate with the Cato Institute's Chris Edwards in the Economist, Mr. Piketty said, "I firmly believe, that imposing a 70% or 80% marginal rate on large segments of the population (say, 25% of the population, or even 10%, or even a few percentage points) would lead to an economic disaster." In other words, sayonara increased tax revenue.Even without disaster, however, it is unclear whether higher rates on the upper echelons of the top 1% would bring in more revenue. I've compared the Piketty-Saez estimates of average federal income-tax rates paid by the top 10th of the top 1% with the revenue collected at the federal level from the same group. The result? From the mid-1960s through the '80s, trends in the average tax rates paid at the top compared with their tax revenues are mirror images. When average tax rates went up from 27.6% in 1965 to 34% in 1975, revenues went down, from 0.6% to 0.5% of the sum of GDP plus capital gains. When average tax rates declined to 23.7% over the second half of the 1970s and the '80s, tax revenues from the top went up, reaching 0.8% of GDP plus capital gains in 1990.This makes intuitive sense. Of all Americans, it is the wealthy who are more likely to take advantage of legal ways to reduce their payments when rates rise. Plus, their work and investment decisions are more sensitive to the after-tax payoff.Admittedly, in the early 1990s, Presidents George H.W. Bush and Bill Clinton raised average tax rates at the top, and revenue from the top 0.1% eventually skyrocketed. But the flood of revenue overwhelmingly reflected not the increase in rates but the stock market's takeoff beginning in late 1994, which resulted in a corresponding rise in income from capital gains and stock options.Consider: If the higher top tax rates had caused the growth in revenue, then revenues should have fallen when Mr. Clinton cut the top tax rate on capital gains to 20% from 28% in 1997. But revenues from the top 0.1% kept pouring in.Proposals to soak the rich by raising their tax rates are unlikely to yield the revenue windfall that Mr. Sanders or Mrs. Clinton are dangling before voters. Leveling with the American people means either scaling back their agendas or admitting that they will have to raise the money from tax hikes on middle-class voters.---Mr. Winship is a senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute.Credit: By Scott Winship

article name: Sanders Gets No Respect
article text: Bernie Sanders won three Western Democratic caucuses by landslides on Saturday, and all he got was this lousy Associated Press headline: "Sanders wins 3 states; Clinton holds delegate lead." The AP header is accurate, but the Vermont Senator and his legions can be forgiven for wondering what he has to do to get some political respect.Mr. Sanders won Alaska with about 82% of the vote, Hawaii with 70% and delegate-rich Washington state with 73%. These may not be bellwether states. But Donald Trump or Ted Cruz would love to have those margins, and in a normal year a front-runner like Hillary Clinton would be running up such totals at this stage of the presidential race. Instead the 74-year-old Mr. Sanders is showing the kind of electoral strength that gives him every right to fight on at least through April's contests and maybe to the convention in July.The challenger's victories reveal Mrs. Clinton's continuing weakness even among Democratic partisans. On Tuesday Mr. Sanders won in Utah and Idaho, while the former Secretary of State won easily in Arizona. She continues to have a delegate lead thanks to her victories in states dominated by older African-American voters and government-employee unions. But she inspires little enthusiasm, and the case for her seems to boil down to her inevitability as the nominee and that her political experience and stolidity are antidotes to the likely GOP nominee, Mr. Trump.Mr. Sanders is also fighting the perception that as an avowed socialist he can't win in November. "Don't let anybody tell you that Hillary Clinton is the strongest Democratic candidate to take on the Republicans," Mr. Sanders told an estimated crowd of 15,000 in the People's Republic of Seattle. "It is not true."The current head-to-head polls bear him out. In the Real Clear Politics polling average, Mr. Sanders leads Mr. Trump by 17.5 points and Mr. Cruz by 8.4. Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Trump by 11.2 and Mr. Cruz by only 2.9. Mr. Sanders is tied with John Kasich, while Mrs. Clinton loses to the Ohio Governor by 6.5 points.Most Americans still don't know much about what Mr. Sanders believes, including his desire to return to 1930s tax rates and his sympathy for Communist regimes during the Cold War. His belief in undiluted socialism would be vetted in a general election campaign in a way it hasn't been in the Democratic primaries.Then again, Mrs. Clinton has helped to validate many of those positions by moving so far left herself. And in Mr. Trump the Republicans may nominate a candidate who is building negative approval ratings that no candidate has been able to recover from and win the White House.Mrs. Clinton remains the all-but-certain Democratic nominee, not least because of her lead in "superdelegates." These are current or former elected officials and other Democratic grandees who are formally unpledged to any candidate before the convention. AP currently has them going 469 for Mrs. Clinton and only 29 for Mr. Sanders.For all the talk about an open convention that could deny Mr. Trump the GOP nomination, the Democratic establishment has done far more to rig the nominating process to favor elites. One reason Mr. Sanders gets no respect is because Democratic elites prefer a nominee who disguises her socialism better than he does.

article name: Four Questions for Sanders
article text: Bernie Sanders isn't quitting the race, but his advisers are hinting that the nomination fight is effectively over. Coming off a series of losses, they acknowledge that Mr. Sanders can't erase Hillary Clinton's lead in pledged delegates in the 14 contests that remain.What that means is that the only way for Mr. Sanders to win is to persuade hundreds of Democratic insiders known as superdelegates to abandon Mrs. Clinton and line up behind the candidate who has criticized the party establishment on and off for decades--a scenario that isn't likely.As the race reaches the endgame, a few questions arise about a Sanders campaign that exceeded expectations but is on a path to fall short.1. Why did Mr. Sanders take the Clinton email issue off the table?The Vermont senator boxed himself in when he told Mrs. Clinton at the first debate in October that Americans were "sick and tired of hearing about your damn emails."Mrs. Clinton exclusively used a private account and server during her tenure as secretary of state. In relying on that system, she ran the risk of exposing sensitive classified material and complicated public-records requests.In February, U.S. District Judge Emmet Sullivan ruled that top aides to Mrs. Clinton could be questioned under oath about whether they deliberately skirted public-records laws by making use of the private email system. "This case is about the public's right to know," the judge said.Mr. Sanders has questioned Mrs. Clinton's judgment and integrity when it comes to other matters. He faulted her for taking money from Wall Street, including large speaking fees.If he sees the Wall Street speeches as fair game, why put the email controversy off limits?2. Why did he wait so long to build ties to African-American voters?If Mrs. Clinton clinches the Democratic nomination, a key reason is the African-American vote. She built her delegate lead on the loyalty of black voters.Mr. Sanders comes from a state with few black voters and seems to have done little in his political career to forge the sorts of relationships in the black community that would prove valuable in a presidential race. That project needed to begin years ago--not in the heat of a race against Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Sanders has spent the past few months scrambling to make the case to African-American voters that he would be a reliable ally in the White House. It hasn't helped. Exit polls show he has gotten crushed by Mrs. Clinton among black voters. Mr. Sanders made some of his most aggressive moves to court black voters during the New York primary fight; Mrs. Clinton won New York and beat him among black voters by 50 points.3. Why did he wait so long to build ties to Democrats?Mr. Sanders spent decades as an independent. Not until he entered the presidential race last year did he declare himself a Democrat.That is an unconventional path for someone who wants to lead the party. And Mr. Sanders is now paying a price. Superdelegates are party leaders and past and present elected officials who get an outsize say in picking the Democratic nominee. They are backing Mrs. Clinton by 520 to 39, according to an Associated Press tally.As a lawmaker Mr. Sanders has consistently voted with the Democrats and has supported Democratic candidates running for office. But he has never been a creature of the party."Party politics has not been central to our lives, that's true," Jane Sanders, the candidate's wife, said in an interview.What seems clear is Mr. Sanders never thought he would be in this position: running a competitive race against the Clinton juggernaut. Had he foreseen where his political career was headed, he might have been helped by joining the Democrats sooner and wooing the officials who wield so much influence.4. Why did he write off the South?The Sanders campaign made an early strategic decision that haunts the candidate to this day. Rather than focus on winning delegates in the early going, Mr. Sanders sought to capture some marquee states and demonstrate Mrs. Clinton was beatable.Trouble is, delegates determine the winner--not states. Sanders aides acknowledge they put up little fight in a slew of Southern states with large black populations.So, Mrs. Clinton won landslide victories in Georgia, Texas, Alabama, Louisiana and elsewhere. Under Democratic rules that award delegates proportionally, she built up a large lead that Mr. Sanders is unlikely to overcome.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Hillary Clinton Says Donald Trump Wouldn't Win Over Bernie Sanders Backers; The Democratic front-runner says she wouldn't back down from a focus on women's issues
article text: Hillary Clinton flatly dismissed Donald Trump's suggestion that he can win over supporters of rival Bernie Sanders in the fall election, arguing that the Republican's views on a range of issues would repel them.In an interview Friday with CNN, Mrs. Clinton also said she wouldn't back down from her focus on women's issues, and professed little concern about Mr. Trump's assertion that she wouldn't win 5% of the vote if she weren't a woman."If playing the 'women's card' means standing up for the concerns that women have and that they express to me, then deal me in," she said, using what has become a signature phrase for her campaign. "Because that's exactly what I've always done for decades [and] what I will do in this campaign."She also cited her two successful elections to the U.S. Senate and the many votes she has received in the 2008 and 2016 presidential elections. "So it doesn't really square with reality," she said. His attacks are "kind of silly," she said, saying she is more bothered by his attacks on other groups.Mr. Trump set off the latest back-and-forth on Tuesday after both he and Mrs. Clinton had strong showings in the East Coast primaries. "Frankly, if Hillary Clinton were a man, I don't think she'd get 5% of the vote. The only thing she's got going is the woman's card," he said. That prompted days of mocking by the Clinton campaign and its supporters. Mr. Trump stuck with the attack, saying that Mrs. Clinton couldn't run for "city council" without the "woman's card."Mr. Trump and Mr. Sanders share some views--such as opposition to free-trade agreements--and have both challenged their respective political establishments. Mr. Trump has suggested that he could win over some of the Sanders backers if Mr. Sanders loses the Democratic nomination.Mrs. Clinton dismissed that idea. She cited climate change, the minimum wage and equitable pay for women as issues where Mr. Sanders and Mr. Trump are at odds and called the Republican front-runner's foreign policy views "reckless, loose, dangerous.""I don't think that's very appealing" to Sanders backers, she said. "I'm going to be very aggressive in...reaching out to Sen. Sanders's supporters, but we have so much more in common. And we have far more in common than they do with Donald Trump or any Republican."Asked about insults Mr. Trump had delivered to her, Mrs. Clinton said in the CNN interview, "I have a lot of experience dealing with men who sometimes get off the reservation in the way they behave and how they speak." An aide said she was referring to past GOP opponents. "I'm not going to deal with their temper tantrums or their bullying or their efforts to try to provoke me," she said.After his losses on Tuesday in four out of five states , Mr. Sanders suggested he was staying in the contest in hopes of influencing the Democratic Party's platform on key issues. Mrs. Clinton suggested there may be room for discussion."We're gonna talk. We're gonna work together. Because, look, we want the same goals," she said. "We really are going to be unified and have a tremendous progressive agenda to run on in the fall. And I really think that will help us win the election and it will also help us govern."Mrs. Clinton also spoke about understanding how hard it is to lose a contest like this. Back in the 2008 Democratic race, she didn't concede the nomination to then-Sen. Barack Obama until June."You throw yourself into these campaigns body and soul. You work 24/7. Your family, your supporters, everybody is so invested in trying to win," she said. But she said that in 2008, she was closer to Mr. Obama than Mr. Sanders is to her in both total votes and delegates. "There comes a time when you have to look at the reality," she said.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Sanders Renews His Push for More Superdelegates; Democratic candidate acknowledges he faces 'uphill climb' to overtake Clinton for presidential nomination
article text: Trailing Hillary Clinton and with time running out, Bernie Sanders said Sunday he can still win the Democratic presidential nomination, though he conceded he faces an "uphill climb" that involves persuading hundreds of party insiders known as superdelegates to switch sides and support his candidacy.Speaking on the first anniversary of entering the primary race, Mr. Sanders said the superdelegates, who play a role in picking the Democratic nominee, should consider polls showing him to be the stronger general-election candidate against Republican front-runner Donald Trump. He added that superdelegates living in states he won decisively should respect the voters' preferences and back him.Mr. Sanders indicated he isn't about to bow to calls for party unity and stand aside while his rival gets the nomination, noting that Mrs. Clinton likely would need superdelegates to help her clinch the nomination.With Mr. Sanders competing with her to win superdelegates, he said the nominating convention in Philadelphia in July will be a "contested" one.But the focus on superdelegates underscores Mr. Sanders's predicament. He ran as an outsider determined to usher in "political revolution" and repudiate "establishment politics." Now he is pinning his hopes on the prospect that superdelegates--party leaders and elected officials--will abandon Mrs. Clinton in numbers that would hand him the nomination. "Nothing I'm telling you today suggests this is going to be an easy climb," Mr. Sanders said.After the news conference in Washington, one of his senior advisers, Tad Devine, was asked if the Sanders strategy was "strange" given his anti-Establishment message. "Can I use 'ironic' instead of 'strange?' " Mr. Devine replied.The campaign's search for superdelegates reflects the hard realities of delegate math. After winning five of the last six states, Mrs. Clinton pushed an already commanding lead to 327 pledged delegates, the kind selected by voters.By the Sanders campaign's calculations, he would need to win 65% of the pledged delegates to close the gap in the 14 contests that are left. While not "impossible," Mr. Sanders said, "that is, admittedly, and I do not deny it for a second, a tough road to climb..."Superdelegates are free to back whomever they choose. They now support Mrs. Clinton by a margin of 520-39, according to an Associated Press tally.Many are siding with Mrs. Clinton, even though Mr. Sanders won their states by large margins. He cited some examples. Despite winning the caucuses in Washington state with 73% of the vote, Mr. Sanders is backed by none of the state's superdelegates, he said. Instead, 10 superdelegates in Washington favor Mrs. Clinton.For some superdelegates, that argument falls flat. They say they have larger responsibilities to the party and country and shouldn't be bound by how their states voted.Billi Gosh is a superdelegate from Mr. Sanders's home state of Vermont, where he beat Mrs. Clinton by 74 percentage points. Ms. Gosh is backing Mrs. Clinton, pointing to reasons that center on credentials."I'm voting for the person who, (a), I think will win and (b), who is the most qualified and will be an outstanding president," Ms. Gosh said. "And that's Hillary Clinton."The Clinton campaign declined to comment.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Bernie Sanders's Fundraising Dropped in April; The $25.8 million raised in April is a sharp fall from March's $44 million haul
article text: Sen. Bernie Sanders's presidential campaign raised nearly $26 million in April, the campaign said Sunday, marking the first time this year that his fundraising dropped from one month to the next.The Vermont senator's supporters may be discouraged by his narrowing path to the presidency. The $25.8 million raised in April is a sharp fall from the $44 million he raised in March, and March's number barely surpassed February's $43.5 million.The campaign said in a news release that April's haul surpasses the monthly average throughout the election of $17 million. April's donations bring his total annual fundraising haul to $210 million, the campaign said.Mr. Sanders' rival, Hillary Clinton, hasn't released her fundraising total for April. Mr. Sanders outraised her campaign in March by nearly $15 million.Corrections & Amplifications: April's donations brought Mr. Sanders's total annual fundraising to $210 million. An earlier version of this article incorrectly stated it was February's fundraising that brought the total to that mark. (May 1, 2016)Write to Anna Louie Sussman at anna.sussman@wsj.comCredit: By Anna Louie Sussman

article name: Bernie Sanders Wins Indiana Primary, Still Faces Uphill Delegate Battle; Vermont senator unlikely to meaningfully reduce Clinton's delegate advantage
article text: Sen. Bernie Sanders won Indiana's primary Tuesday , giving his flagging presidential campaign ammunition to press forward and making plain front-runner Hillary Clinton's persistent trouble unifying the Democratic Party.With 80% of precincts reporting, Mr. Sanders had 53% to Mrs. Clinton's 47%, according to the Associated Press.Even with the win, Mr. Sanders still faces a wide deficit in convention delegates and virtually no chance to close the gap. He picked up at least 43 of the 83 pledged delegates at stake, but Mrs. Clinton took at least 37, according to an AP tally.Still, the late-in-the-game win by the Vermont senator creates an odd split-screen for the Democrats, with the Clinton campaign increasingly focused on Republican Donald Trump even as Mr. Sanders lays bare her weakness with a large slice of Democrats. Exit polls showed he again beat her among young people, white voters, political independents and people who most value honesty in a candidate.The senator's win in Indiana may make it more awkward for Mrs. Clinton to look past him, as she did this week. Confident in her delegate lead , she spent much of Tuesday campaigning in the fall battleground state of Ohio. Her campaign in recent days began hiring staff across states expected to be competitive this fall, and her advisers were in the early stages of a vice-presidential selection process.Speaking Tuesday evening in Louisville, Ky., before the results were announced, Mr. Sanders noted how far his campaign has come since its early days a year ago and highlighted his strong support with young voters."That is important because it tells me that the ideas that we are fighting for are the ideas of the future of America," he said.The speech showed Mr. Sanders in no mood for party unification, as some Democrats would like. He hit Mrs. Clinton on her paid speeches to Wall Street, her 2002 vote to authorize the Iraq war and her support for a $12-an-hour--but not $15--federal minimum wage, which he thundered was "not good enough!"This month is likely to bring Mr. Sanders additional wins in a string of primaries in Nebraska, West Virginia, Oregon and Kentucky. The prospect of more Sanders victories echoes the 2008 Democratic primary, where Mrs. Clinton won several contests late in the calendar but was unable to catch then-Sen. Barack Obama, who built an early lead.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Live Coverage: Indiana Primary* Indiana Primaries: What to Watch* Independents Are Souring on Hillary Clinton* Who's Winning the Delegate Race?The voting wraps up in June, with big prizes including California and New Jersey. Democratic rules allocate delegates proportionately, meaning the loser gets nearly as many delegates as the winner in a close race, making it hard to catch up.Mr. Sanders made a strong play for Indiana, spending $1.5 million in TV ads and headlining a half-dozen rallies. State rules were in his favor, allowing independents, who typically favor him, to participate in the primary.Expecting a loss, Mrs. Clinton spent no money on TV ads and appeared at just three campaign rallies in Indiana. Campaign officials said they were husbanding funds raised for the primary campaign to spend later this spring and summer in states that are likely to be competitive in the fall."I think we had a good campaign" in Indiana, Mrs. Clinton said Tuesday on MSNBC. "We ran hard. But you know I'm really focused on moving into the general election."Mr. Sanders and his aides acknowledged it was virtually impossible for him to overtake her lead in pledged delegates, the type chosen by voters. Instead, they said he would work to win over super delegates, party leaders who can vote for whomever they like and who currently favor Mrs. Clinton by a wide margin.Mr. Sanders said Tuesday that superdelegates "have got to take a hard look at which candidate is more likely to defeat Donald Trump or whoever the Republican nominee may be.""I'm the stronger candidate," he said.Sanders advisers say they will also press the senator's progressive agenda at the party's national convention in Philadelphia this summer.Indiana voters split along familiar lines, with Sanders supporters lauding the breadth of his ideas and Clinton supporters calling her more pragmatic, experienced and electable in the fall."I think he's very relatable and I just agree with his ideas," said Sommer Hofman, a 17-year-old student in Carmel, Ind., who cast her first ballot for the Vermont senator on Tuesday."I like some of his ideas but I think the most important thing is that we win in November," said Jack Carrithers, 68, a retired ad executive from outside of Indianapolis.Coming into the balloting, Mrs. Clinton had 1,645 pledged delegates and Mr. Sanders had 1,318, meaning her lead was 327. Including superdelegates, she had 2,165 delegates to his 1,357, according to Associated Press tallies.A total of 2,383 delegates are needed to claim the nomination, so ahead of Indiana she was just over 200 from victory when superdelegates are counted.The Clinton campaign began turning its attention to November in earnest after last week's victory in four out of five northeastern states .The campaign named state directors in Colorado, Florida and New Hampshire, with more announcements to follow. It is hiring senior advisers, communications directors and digital outreach directors in these states. Aides were also calculating the election map, tentatively seeing North Carolina as competitive but less optimistic about Arizona and Georgia, two states Democrats have thought could flip to their side because of an influx of minority voters.The vice-presidential vetting was being led by campaign chairman John Podesta, with longtime aide Cheryl Mills also expected to play an active role. An announcement wasn't expected until July.Separately, the Hillary Victory Fund, a joint fundraising committee with the Democratic National Committee, has begun transferring money to state parties, including about $200,000 each to those in Ohio, Virginia and Florida. The money will be used to hire field staffers to support the presidential nominee and other Democratic candidates on the ballot.The party has begun hiring dozens of organizers in those states.Campaign officials said Mrs. Clinton would contest every primary through the final contests in mid-June. But they were braced for losses in May, in states where Mr. Sanders held the edge, and it was unclear whether the campaign would spend money in any of these states. One big question was whether California would be competitive enough to require TV advertising.Mrs. Clinton's travel schedule reflects her desire to keep an eye on the primaries while laying groundwork for the general election.This week, she traveled to Appalachia, making stops in West Virginia and Kentucky, two states that will hold contests this month, as well as Ohio, which will be closely contested in the fall.In Appalachia on Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton hit several general-election themes, pledging to fight for those who are disheartened and believe government, politics and the economy have failed them. As president, she said she would be "the convener-in-chief," bringing people together at the White House to forge solutions.She repeatedly attacked the GOP front-runner, Mr. Trump, warning that his tax plan would give trillions of dollars to millionaires and billionaires and calling his foreign policy reckless."When I listen to Donald Trump say some of what he's saying about foreign policy and national security, even I find it scary," she said. "He has given no indication that he understands the gravity of the responsibilities that go with being commander in chief and that will be a big part of my campaign."Byron Tau contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Bernie Sanders Seeks Indiana Win as Hillary Clinton Looks to November; Even with a win, Vermont senator unlikely to meaningfully reduce front-runner's delegate advantage
article text: ATHENS, Ohio--Hillary Clinton campaigned Tuesday in the fall battleground state of Ohio, looking past her Democratic primary contest against Sen. Bernie Sanders with confidence that her significant delegate lead would deliver the presidential nomination.The campaign in recent days began hiring staff across states expected to be competitive this fall, and her advisers were in the early stages of a vice-presidential selection process.While Tuesday's balloting was in Indiana , Mrs. Clinton spent no money on TV ads and appeared at just three campaign rallies in the state. Campaign officials, braced for a defeat, said they were husbanding funds raised for the primary campaign to spend later this spring and summer in states likely to be competitive in the fall."I think we had a good campaign" in Indiana, Mrs. Clinton said Tuesday on MSNBC. "We ran hard. But you know I'm really focused on moving into the general election."Mr. Sanders was hoping a victory could help his fundraising and fuel his argument for staying in the race, but even a win wasn't likely to meaningfully reduce her advantage.Mr. Sanders made a strong play for Indiana's 83 pledged delegates, spending $1.5 million in TV ads and headlining a half-dozen rallies. State rules were in his favor, allowing independents, who typically favor him, to participate in the primary.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Live Coverage: Indiana Primary* Indiana Primaries: What to Watch* Independents Are Souring on Hillary Clinton* Who's Winning the Delegate Race?Still, the senator and his aides acknowledged it was virtually impossible to overtake Mrs. Clinton's lead in pledged delegates, the type chosen by voters. Instead, they said he would work to win over superdelegates, party leaders who can vote for whomever they like and who favor Mrs. Clinton by a wide margin.Mr. Sanders said Tuesday that superdelegates "have got to take a hard look at which candidate is more likely to defeat Donald Trump or whoever the Republican nominee may be.""I'm the stronger candidate," he said.In Indiana, voters split along familiar lines, with Sanders supporters lauding the breadth of his ideas and Clinton supporters calling her more pragmatic, experienced and more electable in the fall."I think he's very relatable and I just agree with his ideas," said Sommer Hofman, a 17-year-old student in Carmel, Ind., who cast her first ballot for the Vermont senator on Tuesday."I like some of his ideas but I think the most important thing is that we win in November," said Jack Carrithers, 68, a retired ad executive from outside of Indianapolis.Coming into the balloting, Mrs. Clinton had 1,645 pledged delegates and Mr. Sanders had 1,318, meaning her lead was 327. Including superdelegates, she had 2,165 delegates to his 1,357, according to Associated Press tallies.A total of 2,383 delegates are needed to claim the nomination, so she was just over 200 from victory when superdelegates are counted.The Clinton campaign began turning its attention to November in earnest after last week's victory in four out of five northeastern states .The campaign named state directors in Colorado, Florida and New Hampshire, with more announcements to follow. It is hiring senior advisers, communications directors and digital outreach directors in these states. Aides were also calculating the election map, tentatively seeing North Carolina as competitive but less optimistic about Arizona and Georgia, two states Democrats have thought could flip to their side because of an influx of minority voters.The vice-presidential vetting was being led by campaign chairman John Podesta, with longtime aide Cheryl Mills also expected to play an active role. An announcement wasn't expected until July.Separately, the Hillary Victory Fund, a joint fundraising committee with the Democratic National Committee, has begun transferring money to state parties, including about $200,000 each to those in Ohio, Virginia and Florida. The money will be used to hire field staffers to support the presidential nominee and other Democratic candidates on the ballot.The party has begun hiring dozens of organizers in those states.Campaign officials said Mrs. Clinton would contest every primary through the final contests in mid-June. But they were braced for losses in May, in states where Mr. Sanders held the edge, and it was unclear whether the campaign would spend money in any of these states. One big question was whether California would be competitive enough to require TV advertising.Mrs. Clinton's travel schedule reflects her desire to keep an eye on the primaries while laying groundwork for the general election.This week, she traveled to Appalachia, making stops in West Virginia and Kentucky, two states that will hold contests this month, as well as Ohio, which will be closely contested in the fall.In Appalachia on Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton hit several general-election themes, pledging to fight for those who are disheartened and believe government, politics and the economy have failed them. As president, she said she would be "the convener-in-chief," bringing people together at the White House to forge solutions.She repeatedly attacked the GOP front-runner, Mr. Trump, warning that his tax plan would give trillions of dollars to millionaires and billionaires and calling his foreign policy reckless."When I listen to Donald Trump say some of what he's saying about foreign policy and national security, even I find it scary," she said. "He has given no indication that he understands the gravity of the responsibilities that go with being commander in chief and that will be a big part of my campaign."Byron Tau contributed to this article.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Hillary Clinton Is Taking Fire From Two Rivals; Democrat is trying to turn her focus to Donald Trump but has yet to fend off Bernie Sanders
article text: Hillary Clinton is now fighting a two-front war for the presidency, facing an emboldened, combative Donald Trump while fending off Bernie Sanders, who promises to take his campaign all the way to the Democratic National Convention in July.Mr. Trump, by contrast, has cleared the Republican field and can direct his firepower at Mrs. Clinton alone. He signaled Wednesday that he would pick up Mr. Sanders's line of attack against the Democratic front-runner."Bernie actually said she's unqualified because she's got bad judgment, and it's true," Mr. Trump told Time magazine.Mrs. Clinton is also attacking Mr. Trump on a daily basis, and Wednesday she told CNN the U.S. can't afford to take a risk on a "blustering, bullying guy." "He is a loose cannon, and loose cannons tend to misfire," she added.The landscape has shifted beneath Mrs. Clinton. For months, it seemed as if Republicans were headed for a messy, contested summer convention, while Democrats would unify behind the front-runner. Mr. Trump still faces an insurgency within his party, with many Republicans vowing they would never support him, but Mrs. Clinton is the one with a persistent primary foe drawing support from a large chunk of the party.Democrats say they are confident that the party will rally around Mrs. Clinton, partly in response to the prospect of a Trump presidency. Mrs. Clinton holds a nearly insurmountable delegate lead. She lost to Mr. Sanders on Tuesday in Indiana , but the victory cut Mrs. Clinton's lead by only six delegates. Three other contests this month favor Mr. Sanders, but they also are unlikely to eat meaningfully into her lead among pledged delegates , which now stands at 321.Nonetheless, victory emboldened the Vermont senator, and he went after Mrs. Clinton directly at a rally Tuesday night. His aides said Wednesday that the aggressive posture would continue at least through the last primary in June and that Mr. Trump's emergence as the presumptive Republican nominee changes nothing. "Full steam ahead, absolutely," said Sanders campaign manager Jeff Weaver.On Tuesday, Mr. Sanders challenged Mrs. Clinton to another debate, in California, which votes on June 7, something Mrs. Clinton had agreed to in February. A Clinton aide declined to comment on the prospect.The Sanders campaign says it will fight to wrest the nomination away from Mrs. Clinton. While lagging behind in pledged delegates, those chosen by voters, he is even farther behind Mrs. Clinton among superdelegates, party leaders who can vote for whomever they like. His strategy is to win over the superdelegates by arguing he would be the stronger general-election candidate.It is a difficult case to make. Mr. Sanders is asking party leaders--the establishment that he rails against in every speech--to overturn the will of Democratic voters, who have cast more votes for Mrs. Clinton than for him. Since Mr. Sanders announced this approach nearly two months ago, not a single superdelegate has switched sides.Either way, Mr. Sanders plans to press for a range of liberal policy issues at the party convention in Philadelphia in July. That means that, at minimum, the Clinton forces will face a strong push for policies that she has already rejected, such as a Medicare-style health-care plan for all, a carbon tax and a $15-an-hour federal minimum wage.Ben Wikler, Washington director for liberal group MoveOn.org, said his members would back Mr. Sanders's push for the party to adopt "the most progressive platform ever" and characterized the coming debate as a "fight for the soul" of the party. But he said MoveOn opposes any effort to have superdelegates overturn the pledged delegates.Others in the party are eager for Mr. Sanders to let up."It's time for Sen. Sanders to tone it down and stop criticizing her....It's no longer at all helpful, and I'd argue that it's problematic," Steve Elmendorf, a veteran of Democratic presidential campaigns who backs Mrs. Clinton, said Wednesday. "People are going to start telling him that."Mark Mellman, a veteran Democratic pollster, added that Mr. Sanders's continued criticism wouldn't change the course of the Democratic campaign, "but it does give Trump fodder for ads and attacks."For its part, the Clinton campaign has turned its attention almost completely to the general election. Mrs. Clinton is traveling to states with Democratic contests to make clear she will "honor the primary" process, and she believes Mr. Sanders should stay in the race as long as he likes, an aide said. But the campaign isn't spending money on TV ads in these states. It has started hiring staff for general-election battleground states, and Mrs. Clinton this week campaigned in Ohio, which is likely to be closely contested this fall. Her advisers are in the early stages of a vice-presidential selection process.Mrs. Clinton said Wednesday she would focus on explaining what she would do as president and would press Mr. Trump to do the same."At some point when you're running for president, you actually have to put a little meat on the bones," she told CNN. "You've got to tell people what it is you're going to do and how you're going do it."With fewer reporters covering Mr. Sanders's events, and the public increasingly focused on the general election, Clinton aides don't appear particularly concerned about the persistent Sanders attacks.Rather, they say Mr. Trump's ascendance will help unify Democrats around her, and Wednesday morning the campaign emailed supporters with an anti-Trump message. "This is really happening," it read. "Trump is going to be the Republican nominee."William Galston, a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution who worked in Bill Clinton's White House, said he doesn't see any contradiction between Mrs. Clinton's campaigning against both Messrs. Sanders and Trump at the same time. He pointed to 2008, when Mrs. Clinton campaigned through the last Democratic primary against then-Sen. Barack Obama, and Sen. John McCain already had clinched the Republican nomination."Hillary Clinton is hardly the first candidate to find herself fighting a two-front war," he said. "My sense is that she will be able to walk and chew gum at the same time."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Election 2016: Key Test for Sanders Looms
article text: NEW YORK -- A New York primary that once looked like a sure thing for Hillary Clinton looms as a pivotal showdown in the Democratic presidential race, with rival Bernie Sanders hoping to embarrass her in her adopted state with a strong showing that would raise doubts about her electability.Both campaigns see New York as a prize with one of two potential outcomes: A Clinton victory that deprives Mr. Sanders of one of his best remaining chances to cut into her delegate lead, or a Sanders upset that would advance his argument to superdelegates that she is a risky bet in the general election.With 247 delegates up for grabs, New York carries the largest cache of the convention representatives of any state left on the calendar save for California. Mrs. Clinton now leads in pledged delegates by 1,243 to 980. If Mr. Sanders can't come out New York with a heavy majority of the state's delegates, the race effectively would be over, Clinton aides said."There's very little evidence to date of their ability to win the big, diverse states like New York by the type of margin they would truly need to overcome the delegate edge," said Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon.Mindful of the stakes, each candidate figures to compete ahead of the April 19 contest in New York with an intensity not seen since Iowa and New Hampshire. Though the Wisconsin primary is Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton peeled away from the Badger State for three straight days of campaigning in New York that will culminate Friday with a pair of campaign stops in Syracuse.Her campaign rolled out a new 30-second TV spot that will air in New York and her husband on Thursday held several rallies in Manhattan. Earlier in the week, Bill Clinton took part in private meetings with African-American and Hispanic leaders who could help boost turnout in minority neighborhoods that favor Mrs. Clinton.One attendee was Bronx Borough President Ruben Diaz Jr. In an interview, Mr. Diaz said the meeting with a small group of elected officials and business leaders covered both policy and political strategy. "They're taking New York state seriously. They're not taking anything for granted," he said.Both candidates boast ties to the state that they will highlight in the run-up to the vote. Mrs. Clinton represented New York for eight years in the Senate and owns a home in Chappaqua; Mr. Sanders grew up in the state.At a rally Thursday at the State University of New York at Purchase, in the same county as her home, Mrs. Clinton, said: "It is so good to be home.. . .Westchester is more than a county to me. It's a community where Bill and Chelsea and I moved back in 1999," she said, rattling off some local restaurants she enjoys.At the university event, she had a brief, tense conversation with a Greenpeace activist on the rope line who asked about contributions she's gotten from the fossil fuel industry. Mrs. Clinton, pointing her finger at the woman, said: "I am so sick, I am so sick of the Sanders campaign lying about this.""I was honestly surprised by her reaction today. I wasn't expecting that," said 26-year-old Eva Resnick-Day, who said neither she nor Greenpeace has any affiliation with the Sanders campaign.Appearing in Harlem on Wednesday, Mrs. Clinton showcased her ties to New York officials. She was accompanied at a stop at a cake shop by Rep. Charlie Rangel, who took aim at Mr. Sanders in a conversation with reporters. He congratulated the Vermont senator on making income inequality a priority."Now I need some help as to what else he's made a priority," Mr. Rangel said.Mr. Sanders was raised in a 3<frac12> room apartment in Brooklyn and despite having lived in Vermont for decades he has retained his New York accent. His campaign is planning events that will highlight his origins, including trips to his old neighborhood and even the running tracks where he competed as a high school athlete in the 1950s."It's going to be difficult for us to win in her home state. But that's what we're going to try to do," said Tad Devine, a senior Sanders strategist. "And I do think that if we can find a way to defeat her it would be a gigantic signal that Hillary Clinton is a weak front-runner."A Quinnipiac University poll released Thursday showed Mrs. Clinton beating Mr. Sanders in the state 54% to 42%. Still, the poll offered some hopeful news for the Vermont senator: New Yorkers seem to like him better.A total of 49% had an unfavorable view of Mrs. Clinton, compared with 45% who viewed her favorably. For Mr. Sanders, 54% had a favorable view, versus only 30% who had a negative opinion of him.---Colleen McCain Nelson and Thomas MacMillan contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Erica Orden

article name: Election 2016 -- Politics Counts: The Race for Followers and 'Influencers' --- An analysis of presidential candidates' social-media accounts shows Republican front-runner Donald Trump with the largest following, while Bernie Sanders is winning among young people
article text: More so than any election before, the 2016 race for the White House is being fueled by Twitter fights and Facebook memes. An analysis of the presidential candidates' social-media followers shows who they are reaching, and suggests how social media could be helping -- or hurting -- the contenders.Businessman Donald Trump has the largest social-media following of the presidential candidates. An analysis by social-media data company Captiv8 of Twitter, Facebook, YouTube and Instagram followers of the candidates shows that Sen. Bernie Sanders has a strong following from young people, while Republican candidates tend to have more followers over age 30.Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton's corps of followers is evenly split between men and women, and her most-engaged followers are 25-34 years old. Of Mr. Trump's most-engaged followers, by comparison, 62% are male and 38% are female, and his most-engaged followers are 30-39 years old. Most-engaged is defined as followers that have liked, commented, shared or retweeted a candidates's social posts.Captiv8 uses image recognition, and links social-media accounts to determine age, gender and location information. The firm says its analysis has a 88%-90% accuracy rate. Captiv8 doesn't track private accounts.Some of Instagram's most-followed accounts, including singers Katy Perry and Miley Cyrus, are following Mrs. Clinton. These so-called "influencers" can help Mrs. Clinton spread her message and draw new followers to her account, says Captiv8 founder Krishna Subramanian.Ms. Perry's 44.4 million followers and Ms. Cyrus's 39.8 million followers are king-size compared with the former secretary of state's one million.(See accompanying chart -- WSJ Apr. 1, 2016)Credit: By Natalie Andrews

article name: Bernie Sanders Supporters Seek to Make His Liberal Agenda Endure; Hard-core believers plan to convert enthusiasm surrounding candidacy into lasting movement
article text: As Bernie Sanders's prospects of reaching the White House fade, his hard-core supporters are taking steps to convert the enthusiasm surrounding his candidacy into an enduring movement that pushes the Democratic Party further left and promotes parts of the liberal agenda he has championed.A loose-knit coalition of ex-Sanders aides and allies are exploring ways to elect like-minded candidates to Congress and influence the Democratic Party platform at the convention in Philadelphia in July.They are planning an event in Chicago in June, "The People's Summit," a likely forum for discussions about keeping the Vermont senator's vision alive even if there is no Sanders presidency."The real question is how do you take those people who are mobilized and all their energy and begin to build local organizations that can actually play a political role in their communities," said Joseph Schwartz, vice chairman of Democratic Socialists of America, one of the groups planning to take part in the summit.What part Mr. Sanders might play in a new movement is unclear. He hasn't given up on defeating front-runner Hillary Clinton in the Democratic primary. Aides say he hasn't committed to attending the summit in Chicago and they indicated he isn't looking past the primary race."Our focus is on giving voters in California, Oregon, West Virginia and other states that still haven't voted a chance to take part in the democratic process," said Sanders spokesman Michael Briggs.Fresh in the minds of older Sanders backers are the Jesse Jackson presidential bids in the 1980s. Like Mr. Sanders, Mr. Jackson attracted passionate voters, but when he lost some were left disillusioned that Mr. Jackson's "Rainbow Coalition" didn't do more to shape the nation's politics.Sanders supporters hope to build on the surprising strength the senator has demonstrated in the primaries. That is a tougher sell without a charismatic candidate on the trail, but Sanders allies say his campaign revealed a widespread yearning for a more liberal tilt to party politics."Bernie's made it remarkably clear that there is an enormous audience for sensible, progressive politics, and shame on us if we don't take advantage of that," said Dan Cantor, national director of the Working Families Party, a third-party group that shares Mr. Sanders's concerns about income inequality.A collection of Sanders volunteers and former staff have started a group called Brand New Congress, which is trying to recruit congressional candidates who are in sync with Mr. Sanders's message."Whether Bernie wins or not, we'll be implementing the plan," said Kristellys Estanga, 28, of Jacksonville, Fla. "With all the networks that we built locally, statewide and nationally with the Bernie campaign, it brought forward the most talented progressives, and we don't want to lose that."Another focus is the party platform to be negotiated at the convention. Sanders supporters see it as a chance to reshape the party's identity.Even if he loses to Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Sanders will have a large share of delegates who want enshrined in the platform many of his ideas: a single-payer, government-run health-care system, a $15 minimum wage, and limits on the role of superdelegates in primaries. That could set up a clash, given that Mrs. Clinton has her own agenda to promote.Making matters tougher for the Sanders forces, the Democratic National Committee has named pro-Clinton co-chairs of the rules and platform committees: former Massachusetts congressman Barney Frank and Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy, respectively.Many delegates will come from the National Nurses United union, one of the most outspoken players in the Sanders coalition. Union leaders said these delegates intend to aggressively push for a platform reflecting Sanders's vision and won't easily accept defeat."It's going to be the most explosive Democratic Party convention in history," said RoseAnn DeMoro, executive director of the union. "People are not going to sit still."Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas
