"We have to keep our eyes, our minds, our hearts, our souls on what we can do to move to that more perfect union."Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Hillary Clinton Looks to Avoid Convention Fight as Bernie Sanders Presses Agenda; Senator's campaign is demanding that Democratic platform reflect his message
article text: Looking to avoid a messy Democratic convention this summer, people close to likely nominee Hillary Clinton predict she will give Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders much of what he wants on the party's platform. But at least for now, the Sanders forces are itching for a fight.Already, Mr. Sanders has accused the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee of stacking convention committees in favor of the former secretary of state and has threatened a floor fight if he isn't treated fairly."This convention should be a real debating place about what the party is and what it should stand for," said Larry Cohen, a Sanders adviser and retired labor leader.Mrs. Clinton says Mr. Sanders has "every right" to continue competing until the last votes are cast, but she has made clear that she expects unity to follow, as it did following her 2008 defeat. "We're going to unify the party, and we're going to have a great convention," she said last week on MSNBC.The different messages reflect the candidates' differing situations. Mrs. Clinton is gearing up for the fall contest; Mr. Sanders is still hoping to wrest the prize from her and, barring that, push the Democratic Party closer to his populist agenda.It is possible that the two sides will reach accommodation after the voting ends in mid-June and before the convention begins in late July. At the moment, though, they appear far from an agreement over the tone and substance of the four-day gathering, which the Clinton campaign views as one of its best opportunities to communicate her vision to voters.Her campaign is in the early stages of planning the program, including who will deliver major speeches and what the overall themes should be. Meantime, people close to the campaign said they were waiting for a signal from Mr. Sanders as to what he wants and how the pair can come together.Mr. Sanders is promising a "contested convention" and says the nominee won't be chosen until delegates arrive in Philadelphia. His campaign also is demanding that the Democratic platform reflect his message and a handful of major changes to how the party picks future nominees.With eight states plus the District of Columbia yet to vote, it is almost impossible for Mr. Sanders to overtake Mrs. Clinton's lead among pledged delegates, the type chosen by voters. He also trails badly among superdelegates, party leaders who can vote for whomever they like.Short of an outright win, aides say Mr. Sanders will insist that a range of his positions be reflected in the platform, including a single-payer, government-run health program; a $15 federal minimum wage; expanded Social Security benefits; opposition to free-trade agreements; and free tuition at public colleges. In each case, Mrs. Clinton has alternative views that don't go as far as his do."It's not about unifying the party," said Warren Gunnels, Mr. Sanders's policy chief, who will likely represent the campaign on the platform-drafting committee. "It's about making sure we have big, bold change that will fundamentally transform the U.S. economy....There are still fundamental disagreements."Mrs. Clinton has argued that most of the Sanders plans are unrealistic and that some of them are unworkable. But several Clinton allies said the campaign is likely to let him insert at least some of what he wants in the party platform. That is partly because they don't see the two as being very far apart, and partly because they say the platform language doesn't really matter anyway.Hilary Rosen, a Democratic consultant who is close to the Clinton campaign, predicted that the campaign would have an "open mind" on these issues and "a commitment to progressive values.""We've heard time and again from Hillary Clinton in the last couple of weeks that she respects Sen. Sanders and she respects his supporters. As far as the Clinton team is concerned, most everything is on the table in terms of how do we most effectively come out of that convention united," she said.Former Pennsylvania Gov. Ed Rendell, another Clinton ally, predicted much more comity than confrontation. Disputes, he said, can be handled in a "healthy way.""If both sides go at these disagreements with the right spirit, you can reach some clearly good agreements," he said.Clinton spokesman Brian Fallon also suggested that her campaign isn't looking for a fight. "Hillary Clinton is proud of the progressive ideas she put forward in this campaign, and we expect the platform will reflect those ideas," he said. "She has also made clear that there is much more that unites Democrats than divides us."The Sanders campaign is also pushing for changes affecting the rules of the party and how future presidential nominations are decided. Priorities include reducing the power of superdelegates, pressuring states to allow independents to vote in party primaries and swearing off super-PAC contributions in primary races, said Mr. Cohen, the Sanders adviser, who is also a member of the Democratic National Committee. He said these points should be debated by the convention's rules committee.It is unclear whether the committee will have the power to deal with these issues. A DNC spokesman said party rules give that panel jurisdiction over rules related to the 2016 convention, not delegate selection or other matters. Other experts on party rules say that these issues could be debated in Philadelphia with recommendations for future action.Former Rep. Barney Frank of Massachusetts, a Clinton ally who will serve as co-chairman of the rules committee, said he is sympathetic to some of the Sanders agenda, including reducing the power of superdelegates as a move to make the process more democratic.As for issues, Mr. Frank doesn't anticipate big fights."There aren't major issue divisions between [Mr. Sanders] and Hillary Clinton," he said.He said Mr. Sanders's call for a $15 minimum wage is "very likely" to be included in a platform, even though Mrs. Clinton backs $12. And Mrs. Clinton herself took a step toward Mr. Sanders on health care this week when she floated the idea of expanding eligibility for Medicare to people as young as 50, who could buy in.Mr. Frank said Democrats have been for "Medicare for all" before. "I don't think there's any problem with that being an ultimate goal."Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: School Once Run by Jane Sanders Plans to Close, After Expansion Fails; Burlington College says $10 million acquisition left it mired in debt
article text: Burlington College, a tiny Vermont liberal arts school once led by Jane Sanders, the wife of presidential candidate Bernie Sanders, said it is shutting down because of financial problems associated with a property acquisition she oversaw.In a formal statement announcing its closure, the school cited the "crushing weight" of debt it took on in a 2010 purchase of more than 30 acres from the local Catholic archdiocese. Mrs. Sanders was the college's president at the time of the $10 million deal.The college had financial challenges before Mrs. Sanders took the helm. In her seven years there, she attempted an ambitious expansion of the school's physical footprint and 200-student body. But the major investment didn't bear fruit in terms of drawing more students and bringing in higher tuition revenue, and the school's financial health has remained fragile since. She resigned in 2011.An attempt to reach Mrs. Sanders through the Sanders campaign wasn't immediately answered.Many smaller colleges are facing bleak fiscal futures, with many forced to offer significant scholarships to woo students but barely breaking even on what tuition revenue they bring in, as expenses continue to rise. The National Association of College and University Business Officers reported Monday that the discount rate for freshmen at private colleges this year hit a record 48.6%, meaning students pay just over 50 cents on every dollar of published tuition.Burlington said in a statement Monday that it has cut its debt to a "manageable level" through property sales, but learned last month that its lender wouldn't renew a credit line, which is needed to cover costs between semesters.Burlington's accreditor, the New England Association of Schools and Colleges, placed it on probation in 2014 because of financial concerns. It is allowed to remain on probation for only two years."These hurdles are insurmountable at this time," the school said.Burlington's board of trustees voted Friday to close its programs effective May 27. The school held its commencement ceremony for the class of 2016 on Saturday.Current students will be able to complete their studies at nearby colleges, Burlington said.Laura Meckler contributed to this article.Write to Melissa Korn at melissa.korn@wsj.comCredit: By Melissa Korn

article name: Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders in Tight Race in Kentucky; In Oregon primaries, Sanders and Donald Trump take victories
article text: LEXINGTON, Ky.--Hillary Clinton held a narrow lead over Bernie Sanders late Tuesday in Kentucky's Democratic presidential primary, a result that blunted the Vermont senator's latest burst of momentum and likely thwarted his hopes of putting together a winning streak in the final state contests.With 99% of precincts reporting, Mrs. Clinton led her Democratic rival by less than 1 percentage point there.Mrs. Clinton declared victory on Twitter. "We just won Kentucky!" she tweeted. "Thanks to everyone who turned out. We're always stronger united."Mr. Sanders won the Democratic primary in Oregon, the other state voting Tuesday, and Donald Trump won the Republican primary there. The New York businessman won the Kentucky GOP caucuses on March 5.Still, Mr. Sanders told supporters in California Tuesday night that his campaign has "a real shot to win" several of the remaining Democratic contests. "We are in until the last ballot is cast," he said.While Mrs. Clinton has amassed a nearly insurmountable lead in gathering the 2,383 delegates needed to clinch the nomination in the Democratic race, she has been lumbering toward the finish line while being forced to simultaneously fend off attacks from Messrs. Sanders and Trump.There were 116 Democratic delegates up for grabs Tuesday, 55 in Kentucky and 61 in Oregon, all of which will be distributed proportionally.Heading into Tuesday's contests, Mrs. Clinton had 2,240, when both pledged delegates and superdelegates were tallied, leaving her just 143 delegates shy of victory. Mr. Sanders had a combined delegate count of 1,473, which meant the only way he could catch her would be to amass a large number of superdelegates.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Sanders Says Campaign Committed to Nonviolence Amid Nevada Dust-Up* Hillary Clinton's Strengths and Weaknesses in Kentucky* Clinton Hints at the Role Her Husband Would Play* In Battleground State, Republicans Are Split on Trump* Analysis: Tea Party Eyes Trump--Warily* May 17: Live Primary Results* What Trump May Look for in His Vice President* Who's Winning the Delegate Race?So far, the Vermont senator has had little luck in persuading those elected officials and party leaders, who are free to back any candidate, to rally behind his candidacy.That challenge likely becomes more difficult now after his supporters, angry over the handling of delegate allocation at a Nevada convention on Saturday , issued death threats to the state's party chairwoman. The messages were so vicious that Nevada officials filed a complaint with the Democratic National Committee.Mr. Sanders in a statement Tuesday condemned "any and all forms of violence," but defended his supporters and railed against the party process for picking a nominee.The Democratic Party "can open its doors and welcome into the party people who are prepared to fight for real economic and social change--people who are willing to take on Wall Street, corporate greed and a fossil fuel industry which is destroying this planet. Or the party can choose to maintain its status quo structure," he said.In an effort to stall Mr. Sanders's momentum, Mrs. Clinton made three trips to Kentucky, visiting churches, holding small-group discussions, shaking hands at an overflowing diner and headlining a half-dozen rallies. She pitched herself as the best candidate to manage the nation's challenges, including national security and what she characterized as Mr. Trump's "reckless" approach to issues."I will work for you. I will fight for you. I will stand up for you," she said at a final rally Monday in Lexington.Her campaign spent about $300,000 on TV ads, compared with about $100,000 for the Vermont senator, a Sanders aide said. Clinton aides said that was partly because they saw the state as winnable and partly because ad time in Kentucky is inexpensive.The Clinton campaign's investment in Kentucky marked a change in strategy after the former secretary of state all but ceded Indiana, where Mr. Sanders won by 5 percentage points, and West Virginia, where his margin of victory was almost 16 points.Mr. Sanders spent four days in Kentucky and continued to argue that he would be a stronger general-election candidate and a tougher foe for the New York businessman."In virtually every national poll and in statewide polls we do better against Donald Trump than Secretary Clinton. We're seeing that all over the country," Mr. Sanders said during a weekend campaign stop in Kentucky."Secretary Clinton does very well with Democrats and so do I, but there are a lot of independents in the country and we do very well with independents," he said.Voters in the state reveled at the chance to size up the candidates so late in the primary process. The last contest is June 14 in Washington, D.C., a week after California, New Jersey and other states hold primaries or caucuses."I really appreciate what she's done for our country and what she will do," Mollijean Frazier said of Mrs. Clinton. The retired schoolteacher was among a crush of people greeting Mrs. Clinton at a Paducah diner Monday morning. "I think Bernie Sanders's people are looking for something that's not going to happen, sort of pie in the sky."In Louisville, Shea Stephens said she planned to cast a ballot for Mr. Sanders. "I can't find anything wrong with the man," said the 42-year-old technical account manager.Ms. Stephens said Mrs. Clinton "is the epitome of everything I do not like in politics."Mrs. Clinton came to Kentucky with some distinct advantages. She easily won the state in the 2008 Democratic presidential primary. The state's rules limit participation to registered Democrats, excluding the independent voters who have favored Mr. Sanders all year.Her husband, former President Bill Clinton, who campaigned separately for her, won the state twice and remains popular. During her appearances, she repeatedly invoked his economic record and promised to put him to work helping to revive the economy.There was concern, though, in the Clinton campaign that the electorate would include conservative Democrats who would cast their ballots against Mrs. Clinton, and therefore for Mr. Sanders. That appeared to be the case last week in West Virginia.She faced other headwinds, including fallout from a comment earlier this year when, in the course of discussing a plan to help coal communities, she predicted that her energy agenda would put a lot of coal miners out of work.Sunday and Monday, she worked to make amends, speaking emotionally of how coal miners' sacrifices allowed the nation to power itself and grow. "We do need to transition" to cleaner forms of energy, she said Monday in Bowling Green, "but we need to take coal country and coal miners and their families with us and not leave them behind."Arian Campo-Flores contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Laura Meckler

article name: Venezuela and Young Supporters of 'The Bern'; The millennials who support Bernie Sanders have no comprehension of the of capitalism or the pain created by socialism.
article text: Everybody who voted for Bernie Sanders must read Mary Anastasia O'Grady's "Venezuela's Hunger Is No Game " (Americas, May 9) to see how destructive socialism is to humanity.Twenty years ago one of my favorite distributors was located in Venezuela. He was so excited about the prospects for his country, and the improvement in the quality of life of all Venezuelans, that he pumped me up. The country had great natural resources and, if managed properly, it and its people could be the most prosperous in South America.Just before I retired a few years ago, I met with him again. He almost wept as he talked about the horrible decline of Venezuela under socialist Hugo Chávez. He told me that it was becoming impossible to do business in Venezuela and that he might have to shut down his business and leave the country he loved. Today, Venezuela is at the brink of total disaster and the suffering of the Venezuelan people is beyond comprehension. They can't even get toilet paper or enough water to survive.Sadly, the 48% of millennials who support Bernie Sanders have no comprehension of the wonderful benefits of capitalism or the horrible pain created by socialism. This is because our liberal-biased media and schools love to attack capitalism. The only positive outcome of the tragedy in Venezuela will be if it serves as the global wake-up call about the disaster that is known as socialism.Randy RossiGrayslake, Ill.

article name: Democrats Fear an Unruly July Convention in Philadelphia; Bernie Sanders backers seek permits to demonstrate, sparking worries of damage to party and Hillary Clinton
article text: A growing number of Democrats are bracing for a divisive and disorderly July presidential convention in Philadelphia that could damage the party and expected nominee Hillary Clinton.A loose coalition of supporters of rival Sen. Bernie Sanders is using social media to plan a series of events at the Democratic National Convention. Using pro-Sanders blogs and websites, organizers will be pressing to insert his progressive agenda--from free college tuition to revisions in the primary process--into the party's platform.At least five of the nine permit applications to hold demonstrations during the four-day event have been filed by pro-Sanders forces with the Philadelphia city government, according to the mayor's office. The groups planning the events are named The Berners, Black Men for Bernie, Movement for Bernie and Bernie-or-Bust. No applications have been filed yet by supporters of Mrs. Clinton.Cleveland, the site of the Republican National Convention, which was once expected to be a disruptive event, reported receiving six permit applications as of early May--none indicating that they are in support of any former Republican candidates."I really wouldn't call it a protest. It's a political revolution. It's something that we will celebrate," said Bill Taylor, a 30-year-old Philadelphia resident and Sanders campaign volunteer who is helping organize the demonstrations at the convention. "There is no stopping the movement that Bernie has created. This isn't about one man."The prospective protests could undermine efforts by the party to unite its wings for the fall fight against presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump, and overshadow the fact that Mrs. Clinton's is the first female nominee of a major U.S. political party.Both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump inched closer to clinching their respective nominations on Tuesday, as the former secretary of state declared victory in the Kentucky primary and Mr. Trump rolled up a win in Oregon. Mr. Sanders won the Oregon Democratic primary, though he has almost no chance of catching Mrs. Clinton in the race for the 2,383 delegates needed to win.Doug Schoen, a polling expert who has advised former President Bill Clinton, said the divisions within the party "appear to be widening, not narrowing, in ways that could be calamitous, particularly if there is ongoing chaos at the Democratic convention."The animus between Mr. Sanders and some party leaders boiled over into public view on Saturday, when his backers, angry over the delegate allocation at a Nevada state convention that favored Mrs. Clinton, began shouting, throwing chairs and issuing death threats to the state party chairwoman. Mrs. Clinton won the Feb. 20 Nevada caucuses.In a text message exchange, one person warned: "We know where you live...where you work...where you eat...where your kids go to school/grandkids...we have everything on you," before adding: "You made a bad choice. Prepare for hell."While party leaders urged Mr. Sanders to act as a calming influence, he inflamed tensions by issuing a complicated statement that condemned violence, justified his supporters' frustrations and railed against the party's process for selecting a nominee.During a California rally Tuesday night, he delivered a message to Democratic leaders, urging them to "do the right thing" and welcome into the fold people who are prepared to fight for the economic and social change proposals in his platform."I say to the leadership of the Democratic Party: Open the doors. Let the people in," Mr. Sanders shouted.Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz said on CNN she deemed Mr. Sanders's response unacceptable.By Wednesday, many Democrats appeared eager to move on from the kerfuffle. Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook called for unity, while adding that harassment and intimidation were unacceptable in the primary process."We are confident that the passion and energy from the primary will be united in a common purpose--to move forward the ideals of our party and keep the White House out of Donald Trump's hands," Mr. Mook said.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* What Kentucky Results Show About Clinton-Sanders Battle* Trump Names 11 Potential Supreme Court Nominees* Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump Face Hurdle Not Seen in Modern History* GOP Near Agreement With Treasury on Puerto Rico Bill* Trump Details His Income SourcesBut the Sanders team refused to relent. Asked on MSNBC if the campaign regretted the tone of its initial remarks, campaign manager John Weaver said: "No, I don't, as a matter of fact."While he called the people who made threatening phone calls "idiots," Mr. Weaver then rattled off a litany of grudges against the DNC, ranging from the debate schedule to the primary rules.Protest organizers say their goal will be to prod the party to make long-term changes to the way it nominates candidates, such as curbing or eliminating the influence of superdelegates--who include many Democratic officeholders--and making more of the primaries open to independents and Republicans.A secondary goal is to convince many of the current superdelegates that Mr. Sanders would be a stronger candidate in the general election, though those delegates are the very party officials and elected leaders whom Mr. Sanders is currently challenging."Of course, we would like to try to convince some superdelegates to sway their vote," said Steve Okan Layne, 24, a Michigan resident and campaign volunteer who helped organize one of the events in Philadelphia.A senior aide to the Sanders campaign said it had little control over what his most ardent supporters might do in Philadelphia or beyond."They are the committed, passionate, ideological, issue-driven base of the party," said the aide. "The establishment wing of the party just wants to treat them like they are transactional folks who will step into line. If that's the way they are going to treat them throughout the convention, that's where we're going to have real trouble."California Sen. Dianne Feinstein expressed concerns about the July convention, saying that Mr. Sanders should have sent a full-throated message to his supporters what happened in Nevada wouldn't be tolerated."I don't want to go back to the '68 convention," she told CNN, referring to the tumultuous Democratic convention in Chicago. "I worry about what it does to the electorate as a whole, and he should, too."While relatively few Democratic officials came to Mr. Sanders's defense in the wake of the Nevada convention, Rep. Raul Grijalva (D., Ariz.) said that Mr. Sanders had responded appropriately."I don't know what more of an apology people want," he said. "That, to a great extent, is an apology. This campaign has instructed everybody in the field that that's not to occur. I don't know what else is expected."Siobhan Hughes contributed to this article.Credit: By Byron Tau and Colleen McCain Nelson

"We just won Kentucky!" she tweeted. "Thanks to everyone who turned out. We're always stronger united."Mr. Sanders won the Democratic primary in Oregon, the other state voting Tuesday, and Donald Trump won the Republican primary there. The New York businessman won the Kentucky GOP caucuses on March 5.Still, Mr. Sanders told supporters in California Tuesday night that his campaign has "a real shot to win" several of the remaining Democratic contests.
