article name: Hillary Clinton Expected to Be First Woman to Win Major Party Nomination; Democratic front-runner expected to win in New Jersey primary; Bernie Sanders aims for California triumph
article text: Hillary Clinton was poised to declare victory Tuesday night in the Democratic presidential primary race, emerging from a bruising battle as a history-making candidate and the first woman within striking distance of occupying the Oval Office.Her rise comes exactly eight years after she ended her 2008 bid by declaring primary voters had helped her put 18 million cracks in the glass ceiling that had prevented women from winning the presidency since the nation's founding."We're on our way to breaking the highest and hardest glass ceiling," she told supporters recently in California in a reference to the November general election, where she will square off with Republican presumptive nominee, Donald Trump.Read More on Capital Journal* Live Updates on Tuesday's Primaries* How Clinton Won* Call on Hillary Clinton Nomination Win Was a Surprise to Democratic Candidates* How California Voting Rules Complicate Bernie Sanders's Primary Challenge* California's Democratic Primary Map: Places to WatchVermont Sen. Bernie Sanders aimed to throw up one last roadblock by winning the California Democratic primary on Tuesday, when six states held contests. Mrs. Clinton's victory, however, was expected to be cemented with a win in New Jersey, hours before the polls closed in California.Ellen Dubois, a professor of history at the University of California, Los Angeles, said the unique road Mrs. Clinton walked underscored the transformation of women's roles. "There's been a gradual movement of women into meaningful positions in political parties and elected offices," she said. "Whatever happens in this election, it will not completely clear the path, but it does open the path."Women helped propel Mrs. Clinton to victory in the Democratic primary, exit polls taken this primary season in 27 states showed. While Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders split men's votes nearly evenly, the polls found the former secretary of state won 61% of women, while the Vermont senator won just 37%.But Mrs. Clinton still has work to do to shore up potential advantages with women voters as she pivots to the general election. A May Wall Street Journal/ NBC News poll found that she leads among women by 13 percentage points; among women with college educations she's ahead by 24 percentage points.But Mr. Trump leads among white women with less than a college education by 11 percentage points--more than his 9-point advantage among men.For his part, Mr. Trump appears determined to confront the gender issue head-on. "I was the one that really broke the glass ceiling on behalf of women more than anybody in the construction industry, and my relationship, I think, is going to end up being very good with women," Mr. Trump told Fox News.Although Mrs. Clinton was long viewed as the inevitable Democratic nominee, the road during this primary season was much rockier than anticipated, with Mr. Sanders posing an unexpectedly persistent and formidable threat.The self-described democratic socialist from Vermont won more than 20 contests along the way and--until this week--denied her the pledged delegates needed to become the party's standard-bearer."I am going to be meeting with our supporters to figure out the best way forward--so that we have a government which represents all of us and not just the 1%," Mr. Sanders told NBC News on Tuesday.Mrs. Clinton, a former New York senator, maintained a lead among superdelegates, party leaders who can back whomever they want, and that gave her an advantage throughout the race. They put her over the 2,383 delegate threshold on Monday, prompting the Associated Press to declare her the presumptive nominee.Mr. Sanders has long objected to the influence of superdelegates , who will officially cast their votes at the July convention in Philadelphia, and he has vowed to try to take some from Mrs. Clinton. It is unclear now, though, whether he will continue to woo them, or even whether he will keep campaigning through the final primary in Washington, D.C., on June 14, where Mrs. Clinton is favored to win.From the start, Mrs. Clinton embraced the historic nature of her candidacy, a contrast to 2008, when advisers concluded her priority should be to project toughness and assure voters she was prepared to be commander in chief.With four years as secretary of state on her résumé, advisers saw her gender in this campaign as a selling point, both for older women who came of age at a time when women had fewer opportunities, and for parents, who wanted to show their daughters anything was possible.On the campaign trail, she has talked frequently about women and children's issues, including equal pay for women . She reminded voters she was a new grandmother. In the campaign's online store, T-shirts made to look like her signature pantsuits were for sale, along with a pillow with the words, "A woman's place is in the White House."Soon, the campaign's social media hashtag became #ImWithHer and her supporters would chant "I believe that she can win."When Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell accused her of "playing the gender card," the campaign decided to highlight his words. Mrs. Clinton would recount the charge at rallies, adding that if sticking up for women's right was playing the gender card, then "deal me in!"Later, when Mr. Trump made a similar charge--this time accusing her of playing the "woman's card"--Mrs. Clinton revived the slogan, and her campaign began selling "woman's cards" to supporters.On Tuesday, the Clinton campaign celebrated the moment with a video featuring words and images of American women who have made history, including feminist Gloria Steinem and Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the first woman appointed to the U.S. Supreme Court. "Think of the suffragettes who gathered at Seneca Falls in 1848," Mrs. Clinton says, "and those who kept fighting until women could cast their vote," starting in 1920.Terry O'Neill, president of the National Organization for Women, said Mrs. Clinton's nomination--and Mr. Trump's focus on her gender--would spark an important discussion about the obstacles women still face. "There are still some progressives who, bless their hearts, are not on board with a woman becoming leader of the free world," she said. "I think it does need to be part of the national conversation."At the polls Tuesday, some voters said they were motivated by the chance to cast a historic vote--and they weren't all women. Andrew Rind, a 56-year-old Montclair, N.J., resident, said he voted for Mrs. Clinton based on her experience and because Mr. Sanders seems "a little too extreme." Electing a woman president "is long overdue," Mr. Rind said. "I'm kind of tired of the prototype of the privileged, white male president."Kate King and Peter Nicholas contributed to this article.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Laura Meckler

article name: Democrats Gird for Battle Over Platform; Hillary Clinton, Bernie Sanders supporters grapple over direction of party's policy agenda
article text: The prolonged Democratic presidential fight now shifts to a different arena, as Sen. Bernie Sanders and his supporters grapple with presumptive nominee Hillary Clinton over their imprint on a platform that will lay out the party's vision and policy goals.A party's platform is often a forgettable offshoot of the presidential nomination process. Once in office, presidents tend to follow their own judgment and don't typically pull out the party platform for guidance.But the Sanders-Clinton battle for the nomination was filled with policy disagreements that carry the potential to leave the party divided. Mrs. Clinton is in a stronger position to shape the platform, but the Sanders forces are hoping to produce a document that reflects some portion of his liberal agenda. Should Mr. Sanders and his supporters come away dissatisfied, it could complicate the Democrats' task of unifying the party following a bitter nomination contest.Jesse Ferguson, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton's campaign, voiced optimism that the two sides would bridge their differences. "Let's all remember, there is far more that unites us than divides us," he said.Indeed, issues of crime, punishment and race might be areas of agreement. Both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders have denounced police tactics that critics say target African-Americans.A Sanders campaign representative, Jonathan Tasini, said that coming to consensus wouldn't be easy. "It's a mistake to think there will be a 'Kumbaya' moment," he said. "We're not going to be standing there on the floor swaying with arms locked. There are fundamental differences about the future of the country and the party."Work begins this week in Washington, D.C., as the party's 15-member platform drafting committee holds two days of hearings devoted to the economy, education, foreign policy and other issues. The panel's task is to help produce a platform that delegates will approve in July at the nominating convention in Philadelphia.Tensions are evident. Mr. Sanders tried to appoint to the drafting committee RoseAnn DeMoro, the executive director of a national nurses union and a strong advocate for a single-payer, government-run health-care system that Mrs. Clinton insists cannot pass.Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz turned down the request. A convention official gave as the reason for excluding Ms. DeMoro a need for diverse membership of convention committees, which means not stacking them with labor leaders.The Sanders campaign has also filed a formal protest asking the DNC to remove Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy from his post as co-chairman of the full platform committee. A DNC panel last month rejected the request, but the Sanders campaign has said it would persist in trying to disqualify Mr. Malloy, describing him as a biased, Clinton partisan. A Malloy representative didn't respond to a request for comment.Another flashpoint is foreign policy. The drafting panel includes six people named by Mrs. Clinton, five by Mr. Sanders and four by Ms. Wasserman Schultz. Two of the Sanders appointees are Cornel West and James Zogby, both of whom have been critical of Israel's treatment of Palestinians.The Democrats' 2012 platform places heavy emphasis on Israel's security. Sanders allies may be looking for a chance to tip the language so that it is more sensitive to Palestinian interests.In an interview, Mr. Zogby, president of the Arab American Institute, spoke of "an emerging new consensus in the Democratic Party" that "Israeli needs and Palestinian needs both have to be understood.""We'll see how willing people are to find language that reflects that," he said.During the campaign, Mrs. Clinton supported a Middle East peace deal that would give Palestinians their own state. Still, there's no certainty Mrs. Clinton would go along with platform language that opponents might portray as elevating the Palestinian cause at the expense of an important U.S. ally, Israel.Other policy differences abound. Mr. Sanders wants a national minimum wage of $15; Mrs. Clinton supports a $12 minimum wage, though she has said she would back a $15 wage in some locations. Mr. Sanders opposes free-trade agreements; Mrs. Clinton has taken more of a case-by-case approach."If we don't get a very firm position against free trade, that will be a problem for me and a lot of other people," Mr. Tasini said.Warren Gunnels, a Sanders aide who is a nonvoting member of the platform drafting committee, said, "We're cautiously optimistic we can come together and have a platform that really addresses the needs of the middle class and working Americans."Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Hillary Clinton Secures Delegates Needed to Clinch Democratic Nomination, AP Tally Finds; Rival Bernie Sanders fights on as California, five other states hold contests
article text: LONG BEACH, Calif.--Hillary Clinton secured the delegates needed to clinch the Democratic nomination Monday night, according a tally by the Associated Press, crossing a historic milestone as she campaigned in California and pushed to end a long presidential primary campaign on a high note.Mrs. Clinton, who was only 23 delegates shy of the 2,383 needed for victory after Sunday's Puerto Rico primary, received commitments from additional delegates late Monday. Just a day before Tuesday's contests in California and five other states, Mrs. Clinton emerged as her party's presumptive nominee and the first woman to lead the ticket for a major U.S. political party.The former secretary of state had been expected to win the delegates needed to secure victory inTuesday's primaries , but a last-minute show of support from a number of superdelegates pushed her across the finish line a day earlier.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* How Clinton Has Fended off Sanders* California's Democratic Primary Map: Places to Watch* Trump Seeks to Rally Support Over His Criticism of Judge* Polls Show Gary Johnson Is Unknown to Most Americans* Pro-Clinton Ad Revisits Donald Trump's Mocking of Disabled ReporterAfter a protracted and contentious primary season, the battle for the Democratic nomination ended with little fanfare. Mrs. Clinton and her advisers declined to take a victory lap, saying that they remained focused on notching wins in Tuesday's contests.Speaking in Long Beach, Calif., on Monday, Mrs. Clinton, said, "According to the news, we are on the brink of a historic, historic, unprecedented moment, but we still have work to do, don't we?"Sen. Bernie Sanders spent Monday in the San Francisco Bay area. While he said he would do "everything I can" to win the 475 pledged delegates up for grabs in California, he toned down his rhetoric on continuing his campaign, sounding less determined to fight through the Democratic National Convention in July.Mr. Sanders's campaign rejected the assertion that Mrs. Clinton is now the presumptive nominee, noting that the delegate total includes superdelegates, who still could change their minds before the Democratic convention in July."It is unfortunate that the media, in a rush to judgment, are ignoring the Democratic National Committee's clear statement that it is wrong to count the votes of superdelegates before they actually vote at the convention this summer," said Michael Briggs, Mr. Sanders's spokesman.The last big primary day on the calendar comes as President Barack Obama is poised to enter the fray and endorse the party's presumed nominee. The president spoke over the weekend with Mr. Sanders, according to a person with knowledge of the phone call, but it isn't known what the men discussed.The six states on Tuesday--New Jersey, New Mexico, Montana, South Dakota and North Dakota are the others--will award a combined total of nearly 700 delegates. Mrs. Clinton holds a substantial lead over Mr. Sanders both in pledged delegates and superdelegates, party leaders or elected officials who are free to support either candidate.Polls show a race that is too close to call in California, and both Democrats have been barnstorming the state, campaigning from early morning until late in the evening.Mrs. Clinton and her husband, former President Bill Clinton, have campaigned separately across the state, holding a couple dozen events between the two of them in the past several days. The former senator and secretary of state on Monday was in the Los Angeles area, where she held rallies and planned to host a star-studded evening concert.Mr. Sanders has planted a flag in California, focusing all of his attention and resources on the state during the past couple of weeks.In a news conference Monday in Emeryville, Mr. Sanders declined to say whether he would consider endorsing Mrs. Clinton before the convention if he doesn't win Tuesday's contest."You're asking me to speculate," Mr. Sanders said. "Let me talk to you after the primary in California. Let's assess where we are after tomorrow before we make statements based on speculation."On Monday, the senator said he would continue to make his case to superdelegates, urging them to switch their allegiance to his campaign. But his remarks were devoid of declarations he had made previously that he would continue his campaign through the convention. During the weekend, he predicted the July convention would be a contested one and vowed to keep fighting after Tuesday's primaries.Mrs. Clinton, for her part, said it was important for Democrats to unite during the coming weeks.Steve Elmendorf, a Democratic strategist who supports Mrs. Clinton, said Tuesday's results ultimately won't change the outcome of the primary campaign or have a significant impact on Mrs. Clinton's prospects in the general election."She is going to be the Democratic nominee for president whether she wins California or not," he said. "It's always better to win than to lose, but at the end of the day, the process will be over."Rebecca Ballhaus and Carol E. Lee contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Democrats Strive for Party Unity; Pressure builds for Bernie Sanders to rally behind presumptive nominee Hillary Clinton
article text: A Democratic Party that split over the fiercely contested presidential primary fight took its first steps toward uniting Wednesday, with prominent Bernie Sanders supporters conceding he had lost the race and saying they would rally behind the presumptive nominee, Hillary Clinton.A day after Mrs. Clinton won California and three other states, Jeff Merkley, an Oregon Democrat who was the lone U.S. senator to endorse Mr. Sanders, said she has earned the party's nomination."Once we have a candidate who has won the majority of the pledged delegates and the majority of the votes, we have a nominee," Mr. Merkley said. "I had hoped the outcome would be that Bernie Sanders would win. In a democracy, one wins and others don't."Aides to Mr. Sanders said he would stay in the race at least through June 14, when Washington, D.C., holds the final Democratic primary. Mr. Sanders was scheduled to hold a campaign event in Washington on Thursday and was also to meet privately with President Barack Obama.Before the voting on Tuesday, Mr. Sanders had said that he would carry the fight all the way to the convention next month in Philadelphia and would try to pry the nomination from Mrs. Clinton by urging her superdelegates to back his candidacy.A liberal group that had endorsed Mr. Sanders, Democracy for America, said Wednesday that if Mr. Sanders follows through on such plans, it wouldn't go along. With Mrs. Clinton leading by 376 pledged delegates--the kind elected by voters--it would be wrong for superdelegates to step in and effectively overturn the popular vote, the group said."We believe [Mr. Sanders] has the right to do that, but we do not plan to help him do that," said Charles Chamberlain, executive director of the group, which recruits and promotes liberal candidates for elective office.Stepping off the sidelines, Mr. Obama is set to endorse Mrs. Clinton as early as Thursday. The pair will later make a joint campaign appearance in a battleground state targeting independent voters, people familiar with the matter said.Mr. Obama seems prepared to play peacemaker and ensure the party is unified in the general election showdown with Republican Donald Trump.In an interview Wednesday on "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon," Mr. Obama said: "It was a healthy thing for the Democratic Party to have a contested primary. I thought that Bernie Sanders brought enormous energy and new ideas." He said his hope is "that over the next couple of weeks we're able to pull things together."The president has spoken to Mr. Sanders at least twice in recent weeks, hoping to gauge what Mr. Sanders might want from the party. The two are scheduled to meet Thursday, and the president is expected to say it is time for Democrats to set aside differences and embark on the larger project of defeating Mr. Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.Even some of Mr. Sanders's advisers aren't entirely sure what he'll do next. He left California and was scheduled to spend the night at his home in Burlington, Vt., on Wednesday.It was unclear whether Mr. Sanders intended to carry out his plan to peel away Mrs. Clinton's superdelegates, or if the four defeats he suffered had caused him to rethink his options."What he said before June 7th may not be the case after June 7th," said Sanders pollster Ben Tulchin. "The reality is he's going back to Vermont. And he has to absorb it and take it in. ... He's got to figure out how he can continue this progressive movement in the most effective and impactful way."Behind the political drama is the disappointment surely felt by a candidate who was never expected to get this far. A self-described democratic socialist, Mr. Sanders wound up winning 22 states. Both the Clinton campaign and Mr. Sanders's allies have sought not to antagonize him by pressuring him to drop out.Mrs. Clinton knows firsthand how difficult it is to accept defeat. In her 2008 campaign against then-Sen. Obama, she stayed in the race until the final contests and then waited four days before giving a speech bowing out."He has to process everything that he's accomplished over the last year," Mr. Tulchin said.Although the two have a strained relationship, Mrs. Clinton called Mr. Sanders on Tuesday evening, part of a series of overtures the Clinton campaign has been making to Mr. Sanders as the race nears the end.In an interview, Mrs. Clinton said: "I called him to really express my appreciation and congratulate him on running a hard-fought and very determined campaign that I thought added a lot to the Democratic Party and to our debate in the country. And I looked forward to having a chance to work with him on these issues."Laura Meckler contributed to this article.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.com and Carol E. Lee at carol.lee@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Carol E. Lee

article name: Hillary Clinton Takes Decisive Lead Over Bernie Sanders in Delegate Count, Popular Vote; The ex-secretary of state is estimated to have outpaced her rival by more than 800 delegates, 3 million votes
article text: WASHINGTON--Hillary Clinton prevailed in the Democratic presidential primary campaign with commanding leads in both the popular vote and delegate count, capping off the race against Bernie Sanders Tuesday evening with a win in delegate-rich California .Competing in more than 50 contests since February, Mrs. Clinton has amassed a majority in the race for delegates. Taking into account the six contests on Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton has at least 2,755 delegates to 1,852 delegates for Mr. Sanders, according to an Associated Press count--enough to for her to declare victory near the end of the primary season. It takes 2,383 delegates to win the Democratic nomination.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Clinton Declares 'Milestone' Victory* Trump Calls Comments on Judge 'Misconstrued'* Judge Delays Sanctions Against Justice Department* Clinton's Time Arrives, but Are the Times Right for Her?* Trump Is Getting a Late Start on Fundraising* Clinton Hopes for Bounce After Winning Democratic RaceJust the District of Columbia has yet to vote, where only 20 delegates are at stake in the city's June 14 primary. Mr. Sanders has vowed to remain in the race until after the D.C. primary.Democrats divide up their delegates into pledged delegates, who are elected in caucuses and primaries, and unpledged "superdelegates," or Democratic Party insiders who are free to cast a vote for any candidate at the party's July convention.The exact number of pledged delegates from Tuesday's contests won't be known until after vote counting is finished in California.Mrs. Clinton dominated Mr. Sanders by three of the metrics needed to win a primary campaign: beating Mr. Sanders handily in the popular vote, amassing nearly 400 more pledged delegate than the Vermont Senator and using her deep ties to the Democratic Party establishment to lock up many superdelegates early in the process.A vote tally compiled by Real Clear Politics gave her a lead of more than 3 million in the popular vote, though some caucuses don't give vote tallies.In pledged delegates, three networks projected she would receive an outright majority.She also dominated in the superdelegate battle, with nearly 600 publicly supporting her. Mr. Sanders has drawn only 48 superdelegates and has made no inroads in convincing her backers to switch sides.The former secretary of state became the presumptive Democratic nominee this week ahead of the six Tuesday primaries after the Associated Press declared she had garnered enough support from the unpledged superdelegates to secure the nomination. The states voting Tuesday night were California, New Jersey, Montana, New Mexico, North Dakota and South Dakota.The Sanders campaign said it would continue to try to sway superdelegates ahead of the Democratic convention."Secretary Clinton does not have and will not have the requisite number of pledged delegates to secure the nomination. She will be dependent on superdelegates who don't vote until July 25 and who can change their minds between now and then," Sanders campaign communications director Michael Briggs said."Our job from now until the convention is to convince those superdelegates that Bernie is by far the strongest candidate against Donald Trump," he added.Mrs. Clinton has built a much more commanding lead over Mr. Sanders than in the last contested Democratic primary campaign in 2008, when President Barack Obama emerged as the winner.By the end of the final set of primaries in the 2008 race, Mr. Obama led Mrs. Clinton by about 125 pledged delegates. He had 389 superdelegates supporting him at the close of the primary season.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Byron Tau

article name: How Millennials Can Still Live Bernie's Dream; Check out this federal experiment in socialism. Free education, free single-payer health care. Forty days of paid leave. Sounds Nordic, but it's all-American!
article text: They backed him over Hillary Clinton in greater numbers than they backed Barack Obama over John McCain. But now, millions of millennials are left licking their wounds after the defeat of Bernie Sanders, the greatest progressive hero since the president he wanted to replace.Many of them recoil at the thought of supporting Mrs. Clinton, a liberal but one with insufficient anticapitalist bona fides. For now, the Bernie-backers' dream of grafting Scandinavian solutions onto American problems is dead.Or is it? Despite some recent budgetary setbacks, a long-running American experiment in socialism is still going strong, and yet somehow it remains one of the country's best-kept secrets.Related Articles* Bernie the Economic Warrior* The Young and the Economically Clueless* Bernie and the 'Lunatic of One Idea'The federal experiment involves 1.3 million Americans--less than 1% of the population, but 75% of the participants are themselves millennials, so Bernie's supporters should feel right at home. Unless they feel like they've arrived in socialist heaven. Consider:These lucky few, including their spouses and children, receive free single-payer health care. Pre-existing conditions? No problem. Prescriptions? Generally free.Bernie only proposed free college for all; that's already a reality for these young Americans. Local elementary schooling for their children is also tossed in at no cost. Vocational training? When do you want to start? And put your wallet away.What's more, the federal government provides these participants with generous living allowances. On top of their normal salaries, they collect a monthly allowance for rent or mortgage payments, an allowance for moving costs incurred when their job location changes, and an allowance for gas consumed when driving for work-related purposes. There's even a clothing allowance. Oh, none of these allowances is taxable. Did I mention that tax preparation services are also free?In case you thought it couldn't get any more Nordic for these chosen few, they get 30 days of paid vacation a year in addition to the usual 10 paid federal holidays. That's 40 days of paid leave every year--more than in the Switzerland, Germany, the Netherlands and Canada.These Americans are also eligible for a lifetime pension. If they enter the program after high school, they can start collecting their retirement--half the dollar amount of their final salary, every year for the rest of their life--at age 38! Not even Bernie thought of that. The amount they collect is calculated annually according to the Consumer Price Index and the effects of inflation, so the pension payments increase each year as the cost of living rises.Speaking of salaries: No gender pay gap here. A male who occupies the same position with the same experience cannot earn more than his female colleague. That's the rule, not subject to the whim of a paymaster.So come on over, disappointed young Bernie fans. Someone's already living your dream. There is one catch: Occasionally the program can get a bit dangerous, and you'll be beyond the reach of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.Welcome to the U.S. Armed Forces, my fellow millennials. Feel the burn?Mr. Stern is a lieutenant in the U.S. Army.Credit: By Jeremy Stern

article name: Elizabeth Warren Endorses Hillary Clinton; Massachusetts senator says Bernie Sanders played constructive role by energizing new voters
article text: WASHINGTON--Sen. Elizabeth Warren, a Massachusetts Democrat with a devoted following from the party's liberal wing, endorsed Hillary Clinton for president Thursday night.Ms. Warren had been one of the last high-profile Democratic leaders to choose between backing Mrs. Clinton and Sen. Bernie Sanders of Vermont as they slogged through the Democratic presidential primary contests. Coming at the end of the primary calendar, Ms. Warren's endorsement is expected to help the former Secretary of State win over Mr. Sanders's supporters."I am ready to get in this fight and work my heart out for Hillary Clinton to become the next president of the United States--and to make sure that Donald Trump never gets anyplace close to the White House," Ms. Warren said on the Rachel Maddow Show on MSNBC Thursday night . Earlier Thursday, President Barack Obama officially endorsed Mrs. Clinton .Although Ms. Warren's focus on curbing Wall Street and diminishing income inequality aligned most closely with Mr. Sanders's campaign, she hadn't endorsed him. Mrs. Clinton long held a commanding lead in delegates and clinched the necessary number to become the presumptive nominee this week.In recent weeks, Democrats worried that the long fight between Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton would harm the party's ability to coalesce if Mr. Sanders's liberal supporters felt alienated by the process. Ms. Warren said Mr. Sanders played a constructive role by highlighting issues that energized new voters."He ran a campaign from the heart, and he ran a campaign where he took these issues and he really thrust them into the spotlight," she said. "He brought millions of people into the process."Mr. Sanders on Thursday said he would compete in the final Democratic presidential primary in Washington, D.C., next week but also hinted he was ready to wind down his candidacy.Republicans said Ms. Warren's endorsement of Mrs. Clinton undermined her attacks on Wall Street and other liberal principles."By endorsing Hillary Clinton, Elizabeth Warren has shown herself to be a sellout," said Republican National Committee spokeswoman Lindsay Walters. "Hillary Clinton represents everything Elizabeth Warren supposedly stands against."Ms. Warren is considered a possible vice presidential pick. If she did run with Mrs. Clinton and won, Ms. Warren's Senate seat would be filled by someone appointed by her state's Republican governor.The senator said she hadn't talked to Mrs. Clinton about being her running mate, but Ms. Warren said she believed she would be capable of serving in the role.Write to Kristina Peterson at kristina.peterson@wsj.comCredit: By Kristina Peterson

article name: Bernie Sanders Vows to Compete in Last Primary, Then Fight Trump; Candidate says he will work with Hillary Clinton to defeat GOP nominee
article text: WASHINGTON--Sen. Bernie Sanders on Thursday vowed to compete in the final Democratic presidential primary next week in Washington, D.C., but also hinted that he was ready to wind down his candidacy as party officials rallied behind Hillary Clinton.Mr. Sanders spent the day in Washington, meeting privately with President Barack Obama, Vice President Joe Biden and Senate colleagues. Party leaders urged him to accept defeat and help unite Democrats for the general-election showdown with Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee.White House press secretary Josh Earnest said Mr. Obama congratulated and complimented Mr. Sanders on his campaign. Mr. Earnest called it "a friendly conversation that was focused on the future." An hour after the Oval Office visit, Mr. Obama endorsed Mrs. Clinton in a video released by her campaign.In another sign the party is coalescing around Mrs. Clinton, Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.), a hero of the liberal Democratic wing, endorsed the former secretary of state Thursday evening in an interview on MSNBC. Ms. Warren's endorsement might prove particularly valuable to Mrs. Clinton, given her credibility with the young, liberal voters who gravitated toward Mr. Sanders.Ms. Warren said Democrats need to be tougher in their dealings with opponents and "ought to be willing to throw a punch." She added: "There are a lot of things that people say about Hillary Clinton but nobody says that she doesn't know how to throw a punch."Before California and five other states voted Tuesday, Mr. Sanders said he would carry his fight to the party's national convention next month in Philadelphia, trying to flip superdelegates loyal to Mrs. Clinton. That calculation may have changed. After losses in California, New Jersey and two other states that day, Mr. Sanders seems to be rethinking that stance.After meeting with Mr. Obama, the Vermont senator went to Capitol Hill for an hourlong session with Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid of Nevada. Mr. Reid suggested to reporters afterward that Mr. Sanders accepts that the race is over. "I didn't hear a single word about him trying to change the fact that she is the nominee," Mr. Reid said.A House member who had endorsed Mr. Sanders, Peter Welch of Vermont, said Thursday he believes Mr. Sanders grasps that he has lost and won't try to change the minds of superdelegates. "It's clear that Hillary Clinton is going to be the nominee of the Democratic Party," Mr. Welch said in an interview. "We all know that. Sen. Sanders knows that."Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Obama Endorses Clinton for President* Clinton Hits Trump on Economics* Trump Will Consult Congress, Agencies On Iran Deal and Muslim Ban, Adviser Says* The Map: Trump Says He Can Win New States for GOP, but Clinton Has the Edge* Hillary Clinton v. Donald Trump: A Look at the NumbersSpeaking briefly to reporters outside the White House, Mr. Sanders didn't say he planned to drop out. But neither did he speak of Mrs. Clinton as a competitor, emphasizing that he planned to meet with her "in the near future to see how we can work together to defeat Donald Trump and to create a government which represents all of us and not just the 1%."Democratic officials are treating Mr. Sanders with care. They need his help in the general election and don't wish to antagonize him as he comes to terms with the outcome of the primary contest. Party leaders are taking pains to praise Mr. Sanders for waging a surprisingly competitive, yearlong campaign.In his video endorsing Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Obama commended Mr. Sanders for mobilizing young voters and "shining a spotlight on issues like income inequality."For his part, Mr. Reid praised the energy that Mr. Sanders brought to the campaign trail and empathized with the candidate."During the conversation, I said, 'Bernie, I don't understand the depth of your feelings, but I have some understanding,' " Mr. Reid said, describing the loss of a 1974 Senate race early in his career by only hundreds of votes. "I understand a little bit what you are going through."After seeing Mr. Reid, Mr. Sanders met privately with Sen. Charles Schumer (D., N.Y.), who is presumed to become the Senate Democratic leader when Mr. Reid retires at the end of the congressional session. "I told him I was proud of him and what he accomplished," Mr. Schumer said. Referring to Mr. Sanders and his wife, he added: "And you could see on his face and on Jane's face--they're proud, too."At a rally outside Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium in Washington, D.C., Thursday evening, Mr. Sanders gave his normal stump speech, focusing on issues of income inequality and criminal justice reform. In a notable departure from past speeches, he backed off any criticism of Mrs. Clinton. He didn't mention her name or discuss his future plans.Carol E. Lee and Julian Routh contributed to this article.Write to Carol E. Lee at carol.lee@wsj.com and Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Barack Obama Endorses Hillary Clinton for President; Mr. Obama calls on Democratic Party to unite around Mrs. Clinton after meeting with Bernie Sanders
article text: WASHINGTON--No sitting U.S. president in recent history has campaigned for his party's nominee as much as Barack Obama plans to for Hillary Clinton.Mr. Obama endorsed the presumptive Democratic nominee on Thursday in a video posted on social media. Her campaign also announced plans for a joint appearance with the president next Wednesday in Green Bay, Wis., kicking off a marathon push to retain Democratic control of the White House."I'm fired up," Mr. Obama said in the video, echoing a chant from his 2008 campaign.The announcements came just 90 minutes after Mrs. Clinton's primary opponent, Sen. Bernie Sanders, emerged from a White House meeting with Mr. Obama, where the Vermont lawmaker gave his strongest signal yet that he wouldn't try to block her nomination at the July convention in Philadelphia.The political co-dependency between Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton, onetime rivals, is a reflection of how much of the president's legacy hinges on his former secretary of state winning the November election and the reality that his standing among voters is higher than hers.Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump responded to the endorsement Thursday with a tweet. "Obama just endorsed Crooked Hillary. He wants four more years of Obama--but nobody else does!" it said.Mr. Obama's popularity hovers around 50% in recent polls, yet voters have a more favorable view of him than of Mrs. Clinton or Mr. Trump, who has struggled to unify Republicans behind his candidacy."It means something for him to say she is everything she says she will be, because he was a doubter," said Julian Zelizer, a professor of history and public affairs at Princeton University, noting that Mr. Obama and Mrs. Clinton were not natural allies.Mark Mellman, a Democratic polling expert, said that for Mr. Obama, the potential reward is greater than any risk. "The peril for any president is you get too involved and lose and have it tarnish your legacy," he said. But if Mr. Obama stayed idle and Mrs. Clinton lost, he would take a hit anyway, Mr. Mellman added, and the president's policy would be at risk, too.Mr. Trump said last week that Mr. Obama shouldn't get involved in the race, warning that "if he campaigns, that means I'm allowed to hit him."More* Clinton Turns Up Heat on Trump With 'Delete Your Account' Tweet* Sanders Vows to Compete in Primary* Clinton Hits Trump on EconomicsVice President Joe Biden and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren quickly threw their public support behind Mrs. Clinton after Mr. Obama's endorsement. Mr. Biden, in an off-the-cuff comment during a speech Thursday night, said "God willing" the next president will be Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Obama faces several challenges. He must try to energize his supporters to vote in a race where he isn't on the ballot. He will also have to persuade voters who view him favorably, but Mrs. Clinton negatively, to back her anyway, and he must unite the Democratic Party after a far-tougher-than-expected primary battle.Mr. Obama made headway Thursday in unifying the party, as Mr. Sanders emerged from their meeting thanking the president for his "impartiality" in the primary race and said he would soon meet with Mrs. Clinton to discuss how to defeat Mr. Trump in November.Yet Mr. Obama has been unable to convince voters to turn out for Democrats in elections when he wasn't on the ballot.During his tenure, Democrats have suffered setbacks up and down the ballot, losing dozens of seats and control of both chambers in Congress and 10 governorships.In 2014, while ranking lower in popularity polls than he does currently, Mr. Obama campaigned for nine Democratic candidates; five of them lost. In addition, many Democrats didn't want to be seen with him, and he was frustrated about being sidelined.David Axelrod, who was an adviser to both Obama campaigns, said the electorate is different--larger and more diverse--in presidential years, and that voters in 2008 and 2012 weren't just turning out for Mr. Obama. "There's no question that part of what brought people out was him, but a lot of what brought people out were shared values and concerns," Mr. Axelrod said.Not since 1988 has a party won three consecutive terms in the White House. But many of the factors that kept the president's predecessors off the campaign trail or largely invisible don't apply to Mr. Obama.President George W. Bush had approval ratings below 30% in 2008, and the Republican nominee, Arizona Sen. John McCain, kept as big a distance from him as possible. President Bill Clinton had overseen significant economic prosperity, but had been tarred by scandal before the 2000 campaign, and Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic nominee, decided he should run as his own man.President Ronald Reagan campaigned for his vice president, George H.W. Bush, in 1988, but the Republican nominee sought to emphasize that he wasn't running for Mr. Reagan's third term.Mrs. Clinton, however, has embraced Mr. Obama's legacy and has pledged to build on much of his policy agenda."I'm excited about having the president's support, because I have said throughout this campaign, I was honored to serve in the president's cabinet as his secretary of state," Mrs. Clinton told reporters this week. "I don't think he's gotten the credit he deserves for saving the economy from the great recession that it was experiencing when he became president."Mr. Obama is equally invested in the November election. Almost all of the policies he implemented in his second term were done through executive power--from the Iran nuclear deal to domestic and international climate-change initiatives--making much of his legacy dependent on the next president continuing his programs.The president will be deployed to energize the Democratic coalition that twice won him the White House, including young voters, African-Americans, Latinos and women. Vice President Biden and first lady Michelle Obama also are expected to stump for Mrs. Clinton.Mr. Obama will have the benefit of the tools of incumbency usually employed to boost a president's re-election campaign, such as holding official White House events that target key constituencies. A White House summit next week focusing on women, for instance, spotlights a core part of the Obama coalition.Mr. Obama plans to spend a lot of time campaigning online for Mrs. Clinton, aides said. He intends to take an optimistic tone and outline what he sees as the two paths for the country under the Republican and Democratic nominees, they said.In 1988, Mr. Reagan, Mr. Bush and their advisers coordinated closely, looking for opportunities to deploy the president, said Craig Fuller, who was Mr. Bush's chief of staff.In the fall, Mr. Reagan began crisscrossing the country making campaign appearances. He also helped deliver critical votes in Southern California that captured the Golden State for Mr. Bush, said Ken Duberstein, who was the president's chief of staff.Mr. Duberstein cast doubt on whether Mr. Obama could help Democrats accomplish that same feat. "Under Reagan, it became 'Morning in America again' ... America was feeling good about itself," he said.In 2000, Mr. Gore called upon Mr. Clinton sparingly--a decision that was both complicated and controversial. Mr. Clinton wanted to spend more time on the campaign trail, but the president's affair with intern Monica Lewinsky was still fresh in voters' minds, and Mr. Gore was eager to establish his own separate political identity, former aides said.Bob Shrum, a longtime Democratic strategist who served as an adviser to Mr. Gore, said he poll-tested the prospect of sending Mr. Clinton to battleground states and found strong evidence that the president would be more hindrance than help.Mr. Clinton's "argument was, if only we had sent him out there, everything would be fine," Mr. Shrum recalled. "The numbers were quite clear."Eight years later, a two-term president was again benched by his party's own nominee when Mr. McCain kept his distance from Mr. Bush.Mr. Bush wrote in his memoir, "Decision Points," that he understood Mr. McCain's decision, but was disappointed that he couldn't do more to help. "I thought it looked defensive for John to distance himself from me," Mr. Bush wrote. "I was confident I could have helped him make his case. But the decision was his."Write to Carol E. Lee at carol.lee@wsj.comCredit: By Carol E. Lee and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: How Millennials Can Still Live Bernie's Dream; Check out this federal experiment in socialism. Free education, free single-payer health care. Forty days of paid leave. Sounds Nordic, but it's all-American!
article text: They backed him over Hillary Clinton in greater numbers than they backed Barack Obama over John McCain. But now, millions of millennials are left licking their wounds after the defeat of Bernie Sanders, the greatest progressive hero since the president he wanted to replace.Many of them recoil at the thought of supporting Mrs. Clinton, a liberal but one with insufficient anticapitalist bona fides. For now, the Bernie-backers' dream of grafting Scandinavian solutions onto American problems is dead.Or is it? Despite some recent budgetary setbacks, a long-running American experiment in socialism is still going strong, and yet somehow it remains one of the country's best-kept secrets.The federal experiment involves 1.3 million Americans--less than 1% of the population, but 75% of the participants are themselves millennials, so Bernie's supporters should feel right at home. Unless they feel like they've arrived in socialist heaven. Consider:These lucky few, including their spouses and children, receive free single-payer health care. Pre-existing conditions? No problem. Prescriptions? Generally free.Bernie only proposed free college for all; that's already a reality for these young Americans. Local elementary schooling for their children is also tossed in at no cost. Vocational training? When do you want to start? And put your wallet away.What's more, the federal government provides these participants with generous living allowances. On top of their normal salaries, they collect a monthly allowance for rent or mortgage payments, an allowance for moving costs incurred when their job location changes, and an allowance for gas consumed when driving for work-related purposes. There's even a clothing allowance. Oh, none of these allowances is taxable. Did I mention that tax preparation services are also free?In case you thought it couldn't get any more Nordic for these chosen few, they get 30 days of paid vacation a year in addition to the usual 10 paid federal holidays. That's 40 days of paid leave every year--more than in the Switzerland, Germany, the Netherlands and Canada.These Americans are also eligible for a lifetime pension. If they enter the program after high school, they can start collecting their retirement--half the dollar amount of their final salary, every year for the rest of their life--at age 38! Not even Bernie thought of that. The amount they collect is calculated annually according to the Consumer Price Index and the effects of inflation, so the pension payments increase each year as the cost of living rises.Speaking of salaries: No gender pay gap here. A male who occupies the same position with the same experience cannot earn more than his female colleague. That's the rule, not subject to the whim of a paymaster.So come on over, disappointed young Bernie fans. Someone's already living your dream. There is one catch: Occasionally the program can get a bit dangerous, and you'll be beyond the reach of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.Welcome to the U.S. Armed Forces, my fellow millennials. Feel the burn?Mr. Stern is a lieutenant in the U.S. Army.Credit: By Jeremy Stern
