article name: Bernie Sanders Not Being Vetted as Hillary Clinton's Running Mate; Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren is among a group of Democratic officials being considered
article text: Hillary Clinton's campaign isn't considering primary rival Bernie Sanders as her running mate, but is actively looking at Sen. Elizabeth Warren, whose populist politics line up closely with Mr. Sanders, people familiar with the process said.The vetting remains in its early stages. So far, potential candidates have been scrutinized using publicly available information. The Clinton team hasn't asked anyone to submit tax returns or other personal information, one of the people said. Conversations with Mrs. Clinton herself about options are just now beginning.Beyond the Massachusetts senator, other prospective candidates include Labor Secretary Tom Perez; Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julián Castro; Sens. Tim Kaine of Virginia, Sherrod Brown of Ohio and Cory Booker of New Jersey; Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti, and Reps. Xavier Becerra of California and Tim Ryan of Ohio, several Democrats said.Read More on Capital JournalCapital Journal is WSJ.com's home for politics, policy and national security news.* Trump Stands on Guns, Gays Unnerve Would-Be Allies* Polls Suggest Voters Soured on Trump After Attacks on Judge* Senators Negotiate Over Possible Gun Curbs* Clinton Shows Another Side in General-Election PivotAsked Tuesday if she would consider Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Clinton told Telemundo, "I haven't even begun to sort all that out." She added, "There are a lot of really qualified, dynamic candidates, I'm sure, to be considered for vice president."The search process is being led by John Podesta, the campaign chairman. Longtime Clinton adviser Cheryl Mills also is an informal adviser.Many Sanders supporters, disappointed by his failure to win the nomination, have held out hope that Mrs. Clinton would pick the Vermont senator in a show of unity and a signal that she will chart a progressive course if elected.At a board meeting of Friends of the Earth Action last week that included senior Sanders advisers, several board members said Mr. Sanders should receive serious consideration as Mrs. Clinton's running mate, said Erich Pica, president of the environmental group. Their argument, he said, was that he has brought ideas and energy to the debate.Larry Cohen, a Sanders adviser who was there, replied that Mr. Sanders would be a "powerful voice" and a major national figure from his Senate perch, Mr. Cohen confirmed.Mr. Sanders isn't particularly interested in the job, nor is he expecting to be offered it, though he doesn't mind being part of the conversation, a senior Sanders adviser said. He sees himself as exercising his strongest influence in the Senate, where his profile is sure to be elevated following his presidential run, the adviser said.The two camps are now in talks about how to unify the Democratic Party, with the Sanders forces pushing for changes in party rules and installing liberal policies in its platform at the July convention in Philadelphia.Mr. Sanders plans a video address to supporters Thursday night, but isn't expected to formally endorse Mrs. Clinton there, an aide said.Mrs. Clinton's top priority is finding someone who is prepared to step in as president, she has said. She also is looking for a working partner who can help advance her agenda, and her advisers are less concerned with demographic and geographic factors, people familiar with the process said.Some Sanders backers are encouraging her to pick someone from the more liberal wing of the party. "I would certainly encourage consideration of Bernie and other folks who represent the progressive side," said Sen. Jeff Merkley (D., Ore.), the only senator to back Mr. Sanders during the primary fight. Mr. Merkley also mentioned Ms. Warren and Mr. Brown.Mrs. Clinton doesn't feel pressured to go that route, since she already embraced such progressive positions as a large increase in the minimum wage and a plan to guarantee debt-free tuition at public universities, a senior strategist said.Clinton officials said they've been impressed by Ms. Warren's sharp critique of Republican Donald Trump, and they've made a point to highlight her endorsement along with those of President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden.Mr. Brown also appears to be under consideration, although if he were elected, Ohio's Republican governor would appoint his successor, which could impact control of the Senate. One person familiar with the process said this is a factor in considering him, but said every candidate brings some sort of wrinkle.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Closes Polling Gap With Clinton --- Tight race weighs on the Democratic front- runner as she tries to pivot to November
article text: Sen. Bernie Sanders has all but eliminated Hillary Clinton's polling lead among Democratic voters nationwide, a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll has found, offering signs that she continues to struggle with the primary electorate at a time when she wanted to build strength for the general election.Mr. Sanders for the first time is close to tying Mrs. Clinton, as 48% of Democratic primary voters picked him as their first choice for president, while 50% picked her. In a poll last month, Mrs. Clinton was ahead by 9 percentage points, a 53%-to-44% edge.A majority of states have already held their primary contests, and the Vermont senator's surge in support likely comes too late for him to overcome Mrs. Clinton's big lead in delegates to the summer nominating convention in Philadelphia. But the survey suggests that the long and bitter primary campaign has taken a toll on the former senator and secretary of state."As she is finishing this primary, she is not gaining strength," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster who conducted the survey with Democrat Fred Yang. "The cracks are showing, and she is losing strength."Mrs. Clinton's saving grace is the weakness of her potential Republican opposition. The survey found that GOP front-runner Donald Trump would have a harder time consolidating his party behind him than she would hers. Some 38% of Republican primary voters said they couldn't see themselves supporting the New York businessman, while 21% of Democrats said they couldn't support Mrs. Clinton.In a hypothetical general election matchup, Mrs. Clinton outpolls Mr. Trump 50% to 39%, the survey found.But for most voters, that would be a lesser-of-two-evils choice: 56% of both Trump and Clinton voters said their vote would be cast because they didn't want the other candidate to win."For these voters, casting their ballot for president in 2016 is not about an idealistic vision of hope and change or a new day in America," Mr. Yang said, "but, rather, a much more sober and pragmatic feeling as they check the box: It could be worse."Among Republicans, Mr. Trump has maintained his advantage as the field of candidates dwindled. He is the first choice of 40% of GOP primary voters, compared with 35% for Texas Sen. Ted Cruz and 24% for Ohio Gov. John Kasich.But the poll could fuel his rivals' argument that Mr. Trump would be the party's weakest candidate against Mrs. Clinton in November: Mr. Cruz trails her by two points, 46% to 44%, in a hypothetical matchup, while Mr. Kasich outpolls her, 51% to 39%.The two parties' front-runners are making history with the negative feelings they inspire. The share of voters who feel negatively toward Mr. Trump, at 65%, or Mrs. Clinton, at 56%, is unprecedented for a major-party nominee. By comparison, President Barack Obama was viewed in a negative light by 43%, and Republican nominee Mitt Romney by 44%, at the end of the 2012 general-election campaign."America is on the path to electing the most unpopular president since 1948," said Peter Hart, a Democratic pollster who also helped conduct the survey.Measuring the front-runners' qualities of character, the poll found that both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Trump are worse for the wear over the past six months.Voters still rate Mrs. Clinton highly for the knowledge and experience she would bring to the office. But over the past six months, she has lost ground on two crucial qualities: Voters, including those in her own party, are less likely to see her as an agent of change and as honest and straightforward.Just 22% of registered voters give her high marks for being able to bring real change to the country. Even among Democratic primary voters, the share giving her high marks dropped to 41%, down from 57% in October.On being honest and straightforward, just 19% rate her highly. Among Democratic primary voters, those rating her highly dropped to 40%, from 52% in October.Mr. Trump has also lost ground on key points. Voters are less likely to give him high marks on his signature claim: that he can get things done. Some 38% rate him highly on that quality, down from 48% in October. Among Republican voters, 64% rate him highly for effectiveness, down from 72%.While "telling it like it is" is Mr. Trump's calling card, fewer voters now see him as honest and straightforward. The share who rated Mr. Trump highly on being honest and straightforward was 35%, down from 43% in October.Asked which party is better equipped to handle foreign policy, voters picked the Democrats by a three-point margin. By a narrow margin, voters also saw the Democratic Party as better able to handle immigration.That could fuel some Republicans' concern that the party's standing would suffer from Mr. Trump's harsh rhetoric about illegal immigration and his support for a reduced role for the U.S. military in world affairs.But Mr. McInturff, the Republican pollster, said he didn't see signs that Mr. Trump was doing any "damage to the Republican Party that is irreparable."Mr. Sanders's strong support among primary voters continued a steady narrowing of the gap since January, when Mrs. Clinton led by 25 points, 59% to 34%. In June 2015, a Journal/NBC News poll found Mrs. Clinton leading the Democratic contest by 60 percentage points, 75% to 15%.Credit: By Janet Hook

article name: Election 2016 --- CAPITAL JOURNAL: The Damage Sanders's Clinton Bashing May Do
article text: As the big New York primary election arrives, it would be a mistake to say the fight for the Democratic presidential nomination is dragging on with no end in sight. Despite tightening poll numbers, it's dragging on with a likely end still in sight: Hillary Clinton prevailing, both in New York and nationwide, because the delegate math works inexorably in her favor.So the question increasingly is this: How much damage is she absorbing at the hands of Sen. Bernie Sanders in the meantime?The answer: The damage is hardly fatal but it is starting to matter, especially in Mrs. Clinton's standing with crucial independent voters. The specific problem isn't merely that Mr. Sanders's tone has turned more harsh in attacking her. The particular problem is that his critique increasingly focuses on declaring she can't be trusted because she takes campaign contributions from big banks and big business. That is a line of attack that seems almost designed to hit Mrs. Clinton in her area of greatest vulnerability, which is voter doubts about her honesty and trustworthiness. The pattern continued Monday when the Sanders campaign accused the Clinton camp of possibly violating campaign-finance laws, prompting Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook to declare that "the Sanders campaign's false attacks have gotten out of hand."Of course, this is the stage of a tough election race when it's common for partisans in either party -- or this year, in both parties -- to lament that a bruising primary season is hurting their chances for victory in the general election. And frequently those concerns turn out to be overblown. Certainly, Democrats lamented the length and tone of the long Barack Obama-Hillary Clinton fight in 2008, and that fight turned out to be, if anything, helpful in tuning up Mr. Obama for a big November win."I think Sanders is hurting Clinton with Republicans -- but they wouldn't have voted for her anyway," says Democratic pollster Mark Mellman. "With Democrats and independents the effect is minimal. So real impact is marginal at best."Still, there is impact, as suggested by a new Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll that showed the share of voters who hold a negative view of Mrs. Clinton continues to grow. Perhaps of most concern to Democrats are the signs of souring views among independent voters. In January, the share of independent voters who had positive views of Mrs. Clinton stood at 35%, while 54% had negative views. In the new survey, just 20% of independents had positive views, while 62% had negative views.There even is evidence of damage among soft Democrats -- that is, people who lean Democratic but aren't core partisans. Among that group, the share holding negative views of Mrs. Clinton grew to 32% this month from 21% in January.Celinda Lake, a longtime Democratic pollster, thinks the "aggressive" Sanders tone is likely to backfire with Democratic women, who make up 59% of the party's primary voters. But she also worries it is eroding one of the party's key advantages this year."Originally, I think Sanders played an important role mobilizing voters and articulating an important economic and change message," she says. "I think voters found refreshing the contrast with the Republicans of two candidates engaged in serious conversation about our country's future and offering a real platform. Now, with ridiculous, overstated attacks like Hillary isn't qualified, it makes us look as bad as the Republicans and turns off voters."The tone problem was on full display at a big Sanders rally in New York City last week, where one speaker, health-care activist Dr. Paul Song, said liberals' goal of achieving Medicare for all won't happen "if we continue to elect corporate Democratic whores who are beholden to big pharma and the private insurance industry."He later apologized and said he was referring to Democrats in Congress, not to Mrs. Clinton, and Mr. Sanders said the remarks were "inappropriate." Still, the tone is the sort of thing that could give moderate Republicans who might otherwise never vote for businessman Donald Trump a reason to think about doing exactly that.It's also rhetoric consistent with Mr. Sanders's broader critique -- she's a captive of special interests who will abandon average folks, on their behalf -- which threatens to exacerbate her biggest problem: In the new Journal/NBC News poll, just 19% gave her good marks for being "honest and straightforward."Mrs. Clinton appears to have the upper hand in a general-election matchup against either Mr. Trump or Texas Sen. Ted Cruz. But in either case, she'll need Sanders voters to show up. And it appears that in a matchup against Mr. Trump, a fair share of her vote would come from people embracing her as the lesser of two evils.The problem with the Sanders attacks is he is close to portraying her as representing a kind of evil in the system, which threatens to erode that particular advantage.Credit: By Gerald F. Seib

article name: Sanders Supporters Seek Ways to Keep 'Bernie' Movement Alive; Election presents choice they had hoped to avoid: Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump
article text: CHICAGO--Liberal activists behind Bernie Sanders's campaign held a weekend conference to commiserate over his loss to Hillary Clinton and plot ways to keep the "Bernie" movement alive now that the candidate is exiting the presidential stage.In their view, the general election presents a painful choice: Mrs. Clinton or presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump.Dominique Scott, a University of Mississippi student, got a standing ovation at a panel discussion Saturday when she described her predicament as a first-time voter in a presidential race. "I'm so discouraged about the moment we're in right now," Ms. Scott said. "I am distraught that the two choices that I get are two people who do not represent me and do not represent the things that I need."While some Sanders supporters are rallying around the presumptive Democratic nominee--including the AFL-CIO, the nation's largest labor coalition--resistance from his most ardent backers threatens to split the party ahead of the showdown with Mr. Trump.Mr. Sanders wasn't at the conference dubbed "The People's Summit." But the Vermont senator was everywhere all the same. Millennials walked through the halls wearing T-shirts bearing sketches of his receding hairline. In panels, participants dissected the campaign's rise and fall and talked wistfully about how close Mr. Sanders came to vanquishing Mrs. Clinton. Piped in over loudspeakers was a song capturing the mood: the Beatles' "Revolution."The conference's lead organizer was National Nurses United, an ally that dispatched a customized bus to various primary states rallying the Sanders faithful. Among the 3,000 attendees were assorted socialists, union officials, community organizers and college students. Together, they represent the wing of the Sanders coalition that is the least enthused about coalescing behind the Clinton campaign."It's a terrible place we find ourselves in," said Becky Bond, a former adviser to Mr. Sanders's campaign, in a session titled "Understanding our Movement Moment." The best a Clinton presidency would produce is a nation "slightly worse than it is under Obama," Ms. Bond said.What worries some at the conference is the fate of Mr. Sanders's email list. They want him to keep it away from the Clinton campaign. Seeing the list as a coveted asset, his supporters want Mr. Sanders to use it to promote like-minded candidates. Clinton aides have other ideas; they want him to use the list to tout her candidacy. Rosario Dawson, an actress who campaigned for Mr. Sanders and attended the conference, said in an interview she has no use for any pro-Clinton messages crossing her cellphone: "If she wants our vote, then she needs to go get it," she said. "We didn't register to vote and phone bank and canvass for her for a reason."A theme of the conference is that the movement that propelled Mr. Sanders doesn't need him to endure. The victories he notched in 23 contests demonstrate a public appetite for the liberal solutions he put forward, participants said.A new goal, they said, is finding a fresh crop of candidates who will push for the policy changes Mr. Sanders championed, including a government-run health-care system and free tuition at public colleges.Mr. Sanders shares that aim. In his online address on Thursday, he urged his supporters to run for elective office and reverse a tide of Republican victories at the state and local level. His campaign said that within 24 hours of the speech, nearly 7,000 people signed up on his website to get more information.The conference attendees see the Democratic Party as an obstacle to the sort of candidate recruitment they believe is necessary. Many would like to have a new party emerge, believing the current leadership incapable of closing the gap between rich and poor.Mr. Sanders, too, wants changes in the way the party does business and has called for the ouster of the chairwoman, U.S. Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida.Nina Turner, a Sanders supporter and former Ohio state senator, said that even though she has been a lifelong Democrat, "a third party might not be bad for this country.""Let's shake it up," Ms. Turner said. "I want to see the Democratic Party live up to our values."As for the question on everyone's mind--what to do in the general election--one speaker offered a piece of advice. Work for a Clinton victory if you must, but never stop pushing for sweeping policy changes, said Tobita Chow, chairman of a Chicago-based political group called "The People's Lobby.""If you're going to spend the next five months volunteering for the Clinton campaign and phone-banking for her, you're not building anything. You're not building this movement. That's five months of wasted time," Mr. Chow said.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Bernie Sanders Makes a Last Push: to Change Party Rules; Democratic candidate's plan could help an insurgent in the 2020 presidential campaign
article text: Sen. Bernie Sanders is winding down his presidential run by pushing for changes to Democratic Party rules that could assist an insurgent campaign like his own in the next presidential election.The Vermont lawmaker is eager to influence the party's platform, which will be approved at the Democratic National Convention next month in Philadelphia. He is pushing for free tuition at public colleges, a $15 federal minimum wage, a carbon tax and other positions where he and presumptive nominee Hillary Clinton disagree.But the Sanders campaign also wants the party to adopt a range of changes to how it governs itself. While party platforms are typically forgotten soon after they are approved, the party rules will affect how the next presidential contest is run."We need major, major changes in the Democratic Party in converting it to a party of the people," Mr. Sanders said this week. "We need an electoral process which is worthy of the Democrats."Specifically, he wants to get rid of superdelegates, the party leaders and elected officials who get to vote for whomever they like for the party's nomination. He wants all presidential primaries to be open to independent voters, and not just to registered Democrats, and for the party to encourage candidates to reject support in primaries from super PACs, the outside political groups that can raise and spend unlimited sums of money.Those issues are fodder for talks under way with the Clinton campaign. For now, Mr. Sanders remains an "active candidate" for the nomination, said his campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, Friday on MSNBC.Clinton aides suggest the two campaigns will overcome their differences. For instance, while Mr. Sanders backs a $15 federal minimum wage and Mrs. Clinton backs a $12 level, they both want to see an increase from the current $7.25. There may be language both candidates can agree to.The rules changes are more complicated. Rules governing primaries, for instance, are set by states. The national party could encourage changes by awarding extra delegates to states that make the requested changes. All of this will likely be turned over to a post-convention commission.Other changes are complicated by the egos and preferences of hundreds of party leaders. That is particularly true of superdelegates, a role created to make sure party leaders had some control over the presidential nomination.The superdelegates have never taken the nomination away from someone who won in the primaries and caucuses, but the Sanders forces believe they exercise an undue influence nonetheless. Before any votes were cast, Mrs. Clinton had a large delegate lead thanks to her support among superdelegates, and Mr. Sanders and his supporters say this gave her an air of inevitability.In the end, Mrs. Clinton beat him by nearly 400 pledged delegates, the type chosen by the voters. Among the 713 superdelegates, she has 581, with 49 for Mr. Sanders, according to an Associated Press tally.Larry Cohen, a Sanders adviser who is a superdelegate himself, said one possibility is to give these elected officials and party leaders floor passes to the convention but not allow them to vote on the nomination. That would allow them to participate without having to run for one of their state's delegate spots.But others say the superdelegates play an important role in bringing professional political experience into the mix. "They allow influence and input from people involved with the party for a long time without letting them make the ultimate decision," said Brady Quirk-Garvan, chairman of the Charleston County, S.C., Democratic Party who will be a regular delegate to the convention, backing Mrs. Clinton.The issue will be hashed out in the Rules Committee, which will be co-chaired by former Rep. Barney Frank of Massachusetts, a vocal Clinton backer. Because of that allegiance, Mr. Sanders has called on him to step down.Mr. Frank has declined to step down, but said in a recent interview that he is open to changes in the superdelegate role as a way of making the process more democratic. "There should be some diminution of their role," he said. He added that he would also like to see the party discourage caucuses, which are harder to participate in than primaries.Mr. Sanders typically did better in caucuses, and some of his advisers have defended them as important party-building exercises.Mr. Frank described superdelegates and caucuses as the two areas "where we fall short of the democratic ideal."Julian Routh contributed to this article.Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Bern Out; Sanders finally surrenders (informally) to the inevitable.
article text: (Best of the Tube this weekend: Catch us on "The Journal Editorial Report" discussing terrorism and the Orlando attack. Fox News Channel--note new time, 3:30 p.m. ET both Saturday and Sunday.) Bye-ku for Bernie SandersThe Bertha movement Million as and billion as It's all a gockyWe thought long and hard--well, OK, neither long nor hard, but we gave the matter some thought--about whether to roll out the Bernie Sanders haiku today. He hasn't formally suspended his campaign, and he said in a speech to supporters last night that "we must take that energy"--not fossil fuels, thank you very much--"into the Democratic National Convention on July 25 in Philadelphia where we will have more than 1,900 delegates."More than 1,900 implies fewer than 2,000, and to paraphrase an apocryphal quote from the first Democratic president, one man with courage makes a majority, but only if he has 2,382 delegates. Hillary Clinton does. Sanders insisted that his "political revolution" will "continue into the future," but his speech amounted to a concession that unless Mrs. Clinton gets arrested (a real possibility with a meager probability), he will not be the Democratic Party's 2016 nomination for president.Sanders made use of analepsis in reminiscing about the campaign's achievements ("Together . . ."), recapitulating its purpose ("It is about . . .") and exhorting the Democratic Party to remake itself in accordance with his ideological preferences ("We must . . .").Sanders has been elected to office 14 times, not once as a Democrat. So what does he mean by "we"? He answered that question in one of the two noteworthy passages of the speech, the introduction to the "We must . . ." section:I . . . look forward to working with Secretary Clinton to transform the Democratic Party so that it becomes a party of working people and young people, and not just wealthy campaign contributors: a party that has the courage to take on Wall Street, the pharmaceutical industry, the fossil fuel industry and the other powerful special interests that dominate our political and economic life.According to Matthew Yglesias , fashion editor of the young-adult site Vox, that "really enrages Democratic leaders":It's incredibly frustrating for people who've been working in mainstream Democratic Party politics to hear their party described as something other than a party for "working people." . . .It's one thing to disagree with people about policy substance or political tactics. But something Sanders has done throughout his campaign and very pointedly did here is straightforwardly challenge the good faith of the vast majority of his colleagues in Democratic Party politics. It's worked pretty well for him on the stump, but it doesn't win you a lot of friends. And to be honest, it's simply wrong.You're only supposed to challenge the good faith of people in the other party. And that Sanders did, in the other noteworthy passage of his speech:This campaign is about defeating Donald Trump, the Republican candidate for president. After centuries of racism, sexism and discrimination of all forms in our country we do not need a major party candidate who makes bigotry the cornerstone of his campaign. We cannot have a president who insults Mexicans and Latinos, Muslims, women and African-Americans. We cannot have a president who, in the midst of so much income and wealth inequality, wants to give hundreds of billions of dollars in tax breaks to the very rich. We cannot have a president who, despite all of the scientific evidence, believes that climate change is a hoax.The major political task that we face in the next five months is to make certain that Donald Trump is defeated and defeated badly.On that last point Sanders is slightly less radical than George Will , who in April hoped for a 50-state Democratic landslide should Trump become the nominee.In some ways, though, Sanders is an unlikely Nevertrump tribune. Sanders and Trump have more in common than one suspects Sanders would like to admit: Trump's history with the Republicans is about as longstanding and deep as Sanders's with the Democrats. Trump has led something of a political revolution as well--and more successfully than Sanders, in part perhaps because he is more talented politically, but also because the Republican establishment proved brittler than the Democratic one.Also like Sanders, Trump seeks to remake the GOP into a "party of working people." In a statement yesterday after the AFL-CIO endorsed the inevitable Democratic nominee, Trump declared: "Hillary Clinton is the enemy of working people and is the best friend Wall Street ever had." Sanders couldn't have said it better, or at least didn't.The obvious question arises: How effective will Sanders be at campaigning against Trump when that means urging his starry-eyed supporters to cast ballots for as unappealing a candidate as Mrs. Clinton?A Bloomberg poll released this week finds Mrs. Clinton picking up a majority of Sanders backers--but not a large majority: "She receives 55 percent from Sanders supporters, while Trump gets 22 percent and [Libertarian Gary] Johnson gets 18 percent." And this was not a Trump-friendly survey: Overall, Mrs. Clinton led him 49% to 37%, with 9% for Johnson."The Republican National Committee is promoting a report that accuses the Democratic Party of conspiring to nominate Hillary Clinton in the early days of the presidential primary," the Hill reports:In an email, the RNC sent to reporters a story published by the New York Post about a document that purportedly shows the Democratic National Committee was strategizing to make Hillary Clinton president--and not a generic Democratic candidate--in the spring of 2015. . . .The story is based on a document posted on the blog of a user named "Guccifer 2.0," and appears to be part of a trove of documents stolen from the DNC by Russian government hackers. . . .It's unclear whether the document that the hacker claims is from the DNC is a real one. . . .The RNC sent out the article in an email blast to reporters, highlighting a point in the report that the memo "appears to show the DNC working on behalf of Hillary Clinton from the start of the presidential campaign--just as Bernie Sanders has claimed."Ironically (assuming the report is genuine), the effort might have ended up helping Sanders. If the Clinton camp and the DNC bigfooted serious potential rivals into forgoing the race, they wouldn't have bothered with the crazy old socialist independent from Vermont. Since nobody else of note ended up running, he became the alternative by default.But then again, here's another counterfactual: What if several serious candidates had challenged Mrs. Clinton for the nomination, preventing her from ever gaining a clear lead? It's possible enough primary voters would have been drawn to Sanders, the nongeneric Democrat, to make him the leader. That's more or less how Trump engineered his political revolution.Metaphor Alert "America saw Barack Obama at low tide yesterday, revealed as brimming with fury and bankrupt of ideas and even sympathy for the dead."--Michael Goodwin, New York Post, June 15We Blame George W. "Little Reality in Trump TV: Experts Say the GOP Front-Runner's Reported Desire to Start a Network Is a Pipedream"--headline, Salon, June 17Make That 366* "5 Things I've Learned From Donald Trump in the Past 365 Days"--headline, Washington Post , June 16* "February 29 Is Leap Day! News , June 17Hypothesis and Disproof* "This Is an Election for the Highest Office, Not a Joke"--headline, Boston Globe , May 31* "Gary Johnson: 'I've Stopped Using Marijuana' During White House Bid"--headline, TheHill.com , June 17With DNC in Mind, City Bans Carrying Urine, Feces "Health Experts: Philly Soda Tax Could Start National Movement"--headline, Philadelphia Inquirer, June 16Not That There's Anything Wrong With That "Feinstein Gives Wine, Blames It on San Jose's Beard"--headline, RollCall.com, June 16Problem and Solution* "Artisanal Mayo Store Getting Priced Out of Prospect Heights, Owner Says"--headline, DNAInfo.com , June 16* "No-Mayo Potato Salad"--headline, Today.com , May 18If the Range Was Hot, He Was Completely Justified "Video: Irate Idiot Yells at Woman for Breastfeeding Baby in Target"--headline, Gothamist, June 16Kangaroo Food Court "Breakfast-Seeking Kangaroo Captured Inside Australian Cafe"--headline, United Press International, June 16Question and Answer* "Here's What Actually Happens at 'Cuddle Parties' "--headline, New York Post , June 16* "Donald Trump Hugs an American Flag While Supporters Chant 'Build The Wall' "--headline, Uproxx.com , June 11Look Out Below! "Southwest Airlines Drops Its Khaki Shorts"--headline, Times-Picayune (New Orleans), June 16It's Always in the Last Place You Look "Trump's Poll Ratings in a Historic Hole"--headline, Politico.com, June 17Breaking News From Matthew 14:25 "Christo's [sic] Newest Project: Walking on Water"--headline, New York Times, June 17Bottom Story of the Day "Democrats Finally Agree--on Worst Gun Bill Ever"--headline, MotherJones.com, June 17By Any Other Name "In an amusing error, The Chicago Tribune published a column criticizing Snoop Doog's [sic] racial politics and stance on the Roots remake while mistakenly attributing it to conservative columnist Jonah Goldberg," reports Mediaite's Alex Griswold:While it'd be an embarrassing mistake in any case, putting the words of columnist Leonard Pitts (who is black) in the mouth of Goldberg (who is not) led to some amusingly offensive statements. "Negro, are you out of your mind?" asks "Goldberg" at one point.Likewise, "Goldberg" went on to wonder at length about how Jews feel about Holocaust movies, even though the real Goldberg is Jewish. "A Jew doesn't walk out of that movie and rub shoulders with the heirs of Nazi Germany while you and I do live side by side with the heirs of antebellum (and Jim Crow) America. In that sense, at least, ours is the heavier emotional burden," says "Goldberg" to Snoop Dogg.Are we alone in thinking this is actually a good idea? The Pitts column sounds wholly uninteresting, yet Goldberg's byline transformed it into a delight. Imagine if, say, the New York Times put Paul Krugman's byline on a David Brooks column, or if the Washington Post attributed a David Ignatius column to Charles Krauthammer.Though on the other hand, we're not volunteering either our column or our byline.Follow @jamestaranto on Twitter.Join Fans of Best of the Web Today on Facebook.Subscribe to the Best of the Web email with one click.(Carol Muller helps compile Best of the Web.
