He said the Clinton campaign needs to do more to reassure the party's liberal base that both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Kaine would stand united in opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation free trade deal.But he also predicted that at the end of the week, Democrats would rally behind the need to defeat Mr. Trump."These two incidents are certainly going to leave a harsh taste in the mouth," Mr. Sroka said. "But there is a deep commitment that goes beyond any one person to making sure that Donald Trump doesn't represent our country on the national or world stage."As for Mr. Sanders, he told NBC that he would have preferred to see Mrs. Clinton choose a more progressive running mate, suggesting Ms. Warren would have been a good choice.But he offered muted praise for Mr. Kaine."Tim is a very, very smart guy. He's a very nice guy," Mr. Sanders said. "His political views are not my political views. He is more conservative than I am."On the eve of the convention, Clinton allies took steps aimed at accommodating Mr. Sanders and his rank-and-file supporters. They accepted a platform that moves the party to the left on a series of issues.Supporters of Mr. Sanders also cheered the convention Rules Committee's approval over the weekend of a new commission that is charged with presenting a plan to reduce the clout of superdelegates, the party leaders and officials who have an outsize role in choosing the presidential nominee. Superdelegates overwhelmingly backed Mrs. Clinton.On Monday, delegates are set to a approve a platform that enshrines many of the proposals Mr. Sanders championed during the race: A $15 federal minimum wage indexed to inflation; stricter regulation of Wall Street banks; an end to the death penalty and renewed efforts to combat global warming."The platform is a huge success," Mr. Weaver said.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Emails That Helped Cost DNC Chief Debbie Wasserman Schultz Her Job Show Democratic Discord; Messages released by WikiLeaks indicate signs of bias in favor of Hillary Clinton over Bernie Sanders
article text: The hacked emails that helped cost Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz her job depict a primary campaign marked by party infighting and smears.Among the more than 19,000 messages released by the WikiLeaks website are signs of bias in favor of Hillary Clinton over Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders's campaign, undermining the DNC's stated objective of broad-based support for Democrats seeking office."He isn't going to be president," Ms. Wasserman Schultz wrote in an email about Mr. Sanders in late May, according to WikiLeaks, weeks before Mr. Sanders endorsed Mrs. Clinton.Another email sent from a DNC address to two DNC communications officials indicated a plan to smear Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump with a fake Craigslist job post for women who wanted to apply to one of Mr. Trump's organizations, with the title "Honey Bunch" and job requirements including "no gaining weight on the job."The emails showed Ms. Wasserman Schultz bristled at accusations of bias over her handling of the Democratic presidential primary. When MSNBC's Mika Brzezinski in mid-May called for the DNC chairwoman to step down for unfair treatment of Mr. Sanders, Ms. Wasserman Schultz in an email called the television host's allegation the "LAST straw.""This is outrageous. She needs to apologize," the DNC chairwoman emailed Communications Director Luis Miranda .In one exchange about polling in Rhode Island, a DNC staffer said of Mrs. Clinton: "If she outperforms this polling, the Bernie camp will go nuts and allege misconduct. They'll probably complain regardless, actually."Ms. Clinton's campaign manager blamed Russian state actors for hacking and leaking emails allegedly sent from senior DNC staffers to boost Mr. Trump's campaign. The Kremlin and Russian Foreign Ministry didn't respond to requests for comment, though Russian officials have previously denied involvement. Kristinn Hrafnsson, a WikiLeaks spokesman, didn't respond to a request for comment.Harriet TorryCredit: By Harriet Torry

article name: U.S. News: College Sanders's Wife Led to Close
article text: Burlington College, a tiny Vermont liberal arts school once led by Jane Sanders, the wife of presidential candidate Bernie Sanders, said it is shutting down because of financial problems associated with a property acquisition she oversaw.In a formal statement announcing its closure, the school cited the "crushing weight" of debt it took on in a 2010 purchase of more than 30 acres from the local Catholic archdiocese. Mrs. Sanders was the college's president at the time of the $10 million deal.The college had financial challenges before Mrs. Sanders took the helm. In her seven years there, she attempted an ambitious expansion of the school's physical footprint and 200-student body. But the major investment didn't bear fruit in terms of drawing more students and bringing in higher tuition revenue, and the school's financial health has remained fragile since. She resigned in 2011.Mrs. Sanders was set to receive total severance of $200,785 between October 2011 and October 2013, according to tax documents the school filed for its fiscal 2012 year.An attempt to reach Mrs. Sanders through the Sanders campaign wasn't answered.Mrs. Sanders received her undergraduate degree in social work from Goddard College in Plainfield, Vt., and briefly served as interim president there in the 1990s. She has worked as a political consultant and is considered to be one of Mr. Sanders's closest advisers.Many smaller colleges are facing bleak fiscal futures, with many forced to offer significant scholarships to woo students but barely breaking even on what tuition revenue they bring in, as expenses continue to rise. The National Association of College and University Business Officers reported Monday that the discount rate for freshmen at private colleges this year hit a record 48.6%, meaning students pay just over 50 cents on every dollar of published tuition.Burlington said Monday that it has cut its debt to a "manageable level" through property sales, but learned last month that its lender wouldn't renew a credit line, which is needed to cover costs between semesters.Burlington's accreditor, the New England Association of Schools and Colleges, placed it on probation in 2014 because of financial concerns. It is allowed to remain on probation for only two years."These hurdles are insurmountable at this time," the school said.Burlington's board of trustees voted Friday to close its programs effective May27. The school held its commencement ceremony for the class of 2016 on Saturday.Current students will be able to complete their studies at nearby colleges, Burlington said."I thought it was going to happen for some time," said Barry Snyder, an adjunct professor at Burlington and former chair of the film and media department.Mr. Snyder, who also runs the Burlington Film Society, said he had heard closure was likely about a month ago. "It's terrible to lose an institution of this sort. It was a very special place," he said. "It did a lot of good for students who didn't fit at other institutions."---Laura Meckler contributed to this article.Credit: By Melissa Korn

article name: Gov. Andrew Cuomo Faces His Critics at Democratic Convention; Left wing of party knocks governor, even as he praises Sen. Bernie Sanders
article text: PHILADELPHIA--Away from his home turf , New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo spent his first day at the Democratic National Convention contending with pockets of the party where he is less than popular.Mr. Cuomo, who four years ago at the convention in Charlotte, N.C., shunned all but a minor address to New York delegates and declined to stay overnight, traveled to Philadelphia to participate more fully this time and has a speaking role later in the week.But on Tuesday he felt the effects of an emboldened Democratic left wing that has been determined to make its voice heard during the convention. Appearing at a breakfast for the New York delegation alongside Bernie Sanders, Mr. Cuomo praised the Vermont senator's presidential campaign."I also want to applaud the senator for keeping his eye on the ball," Mr. Cuomo said, to cheers. "The goal for the Democratic Party is to make sure [Donald] Trump and that philosophy has no place in this country, ever."But even as Mr. Sanders congratulated Mr. Cuomo for raising the statewide minimum wage and instituting a paid family-leave program, Sanders backers said they have already begun organizing to oppose Mr. Cuomo's re-election bid in 2018.Asked if she was a supporter of the New York governor, Sanders delegate and Queens resident Nancy de Delva said: "I'm definitely not.""All of his ideas are more Republican," said Ms. de Delva.She said she wasn't appeased by the governor's efforts on progressive ideals such as raising the minimum wage. "These were not his ideas. Mayor de Blasio wanted all this from the beginning," she said.A spokesman for Mr. Cuomo pointed out that the governor had long supported increases to the minimum wage, including before Mr. de Blasio became mayor, and took unilateral actions to raise it for fast-food workers and others prior to this year.Poornima Subramanian, a University of Buffalo pharmacy student, said fellow Sanders delegates have already selected a 2018 candidate: "We'd like to see [New York Attorney General] Eric Schneiderman run against Andrew Cuomo."Mr. Schneiderman has said that he doesn't intend to do that.At Mr. Cuomo's other public address of the day, to the Democratic Party's lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender caucus, he faced a more receptive crowd. He drew hearty applause for signing legislation legalizing same-sex marriage in New York and for describing the June mass shooting in Orlando, Fla., as "a terrorist attack on gay Americans."Still, even among friendly faces, Mr. Cuomo encountered some detractors in the form of protesters who disrupted his speech to voice their opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership and to criticize him for an executive order to force state agencies to divest themselves of companies supporting a Palestinian-backed boycott movement against Israel.Mr. Cuomo recovered quickly from the disruption, and he was soon met with another vocal crowd member with a more supportive message concerning the state's embrace of same-sex marriage rights.Shouted one woman in the audience: "We did it by having the best governor ever in New York!"Write to Erica Orden at erica.orden@wsj.comWe Want to Hear From YouHave something to say about an article in Greater New York? Email us, along with your contact information, at gnyltrs@wsj.com . Letters will be edited for brevity and clarity. Please include your city and state.Credit: By Erica Orden

article name: Feel the Fizzle; Sanders's revolution ends with a whimper.
article text: PHILADELPHIA--Sen. Ted Cruz got booed last week for declining to endorse his party's presidential nominee. This week, Sen. Bernie Sanders got booed for endorsing his party's inevitable nominee. (Or to be precise, the inevitable nominee of the party whose nomination Sanders was contesting. As far as we know, Sanders still isn't formally a Democrat.)And it happened to Sanders twice. As the Daily Caller notes, Sanders told an early-afternoon rally, "We have got to elect Hillary Clinton":The boisterous crowd interrupted his speech with boos after he stated his support for Clinton and Tim Kaine.Sanders went on to say, "Brothers and sisters, this is, this is the real world that we live in."Sanders delegates, meanwhile, were threatening to unleash "chaos" at the convention, Mother Jones's David Corn reported:As thousands of delegates to the Democratic convention hit the City of Brotherly Love (and Sisterly Affection), it was clear that the Clinton campaign's talk of unity, in the wake of announcing Tim Kaine as Clinton's running mate, was more hope than reality.OK, stop right there. "And Sisterly Affection"? Really? If you're going to rewrite Philadelphia's old motto to make it politically correct, why do it in such a transphobic way? You might as well call it the City of Binary Love.We missed Sanders's rally speech, as we spent the morning and early afternoon working at Philadelphia's elegant Union League Club. But we determined we'd see him address the convention during the evening. Walking out onto Broad Street at midafternoon, we found it closed to traffic as Sanders supporters marched.The mood was angrier than at Sunday's rally . The crowd chanted, "Hell, no, DNC! We won't vote for Hillary!" and "If we don't get it, shut it down!" Again there were interesting bespoke signs and banners. "Voting won't solve capitalism," read one (pictured above). Another mansplained : "Hey Hillary: First rule of all lives matter is don't bomb people. So shut up." One marcher flew a North Korean flag.We rode the Septa subway--which, by the way, was clean and reasonably efficient--to the terminus, known as the AT&T station. (Apart from underground cell towers, there's no AT&T facility nearby. The telecom corporation purchased naming rights from Septa.)Hundreds of pro-Sanders protesters had gathered near the station, determined to inflict their message on delegates. We passed the security checkpoint and found a long row of protesters pressed up against the metal barrier --hey, we thought these guys built bridges, not walls--and heard the same chants: "Hell, no, DNC! . . ." They looked like they were in a cage, though actually we were the ones on the inside.Things soon got even worse for the delegates. U.S. News reported at 4:50 p.m.--less than an hour after we arrived--that authorities had shut down the AT&T station "due to 'security measures' as protesters marched outside." That meant delegates had to walk an extra three-quarters of a mile in mid-90s temperatures. Talk about feeling the burn.The convention itself got off to a rocky start, Vox's Libby Nelson reports:Just moments after the convention officially opened, it devolved into internecine warfare. . . . Every time Hillary Clinton's name was mentioned at the outset, delegates booed loudly from the floor. . . . The "lock her up" chant--a favorite of delegates to the Republican National Convention that was heavily criticized--has made an appearance at the Democratic convention as well.The Hill reports that Sanders sent a message to supporters "asking, as a 'personal courtesy to me,' that they not protest or demonstrate on the floor":"Our credibility as a movement will be damaged by booing, turning of backs, walking out or other similar displays," he wrote in the email. "That's what corporate media wants. That's what [GOP presidential nominee] Donald Trump wants."As we watched the early proceedings on TV from the press center, we noted at one point a CNN chyron that read BREAKING NEWS: MOMENT OF SILENCE AT DNC. We suppose that would qualify as a man-bites-donk story.The good news for journalists was that the press work area was right across the street from the Wells Fargo Center (named after a bank, O the irony!), site of the convention. The bad news was that the DNC put us journos into big tents. When an early-evening thunderstorm struck, water started dripping in--a literal DNC leak . To judge by some of the tweets compiled by Twitchy , other news organizations got rained on considerably worse than The Wall Street Journal did. But there are still three days to go.At length the rain stopped and we made our way over to the Wells Fargo. We planned to stay through Sanders's speech then leave, allowing us to make a reasonably early night of it. But we discovered the order of the speakers had changed, so that Sanders would go on last. By the time he was finished, it was past 11 p.m.--outside of prime time in the Eastern and Central time zones.The delay did afford us the ability to see a good cross-section of DNC speakers. By far the star of the evening was Michelle Obama , who denounced Donald Trump as a bad influence on children. She described her and Barack's approach to rearing their daughters:With every word we utter, with every action we take, we know our kids are watching us. We as parents are their most important role models. And let me tell you, Barack and I take that same approach to our jobs as president and first lady because we know that our words and actions matter, not just to our girls, but the children across this country, kids who tell us I saw you on TV, I wrote a report on you for school.Kids like the little black boy who looked up at my husband, his eyes wide with hope and he wondered, is my hair like yours?She's got a point there: Imagine a little kid looking at Donald Trump and asking "Is my hair like yours?"It's something of a role reversal that Democrats are portraying themselves as wholesome vs. the transgressive Republicans, but it's certainly fitting given the public personae of the Obamas and Trump, respectively. Mrs. Obama had high praise for Mrs. Clinton, as you'd expect, but didn't mention her until after the role-model riff.Mrs. Obama also took issue with Trump's slogan:So, look, so don't let anyone ever tell you that this country isn't great, that somehow we need to make it great again. Because this right now is the greatest country on earth!Which raises the questions: Was America great before the Obamas arrived in the White House? And if so, why did Mr. Obama see a need for "fundamentally transforming" it?Mrs. Obama's happy talk was in contrast with the later speeches of Elizabeth Warren and Sanders, both of which were, if we may employ a five-day-old cliché, dark."America isn't going broke," Warren said, striking what turned out to be a deceptively optimistic note:The stock market is breaking records. Corporate profits are at all-time highs. CEOs make tens of millions of dollars. There's lots of wealth in America, but it isn't trickling down to hard-working families like yours.Does anyone here have a problem with that? Well, I do too.People get it: the system is rigged.You know who else said the system is rigged?There was some irony in Warren's complaining of a "rigged" system when the DNC's nomination system had just been proven rigged in favor of the candidate she was endorsing. The crowd's response to Warren was notably tepid, especially by comparison with Mrs. Obama. At several points she was heckled. We couldn't make out what the hecklers were saying, but Business Insider reports:"We trusted you! We trusted you!" factions of the audience chanted. . . . Loud boos and jeers came soon after, when the Massachusetts senator said it was imperative that [Mrs.] Clinton and Tim Kaine, her running mate, be elected to the White House.And toward the end of Warren's speech, the more progressive delegates began chanting again."Goldman Sachs! Goldman Sachs!" portions of the crowd chanted.Chants of "tax Wall Street" also came from the crowd.Likewise Sanders 's speech was dark:This election is about ending the 40-year decline of our middle class--the reality that 47 million men, women and children live in poverty. It is about understanding that if we do not transform our economy, our younger generation will likely have a lower standard of living than their parents.This election is about ending the grotesque level of income and wealth inequality that we currently experience, the worst it has been since 1928. It is not moral, not acceptable and not sustainable that the top one-tenth of one percent now own almost as much wealth as the bottom 90%, or that the top 1% in recent years has earned 85% of all new income. That is unacceptable. That must change.Nor were the cheers for him very enthusiastic--except toward the end, when he called for "strong opposition to job-killing free trade agreements like the Trans-Pacific Partnership." Trump couldn't have said it better.Even we heard the boos from Sanders supporters when he began his coda with an exhortation to vote for Mrs. Clinton. And you can see why they were unhappy. Sanders more or less acknowledged he was urging a choice of the lesser evil:Any objective observer will conclude that--based on her ideas and her leadership--Hillary Clinton must become the next president of the United States. The choice is not even close.In response, Trump tweeted : "Sad to watch Bernie Sanders abandon his revolution. We welcome all voters who want to fix our rigged system and bring back our jobs."Earlier, Sarah Silverman had appeared with Sen. Al Franken in the dullest assemblage of former "Saturday Night Live" talent since Norm Macdonald dined alone. As the Chicago Tribune notes, Silverman, who supported Sanders, said: "Can I just say to the 'Bernie or bust' people, you're being ridiculous."She has a point--and so does Sanders. If you want America to become more like Denmark, or like North Korea, Bernie Sanders was the best of the candidates seeking either party's nomination. But given the remaining options (and setting aside Green Jill Stein), Mrs. Clinton, bad as she is, is obviously better by lefty lights than Trump.It seems to this columnist the Nevertrump conservatives are also being ridiculous. Trump is arguably the least conservative of the 17 Republicans who sought the nomination, and he has some glaring character flaws. But Mrs. Clinton is much worse. From a conservative standpoint, to quote Sanders, "the choice is not even close."So why did the supposedly idealistic Sanders, in contrast with Cruz, make the ideologically practical calculation that it's better to elect the lesser of evils? Maybe because he, who will be 79 by Election Day 2020, is unlikely to run for president again. Cruz is nearly three decades Sanders's junior, young enough to harbor intense ambitions. Though he might have better served those ambitions with a Sanders-like show of selflessness.Worst Appeals to Authority "Geraldo Vouches for US General Accused of Plotting Failed Turkish Coup"--headline, FoxNews.com, July 25We Blame George W. There are people of all ages, and, yes, all races exercising, strolling hand in hand, playing with their dogs, kicking soccer balls and throwing Frisbees. There are a few homeless people, but the overall atmosphere is friendly--New Yorkers tend to be rushed, but they're not nasty--and, well, nice.Yes, the Upper West Side is affluent. But still, I've seen New York over the decades, and it has never been as pleasant, as safe in feel, as it is now. And this is the big bad city!The point is that lived experience confirms what the statistics say: crime hasn't been lower, society hasn't been safer, in generations. Which, of course, leads us to the Trump gambit from last [week]. Can he raise 1968-type fears in a country that looks, feels, and is nothing like it was back then?We're going to guess not. In fact, we'll go out on a limb and predict that Hillary Clinton wins by a landslide (in the Upper West Side).Follow @jamestaranto on Twitter.Join Fans of Best of the Web Today on Facebook.Subscribe to the Best of the Web email with one click.(Carol Muller helps compile Best of the Web. article name: Emails Show DNC Taking Aim at Bernie Sanders; Hack appears to show a continuing rift between the party and the primary runner-up
article text: Private emails released Friday by the WikiLeaks website have rocked the Democratic Party at its convention this week, just as party leaders aim to appear unified behind presumptive presidential nominee Hillary Clinton.The hacked emails , which appear to show evidence of a continuing rift between the Democratic National Committee and Mrs. Clinton's primary rival, Bernie Sanders, caused an uproar among the Vermont senator's supporters, who alleged during the primary that the DNC was unfairly tipping the scale in favor of Mrs. Clinton.DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz is stepping down from her role in light of the email leak.Brian Fallon, press secretary for Mrs. Clinton, told reporters Monday that the campaign doesn't condone the content of the leaked emails, singling out as particularly egregious one message that questioned Mr. Sanders's Jewish faith and suggested casting the Vermont senator as an atheist. The DNC in a statement apologized to Mr. Sanders about the emails.House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said Monday the role played by staffers at the DNC "should be scrutinized" and others dismissed if warranted. Donna Brazile, who will serve as interim DNC chairwoman, said she would conduct a probe before making any decisions about whether additional officials should lose their jobs.Of the more than 19,000 emails sent from DNC officials between early 2015 and mid-2016 that were dumped online by WikiLeaks (and are available by search ), here are nine that stand out:1. April 24, 2016 : DNC officials discuss a television appearance that day by Ms. Wasserman Schultz. Communications Director Luis Miranda writes, "She can't take Sanders on directly, it would turn into a fight and any time it's DNC Chair vs Sanders, DNC Chair is going to lose."2. April 24, 2016 : Ms. Wasserman Schultz, responding to an email about Mr. Sanders's saying he will stay in the primary race until the end, writes, "Spoken like someone who has never been a member of the Democratic Party and has no understanding of what we do."3. May 5, 2016 : DNC officials appear to suggest a plan to bring Mr. Sanders's religion into the primary narrative. In an email from Chief Financial Officer Brad Marshall to Chief Executive Amy Dacey, Mr. Marshall writes, "It might may no difference, but for KY and WVA can we get someone to ask his belief. Does he believe in a God. He had skated on saying he has a Jewish heritage. I think I read he is an atheist."In a Facebook post on Saturday, Mr. Marshall apologized for what he called "insensitive, emotional emails."4. May 13, 2016 : In an email to DNC press secretary Mark Paustenbach, Ms. Wasserman Schultz calls Sanders campaign manager Jeff Weaver "an ASS" for his comments about taking the primary fight to the convention.5. May 17, 2016 : When sent Mr. Weaver's comments on Sanders supporters protesting in Nevada, Ms. Wasserman Schultz says, "Damn liar. Particularly scummy that he barely acknowledges the violent and threatening behavior that occurred." Mr. Weaver had called on protesters to act civilly, but accused the Nevada state party of ignoring votes from the floor of the state convention.6. May 18, 2016 : Ms. Wasserman Schultz writes to MSNBC's Chuck Todd asking to discuss unfavorable coverage from the network's program, "Morning Joe." The email's subject line is, "Chuck, this must stop."7. May 18, 2016 : Christina Freundlich, DNC deputy communications director, asks for approval to post a fake job listing on Craigslist for women who want to apply to jobs at one of Donald Trump's organizations. The requirements for the job, listed in the email, include "no gaining weight on the job" and "must be open to public humiliation and open-press workouts if you do gain weight on the job."8. May 21, 2016 : The communications team floats the idea of creating an anti-Sanders narrative. Mr. Paustenbach emails Mr. Miranda: "Wondering if there's a good Bernie narrative for a story, which is that Bernie never ever had his act together, that his campaign was a mess."9. May 21, 2016 : Responding to Mr. Sanders's remarks that he would not reappoint Ms. Wasserman Schultz if he were elected president, the DNC chairwoman writes, "This is a silly story. He isn't going to be president."Write to Julian Routh at Julian.Routh@wsj.comRelated Coverage* DNC Hack Prompts Allegations of Russian Involvement* Twelve DNC Emails Released by WikiLeaks That Stand Out* Debbie Wasserman Schultz Won't Address Democratic Convention* On Eve of Democratic Convention, Party Seeks Unity With Official's Ouster* DNC Chair Debbie Wasserman Schultz to Resign Amid Email HackCredit: By Julian Routh

article name: For the Bernie Sanders Army, the Fight Isn't Over; At the Democratic convention, the senator's supporters vent their unhappiness
article text: PHILADELPHIA--Sen. Bernie Sanders raised an angry army to propel him through this year's presidential primaries. He didn't win that war, but his foot-soldiers showed on Monday they had one more battle they wanted to fight.That fight unfolded here on the first day of the Democratic Party's national convention . Sanders supporters took to the streets, to the hotel ballrooms where state delegations were meeting and ultimately to the floor of the convention itself to vent their unhappiness with the way they say they were treated by the party, and with their party's nominee-to-be, Hillary Clinton.Along the way, Sanders forces didn't merely make their party's leaders squirm. They served notice that, having barged into the party's inner sanctum, they aren't interested in exiting--certainly not exiting quietly.As the day began, they booed their ousted national charwoman, Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, at a meeting of her home-state Florida delegation because of newly disclosed emails showing that, under her, the party's apparatus had been eager to help Mrs. Clinton and put down Mr. Sanders. They booed House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D. Calif.), long a stalwart of the party's liberal wing, presumably because of her support for Mrs. Clinton.They even booed their hero, Mr. Sanders, at a morning rally when he urged them to unite behind Mrs. ClintonBy the time the convention formally opened just after 4 p.m., the Sanders backers had succeeded in scaring Ms. Wasserman Schultz off the convention stage entirely; she declined to open the convention proceedings as planned, knowing that her appearance would have produced a cascade of boos and catcalls.Yet that victory didn't calm the pro-Sanders camp, at least not entirely. As the convention opened, every time Mrs. Clinton's name was spoken, boos and jeers were heard from the crowd. The testiness between the Sanders and Clinton forces were obvious; after hearing the heckling, Rep. Marcia Fudge of Ohio, the permanent chair of the convention, scolded the audience."I will be respectful of you and I want you to be respectful of me," she said. "We are all Democrats and we need to act like it." Similarly, former Denver mayor Wellington Webb, a Clinton supporter, urged the crowd to cheer not one candidate or the other, but to cheer both Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton.Hundreds of Sanders supporters streamed into the Pennsylvania Convention Center to hear Mr. Sanders's Monday-afternoon speech, chanting "Feel the Bern" as they did so. They were skeptical of Mrs. Clinton's liberal credentials--but even more agitated at the email disclosure that they said showed the party's pro-Clinton bias."I just feel like if they really were sincere, then the whole party would be standing up and saying this is not acceptable and we don't agree with it," said Susan Hall, a delegate for Mr. Sanders from Scranton, Pa. Ms. Hall said that Mr. Sanders had backed Mrs. Clinton for strategic reasons and that she would "follow his lead"--suggesting the pressure on Mr. Sanders to help line up his supporters behind Mrs. Clinton.Rob Deppert, an alternate delegate from Indiana, wore a green Robin Hood hat handed out by a nurses union seeking to highlight Mr. Sanders's call to tax the rich to benefit the less well-off. Mr. Deppert complained that the emails showed "basically that the Democratic National Committee had its thumb on the scales and was working with the press to limit Bernie's access," producing a "rigged process."Meanwhile, out on the streets of Philadelphia, protesters braved temperatures of nearly 100 degrees to support Mr. Sanders. A spirited crowd gathered outside the entrance to the convention, shouting to passing delegates and carrying signs calling for Mr. Sanders to be made the nominee.They chanted, "Hell no, DNC, we won't vote for Hillary," and, "A vote for Hillary is a vote for Trump." Others carried signs calling for Mrs. Clinton to be indicted or jailed over her use of email while secretary of state. Police handcuffed a number of demonstrators but didn't arrest them. Instead, the police issued 55 citations for disorderly conduct."We need Bernie -- we need what he represents to the American people. The American people need the government to represent what it needs," said Michelle Gale, a 28-year old who traveled from Chicago to demonstrate. "We do not want Hillary."Almost lost in the hubbub was the more substantive impact of the Sanders insurrection--victories his supporters seemed to almost look past. The convention adopted by acclamation the most liberal platform in decades, which moved toward Sanders positions on the minimum wage , trade and college costs .The party also moved to appease the Sanders army's complaints about the structure of party primaries, adopting a plan to reduce the role of so-called superdelegates--party leaders who are automatically made delegates to the party's convention and free to support the candidate of their choice.Mr. Sanders and his supporters complained frequently and vociferously that the superdelegates gave Mrs. Clinton an unfair advantage, though she defeated him in both popular votes and other delegates in the party's primaries and caucuses."We've won this by standing up," says Maine state Rep. Diane Russell, commenting on the Democratic Party's decision to appoint a committee with an eye to overhauling the role of superdelegates. "We did this. We won this by standing together," she shouted, eliciting cheers of "Bernie, Bernie!"But she closed her remarks by saying she would do everything she could to ensure Mrs. Clinton wins the presidency--a needed boost at a convention with plenty of intraparty divisions.As that suggested, the Sanders insurrection was quieting down, at least temporarily, by the time evening fell, in part because leaders of the Sanders and Clinton campaigns joined forces to calm the atmosphere. Mr. Sanders again made clear to his followers that he wanted them to swing behind the party's nominee.Still, the day showed that the Sanders army isn't interested in disbanding, and may have longer-term ambitions for the party it has rocked.Write to Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.com and Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comCredit: By Siobhan Hughes and Byron Tau

article name: Clinton Won the Battle, Sanders the War; Hillary is living in Bernie's party. So she backs free college and a 'public option' while jettisoning trade and charter schools.
article text: Bill Clinton took Democrats to the political middle. He met with Republicans to pass welfare-to-work laws and put more police on the streets. Barack Obama steered the party leftward with "change we can believe in." He promised to end long-running wars, deliver an economic recovery, offer medical coverage to the uninsured and unify an increasingly diverse nation.Hillary Clinton will claim the Democratic nomination this week in Philadelphia, but the party is no longer defined by its standard-bearer. The energy rests instead with a rising generation of Democrats excited to use activist government to protect them in anxious economic times.Older Democrats and minority voters provided a "firewall" that allowed Mrs. Clinton to defeat her rival in the primaries, Sen. Bernie Sanders. Democrats who call themselves "somewhat liberal" went for Hillary by 13 percentage points, according to exit poll data analyzed by Public Opinion Strategies. "Moderates" backed her by 23 percentage points. But among the quarter of Democrats who see themselves as "very liberal," she ran even with the socialist.Bernie Sanders and his activist supporters have moved Mrs. Clinton and the party's platform to the left. The result is that the Democrats have taken on an identity that comes from a new base: voters under 40 who have no problem with Mr. Sanders's socialist vision. A 2015 study by the Pew Research Center found that 51% of millennials "identify as Democrats or lean Democratic," compared with only 35% for Republicans. Two-fifths of millennials are people of color and immigrants.This is not your father's--or even your older sister's--Democratic Party. It is far more left-leaning than under Bill Clinton or President Obama.Almost 60% of Democratic voters agree that "socialism has a positive" impact on society, according to a February poll by OnMessage Inc. and the American Action Network. In Iowa 43% of Democrats said in January that they would use the word "socialist" to describe themselves, a survey by the Des Moines Register and Bloomberg Politics found.Forty-seven percent of Democrats told Gallup last year that they are both "socially liberal and economically moderate/liberal"--the highest level in the poll's history. In 2001 only 30% of Democrats described themselves that way. Between 2000 and 2015 the percentage of "Democratic and Democratic-leaning registered voters" who consider themselves liberal has gone up to 42% from 27%, according to a Pew study in February.Mrs. Clinton has been running to the front of this liberal parade. This month she wrapped her arms around one of Mr. Sanders's biggest causes by backing tuition-free college at in-state public universities for families making under $125,000 a year.She broke with Mr. Obama by calling for repeal of the so-called Cadillac tax on health-insurance plans, a priority for labor unions. She gave a sop to the teachers unions by backtracking on her decades-old support for charter schools. It is clear that in this new liberal order of Democratic politics, the unions will be the enforcers.Mrs. Clinton is now even backing a "public option"--a Medicare-style government program to compete against private insurance companies. This idea was so radioactive during the debate over the Affordable Care Act that Democrats jettisoned it for fear of being tarred as proponents of socialized medicine.With the implicit support of Mrs. Clinton and her allies, the Sanders coalition added language to the Democratic platform calling to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour, put a price on climate-altering emissions like carbon, and abolish the death penalty.The party also stripped out language supporting the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, which Mr. Sanders opposed during the campaign. Mrs. Clinton had once praised the deal a "gold standard," but last fall she withdrew her support."It is no secret that Hillary Clinton and I disagree on a number of issues," Mr. Sanders said this month as he endorsed her in New Hampshire. He correctly noted that the threat of a divided party had forced Mrs. Clinton to accept "the most progressive platform in the history of the Democratic Party."Mr. Sanders then urged his supporters to keep the pressure on: "Our job now is to see that platform implemented by a Democratic Senate, a Democratic House and a Hillary Clinton presidency--and I am going to do everything I can to make that happen." The Vermonter has a stronger hand to play after the success of his populist campaign.Meanwhile, Democrats in Congress have become more liberal--the mirror image of what has happened to the GOP. Democratic incumbents who were defeated during the Obama years were largely centrists from red states: Sens. Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, Mark Pryor of Arkansas and Mark Begich of Alaska.After the 2012 election, much was written, including by me, about whether the Obama coalition of young people, blacks, Hispanics, gays and single women would keep Democrats in the White House for the near future. No one predicted that first of these core constituencies, young people, would become so vocally liberal.A final factor is the GOP's strategy of unrelenting obstructionism against President Obama, which sparked a low-grade fury among the left wing. This is why Monday night's convention speaker, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, gets hundreds of thousands of views every time she posts a fiery speech on YouTube.Senate Republicans have refused to have a hearing, much less a vote, on Merrick Garland, President Obama's nominee to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell even refused to give Mr. Garland the courtesy of a simple introductory meeting.The result is that the bare-knuckle, activist-driven, take-to-the-streets politics of Occupy Wall Street and Black Lives Matter is becoming the rule among Democrats. This month Senate Democrats blocked Republican efforts to defund so-called sanctuary cities and impose harsh prison sentences on undocumented immigrants.History will record this week's convention as a coming-of-age for a new era of liberal Democratic politics. This is now Bernie Sanders's party: Other Democrats--including Hillary Clinton--are merely living in it.Mr. Williams, a political analyst for Fox News and columnist for the Hill, is the author of "We the People: The Modern-Day Figures Who Have Reshaped and Affirmed the Founding Fathers' Vision of America" (Crown. 2016).Related Articles* Why the Democrats Have Turned Left* His and Her Clintonomics* Free College, DudeCredit: By Juan Williams

article name: Clinton in Tight Race In Kentucky; Sanders Wins Oregon
article text: LEXINGTON, Ky. -- Hillary Clinton held a narrow lead over Bernie Sanders late Tuesday in Kentucky's Democratic presidential primary, a result that blunted the Vermont senator's latest burst of momentum and likely thwarted his hopes of putting together a winning streak in the final state contests.With 99% of precincts reporting, Mrs. Clinton led her Democratic rival by less than 1 percentage point there.She declared victory on Twitter. "We just won Kentucky!" she tweeted. "Thanks to everyone who turned out. We're always stronger united."Mr. Sanders won the Democratic primary in Oregon, the other state voting Tuesday, and Donald Trump won the Republican primary there. The New York businessman won the Kentucky GOP caucuses on March 5.The decision by Mrs. Clinton to invest both time and resources in Kentucky paid dividends by moving her closer to securing her party's nomination and underscored the virtually impossible task Mr. Sanders faces in trying to chip away at his rival's advantage.Still, Mr. Sanders told supporters in California Tuesday night that his campaign has "a real shot to win" several of the remaining Democratic contests. "We are in until the last ballot is cast," he said.While Mrs. Clinton has amassed a nearly insurmountable lead in the Democratic race, she has been lumbering toward the finish line while being forced to simultaneously fend off attacks from Messrs. Sanders and Trump.There were 116 Democratic delegates up for grabs Tuesday, 55 in Kentucky and 61 in Oregon, all of which will be distributed proportionally.Heading into Tuesday's contests, Mrs. Clinton had 2,240 of the 2,383 delegates needed to clinch the nomination, when both pledged delegates and superdelegates were tallied, leaving her just 143 delegates shy of victory. Mr. Sanders had a combined total of 1,473, which meant the only way he could catch her would be to amass a large number of superdelegates.So far, the Vermont senator has had little luck in persuading those elected officials and party leaders, who are free to back any candidate, to rally behind his candidacy.That challenge likely becomes more difficult now after his supporters, angry over the handling of delegate allocation at a Nevada convention on Saturday, issued death threats to the state's party chairwoman. The messages were so vicious that Nevada officials filed a complaint with the Democratic National Committee.Mr. Sanders in a statement Tuesday condemned "any and all forms of violence," but defended his supporters and railed against the party process for picking a nominee. The Democratic Party "can open its doors and welcome into the party people who are prepared to fight for real economic and social change -- people who are willing to take on Wall Street, corporate greed and a fossil fuel industry which is destroying this planet. Or the party can choose to maintain its status quo structure," he said.In an effort to stall Mr. Sanders's momentum, Mrs. Clinton made three trips to Kentucky, visiting churches, holding small-group discussions, shaking hands at an overflowing diner and headlining a half-dozen rallies. She pitched herself as the best candidate to manage the nation's challenges, including national security and what she characterized as Mr. Trump's "reckless" approach to issues.Her campaign spent about $300,000 on TV ads, compared with about $100,000 for the Vermont senator, a Sanders aide said. Clinton aides said that was partly because they saw the state as winnable and partly because ad time in Kentucky is inexpensive. The Clinton campaign's investment in Kentucky marked a change in strategy after she all but ceded Indiana, where Mr. Sanders won by 5 percentage points, and West Virginia, where his margin of victory was almost 16 points.Mr. Sanders spent four days in Kentucky and continued to argue that he would be a stronger general-election candidate and a tougher foe for the New York businessman."In virtually every national poll and in statewide polls we do better against Donald Trump than Secretary Clinton. We're seeing that all over the country," he said during a campaign stop in Kentucky. "Secretary Clinton does very well with Democrats and so do I, but there are a lot of independents in the country and we do very well with independents," he said.Voters in the state reveled at the chance to size up the candidates so late in the primary process. The last contest is June 14 in Washington, D.C., a week after California, New Jersey and other states hold primaries or caucuses."I really appreciate what she's done for our country and what she will do," Mollijean Frazier said of Mrs. Clinton. The retired schoolteacher was among a crush of people greeting Mrs. Clinton at a Paducah diner Monday morning. "I think Bernie Sanders's people are looking for something that's not going to happen, sort of pie in the sky."In Louisville, Shea Stephens said she planned to cast a ballot for Mr. Sanders. "I can't find anything wrong with the man," said the 42-year-old technical account manager.Ms. Stephens said Mrs. Clinton "is the epitome of everything I do not like in politics."Mrs. Clinton came to Kentucky with some distinct advantages. She easily won the state in the 2008 Democratic presidential primary. The state's rules limit participation to registered Democrats, excluding the independent voters who have favored Mr. Sanders all year.Her husband, former President Bill Clinton, who campaigned separately for her, won the state twice and remains popular. During her appearances, she repeatedly invoked his economic record and promised to put him to work helping to revive the economy.There was concern, though, in the Clinton camp that the electorate would include conservative Democrats who would cast their ballots against Mrs. Clinton, and therefore for Mr. Sanders. That appeared to be the case last week in West Virginia. She faced other headwinds, including fallout from a comment earlier this year when, in the course of discussing a plan to help coal communities, she predicted that her energy agenda would put a lot of coal miners out of work.---Arian Campo-Flores contributed to this article.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Laura Meckler

article name: Election 2016: Nevada Unrest Shows Democratic Rifts --- Sanders rejects charge his backers are prone to violence after state convention dispute
article text: Bernie Sanders's feud with the Democratic establishment and front-runner Hillary Clinton continued to boil Tuesday in the wake of an unruly party convention in Nevada, raising new doubts about how easily the party can unite behind its eventual presidential nominee.In the latest turn, the Vermont senator in a statement Tuesday rejected accusations that his supporters were prone to violence and insisted the party must accommodate people fighting for "real" change.The comments stood as a clear sign that the Democratic underdog is unwilling to play the role of fence-mender while he battles Mrs. Clinton in the final primaries.At the Nevada state Democratic convention on Saturday in Las Vegas, disputes between supporters of Mr. Sanders and party officials turned physical. After the event, supporters of Mr. Sanders flooded the state party chairwoman with text messages and voice mails -- some containing veiled threats and obscene comments, according to screenshots and voice mails that were compiled by the Nevada Democratic Party.After the convention, the Nevada Democratic Party took the unusual step of filing a complaint about Mr. Sanders and his supporters with the Democratic National Committee, the national arm of the party. In the letter sent Monday, Nevada Democrats said Mr. Sanders's supporters had a "penchant" for violence and disruption, warning that the party's national convention in Philadelphia this summer could see similar actions.Mr. Sanders responded in his Tuesday statement that claims of a penchant for violence were "nonsense." He added: "Our campaign of course believes in nonviolent change and it goes without saying that I condemn any and all forms of violence, including the personal harassment of individuals."He said his campaign, too, had faced threats and intimidation, noting gunshots fired at a campaign office in Nevada earlier this year.He added that the party could welcome "people who are prepared to fight for real economic and social change" or "choose to maintain its status quo structure."Senate Democratic Leader Harry Reid of Nevada said Tuesday that he spoke with Mr. Sanders about the violence in his home state and that he hoped the senator "will do the right thing."Later, however, Mr. Reid said he was disappointed by the Sanders statement. "Bernie is better than that," Mr. Reid said.The escalating conflicts demonstrate the deep rifts in the party as the primary process nears an end. Mr. Sanders trails in the convention delegate count but has vowed to keep his campaign going until the July national convention.Heading into Tuesday's contests in Kentucky and Oregon, Mrs. Clinton led by nearly 300 pledged delegates and had the support of more than 500 party officials who serve as "superdelegates" and can support any candidate they wish. She is the overwhelming favorite to win the nomination.In Nevada, Mr. Sanders lost the state's popular vote by 5 percentage points in February, but his campaign was hoping to secure additional delegates at the state party convention. Mrs. Clinton's team ultimately prevailed in winning most of the state's delegates.At the convention, Sanders supporters repeatedly shouted down party officials and heckled the featured speaker, Sen. Barbara Boxer (D, Calif.).Afterward, activists directed their displeasure about the outcome at the chairwoman of the state party, Roberta Lange, posting her phone number online and flooding her phone with angry and occasionally threatening messages.In one voice mail shared by the Nevada Democratic Party, a caller says Ms. Lange is a "corrupt, evil, cynical woman." Another warns "the rest of your life is going to be hell."Another person said: "I don't know how you can go to sleep in good conscience every night."Nevada Democrats contacted local law enforcement about some of the text messages and voice mails, a person familiar with the matter said.Credit: By Byron Tau

article name: Bernie Sanders to Serve Senate Term as Independent
article text: PHILADELPHIA--Bernie Sanders said he plans to return to the Senate as an independent, despite winning 13 million votes in the Democratic Party's presidential primary contest."I was elected as an independent; I'll stay two years more as an independent," Mr. Sanders said.Speaking at the Bloomberg Politics breakfast on Tuesday, Mr. Sanders also said the resignation of Debbie Wasserman Schultz as chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee doesn't go far enough in fixing the situation and that more staff members need to leave following embarrassing disclosures of thousands of internal emails."We need a DNC which has as very different direction," he said. "I honestly don't know many of the people there. But my guess is we're going to need new leadership, a new direction and new personnel."Asked after the event whether Mr. Sanders considers himself a Democrat or an independent, a campaign aide said, "He ran for president as a Democrat but was elected to a six-year term in the Senate as an independent."Mr. Sanders's appearance followed his prime-time speech Monday in which he urged his supporters to back Hillary Clinton. As for his own future in the party, he said he would remain an independent as he serves out his senate term.Vermont has no party registration. But when Mr. Sanders entered the presidential race last year he proclaimed himself a Democrat.The emails, released by WikiLeaks, appear to show DNC aides plotting ways to undermine Mr. Sanders's campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination. In some measure they confirm a charge that the Sanders campaign made from the beginning of the primary fight: that Ms. Wasserman Schultz and her staff wanted Mrs. Clinton to prevail.On the eve of the four-day convention devoted to Mrs. Clinton's nomination, Ms. Wasserman Schultz announced she was stepping down as chairwoman. She has played no public role in the convention proceedings.Mr. Sanders cast the DNC as an inept operation that has failed to inspire people to vote, resulting in large Democratic losses in years when the president isn't on the ballot.He said the DNC needs new "leadership and a new chair that would lead the process of transforming the Democratic Party."Donna Brazile, a longtime Democratic official, has stepped in as interim chairwoman. On Monday, she issued an apology for the emails.She has also made an overture to Mr. Sanders, inviting his campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, to lend help to the committee in "voter participation" and "civic engagement.""I'll help Donna Brazile any way he can," Mr. Weaver said in an interview.Write to Peter Nicholas at peter.nicholas@wsj.comCredit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Democrats Achieve an Uneasy Détente at Convention; Many Bernie Sanders supporters signaled a willingness to support Hillary Clinton, but some walked out
article text: PHILADELPHIA--A fragile détente binding the dueling wings of the Democratic Party held together on Tuesday, quieting many unhappy supporters of Sen. Bernie Sanders and allowing Hillary Clinton's team to tamp down the most visible signs of upheaval at this week's convention.But underlying the uneasy peace that emerged from a raucous opening day in Philadelphia were questions about how many Sanders supporters would follow the lead of the Vermont senator, who offered a strong endorsement of Mrs. Clinton in his convention speech on Monday.In many cases, the answers inside the convention hall were different from those on the outside of Philadelphia's Wells Fargo Center.Outside the arena, along a median where protesters were corralled, scores of Sanders supporters on Tuesday voiced anger that their candidate's campaign for the nomination had ended, but seemed at loose ends over what to do next.Eric Goodman, a 20-year-old student from Burlington, Vt., was resolute Tuesday in his opposition to Mrs. Clinton's candidacy, declaring, "I am angry at Bernie. I think he betrayed all of his supporters."Later Tuesday, Sanders supporters expressed their disappointment with Mrs. Clinton's nomination by walking out of the convention hall. A crowd of at least several hundred assembled outside the Wells Fargo Arena. Most sat in the street singing, though a handful threatened to breach the barricades outside the convention center.The U.S. Secret Service said that four people were arrested during Tuesday's demonstrations for attempting to breach the inner perimeter protecting the Wells Fargo arena, where the convention is being held. The Secret Service said they would be charged with attempting to enter a restricted area. Those were the first four arrests of the convention, though more than 50 people were cited on Monday for disorderly conduct.But overall, the signs of disunity on Tuesday were muted.On the convention floor on Monday, many of Mr. Sanders's backers had swallowed their disappointment and signaled a willingness to back Mrs. Clinton in November.The Sanders supporters all had similar complaints: That Mrs. Clinton belonged to a political and financial establishment that wouldn't sufficiently champion workers, and that the Democratic National Committee had rigged the primary system to help her campaign. The question was whether to back Mrs. Clinton or to take another course.To keep the peace on Monday, Clinton and Sanders staffers had teamed up in an urgent scramble to quell protests and smooth intra-party rifts.That afternoon, Sanders officials reached out to the Clinton camp to say tensions were running high over hacked Democratic National Committee emails showing efforts to undercut Mr. Sanders's campaign. DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz had offered her resignation, but the Vermont senator's delegates still were angry.Clinton and Sanders aides huddled, hatching a plan to limit disruptions on the convention floor. Meantime, Mr. Sanders himself sent a text message to his delegates."I ask you as a personal courtesy to me to not engage in any kind of protest on the floor," he wrote. "It's of utmost importance you explain this to your delegations --Bernie"The Sanders campaign also sent aides into the aisles of the convention hall to placate unhappy delegates.One Sanders aide went into the California section to talk directly to Sanders delegates, explaining why the protests needed to subside, a person familiar with the matter said.The pitch: Mr. Sanders had come far but fallen short, and Mrs. Clinton had embraced many progressive positions on health care, education and other matters important to the Sanders movement.The Sanders team also talked about the importance of compromise in politics, saying that "You never get everything you want," and the best choice at this moment was Mrs. Clinton, this person said.The Clinton campaign called on one of its high-profile surrogates--former President Bill Clinton--to pitch in with the effort to bridge divisions.Late Monday afternoon, Democratic lawmakers arrived at the arena and were ushered in to a bar, where Mr. Clinton shook hands and took pictures, according to a person familiar with the matter.The reception served a strategic purpose. As Democrats waited to enter, Clinton campaign staffers hovered at the entry point, quietly asking the Democratic lawmakers and officials whether they could help calm tensions on the convention floor if mayhem broke out among the Sanders delegates, the person said.That evening at center stage, convention speakers urged calm and cohesion, prodding Sanders supporters to fall in line.Comedian Sarah Silverman, who had backed the Vermont senator, was blunt. "To the 'Bernie or bust' people, you're being ridiculous," she said.Mr. Sanders himself took a gentler approach, telling his supporters that he understood their disappointment, while making the case for sending Mrs. Clinton to the White House."He did what he needed to do, but still spoke to the progressive movement that's carrying a lot of us here today and beyond," Mina Davis, a Nebraska delegate for Mr. Sanders, said after his speech.The result was a chorus of cheers--with only a smattering of boos--and a declaration of success from both camps."We ended the night well," said John Podesta, chairman of the Clinton campaign. "Are there people who are still grumpy on his side? I have every confidence that there are people who are still grumpy."For the moment at least, a revolt had been averted. And on the convention floor, Donna Brazile, the incoming interim chairman of the DNC, and Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager, were all smiles as they held court.Ms. Brazile said that for the good of the party, she wouldn't cast a ballot during the roll call on Tuesday night. "It breaks my heart," Ms. Brazile said. "I come from a tradition where the right to vote means everything to me, but I'm going to do it for unity."Peter Nicholas, Carol E. Lee, Laura Meckler and Byron Tau contributed to this article.Write to Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.com and Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.comConvention CalendarWednesday, July 27* Among prime-time speakers: President Barack Obama, Vice President Joe Biden and Virginia Sen. Tim Kaine, the Democratic vice-presidential nomineeMore on Election 2016* Live Updates: Democratic Convention* Clinton Wins Historic Nomination* For Some Women, Gender Isn't Enough* Economic Messages Reveal Tensions* Kaine Runs Left on Social Issues* Sen. Sanders to Serve Term as Independent* Obama to Play Central Role* Clinton Committed to 'New Approach' on Trade Deal, Podesta Says* 2016 Election: Polls, Calendar, Money and MoreCredit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Gov. Andrew Cuomo Faces His Critics at Democratic Convention; Left wing of party knocks governor, even as he praises Sen. Bernie Sanders
article text: Corrections & AmplificationsProtesters raised criticism on several topics during Mr. Cuomo's second public address Tuesday. An earlier version of this article only mentioned the criticism of his executive order related to a boycott movement against Israel. (July 27, 2016)PHILADELPHIA--Away from his home turf , New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo spent his first day at the Democratic National Convention contending with pockets of the party where he is less than popular.Mr. Cuomo, who four years ago at the convention in Charlotte, N.C., shunned all but a minor address to New York delegates and declined to stay overnight, traveled to Philadelphia to participate more fully this time and has a speaking role later in the week.But on Tuesday he felt the effects of an emboldened Democratic left wing that has been determined to make its voice heard during the convention. Appearing at a breakfast for the New York delegation alongside Bernie Sanders, Mr. Cuomo praised the Vermont senator's presidential campaign and both politicians entered to a standing ovation."I also want to applaud the senator for keeping his eye on the ball," Mr. Cuomo said, to cheers. "The goal for the Democratic Party is to make sure [Donald] Trump and that philosophy has no place in this country, ever."But even as Mr. Sanders congratulated Mr. Cuomo for raising the statewide minimum wage and instituting a paid family-leave program, Sanders backers said they have already begun organizing to oppose Mr. Cuomo's re-election bid in 2018.Asked if she was a supporter of the New York governor, Sanders delegate and Queens resident Nancy de Delva said: "I'm definitely not.""All of his ideas are more Republican," said Ms. de Delva.She said she wasn't appeased by the governor's efforts on progressive ideals such as raising the minimum wage. "These were not his ideas. Mayor de Blasio wanted all this from the beginning," she said.A spokesman for Mr. Cuomo pointed out that the governor had long supported increases to the minimum wage, including before Mr. de Blasio became mayor, and took unilateral actions to raise it for fast-food workers and others prior to this year.Poornima Subramanian, a University of Buffalo pharmacy student, said fellow Sanders delegates have already selected a 2018 candidate: "We'd like to see [New York Attorney General] Eric Schneiderman run against Andrew Cuomo." Mr. Schneiderman has said that he doesn't intend to do that.At Mr. Cuomo's other public address of the day, to the Democratic Party's lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender caucus, he faced a more receptive crowd. He drew hearty applause for signing legislation legalizing same-sex marriage in New York and for describing the June mass shooting in Orlando, Fla., as "a terrorist attack on gay Americans."Still, even among friendly faces, Mr. Cuomo encountered some detractors in the form of protesters who disrupted his speech to criticize him for, among other things, an executive order to force state agencies to divest themselves of companies supporting a Palestinian-backed boycott movement against Israel.Mr. Cuomo recovered quickly from the disruption, and he was soon met with another vocal crowd member with a more supportive message concerning the state's embrace of same-sex marriage rights.Shouted one woman in the audience: "We did it by having the best governor ever in New York!"Write to Erica Orden at erica.orden@wsj.comWe Want to Hear From YouHave something to say about an article in Greater New York? Email us, along with your contact information, at gnyltrs@wsj.com . Letters will be edited for brevity and clarity. Please include your city and state.Credit: By Erica Orden

DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz had offered her resignation, but the Vermont senator's delegates still were angry.Clinton and Sanders aides huddled, hatching a plan to limit disruptions on the convention floor. Meantime, Mr. Sanders himself sent a text message to his delegates."I ask you as a personal courtesy to me to not engage in any kind of protest on the floor," he wrote. "It's of utmost importance you explain this to your delegations --Bernie"The Sanders campaign also sent aides into the aisles of the convention hall to placate unhappy delegates.One Sanders aide went into the California section to talk directly to Sanders delegates, explaining why the protests needed to subside, a person familiar with the matter said.The pitch: Mr. Sanders had come far but fallen short, and Mrs. Clinton had embraced many progressive positions on health care, education and other matters important to the Sanders movement.The Sanders team also talked about the importance of compromise in politics, saying that "You never get everything you want," and the best choice at this moment was Mrs. Clinton, this person said.The Clinton campaign called on one of its high-profile surrogates--former President Bill Clinton--to pitch in with the effort to bridge divisions.Late Monday afternoon, Democratic lawmakers arrived at the arena and were ushered in to a bar, where Mr. Clinton shook hands and took pictures, according to a person familiar with the matter.The reception served a strategic purpose. As Democrats waited to enter, Clinton campaign staffers hovered at the entry point, quietly asking the Democratic lawmakers and officials whether they could help calm tensions on the convention floor if mayhem broke out among the Sanders delegates, the person said.That evening at center stage, convention speakers urged calm and cohesion, prodding Sanders supporters to fall in line.Comedian Sarah Silverman, who had backed the Vermont senator, was blunt. "To the 'Bernie or bust' people, you're being ridiculous," she said.Mr. Sanders himself took a gentler approach, telling his supporters that he understood their disappointment, while making the case for sending Mrs. Clinton to the White House."He did what he needed to do, but still spoke to the progressive movement that's carrying a lot of us here today and beyond," Mina Davis, a Nebraska delegate for Mr. Sanders, said after his speech.The result was a chorus of cheers--with only a smattering of boos--and a declaration of success from both camps."We ended the night well," said John Podesta, chairman of the Clinton campaign. "Are there people who are still grumpy on his side? I have every confidence that there are people who are still grumpy."For the moment at least, a revolt had been averted. And on the convention floor, Donna Brazile, the incoming interim chairman of the DNC, and Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager, were all smiles as they held court.Ms. Brazile said that for the good of the party, she wouldn't cast a ballot during the roll call on Tuesday night. "It breaks my heart," Ms. Brazile said. "I come from a tradition where the right to vote means everything to me, but I'm going to do it for unity."Peter Nicholas, Carol E. Lee, Laura Meckler and Byron Tau contributed to this article.Credit: By Colleen McCain Nelson and Siobhan Hughes

article name: Formula One Chief's Mother-in-Law Kidnapped in Brazil; Seizure of Bernie Ecclestone's relative at São Paulo home comes less than two weeks before start of Rio Games
article text: SÃO PAULO--The Brazilian mother-in-law of billionaire Formula One chief executive Bernie Ecclestone was kidnapped on Friday in the country's largest city.A person familiar with the investigation on Tuesday said Aparecida Schunck was kidnapped from her São Paulo home.The kidnappers are asking for 120 million reais ($36.7 million) to free Ms. Schunck, whose daughter Fabiana Flosi married Mr. Ecclestone in 2012, the Brazilian magazine Veja reported.Ms. Flosi, who used to work for Brazil's Formula One championship organization, met Mr. Ecclestone in 2009. They now live in London.Spokespeople for the Brazilian police wouldn't comment on the kidnapping.The kidnapping comes less than two weeks before the Aug. 5 opening of the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro amid concerns about street crime and recent terror-related threats, some linked to Islamic State.Kidnappings increased in Brazil and other Latin American countries in the early 2000s, as drug traffickers and criminal gangs used ransom payments to help finance their activities. Brazilian police formed anti-kidnapping units that significantly reduced the problem.Still, kidnappings persist, including instances in which victims are seized for a few hours or days and forced to withdraw money from automated-teller machines.Jason Lee, a jujitsu champion from New Zealand living in Rio de Janeiro, posted to his Twitter account and his Facebook page that he was seized by armed men dressed in police uniforms on Saturday. He said the men threatened him with arrest, forced him into a car, then drove him to two ATMs and told him to withdraw money.On Tuesday, the Rio de Janeiro military police said they have ordered the arrest of two officers suspected of kidnapping Mr. Lee.Credit: By Luciana Magalhaes and Reed Johnson

article name: For the Bernie Sanders Army, the Fight Isn't Over; At the Democratic convention, the senator's supporters vent their unhappiness
article text: PHILADELPHIA--Sen. Bernie Sanders raised an angry army to propel him through this year's presidential primaries. He didn't win that war, but his foot-soldiers showed on Monday they had one more battle they wanted to fight.That fight unfolded here on the first day of the Democratic Party's national convention . Sanders supporters took to the streets, to the hotel ballrooms where state delegations were meeting and ultimately to the floor of the convention itself to vent their unhappiness with the way they say they were treated by the party, and with their party's nominee-to-be, Hillary Clinton.By night's end, the Sanders forces were able to turn from jeering to cheering when Mr. Sanders spoke to the convention and gave a full-throated endorsement of Mrs. Clinton. Still, the day served noticed that, having barged into the party's inner sanctum, they won't exit quietly. Mr. Sanders himself, during his prime-time speech, said his political "revolution" would continue.As the day began, they booed their ousted national charwoman, Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, at a meeting of her home-state Florida delegation because of newly disclosed emails showing that, under her, the party's apparatus had been eager to help Mrs. Clinton and put down Mr. Sanders. They booed House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D. Calif.), long a stalwart of the party's liberal wing, presumably because of her support for Mrs. Clinton.They even booed their hero, Mr. Sanders, at a morning rally when he urged them to unite behind Mrs. Clinton.By the time the convention formally opened just after 4 p.m., the Sanders backers had succeeded in scaring Ms. Wasserman Schultz off the convention stage entirely; she declined to open the convention proceedings as planned, knowing that her appearance would have produced a cascade of boos and catcalls.Yet that victory didn't calm the pro-Sanders camp, at least not entirely. As the convention opened, every time Mrs. Clinton's name was spoken, boos and jeers were heard from the crowd. The testiness between the Sanders and Clinton forces were obvious; after hearing the heckling, Rep. Marcia Fudge of Ohio, the permanent chair of the convention, scolded the audience."I will be respectful of you and I want you to be respectful of me," she said. "We are all Democrats and we need to act like it." Similarly, former Denver mayor Wellington Webb, a Clinton supporter, urged the crowd to cheer not one candidate or the other, but to cheer both Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton.Hundreds of Sanders supporters streamed into the Pennsylvania Convention Center to hear Mr. Sanders's Monday-afternoon speech, chanting "Feel the Bern" as they did so. They were skeptical of Mrs. Clinton's liberal credentials--but even more agitated at the email disclosure that they said showed the party's pro-Clinton bias."I just feel like if they really were sincere, then the whole party would be standing up and saying this is not acceptable and we don't agree with it," said Susan Hall, a delegate for Mr. Sanders from Scranton, Pa. Ms. Hall said that Mr. Sanders had backed Mrs. Clinton for strategic reasons and that she would "follow his lead"--suggesting the pressure on Mr. Sanders to help line up his supporters behind Mrs. Clinton.Rob Deppert, an alternate delegate from Indiana, wore a green Robin Hood hat handed out by a nurses union seeking to highlight Mr. Sanders's call to tax the rich to benefit the less well-off. Mr. Deppert complained that the emails showed "basically that the Democratic National Committee had its thumb on the scales and was working with the press to limit Bernie's access," producing a "rigged process."Meanwhile, out on the streets of Philadelphia, protesters braved temperatures of nearly 100 degrees to support Mr. Sanders. A spirited crowd gathered outside the entrance to the convention, shouting to passing delegates and carrying signs calling for Mr. Sanders to be made the nominee.They chanted, "Hell no, DNC, we won't vote for Hillary," and, "A vote for Hillary is a vote for Trump." Others carried signs calling for Mrs. Clinton to be indicted or jailed over her use of email while secretary of state. Police handcuffed a number of demonstrators but didn't arrest them. Instead, the police issued 54 citations for disorderly conduct."We need Bernie -- we need what he represents to the American people. The American people need the government to represent what it needs," said Michelle Gale, a 28-year old who traveled from Chicago to demonstrate. "We do not want Hillary."Almost lost in the hubbub was the more substantive impact of the Sanders insurrection--victories his supporters seemed to almost look past. The convention adopted by acclamation the most liberal platform in decades, which moved toward Sanders positions on the minimum wage , trade and college costs .The party also moved to appease the Sanders army's complaints about the structure of party primaries, adopting a plan to reduce the role of so-called superdelegates--party leaders who are automatically made delegates to the party's convention and free to support the candidate of their choice.Mr. Sanders and his supporters complained frequently and vociferously that the superdelegates gave Mrs. Clinton an unfair advantage, though she defeated him in both popular votes and other delegates in the party's primaries and caucuses."We've won this by standing up," says Maine state Rep. Diane Russell, commenting on the Democratic Party's decision to appoint a committee with an eye to overhauling the role of superdelegates. "We did this. We won this by standing together," she shouted, eliciting cheers of "Bernie, Bernie!"But she closed her remarks by saying she would do everything she could to ensure Mrs. Clinton wins the presidency--a needed boost at a convention with plenty of intraparty divisions.As that suggested, the Sanders insurrection was quieting down, at least temporarily, by the time evening fell, in part because leaders of the Sanders and Clinton campaigns joined forces to calm the atmosphere. Mr. Sanders, even before his speech, again made clear to his followers that he wanted them to swing behind the party's nominee.Still, the day showed that the Sanders army isn't interested in disbanding, and may have longer-term ambitions for the party it has rocked.Write to Siobhan Hughes at siobhan.hughes@wsj.com and Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.comMore* Emails Show DNC Taking Aim at Sanders* Hack Prompts Allegations of Russian InvolvementCredit: By Siobhan Hughes and Byron Tau

article name: The Democrats' Second Email Problem; Hacked messages showing the party connived against Sanders have sent his fans in Philly into a tizzy.
article text: Donald Trump got a post-convention gift Friday when WikiLeaks released a trove of hacked emails that showed Democratic National Committee leaders conniving against Bernie Sanders.Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz disparaged Mr. Sanders's party loyalty in one email and called his campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, a "damn liar." The party's CFO, Brad Marshall, suggested trying to make an issue of the Vermonter's religion: "Does he believe in a God. He had skated on saying he has a Jewish heritage. I think I read he is an atheist." Amy Dacey, the party's CEO, replied: "AMEN."It's hardly news that the Democratic machine assisted Hillary Clinton throughout the primary. The party scheduled debates at times likely to draw few viewers--for instance, Sunday night at 9 p.m. Still, it's bracing to see the political cynicism lain out in black and white.The uproar cost Ms. Wasserman Schultz her job, as the chairwoman announced she will step down at the end of the convention. She leaves after having accomplished her mission of nominating Mrs. Clinton, for which she is being rewarded with a titular position as head of the Clinton campaign's "50-state program" to elect Democrats nationwide.At first the party establishment expressed remorse only that the improper collusion was exposed. Mr. Marshall, the CFO, apologized Saturday. "I deeply regret," he wrote in a post on Facebook, "that my insensitive, emotional emails would cause embarrassment to the DNC." The following day, after Ms. Wasserman Schultz announced her resignation, President Obama lauded her service, saying that "her fundraising and organizing skills were matched only by her passion, her commitment and her warmth." Mrs. Clinton thanked her "longtime friend" for "getting the Democratic Party to this year's historic convention."Meantime, Team Clinton is using Russian hackers as a diversion. "Sources are saying the Russians are releasing these emails for the purpose of actually helping Donald Trump," campaign manager Robby Mook said.
