Likewise, a reduced U.S. commitment to Europe and NATO, as Mr. Trump has proposed in his ad hoc way, could lead to greater Russian influence and more frequent conflict.Commitments to allies serve two purposes. One is to deter would-be adversaries and to reduce the chances of conflict. The other is to reassure countries that would otherwise have to appease their more powerful neighbors or develop their own capacities for self-defense, which in this era could entail developing nuclear weapons. The benefits and influence that the U.S. derives from its longstanding alliance commitments far exceed the costs.Isolationists must not prevail in this new debate over foreign-policy fundamentals, one which I had never imagined would take place in my lifetime. Turning away from global engagement would mean not just opportunities lost: in jobs reliant on exports, the chance to invest overseas, the ability to travel without fear. It also would bring conflict and nuclear proliferation. As the world unraveled, Americans would be more vulnerable to terrorism, illegal immigration, climate change and disease.We do not have the option of becoming a giant gated community. Sooner or later, we would feel compelled to step in to restore stability and to right the balance of power.What will it take for internationalists to advance their cause in today's bitter debate? A start would be to rebuild a consensus in favor of free trade. Trade has multiple benefits. It contributes to economic growth and to well-paying export-oriented jobs. It can fuel development, thereby reducing the number of weak or failed states that host terrorists, pirates and drug cartels. It can strengthen allies. And it can enmesh potential adversaries in a network of mutually beneficial ties that make the option of disrupting them through war less attractive.Winning the debate, though, will take more than marshaling facts. Those who lose their jobs because of trade deserve assistance, both to tide them over and to train them for new jobs. Trade partners must be held to high standards when it comes to labor conditions, the environment and manipulation of currencies. The playing field must be level.The cause of internationalism would also be helped by policies that increase economic growth, from infrastructure modernization to tax, entitlement and immigration reform. Populism and parochialism are much more likely to gain traction amid anxiety over jobs and stagnant or declining standards of living.It also will be important to remind Americans of the benefits of U.S. leadership--and the likely costs of abdication. Current U.S. spending on defense as a percentage of GDP is close to a post-World War II low. We can do what we should in the world at a reasonable cost.Congress has a role to play in this wider discussion of America's global role; televised hearings dealing with fundamental foreign policy issues could be invaluable. The next secretary of state will want to spend more time at home explaining why American world leadership is as much a favor to ourselves as to others.Above all, the president will want to take advantage of the unique classroom that is the Oval Office. Mr. Obama could do worse than to use some part of his remaining months as president to discuss with the American people why the world matters and how the U.S. gains from what it does beyond its borders--and stands to lose if it fails to do them. Success in reminding Americans of their deep stake in the wider world could turn out to be one of his most important legacies.Dr. Haass is the president of the Council on Foreign Relations and the author of "A World in Disarray: American Foreign Policy and the Crisis of the Old Order," which will be published in January by the Penguin Press.Related Reading* Brexit: A Very British Revolution (June 24, 2016)* After Orlando, a Long War (June 17, 2016)* For China, a Plunge and a Reckoning (Aug. 28, 2015)* Desert Storm, the Last Classic War (July 31, 2015)Credit: By Richard N. Haass

article name: From Wall Street to Sing Sing; The Bernie Madoff of his time, Richard Whitney had tasted glory in 1930 as the youngest president ever of the New York Stock Exchange.
article text: The most prominent Wall Streeter-turned-jailbird emerged from Sing Sing 75 years ago this week, in 1941. In raw dollar figures, Richard Whitney's financial folly fell far short of Bernie Madoff's--a few $100,000s (in 1930s dollars), here and there, a mere drop in the latter's Ponzi bucket of billions. But Whitney was much better known on the public stage long before he went to the pen.A Boston-bred blue blood whose youthful pedigrees included Groton and Harvard's Porcellian Club, Whitney bought a New York Stock Exchange seat at age 23. He was elected to the NYSE board of governors in 1919. In 1930, at age 41, he became the youngest president in the exchange's 138-year history.Whitney's star shined brightest on his institution's bleakest day--Black Thursday, Oct. 24, 1929. As stock prices plummeted, Whitney, then the exchange's vice president, conferred with the city's elite bankers to reverse the slide. Acting with their cash, he strode onto the exchange floor, walked up to U.S. Steel's trading booth, and bought a huge block of shares at $205, far above the listed price. He similarly bid up General Electric and other sagging blue chips. He was hailed as a savior as the market steadied.Five days later--Black Tuesday--came the heaviest selloff in the exchange's history. No rescue this time. As America lapsed into its Great Depression, Whitney began the first of five terms as exchange president. On leaving the exchange presidency in 1935, he focused on an apparently thriving brokerage firm and personal investments.But all was sham. He speculated, lost, then speculated more. Unsecured sums lent by relatives, friends and business associates failed to cover losses. He embezzled $214,000 from client accounts. He misappropriated funds from his father-in-law's estate. He raided the New York Yacht Club treasury. He even dipped into the New York Stock Exchange Gratuity Fund, of which he was trustee.The dam broke in March 1938, when an audit of NYSE member firms revealed that Richard Whitney & Co. was insolvent. Public disclosures followed, and then came a grand jury indictment. Whitney pleaded guilty to embezzlement.On April 12, Whitney stepped out of a police van at Grand Central Station and boarded a train to go up the river to Sing Sing. First assigned to mop floors, he was soon promoted to chief clerk in a prison office and regarded as a model prisoner. Fellow convicts and guards asked for autographs.When a paroled Whitney walked out to freedom on Aug. 11, 1941. A chauffeured limousine awaited. Inside was his elder brother, George, a partner and pillar at J.P. Morgan & Co. who had paid off all of his wayward brother's debts. Richard Whitney then drove away into obscurity.At one point he was said to be managing a small dairy farm, but he was never newsworthy again until he died on Dec. 5, 1974. And once more after 2008, when the old print media, which once knew him well, and the electronic media, which knew him not at all, began looking for past Madoffs on Wall Street.Mr. Rosenberg is the author, with Louis Eisenstein, of "A Stripe of Tammany's Tiger" (Cornell University, 2013 paperback).Related Articles* Blue Blood, Red Ink* Out for Blood* Taking Revenge on the Rich Will Not Bring RecoveryCredit: By Elliot Rosenberg

article name: Hillary Clinton's Free College-Tuition Plan Short on Specifics; Details on Democratic presidential candidate's proposal, put forth during negotiations with party rival Bernie Sanders, are hard to come by
article text: Hillary Clinton, who prides herself on the details of public policy, has said little about what is now the most ambitious and expensive proposal on her agenda: making public college tuition free for most Americans .On the campaign trail, she typically offers a sentence, maybe two, about the plan. Sometimes it goes unmentioned altogether. Her campaign has offered few specifics about how the program would work, hasn't said how much money states would have to provide or where the program would fall on her list of priorities.The campaign website no longer lists a cost for the program, though campaign aides said they estimate it would take $500 billion in new federal spending over 10 years, $150 billion more thanthe college plan she put out last summer . Others estimate the costs would be much higher.The sketchiness may owe something to the way the free-tuition plan came to be part of Mrs. Clinton's platform. Rather than taking months or years to craft, like many of her other proposals, it was inserted as part of negotiations in July to win the backing of Democratic rival Sen. Bernie Sanders.Lanae Erickson Hatalsky, who tracks higher education and other issues at the centrist Democratic think tank Third Way, said it was obvious that the plan was put together to win over Mr. Sanders.Most of Mrs. Clinton's policy proposals "are five pages of dense text with very specific ways of how they're going to pay for it and how much it would cost," she said. "This sounded much more like something intended to energize a campaign rally."The Clinton plan still is more detailed than most of the ideas put forth by her opponent, Republican Donald Trump, who doesn't typically give the cost of his plans and sometimes changes significant planks. Still, Mrs. Clinton prides herself on her policy chops and says candidates owe it to voters to be clear about their plans. Mr. Trump's campaign didn't respond to a request for comment.Mrs. Clinton says she would pay for the college plan with higher taxes on the wealthy, including new limits on deductions. Campaign aides said that once school is back in session and younger voters are paying more attention, she would talk more about the college plan.Clinton spokesman Jesse Ferguson said Mrs. Clinton is "deeply committed" to the revised plan. "Hillary Clinton put forward an ambitious proposal in the primary and, after listening to voters on the campaign trail, expanded it to more effectively reach the goal of erasing the barrier of debt to a college of education," he said.Passing this program into law will be a challenge, though, particularly if Republicans continue to control at least one house of Congress. Even some Democrats think Mrs. Clinton's first proposal would have a better chance and worry that the revised version is too heavy a lift.The new Clinton policy was described in a single paragraph issued by the campaign in early July amid talks with Mr. Sanders, who had campaigned against her in the primary on a more expansive free-tuition plan. His concept was that public colleges should be free for all, like public high schools.Mrs. Clinton had already put forth a detailed plan last summer to assure that students could attend public colleges without borrowing money for tuition, but she said families should contribute what they could afford. To win over Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Clinton agreed that students in families earning $85,000 a year or less would be assured free tuition, with that threshold climbing to $125,000 over four years.The political goals were clear. The policy was a priority for Mr. Sanders, and after her shift, he endorsed her. She also put herself in position to appeal to younger voters, who overwhelmingly backed Mr. Sanders in the primaries and are an important part of the coalition that twice elected President Barack Obama.In his speech at July's Democratic National Convention endorsing Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Sanders specifically cited this policy shift. It was one of several she made that were key to winning his support, including an agreement to back additional funding for community health centers.For now, the new plan appears to cut against two points Mrs. Clinton made during the primaries.First, she had long described her plan, which she calls the New College Compact , as a balanced way of making sure all players have "skin in the game," including federal and state governments, universities, families and students."I think it ought to be a compact," she said during a Democratic debate last year. "Families contribute, kids contribute."Under her new plan, 80% of families would qualify for tuition-free school, even if they could afford some contribution. A Clinton aide replied by noting that students are still expected to have a job that will help pay expenses, and said that it is most important that government pay its fair share.Second, one of her chief criticisms of the Sanders tuition-free plan was that it relied on governors, including critical Republican governors, to put up one-third of the funding. But her plan requires substantial state contributions as well, though her campaign hasn't specified how much.The Clinton aide said states will be more likely to fund her plan because it would be phased in gradually.She did stick by her view, voiced often during the primaries, that the government shouldn't offer free tuition to very rich families.Other aspects of the Clinton plan would lower borrowing costs for existing borrowers and those who attend private colleges, and would make community college free.Meantime, Mrs. Clinton appears to be offering another change to her program that she hasn't yet explained. In an economic speech on Thursday , she promised "tuition-free" college for the middle class, and "debt-free college" for everyone.Aides said debt-free is a goal meant to assure no student has to borrow money to pay any college costs, including room, board and other expenses, which can represent half the total costs. That goes beyond her original concept and isn't detailed in the pages of facts sheets provided by her campaign.Many advocates welcome the expansions. Tamara Draut, of the advocacy group Demos, which promotes debt-free college, said it is essential that students be able to pay for all college expenses without taking loans, and that this is her understanding of the Clinton plan. She said she expects more details to come."I think we're a long way from governing and there is more detail there than her opponent's policy platforms, for sure," she said.Write to Laura Meckler at laura.meckler@wsj.comMore on Election 2016* Hillary Clinton Widens Lead Over Donald Trump in Battleground States (Aug. 12)* Hillary Clinton Releases Tax Return, Pressuring Donald Trump to Follow (Aug. 12)* Washington Wire: Trump Warns of Electoral 'Cheating' During Pennsylvania Rally (Aug. 12)Credit: By Laura Meckler

article name: Long Before the Bernie Bros; Politics in the 19th century was a form of entertainment. Soon it had fierce competition: the bicycle craze, team sports and vaudeville.
article text: It is often taken as a good thing when young people show an interest in politics--especially, it seems, when they vote to the left of their elders. In 1972, for example, young voters split evenly between Richard Nixon and George McGovern, and in 2012 they provided pretty much all of Barack Obama's popular-vote margin.But these were not the peak years of young Americans' influence on electoral politics. The peak came in the turbulent politics of the pre-Civil War years and the decades after, roughly 1840 to 1900. The period is chronicled in vivid and loving detail by Jon Grinspan, a historian and Smithsonian curator, in "The Virgin Vote."The book's title comes not from the snarky 2012 campaign video--the one using double-entendre to encourage young women to vote for Barack Obama--but from a label proudly self-applied in the 19th century by young men who were casting their vote for the first time. "Virgin voters were likely to vote in groups, often joined by brothers, father and friends," Mr. Grinspan writes. And the commotion attracted notice: "While young men fluffed their beards, donned new hats and headed off to the polls, their sisters looked on with a combination of support, pride and--sometimes--resentment."The Virgin VoteBy Jon Grinspan North Carolina, 256 pages, $28Virgin voting and active electioneering were well-nigh universal in mid- and late 19th-century America. From 1840 to 1900, Mr. Grinspan says, between 70% and 80% of those eligible to vote did so in every presidential election, more than ever before or since. Young women were active as well, canvassing and participating in rallies. Young free blacks voted, too, until they were blocked from the polls by Democratic politicians and the Ku Klux Klan.Drawing on a wide range of scholarship and dozens of diaries, Mr. Grinspan tells his story more in personal than statistical terms. We see 19-year-old Oscar Lawrence Jackson orating for Abraham Lincoln in southern Ohio in 1860; 15-year-old George Washington Albright sneaking out at night to tell other slaves on nearby Mississippi plantations about the Emancipation Proclamation; 16-year-old James Witham arguing politics in the caboose of a westbound train in Nebraska in 1872.In some of these accounts we hear serious arguments about politics and policy, but they also include ridicule and rowdiness, alcohol consumption and tobacco expectoration, flirting and frivolity, and roving gangs of young men like Lincoln's Wide Awake boys, who prowled at the edge of crowds looking for trouble. Altogether Mr. Grinspan's narrative is a riveting picture of 19th-century politicking.And a picture in some ways unsettling. Young Americans tended to inherit their political views from their elders and, in this supercharged political atmosphere, tended to stick with the party they supported with their virgin votes. There were some exceptions--Mr. Grinspan zeroes in on the party-switching and ultimately nonpartisan author William Dean Howells--but party loyalties then seem much like loyalties to sports teams today: You keep rooting for the Yankees or the Cowboys regardless of changes in players and coaches and owners, overlooking the team's weaknesses and excusing its fouls. Sometimes old parties disappear and new ones are formed, as in the 1850s, just as sports leagues expand and teams relocate. But mostly this was a period, not unlike our two most recent decades, of static partisan divisions, with just a few votes making the difference between victory and defeat.Yet the rough-and-ready politics of such a time had to deal with the great, and greatly divisive, issues of slavery and civil rights, which accounted for some of the fervor of the virgin voters. One reads Mr. Grinspan's chapter on Oscar Lawrence Jackson's 1860 speech aware that the victory of his candidate culminated in a civil war in which 600,000 died--and in which Jackson himself survived a shot in the face. He was elected to Congress in the 1880s and died in 1920.By that time the age of the virgin voter was long over. Voter participation began to fall off in the 1890s. One reason was reform, starting with the ballot itself. Initially each political party printed ballots with only its own candidates listed. The ballots were distributed to would-be virgin voters by armies of young men on Election Day. Between 1887 and 1896, to prevent ballot-box stuffing and discourage straight-ticket voting, most states adopted the so-called Australian ballot, which listed candidates of all parties and was handed out by election clerks. Casting votes, including virgin votes, became a perfunctory matter, Mr. Grinspan notes, rather than a theatrical performance.For the youth of this period, politics was clearly a form of entertainment, but it eventually met competition: The bicycle craze, the rise of team sports like baseball and the growth of vaudeville provided other pastimes and venues where young men and women could spend time together. By the 1890s, Mr. Grinspan writes, "youth and politics were quietly untangling themselves." Even as the potential electorate was expanded by women's suffrage and the naturalization of Ellis Island immigrants, political participation and voter turnout declined.Should we wish for a revival of young people's participation in politics? Implicitly throughout and explicitly in an afterword, the author answers "yes." Amid so many distractions, he argues, the key "to getting young people involved in politics, regardless of brain chemistry or habits, is to raise them in a culture that cares."A skeptic may question whether the quality of the election result is improved by the participation of the otherwise indifferent and whether a caring culture will always care wisely. "The Virgin Vote" plunges readers into a pulsating political culture long vanished--and unlikely to be revived in a year when most young voters dislike both major parties' presidential nominees.Mr. Barone is senior political analyst for the Washington Examiner, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and co-author of "The Almanac of American Politics."Credit: By Michael Barone

article name: California Liberals Await the Bernie Effect
article text: Bernie Sanders is hoping to pull off an upset victory over Hillary Clinton in California's June 7 presidential primary, buttressing his argument to Democratic superdelegates -- now in the favorite's pocket -- that Mrs. Clinton isn't too big to fail. But even if Mr. Sanders loses on Tuesday, he could be a winner for California's liberal politicians: The self-described socialist is expected to turn out masses of young people, and that could be a boon for down-ballot left-wing candidates for the state legislature.In heavily Democratic California, the party's primary is when most legislative contests are decided, and those can hinge on a few hundred votes. Despite California's open primary, in which the top two finishers regardless of their party face each other in November, it's unlikely that two Democrats will emerge unless there's very low Republican turnout. The Sanders effect could give Democrats a supermajority in Sacramento, pulling the party -- and the state -- even further to the left than it already is.Public unions, liberal groups, government reformers and businesses are wading into the primary in a big way. Because of term limits, there are six Senate (of 40) and 16 Assembly seats (of 80) open. The goal of many working to influence the primary is to shift the moderate-liberal balance of power in the Democratic caucus, since the Republican minority is usually irrelevant except for close votes to block tax increases.Consider the 27th Assembly-district race in Silicon Valley, where six Democrats and one Republican are on the primary ballot. The general election is unlikely to be competitive since Democrats outnumber Republicans in the district by more than two to one.The leading Democratic contenders are Madison Nguyen and Ash Kalra, both of whom have recently served on the San Jose city council. In 2012, Ms. Nguyen supported sweeping public-pension reforms -- which Mr. Kalra complains "eroded employee morale and created the most toxic labor-management relationship in the city's history." Labor groups have endorsed Mr. Kalra, while Ms. Nguyen enjoys support from government reformers, like former mayor Chuck Reed, who hope to elect more moderate Democrats to the legislature.In an overlapping Senate district, oil companies have spent $340,000 backing a challenge by term-limited Democratic Assembly member Nora Campos to unseat incumbent Jim Beall. Ms. Campos was one of 21 Democratic Assembly members (most representing middle and low-income communities) who helped defeat a sweeping climate-change bill last year that would have given the California Air Resources Board plenary authority to cut statewide gas consumption by 50%. Ms. Campos recently said: "I always think about real-world impacts from the legislation we pass," a sentiment not shared by many Democrats in Sacramento. Billionaire environmentalist Tom Steyer has spent $500,000 supporting Mr. Beall.In the 11th Senate district, San Francisco supervisors Jane Kim and Scott Wiener are sparring over "quality of life" issues. Ms. Kim, a former Green Party member who was recently endorsed by Bernie Sanders, supports a "Right to Rest" bill in the legislature that would bar police from clearing homeless encampments. She also wants to restrict tech-company shuttle buses that ferry employees around town and have stirred resentment in some quarters. Considered a pro-business moderate in San Francisco, Mr. Wiener opposes both proposals.The Democratic supervisors also differed on a pair of local referendums last fall that would have imposed a building moratorium on market-rate condos in San Francisco's Mission District and limited short-term apartment rentals through startups like Airbnb. Both referendums failed despite Ms. Kim's backing.In the Central Coast 30th Assembly district, public unions, nearly all Democratic statewide officers and Assembly Speaker Anthony Rendon are backing Karina Cervantez Alejo, the wife of term-limited Assembly member Luis Alejo, who is known as a good friend to labor. In wine country's third Senate district, public unions are bankrolling Mariko Yamada, who supports free community-college education and a ban on foods including genetically modified organisms, or GMOs. Ms. Yamada's main contender is Democratic assembly member Bill Dodd, a former Republican.In these and other races, liberal candidates may benefit from the Sanders campaign. The senator's supporters have been holding voter-registration drives throughout the Bay Area, including at medical marijuana shops, farmers markets and college campuses. Last month, analytics firm Political Data reported that new voter registration in California during the first four months of this year is at its highest since 1980. Nearly half of newly registered voters are Democrats; just 16.7% are Republicans. Two-thirds are under age 35, and about 30% are Hispanic.These trends suggest that the primary electorate will be more liberal than usual, a good sign for Democrats. The party needs only to pick up one Senate and two Assembly seats to reclaim the supermajority that Democrats briefly held in 2013 before three senators were separately indicted on charges of corruption and fraud. (Two have since been convicted.) Fair warning to California voters who also pay taxes: This time around, thanks to Bernie Sanders, a Democratic supermajority would likely be much more liberal than the last one.---Ms. Finley is an editorial writer for the Journal.Credit: By Allysia Finley

article name: Bernie the Economic Warrior
article text: The Golden State Warriors rallied to defeat the Oklahoma City Thunder in game seven of the NBA western conference finals Monday, and among the celebrities on hand was Bernie Sanders. Even politicians deserve an occasional respite from politics -- though the Vermont socialist couldn't resist a political allusion of his own."The Warriors were down 3-1 and they turned it around and I think that that's what we're going to do too. A very good omen for our campaign," Mr. Sanders said, according to the pool report. He'll take anything he can get ahead of the California primary next week, though for now his induction into Dub Nation raises some questions about his conception of economic justice.To wit, does Mr. Sanders consider Oakland's Oracle Arena a monument to the corporate greed he so often decries? Why was he cheering, rather than occupying? Isn't the minimum wage spelled out in Steph Curry's four-year, $44 million contract an outrage when income inequality is growing? Is it right that the team that scores the most points wins, rather than redistributing points equally?Then there's Mr. Sanders's unearned privilege to sit in the 15th row behind the Thunder basket, with the actor Danny Glover ("Lethal Weapon" 1-4). The pool reporter, Joe Garofoli of the San Francisco Chronicle, joked that Mr. Sanders scored "good seats but not the ones frequented by millionaires and billionaires."Maybe so, but ESPN reveals that list prices for tickets averaged $960, and tickets near Mr. Sanders's section were trading on the secondary market between $1,650 and $1,750. Courtside floor seats a few rows ahead were going for as much as $58,000 a pair.That small fortune could almost pay for a year of debt-free tuition at an elite university. Contra Mr. Garofoli, it's reasonable to conclude Mr. Sanders sat among the 1% he otherwise says need to be held accountable, and presumably he doesn't mean for Mr. Glover's movies "Operation Dumbo Drop" and "Dirty Grandpa."Ethics rules prohibit Senators from accepting gifts valued over $100, with an exception for gifts over $250 from personal friends with written permission. If the campaign purchased or reimbursed the ticket for the candidate, that's a lot of $27 contributions. Perhaps Mr. Sanders should clarify exactly which type of money he wants out of politics.

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Backers Work to Shape Party's Platform
article text: The prolonged Democratic presidential fight now shifts to a different arena, as Sen. Bernie Sanders and his supporters grapple with presumptive nominee Hillary Clinton over their imprint on a platform that will lay out the party's vision and policy goals.A party's platform is often a forgettable offshoot of the presidential nomination process. Once in office, presidents tend to follow their judgment and don't typically pull out the party platform for guidance.But the Sanders-Clinton battle for the nomination was filled with policy disagreements that carry the potential to leave the party divided. Mrs. Clinton is in a stronger position to shape the platform, but the Sanders forces are hoping to produce a document that reflects some portion of his liberal agenda. Should Mr. Sanders and his supporters come away dissatisfied, it could complicate the Democrats' task of unifying the party following a bitter nomination contest.Jesse Ferguson, a spokesman for Mrs. Clinton's campaign, voiced optimism that the two sides would bridge their differences. "Let's all remember, there is far more that unites us than divides us," he said.Indeed, issues of crime, punishment and race might be areas of agreement. Both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders have denounced police tactics that critics say target African-Americans.A Sanders campaign representative, Jonathan Tasini, said that coming to consensus wouldn't be easy. "It's a mistake to think there will be a 'Kumbaya' moment," he said. "We're not going to be standing there on the floor swaying with arms locked. There are fundamental differences about the future of the country and the party."Work begins this week in Washington, D.C., as the party's 15-member platform drafting committee holds two days of hearings devoted to the economy, education, foreign policy and other issues. The panel's task is to help produce a platform that delegates will approve in July at the nominating convention in Philadelphia.Tensions are evident. Mr. Sanders tried to appoint to the drafting committee RoseAnn DeMoro, the executive director of a national nurses union and a strong advocate for a single-payer, government-run health-care system that Mrs. Clinton insists cannot pass.Democratic National Committee Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz turned down the request. A convention official gave as the reason for excluding Ms. DeMoro a need for diverse membership of convention committees, which means not stacking them with labor leaders.The Sanders campaign has also filed a formal protest asking the DNC to remove Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy from his post as co-chairman of the full platform committee. A DNC panel last month rejected the request, but the Sanders campaign has said it would persist in trying to disqualify Mr. Malloy, describing him as a biased, Clinton partisan. A Malloy representative didn't respond to a request for comment.Another flashpoint is foreign policy. The drafting panel includes six people named by Mrs. Clinton, five by Mr. Sanders and four by Ms. Wasserman Schultz. Two of the Sanders appointees are Cornel West and James Zogby, both of whom have been critical of Israel's treatment of Palestinians.During the campaign, Mrs. Clinton supported a Middle East peace deal that would give Palestinians their own state. Still, there's no certainty Mrs. Clinton would go along with platform language that opponents might portray as elevating the Palestinian cause at the expense of an important U.S. ally, Israel.Other policy differences abound. Mr. Sanders wants a national minimum wage of $15; Mrs. Clinton supports a $12 minimum wage, though she has said she would back a $15 wage in some locations. Mr. Sanders opposes free-trade agreements; Mrs. Clinton has taken more of a case-by-case approach."If we don't get a very firm position against free trade, that will be a problem for me and a lot of other people," Mr. Tasini said.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Democrats Strive for Party Unity --- Pressure builds for Sanders to rally behind presumptive nominee Clinton
article text: A Democratic Party that split over the fiercely contested presidential primary fight took its first steps toward uniting Wednesday, with prominent Bernie Sanders supporters conceding he had lost the race and saying they would rally behind the presumptive nominee, Hillary Clinton.A day after Mrs. Clinton won California and three other states, Jeff Merkley, an Oregon Democrat who was the lone U.S. senator to endorse Mr. Sanders, said she has earned the party's nomination."Once we have a candidate who has won the majority of the pledged delegates and the majority of the votes, we have a nominee," Mr. Merkley said. "I had hoped the outcome would be that Bernie Sanders would win. In a democracy, one wins and others don't."Aides to Mr. Sanders said he would stay in the race at least through June 14, when Washington, D.C., holds the final Democratic primary. Mr. Sanders was scheduled to hold a campaign event in Washington on Thursday and was also to meet privately with President Barack Obama.Before the voting on Tuesday, Mr. Sanders had said that he would carry the fight all the way to the convention next month in Philadelphia and would try to pry the nomination from Mrs. Clinton by urging her superdelegates to back his candidacy.A liberal group that had endorsed Mr. Sanders, Democracy for America, said Wednesday that if Mr. Sanders follows through on such plans, it wouldn't go along. With Mrs. Clinton leading by 376 pledged delegates -- the kind elected by voters -- it would be wrong for superdelegates to step in and effectively overturn the popular vote, the group said."We believe [Mr. Sanders] has the right to do that, but we do not plan to help him do that," said Charles Chamberlain, executive director of the group, which recruits and promotes liberal candidates for elective office.Stepping off the sidelines, Mr. Obama is set to endorse Mrs. Clinton as early as Thursday. The pair will later make a joint campaign appearance in a battleground state targeting independent voters, people familiar with the matter said.Mr. Obama seems prepared to play peacemaker and ensure the party is unified in the general election showdown with Republican Donald Trump.In an interview Wednesday on "The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon," Mr. Obama said: "It was a healthy thing for the Democratic Party to have a contested primary. I thought that Bernie Sanders brought enormous energy and new ideas." He said his hope is "that over the next couple of weeks we're able to pull things together."The president has spoken to Mr. Sanders at least twice in recent weeks, hoping to gauge what Mr. Sanders might want from the party. The two are scheduled to meet Thursday, and the president is expected to say it is time for Democrats to set aside differences and embark on the larger project of defeating Mr. Trump, according to people familiar with the matter.Even some of Mr. Sanders's advisers aren't entirely sure what he'll do next. He left California and was scheduled to spend the night at his home in Burlington, Vt., on Wednesday.It was unclear whether Mr. Sanders intended to carry out his plan to peel away Mrs. Clinton's superdelegates, or if the four defeats he suffered had caused him to rethink his options."What he said before June 7th may not be the case after June 7th," said Sanders pollster Ben Tulchin. "The reality is he's going back to Vermont. And he has to absorb it and take it in. . . . He's got to figure out how he can continue this progressive movement in the most effective and impactful way."Behind the political drama is the disappointment surely felt by a candidate who was never expected to get this far. A self-described democratic socialist, Mr. Sanders wound up winning 22 states. Both the Clinton campaign and Mr. Sanders's allies have sought not to antagonize him by pressuring him to drop out.Mrs. Clinton knows firsthand how difficult it is to accept defeat. In her 2008 campaign against Mr. Obama, she stayed in the race until the final contests and then waited four days before giving a speech bowing out.Although the two have a strained relationship, Mrs. Clinton called Mr. Sanders on Tuesday evening, part of a series of overtures the Clinton campaign has been making to Mr. Sanders as the race nears the end.In an interview, Mrs. Clinton said: "I called him to really express my appreciation and congratulate him on running a hard-fought and very determined campaign that I thought added a lot to the Democratic Party and to our debate in the country."---Laura Meckler contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Carol E. Lee

article name: Bernie Should Hold Out
article text: There is a reason why Hillary Clinton's milestone as the U.S.'s first female presidential nominee is having trouble reaching elevation. The reason is that her victory is not the most significant event of the Democratic primaries.The real claim to Democratic Party history belongs to Bernie Sanders. Sen. Sanders has recentered the Democrats, once and for all, as a party of the political left. He has reimagined the Democrats -- almost with the force of his personality -- as a party of the state, of government and of redistribution. Period.Barack Obama himself became a Bernista in his June 1 speech in Elkhart, Ind., when he essentially proposed delinking Social Security's benefits from any known economic reality.The party of Franklin Roosevelt through Lyndon Johnson and its alliance with private-sector industrial unions made Democrats aware that their fortunes ultimately were joined to the success of the private sector.The Democrats are now the party of Bernie Sanders, the progressive icon Sen. Elizabeth Warren and -- make no mistake -- of Barack Obama, a man of the left from day one. Rather than distrust the private sector, they disdain and even loathe it.In this milieu, Hillary Clinton was the odd woman out. If she'd had any credibility as an authentic member of the party's new Sanders-Warren center, she would have overwhelmed this obscure Vermont senator in the Iowa caucuses. Instead, liberals under 40, especially millennials, don't believe she is one of them.The policies of John Kennedy and Bill Clinton, now in disrepute, ensured that annual economic growth remained at its postwar average of about 3%. Those Democrats understood the private sector, even if they distrusted it.That understanding is gone, as proven by the seven-year Obama growth rate between zero and little more than 2%. If Hillary Clinton utters the phrase "corporate tax reform," she will lose the election. The Sanders wing of the Obama coalition will walk away from her.In the new Democratic Party, defined by the substance of Sen. Sanders's campaign, the role of the private sector is to transmit revenue to the public purse. Private business has become an exotic abstraction, like the province of Cappadocia in the Roman empire.As the Obama presidency made clear, this new relationship is not based on the tax code, which the new Democrats think of as a kind of dumb sump pump. The driver now is legal prosecution or the constant threat of it by government enforcement agencies -- Justice, Labor, the NLRB, and the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, whose originator was Elizabeth Warren.Ralph Nader this week told the Washington Post that Sen. Sanders had broken the taboo on the word "socialism." Bernie, said Mr. Nader, "has brought the word into the mainstream and made class distinctions central to his campaign."But not even Sen. Sanders uses the S-word much, preferring the euphemisms of "income inequality" and "social justice," which are gentler on American ears. Mrs. Clinton will use most of the Sanders vocabulary.That said, many activists on the left believe, rightly, that they haven't gained permanent control of the party. They have its heart and soul, but the Sanders revolution doesn't yet command the power stations. Effective party power remains with what Sen. Sanders repeatedly calls the "establishment."But Bernie has something close to veto power. Sen. Sanders has disconnected Mrs. Clinton from most of the party's younger voters. They're listening to him, not her, and maybe not even to Barack Obama anymore. Indeed, one may ask whether the Democratic establishment abhorred by Sen. Sanders's base now includes Mr. Obama.All of which makes the scorpion dance over "unifying the party" between Sen. Sanders and bloodless Democratic heavyweights a show not to be missed.I am reminded of the Corleone family in "The Godfather -- II" when Tom Hagen tells Frankie Pentangeli it's time to go. I see Harry Reid as making the Hagen buyout offer to Bernie.Tom Hagen: "When a plot against the emperor failed, the plotters were always given a chance to let their families keep their fortunes.Frankie Pentangeli: "Yeah, but only the rich guys. The little guys got knocked off."But Bernie isn't in Frankie Pentangeli's bathtub by himself. A whole generation of young Democratic voters -- who see Hillary and what she represents as the moribund empire and themselves as the little guys -- will be watching the deal the party offers to make Bernie go.Bernie's brigades should hold out for more than writing platform boilerplate. If Sen. Sanders forced Hillary to pick Elizabeth Warren as her running mate, it would be the capstone to Bernie's career. History would record him as someone who decisively shifted the locus of a major American party, rather than just another eccentric candidate who briefly caught fire.Plus, we'd get the spectacle of Donald Trump battling two women, not least Sen. Warren, progressivism's central processing unit.We are all in a five-month skydive, so it might as well be fun. Even for Bernie Sanders.Credit: By Daniel Henninger

article name: Sanders Camp Is Split Over Next Step
article text: A split is emerging inside the Bernie Sanders campaign over whether the senator should stand down after Tuesday's election contests and unite behind Democratic front-runner Hillary Clinton, or take the fight all the way to the July party convention and try to pry the nomination from her.One camp might be dubbed the Sandersistas, the loyalists who helped guide Mr. Sanders's political ascent in Vermont and the U.S. Congress and are loath to give up a fight that has far surpassed expectations. Another has ties not only to Mr. Sanders but to the broader interests of a Democratic Party pining to beat back the challenge from Republican Donald Trump and make gains in congressional elections.Mr. Sanders in recent weeks has made clear he aims to take his candidacy past the elections on Tuesday, when California, New Jersey and four other states vote. But the debate within the campaign indicates that Mr. Sanders's next move isn't settled.For now, Democratic officials, fund-raisers and operatives are getting impatient, calling on Mr. Sanders to quit the race and begin thework of unifying the party for the showdown with the Republican presumptive nominee.Orin Kramer, a New York hedge-fund manager who has raised campaign funds for both President Barack Obama and Mrs. Clinton, said with respect to Mr. Sanders's future plans: "I would hope people would understand what a Trump presidency would mean and act accordingly -- and 'accordingly' means quickly."A strong showing in New Jersey on Tuesday, before California results even come in, could help Mrs. Clinton reach the 2,383 delegates needed to clinch the nomination. Her total includes hundreds of superdelegates -- party leaders and elected officials who can back either candidate. Mr. Sanders is hoping that defeating Mrs. Clinton in the most populous state later Tuesday might give superdelegates reason to drop her and get behind his candidacy. Those superdelegates have given no indication they will shift allegiances.Even so, Mr. Sanders isn't backing off. In an interview that airedSundayon CNN, he stepped up an attack on Mrs. Clinton involving the Clinton Foundation. Echoing a critique made by Republicans, Mr. Sanders said he has "a problem" with the foundation accepting money from foreign sources during her service as secretary of state.In a news conference Saturday in California, Mr. Sanders indicated he would battle for superdelegates all the way to the convention."The Democratic National Convention will be a contested convention," he said.Mrs. Clinton, who won Puerto Rico's Democratic primary on Sunday, seems to be running out of patience with Mr. Sanders. Having shifted her focus to Mr. Trump, she told CNN that afterTuesday, "I'm going to do everything I can to reach out to try to unify the Democratic Party, and I expect Sen. Sanders to do the same."When she ran against Mr. Obama in 2008, Mrs. Clinton stayed in the race until the end. As late as the final week of voting, she was talking hopefully of wooing super-delegates and capturing the nomination. But on June 7of that year -- four days after the primary season ended -- she gave a speech bowing out and immediately threw her support to Mr. Obama.Tad Devine, a senior Sanders strategist who advised Democratic nominees Al Gore in 2000 and John Kerry in 2004, among others, suggested the "path forward" is uncertain, hinging on the outcome in California and other states. He voiced a conciliatory note, describing how the two campaigns might set aside differences that have grown more pronounced in the heat of the year-long campaign."What will happen hopefully when the voting is done, our two campaigns will begin to talk once more to one another and figure out where the common ground is," he said.Campaign manager Jeff Weaver, who has worked in Mr. Sanders's congressional offices and Vermont-based campaigns dating to the mid-1980s, takes a more aggressive approach.A victory in California and elsewhereon Tuesday would "strengthen" the argument for the nomination, Mr. Weaver said, but it isn't necessary to keep the candidacy alive through the convention."The plan is as the senator has described it: to go forward after Tuesday and keep the campaign going to the convention and make the case to superdelegates that Sen. Sanders is the best chance that Democrats have to beat Trump," Mr. Weaver said.That is what worries Democratic leaders. Pointing to polls indicating a tightening race in November, they say Mr. Sanders, if he is sincere about beating back Mr. Trump, must quickly join forces with the party front-runner."Democrats will need as much unity as early as we can get it as possible," said Tom Daschle, a former Senate Democratic leader. "It would be a huge mistake to underestimate [Mr. Trump]. We've done that the entire election season."Democratic Senate leader Harry Reid has concluded Mr. Sanders has no path to the nomination, an aide said, and that he should shift focus to helping Democrats pick up Senate seats. Doing so would help Mr. Sanders return to the chamber with more power than he wielded before the presidential race began a year ago, the aide said.William Daley, who chaired Mr. Gore's presidential campaign and served as a White House chief of staff for Mr. Obama, said in an interview the "damage" Mr. Sanders could do is "overwhelming if he doesn't give [Mrs. Clinton] the breather she needs in the run-up to the convention to take on Trump."At a minimum, some of Mrs. Clinton's supporters would like to see Mr. Sanders lay off the attacks. Alan Kessler, a longtime Democratic fundraiser, said Mr. Sanders's tone is "a little disappointing.""There's no reason why he shouldn't fight for the things that he's talking about, but there's no need to continually make it personal," he added.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Hints at Endgame
article text: WASHINGTON -- Sen. Bernie Sanders on Thursday vowed to compete in the final Democratic presidential primary next week in Washington, D.C., but also hinted that he was ready to wind down his candidacy as party officials rallied behind Hillary Clinton.Mr. Sanders spent the day in Washington, meeting privately with President Barack Obama, Vice President Joe Biden and Senate colleagues. Party leaders urged him to accept defeat and help unite Democrats for the general-election showdown with Donald Trump, the presumptive Republican nominee.White House press secretary Josh Earnest said Mr. Obama congratulated and complimented Mr. Sanders on his campaign. Mr. Earnest called it "a friendly conversation that was focused on the future." An hour after the Oval Office visit, Mr. Obama endorsed Mrs. Clinton in a video released by her campaign.In another sign the party is coalescing around Mrs. Clinton, Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D., Mass.), a hero of the liberal Democratic wing, endorsed the former secretary of state Thursday evening in an interview on MSNBC. Ms. Warren's endorsement might prove particularly valuable to Mrs. Clinton, given her credibility with the young, liberal voters who gravitated toward Mr. Sanders.Before California and five other states voted Tuesday, Mr. Sanders said he would carry his fight to the party's national convention next month in Philadelphia, trying to flip superdelegates loyal to Mrs. Clinton. After losses in California, New Jersey and two other states that day, Mr. Sanders seems to be rethinking that stance.After meeting with Mr. Obama, the Vermont senator went to Capitol Hill for an hourlong session with Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid of Nevada. Mr. Reid suggested to reporters afterward that Mr. Sanders accepts that the race is over. "I didn't hear a single word about him trying to change the fact that she is the nominee," Mr. Reid said.A House member who had endorsed Mr. Sanders, Peter Welch of Vermont, said Thursday he believes Mr. Sanders grasps that he has lost and won't try to change the minds of superdelegates. "It's clear that Hillary Clinton is going to be the nominee of the Democratic Party," Mr. Welch said in an interview. "We all know that. Sen. Sanders knows that."Speaking briefly to reporters outside the White House, Mr. Sanders didn't say he planned to drop out. But neither did he speak of Mrs. Clinton as a competitor, emphasizing that he planned to meet with her "in the near future to see how we can work together to defeat Donald Trump and to create a government which represents all of us and not just the 1%."Democratic officials are treating Mr. Sanders with care. They need his help in the general election and don't wish to antagonize him as he comes to terms with the outcome of the primary contest.For his part, Mr. Reid praised the energy that Mr. Sanders brought to the campaign trail and empathized with the candidate."During the conversation, I said, 'Bernie, I don't understand the depth of your feelings, but I have some understanding,'" Mr. Reid said, describing the loss of a 1974 Senate race early in his career by only hundreds of votes.After seeing Mr. Reid, Mr. Sanders met privately with Sen. Charles Schumer (D., N.Y.), who is presumed to become the Senate Democratic leader when Mr. Reid retires at the end of the congressional session. "I told him I was proud of him and what he accomplished," Mr. Schumer said.At a rally outside Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium in Washington Thursday evening, Mr. Sanders gave his normal stump speech, focusing on issues of income inequality and criminal-justice reform. In a notable departure from past speeches, he backed off any criticism of Mrs. Clinton. He didn't mention her name or discuss his future plans.---Carol E. Lee and Julian Routh contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Siobhan Hughes

article name: How Millennials Can Live Bernie's Dream
article text: They backed him over Hillary Clinton in greater numbers than they backed Barack Obama over John McCain. But now, millions of millennials are left licking their wounds after the defeat of Bernie Sanders, the greatest progressive hero since the president he wanted to replace.Many of them recoil at the thought of supporting Mrs. Clinton, a liberal but one with insufficient anticapitalist bona fides. For now, the Bernie-backers' dream of grafting Scandinavian solutions onto American problems is dead.Or is it? Despite some recent budgetary setbacks, a long-running American experiment in socialism is still going strong, and yet somehow it remains one of the country's best-kept secrets.The federal experiment involves 1.3 million Americans -- less than 1% of the population, but 75% of the participants are themselves millennials, so Bernie's supporters should feel right at home. Unless they feel like they've arrived in socialist heaven. Consider:These lucky few, including their spouses and children, receive free single-payer health care. Pre-existing conditions? No problem. Prescriptions? Generally free.Bernie only proposed free college for all; that's already a reality for these young Americans. Local elementary schooling for their children is also tossed in at no cost. Vocational training? When do you want to start? And put your wallet away.What's more, the federal government provides these participants with generous living allowances. On top of their normal salaries, they collect a monthly allowance for rent or mortgage payments, an allowance for moving costs incurred when their job location changes, and an allowance for gas consumed when driving for work-related purposes. There's even a clothing allowance. Oh, none of these allowances is taxable. Did I mention that tax preparation services are also free?In case you thought it couldn't get any more Nordic for these chosen few, they get 30 days of paid vacation a year in addition to the usual 10 paid federal holidays. That's 40 days of paid leave every year -- more than in the Switzerland, Germany, the Netherlands and Canada.These Americans are also eligible for a lifetime pension. If they enter the program after high school, they can start collecting their retirement -- half the dollar amount of their final salary, every year for the rest of their life -- at age 38! Not even Bernie thought of that. The amount they collect is calculated annually according to the Consumer Price Index and the effects of inflation, so the pension payments increase each year as the cost of living rises.Speaking of salaries: No gender pay gap here. A male who occupies the same position with the same experience cannot earn more than his female colleague. That's the rule, not subject to the whim of a paymaster.So come on over, disappointed young Bernie fans. Someone's already living your dream. There is one catch: Occasionally the program can get a bit dangerous, and you'll be beyond the reach of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration.Welcome to the U.S. Armed Forces, my fellow millennials. Feel the burn?---Mr. Stern is a lieutenant in the U.S. Army.Credit: By Jeremy Stern

article name: Main Street: Bernie 'Wins' California
article text: Could Bernie Sanders really defeat Hillary Clinton in California?The question has been dominating the news coverage, because the socialist senator from Vermont is now locked in a statistical dead heat with the former secretary of state as Californians get ready to make their pick in Tuesday's Democratic primary. Though a Sanders upset in California would not likely deprive Mrs. Clinton of the nomination, it would leave her limping into what her rival insists will be a contested convention.For the American people, the more salient point is this: When it comes to economics, Bernie Sanders won California a long time ago. The senator's progressive pieties and obsessions are more or less California's pieties and obsessions. And there's the rub, because the great cautionary tale of progressivism is that you have to be fairly rich to enjoy the benefits.Joel Kotkin, a presidential fellow at Chapman University and the executive director of the Center for Opportunity Urbanism, calls California's progressive economy the "new feudalism.""In practice," Mr. Kotkin says, "it makes upward mobility very difficult and hurts the very people it claims to help."If a May 25 Field Poll is to be believed, Bernie's popularity with California Democrats shouldn't be any surprise. Though both Democrats and Republicans rank jobs and the economy as their top concern, from there they go in much different directions. Indeed, likely Democratic voters list among their top 10 priorities "climate change, income inequality, college affordability, equal pay for women, ensuring clean air/water, and keeping the U.S. out of war."Sure sounds like Bernie. Here it's not just talk, either. From the new $15-an-hour state minimum wage to the war on greenhouse gases to the imposition of the nation's highest top marginal income-tax rate, the Bernie agenda has blossomed in California.Gov. Jerry Brown admitted as much last week. At the same time he endorsed Mrs. Clinton, he spoke warmly of Bernie's war on "the one percent," saying it reminded him of his own campaign for president back in 1992.Though he failed at the national level, in California Mr. Brown today presides over a tax code right out of a Bernie Sanders dream. The governor took one of America's most progressive tax codes and made it even more top-heavy -- with a "temporary" (we'll see about that) tax hike that jacked the state's top marginal tax rate to 13.3%.As a result, the wealthiest 1% of Californians today pay half the state's income taxes despite accounting for only about a quarter of its income. State tax revenues are up, state unemployment is down and jobs now exceed prerecession levels.In the process Mr. Brown has been transformed from Governor Moonbeam to the Practical Progressive. The accolades have been quick in coming: Rolling Stone ("Jerry Brown's Tough-Love California Miracle"); Newsweek ("How Jerry Brown Quietly Saved California"); the Nation ("How Jerry Brown Got Californians to Raise Their Taxes and Save Their State"); well, you get the picture.So what's not to like?Answer: a downturn.For notwithstanding the headlines about how today's California refutes Republican scaremongering on taxes and regulation, California's state funding structure remains as precarious as ever. Because California is so dependent on individuals and capital gains, the moment there's a downturn in the stock market, all the old problems will come roaring back.Even now California's economic boom is masking some hard realities, especially for those on the lower rungs of society whose cause Mr. Sanders professes to champion.Most glaring of all is housing. In California, only the very wealthy can afford what was once deemed the essence of the American dream: a home of your own. When the cost of housing is factored in, moreover, it turns out California has the highest poverty rate in the nation.Today progressives crow that there's no evidence the rich are fleeing California's high marginal tax rates. But is it a progressive achievement that people of more modest means are being driven out of the state by housing prices that are themselves being driven up by California's no-build mentality? Is it a victory for the little guy that, for those without a bachelor's degree or an annual income of at least $50,000, California now has more people moving out than moving in?It's partly for these reasons the Hoover Institution's Carson Bruno says that the so-called California comeback should really be called "Silicon Valley holding up the rest of the state." Meaning that if you confine your gaze to this high-tech oasis of wealth, weather and well-being, it's easy to feel the Bern.Point is, whoever emerges at the top of California's Democratic primary, Mr. Sanders has already won the argument. And the folks paying the highest price for this progressive victory are those who can't afford a Volvo to put their Bernie stickers on.Credit: By William McGurn

article name: Election 2016: Clinton Seeks Sanders Backing, Voter List --- Rival still not ready to endorse former secretary of state as she wins final primary
article text: The Democratic presidential race officially came to an end Tuesday with Hillary Clinton winning the primary in the District of Columbia, and now the negotiations with her rival Bernie Sanders begin in earnest.Mrs. Clinton wants Mr. Sanders to endorse her for president and deploy his email list to persuade his supporters to unite behind her, campaign advisers say, in hopes of bridging differences within the party and leaving Democrats best positioned to defeat Republican Donald Trump in the general election.But for now, Mr. Sanders is withholding his endorsement as he presses Mrs. Clinton and Democratic leaders to agree to some of the liberal policy goals and electoral changes he touted on the campaign trail.The two met Tuesday night at a hotel near the White House as the votes were being counted in the last of the 57 Democratic contests. In similarly worded statements later, they said they had a positive discussion about how to unify the party, bring more people into the political process "and about the dangerous threat that Donald Trump poses to our nation."The two, joined by top campaign aides and Jane Sanders, the candidate's wife, also discussed the Democratic Party platform, which Mr. Sanders wants to tilt in a more liberal direction. "Sanders and Clinton agreed to continue working to develop a progressive agenda that addresses the needs of working families and the middle class and adopting a progressive platform for the Democratic National Convention," the Sanders statement said.Tuesday's Washington, D.C., primary results -- Clinton posted a 79% to 21% win -- had no practical effect on the race. With a combination of 2,784 pledged and superdelegates ahead of the result, Mrs. Clinton already had become the party's presumptive nominee, having easily cleared the 2,383 delegate threshold.While Sanders aides say his campaign is still "active," they indicated that he accepts the mathematical realities and understands he can no longer wrest the nomination from Mrs. Clinton. Speaking outside a campaign office in Washington earlier in the day, Mr. Sanders called for the ouster of Democratic National Committee chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz, depicting her as more focused on raising campaign funds than expanding the party and imbuing it with fresh energy."We need a person at the leadership of the DNC who is vigorously supporting and out working to bring people into the political process," he said.Ms. Wasserman Schultz told MSNBC Tuesday she wouldn't step down.Mr. Sanders, who identified as an independent until entering the presidential race, also called for the elimination of superdelegates -- the hundreds of party leaders and elected officials who have an outsize influence on the nomination. Party officials created the superdelegate system to head off debacles such as Democratic Sen. George McGovern's landslide defeat in 1972. The idea is that superdelegates could intervene should voters produce a nominee seen as unelectable.Sen. Jeff Merkley (D., Ore.) took part in a meeting at Mr. Sanders's home in Burlington, Vt., over the weekend to talk about his next steps."He wants to spend a lot of time thinking about how to drive forward this agenda, to basically take on the big issues facing America," Mr. Merkley said in an interview.Clinton aides seem willing to accommodate Mr. Sanders up to a point. But they also stress it's incumbent on him to help mobilize his supporters. One step they see as helpful is Mr. Sanders using his email list to help make the case for victory over Mr. Trump, the presumptive GOP nominee. Mrs. Clinton leads Mr. Trump in recent polls, and was up by more than four points in the average of polls compiled by Real Clear Politics.Mr. Sanders will be speaking to supporters via video message on Thursday evening to discuss his political future. "I told you that I run not to oppose any man or woman, but to propose new and far-reaching policies to deal with the crises of our time," he said in a statement. "After June 14, the voting is done, but our political revolution continues."Both candidates campaigned in the city in advance of the primary campaign, and touted their support for D.C. statehood, which would give city residents full representation in Congress.Mr. Sanders held a rally outside of RFK Stadium, drawing a large crowd. On Friday, Mrs. Clinton visited a muffin shop in the city's rapidly developing Shaw neighborhood, flanked by city council members Jack Evans and Anita Bonds, as well as Washington's nonvoting delegate to Congress, Eleanor Holmes Norton.---Julian Routh contributed to this article.Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Byron Tau

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Backers Stoke Movement
article text: CHICAGO -- Liberal activists behind Bernie Sanders's campaign held a weekend conference to commiserate over his loss to Hillary Clinton and plot ways to keep the "Bernie" movement alive now that the candidate is exiting the presidential stage.In their view, the general election presents a painful choice: Mrs. Clinton or presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump.Dominique Scott, a University of Mississippi student, got a standing ovation at a panel discussion Saturday when she described her predicament as a first-time voter. "I'm so discouraged about the moment we're in right now," Ms. Scott said. "I am distraught that the two choices that I get are two people who do not represent me and do not represent the things that I need."While some Sanders supporters are rallying around the presumptive Democratic nominee -- including the AFL-CIO, the nation's largest labor coalition -- resistance from his most ardent backers threatens to split the party ahead of the showdown with Mr. Trump.Mr. Sanders wasn't at the conference. But the Vermont senator was everywhere all the same. Millennials walked through the halls wearing T-shirts bearing sketches of his receding hairline. In panels, participants dissected the campaign's rise and fall and talked about how close Mr. Sanders came to vanquishing Mrs. Clinton.The conference's lead organizer was National Nurses United. Among the 3,000 attendees were assorted socialists, union officials, community organizers and college students. Together, they represent the wing of the Sanders coalition least enthused about coalescing behind the Clinton campaign."It's a terrible place we find ourselves in," said Becky Bond, a former adviser to Mr. Sanders's campaign, in a session titled "Understanding our Movement Moment." The best a Clinton presidency would produce is a nation "slightly worse than it is under Obama," Ms. Bond said.What worries some at the conference is the fate of Mr. Sanders's email list. Seeing the list as a coveted asset, his supporters want Mr. Sanders to use it to promote like-minded candidates. Clinton aides want him to use the list to tout her candidacy. Rosario Dawson, an actress who campaigned for Mr. Sanders and attended the conference, said: "If she wants our vote, then she needs to go get it," she said.A conference theme was that the movement that propelled Mr. Sanders doesn't need him to endure. A new goal, they said, is finding candidates who will push for the policy changes he championed, including a government-run health-care system.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Not Being Vetted for Running Mate
article text: Hillary Clinton's campaign isn't considering primary rival Bernie Sanders as her running mate, but is actively looking at Sen. Elizabeth Warren, whose populist politics line up closely with Mr. Sanders, people familiar with the process said.The vetting remains in its early stages. So far, potential candidates have been scrutinized using publicly available information. The Clinton team hasn't asked anyone to submit tax returns or other personal information, one of the people said. Conversations with Mrs. Clinton herself about options are just now beginning.Beyond the Massachusetts senator, other prospective candidates include Labor Secretary Tom Perez; Housing and Urban Development Secretary Julian Castro; Sens. Tim Kaine of Virginia, Sherrod Brown of Ohio and Cory Booker of New Jersey; Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti, and Reps. Xavier Becerra of California and Tim Ryan of Ohio, several Democrats said.Asked Tuesday if she would consider Mr. Sanders, Mrs. Clinton told Telemundo, "I haven't even begun to sort all that out." She added, "There are a lot of really qualified, dynamic candidates, I'm sure, to be considered for vice president."The search process is being led by John Podesta, the campaign chairman. Longtime Clinton adviser Cheryl Mills also is an informal adviser.Many Sanders supporters, disappointed by his failure to win the nomination, have held out hope that Mrs. Clinton would pick the Vermont senator in a show of unity and a signal that she will chart a progressive course if elected.At a board meeting of Friends of the Earth Action last week that included senior Sanders advisers, several board members said Mr. Sanders should receive serious consideration as Mrs. Clinton's running mate, said Erich Pica, president of the environmental group. Their argument, he said, was that he has brought ideas and energy to the debate.Larry Cohen, a Sanders adviser who was there, replied that Mr. Sanders would be a "powerful voice" and a major national figure from his Senate perch, Mr. Cohen confirmed.Mr. Sanders isn't particularly interested in the job, nor is he expecting to be offered it, though he doesn't mind being part of the conversation, a senior Sanders adviser said. He sees himself as exercising his strongest influence in the Senate, where his profile is sure to be elevated following his presidential run, the adviser said.The two camps are now in talks about how to unify the Democratic Party, with the Sanders forces pushing for changes in party rules and installing liberal policies in its platform at the July convention in Philadelphia.Mr. Sanders plans a video address to supporters Thursday night, but isn't expected to formally endorse Mrs. Clinton there, an aide said.Mrs. Clinton's top priority is finding someone who is prepared to step in as president, she has said. She also is looking for a working partner who can help advance her agenda, and her advisers are less concerned with demographic and geographic factors, people familiar with the process said.Some Sanders backers are encouraging her to pick someone from the more liberal wing of the party. "I would certainly encourage consideration of Bernie and other folks who represent the progressive side," said Sen. Jeff Merkley (D., Ore.), the only senator to back Mr. Sanders during the primary fight. Mr. Merkley also mentioned Ms. Warren and Mr. Brown.Mrs. Clinton doesn't feel pressured to go that route, since she already embraced such progressive positions as a large increase in the minimum wage and a plan to guarantee debt-free tuition at public universities, a senior strategist said.Clinton officials said they've been impressed by Ms. Warren's sharp critique of Republican Donald Trump, and they've made a point to highlight her endorsement along with those of President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden.Mr. Brown also appears to be under consideration, although if he were elected, Ohio's Republican governor would appoint his successor, which could impact control of the Senate. One person familiar with the process said this is a factor in considering him, but said every candidate brings some sort of wrinkle.---Peter Nicholas contributed to this article.Credit: By Laura Meckler and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Election 2016: Sanders Positioning Himself for New Role --- Now that Clinton has locked up nomination, he presses Democrats to embrace his goals
article text: Bernie Sanders said he would work feverishly to defeat Republican Donald Trump in November's presidential election, urged his volunteers to run for elective office and said he would press his Democratic rival Hillary Clinton to embrace a liberal policy agenda.But he neither endorsed Mrs. Clinton nor announced he was ending his campaign in a 23-minute speech to his supporters Thursday night, moves that might have drained his leverage in trying to shape the Democratic Party's future. He made plain that one of his overriding goals is to bring about Mr. Trump's defeat."The major political task that we face in the next five months is to make certain that Donald Trump is defeated and defeated badly," he said as he spoke in an internet address against a simple blue backdrop with his campaign logo. "And I personally intend to begin my role in that process in a very short period of time." His campaign said there were 218,000 viewers over the length of the address.The Clinton campaign declined to comment about the Sanders speech.Mr. Sanders's plans have been a bit of a mystery since Mrs. Clinton last week secured the delegates making her the presumptive Democratic nominee.The address offered few new insights. His tone was somewhat wistful, celebrating a campaign that far surpassed expectations but fell short in the end. He noted that he won 22 state primaries and caucuses, saying "we came very close -- within two points or less -- in five more states."What's clear is Mr. Sanders has accepted defeat and has given up plans to wrest the nomination from Mrs. Clinton. His new agenda, he said, is to transform the political system and open the Democratic Party to new voters and push it in a leftward direction.He mentioned his private meeting earlier this week with Mrs. Clinton, in which the two began discussing ways to bridge differences. "I look forward, in the coming weeks to continued discussions between the two campaigns to make certain that your voices are heard and that the Democratic Party passes the most progressive platform in its history and that Democrats actually fight for that agenda," he said.Looking ahead, he said he wants his campaign supporters to be at the vanguard of a 50-state strategy that would reverse Republican gains in statehouses and local offices.He urged viewers to visit his website and see how "you can effectively run for office or get involved in politics at the local or state level."Ahead of the speech, many Sanders supporters were divided about his future. Some want to see him stay in the race and fight for the nomination at the convention next month in Philadelphia. Others are moving on, rallying behind Mrs. Clinton."His base is looking for signals about where he's going, what he's doing and what he's thinking," said RoseAnn DeMoro, executive director of National Nurses United, a union that has been among Mr. Sanders's most ardent supporters. "People are looking to Bernie for direction."Having locked up the nomination, Mrs. Clinton's campaign began putting its imprint on the Democratic National Committee on Thursday, installing Brandon Davis as general election chief of staff. Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook visited the DNC headquarters in Washington, D.C., to introduce Mr. Davis, who had been national political director for the Service Employees International Union. The union endorsed Mrs. Clinton last year.Not wanting to antagonize Sanders supporters, the DNC won't immediately recast itself as an arm of the campaign, a Clinton adviser said. Campaign officials are treating Mr. Sanders and his supporters carefully, hoping to win them over and unite the party for the general election fight against Mr. Trump.Still, the Vermont senator doesn't have unlimited time to readjust. With each day, his leverage diminishes as the party coalesces behind Mrs. Clinton. The AFL-CIO, a coalition of labor unions that represents 12.5 million members, had been split during the primary; on Thursday, it endorsed the former secretary of state.Rep. Raul Grijalva (D., Ariz.), an early Sanders supporter, said Thursday he wants to see the party unify and now backs Mrs. Clinton.Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Broadway Veteran Tapped to Produce Mall Entertainment; Tony Award-winning producer Scott Sanders to create 'unique and spectacular' events, while still juggling his Broadway projects
article text: An international retail giant is poaching some razzle-dazzle from Broadway.Westfield Corp., the Australian shopping-center company with 35 malls including lower Manhattan's Westfield World Trade C enter , has tapped Broadway producer Scott Sanders to lead its entertainment offerings.Mr. Sanders, who won a Tony Award this year with his revival of "The Color Purple," will have the official title of creative head of global entertainment.And the role will include thinking broadly about performances to create "unique and spectacular events," he said, possibly including music, dance, food and fashion.He will continue to work on his Broadway projects in development, including stage adaptations of "Tootsie" and "Coal Miner's Daughter."The new role comes as brick-and-mortar retailers are scrambling to create new reasons for consumers to shop in stores instead of online, said Mark Hunter, managing director of retail asset services for CBRE Group Inc., a commercial real-estate-services and investment firm."They are not only competing against other retail property owners," said Mr. Hunter. "They are also competing against e-commerce for the attention and spending dollars of consumers."Mr. Sanders, 59 years old, comes armed for the task with experience in TV and film, plus 15 years at Radio City Music Hall presenting and producing major acts from Madonna to Sting, as well as Michael Jackson's 1993 Super Bowl halftime show.While Broadway elements could be part of the mix, Mr. Sanders said the intent is not to transplant shows into the flagship shopping centers.
