article name: Hacked Emails Show Clinton Links With Democratic Party; Disclosures raise questions about whether Bernie Sanders supporters may turn against the party's presidential nominee
article text: Newly disclosed emails show there were close ties between Hillary Clinton's presidential campaign and top Democratic Party officials long before she wrapped up the nomination, despite a longstanding mandate that the national party remain neutral in intraparty fights.More emails from Clinton campaign chairman John Podesta were published Wednesday by the website WikiLeaks, shedding new light on the relationship between top party officials and Mrs. Clinton's campaign--a source of acrimony among Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, Mrs. Clinton and the Democratic National Committee during the primary campaign season.The emails have the potential to revive the anger some Sanders supporters felt toward the party and its leaders. Mrs. Clinton has had trouble consolidating some of the demographic groups that backed Mr. Sanders, especially younger voters--though Mr. Sanders himself has become an enthusiastic surrogate for Mrs. Clinton.On Wednesday, Mr. Podesta's Twitter account also was hacked, with a message posted declaring, "I've switched teams. Vote Trump 2016."The emails released so far contain mostly embarrassing but not politically explosive banter among Mrs. Clinton's top aides about politics, personnel and campaign strategy. But Republican nominee Donald Trump has made the leak a prominent theme on the campaign trail, alleging the emails demonstrate "corruption.""The Hillary Clinton documents released today by WikiLeaks make more clear than ever just how much is at stake in this election, so much corruption. This election will determine whether we remain a free country in the truest sense of the word or we become a corrupt banana republic," Mr. Trump said at a Tuesday rally.Donna Brazile, who was a CNN contributor and then the vice chairwoman of the DNC, wrote in one email to Mr. Podesta that "as soon as the nomination is wrapped up, I will be your biggest surrogate." In another chain, she appears to have been in possession of a question that would be asked of Mrs. Clinton one day later at a town-hall meeting, sharing it with Clinton campaign officials.A day before a CNN Democratic presidential town hall event, Ms. Brazile sent Clinton communications director Jennifer Palmieri an email with the heading: "From time to time I get the questions in advance."Ms. Brazile included a question about the death penalty in the email, saying, "here's one that worries me about HRC." The following day, Ricky Jackson, a former death-row inmate who was exonerated, asked Mrs. Clinton about the issue during the televised town-hall event."I often shared my thoughts with each and every campaign, and any suggestions that indicate otherwise are simply untrue," Ms. Brazile, who is now the party's interim chairwoman, said in a statement. "As it pertains to the CNN Debates, I never had access to questions and would never have shared them with the candidates if I did."Added a CNN spokesperson: "As we have said since news of this broke, CNN did not share a question with Donna Brazile, or anyone else for that matter, prior to the town hall," adding that the network believed a broadcast partner on the town hall may have shared the question.In another thread, an adviser to Mrs. Clinton drafted a memo concerning the debate schedule, suggesting limiting the number of debates and limiting Mrs. Clinton's one-on-one debates. The DNC initially scheduled six debates, drawing protests from Mr. Sanders and Martin O'Malley, another Democratic candidate, that more were needed.Mr. Podesta and Mrs. Clinton's campaign communications director, Jennifer Palmieri, also received an email from a scholar at the Center for American Progress noting that then-Wall Street Journal managing editor Robert Thomson and Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News Corp, which owns the Journal, were raising their children as Catholics."Many of the most powerful elements of the conservative movement are all Catholic (many converts) from the SC and think tanks to the media and social groups," wrote John Halpin, a senior fellow at the Center.Ms. Palmieri wrote back: "I imagine they think it is the most socially acceptable politically conservative religion. Their rich friends wouldn't understand if they became evangelicals."Mrs. Clinton's campaign has refused to confirm or deny the authenticity of the hacked documents, which WikiLeaks claims amount to about 50,000 emails belonging to Mr. Podesta, one of Mrs. Clinton's top advisers and political strategists. So far, the organization has published about 7,200 documents, and campaign officials are bracing for the release of a few thousand documents a day until Election Day.The Federal Bureau of Investigation suspects Russian intelligence agencies are behind the disclosures of the Clinton campaign emails and of a contractor handling Florida voter data, according to people briefed on the investigations.Top Russian officials shifted on Wednesday from denying a role in a separate hack of the DNC. "Everyone is saying, 'Who did it?' " President Vladimir Putin said at an investor forum in Moscow. "But does it matter that much? It's what's inside the information that matters.""If you think you'd like all the contents of all your emails for 10 years dumped into public, think about how that feels. It doesn't feel great," Mr. Podesta told reporters Tuesday. "But I'm kind of Zen about it at this stage." The Clinton campaign has suggested that Russia may have orchestrated the hack. The FBI suspects Russian intelligence agencies are behind the hack, according to people briefed on the investigations.Mr. Sanders made the removal of DNC chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz a priority during the primaries. Ms. Wasserman Schultz stepped down over the summer, after a separate email leak showed DNC staffers disparaging Mr. Sanders."The job of the progressive movement now is to look forward, not backward," Sen. Sanders said in a statement. "No matter what Secretary Clinton may have said years ago behind closed doors, what's important today is that millions of people stand up and demand that the Democratic Party implement the most progressive platform in the history of our country."In an email thread from 2014, Mr. Podesta and Mrs. Clinton's campaign manager, Robby Mook, discussed the potential Democratic primary election calendar, which at that point was still in flux amid negotiations among state parties, state governments and the DNC.Democratic consultant Chris Lehane "called me about [California] primary and I told him that the operating strategy is to keep blue states late (i.e. don't move CA)," Mr. Mook wrote. "He said he was at dinner with you and was under the impression that you wanted to move it earlier. He's wondering how to proceed and I said I'd try to get us on the same page and go back with an answer. Are you OK with me saying that we both want CA to stay where it is?"In another email, an adviser named Charlie Baker sent a "debate proposal" outlining that the Clinton campaign had concluded that it was in its interest to limit the number of debates, start them later in the calendar and avoid any February events."The other campaigns have advocated (not surprisingly) for more debates and for the schedule to start significantly earlier. Mo and Anita believe that this announcement prior to the actual entry into the race of other candidates will strengthen their hand as they lock a schedule in with local media partners and state parties," Mr. Baker wrote, referring to a DNC staff member and a consultant.The initial plan that the Democratic Party eventually adopted many of Mrs. Clinton's campaign recommendations, scheduling six debates which started in October, 2015--months after the Republicans held their first debate. Under pressure from Mr. Sanders, the party eventually added several forums. A Democratic Party official said Wednesday that the party had been in contact with all its presidential candidates and it's unclear what transpired in the internal debate or why the party made the decisions it made.In other emails, the independence of the DNC was questioned. In a March, 2015 email exchange, a top Clinton adviser expressed frustration that Ms. Wasserman Schultz was moving ahead with plans to hire a chief for the Democratic National Convention without the Clinton team's stamp of approval."I'm distressed that DWS hired a convention CEO without consulting us," Mr. Mook wrote. "John--you, Charlie and I may need to sit down with Debbie to make clear how we want things to change/improve before we are willing to consider playing ball with them." The email was sent before Mrs. Clinton even had officially launched her campaign.Mr. Mook wrote in a subsequent message to Mrs. Clinton: "It boggles my mind that they didn't even consult the White House or us."Devlin Barrett, Damian Paletta, Carol E. Lee and Reid J. Epstein contributed to this article.Write to Byron Tau at byron.tau@wsj.com and Colleen McCain Nelson at colleen.nelson@wsj.comCredit: By Byron Tau and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: In Emails, NYC Mayor Bill de Blasio Briefed Hillary Clinton's Campaign Before He Endorsed Her; Messages released by WikiLeaks show Mr. de Blasio shared his thoughts on Sanders and Clinton with her campaign manager
article text: New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio was slow to endorse Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton last year, drawing criticism from her aides and bewilderment from some of his own . But according to leaked emails released on Wednesday, Mr. de Blasio was working with the campaign, briefing members about a meeting with Sen. Bernie Sanders and working on talking points for television appearances."My message to him (saying this in confidence to you) is that I will always want to work with him in the future and will never have a bad word about him, but won't be supporting him in this campaign," Mr. de Blasio said to Clinton campaign manager John Podesta in September 2015, ahead of a meeting between the mayor and the Vermont senator.Mr. de Blasio, a Democrat who managed Mrs. Clinton's 2000 Senate campaign, publicly said he hadn't made up his mind until he endorsed Mrs. Clinton for president in late October 2015. He declined to endorse Mrs. Clinton on many occasions, including during an appearance on NBC's "Meet the Press" a day after she announced she was running.A spokesman for Mr. de Blasio declined to comment on the emails, posted by the website WikiLeaks .A Clinton spokesman said: "By dribbling these out every day, WikiLeaks is proving they are nothing but a propaganda arm of the Kremlin with a political agenda doing Putin's dirty work to help elect Donald Trump. The FBI is now investigating this crime, the unanswered questions are why Donald Trump strangely won't condemn it and whether any of his associates are involved."Mr. Podesta said earlier this week that he had been in contact with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, calling the leak a "criminal hack."Mr. de Blasio told the Clinton campaign how he would praise Mrs. Clinton on TV."If asked what's holding me up on Hillary, I'll allude to the Progressive Agenda and a few areas where I'm seeking clarification," he said, a reference to a nonprofit designed by de Blasio allies focused on issues such as income inequality.Before he endorsed Mrs. Clinton, he tried to convince both her and Mr. Sanders to attend his Progressive Agenda presidential forum in Iowa. "I quietly first want to see what date works for you guys before locking anything down," he said to Mr. Podesta.Neither candidate agreed to attend, and the event was canceled .Mr. de Blasio gave Mr. Podesta advice about Mrs. Clinton and her debate performance in March. "Hillary was fantastic on the gun control answer, then totally blew the mass incarceration question. Why on Earth did she say 'Are you going to ask Senator Sanders that question?' instead of just addressing the issue. When she makes it about her, she loses the high ground. Stating the obvious, I know, but she keeps doing it," he said in an email to Mr. Podesta.Mr. de Blasio tried to convince Clinton aides to give him more access to Mrs. Clinton but seemed to be rebuffed. At the Democratic National Convention, he was given an afternoon speaking slot.In one email to another Clinton aide, Mr. Podesta jokes: "Bill de Blasio for president!!"Write to Josh Dawsey at JOSHUA.DAWSEY@dowjones.comCredit: By Josh Dawsey

article name: Bernie Sanders's Memoir to Hit Bookshelves Nov. 15; Publisher to print 300,000 copies in a strong showing of faith the Vermont senator's admirers still 'Feel the Bern'
article text: A week after Election Day, there will be a second popular vote. Bernie Sanders's admirers will have an opportunity to show whether their affection for the senator from Vermont was a flirtation or something more serious.On Nov. 15, Sen. Sanders's memoir, "Our Revolution," will hit bookstores. Thomas Dunne Books, an imprint of St. Martin's Press, is printing 300,000 hardcover copies in a strong showing of faith. The hardcover edition is priced at $27, which Sen. Sanders has said was the size of his average campaign contribution."The campaign itself is a significant part of the book," says Thomas Dunne, a veteran publisher. "I'm hoping everybody who voted for him or donated money to the campaign will have to have the book."Sen. Sanders's work is one of two major titles debuting Nov. 15th. HarperCollins Publishers is publishing 2 million hardcover copies of Fox News star Megyn Kelly's memoir, "Settle for More," on the same day.Both books are embargoed, meaning their publishers aren't releasing early copies. HarperCollins, like The Wall Street Journal, is owned by News Corp.Whether readers will embrace a new political memoir published so closely after the coming election is unclear. "There's never a guarantee," says Vivien Jennings, owner of the independent store Rainy Day Books based in Fairway, Kan. "Once the election is over, people might say, 'I'm so done with this!'"Sen. Sanders attracted 13 million votes, or 43% of the total nationwide Democratic popular vote, according to TheGreenPapers.com, an independent website that focuses on federal and statewide elections."There will certainly be more than a few 'politics geeks' who will likely want to read about the man at the center of the 'Sanders phenomenon' in 2016 Democratic Party politics in his own words," said Richard E. Berg-Andersson, the website's lead commentator.Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton and her running mate, Sen. Tim Kaine, tested the publishing waters in early September with their policy book, "Stronger Together: A Blueprint for America's Future." The title has sold a modest 10,000 copies in paperback, according to book-sales tracker Nielsen BookScan."There is a long tradition of publishing campaign books, and as Hillary's longtime publisher we felt it was important that we make her and Tim Kaine's policy positions available to readers," said Cary Goldstein, a spokesman for the Simon & Schuster imprint of CBS Corp.'s Simon & Schuster publishing arm. The publishing house didn't pay an advance, he added.Mrs. Clinton's presidential rival, Republican candidate Donald Trump, has also reached out to voters with a book. Last November, Simon & Schuster's Threshold Editions published Mr. Trump's blueprint for reshaping the U.S., "Crippled America: How to Make America Great Again." This past July, the book was published as a fancy paperback with a new cover and new title: "Great Again: How to Fix Our Crippled America.""It was a best-seller in the U.S.," says Louise Burke, publisher of Threshold Editions. "What surprised me is that foreign rights sales for the hardcover edition were also strong." The hardcover and paperback editions together have sold 267,000 copies, according to Nielsen BookScan.Ronald Goldfarb, a Washington lawyer and literary agent, first approached Sen. Sanders about writing a book in the spring of 2015. Mr. Goldfarb later circled back after the Senator's quest to become the Democratic nominee for president had ended."He wrote it himself," added Mr. Goldfarb, who sold the book without going to auction. "He didn't want a ghost writer." Terms weren't disclosed. A spokesman for the senator said he was unavailable for comment.Sen. Sanders will promote his book on tour, including a stop at the Miami Book Fair on Nov. 19. Lissette Mendez, the fair's director of programming, says she expects his appearance will fill 1,000 seats at Miami Dade College's Chapman Conference Center in downtown Miami and that the fair plans to live-stream the event to nearby locations on campus.Earlier in his career Sen. Sanders collaborated on a book that chronicled his years in Vermont, including his election to the House of Representatives as an independent. "Outsider in the House," written with Huck Gutman, an English professor at the University of Vermont, was updated last year by Verso Books and given a new title, "Outsider in the White House."The work has sold a respectable 27,000 copies in paperback and as an e-book, according to Andrew Hsiao, Verso's U.S. publisher. "It was nice to see a new life for an old book," he said.Write to Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg at jeffrey.trachtenberg@wsj.comCredit: By Jeffrey A. Trachtenberg

article name: Trump's 'Rigged' Election -- and Bernie's
article text: Donald Trump recently declared himself "unshackled," and now we know what he meant: The businessman is in full Steve Bannon-Breitbart mode, invoking an international conspiracy to steal the election and maybe fluoridate the water. As demagogic as this rhetoric is, his critics sure are selective in their outrage."The election is absolutely being rigged by the dishonest and distorted media pushing Crooked Hillary - but also at many polling places - SAD," Mr. Trump posted on Twitter Sunday night. He followed up Monday morning that "of course" there is "large scale voter fraud," and the plot against him is now a regular line at his rallies. This is Mr. Trump's response to the oppo-research hits about his personal misconduct and sexual ethics, though he tends to conflate his two "rigging" claims about electoral fraud and media bias.No presidential candidate should portray U.S. elections as illegitimate, and Mike Pence was right to say Sunday that the GOP will "absolutely" abide by November's results. Hillary Clinton is not going to steal the White House like Lyndon Johnson stole a Texas Senate seat in 1948. Voting irregularities are real, and cheating sometimes happens, especially in machine cities, but voters should have confidence in the electoral system. There's zero evidence that the process is compromised across multiple states and precincts.But the liberal freak-out over Mr. Trump's allegedly "unprecedented" and "dangerous" remarks could use some perspective. Where would Mr. Trump possibly get the idea that the system is rigged?Well, maybe he listened to Bernie Sanders, who in January described his "message, which says that the economy today is rigged, that it benefits the wealthy and the powerful at the expense of everybody else, that the campaign finance system that exists today is corrupt and undermining American democracy." Or maybe Mr. Trump caught Elizabeth Warren at the Democratic convention saying "the system is rigged" or "the rigged system" five times in one speech.President Obama and Eric Holder also regularly push the canard that voter-identification laws are attempts at racially motivated disenfranchisement. As recently as 2014, Democrats attempting to keep the Senate tried to motivate minority turnout with ads that explicitly played on black fears of intimidation.African-American registration and voting increased, and at a faster rate than white participation, after allegedly racist North Carolina and Georgia recently passed voter ID laws, but that's not the point. Democrats can't sauce this goose and then complain when Mr. Trump adopts their tactics for his purposes.As it happens, David Remnick reported in the New Yorker last year that John Kerry is convinced that the George W. Bush campaign manipulated the voting machines in 2004 to carry Ohio. The Secretary of State even used this "very personal experience" to reassure Afghans that free and fair elections are hard, even in advanced countries. We can't recall the media assault on the top U.S. diplomat for subverting U.S. democracy with such baseless speculation, and where Mr. Trump does have a point is when he says the press corps is nearly unanimous against him.This is usually the case with Republicans, though the difference this year is that journalists say openly that Mr. Trump is a unique threat to democracy. The First Amendment stalwarts would have more credibility if they hadn't portrayed Mitt Romney as a plundering executive with retrograde family values, or tried to take down John McCain in 2008 with innuendo about philandering. GOP voters understand that it doesn't matter how admirable their nominee is, the press will still trash him.---The question for the media this year is that if Mr. Trump poses a threat to the American way, where were they during the GOP primaries? Back then, progresssive partisans who now say Mr. Trump will end civilization turned out columns like "Why Liberals Should Support a Trump Republican Nomination" or "Why I'm more worried about Marco Rubio than Donald Trump."Many in the media cheered on Mr. Trump when it appeared that he might oppose the GOP's traditional free-market agenda. NBC's "Access Hollywood" tape with Mr. Trump and Billy Bush is 11 years old, and weren't Howard Stern's greatest hits as relevant last autumn as they are said to be now? It's not a conspiracy theory to think that the stories coming out in late October are no accident.Disqualifying Mr. Trump with a dump of sleazy passes at women was sure to enrage his supporters who know the history of Bill and Hillary Clinton. Mr. Trump always overreacts and thus he's on a path to lose -- and if he keeps raving about "the illusion of democracy," as he did last week in West Palm Beach, he'll deserve to. But in winning ugly, Mrs. Clinton and the left will pay a steep price in even more polarized and divisive politics.

article name: The Democratic Convention: Progressive Wing to Take Center Stage --- Sanders to stress Democratic unity on Monday and push for measures he backed
article text: PHILADELPHIA -- Hillary Clinton's campaign plans to open her nominating convention Monday with a full-throated overture to the Democratic Party's progressive wing, hoping to mend rifts and put to rest grievances that have jeopardized party unity.Two of the speakers on the convention's opening night are senators whose fiery denunciations of corporate power and wealth have made them darlings of the left: Bernie Sanders of Vermont, Mrs. Clinton's rival in the presidential primaries, and Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts.Another is Astrid Silva, the daughter of undocumented Mexican immigrants who has become a leading advocate for a path to citizenship for people living in the U.S. illegally. An overhaul of the nation's immigration laws is a galvanizing issue for the party's Hispanic constituents, some of whom were disappointed Mrs. Clinton didn't choose a Hispanic as a running mate.A message Mr. Sanders intends to offer is that Democrats need to coalesce behind the larger goal of defeating the Republican presidential nominee, an aide to the senator said Sunday."It will be a speech that stresses unity and the need to elect Hillary Clinton and defeat Donald Trump," Jeff Weaver, Mr. Sanders's campaign manager, said in an interview. "At the same time," he added, Mr. Sanders plans to urge Democrats to "continue to push for the progressive future that his campaign was based on."Coming into the convention, the party's liberal core has been restive, unhappy about Mrs. Clinton's selection of Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia as her running mate and outraged by leaked Democratic National Committee emails that show party operatives maneuvering against Mr. Sanders's campaign.With the email controversy mushrooming, the committee's chairwoman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, said Sunday she was stepping down, a move that could help mollify Mr. Sanders's supporters who have long feared he was undercut by the Democratic leadership.Jonathan Tasini, a Sanders surrogate and Democratic delegate at the convention, said that Ms. Wasserman Schultz's departure "removes a flashpoint."A potential pitfall for Mrs. Clinton is that by seeming to appease the liberal base in such a prominent way on the opening night of the convention, she could alienate more moderate and independent voters who are important to winning in November. The effort could undermine Mrs. Clinton's plans to position herself in the center, where most voters reside.In choosing Mr. Kaine as her running mate, Mrs. Clinton sent a strong signal that she plans to govern from the center, not the left. Indeed, in a recent interview on CBS she described the party she leads as "center-left,"putting particular emphasis on the word "center."RoseAnn DeMoro, executive director of National Nurses United, one of Mr. Sanders's strongest allies, said of the selection of Mr. Kaine: "It's outrageous. It was a snub to the Bernie base."Neil Sroka, communications director of the liberal group Democracy for America, said both the DNC emails and Mr. Kaine's selection were disheartening for progressive voters. He said the Clinton campaign needs to do more to reassure the party's liberal base that both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Kaine would stand united in opposition to the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a 12-nation free trade deal.But he also predicted that at the end of the week, Democrats would rally behind the need to defeat Mr. Trump."These two incidents are certainly going to leave a harsh taste in the mouth," Mr. Sroka said. "But there is a deep commitment that goes beyond any one person to making sure that Donald Trump doesn't represent our country on the national or world stage."As for Mr. Sanders, he told NBC that hewould have preferred to see Mrs. Clinton choose a more progressive running mate, suggesting Ms. Warren would have been a good choice.But he offered muted praise for Mr. Kaine. "Tim is a very, very smart guy. He's a very nice guy," Mr. Sanders said. "His political views are not my political views. He is more conservative than I am."Credit: By Peter Nicholas and Colleen McCain Nelson

article name: Clinton Won the Battle, Sanders the War
article text: Bill Clinton took Democrats to the political middle. He met with Republicans to pass welfare-to-work laws and put more police on the streets. Barack Obama steered the party leftward with "change we can believe in." He promised to end long-running wars, deliver an economic recovery, offer medical coverage to the uninsured and unify an increasingly diverse nation.Hillary Clinton will claim the Democratic nomination this week in Philadelphia, but the party is no longer defined by its standard-bearer. The energy rests instead with a rising generation of Democrats excited to use activist government to protect them in anxious economic times.Older Democrats and minority voters provided a "firewall" that allowed Mrs. Clinton to defeat her rival in the primaries, Sen. Bernie Sanders. Democrats who call themselves "somewhat liberal" went for Hillary by 13 percentage points, according to exit poll data analyzed by Public Opinion Strategies. "Moderates" backed her by 23 percentage points. But among the quarter of Democrats who see themselves as "very liberal," she ran even with the socialist.Bernie Sanders and his activist supporters have moved Mrs. Clinton and the party's platform to the left. The result is that the Democrats have taken on an identity that comes from a new base: voters under 40 who have no problem with Mr. Sanders's socialist vision. A 2015 study by the Pew Research Center found that 51% of millennials "identify as Democrats or lean Democratic," compared with only 35% for Republicans. Two-fifths of millennials are people of color and immigrants.This is not your father's -- or even your older sister's -- Democratic Party. It is far more left-leaning than under Bill Clinton or President Obama.Almost 60% of Democratic voters agree that "socialism has a positive" impact on society, according to a February poll by OnMessage Inc. and the American Action Network. In Iowa 43% of Democrats said in January that they would use the word "socialist" to describe themselves, a survey by the Des Moines Register and Bloomberg Politics found.Forty-seven percent of Democrats told Gallup last year that they are both "socially liberal and economically moderate/liberal" -- the highest level in the poll's history. In 2001 only 30% of Democrats described themselves that way. Between 2000 and 2015 the percentage of "Democratic and Democratic-leaning registered voters" who consider themselves liberal has gone up to 42% from 27%, according to a Pew study in February.Mrs. Clinton has been running to the front of this liberal parade. This month she wrapped her arms around one of Mr. Sanders's biggest causes by backing tuition-free college at in-state public universities for families making under $125,000 a year.She broke with Mr. Obama by calling for repeal of the so-called Cadillac tax on health-insurance plans, a priority for labor unions. She gave a sop to the teachers unions by backtracking on her decades-old support for charter schools. It is clear that in this new liberal order of Democratic politics, the unions will be the enforcers.Mrs. Clinton is now even backing a "public option" -- a Medicare-style government program to compete against private insurance companies. This idea was so radioactive during the debate over the Affordable Care Act that Democrats jettisoned it for fear of being tarred as proponents of socialized medicine.With the implicit support of Mrs. Clinton and her allies, the Sanders coalition added language to the Democratic platform calling to raise the minimum wage to $15 an hour, put a price on climate-altering emissions like carbon, and abolish the death penalty.The party also stripped out language supporting the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal, which Mr. Sanders opposed during the campaign. Mrs. Clinton had once praised the deal a "gold standard," but last fall she withdrew her support."It is no secret that Hillary Clinton and I disagree on a number of issues," Mr. Sanders said this month as he endorsed her in New Hampshire. He correctly noted that the threat of a divided party had forced Mrs. Clinton to accept "the most progressive platform in the history of the Democratic Party."Mr. Sanders then urged his supporters to keep the pressure on: "Our job now is to see that platform implemented by a Democratic Senate, a Democratic House and a Hillary Clinton presidency -- and I am going to do everything I can to make that happen." The Vermonter has a stronger hand to play after the success of his populist campaign.Meanwhile, Democrats in Congress have become more liberal -- the mirror image of what has happened to the GOP. Democratic incumbents who were defeated during the Obama years were largely centrists from red states: Sens. Mary Landrieu of Louisiana, Mark Pryor of Arkansas and Mark Begich of Alaska.After the 2012 election, much was written, including by me, about whether the Obama coalition of young people, blacks, Hispanics, gays and single women would keep Democrats in the White House for the near future. No one predicted that first of these core constituencies, young people, would become so vocally liberal.A final factor is the GOP's strategy of unrelenting obstructionism against President Obama, which sparked a low-grade fury among the left wing. This is why Monday night's convention speaker, Sen. Elizabeth Warren, gets hundreds of thousands of views every time she posts a fiery speech on YouTube.Senate Republicans have refused to have a hearing, much less a vote, on Merrick Garland, President Obama's nominee to fill the vacancy on the Supreme Court. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell even refused to give Mr. Garland the courtesy of a simple introductory meeting.The result is that the bare-knuckle, activist-driven, take-to-the-streets politics of Occupy Wall Street and Black Lives Matter is becoming the rule among Democrats. This month Senate Democrats blocked Republican efforts to defund so-called sanctuary cities and impose harsh prison sentences on undocumented immigrants.History will record this week's convention as a coming-of-age for a new era of liberal Democratic politics. This is now Bernie Sanders's party: Other Democrats -- including Hillary Clinton -- are merely living in it.---Mr. Williams, a political analyst for Fox News and columnist for the Hill, is the author of "We the People: The Modern-Day Figures Who Have Reshaped and Affirmed the Founding Fathers' Vision of America" (Crown. 2016).(See related letters: "Letters to the Editor: Bernie Won the War, Making U.S. Less Special" -- WSJ August 5, 2016)Credit: By Juan Williams

article name: Election at Bernie's
article text: It's election season, which means Democrats are again pushing the line that voter fraud is a myth. Allow us to introduce them to the 19 dead registered voters in Harrisonburg, Virginia.Harrisonburg Registrar Debbie Logan late last week acknowledged that her office had fielded 19 fraudulent applications, submitted under the names of dead Virginians. The fraud came to light because a long-time clerk saw an application under the name of Richard Claybrook Sr., the deceased father of a well-known local judge. The elder Claybrook died in 2014.According to news reports, investigators have obtained a confession from Andrew Spieles, a James Madison University student working for a voter registration shop called HarrisonburgVOTES. The outfit purports to be nonpartisan, but it is run by Joe Fitzgerald, the chairman of his congressional district's Democratic Committee, and Mr. Spieles is a member of Virginia Young Democrats.Mr. Fitzgerald told reporters that he fired Mr. Spieles after he confessed, and no charges have been filed, though officials say the investigation continues. Meanwhile, the Colorado Secretary of State is investigating another case of Election at Bernie's, after a local CBS affiliate uncovered multiple instances of dead Coloradans who cast ballots in recent elections.Democrats are already saying the dead Harrisonburg 19 are no big deal, with Virginia House Minority Leader David Toscano claiming there was no voter fraud because "they caught him" before the votes were cast. Which is like saying it wasn't a robbery because the thief was caught carrying the TV out of the house.Democrats push the fraud-is-a-myth theme because it furthers their political goal of portraying any ballot-security measure as racist in order to drive minority turnout. But the integrity of the ballot matters as much as access to the ballot, and every fraudulent vote cancels a legitimate one. With trust in democratic institutions already frayed, the country doesn't need elections that are tainted by voter fraud, which is no myth.(See related letter: "Letters to the Editor: The Politics of Eternal Life" -- WSJ Oct. 22, 2016)

article name: For Sanders Army, Fight Isn't Over
article text: PHILADELPHIA -- Sen. Bernie Sanders raised an angry army to propel him through this year's presidential primaries. He didn't win that war, but his foot-soldiers showed on Monday they had one more battle they wanted to fight.That fight unfolded here on the first day of the Democratic Party's national convention. Sanders supporters took to the streets, to the hotel ballrooms where state delegations were meeting and ultimately to the floor of the convention itself to vent their unhappiness with the way they say they were treated by the party, and with their party's nominee-to-be, Hillary Clinton.By night's end, the Sanders forces were able to turn from jeering to cheering when Mr. Sanders spoke to the convention and gave a full-throated endorsement of Mrs. Clinton. Still, the day served noticed that, having barged into the party's inner sanctum, they won't exit quietly. Mr. Sanders himself, during his prime-time speech, said his political "revolution" would continue.As the day began, they booed their ousted national chairwoman, Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, at a meeting of her home-state Florida delegation because of newly disclosed emails showing that, under her, the party's apparatus had been eager to help Mrs. Clinton and put down Mr. Sanders. They booed House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi (D. Calif.), long a stalwart of the party's liberal wing, presumably because of her support for Mrs. Clinton.They even booed their hero, Mr. Sanders, at a morning rally when he urged them to unite behind Mrs. Clinton.By the time the convention formally opened just after 4 p.m., the Sanders backers had succeeded in scaring Ms. Wasserman Schultz off the convention stage entirely; she declined to open the convention proceedings as planned, knowing that her appearance would have produced a cascade of boos and catcalls.Yet that victory didn't calm the pro-Sanders camp, at least not entirely. As the convention opened, every time Mrs. Clinton's name was spoken, boos and jeers were heard. The testiness between the Sanders and Clinton forces were obvious; after hearing the heckling, Rep. Marcia Fudge of Ohio, the permanent chair of the convention, scolded the audience."I will be respectful of you and I want you to be respectful of me," she said. "We are all Democrats and we need to act like it." Similarly, former Denver mayor Wellington Webb, a Clinton supporter, urged the crowd to cheer not one candidate or the other, but to cheer both Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton.Hundreds of Sanders supporters streamed into the Pennsylvania Convention Center to hear Mr. Sanders's Monday-afternoon speech, chanting "Feel the Bern" as they did so. They were skeptical of Mrs. Clinton's liberal credentials -- but even more agitated at the email disclosure that they said showed the party's pro-Clinton bias."I just feel like if they really were sincere, then the whole party would be standing up and saying this is not acceptable and we don't agree with it," said Susan Hall, a delegate for Mr. Sanders from Scranton, Pa. Ms. Hall said that Mr. Sanders had backed Mrs. Clinton for strategic reasons and that she would "follow his lead."Rob Deppert, an alternate delegate from Indiana, wore a green Robin Hood hat handed out by a nurses union seeking to highlight Mr. Sanders's call to tax the rich to benefit the less well-off. Mr. Deppert complained that the emails showed "basically that the Democratic National Committee had its thumb on the scales and was working with the press to limit Bernie's access," producing a "rigged process."Meanwhile, out on the streets of Philadelphia, protesters braved temperatures of nearly 100 degrees to support Mr. Sanders.A spirited crowd gathered outside the entrance to the convention, shouting to passing delegates and carrying signs calling for Mr. Sanders to be made the nominee.They chanted, "Hell no, DNC, we won't vote for Hillary," and, "A vote for Hillary is a vote for Trump." Others carried signs calling for Mrs. Clinton to be indicted or jailed over her use of email while secretary of state. Police handcuffed a number of demonstrators but didn't arrest them. Instead, the police issued 54 citations for disorderly conduct."We need Bernie -- we need what he represents to the American people. The American people need the government to represent what it needs," said Michelle Gale, a 28-year old who traveled from Chicago to demonstrate. "We do not want Hillary."Almost lost in the hubbub was the more substantive impact of the Sanders insurrection -- victories his supporters seemed to almost look past. The convention adopted by acclamation the most liberal platform in decades, which moved toward Sanders positions on the minimum wage, trade and college costs.The party also moved to appease the Sanders army's complaints about the structure of party primaries, adopting a plan to reduce the role of so-called superdelegates -- party leaders who are automatically made delegates to the party's convention and free to support the candidate of their choice.Mr. Sanders and his supporters complained frequently and vociferously that the superdelegates gave Mrs. Clinton an unfair advantage, though she defeated him in both popular votes and other delegates in the party's primaries and caucuses."We've won this by standing up," says Maine state Rep. Diane Russell, commenting on the Democratic Party's decision to appoint a committee with an eye to overhauling the role of superdelegates. "We did this. We won this by standing together," she shouted, eliciting cheers of "Bernie, Bernie!"But she closed her remarks by saying she would do everything she could to ensure Mrs. Clinton wins the presidency -- a needed boost at a convention with plenty of intraparty divisions.As that suggested, the Sanders insurrection was quieting down by the time evening fell, in part because leaders of the Sanders and Clinton campaigns joined forces to calm the atmosphere. Mr. Sanders, even before his speech, again made clear to his followers that he wanted them to swing behind the party's nominee.Still, the day showed that the Sanders army isn't interested in disbanding, and may have longer-term ambitions for the party it has rocked.Credit: By Siobhan Hughes and Byron Tau

article name: The Democratic Convention: Emails Show DNC Taking Aim at Sanders
article text: Private emails released Friday by the WikiLeaks website have rocked the Democratic Party at its convention this week, just as party leaders aim to appear unified behind presumptive presidential nominee Hillary Clinton.The hacked emails, which appear to show evidence of a continuing rift between the Democratic National Committee and Mrs. Clinton's primary rival, Bernie Sanders, caused an uproar among the Vermont senator's supporters, who alleged during the primary that the DNC was unfairly tipping the scale in favor of Mrs. Clinton.DNC Chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz is stepping down from her role in light of the email leak.Brian Fallon, press secretary for Mrs. Clinton, told reporters Monday that the campaign doesn't condone the content of the leaked emails, singling out as particularly egregious one message that questioned Mr. Sanders's Jewish faith and suggested casting the Vermont senator as an atheist. The DNC in a statement apologized to Mr. Sanders about the emails.House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi said Monday the role played by staffers at the DNC "should be scrutinized" and others dismissed if warranted. Donna Brazile, who will serve as interim DNC chairwoman, said she would conduct a probe before making any decisions about whether additional officials should lose their jobs.Of the more than 19,000 emails sent from DNC officials between early 2015 and mid-2016 that were dumped online by WikiLeaks (and are available by search), here are nine that standout:-- April 24, 2016: DNC officials discuss a TV appearance that day by Ms. Wasserman Schultz. Communications Director Luis Miranda writes, "She can't take Sanders on directly, it would turn into a fight and any time it's DNC Chair vs Sanders, DNC Chair is going to lose."-- April 24, 2016: Ms. Wasserman Schultz, responding to an email about Mr. Sanders's saying he will stay in the primary race until the end, writes, "Spoken like someone who has never been a member of the Democratic Party and has no understanding of what we do."-- May 5, 2016: DNC officials appear to suggest a plan to bring Mr. Sanders's religion into the primary narrative. In an email from Chief Financial Officer Brad Marshall to Chief Executive Amy Dacey, Mr. Marshall writes, "It might may no difference, but for KY and WVA can we get someone to ask his belief. Does he believe in a God. He had skated on saying he has a Jewish heritage. I think I read he is an atheist."In a Facebook post on Saturday, Mr. Marshall apologized for what he called "insensitive, emotional emails."-- May 13, 2016: In an email to DNC press secretary Mark Paustenbach, Ms. Wasserman Schultz calls Sanders campaign manager Jeff Weaver "an ASS" for his comments about taking the primary fight to the convention.-- May 17, 2016: When sent Mr. Weaver's comments on Sanders supporters protesting in Nevada, Ms. Wasserman Schultz says, "Damn liar. Particularly scummy that he barely acknowledges the violent and threatening behavior that occurred."Mr. Weaver had called on protesters to act civilly, but accused the Nevada state party of ignoring votes from the floor of the state convention.-- May 18, 2016: Ms. Wasserman Schultz writes to MSNBC's Chuck Todd asking to discuss unfavorable coverage from the network's program, "Morning Joe." The email's subject line is, "Chuck, this must stop."-- May 18, 2016: Christina Freundlich, DNC deputy communications director, asks for approval to post a fake job listing on Craigslist for women who want to apply to jobs at one of Donald Trump's organizations. The requirements for the job, listed in the email, include "no gaining weight on the job" and "must be open to public humiliation and open-press workouts if you do gain weight on the job."-- May 21, 2016: The communications team floats the idea of creating an anti-Sanders narrative. Mr. Paustenbach emails Mr. Miranda: "Wondering if there's a good Bernie narrative for a story, which is that Bernie never ever had his act together, that his campaign was a mess."-- May 21, 2016: Responding to Mr. Sanders's remarks that he would not reappoint Ms. Wasserman Schultz if he were elected president, the DNC chairwoman writes, "This is a silly story. He isn't going to be president."Credit: By Julian Routh

article name: The Democratic Convention: Sen. Sanders to Serve Term as Independent
article text: PHILADELPHIA -- Bernie Sanders said he plans to return to the Senate as an independent, despite winning 13 million votes in the Democratic Party's presidential primary contest."I was elected as an independent; I'll stay two years more as an independent," Mr. Sanders said.Speaking at the Bloomberg Politics breakfast on Tuesday, Mr. Sanders also said the resignation of Debbie Wasserman Schultz as chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee doesn't go far enough in fixing the situation and that more staff members need to leave following embarrassing disclosures of thousands of internal emails."We need a DNC which has as very different direction," he said. "I honestly don't know many of the people there. But my guess is we're going to need new leadership, a new direction and new personnel."Asked after the event whether Mr. Sanders considers himself a Democrat or an independent, a campaign aide said, "He ran for president as a Democrat but was elected to a six-year term in the Senate as an independent."Mr. Sanders's appearance followed his prime-time speech Monday in which he urged his supporters to back Hillary Clinton. As for his own future in the party, he said he would remain an independent as he serves out his senate term.Vermont has no party registration. But when Mr. Sanders entered the presidential race last year he proclaimed himself a Democrat.The emails, released by WikiLeaks, appear to show DNC aides plotting ways to undermine Mr. Sanders's campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination.On the eve of the four-day convention devoted to Mrs. Clinton's nomination, Ms. Wasserman Schultz announced she was stepping down as chairwoman. She has played no public role in the convention proceedings.Mr. Sanders cast the DNC as an inept operation that has failed to inspire people to vote, resulting in large Democratic losses in years when the president isn't on the ballot.He said the DNC needs new "leadership and a new chair that would lead the process of transforming the Democratic Party."Donna Brazile, a longtime Democratic official, has stepped in as interim chairwoman. On Monday, she issued an apology for the emails.She has also made an overture to Mr. Sanders, inviting his campaign manager, Jeff Weaver, to lend help to the committee in "voter participation" and "civic engagement."Credit: By Peter Nicholas

article name: Feel the Sanders Fizzle in Philly
article text: We didn't realize until we arrived in the hall Monday night that Bernie Sanders's speech had been moved to the end of the program, pushing him mostly out of prime time. The delay afforded us the opportunity to see a good cross-section of DNC speakers. By far the star of the evening was Michelle Obama, who denounced Donald Trump as a bad influence on children.She described the Obamas' consciousness of being role models: "We know that our words and actions matter, not just to our girls, but the children across this country. . . . Kids like the little black boy who looked up at my husband, his eyes wide with hope, and he wondered, 'Is my hair like yours?'"She's got a point: Imagine a little kid looking at Mr. Trump and asking, "Is my hair like yours?"It's something of a role reversal that Democrats are portraying themselves as wholesome vs. the transgressive Republicans, but it's certainly fitting given the public personae of the Obamas and Mr. Trump. Mrs. Obama had high praise for Hillary Clinton but didn't mention her until after the role-model riff.Mrs. Obama also took issue with Trump's slogan: "Don't let anyone ever tell you that this country isn't great, that somehow we need to make it great again. Because this right now is the greatest country on earth!" Her happy talk was in contrast with the later speeches of Elizabeth Warren and Mr. Sanders, both of which were, if we may employ a five-day-old cliche, dark."America isn't going broke," Ms. Warren said, striking a deceptively optimistic note: "There's lots of wealth in America, but it isn't trickling down to hard-working families like yours. . . . People get it: The system is rigged."You know who else said the system is rigged?The crowd's response to Ms. Warren was notably tepid, especially by comparison with Mrs. Obama. At several points she was heckled.Likewise Mr. Sanders's speech was dark. He spoke of "the 40-year decline of our middle class," the likelihood that "our younger generation will . . . have a lower standard of living than their parents," and "the grotesque level of income and wealth inequality."Nor were the cheers for him very enthusiastic -- except toward the end, when he called for "strong opposition to job-killing free trade agreements like the Trans-Pacific Partnership." Mr. Trump couldn't have said it better.Sanders supporters booed when he exhorted them to vote for Mrs. Clinton. Earlier, Sarah Silverman had appeared with Sen. Al Franken in the dullest assemblage of former "Saturday Night Live" talent since Norm Macdonald dined alone. As the Chicago Tribune notes, Ms. Silverman, who supported Mr. Sanders, said: "Can I just say to the 'Bernie or bust' people, you're being ridiculous."She has a point -- and so does Mr. Sanders. If you want a socialist America, Mr. Sanders was the best of the candidates seeking either party's nomination. But Mrs. Clinton, bad as she is, is obviously better by lefty lights than Mr. Trump.Credit: By James Taranto

article name: The Warren-Sanders Presidency; Elizabeth Warren is barnstorming so she can co-run the government from Capitol Hill, writes Daniel Henninger.
article text: Do not for a moment think Elizabeth Warren is barnstorming the country now only to elect Hillary Clinton, writes Daniel Henninger for The Wall Street Journal . She's getting out the vote to make sure Elizabeth Warren is in position next year to co-run the government from Capitol Hill. If Democrats regain control of the Senate, would you be happy with Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders as co-presidents of the United States? Ignore the Senate and voters will pay a price even bigger than a Clinton presidency, Mr. Henninger writes.

article name: The Warren-Sanders Presidency
article text: The useful cliche that is pounding like a bad headache through the frontal lobe of millions of voters is the one about choosing between the devil and the deep blue sea.The presidential devil vote may already be over. But choosing the deep blue sea -- also known as the U.S. Senate -- is very much in play.That fact may be found by scrolling down to question 11A in the most recent NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll:"Thinking more about the election for U.S. Congress, would you be more likely to vote for a Republican candidate who will be a check-and-balance to Hillary Clinton . . . or a Democratic candidate who will help Hillary Clinton and Congressional Democrats pass their agenda?"A Republican: 53%A Democrat: 40%From that 13-point gap an obvious question flows: If Democrats regain control of the Senate, would you be happy with Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders as co-presidents of the United States? Ignore the Senate and voters will pay a price even bigger than a Clinton presidency.Do not for a moment think Elizabeth Warren is barnstorming the country now only to elect Hillary Clinton. She's getting out the vote to make sure Elizabeth Warren is in position next year to co-run the government from Capitol Hill.Sens. Warren and Sanders remember what happened in 2008. The Democratic presidential primaries that year were the historic battlegrounds for control of the Democratic Party's direction. The Clinton machine, which had captured the party's policy and donor apparatus, was considered unbeatable. Until a freshman Illinois senator pulled progressives together into an astonishing political force that overthrew the Clintons.That happened because progressives didn't like what they believed the Clintons represented -- cynical centrism -- and they don't like it now. There is no way the left now lets the Clinton Foundation and the politics it embodies recapture control of the party.Elizabeth Warren, the Democrats' Madame Defarge, and Bernie Sanders, winner of 22 millennial-fueled primaries, are going to guarantee the revolution's purity in any Clinton presidency.For starters, they have a list. Politico reported in early September that Sen. Warren and progressive policy groups such as the Roosevelt Institute are "developing a hit list of the types of people they'll oppose -- what one source called 'hell no' appointments -- in a Clinton administration."The Warren veto over the next Treasury Secretary is well known. But any such "list" will extend to the people put in charge of the government's powerful enforcement bureaus in the departments of Justice, Labor, Education and the regulatory agencies. The Warren wing will appoint the people who, as they did in the Obama years, tell the rest of America what to do. Under this system, your role is to salute -- or get sued by federal lawyers.It is assumed that in return for dropping his opposition to Mrs. Clinton, the Vermont socialist will become chairman of the Senate budget committee. Days ago, Sen. Sanders tweeted that becoming budget chairman "sounds good to me."Sen. Warren sits on the banking committee, which many people think she already runs. The Democratic chairman would be left-wing Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown.As to Majority Leader Chuck Schumer arbitrating all this, Ms. Warren and Mr. Sanders can turn the masses against anyone they want, including Chuck Schumer.The basis of their beliefs aside, a Clinton-Warren-Sanders government would extend and expand administrative-agency policies that have suppressed economic activity the past eight years.One example is the EPA's Clean Power Plan, finalized in 2015. Donald Trump got support in places like West Virginia and western Pennsylvania because of the destructive effect of the Obama "climate-change" policies on their livelihoods.Mrs. Clinton's solution, stated in the first debate, was replacement jobs making "a half a billion more solar panels." Most displaced workers know this is pie in the sky, like "free" college tuition.Many voters in the Republican suburbs of battleground states such as Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Wisconsin, New Hampshire or Missouri likely think life is good for them and will remain so no matter who runs the Senate. One big news story this week -- about what is happening to ObamaCare -- should make anyone who is complacent about their Senate vote think again.Insurers have dropped hundreds of thousands from health plans. If a person doesn't find a plan by Dec. 15, the federal government will assign them to a plan in a letter that includes their estimated subsidy for it.Where does this "subsidy" come from? The 1%? Of course not. One way or another, it will get pulled out of the incomes of middle-class Americans -- through higher premiums on their plans, indirect taxes or forgone wage gains.In the world of Sens. Warren and Sanders, "fairness" requires Americans being pitted against each other by their own government. No wonder 63% of them feel the country's going in the wrong direction.A few days ago, Hillary Clinton said to a campaign rally, "I could listen to Elizabeth Warren go on all day." Whether the country wants to remains to be seen.---Write henninger@wsj.com.Credit: By Daniel Henninger

The Warren wing will appoint the people who, as they did in the Obama years, tell the rest of America what to do. Under this system, your role is to salute--or get sued by federal lawyers.It is assumed that in return for dropping his opposition to Mrs. Clinton, the Vermont socialist will become chairman of the Senate budget committee. Days ago, Sen. Sanders tweeted that becoming budget chairman "sounds good to me."Sen. Warren sits on the banking committee, which many people think she already runs. The Democratic chairman would be left-wing Ohio Sen. Sherrod Brown.As to Majority Leader Chuck Schumer arbitrating all this, Ms. Warren and Mr. Sanders can turn the masses against anyone they want, including Chuck Schumer.The basis of their beliefs aside, a Clinton-Warren-Sanders government would extend and expand administrative-agency policies that have suppressed economic activity the past eight years.One example is the EPA's Clean Power Plan, finalized in 2015. Donald Trump got support in places like West Virginia and western Pennsylvania because of the destructive effect of the Obama "climate-change" policies on their livelihoods.Mrs. Clinton's solution, stated in the first debate, was replacement jobs making "a half a billion more solar panels." Most displaced workers know this is pie in the sky, like "free" college tuition.Many voters in the Republican suburbs of battleground states such as Pennsylvania, North Carolina, Wisconsin, New Hampshire or Missouri likely think life is good for them and will remain so no matter who runs the Senate. One big news story this week--about what is happening to ObamaCare--should make anyone who is complacent about their Senate vote think again.Insurers have dropped hundreds of thousands from health plans. If a person doesn't find a plan by Dec. 15, the federal government will assign them to a plan in a letter that includes their estimated subsidy for it.Where does this "subsidy" come from? The 1%? Of course not. One way or another, it will get pulled out of the incomes of middle-class Americans--through higher premiums on their plans, indirect taxes or forgone wage gains.In the world of Sens. Warren and Sanders, "fairness" requires Americans being pitted against each other by their own government. No wonder 63% of them feel the country's going in the wrong direction.A few days ago, Hillary Clinton said to a campaign rally, "I could listen to Elizabeth Warren go on all day." Whether the country wants to remains to be seen.Write henninger@wsj.com.Credit: By Daniel Henninger

article name: Should Sanders and Warren Run the Senate? Plus, a nationwide state taxathon.
article text: "If Democrats regain control of the Senate, would you be happy with Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders as co-presidents of the United States?" That's the question posed by Daniel Henninger, who warns, "Ignore the Senate and voters will pay a price even bigger than a Clinton presidency." Our columnist adds that Ms. Warren is barnstorming the country to get out the vote so that she "is in position next year to co-run the government from Capitol Hill ."Morning Editorial ReportClick here to receive this daily Opinion summary via email.From California to Maine, voters are being asked to raise taxes in a rash of state ballot initiatives. "State government revenues have swelled 30% in the last five years. That's a bigger raise than most workers have received, but public unions and their friends are asking voters for more at the ballot box on Nov. 8," explains a Journal editorial . ...Joel Fox has more on the multiple tax-hike proposals before voters in California .The Labor Department is claiming discrimination --without producing any victims--at Palantir, a tech company that serves the government's intel community and was co-founded by Trump backer Peter Thiel .A new Gallup survey out this week finds that a full 76% of Americans say they have "a great deal" of respect for the police in their area , up from 64% in 2015."The U.S. had a $334.1 billion trade deficit with China in 2015 , including services, according to the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis. It also had a $77.3 billion deficit with Germany and $55.4 billion with Japan . What do all these countries have in common? None have trade agreements with the U.S. Mr. Trump can't 'renegotiate' trade deals that were never negotiated," writes Alan Reynolds .But could Donald Trump's emphasis on trade and immigration allow him to turn out millions of white voters who stayed home in 2012? Karl Rove is skeptical .Credit: By James Freeman

article name: Long Before The Bernie Bros
article text: The Virgin VoteBy Jon Grinspan(North Carolina, 256 pages, $28)It is often taken as a good thing when young people show an interest in politics -- especially, it seems, when they vote to the left of their elders. In 1972, for example, young voters split evenly between Richard Nixon and George McGovern, and in 2012 they provided pretty much all of Barack Obama's popular-vote margin.But these were not the peak years of young Americans' influence on electoral politics. The peak came in the turbulent politics of the pre-Civil War years and the decades after, roughly 1840 to 1900. The period is chronicled in vivid and loving detail by Jon Grinspan, a historian and Smithsonian curator, in "The Virgin Vote."The book's title comes not from the snarky 2012 campaign video -- the one using double-entendre to encourage young women to vote for Barack Obama -- but from a label proudly self-applied in the 19th century by young men who were casting their vote for the first time. "Virgin voters were likely to vote in groups, often joined by brothers, father and friends," Mr. Grinspan writes. And the commotion attracted notice: "While young men fluffed their beards, donned new hats and headed off to the polls, their sisters looked on with a combination of support, pride and -- sometimes -- resentment."Virgin voting and active electioneering were well-nigh universal in mid- and late 19th-century America. From 1840 to 1900, Mr. Grinspan says, between 70% and 80% of those eligible to vote did so in every presidential election, more than ever before or since. Young women were active as well, canvassing and participating in rallies. Young free blacks voted, too, until they were blocked from the polls by Democratic politicians and the Ku Klux Klan.Drawing on a wide range of scholarship and dozens of diaries, Mr. Grinspan tells his story more in personal than statistical terms. We see 19-year-old Oscar Lawrence Jackson orating for Abraham Lincoln in southern Ohio in 1860; 15-year-old George Washington Albright sneaking out at night to tell other slaves on nearby Mississippi plantations about the Emancipation Proclamation; 16-year-old James Witham arguing politics in the caboose of a westbound train in Nebraska in 1872.In some of these accounts we hear serious arguments about politics and policy, but they also include ridicule and rowdiness, alcohol consumption and tobacco expectoration, flirting and frivolity, and roving gangs of young men like Lincoln's Wide Awake boys, who prowled at the edge of crowds looking for trouble. Altogether Mr. Grinspan's narrative is a riveting picture of 19th-century politicking.And a picture in some ways unsettling. Young Americans tended to inherit their political views from their elders and, in this supercharged political atmosphere, tended to stick with the party they supported with their virgin votes. There were some exceptions -- Mr. Grinspan zeroes in on the party-switching and ultimately nonpartisan author William Dean Howells -- but party loyalties then seem much like loyalties to sports teams today: You keep rooting for the Yankees or the Cowboys regardless of changes in players and coaches and owners, overlooking the team's weaknesses and excusing its fouls. Sometimes old parties disappear and new ones are formed, as in the 1850s, just as sports leagues expand and teams relocate. But mostly this was a period, not unlike our two most recent decades, of static partisan divisions, with just a few votes making the difference between victory and defeat.Yet the rough-and-ready politics of such a time had to deal with the great, and greatly divisive, issues of slavery and civil rights, which accounted for some of the fervor of the virgin voters. One reads Mr. Grinspan's chapter on Oscar Lawrence Jackson's 1860 speech aware that the victory of his candidate culminated in a civil war in which 600,000 died -- and in which Jackson himself survived a shot in the face. He was elected to Congress in the 1880s and died in 1920.By that time the age of the virgin voter was long over. Voter participation began to fall off in the 1890s. One reason was reform, starting with the ballot itself. Initially each political party printed ballots with only its own candidates listed. The ballots were distributed to would-be virgin voters by armies of young men on Election Day. Between 1887 and 1896, to prevent ballot-box stuffing and discourage straight-ticket voting, most states adopted the so-called Australian ballot, which listed candidates of all parties and was handed out by election clerks. Casting votes, including virgin votes, became a perfunctory matter, Mr. Grinspan notes, rather than a theatrical performance.For the youth of this period, politics was clearly a form of entertainment, but it eventually met competition: The bicycle craze, the rise of team sports like baseball and the growth of vaudeville provided other pastimes and venues where young men and women could spend time together. By the 1890s, Mr. Grinspan writes, "youth and politics were quietly untangling themselves." Even as the potential electorate was expanded by women's suffrage and the naturalization of Ellis Island immigrants, political participation and voter turnout declined.Should we wish for a revival of young people's participation in politics? Implicitly throughout and explicitly in an afterword, the author answers "yes." Amid so many distractions, he argues, the key "to getting young people involved in politics, regardless of brain chemistry or habits, is to raise them in a culture that cares."A skeptic may question whether the quality of the election result is improved by the participation of the otherwise indifferent and whether a caring culture will always care wisely. "The Virgin Vote" plunges readers into a pulsating political culture long vanished -- and unlikely to be revived in a year when most young voters dislike both major parties' presidential nominees.---Mr. Barone is senior political analyst for the Washington Examiner, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute and co-author of "The Almanac of American Politics."Credit: By Michael Barone
